name: alabama
sentence: Alabama () is a state in the Deep South region of the Southern United States, bordered by Tennessee to the north; Georgia to the east; Florida and the Gulf of Mexico to the south; and Mississippi to the west.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama is the 30th largest by area and the 24th-most populous of the US states.

name: alabama
sentence: With a total of 1,500 miles (2,400 km) of inland waterways, Alabama has among the most of any state.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama is nicknamed the Yellowhammer State, after the state bird.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama is also known as the "Heart of Dixie" and the "Cotton State".

name: alabama
sentence: The state tree is the longleaf pine, and the state flower is the camellia.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama's capital is Montgomery.

name: alabama
sentence: The largest city by population is Birmingham, which has long been the most industrialized city; the largest city by land area is Huntsville.

name: alabama
sentence: The oldest city is Mobile, founded by French colonists in 1702 as the capital of French Louisiana.

name: alabama
sentence: Greater Birmingham is Alabama's largest urban economy, its most populous urban area, and its economic center.

name: alabama
sentence: From the American Civil War until World War II, Alabama, like many states in the southern US, suffered economic hardship, in part because of its continued dependence on agriculture.

name: alabama
sentence: Similar to other former slave states, Alabamian legislators employed Jim Crow laws to disenfranchise and otherwise discriminate against African Americans from the end of the Reconstruction Era up until at least the 1970s.

name: alabama
sentence: Despite the growth of major industries and urban centers, white rural interests dominated the state legislature from 1901 to the 1960s.

name: alabama
sentence: During this time, urban interests and African Americans were markedly under-represented.

name: alabama
sentence: Following World War II, Alabama grew as the state's economy changed from one primarily based on agriculture to one with diversified interests.

name: alabama
sentence: The state's economy in the 21st century is based on management, automotive, finance, manufacturing, aerospace, mineral extraction, healthcare, education, retail, and technology.

name: alabama
sentence: The European-American naming of the Alabama River and state was derived from the Alabama people, a Muskogean-speaking tribe whose members lived just below the confluence of the Coosa and Tallapoosa rivers on the upper reaches of the river.

name: alabama
sentence: In the Alabama language, the word for a person of Alabama lineage is Albaamo (or variously Albaama or Albàamo in different dialects; the plural form is Albaamaha).

name: alabama
sentence: The suggestion that "Alabama" was borrowed from the Choctaw language is unlikely.

name: alabama
sentence: The word's spelling varies significantly among historical sources.

name: alabama
sentence: The first usage appears in three accounts of the Hernando de Soto expedition of 1540: Garcilaso de la Vega used Alibamo, while the Knight of Elvas and Rodrigo Ranjel wrote Alibamu and Limamu, respectively, in transliterations of the term.

name: alabama
sentence: As early as 1702, the French called the tribe the Alibamon, with French maps identifying the river as Rivière des Alibamons.

name: alabama
sentence: Other spellings of the name have included Alibamu, Alabamo, Albama, Alebamon, Alibama, Alibamou, Alabamu, Allibamou.

name: alabama
sentence: Sources disagree on the word's meaning.

name: alabama
sentence: Some scholars suggest the word comes from the Choctaw alba (meaning "plants" or "weeds") and amo (meaning "to cut", "to trim", or "to gather").

name: alabama
sentence: The meaning may have been "clearers of the thicket" or "herb gatherers", referring to clearing land for cultivation or collecting medicinal plants.

name: alabama
sentence: The state has numerous place names of Native American origin.

name: alabama
sentence: However, there are no correspondingly similar words in the Alabama language.

name: alabama
sentence: An 1842 article in the Jacksonville Republican proposed it meant "Here We Rest".

name: alabama
sentence: This notion was popularized in the 1850s through the writings of Alexander Beaufort Meek.

name: alabama
sentence: Experts in the Muskogean languages have not found any evidence to support such a translation.

name: alabama
sentence: Indigenous peoples of varying cultures lived in the area for thousands of years before the advent of European colonization.

name: alabama
sentence: Trade with the northeastern tribes by the Ohio River began during the Burial Mound Period (1000 BCE – 700 CE) and continued until European contact.

name: alabama
sentence: The agrarian Mississippian culture covered most of the state from 1000 to 1600 CE, with one of its major centers built at what is now the Moundville Archaeological Site in Moundville, Alabama.

name: alabama
sentence: This is the second-largest complex of the classic Middle Mississippian era, after Cahokia in present-day Illinois, which was the center of the culture.

name: alabama
sentence: Analysis of artifacts from archaeological excavations at Moundville were the basis of scholars' formulating the characteristics of the Southeastern Ceremonial Complex (SECC).

name: alabama
sentence: Contrary to popular belief, the SECC appears to have no direct links to Mesoamerican culture, but developed independently.

name: alabama
sentence: The Ceremonial Complex represents a major component of the religion of the Mississippian peoples

name: alabama
sentence: Among the historical tribes of Native American people living in present-day Alabama at the time of European contact were the Cherokee, an Iroquoian language people; and the Muskogean-speaking Alabama (Alibamu), Chickasaw, Choctaw, Creek, and Koasati.

name: alabama
sentence: While part of the same large language family, the Muskogee tribes developed distinct cultures and languages.

name: alabama
sentence: With exploration in the 16th century, the Spanish were the first Europeans to reach Alabama.

name: alabama
sentence: The expedition of Hernando de Soto passed through Mabila and other parts of the state in 1540.

name: alabama
sentence: More than 160 years later, the French founded the region's first European settlement at Old Mobile in 1702.

name: alabama
sentence: The city was moved to the current site of Mobile in 1711.

name: alabama
sentence: This area was claimed by the French from 1702 to 1763 as part of La Louisiane.

name: alabama
sentence: After the French lost to the British in the Seven Years' War, it became part of British West Florida from 1763 to 1783.

name: alabama
sentence: After the United States victory in the American Revolutionary War, the territory was divided between the United States and Spain.

name: alabama
sentence: The latter retained control of this western territory from 1783 until the surrender of the Spanish garrison at Mobile to US forces on April 13, 1813.

name: alabama
sentence: Thomas Bassett, a loyalist to the British monarchy during the Revolutionary era, was one of the earliest white settlers in the state outside Mobile.

name: alabama
sentence: He settled in the Tombigbee District during the early 1770s.

name: alabama
sentence: The district's boundaries were roughly limited to the area within a few miles of the Tombigbee River and included portions of what is today southern Clarke County, northernmost Mobile County, and most of Washington County.

name: alabama
sentence: What is now the counties of Baldwin and Mobile became part of Spanish West Florida in 1783, part of the independent Republic of West Florida in 1810, and was finally added to the Mississippi Territory in 1812.

name: alabama
sentence: Most of what is now the northern two-thirds of Alabama was known as the Yazoo lands beginning during the British colonial period.

name: alabama
sentence: It was claimed by the Province of Georgia from 1767 onwards.

name: alabama
sentence: Following the Revolutionary War, it remained a part of Georgia, although heavily disputed.

name: alabama
sentence: With the exception of the area around Mobile and the Yazoo lands, what is now the lower one-third of Alabama was made part of the Mississippi Territory when it was organized in 1798.

name: alabama
sentence: The Yazoo lands were added to the territory in 1804, following the Yazoo land scandal.

name: alabama
sentence: Spain kept a claim on its former Spanish West Florida territory in what would become the coastal counties until the Adams–Onís Treaty officially ceded it to the United States in 1819.

name: alabama
sentence: Before Mississippi's admission to statehood on December 10, 1817, the more sparsely settled eastern half of the territory was separated and named the Alabama Territory.

name: alabama
sentence: The United States Congress created the Alabama Territory on March 3, 1817.

name: alabama
sentence: St. Stephens, now abandoned, served as the territorial capital from 1817 to 1819.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama was admitted as the 22nd state on December 14, 1819, with Congress selecting Huntsville as the site for the first Constitutional Convention.

name: alabama
sentence: From July 5 to August 2, 1819, delegates met to prepare the new state constitution.

name: alabama
sentence: Huntsville served as temporary capital from 1819 to 1820, when the seat of government moved to Cahaba in Dallas County.

name: alabama
sentence: Cahaba, now a ghost town, was the first permanent state capital from 1820 to 1825.

name: alabama
sentence: The Alabama Fever land rush was underway when the state was admitted to the Union, with settlers and land speculators pouring into the state to take advantage of fertile land suitable for cotton cultivation.

name: alabama
sentence: Part of the frontier in the 1820s and 1830s, its constitution provided for universal suffrage for white men.

name: alabama
sentence: Southeastern planters and traders from the Upper South brought slaves with them as the cotton plantations in Alabama expanded.

name: alabama
sentence: The economy of the central Black Belt (named for its dark, productive soil) was built around large cotton plantations whose owners' wealth grew mainly from slave labor.

name: alabama
sentence: The area also drew many poor, disfranchised people who became subsistence farmers.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama had an estimated population of under 10,000 people in 1810, but it increased to more than 300,000 people by 1830.

name: alabama
sentence: Most Native American tribes were completely removed from the state within a few years of the passage of the Indian Removal Act by Congress in 1830.

name: alabama
sentence: From 1826 to 1846, Tuscaloosa served as Alabama's capital.

name: alabama
sentence: On January 30, 1846, the Alabama legislature announced it had voted to move the capital city from Tuscaloosa to Montgomery.

name: alabama
sentence: The first legislative session in the new capital met in December 1847.

name: alabama
sentence: A new capitol building was erected under the direction of Stephen Decatur Button of Philadelphia.

name: alabama
sentence: The first structure burned down in 1849, but was rebuilt on the same site in 1851.

name: alabama
sentence: This second capitol building in Montgomery remains to the present day.

name: alabama
sentence: It was designed by Barachias Holt of Exeter, Maine.

name: alabama
sentence: By 1860, the population had increased to 964,201 people, of which nearly half, 435,080, were enslaved African Americans, and 2,690 were free people of color.

name: alabama
sentence: On January 11, 1861, Alabama declared its secession from the Union.

name: alabama
sentence: After remaining an independent republic for a few days, it joined the Confederate States of America.

name: alabama
sentence: The Confederacy's capital was initially at Montgomery.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama was heavily involved in the American Civil War.

name: alabama
sentence: Although comparatively few battles were fought in the state, Alabama contributed about 120,000 soldiers to the war effort.

name: alabama
sentence: A company of cavalry soldiers from Huntsville, Alabama, joined Nathan Bedford Forrest's battalion in Hopkinsville, Kentucky.

name: alabama
sentence: The company wore new uniforms with yellow trim on the sleeves, collar and coat tails.

name: alabama
sentence: This led to them being greeted with "Yellowhammer", and the name later was applied to all Alabama troops in the Confederate Army.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama's slaves were freed by the 13th Amendment in 1865.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama was under military rule from the end of the war in May 1865 until its official restoration to the Union in 1868.

name: alabama
sentence: From 1867 to 1874, with most white citizens barred temporarily from voting and freedmen enfranchised, many African Americans emerged as political leaders in the state.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama was represented in Congress during this period by three African-American congressmen: Jeremiah Haralson, Benjamin S. Turner, and James T. Rapier.

name: alabama
sentence: Following the war, the state remained chiefly agricultural, with an economy tied to cotton.

name: alabama
sentence: During Reconstruction, state legislators ratified a new state constitution in 1868 which created the state's first public school system and expanded women's rights.

name: alabama
sentence: Legislators funded numerous public road and railroad projects, although these were plagued with allegations of fraud and misappropriation.

name: alabama
sentence: Organized insurgent, resistance groups tried to suppress the freedmen and Republicans.

name: alabama
sentence: Besides the short-lived original Ku Klux Klan, these included the Pale Faces, Knights of the White Camellia, Red Shirts, and the White League.

name: alabama
sentence: Reconstruction in Alabama ended in 1874, when the Democrats regained control of the legislature and governor's office through an election dominated by fraud and violence.

name: alabama
sentence: They wrote another constitution in 1875, and the legislature passed the Blaine Amendment, prohibiting public money from being used to finance religious-affiliated schools.

name: alabama
sentence: The same year, legislation was approved that called for racially segregated schools.

name: alabama
sentence: Railroad passenger cars were segregated in 1891.

name: alabama
sentence: After disenfranchising most African Americans and many poor whites in the 1901 constitution, the Alabama legislature passed more Jim Crow laws at the beginning of the 20th century to impose segregation in everyday life.

name: alabama
sentence: The new 1901 Constitution of Alabama included provisions for voter registration that effectively disenfranchised large portions of the population, including nearly all African Americans and Native Americans, and tens of thousands of poor whites, through making voter registration difficult, requiring a poll tax and literacy test.

name: alabama
sentence: The 1901 constitution required racial segregation of public schools.

name: alabama
sentence: By 1903 only 2,980 African Americans were registered in Alabama, although at least 74,000 were literate.

name: alabama
sentence: This compared to more than 181,000 African Americans eligible to vote in 1900.

name: alabama
sentence: The numbers dropped even more in later decades.

name: alabama
sentence: The state legislature passed additional racial segregation laws related to public facilities into the 1950s: jails were segregated in 1911; hospitals in 1915; toilets, hotels, and restaurants in 1928; and bus stop waiting rooms in 1945.

name: alabama
sentence: While the planter class had persuaded poor whites to vote for this legislative effort to suppress black voting, the new restrictions resulted in their disenfranchisement as well, due mostly to the imposition of a cumulative poll tax.

name: alabama
sentence: By 1941, whites constituted a slight majority of those disenfranchised by these laws: 600,000 whites vs. 520,000 African-Americans.

name: alabama
sentence: Nearly all African Americans had lost the ability to vote.

name: alabama
sentence: Despite numerous legal challenges which succeeded in overturning certain provisions, the state legislature would create new ones to maintain disenfranchisement.

name: alabama
sentence: The exclusion of blacks from the political system persisted until after passage of federal civil rights legislation in 1965 to enforce their constitutional rights as citizens.

name: alabama
sentence: The rural-dominated Alabama legislature consistently underfunded schools and services for the disenfranchised African Americans, but it did not relieve them of paying taxes.

name: alabama
sentence: Partially as a response to chronic underfunding of education for African Americans in the South, the Rosenwald Fund began funding the construction of what came to be known as Rosenwald Schools.

name: alabama
sentence: In Alabama these schools were designed and the construction partially financed with Rosenwald funds, which paid one-third of the construction costs.

name: alabama
sentence: The fund required the local community and state to raise matching funds to pay the rest.

name: alabama
sentence: Black residents effectively taxed themselves twice, by raising additional monies to supply matching funds for such schools, which were built in many rural areas.

name: alabama
sentence: They often donated land and labor as well.

name: alabama
sentence: Beginning in 1913, the first 80 Rosenwald Schools were built in Alabama for African-American children.

name: alabama
sentence: A total of 387 schools, seven teachers' houses, and several vocational buildings were completed by 1937 in the state.

name: alabama
sentence: Several of the surviving school buildings in the state are now listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

name: alabama
sentence: Continued racial discrimination and lynchings, agricultural depression, and the failure of the cotton crops due to boll weevil infestation led tens of thousands of African Americans from rural Alabama and other states to seek opportunities in northern and midwestern cities during the early decades of the 20th century as part of the Great Migration out of the South.

name: alabama
sentence: Reflecting this emigration, the population growth rate in Alabama (see "historical populations" table below) dropped by nearly half from 1910 to 1920.

name: alabama
sentence: At the same time, many rural people migrated to the city of Birmingham to work in new industrial jobs.

name: alabama
sentence: Birmingham experienced such rapid growth it was called the "Magic City".

name: alabama
sentence: By 1920, Birmingham was the 36th-largest city in the United States.

name: alabama
sentence: Heavy industry and mining were the basis of its economy.

name: alabama
sentence: Its residents were under-represented for decades in the state legislature, which refused to redistrict after each decennial census according to population changes, as it was required by the state constitution.

name: alabama
sentence: This did not change until the late 1960s following a lawsuit and court order.

name: alabama
sentence: Industrial development related to the demands of World War II brought a level of prosperity to the state not seen since before the civil war.

name: alabama
sentence: Rural workers poured into the largest cities in the state for better jobs and a higher standard of living.

name: alabama
sentence: One example of this massive influx of workers occurred in Mobile.

name: alabama
sentence: Between 1940 and 1943, more than 89,000 people moved into the city to work for war-related industries.

name: alabama
sentence: Cotton and other cash crops faded in importance as the state developed a manufacturing and service base.

name: alabama
sentence: Despite massive population changes in the state from 1901 to 1961, the rural-dominated legislature refused to reapportion House and Senatorte seats based on population, as required by the state constitution to follow the results of decennial censuses.

name: alabama
sentence: They held on to old representation to maintain political and economic power in agricultural areas.

name: alabama
sentence: One result was that Jefferson County, containing Birmingham's industrial and economic powerhouse, contributed more than one-third of all tax revenue to the state, but did not receive a proportional amount in services.

name: alabama
sentence: Urban interests were consistently underrepresented in the legislature.

name: alabama
sentence: A 1960 study noted that because of rural domination, "a minority of about 25% of the total state population is in majority control of the Alabama legislature."

name: alabama
sentence: In the United States Supreme Court cases of Baker v. Carr (1962) and Reynolds v. Sims (1964), the court ruled that the principle of "one man, one vote" needed to be the basis of both houses of state legislatures, and that their districts had to be based on population rather than geographic counties.

name: alabama
sentence: In 1972, for the first time since 1901, the legislature completed the congressional redistricting based on the decennial census.

name: alabama
sentence: This benefited the urban areas that had developed, as well as all in the population who had been underrepresented for more than sixty years.

name: alabama
sentence: Other changes were made to implement representative state house and senate districts.

name: alabama
sentence: African Americans continued to press in the 1950s and 1960s to end disenfranchisement and segregation in the state through the civil rights movement, including legal challenges.

name: alabama
sentence: In 1954, the US Supreme Court ruled in Brown v. Board of Education that public schools had to be desegregated, but Alabama was slow to comply.

name: alabama
sentence: During the 1960s, under Governor George Wallace, Alabama resisted compliance with federal demands for desegregation.

name: alabama
sentence: The civil rights movement had notable events in Alabama, including the Montgomery bus boycott (1955–56), Freedom Rides in 1961, and 1965 Selma to Montgomery marches.

name: alabama
sentence: These contributed to Congressional passage and enactment of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and Voting Rights Act of 1965 by the US Congress.

name: alabama
sentence: Legal segregation ended in the states in 1964, but Jim Crow customs often continued until specifically challenged in court.

name: alabama
sentence: According to The New York Times, by 2017, many of Alabama's African-Americans were living in Alabama's cities such as Birmingham and Montgomery.

name: alabama
sentence: Also, the Black Belt region across central Alabama "is home to largely poor counties that are predominantly African-American.

name: alabama
sentence: These counties include Dallas, Lowndes, Marengo and Perry."

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama has made some changes since the late 20th century and has used new types of voting to increase representation.

name: alabama
sentence: In the 1980s, an omnibus redistricting case, Dillard v. Crenshaw County, challenged the at-large voting for representative seats of 180 Alabama jurisdictions, including counties and school boards.

name: alabama
sentence: At-large voting had diluted the votes of any minority in a county, as the majority tended to take all seats.

name: alabama
sentence: Despite African Americans making up a significant minority in the state, they had been unable to elect any representatives in most of the at-large jurisdictions.

name: alabama
sentence: As part of settlement of this case, five Alabama cities and counties, including Chilton County, adopted a system of cumulative voting for election of representatives in multi-seat jurisdictions.

name: alabama
sentence: This has resulted in more proportional representation for voters.

name: alabama
sentence: In another form of proportional representation, 23 jurisdictions use limited voting, as in Conecuh County.

name: alabama
sentence: In 1982, limited voting was first tested in Conecuh County.

name: alabama
sentence: Together use of these systems has increased the number of African Americans and women being elected to local offices, resulting in governments that are more representative of their citizens.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama is the thirtieth-largest state in the United States with 52,419 square miles (135,760 km2) of total area: 3.2% of the area is water, making Alabama 23rd in the amount of surface water, also giving it the second-largest inland waterway system in the United States.

name: alabama
sentence: About three-fifths of the land area is a gentle plain with a general descent towards the Mississippi River and the Gulf of Mexico.

name: alabama
sentence: The North Alabama region is mostly mountainous, with the Tennessee River cutting a large valley and creating numerous creeks, streams, rivers, mountains, and lakes.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama is bordered by the states of Tennessee to the north, Georgia to the east, Florida to the south, and Mississippi to the west.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama has coastline at the Gulf of Mexico, in the extreme southern edge of the state.

name: alabama
sentence: The state ranges in elevation from sea level at Mobile Bay to nearly half a mile in the northeast, to wit Mount Cheaha at 2,413 ft (735 m).

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama's land consists of 22 million acres (89,000 km2) of forest or 67% of total land area.

name: alabama
sentence: Suburban Baldwin County, along the Gulf Coast, is the largest county in the state in both land area and water area.

name: alabama
sentence: Areas in Alabama administered by the National Park Service include Horseshoe Bend National Military Park near Alexander City

name: alabama
sentence: Additionally, Alabama has four National Forests: Conecuh, Talladega, Tuskegee, and William B. Bankhead.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama also contains the Natchez Trace Parkway, the Selma To Montgomery National Historic Trail, and the Trail of Tears National Historic Trail.

name: alabama
sentence: Notable natural wonders include: the "Natural Bridge" rock, the longest natural bridge east of the Rockies, located just south of Haleyville; Cathedral Caverns in Marshall County, named for its cathedral-like appearance, features one of the largest cave entrances and stalagmites in the world; Ecor Rouge in Fairhope, the highest coastline point between Maine and Mexico; DeSoto Caverns in Childersburg, the first officially recorded cave in the United States; Noccalula Falls in Gadsden features a 90-foot waterfall; Dismals Canyon near Phil Campbell, home to two waterfalls, six natural bridges and allegedly served as a hideout for legendary outlaw Jesse James; Stephens Gap Cave in Jackson County boasts a 143-foot pit, two waterfalls and is one of the most photographed wild cave scenes in America; Little River Canyon near Fort Payne, one of the nation's longest mountaintop rivers; Rickwood Caverns near Warrior features an underground pool, blind cave fish and 260-million-year-old limestone formations; and the Walls of Jericho canyon on the Alabama-Tennessee state line.

name: alabama
sentence: A 5-mile (8 km)-wide meteorite impact crater is located in Elmore County, just north of Montgomery.

name: alabama
sentence: This is the Wetumpka crater, the site of "Alabama's greatest natural disaster".

name: alabama
sentence: A 1,000-foot (300 m)-wide meteorite hit the area about 80 million years ago.

name: alabama
sentence: The hills just east of downtown Wetumpka showcase the eroded remains of the impact crater that was blasted into the bedrock, with the area labeled the Wetumpka crater or astrobleme ("star-wound") because of the concentric rings of fractures and zones of shattered rock that can be found beneath the surface.

name: alabama
sentence: In 2002, Christian Koeberl with the Institute of Geochemistry University of Vienna published evidence and established the site as the 157th recognized impact crater on Earth.

name: alabama
sentence: The state is classified as humid subtropical (Cfa) under the Koppen Climate Classification.

name: alabama
sentence: The average annual temperature is 64 °F (18 °C).

name: alabama
sentence: Temperatures tend to be warmer in the southern part of the state with its proximity to the Gulf of Mexico, while the northern parts of the state, especially in the Appalachian Mountains in the northeast, tend to be slightly cooler.

name: alabama
sentence: Generally, Alabama has very hot summers and mild winters with copious precipitation throughout the year.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama receives an average of 56 inches (1,400 mm) of rainfall annually and enjoys a lengthy growing season of up to 300 days in the southern part of the state.

name: alabama
sentence: Summers in Alabama are among the hottest in the US, with high temperatures averaging over 90 °F (32 °C) throughout the summer in some parts of the state.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama is also prone to tropical storms and even hurricanes.

name: alabama
sentence: Areas of the state far away from the Gulf are not immune to the effects of the storms, which often dump tremendous amounts of rain as they move inland and weaken.

name: alabama
sentence: South Alabama reports many thunderstorms.

name: alabama
sentence: The Gulf Coast, around Mobile Bay, averages between 70 and 80 days per year with thunder reported.

name: alabama
sentence: This activity decreases somewhat further north in the state, but even the far north of the state reports thunder on about 60 days per year.

name: alabama
sentence: Occasionally, thunderstorms are severe with frequent lightning and large hail; the central and northern parts of the state are most vulnerable to this type of storm.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama ranks ninth in the number of deaths from lightning and tenth in the number of deaths from lightning strikes per capita.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama, along with Oklahoma and Iowa, has the most confirmed F5 and EF5 tornadoes of any state, according to statistics from the National Climatic Data Center for the period January 1, 1950, to June 2013.

name: alabama
sentence: Several long-tracked F5/EF5 tornadoes have contributed to Alabama reporting more tornado fatalities since 1950 than any other state.

name: alabama
sentence: The state was affected by the 1974 Super Outbreak and was devastated tremendously by the 2011 Super Outbreak.

name: alabama
sentence: The 2011 Super Outbreak produced a record amount of tornadoes in the state.

name: alabama
sentence: The tally reached 62.

name: alabama
sentence: The peak season for tornadoes varies from the northern to southern parts of the state.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama is one of the few places in the world that has a secondary tornado season in November and December besides the typically severe spring.

name: alabama
sentence: The northern part—along the Tennessee River Valley—is most vulnerable.

name: alabama
sentence: The area of Alabama and Mississippi most affected by tornadoes is sometimes referred to as Dixie Alley, as distinct from the Tornado Alley of the Southern Plains.

name: alabama
sentence: Winters are generally mild in Alabama, as they are throughout most of the Southeastern United States, with average January low temperatures around 40 °F (4 °C) in Mobile and around 32 °F (0 °C) in Birmingham.

name: alabama
sentence: Although snow is a rare event in much of Alabama, areas of the state north of Montgomery may receive a dusting of snow a few times every winter, with an occasional moderately heavy snowfall every few years.

name: alabama
sentence: Historic snowfall events include New Year's Eve 1963 snowstorm and the 1993 Storm of the Century.

name: alabama
sentence: The annual average snowfall for the Birmingham area is 2 inches (51 mm) per year.

name: alabama
sentence: In the southern Gulf coast, snowfall is less frequent, sometimes going several years without any snowfall.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama's highest temperature of 112 °F (44 °C) was recorded on September 5, 1925, in the unincorporated community of Centerville.

name: alabama
sentence: The record low of −27 °F (−33 °C) occurred on January 30, 1966, in New Market.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama is home to a diverse array of flora and fauna in habitats that range from the Tennessee Valley, Appalachian Plateau, and Ridge-and-Valley Appalachians of the north to the Piedmont, Canebrake, and Black Belt of the central region to the Gulf Coastal Plain and beaches along the Gulf of Mexico in the south.

name: alabama
sentence: The state is usually ranked among the top in nation for its range of overall biodiversity.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama is in the subtropical coniferous forest biome and once boasted huge expanses of pine forest, which still form the largest proportion of forests in the state.

name: alabama
sentence: It currently ranks fifth in the nation for the diversity of its flora.

name: alabama
sentence: It is home to nearly 4,000 pteridophyte and spermatophyte plant species.

name: alabama
sentence: Indigenous animal species in the state include 62 mammal species, 93 reptile species, 73 amphibian species, roughly 307 native freshwater fish species, and 420 bird species that spend at least part of their year within the state.

name: alabama
sentence: Invertebrates include 97 crayfish species and 383 mollusk species.

name: alabama
sentence: 113 of these mollusk species have never been collected outside the state.

name: alabama
sentence: The United States Census Bureau estimates the population of Alabama was 4,903,185 on July 1, 2019, which represents an increase of 123,440 or 2.58%, since the 2010 Census.

name: alabama
sentence: This includes a natural increase since the last census of 121,054 (502,457 births minus 381,403 deaths) and an increase due to net migration of 104,991 into the state.

name: alabama
sentence: Immigration from outside the US resulted in a net increase of 31,180 people, and migration within the country produced a net gain of 73,811 people.

name: alabama
sentence: The state had 108,000 foreign-born (2.4% of the state population), of which an estimated 22.2% were undocumented (24,000).

name: alabama
sentence: The center of population of Alabama is located in Chilton County, outside the town of Jemison.

name: alabama
sentence: According to the 2010 Census, Alabama had a population of 4,779,736.

name: alabama
sentence: The racial composition of the state was 68.5% White (67% Non-Hispanic White and 1.5% Hispanic White), 26.2% Black or African American, 3.9% Hispanic or Latino of any race, 1.1% Asian, 0.6% American Indian and Alaska Native, 0.1% Native Hawaiian and Other Pacific Islander, 2% from "Some Other Race", and 1.5% from "Two or More Races".

name: alabama
sentence: In 2011, 46.6% of Alabama's population younger than age 1 were minorities.

name: alabama
sentence: The largest reported ancestry groups in Alabama are: African (26.2%), English (23.6%), Irish (7.7%), German (5.7%), and Scots-Irish (2%).

name: alabama
sentence: Those citing "American" ancestry in Alabama are generally of English or British ancestry; many Anglo-Americans identify as having American ancestry because their roots have been in North America for so long, in some cases since the 1600s.

name: alabama
sentence: Demographers estimate that 20–23% of people in Alabama are of predominantly English ancestry and the figure is likely higher.

name: alabama
sentence: In the 1980 census, 41% of the people in Alabama identified as being of English ancestry, making them the largest ethnic group at the time.

name: alabama
sentence: Based on historic migration and settlement patterns in the southern colonies and states, demographers estimated there are more people in Alabama of Scots-Irish origins than self-reported.

name: alabama
sentence: Many people in Alabama claim Irish ancestry because of the term Scots-Irish but, based on historic immigration and settlement, their ancestors were more likely Protestant Scots-Irish coming from the northern province of Ulster, where they had been for a few generations as part of the English colonization.

name: alabama
sentence: The Scots-Irish were the largest non-English immigrant group from the British Isles before the American Revolution, and many settled in the South, later moving into the Deep South as it was developed.

name: alabama
sentence: In 1984, under the Davis–Strong Act, the state legislature established the Alabama Indian Affairs Commission.

name: alabama
sentence: Native American groups within the state had increasingly been demanding recognition as ethnic groups and seeking an end to discrimination.

name: alabama
sentence: Given the long history of slavery and associated racial segregation, the Native American peoples, who have sometimes been of mixed race, have insisted on having their cultural identification respected.

name: alabama
sentence: In the past, their self-identification was often overlooked as the state tried to impose a binary breakdown of society into white and black.

name: alabama
sentence: The state has officially recognized nine American Indian tribes in the state, descended mostly from the Five Civilized Tribes of the American Southeast.

name: alabama
sentence: These are the following.

name: alabama
sentence: The state government has promoted recognition of Native American contributions to the state, including the designation in 2000 for Columbus Day to be jointly celebrated as American Indian Heritage Day.

name: alabama
sentence: Most Alabama residents (95.1% of those five and older) spoke only English at home in 2010, a minor decrease from 96.1% in 2000.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama English is predominantly Southern, and is related to South Midland speech which was taken across the border from Tennessee.

name: alabama
sentence: In the major Southern speech region, there is the decreasing loss of the final r, for example the "boyd" pronunciation of "bird".

name: alabama
sentence: In the northern third of the state, there is a South Midland "arm" and "barb" rhyming with "form" and "orb".

name: alabama
sentence: Unique words in Alabama English include: redworm (earthworm), peckerwood (woodpecker), snake doctor and snake feeder (dragonfly), tow sack (burlap bag), plum peach (clingstone), French harp (harmonica), and dog irons (andirons).

name: alabama
sentence: In the 2008 American Religious Identification Survey, 86% of Alabama respondents reported their religion as Christian, including 6% Catholic, with 11% as having no religion.

name: alabama
sentence: The composition of other traditions is 0.5% Mormon, 0.5% Jewish, 0.5% Muslim, 0.5% Buddhist, and 0.5% Hindu.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama is located in the middle of the Bible Belt, a region of numerous Protestant Christians.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama has been identified as one of the most religious states in the United States, with about 58% of the population attending church regularly.

name: alabama
sentence: A majority of people in the state identify as Evangelical Protestant.

name: alabama
sentence: As of 2010, the three largest denominational groups in Alabama are the Southern Baptist Convention, The United Methodist Church, and non-denominational Evangelical Protestant.

name: alabama
sentence: In Alabama, the Southern Baptist Convention has the highest number of adherents with 1,380,121; this is followed by the United Methodist Church with 327,734 adherents, non-denominational Evangelical Protestant with 220,938 adherents, and the Catholic Church with 150,647 adherents.

name: alabama
sentence: Many Baptist and Methodist congregations became established in the Great Awakening of the early 19th century, when preachers proselytized across the South.

name: alabama
sentence: The Assemblies of God had almost 60,000 members, the Churches of Christ had nearly 120,000 members.

name: alabama
sentence: The Presbyterian churches, strongly associated with Scots-Irish immigrants of the 18th century and their descendants, had a combined membership around 75,000 (PCA—28,009 members in 108 congregations, PC(USA)—26,247 members in 147 congregations, the Cumberland Presbyterian Church—6,000 members in 59 congregations, the Cumberland Presbyterian Church in America—5,000 members and fifty congregations plus the EPC and Associate Reformed Presbyterians with 230 members and nine congregations).

name: alabama
sentence: In a 2007 survey, nearly 70% of respondents could name all four of the Christian Gospels.

name: alabama
sentence: Of those who indicated a religious preference, 59% said they possessed a "full understanding" of their faith and needed no further learning.

name: alabama
sentence: In a 2007 poll, 92% of Alabamians reported having at least some confidence in churches in the state.

name: alabama
sentence: Although in much smaller numbers, many other religious faiths are represented in the state as well, including Judaism, Islam, Hinduism, Buddhism, Sikhism, the Baháʼí Faith, and Unitarian Universalism.

name: alabama
sentence: Jews have been present in what is now Alabama since 1763, during the colonial era of Mobile, when Sephardic Jews immigrated from London.

name: alabama
sentence: The oldest Jewish congregation in the state is Congregation Sha'arai Shomayim in Mobile.

name: alabama
sentence: It was formally recognized by the state legislature on January 25, 1844.

name: alabama
sentence: Later immigrants in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries tended to be Ashkenazi Jews from eastern Europe.

name: alabama
sentence: Jewish denominations in the state include two Orthodox, four Conservative, ten Reform, and one Humanistic synagogue.

name: alabama
sentence: Muslims have been increasing in Alabama, with 31 mosques built by 2011, many by African-American converts.

name: alabama
sentence: Several Hindu temples and cultural centers in the state have been founded by Indian immigrants and their descendants, the best-known being the Shri Swaminarayan Mandir in Birmingham, the Hindu Temple and Cultural Center of Birmingham in Pelham, the Hindu Cultural Center of North Alabama in Capshaw, and the Hindu Mandir and Cultural Center in Tuscaloosa.

name: alabama
sentence: There are six Dharma centers and organizations for Theravada Buddhists.

name: alabama
sentence: Most monastic Buddhist temples are concentrated in southern Mobile County, near Bayou La Batre.

name: alabama
sentence: This area has attracted an influx of refugees from Cambodia, Laos, and Vietnam during the 1970s and thereafter.

name: alabama
sentence: The four temples within a ten-mile radius of Bayou La Batre, include Chua Chanh Giac, Wat Buddharaksa, and Wat Lao Phoutthavihan.

name: alabama
sentence: The first community of adherents of the Baháʼí Faith in Alabama was founded in 1896 by Paul K. Dealy, who moved from Chicago to Fairhope.

name: alabama
sentence: Baháʼí centers in Alabama exist in Birmingham, Huntsville, and Florence.

name: alabama
sentence: A Centers for Disease Control and Prevention study in 2008 showed that obesity in Alabama is a problem, with most counties having more than 29% of adults obese, except for ten which had a rate between 26% and 29%.

name: alabama
sentence: Residents of the state, along with those in five other states, were least likely in the nation to be physically active during leisure time.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama, and the southeastern US in general, has one of the highest incidences of adult onset diabetes in the country, exceeding 10% of adults.

name: alabama
sentence: On May 14, 2019, Alabama passed the Human Life Protection Act, banning abortion at any stage of pregnancy unless there is a "serious health risk", with no exceptions for rape and incest.

name: alabama
sentence: The law, if enacted, would punish doctors who perform abortions with 10 to 99 years imprisonment and be the most restrictive abortion law in the country.

name: alabama
sentence: However, on October 29, 2019, US District Judge Myron Thompson blocked the law from taking effect.

name: alabama
sentence: The state has invested in aerospace, education, health care, banking, and various heavy industries, including automobile manufacturing, mineral extraction, steel production and fabrication.

name: alabama
sentence: By 2006, crop and animal production in Alabama was valued at $1.5 billion.

name: alabama
sentence: In contrast to the primarily agricultural economy of the previous century, this was only about one percent of the state's gross domestic product.

name: alabama
sentence: The number of private farms has declined at a steady rate since the 1960s, as land has been sold to developers, timber companies, and large farming conglomerates.

name: alabama
sentence: Non-agricultural employment in 2008 was 121,800 in management occupations; 71,750 in business and financial operations; 36,790 in computer-related and mathematical occupation; 44,200 in architecture and engineering; 12,410 in life, physical, and social sciences; 32,260 in community and social services; 12,770 in legal occupations; 116,250 in education, training, and library services; 27,840 in art, design and media occupations; 121,110 in healthcare; 44,750 in fire fighting, law enforcement, and security; 154,040 in food preparation and serving; 76,650 in building and grounds cleaning and maintenance; 53,230 in personal care and services; 244,510 in sales; 338,760 in office and administration support; 20,510 in farming, fishing, and forestry; 120,155 in construction and mining, gas, and oil extraction; 106,280 in installation, maintenance, and repair; 224,110 in production; and 167,160 in transportation and material moving.

name: alabama
sentence: According to the US Bureau of Economic Analysis, the 2008 total gross state product was $170 billion, or $29,411 per capita.

sentence: Alabama's 2012 GDP increased 1.2% from the previous year.

name: alabama
sentence: The single largest increase came in the area of information.

sentence: In 2010, per capita income for the state was $22,984.

name: alabama
sentence: The state's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was 5.8% in April 2015.

name: alabama
sentence: This compared to a nationwide seasonally adjusted rate of 5.4%.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama has no minimum wage and in February 2016 passed legislation preventing municipalities from setting one.

name: alabama
sentence: (A Birmingham city ordinance would have raised theirs to $10.10.)

name: alabama
sentence: As of 2018, Alabama has the sixth highest poverty rate among states in the US

name: alabama
sentence: In 2017, United Nations Special Rapporteur Philip Alston toured parts of rural Alabama and observed environmental conditions he said were poorer than anywhere he had seen in the developed world.
