name: alabama
sentence: Alabama's agricultural outputs include poultry and eggs, cattle, fish, plant nursery items, peanuts, cotton, grains such as corn and sorghum, vegetables, milk, soybeans, and peaches.

name: alabama
sentence: Although known as "The Cotton State", Alabama ranks between eighth and tenth in national cotton production, according to various reports, with Texas, Georgia and Mississippi comprising the top three.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama's industrial outputs include iron and steel products (including cast-iron and steel pipe); paper, lumber, and wood products; mining (mostly coal); plastic products; cars and trucks; and apparel.

name: alabama
sentence: In addition, Alabama produces aerospace and electronic products, mostly in the Huntsville area, the location of NASA's George C. Marshall Space Flight Center and the US Army Materiel Command, headquartered at Redstone Arsenal.

name: alabama
sentence: A great deal of Alabama's economic growth since the 1990s has been due to the state's expanding automotive manufacturing industry.

name: alabama
sentence: Located in the state are Honda Manufacturing of Alabama, Hyundai Motor Manufacturing Alabama, Mercedes-Benz US International, and Toyota Motor Manufacturing Alabama, as well as their various suppliers.

name: alabama
sentence: Since 1993, the automobile industry has generated more than 67,800 new jobs in the state.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama currently ranks 4th in the nation for vehicle exports.

name: alabama
sentence: Automakers accounted for approximately a third of the industrial expansion in the state in 2012.

name: alabama
sentence: The eight models produced at the state's auto factories totaled combined sales of 74,335 vehicles for 2012.

name: alabama
sentence: The strongest model sales during this period were the Hyundai Elantra compact car, the Mercedes-Benz GL-Class sport utility vehicle and the Honda Ridgeline sport utility truck.

name: alabama
sentence: Steel producers Outokumpu, Nucor, SSAB, ThyssenKrupp, and US Steel have facilities in Alabama and employ more than 10,000 people.

name: alabama
sentence: In May 2007, German steelmaker ThyssenKrupp selected Calvert in Mobile County for a 4.65 billion combined stainless and carbon steel processing facility.

name: alabama
sentence: ThyssenKrupp's stainless steel division, Inoxum, including the stainless portion of the Calvert plant, was sold to Finnish stainless steel company Outokumpu in 2012.

name: alabama
sentence: The remaining portion of the ThyssenKrupp plant had final bids submitted by ArcelorMittal and Nippon Steel for $1.6 billion in March 2013.

name: alabama
sentence: Companhia Siderúrgica Nacional submitted a combined bid for the mill at Calvert, plus a majority stake in the ThyssenKrupp mill in Brazil, for $3.8 billion.

name: alabama
sentence: In July 2013, the plant was sold to ArcelorMittal and Nippon Steel.

name: alabama
sentence: The Hunt Refining Company, a subsidiary of Hunt Consolidated, Inc., is based in Tuscaloosa and operates a refinery there.

name: alabama
sentence: The company also operates terminals in Mobile, Melvin, and Moundville.

name: alabama
sentence: JVC America, Inc. operates an optical disc replication and packaging plant in Tuscaloosa.

name: alabama
sentence: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company operates a large plant in Gadsden which employs about 1,400 people.

name: alabama
sentence: It has been in operation since 1929.

name: alabama
sentence: Construction of an Airbus A320 family aircraft assembly plant in Mobile was formally announced by Airbus CEO Fabrice Brégier from the Mobile Convention Center on July 2, 2012.

name: alabama
sentence: The plans include a $600 million factory at the Brookley Aeroplex for the assembly of the A319, A320 and A321 aircraft.

name: alabama
sentence: Construction began in 2013, with plans for it to become operable by 2015 and produce up to 50 aircraft per year by 2017.

name: alabama
sentence: The assembly plant is the company's first factory to be built within the United States.

name: alabama
sentence: It was announced on February 1, 2013, that Airbus had hired Alabama-based Hoar Construction to oversee construction of the facility.

name: alabama
sentence: According to Business Insider, Alabama ranked 14th in most popular states to visit in 2014.

name: alabama
sentence: An estimated 26 million tourists visited the state in 2018, more than 100,000 of them from other countries including Canada, the United Kingdom, Germany and Japan.

name: alabama
sentence: In 2006, 22.3 million travellers spent $8.3 billion providing an estimated 162,000 jobs in the state.

name: alabama
sentence: The state is home to various attractions, natural features, parks and events that attract visitors from around the globe, notably the annual Hangout Music Festival, held on the public beaches of Gulf Shores; the Alabama Shakespeare Festival, one of the ten largest Shakespeare festivals in the world; the Robert Trent Jones Golf Trail, a collection of championship caliber golf courses distributed across the state; casinos such as Victoryland; amusement parks such as Alabama Splash Adventure; the Riverchase Galleria, one of the largest shopping centers in the southeast; Guntersville Lake, voted the best lake in Alabama by Southern Living Magazine readers; and the Alabama Museum of Natural History, the oldest museum in the state.

name: alabama
sentence: Mobile is known for having the oldest organized Mardi Gras celebration in the United States, beginning in 1703.

name: alabama
sentence: It was also host to the first formally organized Mardi Gras parade in the United States in 1830, a tradition that continues to this day.

name: alabama
sentence: Mardi Gras is an official state holiday in Mobile and Baldwin counties.

name: alabama
sentence: In 2018, Mobile's Mardi Gras parade was the state's top event, producing the most tourists with an attendance of 892,811.

name: alabama
sentence: The top attraction was the US Space & Rocket Center in Huntsville with an attendance of 849,981, followed by the Birmingham Zoo with 543,090.

name: alabama
sentence: Of the parks and natural destinations, Alabama's Gulf Coast topped the list with 6,700,000 visitors.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama has historically been a popular region for film shoots due to its diverse landscapes and contrast of environments.

name: alabama
sentence: Movies filmed in Alabama include: Close Encounters of the Third Kind, Get Out, 42, Selma, Big Fish, The Final Destination, Due Date, Need For Speed and many more.

name: alabama
sentence: UAB Hospital, USA Health University Hospital, Huntsville Hospital, and Children's Hospital of Alabama are the only Level I trauma centers in Alabama.

name: alabama
sentence: UAB is the largest state government employer in Alabama, with a workforce of about 18,000.

name: alabama
sentence: A 2017 study found that Alabama had the least competitive health insurance market in the country, with Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Alabama having a market share of 84% followed by UnitedHealth Group at 7%.

name: alabama
sentence: Regions Financial Corporation and BBVA USA Bank are the largest banks headquartered in Alabama.

name: alabama
sentence: Birmingham-based Compass Banchshares was acquired by Spanish-based BBVA in September 2007 with the headquarters of BBVA USA remaining in Birmingham.

name: alabama
sentence: In November 2006, Regions Financial acquired AmSouth Bancorporation, which was also headquartered in Birmingham.

name: alabama
sentence: SouthTrust Corporation, another large bank headquartered in Birmingham, was acquired by Wachovia in 2004.

name: alabama
sentence: Wells Fargo has a regional headquarters, an operations center campus, and a $400 million data center in Birmingham.

name: alabama
sentence: Many smaller banks are also headquartered in the Birmingham area, including ServisFirst and New South Federal Savings Bank.

name: alabama
sentence: Birmingham also serves as the headquarters for several large investment management companies, including Harbert Management Corporation.

name: alabama
sentence: Telecommunications provider AT&T, formerly BellSouth, has a major presence in Alabama with several large offices in Birmingham.

name: alabama
sentence: Many commercial technology companies are headquartered in Huntsville, such as network access company ADTRAN, computer graphics company Intergraph, and IT infrastructure company Avocent.

name: alabama
sentence: Rust International has grown to include Brasfield & Gorrie, BE&K, Hoar Construction, and B.L.

name: alabama
sentence: Harbert International, which all routinely are included in the Engineering News-Record lists of top design, international construction, and engineering firms.

name: alabama
sentence: (Rust International was acquired in 2000 by Washington Group International, which was in turn acquired by San-Francisco based USCorporation in 2007.)

name: alabama
sentence: The foundational document for Alabama's government is the Alabama Constitution, which was ratified in 1901.

name: alabama
sentence: At almost 800 amendments and 310,000 words, it is by some accounts the world's longest constitution and is roughly forty times the length of the United States Constitution.

name: alabama
sentence: There has been a significant movement to rewrite and modernize Alabama's constitution.

name: alabama
sentence: Critics argue that Alabama's constitution maintains highly centralized power with the state legislature, leaving practically no power in local hands.

name: alabama
sentence: Most counties do not have home rule.

name: alabama
sentence: Any policy changes proposed in different areas of the state must be approved by the entire Alabama legislature and, frequently, by state referendum.

name: alabama
sentence: One criticism of the current constitution claims that its complexity and length intentionally codify segregation and racism.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama's government is divided into three coequal branches.

name: alabama
sentence: The legislative branch is the Alabama Legislature, a bicameral assembly composed of the Alabama House of Representatives, with 105 members, and the Alabama Senatorte, with 35 members.

name: alabama
sentence: The Legislature is responsible for writing, debating, passing, or defeating state legislation.

name: alabama
sentence: The Republican Party currently holds a majority in both houses of the Legislature.

name: alabama
sentence: The Legislature has the power to override a gubernatorial veto by a simple majority (most state Legislatures require a two-thirds majority to override a veto).

name: alabama
sentence: Until 1964, the state elected state senators on a geographic basis by county, with one per county.

name: alabama
sentence: It had not redistricted congressional districts since passage of its constitution in 1901; as a result, urbanized areas were grossly underrepresented.

name: alabama
sentence: It had not changed legislative districts to reflect the decennial censuses, either.

name: alabama
sentence: In Reynolds v. Sims (1964), the US Supreme Court implemented the principle of "one man, one vote", ruling that congressional districts had to be reapportioned based on censuses (as the state already included in its constitution but had not implemented.)

name: alabama
sentence: Further, the court ruled that both houses of bicameral state legislatures had to be apportioned by population, as there was no constitutional basis for states to have geographically based systems.

name: alabama
sentence: At that time, Alabama and many other states had to change their legislative districting, as many across the country had systems that underrepresented urban areas and districts.

name: alabama
sentence: This had caused decades of underinvestment in such areas.

name: alabama
sentence: For instance, Birmingham and Jefferson County taxes had supplied one-third of the state budget, but Jefferson County received only 1/67th of state services in funding.

name: alabama
sentence: Through the legislative delegations, the Alabama legislature kept control of county governments.

name: alabama
sentence: The executive branch is responsible for the execution and oversight of laws.

name: alabama
sentence: It is headed by the governor of Alabama.

name: alabama
sentence: Other members of executive branch include the cabinet, the lieutenant governor of Alabama, the Attorney General of Alabama, the Alabama Secretary of State, the Alabama State Treasurer, and the State Auditor of Alabama.

name: alabama
sentence: The current governor is Republican Kay Ivey.

name: alabama
sentence: The members of the Legislature take office immediately after the November elections.

name: alabama
sentence: Statewide officials, such as the governor, lieutenant governor, attorney general, and other constitutional officers, take office the following January.

name: alabama
sentence: The judicial branch is responsible for interpreting the state's Constitution and applying the law in state criminal and civil cases.

name: alabama
sentence: The state's highest court is the Supreme Court of Alabama.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama uses partisan elections to select judges.

name: alabama
sentence: Since the 1980s judicial campaigns have become increasingly politicized.

name: alabama
sentence: The current chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court is Republican Tom Parker.

name: alabama
sentence: All sitting justices on the Alabama Supreme Court are members of the Republican Party.

name: alabama
sentence: There are two intermediate appellate courts, the Court of Civil Appeals and the Court of Criminal Appeals, and four trial courts: the circuit court (trial court of general jurisdiction), and the district, probate, and municipal courts.

name: alabama
sentence: Some critics believe the election of judges has contributed to an exceedingly high rate of executions.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama has the highest per capita death penalty rate in the country.

name: alabama
sentence: In some years, it imposes more death sentences than does Texas, a state which has a population five times larger.

name: alabama
sentence: However, executions per capita are significantly higher in Texas.

name: alabama
sentence: Some of its cases have been highly controversial

name: alabama
sentence: It was the only state to allow judges to override jury decisions in whether or not to use a death sentence

name: alabama
sentence: This judicial authority was removed in April 2017.

name: alabama
sentence: Taxes are collected by the Alabama Department of Revenue.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama levies a 2, 4, or 5 percent personal income tax, depending on the amount earned and filing status.

name: alabama
sentence: Taxpayers are allowed to deduct their federal income tax from their Alabama state tax, even if taking the standard deduction; those who itemize can also deduct FICA (the Social Security and Medicare tax).

name: alabama
sentence: The state's general sales tax rate is 4%.

name: alabama
sentence: Sales tax rates for cities and counties are also added to purchases.

name: alabama
sentence: For example, the total sales tax rate in Mobile is 10% and there is an additional restaurant tax of 1%, which means a diner in Mobile would pay an 11% tax on a meal.

name: alabama
sentence: As of 1999, sales and excise taxes in Alabama account for 51% of all state and local revenue, compared with an average of about 36% nationwide.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama is one of seven states that levy a tax on food at the same rate as other goods, and one of two states (the other being neighboring Mississippi) which fully taxes groceries without any offsetting relief for low-income families.

name: alabama
sentence: (Most states exempt groceries from sales tax or apply a lower tax rate.)

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama's income tax on poor working families is among the highest in the US Alabama is the only state that levies income tax on a family of four with income as low as $4,600, which is barely one-quarter the federal poverty line.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama's threshold is the lowest among the 41 states and the District of Columbia with income taxes.

name: alabama
sentence: The corporate income tax rate is currently 6.5%.

name: alabama
sentence: The overall federal, state, and local tax burden in Alabama ranks the state as the second least tax-burdened state in the country.

name: alabama
sentence: Property taxes are the lowest in the US

name: alabama
sentence: The current state constitution requires a voter referendum to raise property taxes.

name: alabama
sentence: Since Alabama's tax structure largely depends on consumer spending, it is subject to high variable budget structure.

name: alabama
sentence: For example, in 2003, Alabama had an annual budget deficit as high as $670 million.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama has 67 counties.

name: alabama
sentence: Each county has its own elected legislative branch, usually called the county commission.

name: alabama
sentence: It also has limited executive authority in the county.

name: alabama
sentence: Because of the constraints of the Alabama Constitution, which centralizes power in the state legislature, only seven counties (Jefferson, Lee, Mobile, Madison, Montgomery, Shelby, and Tuscaloosa) in the state have limited home rule.

name: alabama
sentence: Instead, most counties in the state must lobby the Local Legislation Committee of the state legislature to get simple local policies approved, ranging from waste disposal to land use zoning.

name: alabama
sentence: The state legislature has retained power over local governments by refusing to pass a constitutional amendment establishing home rule for counties, as recommended by the 1973 Alabama Constitutional Commission.

name: alabama
sentence: Legislative delegations retain certain powers over each county.

name: alabama
sentence: United States Supreme Court decisions in Baker v. Carr (1964) required that both houses have districts established on the basis of population, and redistricted after each census, to implement the principle of "one man, one vote".

name: alabama
sentence: Before that, each county was represented by one state senator, leading to under-representation in the state senate for more urbanized, populous counties.

name: alabama
sentence: The rural bias of the state legislature, which had also failed to redistrict seats in the state house, affected politics well into the 20th century, failing to recognize the rise of industrial cities and urbanized areas.

name: alabama
sentence: "The lack of home rule for counties in Alabama has resulted in the proliferation of local legislation permitting counties to do things not authorized by the state constitution.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama's constitution has been amended more than 700 times, and almost one-third of the amendments are local in nature, applying to only one county or city.

name: alabama
sentence: A significant part of each legislative session is spent on local legislation, taking away time and attention of legislators from issues of statewide importance."

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama is an alcoholic beverage control state, meaning the state government holds a monopoly on the sale of alcohol.

name: alabama
sentence: The Alabama Alcoholic Beverage Control Board controls the sale and distribution of alcoholic beverages in the state.

name: alabama
sentence: A total of 25 of the 67 counties are "dry counties" which ban the sale of alcohol, and there are many dry municipalities in counties which permit alcohol sales.

name: alabama
sentence: During Reconstruction following the American Civil War, Alabama was occupied by federal troops of the Third Military District under General John Pope.

name: alabama
sentence: In 1874, the political coalition of white Democrats known as the Redeemers took control of the state government from the Republicans, in part by suppressing the black vote through violence, fraud and intimidation.

name: alabama
sentence: After 1890, a coalition of White Democratic politicians passed laws to segregate and disenfranchise African American residents, a process completed in provisions of the 1901 constitution.

name: alabama
sentence: Provisions which disenfranchised blacks resulted in excluding many poor Whites.

name: alabama
sentence: By 1941 more Whites than Blacks had been disenfranchised: 600,000 to 520,000.

name: alabama
sentence: The total effects were greater on the black community, as almost all its citizens were disfranchised and relegated to separate and unequal treatment under the law.

name: alabama
sentence: From 1901 through the 1960s, the state did not redraw election districts as population grew and shifted within the state during urbanization and industrialization of certain areas.

name: alabama
sentence: As counties were the basis of election districts, the result was a rural minority that dominated state politics through nearly three-quarters of the century, until a series of federal court cases required redistricting in 1972 to meet equal representation.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama state politics gained nationwide and international attention in the 1950s and 1960s during the civil rights movement, when whites bureaucratically, and at times violently, resisted protests for electoral and social reform.

name: alabama
sentence: Governor George Wallace, the state's only four-term governor, was a controversial figure who vowed to maintain segregation.

name: alabama
sentence: Only after passage of the federal Civil Rights Act of 1964 and Voting Rights Act of 1965 did African Americans regain the ability to exercise suffrage, among other civil rights.

name: alabama
sentence: In many jurisdictions, they continued to be excluded from representation by at-large electoral systems, which allowed the majority of the population to dominate elections.

name: alabama
sentence: Some changes at the county level have occurred following court challenges to establish single-member districts that enable a more diverse representation among county boards.

name: alabama
sentence: In 2007, the Alabama Legislature passed, and Republican governor Bob Riley signed a resolution expressing "profound regret" over slavery and its lingering impact.

name: alabama
sentence: In a symbolic ceremony, the bill was signed in the Alabama State Capitol, which housed Congress of the Confederate States of America.

name: alabama
sentence: In 2010, Republicans won control of both houses of the legislature for the first time in 136 years.

name: alabama
sentence: As of December 2017, there are a total of 3,326,812 registered voters, with 2,979,576 active, and the others inactive in the state.

name: alabama
sentence: With the disfranchisement of Blacks in 1901, the state became part of the "Solid South", a system in which the Democratic Party operated as effectively the only viable political party in every Southern state.

name: alabama
sentence: For nearly a hundred years local and state elections in Alabama were decided in the Democratic Party primary, with generally only token Republican challengers running in the General Election.

name: alabama
sentence: Since the mid- to late 20th century, however, white conservatives started shifting to the Republican Party.

name: alabama
sentence: In Alabama, majority-white districts are now expected to regularly elect Republican candidates to federal, state and local office.

name: alabama
sentence: Members of the nine seats on the Supreme Court of Alabama and all ten seats on the state appellate courts are elected to office.

name: alabama
sentence: Until 1994, no Republicans held any of the court seats.

name: alabama
sentence: In that general election, the then-incumbent chief justice, Ernest C. Hornsby, refused to leave office after losing the election by approximately 3,000 votes to Republican Perry O. Hooper Sr. Hornsby sued Alabama and defiantly remained in office for nearly a year before finally giving up the seat after losing in court.

name: alabama
sentence: The Democrats lost the last of the nineteen court seats in August 2011 with the resignation of the last Democrat on the bench.

name: alabama
sentence: In the early 21st century, Republicans hold all seven of the statewide elected executive branch offices.

name: alabama
sentence: Republicans hold six of the eight elected seats on the Alabama State Board of Education.

name: alabama
sentence: In 2010, Republicans took large majorities of both chambers of the state legislature, giving them control of that body for the first time in 136 years.

name: alabama
sentence: The last remaining statewide Democrat, who served on the Alabama Public Service Commission was defeated in 2012.

name: alabama
sentence: Only three Republican lieutenant governors have been elected since the end of Reconstruction, when Republicans generally represented Reconstruction government, including the newly emancipated freedmen who had gained the franchise.

name: alabama
sentence: The three GOP lieutenant governors are Steve Windom (1999–2003), Kay Ivey (2011–2017), and Will Ainsworth (2019–present).

name: alabama
sentence: Many local offices (county commissioners, boards of education, tax assessors, tax collectors, etc.)

name: alabama
sentence: in the state are still held by Democrats.

name: alabama
sentence: Many rural counties have voters who are majority Democrats, resulting in local elections being decided in the Democratic primary.

name: alabama
sentence: Similarly many metropolitan and suburban counties are majority-Republican and elections are effectively decided in the Republican Primary, although there are exceptions.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama's 67 county sheriffs are elected in partisan, at-large races, and Democrats still retain the narrow majority of those posts.

name: alabama
sentence: The current split is 35 Democrats, 31 Republicans, and one Independent Fayette.

name: alabama
sentence: However, most of the Democratic sheriffs preside over rural and less populated counties.

name: alabama
sentence: The majority of Republican sheriffs have been elected in the more urban/suburban and heavily populated counties.

name: alabama
sentence: As of 2015, the state of Alabama has one female sheriff, in Morgan County, Alabama, and ten African-American sheriffs.

name: alabama
sentence: The state's two US senators are Republican Richard C. Shelby and Republican Tommy Tuberville.

name: alabama
sentence: Shelby was originally elected to the Senatorte as a Democrat in 1986 and re-elected in 1992, but switched parties immediately following the November 1994 general election.

name: alabama
sentence: In the US House of Representatives, the state is represented by seven members, six of whom are Republicans: (Bradley Byrne, Mike D. Rogers, Robert Aderholt, Morris J. Brooks, Martha Roby, and Gary Palmer) and one Democrat: Terri Sewell who represents the Black Belt as well as most of the predominantly black portions of Birmingham, Tuscaloosa and Montgomery.

name: alabama
sentence: Public primary and secondary education in Alabama is under the purview of the Alabama State Board of Education as well as local oversight by 67 county school boards and 60 city boards of education.

name: alabama
sentence: Together, 1,496 individual schools provide education for 744,637 elementary and secondary students.

name: alabama
sentence: Public school funding is appropriated through the Alabama Legislature through the Education Trust Fund.

name: alabama
sentence: In FY 2006–2007, Alabama appropriated $3,775,163,578 for primary and secondary education.

name: alabama
sentence: That represented an increase of $444,736,387 over the previous fiscal year.

name: alabama
sentence: In 2007, more than 82 percent of schools made adequate yearly progress (AYP) toward student proficiency under the National No Child Left Behind law, using measures determined by the state of Alabama.

name: alabama
sentence: While Alabama's public education system has improved in recent decades, it lags behind in achievement compared to other states.

name: alabama
sentence: According to US Census data (2000), Alabama's high school graduation rate (75%) is the fourth lowest in the US (after Kentucky, Louisiana and Mississippi).

name: alabama
sentence: The largest educational gains were among people with some college education but without degrees.

name: alabama
sentence: Generally prohibited in the West at large, school corporal punishment is not unusual in Alabama, with 27,260 public school students paddled at least one time, according to government data for the 2011–2012 school year.

name: alabama
sentence: The rate of school corporal punishment in Alabama is surpassed by only Mississippi and Arkansas.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama's programs of higher education include 14 four-year public universities, two-year community colleges, and 17 private, undergraduate and graduate universities.

name: alabama
sentence: In the state are four medical schools (as of fall 2015) (University of Alabama School of Medicine, University of South Alabama and Alabama College of Osteopathic Medicine and The Edward Via College of Osteopathic Medicine—Auburn Campus), two veterinary colleges (Auburn University and Tuskegee University), a dental school (University of Alabama School of Dentistry), an optometry college (University of Alabama at Birmingham), two pharmacy schools (Auburn University and Samford University), and five law schools (University of Alabama School of Law, Birmingham School of Law, Cumberland School of Law, Miles Law School, and the Thomas Goode Jones School of Law).

name: alabama
sentence: Public, post-secondary education in Alabama is overseen by the Alabama Commission on Higher Education and the Alabama Department of Postsecondary Education.

name: alabama
sentence: Colleges and universities in Alabama offer degree programs from two-year associate degrees to a multitude of doctoral level programs.

name: alabama
sentence: The largest single campus is the University of Alabama, located in Tuscaloosa, with 37,665 enrolled for fall 2016.

name: alabama
sentence: Troy University was the largest institution in the state in 2010, with an enrollment of 29,689 students across four Alabama campuses (Troy, Dothan, Montgomery, and Phenix City), as well as sixty learning sites in seventeen other states and eleven other countries.

name: alabama
sentence: The oldest institutions are the public University of North Alabama in Florence and the Catholic Church-affiliated Spring Hill College in Mobile, both founded in 1830.

name: alabama
sentence: Accreditation of academic programs is through the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools (SACS) as well as other subject-focused national and international accreditation agencies such as the Association for Biblical Higher Education (ABHE), the Council on Occupational Education (COE), and the Accrediting Council for Independent Colleges and Schools (ACICS).

name: alabama
sentence: According to the 2011 US News & World Report, Alabama had three universities ranked in the top 100 Public Schools in America (University of Alabama at 31, Auburn University at 36, and University of Alabama at Birmingham at 73).

name: alabama
sentence: According to the 2012 US News & World Report, Alabama had four tier one universities (University of Alabama, Auburn University, University of Alabama at Birmingham and University of Alabama in Huntsville).

name: alabama
sentence: Major newspapers include Birmingham News, Mobile Press-Register, and Montgomery Advertiser.

name: alabama
sentence: Major television network affiliates in Alabama include:

name: alabama
sentence: College football is extremely popular in Alabama, particularly the University of Alabama Crimson Tide and Auburn University Tigers, rivals in the Southeastern Conference.

name: alabama
sentence: In the 2013 season, Alabama averaged over 100,000 fans per game and Auburn averaged over 80,000—both numbers among the top twenty in the nation.

name: alabama
sentence: Bryant–Denny Stadium is the home of the Alabama football team, and has a seating capacity of 101,821, and is the fifth largest stadium in America.

name: alabama
sentence: Jordan-Hare Stadium is the home field of the Auburn football team and seats up to 87,451.

name: alabama
sentence: Legion Field is home for the UAB Blazers football program and the Birmingham Bowl.

name: alabama
sentence: It seats 71,594.

name: alabama
sentence: Ladd–Peebles Stadium in Mobile is the home of the University of South Alabama football team, and serves as the home of the NCAA Senatoror Bowl, Dollar General Bowl (formerly GoDaddy.com Bowl), and Alabama-Mississippi All Star Classic; the stadium seats 40,646.

name: alabama
sentence: In 2009, Bryant–Denny Stadium and Jordan-Hare Stadium became the homes of the Alabama High School Athletic Association state football championship games, after previously being held at Legion Field in Birmingham.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama has several professional and semi-professional sports teams, including three minor league baseball teams.

name: alabama
sentence: The Talladega Superspeedway motorsports complex hosts a series of NASCAR events.

name: alabama
sentence: It has a seating capacity of 143,000 and is the thirteenth largest stadium in the world and sixth largest stadium in America.

name: alabama
sentence: Also, the Barber Motorsports Park has hosted IndyCar Series and Rolex Sports Car Series races.

name: alabama
sentence: The ATP Birmingham was a World Championship Tennis tournament held from 1973 to 1980.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama has hosted several professional golf tournaments, such as the 1984 and 1990 PGA Championship at Shoal Creek, the Barbasol Championship (PGA Tour), the Mobile LPGA Tournament of Champions, Airbus LPGA Classic, and Yokohama Tire LPGA Classic (LPGA Tour), and The Tradition (Champions Tour).

name: alabama
sentence: Major airports with sustained operations in Alabama include Birmingham-Shuttlesworth International Airport (BHM), Huntsville International Airport (HSV), Dothan Regional Airport (DHN), Mobile Regional Airport (MOB), Montgomery Regional Airport (MGM), Northwest Alabama Regional Airport (MSL) and Northeast Alabama Regional Airport (GAD).

name: alabama
sentence: For rail transport, Amtrak schedules the Crescent, a daily passenger train, running from New York to New Orleans with station stops at Anniston, Birmingham, and Tuscaloosa.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama has six major interstate routes: Interstate 65 (I-65) travels north–south roughly through the middle of the state; I-20/I-59 travel from the central west Mississippi state line to Birmingham, where I-59 continues to the north-east corner of the state and I-20 continues east towards Atlanta; I-85 originates in Montgomery and travels east-northeast to the Georgia state line, providing a main thoroughfare to Atlanta; and I-10 traverses the southernmost portion of the state, traveling from west to east through Mobile.

name: alabama
sentence: I-22 enters the state from Mississippi and connects Birmingham with Memphis, Tennessee.

name: alabama
sentence: In addition, there are currently five auxiliary interstate routes in the state: I-165 in Mobile, I-359 in Tuscaloosa, I-459 around Birmingham, I-565 in Decatur and Huntsville, and I-759 in Gadsden.

name: alabama
sentence: A sixth route, I-685, will be formed when I-85 is rerouted along a new southern bypass of Montgomery.

name: alabama
sentence: A proposed northern bypass of Birmingham will be designated as I-422.

name: alabama
sentence: Since a direct connection from I-22 to I-422 will not be possible, I-222 has been proposed, as well.

name: alabama
sentence: Several US

name: alabama
sentence: Highways also pass through the state, such as US Route 11 (US-11), US-29, US-31, US-43, US-45, US-72, US-78, US-80, US-82, US-84, US-90, US-98, US-231, US-278, US-280, US-331, US-411, and US-431.

name: alabama
sentence: There are four toll roads in the state: Montgomery Expressway in Montgomery

name: alabama
sentence: The Port of Mobile, Alabama's only saltwater port, is a large seaport on the Gulf of Mexico with inland waterway access to the Midwest by way of the Tennessee–Tombigbee Waterway.

name: alabama
sentence: The Port of Mobile was ranked 12th by tons of traffic in the United States during 2009.

name: alabama
sentence: The newly expanded container terminal at the Port of Mobile was ranked as the 25th busiest for container traffic in the nation during 2011.

name: alabama
sentence: The state's other ports are on rivers with access to the Gulf of Mexico.

name: alabama
sentence: Water ports of Alabama, listed from north to south:

sentence: "Alabama—History and Culture".

name: alabama
sentence: Adventure Tourism—Experiential Travel Guides.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska ( (listen); Aleut: Alax̂sxax̂; Inupiaq: Alaasikaq; Pacific Gulf Yupik: Alas'kaaq; Tlingit: Anáaski) is a US state on the northwest extremity of the country's West Coast, just across the Bering Strait.

name: alaska
sentence: A semi-exclave of the US, it borders the Canadian province of British Columbia and territory of Yukon to the east and southeast and has a maritime border with Russia's Chukotka Autonomous Okrug to the west.

name: alaska
sentence: To the north are the Chukchi and Beaufort seas of the Arctic Ocean, while the Pacific Ocean lies to the south and southwest.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska is by far the largest US state by area, comprising more total area than the next three largest states Texas, California, and Montana combined, and the seventh-largest subnational division in the world.

name: alaska
sentence: It is the third-least populous and the most sparsely populated state, but by far the continent's most populous territory located mostly north of the 60th parallel, with an estimated population of 738,432 as of 2015—more than quadruple the combined populations of Northern Canada and Greenland.

name: alaska
sentence: Approximately half of Alaska's residents live within the Anchorage metropolitan area.

name: alaska
sentence: The state capital of Juneau is the second-largest city in the United States by area, comprising more territory than the states of Rhode Island and Delaware.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska was occupied by various indigenous peoples for thousands of years before the arrival of Europeans.

name: alaska
sentence: The state is considered the entry point for the settlement of North America by way of the Bering land bridge.

name: alaska
sentence: The Russians were the first Europeans to settle the area beginning in the 18th century, eventually establishing Russian America, which spanned most of the current state.

name: alaska
sentence: The expense and difficulty of maintaining this distant possession prompted its sale to the US in 1867 for US$7.2 million, or approximately two cents per acre ($4.74/km2).

name: alaska
sentence: The area went through several administrative changes before becoming organized as a territory on May 11, 1912.

name: alaska
sentence: It was admitted as the 49th state of the US on January 3, 1959.

name: alaska
sentence: While it has one of the smallest state economies in the country, Alaska's per capita income is among the highest, owing to a diversified economy dominated by fishing, natural gas, and oil, all of which it has in abundance.

name: alaska
sentence: United States armed forces bases and tourism are also a significant part of the economy; more than half the state is federally owned public land, including a multitude of national forests, parks, and wildlife refuges.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska's indigenous population is proportionally the highest of any US state, at over 15 percent.

name: alaska
sentence: Close to two dozen native languages are spoken, and Alaskan Natives exercise considerable influence in local and state politics.

name: alaska
sentence: The name "Alaska" (Russian: Аля́ска, tr.

name: alaska
sentence: Alyáska) was introduced in the Russian colonial period when it was used to refer to the Alaska Peninsula.

name: alaska
sentence: It was derived from an Aleut-language idiom, which figuratively refers to the mainland.

name: alaska
sentence: Literally, it means object to which the action of the sea is directed.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska is the northernmost and westernmost state in the United States and has the most easterly longitude in the United States because the Aleutian Islands extend into the Eastern Hemisphere.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska is the only non-contiguous US state on continental North America

name: alaska
sentence: It is technically part of the continental US, but is sometimes not included in colloquial use; Alaska is not part of the contiguous US, often called "the Lower 48".

name: alaska
sentence: The capital city, Juneau, is situated on the mainland of the North American continent but is not connected by road to the rest of the North American highway system.

name: alaska
sentence: The state is bordered by Canada's Yukon and British Columbia to the east (making it the only state to border a Canadian territory), the Gulf of Alaska and the Pacific Ocean to the south and southwest, the Bering Sea, Bering Strait, and Chukchi Sea to the west and the Arctic Ocean to the north.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska's territorial waters touch Russia's territorial waters in the Bering Strait, as the Russian Big Diomede Island and Alaskan Little Diomede Island are only 3 miles (4.8 km) apart.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska has a longer coastline than all the other US states combined.

name: alaska
sentence: At 663,268 square miles (1,717,856 km2) in area, Alaska is by far the largest state in the United States, and is more than twice the size of the second-largest US state, Texas.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska is the seventh largest sub-national division in the world, and if it was an independent nation would be the 19th largest country in the world.

name: alaska
sentence: There are no officially defined borders demarcating the various regions of Alaska, but there are six widely accepted regions:

name: alaska
sentence: The most populous region of Alaska, containing Anchorage, the Matanuska-Susitna Valley and the Kenai Peninsula.

name: alaska
sentence: Rural, mostly unpopulated areas south of the Alaska Range and west of the Wrangell Mountains also fall within the definition of South Central, as do the Prince William Sound area and the communities of Cordova and Valdez.

name: alaska
sentence: Also referred to as the Panhandle or Inside Passage, this is the region of Alaska closest to the rest of the United States.

name: alaska
sentence: As such, this was where most of the initial non-indigenous settlement occurred in the years following the Alaska Purchase.

name: alaska
sentence: The region is dominated by the Alexander Archipelago as well as the Tongass National Forest, the largest national forest in the United States.

name: alaska
sentence: It contains the state capital Juneau, the former capital Sitka, and Ketchikan, at one time Alaska's largest city.

name: alaska
sentence: The Alaska Marine Highway provides a vital surface transportation link throughout the area, as only three communities (Haines, Hyder and Skagway) enjoy direct connections to the contiguous North American road system.

name: alaska
sentence: The Interior is the largest region of Alaska

name: alaska
sentence: Fairbanks is the only large city in the region.

name: alaska
sentence: Denali National Park and Preserve is located here.

name: alaska
sentence: Denali, formerly Mount McKinley, is the highest mountain in North America.

name: alaska
sentence: Southwest Alaska is a sparsely inhabited region stretching some 500 miles (800 km) inland from the Bering Sea.

name: alaska
sentence: Most of the population lives along the coast.

name: alaska
sentence: Kodiak Island is also located in Southwest.

name: alaska
sentence: The massive Yukon–Kuskokwim Delta, one of the largest river deltas in the world, is here.

name: alaska
sentence: Portions of the Alaska Peninsula are considered part of Southwest, with the remaining portions included with the Aleutian Islands (see below).

name: alaska
sentence: The North Slope is mostly tundra peppered with small villages.

name: alaska
sentence: The area is known for its massive reserves of crude oil and contains both the National Petroleum Reserve–Alaska and the Prudhoe Bay Oil Field.

name: alaska
sentence: The city of Utqiagvik, formerly known as Barrow, is the northernmost city in the United States and is located here.

name: alaska
sentence: The Northwest Arctic area, anchored by Kotzebue and also containing the Kobuk River valley, is often regarded as being part of this region.

name: alaska
sentence: However, the respective Inupiat of the North Slope and of the Northwest Arctic seldom consider themselves to be one people.

name: alaska
sentence: More than 300 small volcanic islands make up this chain, which stretches more than 1,200 miles (1,900 km) into the Pacific Ocean.

name: alaska
sentence: Some of these islands fall in the Eastern Hemisphere, but the International Date Line was drawn west of 180° to keep the whole state, and thus the entire North American continent, within the same legal day.

name: alaska
sentence: Two of the islands, Attu and Kiska, were occupied by Japanese forces during World War II.

name: alaska
sentence: With its myriad islands, Alaska has nearly 34,000 miles (55,000 km) of tidal shoreline.

name: alaska
sentence: The Aleutian Islands chain extends west from the southern tip of the Alaska Peninsula.

name: alaska
sentence: Many active volcanoes are found in the Aleutians and in coastal regions.

name: alaska
sentence: Unimak Island, for example, is home to Mount Shishaldin, which is an occasionally smoldering volcano that rises to 10,000 feet (3,000 m) above the North Pacific.

name: alaska
sentence: It is the most perfect volcanic cone on Earth, even more symmetrical than Japan's Mount Fuji.

name: alaska
sentence: The chain of volcanoes extends to Mount Spurr, west of Anchorage on the mainland.

name: alaska
sentence: Geologists have identified Alaska as part of Wrangellia, a large region consisting of multiple states and Canadian provinces in the Pacific Northwest, which is actively undergoing continent building.

name: alaska
sentence: One of the world's largest tides occurs in Turnagain Arm, just south of Anchorage, where tidal differences can be more than 35 feet (10.7 m).

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska has more than three million lakes.

name: alaska
sentence: Marshlands and wetland permafrost cover 188,320 square miles (487,700 km2) (mostly in northern, western and southwest flatlands).

name: alaska
sentence: Glacier ice covers about 28,957 square miles (75,000 km2) of Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: The Bering Glacier is the largest glacier in North America, covering 2,008 square miles (5,200 km2) alone.

name: alaska
sentence: According to an October 1998 report by the United States Bureau of Land Management, approximately 65% of Alaska is owned and managed by the US federal government as public lands, including a multitude of national forests, national parks, and national wildlife refuges.

name: alaska
sentence: Of these, the Bureau of Land Management manages 87 million acres (35 million hectares), or 23.8% of the state.

name: alaska
sentence: The Arctic National Wildlife Refuge is managed by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.

name: alaska
sentence: It is the world's largest wildlife refuge, comprising 16 million acres (6.5 million hectares).

name: alaska
sentence: Of the remaining land area, the state of Alaska owns 101 million acres (41 million hectares), its entitlement under the Alaska Statehood Act.

name: alaska
sentence: A portion of that acreage is occasionally ceded to organized boroughs, under the statutory provisions pertaining to newly formed boroughs.

name: alaska
sentence: Smaller portions are set aside for rural subdivisions and other homesteading-related opportunities.

name: alaska
sentence: These are not very popular due to the often remote and roadless locations.

name: alaska
sentence: The University of Alaska, as a land grant university, also owns substantial acreage which it manages independently.

name: alaska
sentence: Another 44 million acres (18 million hectares) are owned by 12 regional, and scores of local, Native corporations created under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act (ANCSA) of 1971.

name: alaska
sentence: Regional Native corporation Doyon, Limited often promotes itself as the largest private landowner in Alaska in advertisements and other communications.

name: alaska
sentence: Provisions of ANCSA allowing the corporations' land holdings to be sold on the open market starting in 1991 were repealed before they could take effect.

name: alaska
sentence: Effectively, the corporations hold title (including subsurface title in many cases, a privilege denied to individual Alaskans) but cannot sell the land.

name: alaska
sentence: Individual Native allotments can be and are sold on the open market, however.

name: alaska
sentence: Various private interests own the remaining land, totaling about one percent of the state.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska is, by a large margin, the state with the smallest percentage of private land ownership when Native corporation holdings are excluded.

name: alaska
sentence: The climate in Southeast Alaska is a mid-latitude oceanic climate (Köppen climate classification: Cfb) in the southern sections and a subarctic oceanic climate (Köppen Cfc) in the northern parts.

name: alaska
sentence: On an annual basis, Southeast is both the wettest and warmest part of Alaska with milder temperatures in the winter and high precipitation throughout the year.

name: alaska
sentence: Juneau averages over 50 in (130 cm) of precipitation a year, and Ketchikan averages over 150 in (380 cm).

name: alaska
sentence: This is also the only region in Alaska in which the average daytime high temperature is above freezing during the winter months.

name: alaska
sentence: The climate of Anchorage and south central Alaska is mild by Alaskan standards due to the region's proximity to the seacoast.

name: alaska
sentence: While the area gets less rain than southeast Alaska, it gets more snow, and days tend to be clearer.

name: alaska
sentence: On average, Anchorage receives 16 in (41 cm) of precipitation a year, with around 75 in (190 cm) of snow, although there are areas in the south central which receive far more snow.

name: alaska
sentence: It is a subarctic climate (Köppen: Dfc) due to its brief, cool summers.

name: alaska
sentence: The climate of Western Alaska is determined in large part by the Bering Sea and the Gulf of Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: It is a subarctic oceanic climate in the southwest and a continental subarctic climate farther north.

name: alaska
sentence: The temperature is somewhat moderate considering how far north the area is.

name: alaska
sentence: This region has a tremendous amount of variety in precipitation.

name: alaska
sentence: An area stretching from the northern side of the Seward Peninsula to the Kobuk River valley (i. e., the region around Kotzebue Sound) is technically a desert, with portions receiving less than 10 in (25 cm) of precipitation annually.

name: alaska
sentence: On the other extreme, some locations between Dillingham and Bethel average around 100 in (250 cm) of precipitation.

name: alaska
sentence: The climate of the interior of Alaska is subarctic.

name: alaska
sentence: Some of the highest and lowest temperatures in Alaska occur around the area near Fairbanks.

name: alaska
sentence: The summers may have temperatures reaching into the 90s °F (the low-to-mid 30s °C), while in the winter, the temperature can fall below −60 °F (−51 °C).

name: alaska
sentence: Precipitation is sparse in the Interior, often less than 10 in (25 cm) a year, but what precipitation falls in the winter tends to stay the entire winter.

name: alaska
sentence: The highest and lowest recorded temperatures in Alaska are both in the Interior.

name: alaska
sentence: The highest is 100 °F (38 °C) in Fort Yukon (which is just 8 mi or 13 km inside the arctic circle) on June 27, 1915, making Alaska tied with Hawaii as the state with the lowest high temperature in the United States.

name: alaska
sentence: The lowest official Alaska temperature is −80 °F (−62 °C) in Prospect Creek on January 23, 1971, one degree above the lowest temperature recorded in continental North America (in Snag, Yukon, Canada).

name: alaska
sentence: The climate in the extreme north of Alaska is Arctic (Köppen: ET) with long, very cold winters and short, cool summers.

name: alaska
sentence: Even in July, the average low temperature in Utqiagvik is 34 °F (1 °C).

name: alaska
sentence: Precipitation is light in this part of Alaska, with many places averaging less than 10 in (25 cm) per year, mostly as snow which stays on the ground almost the entire year.

name: alaska
sentence: Numerous indigenous peoples occupied Alaska for thousands of years before the arrival of European peoples to the area.

name: alaska
sentence: Linguistic and DNA studies done here have provided evidence for the settlement of North America by way of the Bering land bridge.

name: alaska
sentence: At the Upward Sun River site in the Tanana River Valley in Alaska, remains of a six-week-old infant were found.

name: alaska
sentence: The baby's DNA showed that she belonged to a population that was genetically separate from other native groups present elsewhere in the New World at the end of the Pleistocene.

name: alaska
sentence: Ben Potter, the University of Alaska Fairbanks archaeologist who unearthed the remains at the Upward River Sun site in 2013, named this new group Ancient Beringians.

name: alaska
sentence: The Tlingit people developed a society with a matrilineal kinship system of property inheritance and descent in what is today Southeast Alaska, along with parts of British Columbia and the Yukon.

name: alaska
sentence: Also in Southeast were the Haida, now well known for their unique arts.

name: alaska
sentence: The Tsimshian people came to Alaska from British Columbia in 1887, when President Grover Cleveland, and later the US Congress, granted them permission to settle on Annette Island and found the town of Metlakatla.

name: alaska
sentence: All three of these peoples, as well as other indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest Coast, experienced smallpox outbreaks from the late 18th through the mid-19th century, with the most devastating epidemics occurring in the 1830s and 1860s, resulting in high fatalities and social disruption.

name: alaska
sentence: The Aleutian Islands are still home to the Aleut people's seafaring society, although they were the first Native Alaskans to be exploited by the Russians.

name: alaska
sentence: Western and Southwestern Alaska are home to the Yup'ik, while their cousins the Alutiiq ~ Sugpiaq lived in what is now Southcentral Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: The Gwich'in people of the northern Interior region are Athabaskan and primarily known today for their dependence on the caribou within the much-contested Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.

name: alaska
sentence: The North Slope and Little Diomede Island are occupied by the widespread Inupiat people.

name: alaska
sentence: Some researchers believe the first Russian settlement in Alaska was established in the 17th century.

name: alaska
sentence: According to this hypothesis, in 1648 several koches of Semyon Dezhnyov's expedition came ashore in Alaska by storm and founded this settlement.

name: alaska
sentence: This hypothesis is based on the testimony of Chukchi geographer Nikolai Daurkin, who had visited Alaska in 1764–1765 and who had reported on a village on the Kheuveren River, populated by "bearded men" who "pray to the icons".

name: alaska
sentence: Some modern researchers associate Kheuveren with Koyuk River.

name: alaska
sentence: The first European vessel to reach Alaska is generally held to be the St. Gabriel under the authority of the surveyor M. S. Gvozdev and assistant navigator I. Fyodorov on August 21, 1732, during an expedition of Siberian cossack A. F. Shestakov and Russian explorer Dmitry Pavlutsky (1729–1735).

name: alaska
sentence: Another European contact with Alaska occurred in 1741, when Vitus Bering led an expedition for the Russian Navy aboard the St. Peter.

name: alaska
sentence: After his crew returned to Russia with sea otter pelts judged to be the finest fur in the world, small associations of fur traders began to sail from the shores of Siberia toward the Aleutian Islands.

name: alaska
sentence: The first permanent European settlement was founded in 1784.

name: alaska
sentence: Between 1774 and 1800, Spain sent several expeditions to Alaska to assert its claim over the Pacific Northwest.

name: alaska
sentence: In 1789 a Spanish settlement and fort were built in Nootka Sound.

name: alaska
sentence: These expeditions gave names to places such as Valdez, Bucareli Sound, and Cordova.

name: alaska
sentence: Later, the Russian-American Company carried out an expanded colonization program during the early-to-mid-19th century.

name: alaska
sentence: Sitka, renamed New Archangel from 1804 to 1867, on Baranof Island in the Alexander Archipelago in what is now Southeast Alaska, became the capital of Russian America.

name: alaska
sentence: It remained the capital after the colony was transferred to the United States.

name: alaska
sentence: The Russians never fully colonized Alaska, and the colony was never very profitable.

name: alaska
sentence: Evidence of Russian settlement in names and churches survive throughout southeast Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: William H. Seward, the United States Secretary of State, negotiated the Alaska Purchase (also known as Seward's Folly) with the Russians in 1867 for $7.2 million.

name: alaska
sentence: Russia's contemporary ruler Tsar Alexander II, the Emperor of the Russian Empire, King of Poland and Grand Duke of Finland, also planned the sale; the purchase was made on March 30, 1867.

name: alaska
sentence: Six months later the commissioners arrived in Sitka and the formal transfer was arranged; the formal flag-raising took place at Fort Sitka on October 18, 1867.

name: alaska
sentence: In the ceremony 250 uniformed US soldiers marched to the governor's house at "Castle Hill", where the Russian troops lowered the Russian flag and the US flag was raised.

name: alaska
sentence: This event is celebrated as Alaska Day, a legal holiday on October 18.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska was loosely governed by the military initially, and was administered as a district starting in 1884, with a governor appointed by the President of the United States.

name: alaska
sentence: A federal district court was headquartered in Sitka.

name: alaska
sentence: For most of Alaska's first decade under the United States flag, Sitka was the only community inhabited by American settlers.

name: alaska
sentence: They organized a "provisional city government", which was Alaska's first municipal government, but not in a legal sense.

name: alaska
sentence: Legislation allowing Alaskan communities to legally incorporate as cities did not come about until 1900, and home rule for cities was extremely limited or unavailable until statehood took effect in 1959.

name: alaska
sentence: Starting in the 1890s and stretching in some places to the early 1910s, gold rushes in Alaska and the nearby Yukon Territory brought thousands of miners and settlers to Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska was officially incorporated as an organized territory in 1912.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska's capital, which had been in Sitka until 1906, was moved north to Juneau.

name: alaska
sentence: Construction of the Alaska Governor's Mansion began that same year.

name: alaska
sentence: European immigrants from Norway and Sweden also settled in southeast Alaska, where they entered the fishing and logging industries.

name: alaska
sentence: During World War II, the Aleutian Islands Campaign focused on Attu, Agattu and Kiska, all which were occupied by the Empire of Japan.

name: alaska
sentence: During the Japanese occupation, a white American civilian and two United States Navy personnel were killed at Attu and Kiska respectively, and nearly a total of 50 Aleut civilians and eight sailors were interned in Japan.

name: alaska
sentence: About half of the Aleuts died during the period of internment.

name: alaska
sentence: Unalaska/Dutch Harbor and Adak became significant bases for the United States Army, United States Army Air Forces and United States Navy.

name: alaska
sentence: The United States Lend-Lease program involved flying American warplanes through Canada to Fairbanks and then Nome; Soviet pilots took possession of these aircraft, ferrying them to fight the German invasion of the Soviet Union.

name: alaska
sentence: The construction of military bases contributed to the population growth of some Alaskan cities.

name: alaska
sentence: Statehood for Alaska was an important cause of James Wickersham early in his tenure as a congressional delegate.

name: alaska
sentence: Decades later, the statehood movement gained its first real momentum following a territorial referendum in 1946.

name: alaska
sentence: The Alaska Statehood Committee and Alaska's Constitutional Convention would soon follow.

name: alaska
sentence: Statehood supporters also found themselves fighting major battles against political foes, mostly in the US Congress but also within Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: Statehood was approved by Congress on July 7, 1958.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska was officially proclaimed a state on January 3, 1959.

name: alaska
sentence: In 1960, the Census Bureau reported Alaska's population as 77.2% White, 3% Black, and 18.8% American Indian and Alaska Native.

name: alaska
sentence: On March 27, 1964, the massive Good Friday earthquake killed 133 people and destroyed several villages and portions of large coastal communities, mainly by the resultant tsunamis and landslides.

name: alaska
sentence: It was the second-most-powerful earthquake in recorded history, with a moment magnitude of 9.2 (more than a thousand times as powerful as the 1989 San Francisco earthquake).

name: alaska
sentence: The time of day (5:36 pm), time of year (spring) and location of the epicenter were all cited as factors in potentially sparing thousands of lives, particularly in Anchorage.

name: alaska
sentence: The 1968 discovery of oil at Prudhoe Bay and the 1977 completion of the Trans-Alaska Pipeline System led to an oil boom.

name: alaska
sentence: Royalty revenues from oil have funded large state budgets from 1980 onward.

name: alaska
sentence: That same year, not coincidentally, Alaska repealed its state income tax.

name: alaska
sentence: In 1989, the Exxon Valdez hit a reef in the Prince William Sound, spilling more than 11 million US gallons (42 megaliters) of crude oil over 1,100 miles (1,800 km) of coastline.

name: alaska
sentence: Today, the battle between philosophies of development and conservation is seen in the contentious debate over oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge and the proposed Pebble Mine.

name: alaska
sentence: The Alaska Heritage Resources Survey (AHRS) is a restricted inventory of all reported historic and prehistoric sites within the state of Alaska

name: alaska
sentence: The survey's inventory of cultural resources includes objects, structures, buildings, sites, districts, and travel ways, with a general provision that they are more than fifty years old.

name: alaska
sentence: As of 31 January 2012, more than 35,000 sites have been reported.

name: alaska
sentence: The United States Census Bureau estimates that the population of Alaska was 731,545 on July 1, 2019, a 3.00% increase since the 2010 United States Census.

name: alaska
sentence: In 2010, Alaska ranked as the 47th state by population, ahead of North Dakota, Vermont, and Wyoming (and Washington, D.C.).

name: alaska
sentence: Estimates show North Dakota ahead as of 2018.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska is the least densely populated state, and one of the most sparsely populated areas in the world, at 1.2 inhabitants per square mile (0.46/km2), with the next state, Wyoming, at 5.8 inhabitants per square mile (2.2/km2).

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska is by far the largest US state by area, and the tenth wealthiest (per capita income).

name: alaska
sentence: As of November 2014, the state's unemployment rate was 6.6%.As of 2018, it is one of 14 US states that still have only one telephone area code.

name: alaska
sentence: According to the 2010 United States Census, Alaska had a population of 710,231.

name: alaska
sentence: In terms of race and ethnicity, the state was 66.7% White (64.1% Non-Hispanic White), 14.8% American Indian and Alaska Native, 5.4% Asian, 3.3% Black or African American, 1.0% Native Hawaiian and Other Pacific Islander, 1.6% from Some Other Race, and 7.3% from Two or More Races.

name: alaska
sentence: Hispanics or Latinos of any race made up 5.5% of the population.

name: alaska
sentence: As of 2011, 50.7% of Alaska's population younger than one year of age belonged to minority groups (i.e., did not have two parents of non-Hispanic white ancestry).

name: alaska
sentence: According to the 2011 American Community Survey, 83.4% of people over the age of five spoke only English at home.

name: alaska
sentence: About 3.5% spoke Spanish at home, 2.2% spoke another Indo-European language, about 4.3% spoke an Asian language (including Tagalog), and about 5.3% spoke other languages at home.

name: alaska
sentence: The Alaska Native Language Center at the University of Alaska Fairbanks claims that at least 20 Alaskan native languages exist and there are also some languages with different dialects.

name: alaska
sentence: Most of Alaska's native languages belong to either the Eskimo–Aleut or Na-Dene language families; however, some languages are thought to be isolates (e.g.

name: alaska
sentence: Haida) or have not yet been classified (e.g.

name: alaska
sentence: Tsimshianic).

name: alaska
sentence: As of 2014 nearly all of Alaska's native languages were classified as either threatened, shifting, moribund, nearly extinct, or dormant languages.

name: alaska
sentence: A total of 5.2% of Alaskans speak one of the state's 20 indigenous languages, known locally as "native languages".

name: alaska
sentence: In October 2014, the governor of Alaska signed a bill declaring the state's 20 indigenous languages to have official status.

name: alaska
sentence: This bill gave them symbolic recognition as official languages, though they have not been adopted for official use within the government.

name: alaska
sentence: The 20 languages that were included in the bill are:

name: alaska
sentence: According to statistics collected by the Association of Religion Data Archives from 2010, about 34% of Alaska residents were members of religious congregations.

name: alaska
sentence: 100,960 people identified as Evangelical Protestants, 50,866 as Roman Catholic, and 32,550 as mainline Protestants.

name: alaska
sentence: Roughly 4% are Mormon, 0.5% are Jewish, 1% are Muslim, 0.5% are Buddhist, 0.2% are Baháʼí, and 0.5% are Hindu.

name: alaska
sentence: The largest religious denominations in Alaska as of 2010 were the Catholic Church with 50,866 adherents, non-denominational Evangelical Protestants with 38,070 adherents, The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints with 32,170 adherents, and the Southern Baptist Convention with 19,891 adherents.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska has been identified, along with Pacific Northwest states Washington and Oregon, as being the least religious states of the USA, in terms of church membership,

name: alaska
sentence: In 1795, the First Russian Orthodox Church was established in Kodiak.

name: alaska
sentence: Intermarriage with Alaskan Natives helped the Russian immigrants integrate into society.

name: alaska
sentence: As a result, an increasing number of Russian Orthodox churches gradually became established within Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska also has the largest Quaker population (by percentage) of any state.

name: alaska
sentence: In 2009 there were 6,000 Jews in Alaska (for whom observance of halakha may pose special problems).

name: alaska
sentence: Alaskan Hindus often share venues and celebrations with members of other Asian religious communities, including Sikhs and Jains.

name: alaska
sentence: In 2010, Alaskan Hindus established the Sri Ganesha Temple of Alaska, making it the first Hindu Temple in Alaska and the northernmost Hindu Temple in the world.

name: alaska
sentence: There are an estimated 2,000–3,000 Hindus in Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: The vast majority of Hindus live in Anchorage or Fairbanks.

name: alaska
sentence: Estimates for the number of Muslims in Alaska range from 2,000 to 5,000.

name: alaska
sentence: The Islamic Community Center of Anchorage began efforts in the late 1990s to construct a mosque in Anchorage.

name: alaska
sentence: They broke ground on a building in south Anchorage in 2010 and were nearing completion in late 2014.

name: alaska
sentence: When completed, the mosque will be the first in the state and one of the northernmost mosques in the world.

name: alaska
sentence: There's also a Baháʼí Center.

name: alaska
sentence: The 2018 gross state product was $55 billion, 48th in the nation.

name: alaska
sentence: Its per capita personal income for 2018 was $73,000, ranking 7th in the nation.

name: alaska
sentence: According to a 2013 study by Phoenix Marketing International, Alaska had the fifth-largest number of millionaires per capita in the United States, with a ratio of 6.75 percent.

name: alaska
sentence: The oil and gas industry dominates the Alaskan economy, with more than 80% of the state's revenues derived from petroleum extraction.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska's main export product (excluding oil and natural gas) is seafood, primarily salmon, cod, Pollock and crab.

name: alaska
sentence: Agriculture represents a very small fraction of the Alaskan economy.

name: alaska
sentence: Agricultural production is primarily for consumption within the state and includes nursery stock, dairy products, vegetables, and livestock.

name: alaska
sentence: Manufacturing is limited, with most foodstuffs and general goods imported from elsewhere.

name: alaska
sentence: Employment is primarily in government and industries such as natural resource extraction, shipping, and transportation.

name: alaska
sentence: Military bases are a significant component of the economy in the Fairbanks North Star, Anchorage and Kodiak Island boroughs, as well as Kodiak.

name: alaska
sentence: Federal subsidies are also an important part of the economy, allowing the state to keep taxes low.

name: alaska
sentence: Its industrial outputs are crude petroleum, natural gas, coal, gold, precious metals, zinc and other mining, seafood processing, timber and wood products.

name: alaska
sentence: There is also a growing service and tourism sector.

name: alaska
sentence: Tourists have contributed to the economy by supporting local lodging.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska has vast energy resources, although its oil reserves have been largely depleted.

name: alaska
sentence: Major oil and gas reserves were found in the Alaska North Slope (ANS) and Cook Inlet basins, but according to the Energy Information Administration, by February 2014 Alaska had fallen to fourth place in the nation in crude oil production after Texas, North Dakota, and California.

name: alaska
sentence: Prudhoe Bay on Alaska's North Slope is still the second highest-yielding oil field in the United States, typically producing about 400,000 barrels per day (64,000 m3/d), although by early 2014 North Dakota's Bakken Formation was producing over 900,000 barrels per day (140,000 m3/d).

name: alaska
sentence: Prudhoe Bay was the largest conventional oil field ever discovered in North America, but was much smaller than Canada's enormous Athabasca oil sands field, which by 2014 was producing about 1,500,000 barrels per day (240,000 m3/d) of unconventional oil, and had hundreds of years of producible reserves at that rate.

name: alaska
sentence: The Trans-Alaska Pipeline can transport and pump up to 2.1 million barrels (330,000 m3) of crude oil per day, more than any other crude oil pipeline in the United States.

name: alaska
sentence: Additionally, substantial coal deposits are found in Alaska's bituminous, sub-bituminous, and lignite coal basins.

name: alaska
sentence: The United States Geological Survey estimates that there are 85.4 trillion cubic feet (2,420 km3) of undiscovered, technically recoverable gas from natural gas hydrates on the Alaskan North Slope.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska also offers some of the highest hydroelectric power potential in the country from its numerous rivers.

name: alaska
sentence: Large swaths of the Alaskan coastline offer wind and geothermal energy potential as well.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska's economy depends heavily on increasingly expensive diesel fuel for heating, transportation, electric power and light.

name: alaska
sentence: Although wind and hydroelectric power are abundant and underdeveloped, proposals for statewide energy systems (e.g.

name: alaska
sentence: with special low-cost electric interties) were judged uneconomical (at the time of the report, 2001) due to low (less than 50¢/gal) fuel prices, long distances and low population.

name: alaska
sentence: The cost of a gallon of gas in urban Alaska today is usually thirty to sixty cents higher than the national average; prices in rural areas are generally significantly higher but vary widely depending on transportation costs, seasonal usage peaks, nearby petroleum development infrastructure and many other factors.

name: alaska
sentence: The Alaska Permanent Fund is a constitutionally authorized appropriation of oil revenues, established by voters in 1976 to manage a surplus in state petroleum revenues from oil, largely in anticipation of the then recently constructed Trans-Alaska Pipeline System.

name: alaska
sentence: The fund was originally proposed by Governor Keith Miller on the eve of the 1969 Prudhoe Bay lease sale, out of fear that the legislature would spend the entire proceeds of the sale (which amounted to $900 million) at once.

name: alaska
sentence: It was later championed by Governor Jay Hammond and Kenai state representative Hugh Malone.

name: alaska
sentence: It has served as an attractive political prospect ever since, diverting revenues which would normally be deposited into the general fund.

name: alaska
sentence: The Alaska Constitution was written so as to discourage dedicating state funds for a particular purpose.

name: alaska
sentence: The Permanent Fund has become the rare exception to this, mostly due to the political climate of distrust existing during the time of its creation.

name: alaska
sentence: From its initial principal of $734,000, the fund has grown to $50 billion as a result of oil royalties and capital investment programs.

name: alaska
sentence: Most if not all the principal is invested conservatively outside Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: This has led to frequent calls by Alaskan politicians for the Fund to make investments within Alaska, though such a stance has never gained momentum.

name: alaska
sentence: Starting in 1982, dividends from the fund's annual growth have been paid out each year to eligible Alaskans, ranging from an initial $1,000 in 1982 (equal to three years' payout, as the distribution of payments was held up in a lawsuit over the distribution scheme) to $3,269 in 2008 (which included a one-time $1,200 "Resource Rebate").

name: alaska
sentence: Every year, the state legislature takes out 8% from the earnings, puts 3% back into the principal for inflation proofing, and the remaining 5% is distributed to all qualifying Alaskans.

name: alaska
sentence: To qualify for the Permanent Fund Dividend, one must have lived in the state for a minimum of 12 months, maintain constant residency subject to allowable absences, and not be subject to court judgments or criminal convictions which fall under various disqualifying classifications or may subject the payment amount to civil garnishment.

name: alaska
sentence: The Permanent Fund is often considered to be one of the leading examples of a "Basic income" policy in the world.

name: alaska
sentence: The cost of goods in Alaska has long been higher than in the contiguous 48 states.

name: alaska
sentence: Federal government employees, particularly United States Postal Service (USPS) workers and active-duty military members, receive a Cost of Living Allowance usually set at 25% of base pay because, while the cost of living has gone down, it is still one of the highest in the country.

name: alaska
sentence: Rural Alaska suffers from extremely high prices for food and consumer goods compared to the rest of the country, due to the relatively limited transportation infrastructure.

name: alaska
sentence: Due to the northern climate and short growing season, relatively little farming occurs in Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: Most farms are in either the Matanuska Valley, about 40 miles (64 km) northeast of Anchorage, or on the Kenai Peninsula, about 60 miles (97 km) southwest of Anchorage.

name: alaska
sentence: The short 100-day growing season limits the crops that can be grown, but the long sunny summer days make for productive growing seasons.

name: alaska
sentence: The primary crops are potatoes, carrots, lettuce, and cabbage.

name: alaska
sentence: The Tanana Valley is another notable agricultural locus, especially the Delta Junction area, about 100 miles (160 km) southeast of Fairbanks, with a sizable concentration of farms growing agronomic crops; these farms mostly lie north and east of Fort Greely.

name: alaska
sentence: This area was largely set aside and developed under a state program spearheaded by Hammond during his second term as governor.

name: alaska
sentence: Delta-area crops consist predominantly of barley and hay.

name: alaska
sentence: West of Fairbanks lies another concentration of small farms catering to restaurants, the hotel and tourist industry, and community-supported agriculture.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaskan agriculture has experienced a surge in growth of market gardeners, small farms and farmers' markets in recent years, with the highest percentage increase (46%) in the nation in growth in farmers' markets in 2011, compared to 17% nationwide.

name: alaska
sentence: The peony industry has also taken off, as the growing season allows farmers to harvest during a gap in supply elsewhere in the world, thereby filling a niche in the flower market.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska, with no counties, lacks county fairs.

name: alaska
sentence: However, a small assortment of state and local fairs (with the Alaska State Fair in Palmer the largest), are held mostly in the late summer.

name: alaska
sentence: The fairs are mostly located in communities with historic or current agricultural activity, and feature local farmers exhibiting produce in addition to more high-profile commercial activities such as carnival rides, concerts and food.

name: alaska
