sentence: "Alaska Grown" is used as an agricultural slogan.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska has an abundance of seafood, with the primary fisheries in the Bering Sea and the North Pacific.

name: alaska
sentence: Seafood is one of the few food items that is often cheaper within the state than outside it.

name: alaska
sentence: Many Alaskans take advantage of salmon seasons to harvest portions of their household diet while fishing for subsistence, as well as sport.

name: alaska
sentence: This includes fish taken by hook, net or wheel.

name: alaska
sentence: Hunting for subsistence, primarily caribou, moose, and Dall sheep is still common in the state, particularly in remote Bush communities.

name: alaska
sentence: An example of a traditional native food is Akutaq, the Eskimo ice cream, which can consist of reindeer fat, seal oil, dried fish meat and local berries.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska's reindeer herding is concentrated on Seward Peninsula, where wild caribou can be prevented from mingling and migrating with the domesticated reindeer.

name: alaska
sentence: Most food in Alaska is transported into the state from "Outside", and shipping costs make food in the cities relatively expensive.

name: alaska
sentence: In rural areas, subsistence hunting and gathering is an essential activity because imported food is prohibitively expensive.

name: alaska
sentence: Although most small towns and villages in Alaska lie along the coastline, the cost of importing food to remote villages can be high, because of the terrain and difficult road conditions, which change dramatically, due to varying climate and precipitation changes.

name: alaska
sentence: The cost of transport can reach as high as 50¢ per pound ($1.10/kg) or more in some remote areas, during the most difficult times, if these locations can be reached at all during such inclement weather and terrain conditions.

name: alaska
sentence: The cost of delivering a 1 US gallon (3.8 L) of milk is about $3.50 in many villages where per capita income can be $20,000 or less.

name: alaska
sentence: Fuel cost per gallon is routinely twenty to thirty cents higher than the contiguous United States average, with only Hawaii having higher prices.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska has few road connections compared to the rest of the US

name: alaska
sentence: The state's road system covers a relatively small area of the state, linking the central population centers and the Alaska Highway, the principal route out of the state through Canada.

name: alaska
sentence: The state capital, Juneau, is not accessible by road, only a car ferry; this has spurred debate over decades about moving the capital to a city on the road system, or building a road connection from Haines.

name: alaska
sentence: The western part of Alaska has no road system connecting the communities with the rest of Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: The Interstate Highways in Alaska consists of a total of 1082 miles.

name: alaska
sentence: One unique feature of the Alaska Highway system is the Anton Anderson Memorial Tunnel, an active Alaska Railroad tunnel recently upgraded to provide a paved roadway link with the isolated community of Whittier on Prince William Sound to the Seward Highway about 50 miles (80 km) southeast of Anchorage at Portage.

name: alaska
sentence: At 2.5 miles (4.0 km), the tunnel was the longest road tunnel in North America until 2007.

name: alaska
sentence: The tunnel is the longest combination road and rail tunnel in North America.

name: alaska
sentence: Built around 1915, the Alaska Railroad (ARR) played a key role in the development of Alaska through the 20th century.

name: alaska
sentence: It links north Pacific shipping through providing critical infrastructure with tracks that run from Seward to Interior Alaska by way of South Central Alaska, passing through Anchorage, Eklutna, Wasilla, Talkeetna, Denali, and Fairbanks, with spurs to Whittier, Palmer and North Pole.

name: alaska
sentence: The cities, towns, villages, and region served by ARR tracks are known statewide as "The Railbelt".

name: alaska
sentence: In recent years, the ever-improving paved highway system began to eclipse the railroad's importance in Alaska's economy.

name: alaska
sentence: The railroad played a vital role in Alaska's development, moving freight into Alaska while transporting natural resources southward, such as coal from the Usibelli coal mine near Healy to Seward and gravel from the Matanuska Valley to Anchorage.

name: alaska
sentence: It is well known for its summertime tour passenger service.

name: alaska
sentence: The Alaska Railroad was one of the last railroads in North America to use cabooses in regular service and still uses them on some gravel trains.

name: alaska
sentence: It continues to offer one of the last flag stop routes in the country.

name: alaska
sentence: A stretch of about 60 miles (100 km) of track along an area north of Talkeetna remains inaccessible by road

name: alaska
sentence: Until construction of the Parks Highway in the 1970s, the railroad provided the only land access to most of the region along its entire route.

name: alaska
sentence: In northern Southeast Alaska, the White Pass and Yukon Route also partly runs through the state from Skagway northwards into Canada (British Columbia and Yukon Territory), crossing the border at White Pass Summit.

name: alaska
sentence: This line is now mainly used by tourists, often arriving by cruise liner at Skagway.

name: alaska
sentence: It was featured in the 1983 BBC television series Great Little Railways.

name: alaska
sentence: The Alaska Rail network is not connected to Outside.

name: alaska
sentence: (The nearest link to the North American railway network is the northwest terminus of the Canadian National Railway at Prince Rupert, British Columbia, several hundred miles to the southeast.)

name: alaska
sentence: In 2000, the US Congress authorized $6 million to study the feasibility of a rail link between Alaska, Canada, and the lower 48.

name: alaska
sentence: Some private companies provides car float service between Whittier and Seattle.

name: alaska
sentence: Many cities, towns and villages in the state do not have road or highway access; the only modes of access involve travel by air, river, or the sea.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska's well-developed state-owned ferry system (known as the Alaska Marine Highway) serves the cities of southeast, the Gulf Coast and the Alaska Peninsula.

name: alaska
sentence: The ferries transport vehicles as well as passengers.

name: alaska
sentence: The system also operates a ferry service from Bellingham, Washington and Prince Rupert, British Columbia, in Canada through the Inside Passage to Skagway.

name: alaska
sentence: The Inter-Island Ferry Authority also serves as an important marine link for many communities in the Prince of Wales Island region of Southeast and works in concert with the Alaska Marine Highway.

name: alaska
sentence: In recent years, cruise lines have created a summertime tourism market, mainly connecting the Pacific Northwest to Southeast Alaska and, to a lesser degree, towns along Alaska's gulf coast.

name: alaska
sentence: The population of Ketchikan for example fluctuates dramatically on many days—up to four large cruise ships can dock there at the same time.

name: alaska
sentence: Cities not served by road, sea, or river can be reached only by air, foot, dogsled, or snowmachine, accounting for Alaska's extremely well developed bush air services—an Alaskan novelty.

name: alaska
sentence: Anchorage and, to a lesser extent Fairbanks, is served by many major airlines.

name: alaska
sentence: Because of limited highway access, air travel remains the most efficient form of transportation in and out of the state.

name: alaska
sentence: Anchorage recently completed extensive remodeling and construction at Ted Stevens Anchorage International Airport to help accommodate the upsurge in tourism (in 2012–2013, Alaska received almost two million visitors).

name: alaska
sentence: Regular flights to most villages and towns within the state that are commercially viable are challenging to provide, so they are heavily subsidized by the federal government through the Essential Air Service program.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska Airlines is the only major airline offering in-state travel with jet service (sometimes in combination cargo and passenger Boeing 737-400s) from Anchorage and Fairbanks to regional hubs like Bethel, Nome, Kotzebue, Dillingham, Kodiak, and other larger communities as well as to major Southeast and Alaska Peninsula communities.

name: alaska
sentence: The bulk of remaining commercial flight offerings come from small regional commuter airlines such as Ravn Alaska, PenAir, and Frontier Flying Service.

name: alaska
sentence: The smallest towns and villages must rely on scheduled or chartered bush flying services using general aviation aircraft such as the Cessna Caravan, the most popular aircraft in use in the state.

name: alaska
sentence: Much of this service can be attributed to the Alaska bypass mail program which subsidizes bulk mail delivery to Alaskan rural communities.

name: alaska
sentence: The program requires 70% of that subsidy to go to carriers who offer passenger service to the communities.

name: alaska
sentence: Many communities have small air taxi services.

name: alaska
sentence: These operations originated from the demand for customized transport to remote areas.

name: alaska
sentence: Perhaps the most quintessentially Alaskan plane is the bush seaplane.

name: alaska
sentence: The world's busiest seaplane base is Lake Hood, located next to Ted Stevens Anchorage International Airport, where flights bound for remote villages without an airstrip carry passengers, cargo, and many items from stores and warehouse clubs.

name: alaska
sentence: In 2006 Alaska had the highest number of pilots per capita of any US state.

name: alaska
sentence: Another Alaskan transportation method is the dogsled.

name: alaska
sentence: In modern times (that is, any time after the mid-late 1920s), dog mushing is more of a sport than a true means of transportation.

name: alaska
sentence: Various races are held around the state, but the best known is the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race, a 1,150-mile (1,850 km) trail from Anchorage to Nome (although the distance varies from year to year, the official distance is set at 1,049 miles or 1,688 km).

name: alaska
sentence: The race commemorates the famous 1925 serum run to Nome in which mushers and dogs like Togo and Balto took much-needed medicine to the diphtheria-stricken community of Nome when all other means of transportation had failed.

name: alaska
sentence: Mushers from all over the world come to Anchorage each March to compete for cash, prizes, and prestige.

name: alaska
sentence: The "Serum Run" is another sled dog race that more accurately follows the route of the famous 1925 relay, leaving from the community of Nenana (southwest of Fairbanks) to Nome.

name: alaska
sentence: In areas not served by road or rail, primary transportation in summer is by all-terrain vehicle and in winter by snowmobile or "snow machine", as it is commonly referred to in Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska's internet and other data transport systems are provided largely through the two major telecommunications companies: GCI and Alaska Communications.

name: alaska
sentence: GCI owns and operates what it calls the Alaska United Fiber Optic system and as of late 2011 Alaska Communications advertised that it has "two fiber optic paths to the lower 48 and two more across Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: In January 2011, it was reported that a $1 billion project to connect Asia and rural Alaska was being planned, aided in part by $350 million in stimulus from the federal government.

name: alaska
sentence: Like all other US states, Alaska is governed as a republic, with three branches of government: an executive branch consisting of the governor of Alaska and his or her appointees which head executive departments; a legislative branch consisting of the Alaska House of Representatives and Alaska Senatorte; and a judicial branch consisting of the Alaska Supreme Court and lower courts.

name: alaska
sentence: The state of Alaska employs approximately 16,000 people statewide.

name: alaska
sentence: The Alaska Legislature consists of a 40-member House of Representatives and a 20-member Senatorte.

name: alaska
sentence: Senatortors serve four-year terms and House members two.

name: alaska
sentence: The governor of Alaska serves four-year terms.

name: alaska
sentence: The lieutenant governor runs separately from the governor in the primaries, but during the general election, the nominee for governor and nominee for lieutenant governor run together on the same ticket.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska's court system has four levels: the Alaska Supreme Court, the Alaska Court of Appeals, the superior courts and the district courts.

name: alaska
sentence: The superior and district courts are trial courts.

name: alaska
sentence: Superior courts are courts of general jurisdiction, while district courts hear only certain types of cases, including misdemeanor criminal cases and civil cases valued up to $100,000.

name: alaska
sentence: The Supreme Court and the Court of Appeals are appellate courts.

name: alaska
sentence: The Court of Appeals is required to hear appeals from certain lower-court decisions, including those regarding criminal prosecutions, juvenile delinquency, and habeas corpus.

name: alaska
sentence: The Supreme Court hears civil appeals and may in its discretion hear criminal appeals.

name: alaska
sentence: Although in its early years of statehood Alaska was a Democratic state, since the early 1970s it has been characterized as Republican-leaning.

name: alaska
sentence: Local political communities have often worked on issues related to land use development, fishing, tourism, and individual rights.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska Natives, while organized in and around their communities, have been active within the Native corporations.

name: alaska
sentence: These have been given ownership over large tracts of land, which require stewardship.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska was formerly the only state in which possession of one ounce or less of marijuana in one's home was completely legal under state law, though the federal law remains in force.

name: alaska
sentence: The state has an independence movement favoring a vote on secession from the United States, with the Alaskan Independence Party.

name: alaska
sentence: Six Republicans and four Democrats have served as governor of Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: In addition, Republican governor Wally Hickel was elected to the office for a second term in 1990 after leaving the Republican party and briefly joining the Alaskan Independence Party ticket just long enough to be reelected.

name: alaska
sentence: He officially rejoined the Republican party in 1994.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska's voter initiative making marijuana legal took effect on February 24, 2015, placing Alaska alongside Colorado and Washington as the first three US states where recreational marijuana is legal.

name: alaska
sentence: The new law means people over 21 can consume small amounts of pot.

name: alaska
sentence: The first legal marijuana store opened in Valdez in October 2016.

name: alaska
sentence: To finance state government operations, Alaska depends primarily on petroleum revenues and federal subsidies.

name: alaska
sentence: This allows it to have the lowest individual tax burden in the United States.

name: alaska
sentence: It is one of five states with no sales tax, one of seven states with no individual income tax, and—along with New Hampshire—one of two that has neither.

name: alaska
sentence: The Department of Revenue Tax Division reports regularly on the state's revenue sources.

name: alaska
sentence: The Department also issues an annual summary of its operations, including new state laws that directly affect the tax division.

name: alaska
sentence: In 2014 the Tax Foundation ranked Alaska as having the fourth most "business friendly" tax policy, behind only Wyoming, South Dakota, and Nevada.

name: alaska
sentence: While Alaska has no state sales tax, 89 municipalities collect a local sales tax, from 1.0 to 7.5%, typically 3–5%.

name: alaska
sentence: Other local taxes levied include raw fish taxes, hotel, motel, and bed-and-breakfast 'bed' taxes, severance taxes, liquor and tobacco taxes, gaming (pull tabs) taxes, tire taxes and fuel transfer taxes.

name: alaska
sentence: A part of the revenue collected from certain state taxes and license fees (such as petroleum, aviation motor fuel, telephone cooperative) is shared with municipalities in Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: The fall in oil prices after the fracking boom in the early 2010s has decimated Alaska's state treasury, which has historically received about 85 percent of its revenue from taxes and fees imposed on oil and gas companies.

name: alaska
sentence: The state government has had to drastically reduce its budget, and has brought its budget shortfall from over $2 billion in 2016 to under $500 million by 2018.

name: alaska
sentence: In 2020, Alaska's state government budget was $4.8 billion, while projected government revenues were only $4.5 billion.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska regularly supports Republicans in presidential elections and has done so since statehood.

name: alaska
sentence: Republicans have won the state's electoral college votes in all but one election that it has participated in (1964).

name: alaska
sentence: No state has voted for a Democratic presidential candidate fewer times.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska was carried by Democratic nominee Lyndon B. Johnson during his landslide election in 1964, while the 1960 and 1968 elections were close.

name: alaska
sentence: Since 1972, however, Republicans have carried the state by large margins.

name: alaska
sentence: In 2008, Republican John McCain defeated Democrat Barack Obama in Alaska, 59.49% to 37.83%.

name: alaska
sentence: McCain's running mate was Sarah Palin, the state's governor and the first Alaskan on a major party ticket.

name: alaska
sentence: Obama lost Alaska again in 2012, but he captured 40% of the state's vote in that election, making him the first Democrat to do so since 1968.

name: alaska
sentence: The Alaska Bush, central Juneau, midtown and downtown Anchorage, and the areas surrounding the University of Alaska Fairbanks campus and Ester have been strongholds of the Democratic Party.

name: alaska
sentence: The Matanuska-Susitna Borough, the majority of Fairbanks (including North Pole and the military base), and South Anchorage typically have the strongest Republican showing.

name: alaska
sentence: In the 2020 election cycle, Alaskan voters approved Ballot Measure 2.

name: alaska
sentence: Bipartisan coalitions led the campaigns for and against the bill.

name: alaska
sentence: The measure passed by a margin of 1.1%, or about 4,000 votes.

name: alaska
sentence: Supporters of the measure claim that it will reduce "dark money" in Alaskan elections by requiring anyone giving over $2,000 to a campaign to disclose the true source of such contributions and all intermediaries.

name: alaska
sentence: The measure also establishes non-partisan blanket primaries for statewide elections (like in Washington state and California) and ranked-choice voting (like in Maine).

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska is the third state with jungle primaries for all statewide races, the second state with ranked voting, and the only state with both.

name: alaska
sentence: The first race to use the new system of elections will be the 2022 Senatorte election in which Lisa Murkowski will run for re-election.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska is not divided into counties, as most of the other US states, but it is divided into boroughs.

name: alaska
sentence: Many of the more densely populated parts of the state are part of Alaska's 16 boroughs, which function somewhat similarly to counties in other states.

name: alaska
sentence: However, unlike county-equivalents in the other 49 states, the boroughs do not cover the entire land area of the state.

name: alaska
sentence: The area not part of any borough is referred to as the Unorganized Borough.

name: alaska
sentence: The Unorganized Borough has no government of its own, but the US Census Bureau in cooperation with the state divided the Unorganized Borough into 11 census areas solely for the purposes of statistical analysis and presentation.

name: alaska
sentence: A recording district is a mechanism for administration of the public record in Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: The state is divided into 34 recording districts which are centrally administered under a State Recorder.

name: alaska
sentence: All recording districts use the same acceptance criteria, fee schedule, etc., for accepting documents into the public record.

name: alaska
sentence: Whereas many US states use a three-tiered system of decentralization—state/county/township—most of Alaska uses only two tiers—state/borough.

name: alaska
sentence: Owing to the low population density, most of the land is located in the Unorganized Borough.

name: alaska
sentence: As the name implies, it has no intermediate borough government but is administered directly by the state government.

name: alaska
sentence: In 2000, 57.71% of Alaska's area has this status, with 13.05% of the population.

name: alaska
sentence: Anchorage merged the city government with the Greater Anchorage Area Borough in 1975 to form the Municipality of Anchorage, containing the city proper and the communities of Eagle River, Chugiak, Peters Creek, Girdwood, Bird, and Indian.

name: alaska
sentence: Fairbanks has a separate borough (the Fairbanks North Star Borough) and municipality (the City of Fairbanks).

name: alaska
sentence: The state's most populous city is Anchorage, home to 278,700 people in 2006, 225,744 of whom live in the urbanized area.

name: alaska
sentence: The richest location in Alaska by per capita income is Halibut Cove ($89,895).

name: alaska
sentence: Yakutat City, Sitka, Juneau, and Anchorage are the four largest cities in the US by area.

name: alaska
sentence: As reflected in the 2010 United States Census, Alaska has a total of 355 incorporated cities and census-designated places (CDPs).

name: alaska
sentence: The tally of cities includes four unified municipalities, essentially the equivalent of a consolidated city–county.

name: alaska
sentence: The majority of these communities are located in the rural expanse of Alaska known as "The Bush" and are unconnected to the contiguous North American road network.

name: alaska
sentence: The table at the bottom of this section lists the 100 largest cities and census-designated places in Alaska, in population order.

name: alaska
sentence: Of Alaska's 2010 Census population figure of 710,231, 20,429 people, or 2.88% of the population, did not live in an incorporated city or census-designated place.

name: alaska
sentence: Approximately three-quarters of that figure were people who live in urban and suburban neighborhoods on the outskirts of the city limits of Ketchikan, Kodiak, Palmer and Wasilla.

name: alaska
sentence: CDPs have not been established for these areas by the United States Census Bureau, except that seven CDPs were established for the Ketchikan-area neighborhoods in the 1980 Census (Clover Pass, Herring Cove, Ketchikan East, Mountain Point, North Tongass Highway, Pennock Island and Saxman East), but have not been used since.

name: alaska
sentence: The remaining population was scattered throughout Alaska, both within organized boroughs and in the Unorganized Borough, in largely remote areas.

name: alaska
sentence: The Alaska Department of Education and Early Development administers many school districts in Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: In addition, the state operates a boarding school, Mt.

name: alaska
sentence: Edgecumbe High School in Sitka, and provides partial funding for other boarding schools, including Nenana Student Living Center in Nenana and The Galena Interior Learning Academy in Galena.

name: alaska
sentence: There are more than a dozen colleges and universities in Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: Accredited universities in Alaska include the University of Alaska Anchorage, University of Alaska Fairbanks, University of Alaska Southeast, and Alaska Pacific University.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska is the only state that has no institutions that are part of NCAA Division I.

name: alaska
sentence: The Alaska Department of Labor and Workforce Development operates AVTEC, Alaska's Institute of Technology.

name: alaska
sentence: Campuses in Seward and Anchorage offer one-week to 11-month training programs in areas as diverse as Information Technology, Welding, Nursing, and Mechanics.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska has had a problem with a "brain drain".

name: alaska
sentence: Many of its young people, including most of the highest academic achievers, leave the state after high school graduation and do not return.

name: alaska
sentence: As of 2013, Alaska did not have a law school or medical school.

name: alaska
sentence: The University of Alaska has attempted to combat this by offering partial four-year scholarships to the top 10% of Alaska high school graduates, via the Alaska Scholars Program.

name: alaska
sentence: The Alaska State Troopers are Alaska's statewide police force.

name: alaska
sentence: They have a long and storied history, but were not an official organization until 1941.

name: alaska
sentence: Before the force was officially organized, law enforcement in Alaska was handled by various federal agencies.

name: alaska
sentence: Larger towns usually have their own local police and some villages rely on "Public Safety Officers" who have police training but do not carry firearms.

name: alaska
sentence: In much of the state, the troopers serve as the only police force available.

name: alaska
sentence: In addition to enforcing traffic and criminal law, wildlife Troopers enforce hunting and fishing regulations.

name: alaska
sentence: Due to the varied terrain and wide scope of the Troopers' duties, they employ a wide variety of land, air, and water patrol vehicles.

name: alaska
sentence: Many rural communities in Alaska are considered "dry", having outlawed the importation of alcoholic beverages.

name: alaska
sentence: Suicide rates for rural residents are higher than urban.

name: alaska
sentence: Domestic abuse and other violent crimes are also at high levels in the state

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska has the highest rate of sexual assault in the nation, especially in rural areas.

name: alaska
sentence: The average age of sexually assaulted victims is 16 years old.

name: alaska
sentence: In four out of five cases, the suspects were relatives, friends or acquaintances.

name: alaska
sentence: Some of Alaska's popular annual events are the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race from Anchorage to Nome, World Ice Art Championships in Fairbanks, the Blueberry Festival and Alaska Hummingbird Festival in Ketchikan, the Sitka Whale Fest, and the Stikine River Garnet Fest in Wrangell.

name: alaska
sentence: The Stikine River attracts the largest springtime concentration of American bald eagles in the world.

name: alaska
sentence: The Alaska Native Heritage Center celebrates the rich heritage of Alaska's 11 cultural groups.

name: alaska
sentence: Their purpose is to encourage cross-cultural exchanges among all people and enhance self-esteem among Native people.

name: alaska
sentence: The Alaska Native Arts Foundation promotes and markets Native art from all regions and cultures in the State, using the internet.

name: alaska
sentence: Influences on music in Alaska include the traditional music of Alaska Natives as well as folk music brought by later immigrants from Russia and Europe.

name: alaska
sentence: Prominent musicians from Alaska include singer Jewel, traditional Aleut flautist Mary Youngblood, folk singer-songwriter Libby Roderick, Christian music singer-songwriter Lincoln Brewster, metal/post hardcore band 36 Crazyfists and the groups Pamyua and Portugal.

name: alaska
sentence: The Man.

name: alaska
sentence: There are many established music festivals in Alaska, including the Alaska Folk Festival, the Fairbanks Summer Arts Festival] the Anchorage Folk Festival, the Athabascan Old-Time Fiddling Festival, the Sitka Jazz Festival, and the Sitka Summer Music Festival.

name: alaska
sentence: The most prominent orchestra in Alaska is the Anchorage Symphony Orchestra, though the Fairbanks Symphony Orchestra and Juneau Symphony are also notable.

name: alaska
sentence: The Anchorage Opera is currently the state's only professional opera company, though there are several volunteer and semi-professional organizations in the state as well.

name: alaska
sentence: The official state song of Alaska is "Alaska's Flag", which was adopted in 1955; it celebrates the flag of Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska's first independent picture entirely made in Alaska was The Chechahcos, produced by Alaskan businessman Austin E. Lathrop and filmed in and around Anchorage.

name: alaska
sentence: Released in 1924 by the Alaska Moving Picture Corporation, it was the only film the company made.

name: alaska
sentence: One of the most prominent movies filmed in Alaska is MGM's Eskimo/Mala The Magnificent, starring Alaska Native Ray Mala.

name: alaska
sentence: In 1932 an expedition set out from MGM's studios in Hollywood to Alaska to film what was then billed as "The Biggest Picture Ever Made".

name: alaska
sentence: Upon arriving in Alaska, they set up "Camp Hollywood" in Northwest Alaska, where they lived during the duration of the filming.

name: alaska
sentence: Louis B. Mayer spared no expense in spite of the remote location, going so far as to hire the chef from the Hotel Roosevelt in Hollywood to prepare meals.

name: alaska
sentence: When Eskimo premiered at the Astor Theatre in New York City, the studio received the largest amount of feedback in its history.

name: alaska
sentence: Eskimo was critically acclaimed and released worldwide; as a result, Mala became an international movie star.

name: alaska
sentence: Eskimo won the first Oscar for Best Film Editing at the Academy Awards, and showcased and preserved aspects of Inupiat culture on film.

name: alaska
sentence: The 1983 Disney movie Never Cry Wolf was at least partially shot in Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: The 1991 film White Fang, based on Jack London's 1906 novel and starring Ethan Hawke, was filmed in and around Haines.

name: alaska
sentence: Steven Seagal's 1994 On Deadly Ground, starring Michael Caine, was filmed in part at the Worthington Glacier near Valdez.

name: alaska
sentence: The 1999 John Sayles film Limbo, starring David Strathairn, Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio, and Kris Kristofferson, was filmed in Juneau.

name: alaska
sentence: The psychological thriller Insomnia, starring Al Pacino and Robin Williams, was shot in Canada, but was set in Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: The 2007 film directed by Sean Penn, Into The Wild, was partially filmed and set in Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: The film, which is based on the novel of the same name, follows the adventures of Christopher McCandless, who died in a remote abandoned bus along the Stampede Trail west of Healy in 1992.

name: alaska
sentence: Many films and television shows set in Alaska are not filmed there; for example, Northern Exposure, set in the fictional town of Cicely, Alaska, was filmed in Roslyn, Washington.

name: alaska
sentence: The 2007 horror feature 30 Days of Night is set in Barrow, Alaska, but was filmed in New Zealand.

name: alaska
sentence: Many reality television shows are filmed in Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: In 2011 the Anchorage Daily News found ten set in the state.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona ( (listen) ARR-iz-OH-nə

name: arizona
sentence: It is also part of the Western and the Mountain states.

name: arizona
sentence: It is the 6th largest and the 14th most populous of the 50 states.

name: arizona
sentence: Its capital and largest city is Phoenix.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona shares the Four Corners region with Utah, Colorado, and New Mexico; its other neighboring states are Nevada and California to the west and the Mexican states of Sonora and Baja California to the south and southwest.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona is the 48th state and last of the contiguous states to be admitted to the Union, achieving statehood on February 14, 1912.

name: arizona
sentence: Historically part of the territory of Alta California in New Spain, it became part of independent Mexico in 1821.

name: arizona
sentence: After being defeated in the Mexican–American War, Mexico ceded much of this territory to the United States in 1848.

name: arizona
sentence: The southernmost portion of the state was acquired in 1853 through the Gadsden Purchase.

name: arizona
sentence: Southern Arizona is known for its desert climate, with very hot summers and mild winters.

name: arizona
sentence: Northern Arizona features forests of pine, Douglas fir, and spruce trees; the Colorado Plateau; mountain ranges (such as the San Francisco Mountains); as well as large, deep canyons, with much more moderate summer temperatures and significant winter snowfalls.

name: arizona
sentence: There are ski resorts in the areas of Flagstaff, Alpine, and Tucson.

name: arizona
sentence: In addition to the internationally known Grand Canyon National Park, which is one of the world's seven natural wonders, there are several national forests, national parks, and national monuments.

name: arizona
sentence: About one-quarter of the state is made up of Indian reservations that serve as the home of 27 federally recognized Native American tribes, including the Navajo Nation, the largest in the state and the United States, with more than 300,000 citizens.

name: arizona
sentence: Although federal law gave all Native Americans US citizenship (and thereby the right to vote) in 1924, Arizona excluded those living on reservations in the state from voting until the state Supreme Court ruled in favor of Native American plaintiffs in Harrison v. Laveen (1948).

name: arizona
sentence: The state's name appears to originate from an earlier Spanish name, Arizonac, derived from the O'odham name alĭ ṣonak, meaning "small spring", which initially applied only to an area near the silver mining camp of Planchas de Plata, Sonora.

name: arizona
sentence: To the European settlers, their pronunciation sounded like Arissona.

name: arizona
sentence: The area is still known as alĭ ṣonak in the O'odham language.

name: arizona
sentence: Another possible origin is the Basque phrase haritz ona ("the good oak"), as there were numerous Basque sheepherders in the area.

name: arizona
sentence: A native Mexican of Basque heritage established the ranchería (village) of Arizona between 1734 and 1736 in the current Mexican state of Sonora, which became notable after a significant discovery of silver there, c. 1737.

name: arizona
sentence: The misconception that the state's name originated from the supposedly Spanish term Árida Zona ("Arid Zone") is considered a case of folk etymology.

name: arizona
sentence: For thousands of years before the modern era, Arizona was home to many Native American tribes.

name: arizona
sentence: Hohokam, Mogollon and Ancestral Puebloan cultures were among those that flourished throughout the state.

name: arizona
sentence: Many of their pueblos, cliffside dwellings, rock paintings and other prehistoric treasures have survived and attract thousands of tourists each year.

name: arizona
sentence: In 1539, Marcos de Niza, a Spanish Franciscan, became the first European to contact Native Americans.

name: arizona
sentence: He explored parts of the present state and made contact with native inhabitants, probably the Sobaipuri.

name: arizona
sentence: The expedition of Spanish explorer Coronado entered the area in 1540–1542 during its search for Cíbola.

name: arizona
sentence: Few Spanish settlers migrated to Arizona.

name: arizona
sentence: One of the first settlers in Arizona was José Romo de Vivar.

name: arizona
sentence: Father Kino was the next European in the region.

name: arizona
sentence: A member of the Society of Jesus ("Jesuits"), he led the development of a chain of missions in the region.

name: arizona
sentence: He converted many of the Indians to Christianity in the Pimería Alta (now southern Arizona and northern Sonora) in the 1690s and early 18th century.

name: arizona
sentence: Spain founded presidios ("fortified towns") at Tubac in 1752 and Tucson in 1775.

name: arizona
sentence: When Mexico achieved its independence from the Kingdom of Spain and its Spanish Empire in 1821, what is now Arizona became part of its Territory of Nueva California, ("New California"), also known as Alta California ("Upper California").

name: arizona
sentence: Descendants of ethnic Spanish and mestizo settlers from the colonial years still lived in the area at the time of the arrival of later European-American migrants from the United States.

name: arizona
sentence: During the Mexican–American War (1847–1848), the US Army occupied the national capital of Mexico City and pursued its claim to much of northern Mexico, including what later became Arizona Territory in 1863 and later the State of Arizona in 1912.

name: arizona
sentence: The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo (1848) specified that, in addition to language and cultural rights of the existing inhabitants of former Mexican citizens being considered as inviolable, the sum of $15 million in compensation (equivalent to $443,250,000 in 2019) be paid to the Republic of Mexico.

name: arizona
sentence: In 1853, the US acquired the land south below the Gila River from Mexico in the Gadsden Purchase along the southern border area as encompassing the best future southern route for a transcontinental railway.

name: arizona
sentence: What is now known as the state of Arizona was initially administered by the United States government as part of the Territory of New Mexico until the southern part of that region seceded from the Union to form the Territory of Arizona.

name: arizona
sentence: This newly established territory was formally organized by the federal government of the Confederate States on Saturday, January 18, 1862, when President Jefferson Davis approved and signed An Act to Organize the Territory of Arizona, marking the first official use of the name "Territory of Arizona".

name: arizona
sentence: The Southern territory supplied the Confederate government with men, horses, and equipment.

name: arizona
sentence: Formed in 1862, Arizona scout companies served with the Confederate States Army during the American Civil War.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona has the westernmost military engagement on record during the Civil War with the Battle of Picacho Pass (1862).

name: arizona
sentence: The Federal government declared a new US Arizona Territory, consisting of the western half of earlier New Mexico Territory, in Washington, D.C., on February 24, 1863.

name: arizona
sentence: These new boundaries would later form the basis of the state.

name: arizona
sentence: The first territorial capital, Prescott, was founded in 1864 following a gold rush to central Arizona.

name: arizona
sentence: The capital was later moved to Tucson, back to Prescott, and then to its final location in Phoenix in a series of controversial moves as different regions of the territory gained and lost political influence with the growth and development of the territory.

name: arizona
sentence: Although names including "Gadsonia", "Pimeria", "Montezuma" and "Arizuma" had been considered for the territory, when 16th President Abraham Lincoln signed the final bill, it read "Arizona", and that name was adopted.

name: arizona
sentence: (Montezuma was not derived from the Aztec emperor, but was the sacred name of a divine hero to the Pima people of the Gila River Valley.

name: arizona
sentence: It was probably considered—and rejected—for its sentimental value before Congress settled on the name "Arizona".)

name: arizona
sentence: Brigham Young, patriarchal leader of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Salt Lake City in Utah, sent Mormons to Arizona in the mid- to late 19th century.

name: arizona
sentence: They founded Mesa, Snowflake, Heber, Safford, and other towns.

name: arizona
sentence: They also settled in the Phoenix Valley (or "Valley of the Sun"), Tempe, Prescott, and other areas.

name: arizona
sentence: The Mormons settled what became northern Arizona and northern New Mexico.

name: arizona
sentence: At the time these areas were in a part of the former New Mexico Territory.

name: arizona
sentence: During the nineteenth century, a series of gold and silver rushes occurred in the territory, the best known being the 1870s stampede to the silver bonanzas of Tombstone, Arizona in southeast Arizona, also known for its legendary outlaws and lawmen.

name: arizona
sentence: By the late 1880s, copper production eclipsed the precious metals with the rise of copper camps like Bisbee, Arizona and Jerome, Arizona.

name: arizona
sentence: The boom and bust economy of mining also left hundreds of ghost towns across the territory, but copper mining continued to prosper with the territory producing more copper than any other state by 1907, which earned Arizona the nickname "the Copper State" at the time of statehood.

name: arizona
sentence: During the first years of statehood the industry experienced growing pains and labor disputes with the Bisbee Deportation of 1917 the result of a copper miners' strike.

name: arizona
sentence: The state continues to produce half of the nation's newly mined copper.

name: arizona
sentence: During the Mexican Revolution from 1910 to 1920, several battles were fought in the Mexican towns just across the border from Arizona settlements.

name: arizona
sentence: Throughout the revolution, many Arizonans enlisted in one of the several armies fighting in Mexico.

name: arizona
sentence: Only two significant engagements took place on US soil between US and Mexican forces: Pancho Villa's 1916 Columbus Raid in New Mexico, and the Battle of Ambos Nogales in 1918 in Arizona.

name: arizona
sentence: The Mexicans won the first battle and the Americans won the latter.

name: arizona
sentence: After Mexican federal troops fired on US soldiers, the American garrison launched an assault into Nogales, Mexico.

name: arizona
sentence: The Mexicans eventually surrendered after both sides sustained heavy casualties.

name: arizona
sentence: A few months earlier, just west of Nogales, an Indian War battle had occurred, considered the last engagement in the American Indian Wars, which lasted from 1775 to 1918.

name: arizona
sentence: US soldiers stationed on the border confronted Yaqui Indians who were using Arizona as a base to raid the nearby Mexican settlements, as part of their wars against Mexico.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona became a US state on February 14, 1912, coincidentally Valentine's Day.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona was the 48th state admitted to the US and the last of the contiguous states to be admitted.

name: arizona
sentence: Cotton farming and copper mining, two of Arizona's most important statewide industries, suffered heavily during the Great Depression.

name: arizona
sentence: But during the 1920s and even the 1930s, tourism began to develop as the important Arizonan industry it is today.

name: arizona
sentence: Dude ranches, such as the K L Bar and Remuda in Wickenburg, along with the Flying V and Tanque Verde in Tucson, gave tourists the chance to take part in the flavor and activities of the "Old West".

name: arizona
sentence: Several upscale hotels and resorts opened during this period, some of which are still top tourist draws.

name: arizona
sentence: They include the Arizona Biltmore Hotel in central Phoenix (opened 1929) and the Wigwam Resort on the west side of the Phoenix area (opened 1936).

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona was the site of German prisoner of war camps during World War II and Japanese American internment camps.

name: arizona
sentence: Because of wartime fears of a Japanese invasion of the US West Coast (which in fact materialized in the Aleutian Islands Campaign in June 1942), the government authorized the removal of all Japanese American residents from all the Alaska Territory and California, the western halves of Washington and Oregon, and Southern Arizona.

name: arizona
sentence: From 1942 to 1945, they were forced to reside in internment camps built in the interior of the country.

name: arizona
sentence: Many lost their homes and businesses.

name: arizona
sentence: The camps were abolished after World War II.

name: arizona
sentence: The Phoenix-area German P.O.W.

name: arizona
sentence: site was purchased after the war by the Maytag family (of major home appliance fame).

name: arizona
sentence: It was developed as the site of the Phoenix Zoo.

name: arizona
sentence: A Japanese-American internment camp was on Mount Lemmon, just outside the state's southeastern city of Tucson.

name: arizona
sentence: Another POW camp was near the Gila River in eastern Yuma County.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona was also home to the Phoenix Indian School, one of several federal Indian boarding schools designed to assimilate Native American children into mainstream European-American culture.

name: arizona
sentence: Children were often enrolled into these schools against the wishes of their parents and families.

name: arizona
sentence: Attempts to suppress native identities included forcing the children to cut their hair, to take and use English names, to speak only English, and to practice Christianity rather than their native religions.

name: arizona
sentence: Numerous Native Americans from Arizona fought for the United States during World War II.

name: arizona
sentence: Their experiences resulted in a rising activism in the postwar years to achieve better treatment and civil rights after their return to the state.

name: arizona
sentence: After Maricopa County did not allow them to register to vote, in 1948 veteran Frank Harrison and Harry Austin, of the Mojave-Apache Tribe at Fort McDowell Indian Reservation, brought a legal suit, Harrison and Austin v. Laveen, to challenge this exclusion.

name: arizona
sentence: The Arizona Supreme Court ruled in their favor.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona's population grew tremendously with residential and business development after World War II, aided by the widespread use of air conditioning, which made the intensely hot summers more comfortable.

name: arizona
sentence: According to the Arizona Blue Book (published by the Arizona Secretary of State's office each year), the state population in 1910 was 294,353.

name: arizona
sentence: The percentage growth each decade averaged about 20% in the earlier decades, and about 60% each decade thereafter.

name: arizona
sentence: In the 1960s, retirement communities were developed.

name: arizona
sentence: These age-restricted subdivisions catered exclusively to the needs of senior citizens and attracted many retirees who wanted to escape the harsh winters of the Midwest and the Northeast.

name: arizona
sentence: Sun City, established by developer Del Webb and opened in 1960, was one of the first such communities.

name: arizona
sentence: Green Valley, south of Tucson, was another such community, designed as a retirement subdivision for Arizona's teachers.

name: arizona
sentence: Many senior citizens from across the US and Canada come to Arizona each winter and stay only during the winter months

name: arizona
sentence: In March 2000, Arizona was the site of the first legally binding election ever held over the internet to nominate a candidate for public office.

name: arizona
sentence: In the 2000 Arizona Democratic Primary, under worldwide attention, Al Gore defeated Bill Bradley.

name: arizona
sentence: Voter turnout in this state primary increased more than 500% over the 1996 primary.

name: arizona
sentence: Three ships named USArizona have been christened in honor of the state, although only USArizona (BB-39) was so named after statehood was achieved.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona is in the Southwestern United States as one of the Four Corners states.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona is the sixth largest state by area, ranked after New Mexico and before Nevada.

name: arizona
sentence: Of the state's 113,998 square miles (295,000 km2), approximately 15% is privately owned.

name: arizona
sentence: The remaining area is public forest and park land, state trust land and Native American reservations.

name: arizona
sentence: There are 24 National Park Service maintained sites in Arizona, including the three national parks of Grand Canyon National Park, Saguaro National Park, and the Petrified Forest National Park.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona is well known for its desert Basin and Range region in the state's southern portions, which is rich in a landscape of xerophyte plants such as the cactus.

name: arizona
sentence: This region's topography was shaped by prehistoric volcanism, followed by the cooling-off and related subsidence.

name: arizona
sentence: Its climate has exceptionally hot summers and mild winters.

name: arizona
sentence: The state is less well known for its pine-covered north-central portion of the high country of the Colorado Plateau (see Arizona Mountains forests).

name: arizona
sentence: Like other states of the Southwest United States, Arizona has an abundance of mountains and plateaus.

name: arizona
sentence: Despite the state's aridity, 27% of Arizona is forest, a percentage comparable to modern-day Romania or Greece.

name: arizona
sentence: The world's largest stand of ponderosa pine trees is in Arizona.

name: arizona
sentence: The Mogollon Rim, a 1,998-foot (609 m) escarpment, cuts across the state's central section and marks the southwestern edge of the Colorado Plateau.

name: arizona
sentence: In 2002, this was an area of the Rodeo–Chediski Fire, the worst fire in state history until 2011.

name: arizona
sentence: Located in northern Arizona, the Grand Canyon is a colorful, deep, steep-sided gorge, carved by the Colorado River.

name: arizona
sentence: The canyon is one of the Seven Natural Wonders of the World and is largely contained in the Grand Canyon National Park—one of the first national parks in the United States.

name: arizona
sentence: President Theodore Roosevelt was a major proponent of designating the Grand Canyon area as a National Park, often visiting to hunt mountain lion and enjoy the scenery.

name: arizona
sentence: The canyon was created by the Colorado River cutting a channel over millions of years, and is about 277 miles (446 km) long, ranges in width from 4 to 18 miles (6 to 29 km) and attains a depth of more than 1 mile (1.6 km).

name: arizona
sentence: Nearly two billion years of the Earth's history have been exposed as the Colorado River and its tributaries cut through layer after layer of sediment as the Colorado Plateau uplifted.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona is home to one of the most well-preserved meteorite impact sites in the world.

name: arizona
sentence: Created around 50,000 years ago, the Barringer Meteorite Crater (better known simply as "Meteor Crater") is a gigantic hole in the middle of the high plains of the Colorado Plateau, about 25 miles (40 km) west of Winslow.

name: arizona
sentence: A rim of smashed and jumbled boulders, some of them the size of small houses, rises 150 feet (46 m) above the level of the surrounding plain.

name: arizona
sentence: The crater itself is nearly a mile (1.6 kilometers) wide and 570 feet (170 m) deep.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona is one of two US states (Hawaii being the other) that do not observe Daylight Saving Time.

name: arizona
sentence: (The large Navajo Nation in the state's northeastern region does.)

name: arizona
sentence: Generally, Arizona is at low risk of earthquakes, except for the southwestern portion which is at moderate risk due to its proximity to southern California.

name: arizona
sentence: On the other hand, northern Arizona is at moderate risk due to numerous faults in the area.

name: arizona
sentence: The regions near and west of Phoenix have the lowest risk.

name: arizona
sentence: The earliest Arizona earthquakes were recorded at Fort Yuma, on the California side of the Colorado River.

name: arizona
sentence: They were centered near the Imperial Valley, or Mexico, back in the 1800s.

name: arizona
sentence: Residents in Douglas felt the 1887 Sonora earthquake with its epicenter 40 miles (64 km) to the south in the Mexican state of Sonora.

name: arizona
sentence: The first damaging earthquake known to be centered within Arizona occurred on January 25, 1906, also including a series of other earthquakes centered near Socorro, New Mexico.

name: arizona
sentence: The shock was violent in Flagstaff.

name: arizona
sentence: In September 1910, a series of 52 earthquakes caused a construction crew near Flagstaff to leave the area.

name: arizona
sentence: In 1912, the year Arizona achieved statehood, on August 18, an earthquake caused a 50-mile crack in the San Francisco Range.

name: arizona
sentence: In early January 1935, the state experienced a series of earthquakes, in the Yuma area and near the Grand Canyon.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona experienced its largest earthquake in 1959, with a tremor of a magnitude 5.6.

name: arizona
sentence: It was centered near Fredonia, in the state's northwest near the border with Utah.

name: arizona
sentence: The tremor was felt across the border in Nevada and Utah.

name: arizona
sentence: Due to its large area and variations in elevation, the state has a wide variety of localized climate conditions.

name: arizona
sentence: In the lower elevations, the climate is primarily desert, with mild winters and extremely hot summers.

name: arizona
sentence: Typically, from late fall to early spring, the weather is mild, averaging a minimum of 60 °F (16 °C).

name: arizona
sentence: November through February are the coldest months, with temperatures typically ranging from 40 to 75 °F (4 to 24 °C), with occasional frosts.

name: arizona
sentence: About midway through February, the temperatures start to rise, with warm days, and cool, breezy nights.

name: arizona
sentence: The summer months of June through September bring a dry heat from 90 to 120 °F (32 to 49 °C), with occasional high temperatures exceeding 125 °F (52 °C) having been observed in the desert area.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona's all-time record high is 128 °F (53 °C) recorded at Lake Havasu City on June 29, 1994, and July 5, 2007; the all-time record low of −40 °F (−40 °C) was recorded at Hawley Lake on January 7, 1971.

name: arizona
sentence: Due to the primarily dry climate, large diurnal temperature variations occur in less-developed areas of the desert above 2,500 ft (760 m).

name: arizona
sentence: The swings can be as large as 83 °F (46 °C) in the summer months.

name: arizona
sentence: In the state's urban centers, the effects of local warming result in much higher measured night-time lows than in the recent past.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona has an average annual rainfall of 12.7 in (323 mm), which comes during two rainy seasons, with cold fronts coming from the Pacific Ocean during the winter and a monsoon in the summer.

name: arizona
sentence: The monsoon season occurs toward the end of summer.

name: arizona
sentence: In July or August, the dewpoint rises dramatically for a brief period.

name: arizona
sentence: During this time, the air contains large amounts of water vapor.

name: arizona
sentence: Dewpoints as high as 81 °F (27 °C) have been recorded during the Phoenix monsoon season.

name: arizona
sentence: This hot moisture brings lightning, thunderstorms, wind, and torrential, if usually brief, downpours.

name: arizona
sentence: These downpours often cause flash floods, which can turn deadly.

name: arizona
sentence: In an attempt to deter drivers from crossing flooding streams, the Arizona Legislature enacted the Stupid Motorist Law.

name: arizona
sentence: It is rare for tornadoes or hurricanes to occur in Arizona.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona's northern third is a plateau at significantly higher altitudes than the lower desert, and has an appreciably cooler climate, with cold winters and mild summers, though the climate remains semiarid to arid.

name: arizona
sentence: Extremely cold temperatures are not unknown; cold air systems from the northern states and Canada occasionally push into the state, bringing temperatures below 0 °F (−18 °C) to the state's northern parts.

name: arizona
sentence: Indicative of the variation in climate, Arizona is the state which has both the metropolitan area with the most days over 100 °F (38 °C) (Phoenix), and the metropolitan area in the lower 48 states with the most days with a low temperature below freezing (Flagstaff).

name: arizona
sentence: The United States Census Bureau estimates Arizona's population was 7,278,717 on July 1, 2019, a 13.87% increase since the 2010 United States Census.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona remained sparsely settled for most of the 19th century.

name: arizona
sentence: The 1860 census reported the population of "Arizona County" to be 6,482, of whom 4,040 were listed as "Indians", 21 as "free colored", and 2,421 as "white".

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona's continued population growth puts an enormous stress on the state's water supply.

name: arizona
sentence: As of 2011, 61.3% of Arizona's children under age one belonged to racial groups of color.

name: arizona
sentence: The population of metropolitan Phoenix increased by 45.3% from 1991 through 2001, helping to make Arizona the second fastest-growing state in the US in the 1990s (the fastest was Nevada).

name: arizona
sentence: As of July 2018, the population of the Phoenix area is estimated to be over 4.9 million.

name: arizona
sentence: According to the 2010 United States Census, Arizona had a population of 6,392,017.

name: arizona
sentence: In 2010, illegal immigrants constituted an estimated 7.9% of the population.

name: arizona
sentence: This was the second highest percentage of any state in the US Arizona has banned sanctuary cities.

name: arizona
sentence: Metropolitan Phoenix (4.7 million) and Tucson (1.0 million) are home to about five-sixths of Arizona's people (as of the 2010 census).

name: arizona
sentence: Metro Phoenix alone accounts for two-thirds of the state's population.

name: arizona
sentence: In 1980, the Census Bureau reported Arizona's population as 16.2% Hispanic, 5.6% Native American, and 74.5% non-Hispanic white.

name: arizona
sentence: In 2010, the racial makeup of the state was:

name: arizona
sentence: Hispanics or Latinos of any race made up 29.6% of the state's population.

name: arizona
sentence: Non-Hispanic whites formed 57.8% of the total population.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona's five largest ancestry groups, as of 2009, were:

name: arizona
sentence: As of 2010, 72.9% (4,215,749) of Arizona residents age five and older spoke only English at home, while 20.8% (1,202,638) spoke Spanish, 1.5% (85,602) Navajo, 0.4% (22,592) German, 0.4% (22,426) Chinese (which includes Mandarin), 0.3% (19,015) Tagalog, 0.3% (17,603) Vietnamese, 0.3% (15,707) Other North American Indigenous Languages (especially indigenous languages of Arizona), and French was spoken as a main language by 0.3% (15,062) of the population over the age of five.

name: arizona
sentence: In total, 27.1% (1,567,548) of Arizona's population age five and older spoke a mother language other than English.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona is home to the largest number of speakers of Native American languages in the 48 contiguous states, as more than 85,000 individuals reported speaking Navajo, and 10,403 people reported Apache, as a language spoken at home in 2005.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona's Apache County has the highest concentration of speakers of Native American Indian languages in the United States.

name: arizona
sentence: Phoenix, in Maricopa County, is Arizona's capital and largest city.

name: arizona
sentence: Other prominent cities in the Phoenix metro area include Mesa (Arizona's third largest city), Chandler (Arizona's fourth largest city), Glendale, Peoria, Buckeye, Sun City, Sun City West, Fountain Hills, Surprise, Gilbert, El Mirage, Avondale, Tempe, Tolleson and Scottsdale, with a total metropolitan population of just over 4.7 million.

name: arizona
sentence: The average high temperature in July, 106 °F (41 °C), is one of the highest of any metropolitan area in the United States, offset by an average January high temperature of 67 °F (19 °C), the basis of its winter appeal.

name: arizona
sentence: Tucson, with a metro population of just over one million, is the state's second-largest city.

name: arizona
sentence: Located in Pima County, approximately 110 miles (180 km) southeast of Phoenix, it was incorporated in 1877, making it the oldest incorporated city in Arizona.

name: arizona
sentence: It is home to the University of Arizona.

name: arizona
sentence: Major incorporated suburbs of Tucson include Oro Valley and Marana northwest of the city, Sahuarita south of the city, and South Tucson in an enclave south of downtown.

name: arizona
sentence: It has an average July temperature of 100 °F (38 °C) and winter temperatures averaging 65 °F (18 °C).

name: arizona
sentence: Saguaro National Park, just west of the city in the Tucson Mountains, is the site of the world's largest collection of Saguaro cacti.

name: arizona
sentence: The Prescott metropolitan area includes the cities of Prescott, Cottonwood, Camp Verde and many other towns in the 8,123 square miles (21,000 km2) of Yavapai County area.

name: arizona
sentence: With 212,635 residents, this cluster of towns is the state's third largest metropolitan area.

name: arizona
sentence: The city of Prescott (population 41,528) lies approximately 100 miles (160 km) northwest of the Phoenix metropolitan area.

name: arizona
sentence: Situated in pine tree forests at an elevation of about 5,500 feet (1,700 m), Prescott enjoys a much cooler climate than Phoenix, with average summer highs around 88 °F (31 °C) and winter temperatures averaging 50 °F (10 °C).

name: arizona
sentence: Yuma is center of the fourth-largest metropolitan area in Arizona.

name: arizona
sentence: Located in Yuma County, it is near the borders of California and Mexico.

name: arizona
sentence: It is one of the hottest cities in the United States, with an average July high of 107 °F (42 °C).

name: arizona
sentence: (The same month's average in Death Valley is 115 °F (46 °C).)

name: arizona
sentence: The city features sunny days about 90% of the year.

name: arizona
sentence: The Yuma Metropolitan Statistical Area has a population of 160,000.

name: arizona
sentence: Yuma attracts many winter visitors from all over the United States.

name: arizona
sentence: Flagstaff, in Coconino County, is the largest city in northern Arizona, and is at an elevation of nearly 7,000 feet (2,100 m).

name: arizona
sentence: With its large Ponderosa pine forests, snowy winter weather and picturesque mountains, it is a stark contrast to the desert regions typically associated with Arizona.

name: arizona
sentence: It is sited at the base of the San Francisco Peaks, the highest mountain range in the state of Arizona, which contain Humphreys Peak, the highest point in Arizona at 12,633 feet (3,851 m).

name: arizona
sentence: Flagstaff has a strong tourism sector, due to its proximity to numerous tourist attractions including: Grand Canyon National Park, Sedona, and Oak Creek Canyon.

name: arizona
sentence: Historic US Route 66 is the main east–west street in the town.

name: arizona
sentence: The Flagstaff metropolitan area is home to 134,421 residents and the main campus of Northern Arizona University.

name: arizona
sentence: Lake Havasu City, in Mohave County, known as "Arizona's playground", was developed on the Colorado River and is named after Lake Havasu.

name: arizona
sentence: Lake Havasu City has a population of about 53,000 people.

name: arizona
sentence: It is famous for huge spring break parties, sunsets and the London Bridge, relocated from London, England.

name: arizona
sentence: Lake Havasu City was founded by real estate developer Robert P. McCulloch in 1963.

name: arizona
sentence: It has two colleges, Mohave Community College and ASU Colleges in Lake Havasu City.

name: arizona
sentence: In 2010, the Association of Religion Data Archives reported that the three largest denominational groups in Arizona were the Catholic Church, The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints and non-denominational Evangelical Protestants.

name: arizona
sentence: The Catholic Church has the highest number of adherents in Arizona (at 930,001), followed by The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints with 410,263 members reported and then non-denominational Evangelical Protestants, reporting 281,105 adherents.

name: arizona
sentence: The religious body with the largest number of congregations is The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (with 836 congregations) followed by the Southern Baptist Convention (with 323 congregations).

name: arizona
sentence: According to the Association of Religion Data Archives, the fifteen largest denominations by number of adherents in 2010 and 2000 were:

name: arizona
sentence: Hinduism became the largest non-Christian religion (when combining all denominations) in 2010 with more than 32,000 adherents, followed by Judaism with more than 20,000 and Buddhism with more than 19,000.

name: arizona
sentence: The 2011 total gross state product was $259 billion.

name: arizona
sentence: This figure gives Arizona a larger economy than such countries as Ireland, Finland, and New Zealand.

name: arizona
sentence: The composition of the state's economy is moderately diverse; although health care, transportation and the government remain the largest sectors.

name: arizona
sentence: The state's per capita income is $40,828, ranking 39th in the US

name: arizona
sentence: The state had a median household income of $50,448, making it 22nd in the country and just below the US national mean.

name: arizona
sentence: Early in its history, Arizona's economy relied on the "five C's": copper (see Copper mining in Arizona), cotton, cattle, citrus, and climate (tourism).

name: arizona
sentence: Copper is still extensively mined from many expansive open-pit and underground mines, accounting for two-thirds of the nation's output.

name: arizona
sentence: The state government is Arizona's largest employer, while Banner Health is the state's largest private employer, with more than 39,000 employees (2016).

name: arizona
sentence: As of August 2020, the state's unemployment rate was 5.9%.

name: arizona
sentence: The largest employment sectors in Arizona are (August 2020, Nonfarm Employment):

name: arizona
sentence: According to The Arizona Republic, the largest private employers in the state as of 2019 were:

name: arizona
sentence: Tax is collected by the Arizona Department of Revenue.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona collects personal income taxes in five brackets: 2.59%, 2.88%, 3.36%, 4.24% and 4.54%.

name: arizona
sentence: The state transaction privilege tax is 5.6%; however, county and municipal sales taxes generally add an additional 2%.

name: arizona
sentence: In 2020, Arizona voters approved Proposition 208 to create an additional income tax bracket of 8% for incomes over $250,000 (single filers) and $500,000 (joint filers).

name: arizona
sentence: However, the law is currently pending as Goldwater Institute filed a lawsuit challenging it.

name: arizona
sentence: The state rate on transient lodging (hotel/motel) is 7.27%.

name: arizona
sentence: The state of Arizona does not levy a state tax on food for home consumption or on drugs prescribed by a licensed physician or dentist.

name: arizona
sentence: However, some cities in Arizona do levy a tax on food for home consumption.

name: arizona
sentence: All fifteen Arizona counties levy a tax.

name: arizona
sentence: Incorporated municipalities also levy transaction privilege taxes which, with the exception of their hotel/motel tax, are generally in the range of 1-to-3%.

name: arizona
sentence: These added assessments could push the combined sales tax rate to as high as 10.7%.

name: arizona
sentence: US 60 | US 64 | Historic US 66 | US 70 | Historic US 80 | US 89 | US 89A | US 91 | US 93 | US 95 | US 160 | US 163 | US 180 | US 191

name: arizona
sentence: Main Interstate routes include I-17, and I-19 traveling north–south, I-8, I-10, and I-40, traveling east–west, and a short stretch of I-15 traveling northeast–southwest through the extreme northwestern corner of the state.

name: arizona
sentence: In addition, the various urban areas are served by complex networks of state routes and highways, such as the Loop 101, which is part of Phoenix's vast freeway system.

name: arizona
sentence: The Phoenix and Tucson metropolitan areas are served by public bus transit systems.

name: arizona
sentence: Yuma and Flagstaff also have public bus systems.

name: arizona
sentence: Greyhound Lines serves Phoenix, Tucson, Flagstaff, Yuma, and several smaller communities statewide.

name: arizona
sentence: A light rail system, called Valley Metro Rail, was completed in December 2008; it connects Central Phoenix with the nearby cities of Mesa and Tempe.

name: arizona
sentence: In Tucson, the Sun Link streetcar system travels through the downtown area, connecting the main University of Arizona campus with Mercado San Agustin on the western edge of downtown Tucson.

name: arizona
sentence: Sun Link, loosely based on the Portland Streetcar, launched in July 2014.

name: arizona
sentence: Amtrak Southwest Chief route serves the northern part of the state, stopping at Winslow, Flagstaff, Williams and Kingman.

name: arizona
sentence: The Texas Eagle and Sunset Limited routes serve South-Central Arizona, stopping at Tucson, Maricopa, Yuma and Benson.

name: arizona
sentence: Phoenix lost Amtrak service in 1996 with the discontinuation of the Desert Wind, and now an Amtrak bus runs between Phoenix and the station in Maricopa.

name: arizona
sentence: Airports with regularly scheduled commercial flights include: Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport (IATA: PHX, ICAO: KPHX) in Phoenix (the state's largest airport and the major international airport); Tucson International Airport (IATA: TUS, ICAO: KTUS) in Tucson; Phoenix-Mesa Gateway Airport (IATA: AZA, ICAO: KIWA) in Mesa; Yuma International Airport (IATA: NYL, ICAO: KNYL) in Yuma; Prescott Municipal Airport (PRC) in Prescott; Flagstaff Pulliam Airport (IATA: FLG, ICAO: KFLG) in Flagstaff, and Grand Canyon National Park Airport (IATA: GCN, ICAO: KGCN, FAA: GCN), a small, but busy, single-runway facility providing tourist flights, mostly from Las Vegas.

name: arizona
sentence: Phoenix Sky Harbor is the world's 7th busiest airport in terms of aircraft movements and 17th for passenger traffic.

name: arizona
sentence: Other significant airports without regularly scheduled commercial flights include Scottsdale Municipal Airport (IATA: SCF, ICAO: KSDL) in Scottsdale, and Deer Valley Airport (IATA: DVT, ICAO: KDVT, FAA: DVT) home to two flight training academies and the nation's busiest general aviation airport.

name: arizona
sentence: The capital of Arizona is Phoenix.

name: arizona
sentence: The original Capitol building, with its distinctive copper dome, was dedicated in 1901 (construction was completed for $136,000 in 1900), when the area was a territory.

name: arizona
sentence: Phoenix became the official state capital with Arizona's admission to the union in 1912.

name: arizona
sentence: The House of Representatives and Senatorte buildings were dedicated in 1960, and an Executive Office Building was dedicated in 1974 (the ninth floor of this building is where the Office of the Governor is located).

name: arizona
sentence: The original Capitol building was converted into a museum.

name: arizona
sentence: The Capitol complex is fronted and highlighted by the richly landscaped Wesley Bolin Memorial Plaza, named after Wesley Bolin, a governor who died in office in the 1970s.

name: arizona
sentence: The site also includes many monuments and memorials, including the anchor and signal mast from the USArizona (one of the US Navy ships sunk in Pearl Harbor) and a granite version of the Ten Commandments.

name: arizona
sentence: The Arizona Legislature is bicameral (like the legislature of every other state except Nebraska) and consists of a thirty-member Senatorte and a 60-member House of Representatives.

name: arizona
sentence: Each of the thirty legislative districts has one senator and two representatives.

name: arizona
sentence: Legislators are elected for two-year terms.

name: arizona
sentence: Each Legislature covers a two-year period.

name: arizona
sentence: The first session following the general election is known as the first regular session, and the session convening in the second year is known as the second regular session.

name: arizona
sentence: Each regular session begins on the second Monday in January and adjourns sine die (terminates for the year) no later than Saturday of the week in which the 100th day from the beginning of the regular session falls.

name: arizona
sentence: The President of the Senatorte and Speaker of the House, by rule, may extend the session up to seven additional days.

name: arizona
sentence: Thereafter, the session can be extended only by a majority vote of members present of each house.

name: arizona
sentence: The majority party is the Republican Party, which has held power in both houses since 1993.

name: arizona
sentence: The Democratic Party picked up several legislative seats in Arizona State House bringing Democratic Leader Charlene Fernandez one seat shy of a majority (31 to 29).

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona state senators and representatives are elected for two-year terms and are limited to four consecutive terms in a chamber, though there is no limit on the total number of terms.

name: arizona
sentence: When a lawmaker is term-limited from office, it is common for him or her to run for election in the other chamber.

name: arizona
sentence: The fiscal year 2006–07 general fund budget, approved by the Arizona Legislature in June 2006, was slightly less than $10 billion.

name: arizona
sentence: Besides the money spent on state agencies, it also included more than $500 million in income and property tax cuts, pay raises for government employees, and additional funding for the K–12 education system.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona's executive branch is headed by a governor, who is elected to a four-year term.

name: arizona
sentence: The governor may serve any number of terms, though no more than two in a row.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona is one of the few states that has no governor's mansion.

name: arizona
sentence: During their term the governors reside within their private residence, with executive offices housed in the executive tower at the state capitol.

name: arizona
sentence: The governor of Arizona is Doug Ducey (R).

name: arizona
sentence: Governor Jan Brewer assumed office in 2009 after Janet Napolitano had her nomination by Barack Obama for Secretary of Homeland Security confirmed by the United States Senatorte.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona has had four female governors, more than any other state.

name: arizona
sentence: Other elected executive officials include the Secretary of State, State Treasurer, State Attorney General, Superintendent of Public Instruction, State Mine Inspector and a five-member Corporation Commission.

name: arizona
sentence: All elected officials hold a term of four years, and are limited to two consecutive terms (except the office of the State Mine Inspector, which is limited to four terms).

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona is one of five states that do not have a lieutenant governor.

name: arizona
sentence: The elected secretary of state is first in line to succeed the governor in the event of death, disability, resignation, or removal from office.

name: arizona
sentence: If appointed, the Secretary of State is not eligible and the next governor is selected from the next eligible official in the line of succession, including the attorney general, state treasurer and superintendent of public instruction.

name: arizona
sentence: Since 1977, four secretaries of state and one attorney general have succeeded to Arizona's governorship.

name: arizona
sentence: The Arizona Supreme Court is the highest court in Arizona, consisting of a chief justice, a vice chief justice, and five associate justices.

name: arizona
sentence: Justices are appointed by the governor from a list recommended by a bipartisan commission, and must be sustained in office by election after the first two years following their appointment.

name: arizona
sentence: Subsequent sustaining elections occur every six years.

name: arizona
sentence: The supreme court has appellate jurisdiction in death penalty cases, but nearly all other appellate cases go through the Arizona Court of Appeals first.

name: arizona
sentence: The court has original jurisdiction in a few other circumstances, as outlined in the state constitution.

name: arizona
sentence: The court may declare laws unconstitutional if seated en banc.

name: arizona
sentence: The court meets in the Arizona Supreme Court Building at the capitol complex (at the southern end of Wesley Bolin Plaza).

name: arizona
sentence: The Arizona Court of Appeals, subdivided into two divisions, is the intermediate court in the state.

name: arizona
sentence: Division One is based in Phoenix, consists of sixteen judges, and has jurisdiction in the Western and Northern regions of the state, along with the greater Phoenix area.

name: arizona
sentence: Division Two is based in Tucson, consists of six judges, and has jurisdiction over the Southern regions of the state, including the Tucson area.

name: arizona
sentence: Judges are selected in a method similar to the one used for state supreme court justices.

name: arizona
sentence: Each county of Arizona has a superior court, the size and organization of which are varied and generally depend on the size of the particular county.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona is divided into 15 counties, ranging in size from 1,238 square miles (3,210 km2) to 18,661 square miles (48,330 km2).

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona's two United States Senatortors are Kyrsten Sinema (D) and Mark Kelly (D).

name: arizona
sentence: Kelly succeeded Martha McSally who was appointed by Governor Doug Ducey following the resignation of Jon Kyl who himself was appointed by Ducey after the death of John McCain in late 2018.

name: arizona
