name: kansas
sentence: At the same time, the Chisholm Trail was opened and the Wild West-era commenced in Kansas.

name: kansas
sentence: Wild Bill Hickok was a deputy marshal at Fort Riley and a marshal at Hays and Abilene.

name: kansas
sentence: Dodge City was another wild cowboy town, and both Bat Masterson and Wyatt Earp worked as lawmen in the town.

name: kansas
sentence: In one year alone, eight million head of cattle from Texas boarded trains in Dodge City bound for the East, earning Dodge the nickname "Queen of the Cowtowns".

name: kansas
sentence: In response to demands of Methodists and other evangelical Protestants, in 1881 Kansas became the first US state to adopt a constitutional amendment prohibiting all alcoholic beverages, which was repealed in 1948.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas is bordered by Nebraska to the north

name: kansas
sentence: The state is divided into 105 counties with 628 cities, with its largest county by area being Butler County.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas is located equidistant from the Pacific and Atlantic oceans.

name: kansas
sentence: The geographic center of the 48 contiguous states is in Smith County near Lebanon.

name: kansas
sentence: Until 1989, the Meades Ranch Triangulation Station in Osborne County was the geodetic center of North America: the central reference point for all maps of North America.

name: kansas
sentence: The geographic center of Kansas is in Barton County.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas is underlain by a sequence of horizontal to gently westward dipping sedimentary rocks.

name: kansas
sentence: A sequence of Mississippian, Pennsylvanian and Permian rocks outcrop in the eastern and southern part of the state.

name: kansas
sentence: The state's western half has exposures of Cretaceous through Tertiary sediments, the latter derived from the erosion of the uplifted Rocky Mountains to the west.

name: kansas
sentence: These are underlain by older Paleozoic and Mesozoic sediments which correlate well with the outcrops to the east.

name: kansas
sentence: The state's northeastern corner was subjected to glaciation in the Pleistocene and is covered by glacial drift and loess.

name: kansas
sentence: The western two-thirds of the state, lying in the great central plain of the United States, has a generally flat or undulating surface, while the eastern third has many hills and forests.

name: kansas
sentence: The land gradually rises from east to west; its altitude ranges from 684 ft (208 m) along the Verdigris River at Coffeyville in Montgomery County, to 4,039 ft (1,231 m) at Mount Sunflower, 0.5 miles (0.80 kilometers) from the Colorado border, in Wallace County.

name: kansas
sentence: It is a common misconception that Kansas is the flattest state in the nation—in 2003, a tongue-in-cheek study famously declared the state "flatter than a pancake".

name: kansas
sentence: In fact, Kansas has a maximum topographic relief of 3,360 ft (1,020 m), making it the 23rd flattest US state measured by maximum relief.

name: kansas
sentence: Nearly 75 mi (121 km) of the state's northeastern boundary is defined by the Missouri River.

name: kansas
sentence: The Kansas River (locally known as the Kaw), formed by the junction of the Smoky Hill and Republican rivers at appropriately-named Junction City, joins the Missouri River at Kansas City, after a course of 170 mi (270 km) across the northeastern part of the state.

name: kansas
sentence: The Arkansas River (pronunciation varies), rising in Colorado, flows with a bending course for nearly 500 mi (800 km) across the western and southern parts of the state.

name: kansas
sentence: With its tributaries, (the Little Arkansas, Ninnescah, Walnut, Cow Creek, Cimarron, Verdigris, and the Neosho), it forms the southern drainage system of the state.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas's other rivers are the Saline and Solomon Rivers, tributaries of the Smoky Hill River; the Big Blue, Delaware, and Wakarusa, which flow into the Kansas River; and the Marais des Cygnes, a tributary of the Missouri River.

name: kansas
sentence: Spring River is located between Riverton and Baxter Springs.

name: kansas
sentence: Areas under the protection of the National Park Service include:

name: kansas
sentence: According to the Köppen climate classification, Kansas's climate can be characterized in terms of three types: it has humid continental, semi-arid steppe, and humid subtropical.

name: kansas
sentence: The eastern two-thirds of the state (especially the northeastern portion) has a humid continental climate, with cool to cold winters and hot, often humid summers.

name: kansas
sentence: Most of the precipitation falls during both the summer and the spring.

name: kansas
sentence: The western third of the state—from roughly the US Route 83 corridor westward—has a semi-arid steppe climate.

name: kansas
sentence: Summers are hot, often very hot, and generally less humid.

name: kansas
sentence: Winters are highly changeable between warm and very cold.

name: kansas
sentence: The western region receives an average of about 16 inches (410 millimeters) of precipitation per year.

name: kansas
sentence: Chinook winds in the winter can warm western Kansas all the way into the 80 degrees Fahrenheit (27 degrees Celsius) range.

name: kansas
sentence: The far south-central and southeastern portions of the state, including the Wichita area, have a humid subtropical climate with hot and humid summers, milder winters, and more precipitation than elsewhere in Kansas.

name: kansas
sentence: Some features of all three climates can be found in most of the state, with droughts and changeable weather between dry and humid not uncommon, and both warm and cold spells in the winter.

name: kansas
sentence: Temperatures in areas between US

name: kansas
sentence: Routes 83 and 81, as well as the southwestern portion of the state along and south of US 50, reach 90 °F (32 °C) or above on most days of June, July, and August.

name: kansas
sentence: High humidity added to the high temperatures sends the heat index into life-threatening territory, especially in Wichita, Hutchinson, Salina, Russell, Hays, and Great Bend.

name: kansas
sentence: Temperatures are often higher in Dodge City, Garden City, and Liberal, but the heat index in those three cities is usually lower than the actual air temperature.

name: kansas
sentence: Although temperatures of 100 °F (38 °C) or higher are not as common in areas east of US 81, higher humidity and the urban heat island effect lead most summer days to heat indices between 107 °F (42 °C) and 114 °F (46 °C) in Topeka, Lawrence, and the Kansas City metropolitan area.

name: kansas
sentence: During the summer, nightly low temperatures in the northeastern part of the state, especially in the aforementioned large cities, struggle to fall below 80 °F (27 °C).

name: kansas
sentence: Also, combined with humidity between 85 and 95 percent, dangerous heat indices can be experienced at every hour of the day.

name: kansas
sentence: Precipitation ranges from about 47 inches (1,200 mm) annually in the state's southeast corner to about 16 inches (410 mm) in the southwest.

name: kansas
sentence: Snowfall ranges from around 5 inches (130 mm) in the fringes of the south, to 35 inches (890 mm) in the far northwest.

name: kansas
sentence: Frost-free days range from more than 200 days in the south, to 130 days in the northwest.

name: kansas
sentence: Thus, Kansas is the country's ninth or tenth sunniest state, depending on the source.

name: kansas
sentence: Western Kansas is as sunny as parts of California and Arizona.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas is prone to severe weather, especially in the spring and the early-summer.

name: kansas
sentence: Despite the frequent sunshine throughout much of the state, due to its location at a climatic boundary prone to intrusions of multiple air masses, the state is vulnerable to strong and severe thunderstorms.

name: kansas
sentence: Some of these storms become supercell thunderstorms; these can produce some tornadoes, occasionally those of EF3 strength or higher.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas averages more than 50 tornadoes annually.

name: kansas
sentence: Severe thunderstorms sometimes drop some very large hail over Kansas as well.

name: kansas
sentence: Furthermore, these storms can even bring in flash flooding and damaging straight line winds.

name: kansas
sentence: According to NOAA, the all-time highest temperature recorded in Kansas is (121 °F or 49.4 °C) on July 24, 1936, near Alton in Osborne County, and the all-time low is −40 °F (−40 °C) on February 13, 1905, near Lebanon in Smith County.

name: kansas
sentence: Alton and Lebanon are approximately 50 miles (80 km) apart.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas's record high of 121 °F (49.4 °C) ties with North Dakota for the fifth-highest record high in an American state, behind California (134 °F or 56.7 °C), Arizona (128 °F or 53.3 °C), Nevada (125 °F or 51.7 °C), and New Mexico (122 °F or 50 °C).

name: kansas
sentence: The United States Census Bureau estimates that the population of Kansas was 2,913,314 on July 1, 2019, a 2.11% increase since the 2010 United States Census and an increase of 58,387, or 2.05%, since 2010.

name: kansas
sentence: This includes a natural increase since the last census of 93,899 (246,484 births minus 152,585 deaths) and a decrease due to net migration of 20,742 people out of the state.

name: kansas
sentence: Immigration from outside the United States resulted in a net increase of 44,847 people, and migration within the country produced a net loss of 65,589 people.

name: kansas
sentence: The population density of Kansas is 52.9 people per square mile.

name: kansas
sentence: The center of population of Kansas is located in Chase County, at 38°27′N 96°32′W, approximately 3 miles (4.8 km) north of the community of Strong City.

name: kansas
sentence: The focus on labor-efficient grain-based agriculture—such as a large wheat farm that requires only one or a few people with large machinery to operate, rather than a vegetable farm that requires many people—is causing the de-population of rural areas across Kansas.

name: kansas
sentence: According to the 2010 United States Census, the racial makeup of the population was:

name: kansas
sentence: Ethnically 10.5% of the total population was of Hispanic or Latino origin (they may be of any race).

name: kansas
sentence: As of 2004, the population included 149,800 foreign-born (5.5% of the state population).

name: kansas
sentence: The ten largest reported ancestry groups, which account for nearly 90% of the population, in the state are: German (33.75%), Irish (14.4%), English (14.1%), American (7.5%), French (4.4%), Scottish (4.2%), Dutch (2.5%), Swedish (2.4%), Italian (1.8%), and Polish (1.5%).

name: kansas
sentence: German descendants are especially present in the northwest, while those of descendants of English and of white Americans from other states are especially present in the southeast.

name: kansas
sentence: Mexicans are present in the southwest and make up nearly half the population in certain counties.

name: kansas
sentence: Many African Americans in Kansas are descended from the Exodusters, newly freed blacks who fled the South for land in Kansas following the Civil War.

name: kansas
sentence: As of 2011, 35.0% of Kansas's population younger than one year of age belonged to minority groups (i.e., did not have two parents of non-Hispanic white ancestry).

name: kansas
sentence: English is the most-spoken language in Kansas, with 91.3% of the population speaking only English at home as of the year 2000.

name: kansas
sentence: 5.5% speak Spanish, 0.7% speak German, and 0.4% speak Vietnamese.

name: kansas
sentence: The 2014 Pew Religious Landscape Survey showed the religious makeup of adults in Kansas was as follows:

name: kansas
sentence: As of 2010, the Association of Religion Data Archives (ARDA) reported that the Catholic Church has the highest number of adherents in Kansas (at 426,611), followed by the United Methodist Church with 202,989 members, and the Southern Baptist Convention, reporting 99,329 adherents.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas's capital Topeka is sometimes cited as the home of Pentecostalism as it was the site of Charles Fox Parham's Bethel Bible College, where glossolalia was first claimed as the evidence of a spiritual experience referred to as the baptism of the Holy Spirit in 1901.

name: kansas
sentence: It is also the home of Reverend Charles Sheldon, author of In His Steps, and was the site where the question "What would Jesus do?"

name: kansas
sentence: originated in a sermon of Sheldon's at Central Congregational Church.

name: kansas
sentence: Topeka is also home of the Westboro Baptist Church, a hate group according to the Southern Poverty Law Center.

name: kansas
sentence: The church has garnered worldwide media attention for picketing the funerals of US servicemen and women for what church members claim as "necessary to combat the fight for equality for gays and lesbians".

name: kansas
sentence: They have sometimes successfully raised lawsuits against the city of Topeka.

name: kansas
sentence: Known as rural flight, the last few decades have been marked by a migratory pattern out of the countryside into cities.

name: kansas
sentence: Out of all the cities in these Midwestern states, 89% have fewer than 3,000 people, and hundreds of those have fewer than 1,000.

name: kansas
sentence: In Kansas alone, there are more than 6,000 ghost towns and dwindling communities, according to one Kansas historian, Daniel C. Fitzgerald.

name: kansas
sentence: At the same time, some of the communities in Johnson County (metropolitan Kansas City) are among the fastest-growing in the country.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas has 627 incorporated cities.

name: kansas
sentence: By state statute, cities are divided into three classes as determined by the population obtained "by any census of enumeration".

name: kansas
sentence: A city of the third class has a population of less than 5,000, but cities reaching a population of more than 2,000 may be certified as a city of the second class.

name: kansas
sentence: The second class is limited to cities with a population of less than 25,000, and upon reaching a population of more than 15,000, they may be certified as a city of the first class.

name: kansas
sentence: First and second class cities are independent of any township and are not included within the township's territory.

name: kansas
sentence: Note: Births in table don't add up, because Hispanics are counted both by their ethnicity and by their race, giving a higher overall number.

name: kansas
sentence: The northeastern portion of the state, extending from the eastern border to Junction City and from the Nebraska border to south of Johnson County is home to more than 1.5 million people in the Kansas City (Kansas portion), Manhattan, Lawrence, and Topeka metropolitan areas.

name: kansas
sentence: Overland Park, a young city incorporated in 1960, has the largest population and the largest land area in the county.

name: kansas
sentence: It is home to Johnson County Community College and the corporate campus of Sprint Nextel, the largest private employer in the metro area.

name: kansas
sentence: In 2006, the city was ranked as the sixth best place to live in America; the neighboring city of Olathe was 13th.

name: kansas
sentence: Olathe is the county seat and home to Johnson County Executive Airport.

name: kansas
sentence: The cities of Olathe, Shawnee, De Soto and Gardner have some of the state's fastest growing populations.

name: kansas
sentence: The cities of Overland Park, Lenexa, Olathe, De Soto, and Gardner are also notable because they lie along the former route of the Santa Fe Trail.

name: kansas
sentence: Among cities with at least one thousand residents, Mission Hills has the highest median income in the state.

name: kansas
sentence: Several institutions of higher education are located in Northeast Kansas including Baker University (the oldest university in the state, founded in 1858 and affiliated with the United Methodist Church) in Baldwin City, Benedictine College (sponsored by St. Benedict's Abbey and Mount St. Scholastica Monastery and formed from the merger of St. Benedict's College (1858) and Mount St. Scholastica College (1923)) in Atchison, MidAmerica Nazarene University in Olathe, Ottawa University in Ottawa and Overland Park, Kansas City Kansas Community College and KU Medical Center in Kansas City, and KU Edwards Campus in Overland Park.

name: kansas
sentence: Less than an hour's drive to the west, Lawrence is home to the University of Kansas, the largest public university in the state, and Haskell Indian Nations University.

name: kansas
sentence: To the north, Kansas City, with the second largest land area in the state, contains a number of diverse ethnic neighborhoods.

name: kansas
sentence: Its attractions include the Kansas Speedway, Sporting Kansas City, Kansas City T-Bones, Schlitterbahn, and The Legends at Village West retail and entertainment center.

name: kansas
sentence: Nearby, Kansas's first settlement Bonner Springs is home to several national and regional attractions including the Providence Medical Center Amphitheather, the National Agricultural Center and Hall of Fame, and the annual Kansas City Renaissance Festival.

name: kansas
sentence: Further up the Missouri River, the city of Lansing is the home of the state's first maximum-security prison.

name: kansas
sentence: Historic Leavenworth, founded in 1854, was the first incorporated city in Kansas.

name: kansas
sentence: North of the city, Fort Leavenworth is the oldest active Army post west of the Mississippi River.

name: kansas
sentence: The city of Atchison was an early commercial center in the state and is well known as the birthplace of Amelia Earhart.

name: kansas
sentence: To the west, nearly a quarter million people reside in the Topeka metropolitan area.

name: kansas
sentence: Topeka is the state capital and home to Washburn University and Washburn Institute of Technology.

name: kansas
sentence: Built at a Kansas River crossing along the old Oregon Trail, this historic city has several nationally registered historic places.

name: kansas
sentence: Further westward along Interstate 70 and the Kansas River is Junction City with its historic limestone and brick buildings and nearby Fort Riley, well known as the home to the US Army's 1st Infantry Division (nicknamed "the Big Red One").

name: kansas
sentence: A short distance away, the city of Manhattan is home to Kansas State University, the second-largest public university in the state and the nation's oldest land-grant university, dating back to 1863.

name: kansas
sentence: South of the campus, Aggieville dates back to 1889 and is the state's oldest shopping district of its kind.

name: kansas
sentence: In south-central Kansas, the Wichita metropolitan area is home to more than 600,000 people.

name: kansas
sentence: Wichita is the largest city in the state in terms of both land area and population.

name: kansas
sentence: 'The Air Capital' is a major manufacturing center for the aircraft industry and the home of Wichita State University.

name: kansas
sentence: Before Wichita was 'The Air Capital' it was a Cowtown.

name: kansas
sentence: With a number of nationally registered historic places, museums, and other entertainment destinations, it has a desire to become a cultural mecca in the Midwest.

name: kansas
sentence: Wichita's population growth has grown by double digits and the surrounding suburbs are among the fastest growing cities in the state.

name: kansas
sentence: The population of Goddard has grown by more than 11% per year since 2000.

name: kansas
sentence: Other fast-growing cities include Andover, Maize, Park City, Derby, and Haysville.

name: kansas
sentence: Wichita was one of the first cities to add the city commissioner and city manager in their form of government.

name: kansas
sentence: Wichita is also home of the nationally recognized Sedgwick County Zoo.

name: kansas
sentence: Up river (the Arkansas River) from Wichita is the city of Hutchinson.

name: kansas
sentence: The city was built on one of the world's largest salt deposits, and it has the world's largest and longest wheat elevator.

name: kansas
sentence: It is also the home of Kansas Cosmosphere and Space Center, Prairie Dunes Country Club and the Kansas State Fair.

name: kansas
sentence: North of Wichita along Interstate 135 is the city of Newton, the former western terminal of the Santa Fe Railroad and trailhead for the famed Chisholm Trail.

name: kansas
sentence: To the southeast of Wichita are the cities of Winfield and Arkansas City with historic architecture and the Cherokee Strip Museum (in Ark City).

name: kansas
sentence: The city of Udall was the site of the deadliest tornado in Kansas on May 25, 1955; it killed 80 people in and near the city.

name: kansas
sentence: To the southwest of Wichita is Freeport, the state's smallest incorporated city (population 5).

name: kansas
sentence: Located midway between Kansas City, Topeka, and Wichita in the heart of the Bluestem Region of the Flint Hills, the city of Emporia has several nationally registered historic places and is the home of Emporia State University, well known for its Teachers College.

name: kansas
sentence: It was also the home of newspaper man William Allen White.

name: kansas
sentence: Southeast Kansas has a unique history with a number of nationally registered historic places in this coal-mining region.

name: kansas
sentence: Located in Crawford County (dubbed the Fried Chicken Capital of Kansas), Pittsburg is the largest city in the region and the home of Pittsburg State University.

name: kansas
sentence: The neighboring city of Frontenac in 1888 was the site of the worst mine disaster in the state in which an underground explosion killed 47 miners.

name: kansas
sentence: "Big Brutus" is located 1.5 miles (2.4 km) outside the city of West Mineral.

name: kansas
sentence: Along with the restored fort, historic Fort Scott has a national cemetery designated by President Lincoln in 1862.

name: kansas
sentence: Salina is the largest city in central and north-central Kansas.

name: kansas
sentence: South of Salina is the small city of Lindsborg with its numerous Dala horses.

name: kansas
sentence: Much of the architecture and decor of this town has a distinctly Swedish style.

name: kansas
sentence: To the east along Interstate 70, the historic city of Abilene was formerly a trailhead for the Chisholm Trail and was the boyhood home of President Dwight D. Eisenhower, and is the site of his Presidential Library and the tombs of the former president, First Lady and son who died in infancy.

name: kansas
sentence: To the west is Lucas, the Grassroots Art Capital of Kansas.

name: kansas
sentence: Westward along the Interstate, the city of Russell, traditionally the beginning of sparsely-populated northwest Kansas, was the base of former US

name: kansas
sentence: Senatortor Bob Dole and the boyhood home of US

name: kansas
sentence: Senatortor Arlen Specter.

name: kansas
sentence: The city of Hays is home to Fort Hays State University and the Sternberg Museum of Natural History, and is the largest city in the northwest with a population of around 20,001.

name: kansas
sentence: Two other landmarks are located in smaller towns in Ellis County: the "Cathedral of the Plains" is located 10 miles (16 km) east of Hays in Victoria, and the boyhood home of Walter Chrysler is 15 miles (24 km) west of Hays in Ellis.

name: kansas
sentence: West of Hays, population drops dramatically, even in areas along I-70, and only two towns containing populations of more than 4,000: Colby and Goodland, which are located 35 miles (56 km) apart along I-70.

name: kansas
sentence: Dodge City, famously known for the cattle drive days of the late 19th century, was built along the old Santa Fe Trail route.

name: kansas
sentence: The city of Liberal is located along the southern Santa Fe Trail route.

name: kansas
sentence: The first wind farm in the state was built east of Montezuma.

name: kansas
sentence: Garden City has the Lee Richardson Zoo.

name: kansas
sentence: In 1992, a short-lived secessionist movement advocated the secession of several counties in southwest Kansas.

name: kansas
sentence: Total Employment of the metropolitan areas in the State of Kansas by total Non-farm Employment in 2016

name: kansas
sentence: Total Number of employer establishments in 2016: 74,884

name: kansas
sentence: The Bureau of Economic Analysis estimates that Kansas's total gross domestic product in 2014 was US$140.964 billion.

name: kansas
sentence: In 2015, the job growth rate in was .8%, among the lowest rate in America with only "10,900 total nonfarm jobs" added that year.

name: kansas
sentence: According to the Kansas Department of Labor's 2016 report, the average annual wage was $42,930 in 2015.

name: kansas
sentence: As of April 2016, the state's unemployment rate was 4.2%.

name: kansas
sentence: The State of Kansas had a $350 million budget shortfall in February 2017.

name: kansas
sentence: In February 2017, S&P downgraded Kansas's credit rating to AA-.

name: kansas
sentence: Nearly 90% of Kansas's land is devoted to agriculture.

name: kansas
sentence: The state's agricultural outputs are cattle, sheep, wheat, sorghum, soybeans, cotton, hogs, corn, and salt.

name: kansas
sentence: As of 2018, there were 59,600 farms in Kansas, 86 (0.14%) of which are certified organic farms.

name: kansas
sentence: The average farm in the state is about 770 acres (more than a square mile), and in 2016, the average cost of running the farm was $300,000.

name: kansas
sentence: By far, the most significant agricultural crop in the state is wheat.

name: kansas
sentence: Eastern Kansas is part of the Grain Belt, an area of major grain production in the central United States.

name: kansas
sentence: Approximately 40% of all winter wheat grown in the US is grown in Kansas.

name: kansas
sentence: Roughly 95% of the wheat grown in the state is hard red winter wheat.

name: kansas
sentence: During 2016, farmers of conventionally grown wheat farmed 8.2 million acres and harvested an average of 57 bushels of wheat per acre.

name: kansas
sentence: The industrial outputs are transportation equipment, commercial and private aircraft, food processing, publishing, chemical products, machinery, apparel, petroleum, and mining.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas is ranked eighth in US petroleum production.

name: kansas
sentence: Production has experienced a steady, natural decline as it becomes increasingly difficult to extract oil over time.

name: kansas
sentence: Since oil prices bottomed in 1999, oil production in Kansas has remained fairly constant, with an average monthly rate of about 2.8 million barrels (450,000 cubic meters) in 2004.

name: kansas
sentence: The recent higher prices have made carbon dioxide sequestration and other oil recovery techniques more economical.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas is also ranked eighth in US natural gas production.

name: kansas
sentence: Production has steadily declined since the mid-1990s with the gradual depletion of the Hugoton Natural Gas Field—the state's largest field which extends into Oklahoma and Texas.

name: kansas
sentence: In 2004, slower declines in the Hugoton gas fields and increased coalbed methane production contributed to a smaller overall decline.

name: kansas
sentence: Average monthly production was over 32 billion cubic feet (0.91 cubic kilometers).

name: kansas
sentence: The state's economy is also heavily influenced by the aerospace industry.

name: kansas
sentence: Several large aircraft corporations have manufacturing facilities in Wichita and Kansas City, including Spirit AeroSystems, Bombardier Aerospace (LearJet), and Textron Aviation (a merger of the former Cessna, Hawker, and Beechcraft brands).

name: kansas
sentence: Boeing ended a decades-long history of manufacturing in Kansas between 2012 and 2013.

name: kansas
sentence: Major companies headquartered in Kansas include the Sprint Corporation (with world headquarters in Overland Park), YRC Worldwide (Overland Park), Garmin (Olathe), Payless Shoes (national headquarters and major distribution facilities in Topeka), and Koch Industries (with national headquarters in Wichita), and Coleman (headquarters in Wichita) .

name: kansas
sentence: Telephone company Embarq formerly had its national headquarters in Overland Park before its acquisition by CenturyTel in 2009, and still employs several hundred people in Gardner.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas is also home to three major military installations: Fort Leavenworth (Army), Fort Riley (Army), and McConnell Air Force Base (Air Force).

name: kansas
sentence: Approximately 25,000 active duty soldiers and airmen are stationed at these bases which also employ approximately 8,000 civilian DoD employees.

name: kansas
sentence: The US Army Reserve also has the 451st Expeditionary Sustainment Command headquartered in Wichita that serves reservists and their units from around the region.

name: kansas
sentence: The Kansas Air National Guard has units at Forbes Field in Topeka and the 184th Intelligence Wing in Wichita.

name: kansas
sentence: The Smoky Hill Weapons Range, a detachment of the Intelligence Wing, is one of the largest and busiest bombing ranges in the nation.

name: kansas
sentence: During World War II, Kansas was home to numerous Army Air Corps training fields for training new pilots and aircrew.

name: kansas
sentence: Many of those airfields live on today as municipal airports.

name: kansas
sentence: Tax is collected by the Kansas Department of Revenue.

name: kansas
sentence: Revenue shortfalls resulting from lower than expected tax collections and slower growth in personal income following a 1998 permanent tax reduction have contributed to the substantial growth in the state's debt level as bonded debt increased from $1.16 billion in 1998 to $3.83 billion in 2006.

name: kansas
sentence: Some increase in debt was expected as the state continues with its 10-year Comprehensive Transportation Program enacted in 1999.

name: kansas
sentence: In 2003, Kansas had three income brackets for income tax calculation, ranging from 3.5% to 6.45%.

name: kansas
sentence: The state sales tax in Kansas is 6.15%.

name: kansas
sentence: Various cities and counties in Kansas have an additional local sales tax.

name: kansas
sentence: Except during the 2001 recession (March–November 2001), when monthly sales tax collections were flat, collections have trended higher as the economy has grown and two rate increases have been enacted.

name: kansas
sentence: If there had been no change in sales tax rates or in the economy, the total sales tax collections for 2003 would have been $1,797 million, compared to $805.3 million in 1990.

name: kansas
sentence: However, they instead amounted to $1,630 million an inflation-adjusted reduction of 10%.

name: kansas
sentence: The state sales tax is a combined destination-based tax, meaning a single tax is applied that includes state, county, and local taxes, and the rate is based on where the consumer takes possession of the goods or services.

name: kansas
sentence: Thanks to the destination structure and the numerous local special taxing districts, Kansas has 920 separate sales tax rates ranging from 6.5% to 11.5%.

name: kansas
sentence: This taxing scheme, known as "Streamlined Sales Tax" was adopted on October 1, 2005, under the governorship of Kathleen Sebelius.

name: kansas
sentence: Groceries are subject to sales tax in the state.

name: kansas
sentence: All sales tax collected is remitted to the state department of revenue, and local taxes are then distributed to the various taxing agencies.

name: kansas
sentence: As of June 2004, Moody's Investors Service ranked the state 14th for net tax-supported debt per capita.

name: kansas
sentence: As a percentage of personal income, it was at 3.8%—above the median value of 2.5% for all rated states and having risen from a value of less than 1% in 1992.

name: kansas
sentence: The state has a statutory requirement to maintain cash reserves of at least 7.5% of expenses at the end of each fiscal year; however, lawmakers can vote to override the rule, and did so during the most recent budget agreement.

name: kansas
sentence: During his campaign for the 2010 election, Governor Sam Brownback called for a complete "phase out of Kansas's income tax".

name: kansas
sentence: In May 2012, Governor Brownback signed into law the Kansas Senatorte Bill Substitute HB 2117.

name: kansas
sentence: Starting in 2013, the "ambitious tax overhaul" trimmed income tax, eliminated some corporate taxes, and created pass-through income tax exemptions, he raised the sales tax by one percent to offset the loss to state revenues but that was inadequate.

name: kansas
sentence: He made cuts to education and some state services to offset lost revenue.

name: kansas
sentence: The tax cut led to years of budget shortfalls, culminating in a $350 million budget shortfall in February 2017.

name: kansas
sentence: From 2013 to 2017, 300,000 businesses were considered to be pass-through income entities and benefited from the tax exemption.

name: kansas
sentence: The tax reform "encouraged tens of thousands of Kansans to claim their wages and salaries as income from a business rather than from employment."

name: kansas
sentence: The economic growth that Brownback anticipated never materialized.

name: kansas
sentence: He argued that it was because of "low wheat and oil prices and a downturn in aircraft sales".

name: kansas
sentence: The state general fund debt load was $83 million in fiscal year 2010 and by fiscal year 2017 the debt load sat at $179 million.

name: kansas
sentence: In 2016, Governor Brownback earned the title of "most unpopular governor in America".

name: kansas
sentence: Only 26 percent of Kansas voters approved of his job performance, compared to 65 percent who said they did not.

name: kansas
sentence: In the summer of 2016 S&P Global Ratings downgraded Kansas's credit rating.

name: kansas
sentence: In February 2017, S&P lowered it to AA-.

name: kansas
sentence: In February 2017, a bi-partisan coalition presented a bill that would repeal the pass-through income exemption, the "most important provisions of Brownback's overhaul", and raise taxes to make up for the budget shortfall.

name: kansas
sentence: Brownback vetoed the bill but "45 GOP legislators had voted in favor of the increase, while 40 voted to uphold the governor's veto."

name: kansas
sentence: On June 6, 2017 a coalition of Democrats and newly elected Republicans overrode [Brownback's] veto and implemented tax increases to a level close to what it was before 2013.

name: kansas
sentence: Brownback's tax overhaul was described in a June 2017 article in The Atlantic as the United States' "most aggressive experiment in conservative economic policy".

name: kansas
sentence: The drastic tax cuts had "threatened the viability of schools and infrastructure" in Kansas.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas is served by two Interstate highways with one beltway, two spur routes, and three bypasses, with over 874 miles (1,407 km) in all.

name: kansas
sentence: The first section of Interstate in the nation was opened on Interstate 70 (I-70) just west of Topeka on November 14, 1956.

name: kansas
sentence: I-70 is a major east–west route connecting to Denver, Colorado and Kansas City, Missouri.

name: kansas
sentence: Cities along this route (from west to east) include Colby, Hays, Salina, Junction City, Topeka, Lawrence, Bonner Springs, and Kansas City.

name: kansas
sentence: I-35 is a major north–south route connecting to Oklahoma City, Oklahoma and Des Moines, Iowa.

name: kansas
sentence: Cities along this route (from south to north) include Wichita, El Dorado, Emporia, Ottawa, and Kansas City (and suburbs).

name: kansas
sentence: Spur routes serve as connections between the two major routes.

name: kansas
sentence: I-135, a north–south route, connects I-35 at Wichita to I-70 at Salina.

name: kansas
sentence: I-335, a southwest–northeast route, connects I-35 at Emporia to I-70 at Topeka.

name: kansas
sentence: I-335 and portions of I-35 and I-70 make up the Kansas Turnpike.

name: kansas
sentence: Bypasses include I-470 around Topeka, I-235 around Wichita, and I-670 in downtown Kansas City.

name: kansas
sentence: I-435 is a beltway around the Kansas City metropolitan area while I-635 bypasses through Kansas City.

name: kansas
sentence: US Route 69 (US-69) travels south to north, from Oklahoma to Missouri.

name: kansas
sentence: The highway passes through the eastern section of Kansas, traveling through Baxter Springs, Pittsburg, Frontenac, Fort Scott, Louisburg, and the Kansas City area.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas also has the country's third largest state highway system after Texas and California.

name: kansas
sentence: This is because of the high number of counties and county seats (105) and their intertwining.

name: kansas
sentence: In January 2004, the Kansas Department of Transportation (KDOT) announced the new Kansas 511 traveler information service.

name: kansas
sentence: By dialing 511, callers will get access to information about road conditions, construction, closures, detours and weather conditions for the state highway system.

name: kansas
sentence: Weather and road condition information is updated every 15 minutes.

name: kansas
sentence: The state's only major commercial (Class C) airport is Wichita Dwight D. Eisenhower National Airport, located along US-54 on the western edge of the city.

name: kansas
sentence: Manhattan Regional Airport in Manhattan offers daily flights to Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport and Chicago's O'Hare International Airport, making it the second-largest commercial airport in the state.

name: kansas
sentence: Most air travelers in northeastern Kansas fly out of Kansas City International Airport, located in Platte County, Missouri, as well as Topeka Regional Airport in the state's capital.

name: kansas
sentence: In the state's southeastern part, people often use Tulsa International Airport in Tulsa, Oklahoma or Joplin Regional Airport in Joplin, Missouri.

name: kansas
sentence: For those in the far western part of the state, Denver International Airport is a popular option.

name: kansas
sentence: Connecting flights are also available from smaller Kansas airports in Dodge City, Garden City, Hays, Hutchinson, Liberal, or Salina.

name: kansas
sentence: Dotted across the state are smaller regional and municipal airports, including the Lawrence Municipal Airport, which houses many aircraft for the city of Lawrence and the University of Kansas, Miami County Airport, Wamego Airport, Osage City Municipal Airport, which is the headquarters of Skydive Kansas, Garden City Regional Airport, Manhattan Regional Airport, and Dodge City Regional Airport.

name: kansas
sentence: The Southwest Chief Amtrak route runs through the state on its route from Chicago to Los Angeles.

name: kansas
sentence: Stops in Kansas include Lawrence, Topeka, Newton, Hutchinson, Dodge City, and Garden City.

name: kansas
sentence: An Amtrak Thruway Motorcoach connects Newton and Wichita to the Heartland Flyer in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma.

name: kansas
sentence: Amtrak is proposing to modify the Southwest Chief from its status as a direct passenger rail operation.

name: kansas
sentence: Plans call for shortening the route to Los Angeles to Albuquerque.

name: kansas
sentence: Thruway buses would replace the train on the route between Albuquerque and Dodge City, where train service east to Chicago would resume.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas is served by four Class I railroads, Amtrak, BNSF, Kansas City Southern, and Union Pacific, as well as many shortline railroads.

name: kansas
sentence: Executive branch: The executive branch consists of one officer and five elected officers.

name: kansas
sentence: The governor and lieutenant governor are elected on the same ticket.

name: kansas
sentence: The attorney general, secretary of state, state treasurer, and state insurance commissioner are each elected separately.

name: kansas
sentence: Legislative branch: The bicameral Kansas Legislature consists of the Kansas House of Representatives, with 125 members serving two-year terms, and the Kansas Senatorte, with 40 members serving four-year terms.

name: kansas
sentence: Judicial branch: The judicial branch of the state government is headed by the Kansas Supreme Court.

name: kansas
sentence: The court has seven judges.

name: kansas
sentence: A vacancy is filled by the Governor picking one of three nominees selected by the nine-member Kansas Supreme Court Nominating Commission.

name: kansas
sentence: The board consists of five Kansas lawyers elected by other Kansas lawyers and four members selected by the governor.

name: kansas
sentence: Since the mid-20th century, Kansas has remained one of the most socially conservative states in the nation.

name: kansas
sentence: The 1990s brought the defeat of prominent Democrats, including Dan Glickman, and the Kansas State Board of Education's 1999 decision to eliminate evolution from the state teaching standards, a decision that was later reversed.

name: kansas
sentence: In 2005, voters accepted a constitutional amendment to ban same-sex marriage.

name: kansas
sentence: The next year, the state passed a law setting a minimum age for marriage at 15 years.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas's path to a solid Republican state has been examined by historian Thomas Frank in his 2004 book What's the Matter with Kansas?.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas has a history of many firsts in legislative initiatives—it was the first state to institute a system of workers' compensation (1910) and to regulate the securities industry (1911).

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas also permitted women's suffrage in 1912, almost a decade before the federal constitution was amended to require it.

name: kansas
sentence: Suffrage in all states would not be guaranteed until ratification of the 19th Amendment to the US Constitution in 1920.

name: kansas
sentence: The council–manager government model was adopted by many larger Kansas cities in the years following World War I while many American cities were being run by political machines or organized crime, notably the Pendergast Machine in neighboring Kansas City, Missouri.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas was also at the center of Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka, a 1954 Supreme Court decision that banned racially segregated schools throughout the US

name: kansas
sentence: The state backed Republicans Wendell Willkie and Thomas E. Dewey in 1940 and 1944, respectively.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas also supported Dewey in 1948 despite the presence of incumbent president Harry S. Truman, who hailed from Independence, Missouri, approximately 15 miles (24 km) east of the Kansas–Missouri state line.

name: kansas
sentence: Since Roosevelt carried Kansas in 1932 and 1936, only one Democrat has won Kansas's electoral votes, Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964.

name: kansas
sentence: In 2008, Governor Kathleen Sebelius vetoed permits for the construction of new coal-fired energy plants in Kansas, saying: "We know that greenhouse gases contribute to climate change.

name: kansas
sentence: As an agricultural state, Kansas is particularly vulnerable.

name: kansas
sentence: Therefore, reducing pollutants benefits our state not only in the short term—but also for generations of Kansans to come."

name: kansas
sentence: However, shortly after Mark Parkinson became governor in 2009 upon Sebelius's resignation to become Secretary of US Department of Health & Human Services, Parkinson announced a compromise plan to allow construction of a coal-fired plant.

name: kansas
sentence: In 2010, Sam Brownback was elected governor with 63 percent of the state vote.

name: kansas
sentence: He was sworn in as governor in 2011, Kansas's first Republican governor in eight years.

name: kansas
sentence: Brownback had established himself as a conservative member of the US Senatorte in years prior, but since becoming governor has made several controversial decisions, leading to a 23% approval rating among registered voters, the lowest of any governor in the United States.

name: kansas
sentence: In May 2011, much to the opposition of art leaders and enthusiasts in the state, Brownback eliminated the Kansas Arts Commission, making Kansas the first state without an arts agency.

name: kansas
sentence: In July 2011, Brownback announced plans to close the Lawrence branch of the Kansas Department of Social and Rehabilitation Services as a cost-saving measure.

name: kansas
sentence: Hundreds rallied against the decision.

name: kansas
sentence: Lawrence City Commission later voted to provide the funding needed to keep the branch open.

name: kansas
sentence: Democrat Laura Kelly defeated former Secretary of State of Kansas Kris Kobach in the 2018 election for Governor with 48.0% of the vote.

name: kansas
sentence: The state's current delegation to the Congress of the United States includes Republican Senatortors Pat Roberts of Dodge City and Jerry Moran of Manhattan; and Republican Representatives Roger Marshall of Great Bend (District 1), Steve Watkins (District 2), Ron Estes of Wichita (District 4), and Democratic Representative Sharice Davids (District 3).

name: kansas
sentence: Davids is the second Native American to represent Kansas in Congress, after Republican Charles Curtis (Kaw).

name: kansas
sentence: Historically, Kansas has been strongly Republican, dating from the Antebellum age when the Republican Party was created out of the movement opposing the extension of slavery into Kansas Territory.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas has not elected a Democrat to the US Senatorte since the 1932 election, when Franklin D. Roosevelt won his first term as president in the wake of the Great Depression.

name: kansas
sentence: This is the longest Senatorte losing streak for either party in a single state.

name: kansas
sentence: Senatortor Sam Brownback was a candidate for the Republican party nomination for president in 2008.

name: kansas
sentence: Brownback was not a candidate for re-election to a third full term in 2010, but he was elected Governor in that year's general election.

name: kansas
sentence: Moran defeated Tiahrt for the Republican nomination for Brownback's seat in the August 2010 primary, then won a landslide general election victory over Democrat Lisa Johnston.

name: kansas
sentence: The only non-Republican presidential candidates Kansas has given its electoral vote to are Populist James Weaver and Democrats Woodrow Wilson, Franklin Roosevelt (twice), and Lyndon Johnson.

name: kansas
sentence: In 2004, George W. Bush won the state's six electoral votes by an overwhelming margin of 25 percentage points with 62% of the vote.

name: kansas
sentence: The only two counties to support Democrat John Kerry in that election were Wyandotte, which contains Kansas City, and Douglas, home to the University of Kansas, located in Lawrence.

name: kansas
sentence: The 2008 election brought similar results as John McCain won the state with 57% of the votes.

name: kansas
sentence: Douglas, Wyandotte, and Crawford County were the only counties in support of President Barack Obama.

name: kansas
sentence: Abilene was the boyhood home to Republican president Dwight D. Eisenhower, and he maintained lifelong ties to family and friends there.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas was the adult home of two losing Republican candidates (Governor Alf Landon in 1936 and Senatortor Bob Dole in 1996).

name: kansas
sentence: The New York Times reported in September 2014 that as the Democratic candidate for Senatortor has tried to drop out of the race, independent Greg Orman has attracted enough bipartisan support to seriously challenge the reelection bid of Republican Pat Roberts:

name: kansas
sentence: The legal drinking age in Kansas is 21.

name: kansas
sentence: In lieu of the state retail sales tax, a 10% Liquor Drink Tax is collected for liquor consumed on the licensed premises and an 8% Liquor Enforcement Tax is collected on retail purchases.

name: kansas
sentence: Although the sale of cereal malt beverage (also known as 3.2 beer) was legalized in 1937, the first post-Prohibition legalization of alcoholic liquor did not occur until the state's constitution was amended in 1948.

name: kansas
sentence: The following year the Legislature enacted the Liquor Control Act which created a system of regulating, licensing, and taxing, and the Division of Alcoholic Beverage Control (ABC) was created to enforce the act.

name: kansas
sentence: The power to regulate cereal malt beverage remains with the cities and counties.

name: kansas
sentence: Liquor-by-the-drink did not become legal until passage of an amendment to the state's constitution in 1986 and additional legislation the following year.

name: kansas
sentence: As of November 2006, Kansas still has 29 dry counties and only 17 counties have passed liquor-by-the-drink with no food sales requirement.

name: kansas
sentence: Today there are more than 2,600 liquor and 4,000 cereal malt beverage licensees in the state.

name: kansas
sentence: Education in Kansas is governed at the primary and secondary school level by the Kansas State Board of Education.

name: kansas
sentence: The state's public colleges and universities are supervised by the Kansas Board of Regents.

name: kansas
sentence: Twice since 1999 the Board of Education has approved changes in the state science curriculum standards that encouraged the teaching of intelligent design.

name: kansas
sentence: Both times, the standards were reversed after changes in the composition of the board in the next election.

name: kansas
sentence: The rock band Kansas was formed in the state capital of Topeka, the hometown of several of the band's members.

name: kansas
sentence: Joe Walsh, guitarist for the famous rock band the Eagles, was born in Wichita.

name: kansas
sentence: Danny Carey, drummer for the band Tool, was raised in Paola.

name: kansas
sentence: Singers from Kansas include Leavenworth native Melissa Etheridge, Sharon native Martina McBride, Chanute native Jennifer Knapp (whose first album was titled Kansas), Kansas City native Janelle Monáe, and Liberal native Jerrod Niemann.

name: kansas
sentence: The state anthem is the American classic Home on the Range, written by Kansan Brewster Higley.

name: kansas
sentence: Another song, the official state march adopted by the Kansas Legislature in 1935 is called The Kansas March, which features the lyrics, "Blue sky above us, silken strands of heat, Rim of the far horizon, where earth and heaven meet, Kansas as a temple, stands in velvet sod, Shrine which the sunshine, sanctifies to God."

name: kansas
sentence: The state's most famous appearance in literature was as the home of Dorothy Gale, the main character in the novel The Wonderful Wizard of Oz (1900).

name: kansas
sentence: Laura Ingalls Wilder's Little House on the Prairie, published in 1935, is another well-known tale about Kansas.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas was also the setting of the 1965 best-seller In Cold Blood, described by its author Truman Capote as a "nonfiction novel".

name: kansas
sentence: Mixing fact and fiction, the book chronicles the events and aftermath of the 1959 murder of a wealthy farmer and his family who lived in the small West Kansas town of Holcomb in Finney County.

name: kansas
sentence: The fictional town of Smallville, Kansas is the childhood home of Clark Kent/Superman in American comic books published by DC Comics.

name: kansas
sentence: Also Keystone City is a Kansas city where The Flash works and lives.

name: kansas
sentence: The science fiction novella A Boy and His Dog, as well as the film based on it, take place in post-apocalyptic Topeka.

name: kansas
sentence: The winner of the 2011 Newbery Medal for excellence in children's literature, Moon Over Manifest, tells the story of a young and adventurous girl named Abilene who is sent to the fictional town of Manifest, Kansas, by her father in the summer of 1936.

name: kansas
sentence: It was written by Kansan Clare Vanderpool.

name: kansas
sentence: Lawrence is the setting for a number of science fiction writer James Gunn's novels.

name: kansas
sentence: The first film theater in Kansas was the Patee Theater in Lawrence.

name: kansas
sentence: Most theaters at the time showed films only as part of vaudeville acts but not as an exclusive and stand alone form of entertainment.

name: kansas
sentence: Though the Patee family had been involved in vaudeville, they believed films could carry the evening without other variety acts, but in order to show the films it was necessary for the Patee's to establish a generating plant (back in 1903 Lawrence was not yet fully electrified).

name: kansas
sentence: The Patee Theater was one of the first of its kind west of the Mississippi River.

name: kansas
sentence: The specialized equipment like the projector came from New York.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas has been the setting of many award-winning and popular American films, as well as being the home of some of the oldest operating cinemas in the world.

name: kansas
sentence: The Plaza Cinema in Ottawa, Kansas, located in the northeastern portion of the state, was built on May 22, 1907, and it is listed by the Guinness Book of World Records as the oldest operating cinema in the world.

name: kansas
sentence: In 1926, The Jayhawk Theatre, an art-deco movie house in Topeka opened its doors for the first time to movie going audiences, and today, in addition to screenings of independent films, the theatre acts as a venue for plays and concerts.

name: kansas
sentence: The Fox Theater in Hutchinson was built in 1930, and was placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1989.

name: kansas
sentence: Like the other theaters listed here, The Fox still plays first run movies to this day.

name: kansas
sentence: Sporting Kansas City, who have played their home games at Village West in Kansas City, since 2008, are the first top-tier professional sports league and first Major League Soccer team to be located within Kansas.

name: kansas
sentence: In 2011 the team moved to their new home, a $165m soccer specific stadium now known as Children's Mercy Park.

name: kansas
sentence: Historically, Kansans have supported the major league sports teams of Kansas City, Missouri, including the Kansas City Royals (MLB), and the Kansas City Chiefs (NFL), in part because the home stadiums for these teams are a few miles from the Kansas border.

name: kansas
sentence: The Chiefs and the Royals play at the Truman Sports Complex, located about 10 miles (16 km) from the Kansas–Missouri state line.

name: kansas
sentence: FC Kansas City, a charter member of the National Women's Soccer League, played the 2013 season, the first for both the team and the league, on the Kansas side of the metropolitan area, but played on the Missouri side until folding after the 2017 season.

name: kansas
sentence: From 1973 to 1997 the flagship radio station for the Royals was WIBW in Topeka.

name: kansas
sentence: Some Kansans, mostly from the westernmost parts of the state, support the professional sports teams of Denver, particularly the Denver Broncos of the NFL.

name: kansas
sentence: Two major auto racing facilities are located in Kansas.

name: kansas
sentence: The Kansas Speedway located in Kansas City hosts races of the NASCAR, IndyCar, and ARCA circuits.

name: kansas
sentence: Also, the National Hot Rod Association (NHRA) holds drag racing events at Heartland Park Topeka.

name: kansas
sentence: The Sports Car Club of America has its national headquarters in Topeka.

name: kansas
sentence: The history of professional sports in Kansas probably dates from the establishment of the minor league baseball Topeka Capitals and Leavenworth Soldiers in 1886 in the Western League.

name: kansas
sentence: The African-American Bud Fowler played on the Topeka team that season, one year before the "color line" descended on professional baseball.

name: kansas
sentence: In 1887, the Western League was dominated by a reorganized Topeka team called the Golden Giants: a high-priced collection of major leaguer players, including Bug Holliday, Jim Conway, Dan Stearns, Perry Werden and Jimmy Macullar, which won the league by 15½ games.

name: kansas
sentence: On April 10, 1887, the Golden Giants also won an exhibition game from the defending World Series champions, the St. Louis Browns (the present-day Cardinals), by a score of 12–9.

name: kansas
sentence: However, Topeka was unable to support the team, and it disbanded after one year.

name: kansas
sentence: The first night game in the history of professional baseball was played in Independence on April 28, 1930 when the Muscogee (Oklahoma) Indians beat the Independence Producers 13–3 in a minor league game sanctioned by the Western League of the Western Baseball Association with 1,500 fans attending the game.

name: kansas
sentence: The permanent lighting system was first used for an exhibition game on April 17, 1930 between the Independence Producers and House of David semi-professional baseball team of Benton Harbor, Michigan with the Independence team winning 9–1 before a crowd of 1,700 spectators.

name: kansas
sentence: The governing body for intercollegiate sports in the United States, the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA), was headquartered in Johnson County, Kansas from 1952 until moving to Indianapolis in 1999.

name: kansas
sentence: While there are no franchises of the four major professional sports within the state, many Kansans are fans of the state's major college sports teams, especially the Jayhawks of the University of Kansas (KU), and the Wildcats of Kansas State University (KSU or "K-State").

name: kansas
sentence: The teams are rivals in the Big 12 Conference.

name: kansas
sentence: Both KU and K-State have tradition-rich programs in men's basketball.

name: kansas
sentence: The Jayhawks are a perennial national power, ranking second in all-time victories among NCAA programs, behind Kentucky.

name: kansas
sentence: The Jayhawks have won five national titles, including NCAA tournament championships in 1952, 1988, and 2008.

name: kansas
sentence: They also were retroactively awarded national championships by the Helms Foundation for 1922 and 1923.

name: kansas
sentence: K-State also had a long stretch of success on the hardwood, lasting from the 1940s to the 1980s, making four Final Fours during that stretch.

name: kansas
sentence: In 1988, KU and K-State met in the Elite Eight, KU taking the game 71–58.

name: kansas
sentence: After a 12-year absence, the Wildcats returned to the NCAA tournament in 2008, and advanced to the Elite Eight in 2010 and 2018.

name: kansas
sentence: KU is fifth all-time with 15 Final Four appearances, while K-State's four appearances are tied for 17th.

name: kansas
sentence: Conversely, success on the gridiron has been less frequent for both KSU and KU.

name: kansas
sentence: However, there have been recent breakthroughs for both schools' football teams.

name: kansas
sentence: The Jayhawks won the Orange Bowl for the first time in three tries in 2008, capping a 12–1 season, the best in school history.

name: kansas
sentence: And when Bill Snyder arrived to coach at K-State in 1989, he turned the Wildcats from one of the worst college football programs in America, into a national force for most of the 1990s and early 2000s.

name: kansas
sentence: The team won the Fiesta Bowl in 1997, achieved an undefeated (11–0) regular season and No.

name: kansas
sentence: 1 ranking in 1998, and took the Big 12 Conference championship in 2003.

name: kansas
sentence: After three seasons in which K-State football languished, Snyder came out of retirement in 2009 and guided them to the top of the college football ranks again, finishing second in the Big 12 in 2011 and earning a berth in the Cotton Bowl, and winning the Big 12 again in 2012.

name: kansas
sentence: Wichita State University, which also fields teams (called the Shockers) in Division I of the NCAA, is best known for its baseball and basketball programs.

name: kansas
sentence: In baseball, the Shockers won the College World Series in 1989.

name: kansas
sentence: In men's basketball, they appeared in the Final Four in 1965 and 2013, and entered the 2014 NCAA tournament unbeaten.

name: kansas
sentence: The school also fielded a football team from 1897 to 1986.

name: kansas
sentence: The Shocker football team is tragically known for a plane crash in 1970 that killed 31 people, including 14 players.

name: kansas
sentence: Notable success has also been achieved by the state's smaller schools in football.

name: kansas
sentence: Pittsburg State University, an NCAA Division II participant, has claimed four national titles in football, two in the NAIA and most recently the 2011 NCAA Division II national title.

name: kansas
sentence: Pittsburg State became the winningest NCAA Division II football program in 1995.

name: kansas
sentence: PSU passed Hillsdale College at the top of the all-time victories list in the 1995 season on its march to the national runner-up finish.

name: kansas
sentence: The Gorillas, in 96 seasons of intercollegiate competition, have accumulated 579 victories, posting a 579–301–48 overall mark.

name: kansas
sentence: Washburn University, in Topeka, won the NAIA Men's Basketball Championship in 1987.

name: kansas
sentence: The Fort Hays State University men won the 1996 NCAA Division II title with a 34–0 record, and the Washburn women won the 2005 NCAA Division II crown.

name: kansas
sentence: St. Benedict's College (now Benedictine College), in Atchison, won the 1954 and 1967 Men's NAIA Basketball Championships.

name: kansas
sentence: The Kansas Collegiate Athletic Conference has its roots as one of the oldest college sport conferences in existence and participates in the NAIA and all ten member schools are in the state of Kansas.

name: kansas
sentence: Other smaller school conferences that have some members in Kansas are the Mid-America Intercollegiate Athletics Association the Midlands Collegiate Athletic Conference, the Midwest Christian College Conference, and the Heart of America Athletic Conference.

name: kansas
sentence: Many junior colleges also have active athletic programs.

name: kansas
sentence: Emporia State's women's basketball team, under head coach Brandon Schneider, who is now serving as the women's basketball coach at the University of Kansas, has seen success as well.

name: kansas
sentence: In 2010 the team won the NCAA Division II National Championship.

name: kansas
sentence: Emporia State and Washburn in Topeka share a heated rivalry in all sports, mostly due to the close proximity of both cities.

name: kansas
sentence: The Kansas Jayhawk Community College Conference has been heralded as one of the best conferences in all of NJCAA football, with Garden City Community College, Independence Community College, and Butler County Community College all consistently in contention for national championships.

name: kansas
sentence: The Kansas State High School Activities Association (KSHSAA) is the organization which oversees interscholastic competition in the state of Kansas at the high school level.

name: kansas
sentence: It oversees both athletic and non-athletic competition, and sponsors championships in several sports and activities.

name: kansas
sentence: The association is perhaps best known for devising the overtime system now used for almost all football games below the professional level (which has also been adopted at all levels of Canadian football).

name: kansas
sentence: Maps

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky (US: (listen) kən-TUK-ee, UK: ken-), officially the Commonwealth of Kentucky, is a state in the Southern United States, bordered by Illinois, Indiana, and Ohio to the north; West Virginia and Virginia to the east; Tennessee to the south; and Missouri to the west.

name: kentucky
sentence: The bluegrass region in the central part of the commonwealth contains the commonwealth's capital, Frankfort, as well as its two largest cities, Louisville and Lexington.

name: kentucky
sentence: Together they comprise more than 20% of the commonwealth's population.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky is the 37th most extensive and the 26th most populous of the 50 United States.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky was admitted into the Union as the 15th state on June 1, 1792, splitting from Virginia in the process.

name: kentucky
sentence: It is known as the "Bluegrass State", a nickname based on Kentucky bluegrass, a species of grass found in many of its pastures, which has supported the thoroughbred horse industry in the center of the state.

name: kentucky
sentence: It is home to the world's longest cave system: Mammoth Cave National Park, as well as the greatest length of navigable waterways and streams in the contiguous United States and the two largest man-made lakes east of the Mississippi River.

name: kentucky
sentence: The state is also known for horse racing, bourbon, moonshine, coal, "My Old Kentucky Home" historic state park, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, Louisville Slugger baseball bats, Kentucky Fried Chicken, and the Kentucky colonel.

name: kentucky
sentence: In 1776 the counties of Virginia beyond the Appalachian Mountains became known to European Americans as Kentucky County, named for the Kentucky River.

name: kentucky
sentence: The precise etymology of the name is uncertain, but likely based on an Iroquoian name meaning "(on) the meadow" or "(on) the prairie" (cf.

name: kentucky
sentence: Mohawk kenhtà:ke, Senatorca gëdá'geh (phonemic /kẽtaʔkeh/), "at the field").

name: kentucky
sentence: Others have suggested the term Kenta Aki, which could have come from an Algonquian language and was possibly derived from Shawnee.

name: kentucky
sentence: Folk etymology translates this as "Land of Our Fathers".

name: kentucky
sentence: The closest approximation in another Algonquian language, Ojibwe, translates as "Land of Our In-Laws", thus making a fairer English translation "The Land of Those Who Became Our Fathers".

name: kentucky
sentence: In any case, the word aki means "land" in most Algonquian languages.

name: kentucky
sentence: Some also theorize that the name Kentucky may be a corruption of the word Catawba, in reference to the Catawba people who inhabited Kentucky.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky is situated in the Upland South.

name: kentucky
sentence: A significant portion of eastern Kentucky is part of Appalachia.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky borders seven states, from the Midwest and the Southeast.

name: kentucky
sentence: West Virginia lies to the northeast, Virginia to the east, Tennessee to the south, Missouri to the west, Illinois to the northwest, and Indiana and Ohio to the north.

name: kentucky
sentence: Only Missouri and Tennessee, both of which border eight states, touch more.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky's northern border is formed by the Ohio River and its western border by the Mississippi River; however, the official border is based on the courses of the rivers as they existed when Kentucky became a state in 1792.

name: kentucky
sentence: For instance, northbound travelers on US 41 from Henderson, after crossing the Ohio River, will be in Kentucky for about two miles (3.2 km).

name: kentucky
sentence: Ellis Park, a thoroughbred racetrack, is located in this small piece of Kentucky.

name: kentucky
sentence: Waterworks Road is part of the only land border between Indiana and Kentucky.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky has a non-contiguous part known as Kentucky Bend, at the far west corner of the state.

name: kentucky
sentence: It exists as an exclave surrounded completely by Missouri and Tennessee, and is included in the boundaries of Fulton County.

name: kentucky
sentence: Road access to this small part of Kentucky on the Mississippi River (populated by 18 people as of 2010) requires a trip through Tennessee.

name: kentucky
sentence: The epicenter of the 1811–12 New Madrid earthquakes was near this area, causing the Mississippi River to flow backwards in some places.

name: kentucky
sentence: Though the series of quakes changed the area geologically and affected the small number of inhabitants of the area at the time, the Kentucky Bend is the result of a surveying error, not the New Madrid earthquake.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky can be divided into five primary regions: the Cumberland Plateau in the east, which contains much of the historic coal mines; the north-central Bluegrass region, where the major cities and the capital are located; the south-central and western Pennyroyal Plateau (also known as the Pennyrile or Mississippi Plateau); the Western Coal Fields; and the far-west Jackson Purchase.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Bluegrass region is commonly divided into two regions, the Inner Bluegrass encircling 90 miles (140 km) around Lexington, and the Outer Bluegrass that contains most of the northern portion of the state, above the Knobs.

name: kentucky
sentence: Much of the outer Bluegrass is in the Eden Shale Hills area, made up of short, steep, and very narrow hills.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Jackson Purchase and western Pennyrile are home to several bald cypress/tupelo swamps.

name: kentucky
sentence: Located within the southeastern interior portion of North America, Kentucky has a climate that is best described as a humid subtropical climate (Köppen: Cfa), only small higher areas of the southeast of the state has an oceanic climate (Cfb) influenced by the Appalachians.

name: kentucky
sentence: Temperatures in Kentucky usually range from daytime summer highs of 87 °F (31 °C) to the winter low of 23 °F (−5 °C).

name: kentucky
sentence: The average precipitation is 46 inches (1,200 mm) a year.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky has four distinct seasons, with substantial variations in the severity of summer and winter.

name: kentucky
sentence: The highest recorded temperature was 114 °F (46 °C) at Greensburg on July 28, 1930, while the lowest recorded temperature was −37 °F (−38 °C) at Shelbyville on January 19, 1994.

name: kentucky
sentence: The state rarely experiences the extreme cold of far northern states, nor the high heat of the states in the Deep South.

name: kentucky
sentence: Temperatures seldom drop below 0 degrees or rise above 100 degrees.

name: kentucky
sentence: Rain and snowfall totals about 45 inches per year.

name: kentucky
sentence: Climate varies markedly within the state.

name: kentucky
sentence: The northern parts tend to be about five degrees cooler than those in western parts of the state.

name: kentucky
sentence: Somerset in the south-central part receives ten more inches of rain per year than, for instance, Covington to the north.

name: kentucky
sentence: Average temperatures for the entire Commonwealth range from the low 30s in January to the high 70s in mid-July.

name: kentucky
sentence: The annual average temperature varies from 55 to 60 °F (13 to 16 °C): of 55 °F (13 °C) in the far north as an average annual temperature and of 60 °F (16 °C) in the extreme southwest.

name: kentucky
sentence: In general, Kentucky has relatively hot, humid, rainy summers, and moderately cold and rainy winters.

name: kentucky
sentence: Mean maximum temperatures in July vary from 83 to 90 °F (28 to 32 °C)

name: kentucky
sentence: In January the mean maximum temperatures range from 36 to 44 °F (2 to 7 °C)

name: kentucky
sentence: Temperature means vary with northern and far-eastern mountain-regions averaging five degrees cooler year-round, compared to the relatively warmer areas of the southern and western regions of the state.

name: kentucky
sentence: Precipitation also varies north to south with the north averaging of 38 to 40 inches (970 to 1,020 mm), and the south averaging of 50 inches (1,300 mm).

name: kentucky
sentence: Days per year below the freezing point vary from about sixty days in the southwest to more than a hundred days in the far-north and far-east.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky has more navigable miles of water than any other state in the union, other than Alaska.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky is the only US state to have a continuous border of rivers running along three of its sides – the Mississippi River to the west, the Ohio River to the north, and the Big Sandy River and Tug Fork to the east.

name: kentucky
sentence: Its major internal rivers include the Kentucky River, Tennessee River, Cumberland River, Green River and Licking River.

name: kentucky
sentence: Though it has only three major natural lakes, Kentucky is home to many artificial lakes.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky has both the largest artificial lake east of the Mississippi in water volume (Lake Cumberland) and surface area (Kentucky Lake).

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky Lake's 2,064 miles (3,322 km) of shoreline, 160,300 acres (64,900 hectares) of water surface, and 4,008,000 acre feet (4.9 billion cubic meters) of flood storage are the most of any lake in the TVA system.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky's 90,000 miles (140,000 km) of streams provides one of the most expansive and complex stream systems in the nation.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky has an expansive park system, which includes one national park, two National Recreation Areas, two National Historic Parks, two national forests, two National Wildlife Refuges, 45 state parks, 37,896 acres (153 km2) of state forest, and 82 wildlife management areas.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky has been part of two of the most successful wildlife reintroduction projects in United States history.

name: kentucky
sentence: In the winter of 1997, the Kentucky Department of Fish and Wildlife Resources began to re-stock elk in the state's eastern counties, which had been extinct from the area for over 150 years.

name: kentucky
sentence: As of 2009, the herd had reached the project goal of 10,000 animals, making it the largest herd east of the Mississippi River.

name: kentucky
sentence: The state also stocked wild turkeys in the 1950s.

name: kentucky
sentence: There were reported to be fewer than 900 at one point.

name: kentucky
sentence: Once nearly extinct here, wild turkeys thrive throughout today's Kentucky.

name: kentucky
sentence: Hunters officially reported a record 29,006 birds taken during the 23-day season in spring 2009.

name: kentucky
sentence: In 1991 the Land Between the Lakes partnered with the US

name: kentucky
sentence: Fish and Wildlife Service for the Red Wolf Recovery Program, a captive breeding program.

name: kentucky
sentence: It is not known exactly when the first humans arrived in what is now Kentucky.

name: kentucky
sentence: Based on evidence in other regions, humans were likely living in Kentucky prior to 10,000 BCE, but "archaeological evidence of their occupation has yet to be documented".

name: kentucky
sentence: Around 1800 BCE, a gradual transition began from a hunter-gatherer economy to agriculturalism.

name: kentucky
sentence: Around 900 CE, a Mississippian culture took root in western and central Kentucky; by contrast, a Fort Ancient culture appeared in eastern Kentucky.

name: kentucky
sentence: While the two had many similarities, the distinctive ceremonial earthwork mounds constructed in the former's centers were not part of the culture of the latter.

name: kentucky
sentence: In about the 10th century, the Kentucky native people's variety of corn became highly productive, supplanting the Eastern Agricultural Complex, and replaced it with a maize-based agriculture in the Mississippian era.

name: kentucky
sentence: French explorers in the 17th century documented numerous tribes living in Kentucky until the Beaver Wars in the 1670s; however, by the time that European colonial explorers and settlers began entering Kentucky in greater numbers in the mid-18th century, there were no major Native American settlements in the region.

name: kentucky
sentence: As of the 16th century, the area known as Kentucky was home to tribes from five different culture groups – Iroquoian, Sioux, Algonquian, Muskogean and Yuchi.

name: kentucky
sentence: Around the Bluestone River was the Siouan Tutelo.

name: kentucky
sentence: North of the Tennessee River was the Yuchi and south of it was the Cherokee.

name: kentucky
sentence: Much of the interior of the state was controlled by the Algonquian Cisca

name: kentucky
sentence: During a period known as the Beaver Wars, 1640–1680, another Algonquian tribe called the Maumee, or Mascouten was chased out of southern Michigan.

name: kentucky
sentence: The vast majority of them moved to Kentucky, pushing the Kispoko east and war broke out with the Tutelo that pushed them deeper into Appalachia, where they merged with the Saponi and Moneton.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Maumee were closely related to the Miami of Indiana.

name: kentucky
sentence: Later, the Kispoko merged with the Shawnee (who broke off from the Powhatan on the east coast) and the Thawikila of Ohio to form the larger Shawnee nation which inhabited the Ohio River Valley into the 19th century.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Shawnee from the northwest and Cherokee from the south also sent parties into the area regularly for hunting.

name: kentucky
sentence: Today there are two state recognized tribes in Kentucky, the Southern Cherokee Nation of Kentucky and the Ridgetop Shawnee.

name: kentucky
sentence: Rene-Robert Cavelier, Sieur de la Salle was a French explorer who claimed all of the land along the Mississippi River Valley, including Kentucky, for France.

name: kentucky
sentence: In July 1669, Robert de la Salle organized twenty four men and six canoes for his expedition.

name: kentucky
sentence: During this venture, he met Louis Joliet and Jacques Marquette, the first white men to explore and map the Mississippi River, in Hamilton, Ontario.

name: kentucky
sentence: The expedition eventually reached the Ohio River, allegedly, which it followed as far as Louisville, Kentucky.

name: kentucky
sentence: In 1774 James Harrod founded the first permanent European settlement in Kentucky at the site of present-day Harrodsburg.

name: kentucky
sentence: As more settlers entered the area, warfare broke out with the Native Americans over their traditional hunting grounds.

name: kentucky
sentence: A 1790 US government report states that 1,500 Kentucky settlers had been killed by Native Americans since the end of the Revolutionary War.

name: kentucky
sentence: In 1786 George Rogers Clark led a group of 1,200 men in actions against Shawnee towns on the Wabash River to begin the Northwest Indian War.

name: kentucky
sentence: On December 31, 1776, the region of Virginia beyond the Appalachian Mountains was established as Kentucky County by the Virginia General Assembly.

name: kentucky
sentence: (Kentucky County was abolished on June 30, 1780, when it was divided into Fayette, Jefferson, and Lincoln counties.)

name: kentucky
