sentence: On several occasions the region's residents petitioned the General Assembly and the Confederation Congress for separation from Virginia and statehood.

name: kentucky
sentence: Ten constitutional conventions were held in Danville between 1784 and 1792.

name: kentucky
sentence: One petition, which had Virginia's assent, came before the Confederation Congress in early July 1788.

name: kentucky
sentence: Unfortunately, its consideration came up a day after word of New Hampshire's all-important ninth ratification of the proposed Constitution, thus establishing it as the new framework of governance for the United States.

name: kentucky
sentence: In light of this development, Congress thought that it would be "unadvisable" to admit Kentucky into the Union, as it could do so "under the Articles of Confederation" only, but not "under the Constitution", and so declined to take action.

name: kentucky
sentence: On December 18, 1789, Virginia again gave its consent to Kentucky statehood.

name: kentucky
sentence: The United States Congress gave its approval on February 4, 1791.

name: kentucky
sentence: (This occurred two weeks before Congress approved Vermont's petition for statehood.)

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky officially became the fifteenth state in the Union on June 1, 1792.

name: kentucky
sentence: Isaac Shelby, a military veteran from Virginia, was elected its first Governor.

name: kentucky
sentence: Central Kentucky, the bluegrass region, was the area of the state with the most slave owners.

name: kentucky
sentence: Planters cultivated tobacco and hemp (see Hemp in Kentucky) and were noted for their quality livestock.

name: kentucky
sentence: During the 19th century, Kentucky slaveholders began to sell unneeded slaves to the Deep South, with Louisville becoming a major slave market and departure port for slaves being transported downriver.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky was one of the border states during the American Civil War.

name: kentucky
sentence: Although frequently described as never having seceded, representatives from 68 of 110 counties met at Russellville calling themselves the "Convention of the People of Kentucky" and passed an Ordinance of Secession on November 20, 1861.

name: kentucky
sentence: They established a Confederate government of Kentucky with its capital in Bowling Green.

name: kentucky
sentence: Though Kentucky was represented by the central star on the Confederate battle flag, it remained officially "neutral" throughout the war due to the Union sympathies of a majority of the Commonwealth's citizens.

name: kentucky
sentence: Some 21st-century Kentuckians observe Confederate Memorial Day on Confederate leader Jefferson Davis' birthday, June 3, and participate in Confederate battle re-enactments.

name: kentucky
sentence: Both Davis and US president Abraham Lincoln were born in Kentucky.

name: kentucky
sentence: John C. Breckinridge, the 14th and youngest-ever Vice President was born in Lexington, Kentucky at Cabell's Dale Farm.

name: kentucky
sentence: On January 30, 1900, Governor William Goebel, flanked by two bodyguards, was mortally wounded by an assassin while walking to the State Capitol in downtown Frankfort.

name: kentucky
sentence: Goebel was contesting the Kentucky gubernatorial election of 1899, which William S. Taylor was initially believed to have won.

name: kentucky
sentence: For several months, J. C. W. Beckham, Goebel's running mate, and Taylor fought over who was the legal governor, until the Supreme Court of the United States ruled in May in favor of Beckham.

name: kentucky
sentence: After fleeing to Indiana, Taylor was indicted as a co-conspirator in Goebel's assassination.

name: kentucky
sentence: Goebel is the only governor of a US state to have been assassinated while in office.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Black Patch Tobacco Wars, a vigilante action, occurred in Western Kentucky in the early 20th century.

name: kentucky
sentence: As a result of the tobacco industry monopoly, tobacco farmers in the area were forced to sell their crops at prices that were too low.

name: kentucky
sentence: Many local farmers and activists united in a refusal to sell their crops to the major tobacco companies.

name: kentucky
sentence: An Association meeting occurred in downtown Guthrie, where a vigilante wing of "Night Riders", formed.

name: kentucky
sentence: The riders terrorized farmers who sold their tobacco at the low prices demanded by the tobacco corporations.

name: kentucky
sentence: They burned several tobacco warehouses throughout the area, stretching as far west as Hopkinsville to Princeton.

name: kentucky
sentence: In the later period of their operation, they were known to physically assault farmers who broke the boycott.

name: kentucky
sentence: Governor Augustus E. Willson declared martial law and deployed the Kentucky National Guard to end the wars.

name: kentucky
sentence: On October 15, 1959, a B-52 carrying two nuclear weapons collided in midair with a KC-135 tanker near Hardinsburg, Kentucky.

name: kentucky
sentence: One of the nuclear bombs was damaged by fire but both weapons were recovered.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky is one of four US states to officially use the term commonwealth.

name: kentucky
sentence: The term was used for Kentucky as it had also been used by Virginia, from which Kentucky was created.

name: kentucky
sentence: The term has no particular significance in its meaning and was chosen to emphasize the distinction from the status of royal colonies as a place governed for the general welfare of the populace.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky was originally styled as the "State of Kentucky" in the act admitting it to the union, since that is how it was referred to in Kentucky's first constitution.

name: kentucky
sentence: The commonwealth term was used in citizen petitions submitted between 1786 and 1792 for the creation of the state.

name: kentucky
sentence: It was also used in the title of a history of the state that was published in 1834 and was used in various places within that book in references to Virginia and Kentucky.

name: kentucky
sentence: The other three states officially called "commonwealths" are Massachusetts, Pennsylvania, and Virginia.

name: kentucky
sentence: Puerto Rico and the Northern Mariana Islands are also formally commonwealths.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky is one of only five states that elect their state officials in odd-numbered years (the others being Louisiana, Mississippi, New Jersey, and Virginia).

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky holds elections for these offices every four years in the years preceding Presidential election years.

name: kentucky
sentence: Thus, Kentucky held gubernatorial elections in 2011, 2015 and 2019.

name: kentucky
sentence: The executive branch is headed by the governor who serves as both head of state and head of government.

name: kentucky
sentence: The lieutenant governor may or may not have executive authority depending on whether the person is a member of the Governor's cabinet.

name: kentucky
sentence: Under the current Kentucky Constitution, the lieutenant governor assumes the duties of the governor only if the governor is incapacitated.

name: kentucky
sentence: (Before 1992 the lieutenant governor assumed power any time the governor was out of the state.)

name: kentucky
sentence: The governor and lieutenant governor usually run on a single ticket (also per a 1992 constitutional amendment), and are elected to four-year terms.

name: kentucky
sentence: The current governor is Andy Beshear, and the lieutenant governor is Jacqueline Coleman.

name: kentucky
sentence: Both are Democrats.

name: kentucky
sentence: The executive branch is organized into the following "cabinets", each headed by a secretary who is also a member of the governor's cabinet:

name: kentucky
sentence: The cabinet system was introduced in 1972 by Governor Wendell Ford to consolidate hundreds of government entities that reported directly to the governor's office.

name: kentucky
sentence: Other elected constitutional offices include the Secretary of State, Attorney General, Auditor of Public Accounts, State Treasurer and Commissioner of Agriculture.

name: kentucky
sentence: Currently, Republican Michael G. Adams serves as the Secretary of State.

name: kentucky
sentence: The commonwealth's chief prosecutor, law enforcement officer, and law officer is the Attorney General, currently Republican Daniel Cameron.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Auditor of Public Accounts is Republican Mike Harmon.

name: kentucky
sentence: Republican Allison Ball is the current Treasurer.

name: kentucky
sentence: Republican Ryan Quarles is the current Commissioner of Agriculture.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky's legislative branch consists of a bicameral body known as the Kentucky General Assembly.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Senatorte is considered the upper house.

name: kentucky
sentence: It has 38 members, and is led by the President of the Senatorte, currently Robert Stivers (R).

name: kentucky
sentence: The House of Representatives has 100 members, and is led by the Speaker of the House, currently David Osborne of the Republican Party.

name: kentucky
sentence: In November 2016, Republicans won control of the House for the first time since 1922, and currently have supermajorities in both the House and Senatorte.

name: kentucky
sentence: The judicial branch of Kentucky is called the Kentucky Court of Justice and comprises courts of limited jurisdiction called District Courts; courts of general jurisdiction called Circuit Courts; specialty courts such as Drug Court and Family Court; an intermediate appellate court, the Kentucky Court of Appeals; and a court of last resort, the Kentucky Supreme Court.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Kentucky Court of Justice is headed by the Chief Justice of the Commonwealth.

name: kentucky
sentence: The chief justice is appointed by, and is an elected member of, the Supreme Court of Kentucky.

name: kentucky
sentence: The current chief justice is John D. Minton Jr.

name: kentucky
sentence: Unlike federal judges, who are usually appointed, justices serving on Kentucky state courts are chosen by the state's populace in non-partisan elections.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky's two US

name: kentucky
sentence: Senatortors are Senatorte Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and Rand Paul, both Republicans.

name: kentucky
sentence: The state is divided into six Congressional Districts, represented by Republicans James Comer (1st), Brett Guthrie (2nd), Thomas Massie (4th), Hal Rogers (5th) and Andy Barr (6th) and Democrat John Yarmuth (3rd).

name: kentucky
sentence: In the federal judiciary, Kentucky is served by two United States district courts: the Eastern District of Kentucky, with its primary seat in Lexington, and the Western District of Kentucky, with its primary seat in Louisville.

name: kentucky
sentence: Appeals are heard in the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, based in Cincinnati, Ohio.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky's body of laws, known as the Kentucky Revised Statutes (KRS), were enacted in 1942 to better organize and clarify the whole of Kentucky law.

name: kentucky
sentence: The statutes are enforced by local police, sheriffs and deputy sheriffs, and constables and deputy constables.

name: kentucky
sentence: Unless they have completed a police academy elsewhere, these officers are required to complete Police Officer Professional Standards (POPS) training at the Kentucky Department of Criminal Justice Training Center on the campus of Eastern Kentucky University in Richmond.

name: kentucky
sentence: Additionally, in 1948, the Kentucky General Assembly established the Kentucky State Police, making it the 38th state to create a force whose jurisdiction extends throughout the given state.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky is one of the 32 states in the United States that sanctions the death penalty for certain murders defined as heinous.

name: kentucky
sentence: Those convicted of capital crimes after March 31, 1998 are always executed by lethal injection; those convicted on or before this date may opt for the electric chair.

name: kentucky
sentence: Only three people have been executed in Kentucky since the US Supreme Court re-instituted the practice in 1976.

name: kentucky
sentence: The most notable execution in Kentucky was that of Rainey Bethea on August 14, 1936.

name: kentucky
sentence: Bethea was publicly hanged in Owensboro for the rape and murder of Lischia Edwards.

name: kentucky
sentence: Irregularities with the execution led to this becoming the last public execution in the United States.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky has been on the front lines of the debate over displaying the Ten Commandments on public property.

name: kentucky
sentence: In the 2005 case of McCreary County v. ACLU of Kentucky, the US Supreme Court upheld the decision of the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals that a display of the Ten Commandments in the Whitley City courthouse of McCreary County was unconstitutional.

name: kentucky
sentence: Later that year, Judge Richard Fred Suhrheinrich, writing for the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals in the case of ACLU of Kentucky v. Mercer County, wrote that a display including the Mayflower Compact, the Declaration of Independence, the Ten Commandments, the Magna Carta, The Star-Spangled Banner, and the national motto could be erected in the Mercer County courthouse.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky has also been known to have unusually high political candidacy age laws, especially compared to surrounding states.

name: kentucky
sentence: The origin of this is unknown, but it has been suggested it has to do with the commonwealth tradition.

name: kentucky
sentence: A 2008 study found that Kentucky's Supreme Court to be the least influential high court in the nation with its decisions rarely being followed by other states.

name: kentucky
sentence: Where politics are concerned, Kentucky historically has been very competitive.

name: kentucky
sentence: It leaned toward the Democratic Party since 1860, when the Whig Party dissolved and was considered among the Democratic Solid South, excepting three occasions when it went for the Republican candidate.

name: kentucky
sentence: The southeastern section had aligned with the Union during the war and tended to support Republican candidates.

name: kentucky
sentence: In a reversal of the demographics of party alignment in the post-Civil War nineteenth century, in the 21st century, state Democrats include liberal whites, African Americans, and other minorities.

name: kentucky
sentence: As of March 2020, 48.42% of the state's voters were officially registered as Democrats, and 42.75% were registered Republican, who tend to be conservative whites.

name: kentucky
sentence: Some 8.83% were registered with some other political party or as Independents.

name: kentucky
sentence: Despite this, a majority of the state's voters have generally elected Republican candidates for federal office since around the turn of the 21st century.

name: kentucky
sentence: From 1964 through 2004, Kentucky voted for the eventual winner of the election for President of the United States; however, in the 2008 election the state lost its bellwether status.

name: kentucky
sentence: Republican John McCain won Kentucky, but he lost the national popular and electoral vote to Democrat Barack Obama (McCain carried Kentucky 57% to 41%).

name: kentucky
sentence: 116 of Kentucky's 120 counties supported former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney in the 2012 election while he lost to Barack Obama nationwide.

name: kentucky
sentence: Voters in the Commonwealth supported the previous three Democratic candidates elected to the White House in the late 20th century, all from Southern states: Lyndon B. Johnson (Texas) in 1964, Jimmy Carter (Georgia) in 1976, and Bill Clinton (Arkansas) in 1992 and 1996.

name: kentucky
sentence: In 21st-century presidential elections, the state has become a Republican stronghold, supporting that party's presidential candidates by double-digit margins from 2000 through 2016.

name: kentucky
sentence: At the same time, voters have continued to elect Democratic candidates to state and local offices in many jurisdictions.

name: kentucky
sentence: The United States Census Bureau estimates that the population of Kentucky was 4,467,673 on July 1, 2019, a 2.96% increase since the 2010 United States Census.

name: kentucky
sentence: As of July 1, 2016, Kentucky had an estimated population of 4,436,974, which is an increase of 12,363 from the prior year and an increase of 97,607, or 2.2%, since the year 2010.

name: kentucky
sentence: This includes a natural increase since the last census of 73,541 people (that is 346,968 births minus 273,427 deaths) and an increase due to net migration of 26,135 people into the state.

name: kentucky
sentence: Immigration from outside the United States resulted in a net increase of 40,051 people, and migration within the country produced a net decrease of 13,916 people.

name: kentucky
sentence: As of 2015, Kentucky's population included about 149,016 foreign-born persons (3.4%).

name: kentucky
sentence: In 2016 the population density of the state was 110 people per square mile (42.5/km2).

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky's population has grown during every decade since records have been kept.

name: kentucky
sentence: But during most decades of the 20th century there was also net out-migration from Kentucky.

name: kentucky
sentence: Since 1900, rural Kentucky counties have had a net loss of more than a million people to migration, while urban areas have experienced a slight net gain.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky's center of population is in Washington County, in the city of Willisburg.

name: kentucky
sentence: According to US Census Bureau official statistics, the largest ancestry in 2013 was American totalling 20.2%.

name: kentucky
sentence: In 1980, before the status of ethnic American was an available option on the official census, the largest claimed ancestries in the commonwealth were English (49.6%), Irish (26.3%), and German (24.2%).

name: kentucky
sentence: In the state's most urban counties of Jefferson, Oldham, Fayette, Boone, Kenton, and Campbell, German is the largest reported ancestry.

name: kentucky
sentence: Americans of Scots-Irish and English stock are present throughout the entire state.

name: kentucky
sentence: Many residents claim Irish ancestry because of known "Scots-Irish" among their ancestors, who immigrated from Ireland, where their ancestors had moved for a period from Scotland during the plantation period.

name: kentucky
sentence: As of the 1980s, the only counties in the United States where over half of the population cited "English" as their only ancestry group were in the hills of eastern Kentucky (virtually every county in this region had a majority of residents identifying as exclusively English in ancestry).

name: kentucky
sentence: The Ridgetop Shawnee organized in the early 21st century as a non-profit to gain structure for their community and increase awareness of Native Americans in Kentucky.

name: kentucky
sentence: In the 2000 census, some 20,000 people in the state identified as Native American (0.49%).

name: kentucky
sentence: In June 2011, Jerry "2 Feather" Thornton, a Cherokee, led a team in the Voyage of Native American Awareness 2011 canoe journey, to begin on the Green River in Rochester, Kentucky and travel through to the Ohio River at Henderson.

name: kentucky
sentence: African Americans, who were mostly enslaved at the time, made up 25% of Kentucky's population before the Civil War; they were held and worked primarily in the central Bluegrass region, an area of hemp and tobacco cultivation, as well as raising blooded livestock.

name: kentucky
sentence: The number of African Americans living in Kentucky declined during the 20th century.

name: kentucky
sentence: Many migrated during the early part of the century to the industrial North and Midwest during the Great Migration for jobs and the chance to leave segregated, oppressive societies.

name: kentucky
sentence: Today, less than 9% of the state's total population is African-American.

name: kentucky
sentence: The state's African-American population is highly urbanized and 52% of them live in the Louisville metropolitan area

name: kentucky
sentence: The county's population is 20% African American.

name: kentucky
sentence: Other areas with high concentrations, beside Christian and Fulton counties and the Bluegrass region, are the cities of Paducah and Lexington.

name: kentucky
sentence: Some mining communities in far Southeastern Kentucky have populations that are between five and 10 percent African-American.

name: kentucky
sentence: In 2000 96.1% of all residents five years old and older spoke only English at home, a decrease from 97.5% in 1990.

name: kentucky
sentence: Speech patterns in the state generally reflect the first settlers' Virginia and Kentucky backgrounds.

name: kentucky
sentence: South Midland features are best preserved in the mountains, but some common to Midland and Southern are widespread.

name: kentucky
sentence: After a vowel, the /r/ may be weak or missing.

name: kentucky
sentence: For instance, Coop has the vowel of put, but the root rhymes with boot.

name: kentucky
sentence: In southern Kentucky, earthworms are called redworms, a burlap bag is known as a tow sack or the Southern grass sack, and green beans are called snap beans.

name: kentucky
sentence: In Kentucky English, a young man may carry, not escort, his girlfriend to a party.

name: kentucky
sentence: Spanish is the second-most-spoken language in Kentucky, after English.

name: kentucky
sentence: As of 2010, the Association of Religion Data Archives (ARDA) reported the following groupings of Kentucky's 4,339,367 residents:

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky is home to several seminaries.

name: kentucky
sentence: Southern Baptist Theological Seminary in Louisville is the principal seminary for the Southern Baptist Convention.

name: kentucky
sentence: Louisville is also the home of the Louisville Presbyterian Theological Seminary, an institution of the Presbyterian Church (USA).

name: kentucky
sentence: Lexington has one seminary, Lexington Theological Seminary (affiliated with the Disciples of Christ).

name: kentucky
sentence: The Baptist Seminary of Kentucky is located on the campus of Georgetown College in Georgetown.

name: kentucky
sentence: Asbury Theological Seminary, a multi-denominational seminary in the Methodist tradition, is located in nearby Wilmore.

name: kentucky
sentence: In addition to seminaries, there are several colleges affiliated with denominations:

name: kentucky
sentence: Louisville is home to the Cathedral of the Assumption, the third-oldest Catholic cathedral in continuous use in the United States.

name: kentucky
sentence: The city also holds the headquarters of the Presbyterian Church (USA) and their printing press.

name: kentucky
sentence: Reflecting late 19th, 20th and 21st-century immigration from different countries, Louisville also has Jewish, Muslim, and Hindu communities.

name: kentucky
sentence: In 1996 the Center for Interfaith Relations established the Festival of Faiths, the first and oldest annual interfaith festival to be held in the United States.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Christian creationist apologetics group, Answers in Genesis, along with its Creation Museum, is headquartered in Petersburg, Kentucky.

name: kentucky
sentence: Early in its history, Kentucky gained recognition for its excellent farming conditions.

name: kentucky
sentence: It was the site of the first commercial winery in the United States (started in present-day Jessamine County in 1799) and due to the high calcium content of the soil in the Bluegrass region quickly became a major horse breeding (and later racing) area.

name: kentucky
sentence: Today Kentucky ranks 5th nationally in goat farming, 8th in beef cattle production, and 14th in corn production.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky has also been a long-standing major center of the tobacco industry – both as a center of business and tobacco farming.

name: kentucky
sentence: Today Kentucky's economy has expanded to importance in non-agricultural terms as well, especially in auto manufacturing, energy fuel production, and medical facilities.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky ranks 4th among US states in the number of automobiles and trucks assembled.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Chevrolet Corvette, Cadillac XLR (2004–2009), Ford Escape, Ford Super Duty trucks, Ford Expedition, Lincoln Navigator, Toyota Camry, Toyota Avalon, Toyota Solara, Toyota Venza, and Lexus ES 350 are assembled in Kentucky.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky has historically been a major coal producer, but the coal industry has been in decline since the 1980s, and the number of people employed in the coal industry there dropped by more than half between 2011 and 2015.

name: kentucky
sentence: As of 2010, 24% of electricity produced in the US depended on either enriched uranium rods coming from the Paducah Gaseous Diffusion Plant (the only domestic site of low grade uranium enrichment), or from the 107,336 tons of coal extracted from the state's two coal fields (which combined produce 4% percent of the electricity in the United States).

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky produces 95% of the world's supply of bourbon whiskey, and the number of barrels of bourbon being aged in Kentucky (more than 5.7 million) exceeds the state's population.

name: kentucky
sentence: Bourbon has been a growing market – with production of Kentucky bourbon rising 170 percent between 1999 and 2015.

name: kentucky
sentence: In 2019 the state had more than fifty distilleries for bourbon production.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky exports reached a record $22.1 billion in 2012, with products and services going to 199 countries.

name: kentucky
sentence: According to the Kentucky Cabinet for Economic Development, the primary state agency in Kentucky responsible for creating new jobs and new investment in the state, new business investment in Kentucky in 2012 totaled nearly $2.7 billion, with the creation of more than 14,000 new jobs.

name: kentucky
sentence: One such investment was L'Oréal in Northern Kentucky, which added 200 jobs on top of the 280 already in existing facilities in Florence and Walton.

name: kentucky
sentence: Fort Knox, a United States Army post best known as the site of the United States Bullion Depository, which is used to house a large portion of the United States official gold reserves, is located in Kentucky between Louisville and Elizabethtown.

name: kentucky
sentence: In May 2010, the Army Human Resource Center of Excellence, the largest office building in the state at nearly 900,000 square feet (84,000 m2) opened at Fort Knox.

name: kentucky
sentence: The new complex employs nearly 4,300 soldiers and civilians.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky contains two of the twenty US Federal Penitentiaries: USP Big Sandy (in the east in Martin County near Inez) and USP McCreary (in the south in McCreary County in the Daniel Boone National Forest).

name: kentucky
sentence: The total gross state product for 2019 Q1 was $213.313 billion.

name: kentucky
sentence: Its per-capita income was $25,888 in 2017.

name: kentucky
sentence: An organization called the Institute for Truth in Accounting estimated that the state government's debts exceeded its available assets by $26,300 per taxpayer as of 2011, ranking the state as having the 5th highest such debt burden in the nation.

name: kentucky
sentence: As of October 2019, the state's unemployment rate is 4.3%.

name: kentucky
sentence: In 2014 Kentucky was found to be the most affordable US state in which to live.

name: kentucky
sentence: Tax is collected by the Kentucky Department of Revenue.

name: kentucky
sentence: There are six income tax brackets, ranging from 2% to 6% of personal income.

name: kentucky
sentence: The sales tax rate in Kentucky is 6%.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky has a broadly based classified property tax system.

name: kentucky
sentence: All classes of property, unless exempted by the Constitution, are taxed by the state, although at widely varying rates.

name: kentucky
sentence: Many of these classes are exempted from taxation by local government.

name: kentucky
sentence: Of the classes that are subject to local taxation, three have special rates set by the General Assembly, one by the Kentucky Supreme Court and the remaining classes are subject to the full local rate, which includes the tax rate set by the local taxing bodies plus all voted levies.

name: kentucky
sentence: Real property is assessed on 100% of the fair market value and property taxes are due by December 31.

name: kentucky
sentence: Once the primary source of state and local government revenue, property taxes now account for only about 6% of the Kentucky's annual General Fund revenues.

name: kentucky
sentence: Until January 1, 2006, Kentucky imposed a tax on intangible personal property held by a taxpayer on January 1 of each year.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Kentucky intangible tax was repealed under House Bill 272.

name: kentucky
sentence: Intangible property consisted of any property or investment that represents evidence of value or the right to value.

name: kentucky
sentence: Some types of intangible property included: bonds, notes, retail repurchase agreements, accounts receivable, trusts, enforceable contracts sale of real estate (land contracts), money in hand, money in safe deposit boxes, annuities, interests in estates, loans to stockholders, and commercial paper.

name: kentucky
sentence: In December 2002, the Kentucky governor Paul Patton unveiled the state slogan "It's that friendly", in hope of drawing more people into the state based on the idea of southern hospitality.

name: kentucky
sentence: This campaign was neither a failure nor a success.

name: kentucky
sentence: Though it was meant to embrace southern values, many Kentuckians rejected the slogan as cheesy and ineffective.

name: kentucky
sentence: It was quickly seen that the slogan did not encourage tourism as much as initially hoped for.

name: kentucky
sentence: So government decided to create a different slogan to embrace Kentucky as a whole while also encouraging more people to visit the Bluegrass.

name: kentucky
sentence: In 2004, then Governor Ernie Fletcher launched a comprehensive branding campaign with the hope of making the state's $12–14 million advertising budget more effective.

name: kentucky
sentence: The resulting "Unbridled Spirit" brand was the result of a $500,000 contract with New West, a Kentucky-based public relations advertising and marketing firm, to develop a viable brand and tag line.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Fletcher administration aggressively marketed the brand in both the public and private sectors.

name: kentucky
sentence: Since that time, the "Welcome to Kentucky" signs at border areas have an "Unbridled Spirit" symbol on them.

name: kentucky
sentence: Tourism has become an increasingly important part of the Kentucky economy.

name: kentucky
sentence: In 2019 tourism grew to $7.6 billion in economic impact.

name: kentucky
sentence: Key attractions include horse racing with events like the Kentucky Derby and the Keeneland Fall and Spring Meets, bourbon distillery tours and natural attractions such as the state's many lakes and parks to include Mammoth Cave, Lake Cumberland and Red River Gorge.

name: kentucky
sentence: The state also has several religious destinations such as the Creation Museum and Ark Encounter of Answers in Genesis.

name: kentucky
sentence: Horse Racing has long been associated with Kentucky.

name: kentucky
sentence: Churchill Downs, the home of the Derby, is a large venue with a capacity exceeding 165,000.

name: kentucky
sentence: The track hosts multiple events throughout the year and is a significant draw to the city of Louisville.

name: kentucky
sentence: Keeneland Race Course, in Lexington, hosts two major meets, the Spring and Fall running.

name: kentucky
sentence: Beyond hosting races Keeneland also hosts a significant horse auction drawing buyers from around the world.

name: kentucky
sentence: In 2019 $360 million was spent on the September Yearling sale.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Kentucky Horse Park in Georgetown hosts multiple events throughout the year, including international equestrian competitions and also offers horseback riding from April to October.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky is served by six major Interstate highways (I-24, I-64, I-65, I-69, I-71, and I-75), seven parkways, and six bypasses and spurs (I-165, I-169, I-264, I-265, I-275, and I-471).

name: kentucky
sentence: The parkways were originally toll roads, but on November 22, 2006, Governor Ernie Fletcher ended the toll charges on the William H. Natcher Parkway and the Audubon Parkway, the last two parkways in Kentucky to charge tolls for access.

name: kentucky
sentence: The related toll booths have been demolished.

name: kentucky
sentence: Ending the tolls some seven months ahead of schedule was generally agreed to have been a positive economic development for transportation in Kentucky.

name: kentucky
sentence: In June 2007, a law went into effect raising the speed limit on rural portions of Kentucky Interstates and parkways from 65 to 70 miles per hour (105 to 113 km/h).

name: kentucky
sentence: Road tunnels include the interstate Cumberland Gap Tunnel and the rural Nada Tunnel.

name: kentucky
sentence: Amtrak, the national passenger rail system, provides service to Ashland, South Portsmouth, Maysville and Fulton.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Cardinal (trains 50 and 51) is the line that offers Amtrak service to Ashland, South Shore, Maysville and South Portsmouth.

name: kentucky
sentence: The City of New Orleans (trains 58 and 59) serve Fulton.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Northern Kentucky area is served by the Cardinal at Cincinnati Union Terminal.

name: kentucky
sentence: The terminal is just across the Ohio River in Cincinnati.

name: kentucky
sentence: Norfolk Southern Railway passes through the Central and Southern parts of the Commonwealth, via its Cincinnati, New Orleans, and Texas Pacific (CNO&TP) subsidiary.

name: kentucky
sentence: The line originates in Cincinnati and terminates 338 miles south in Chattanooga, Tennessee.

name: kentucky
sentence: As of 2004, there were approximately 2,640 miles (4,250 km) of railways in Kentucky, with about 65% of those being operated by CSX Transportation.

name: kentucky
sentence: Coal was by far the most common cargo, accounting for 76% of cargo loaded and 61% of cargo delivered.

name: kentucky
sentence: Bardstown features a tourist attraction known as My Old Kentucky Dinner Train.

name: kentucky
sentence: Run along a 20-mile (30 km) stretch of rail purchased from CSX in 1987, guests are served a four-course meal as they make a two-and-a-half-hour round-trip between Bardstown and Limestone Springs.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Kentucky Railway Museum is located in nearby New Haven.

name: kentucky
sentence: Other areas in Kentucky are reclaiming old railways in rail trail projects.

name: kentucky
sentence: One such project is Louisville's Big Four Bridge.

name: kentucky
sentence: When the bridge's Indiana approach ramps opened in 2014, completing the pedestrian connection across the Ohio River, the Big Four Bridge rail trail became the second-longest pedestrian-only bridge in the world.

name: kentucky
sentence: The longest pedestrian-only bridge is also found in Kentucky – the Newport Southbank Bridge, popularly known as the "Purple People Bridge", connecting Newport to Cincinnati, Ohio.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky's primary airports include Louisville International Airport (Standiford Field (SDF)) of Louisville, Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky International Airport (CVG) of Cincinnati/Covington, and Blue Grass Airport (LEX) in Lexington.

name: kentucky
sentence: Louisville International Airport is home to USs Worldport, its international air-sorting hub.

name: kentucky
sentence: Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky International Airport is the largest airport in the state, and is a focus city for passenger airline Delta Air Lines and headquarters of its Delta Private Jets.

name: kentucky
sentence: The airport is one of DHL Aviation's three super-hubs, serving destinations throughout the Americas, Europe, Africa, and Asia, making it the 7th busiest airport in the US and 36th in the world based on passenger and cargo operations.

name: kentucky
sentence: CVG is also a focus city for Frontier Airlines and is the largest O&D airport and base for Allegiant Air, along with home to a maintenance for American Airlines subsidiary PSA Airlines and Delta Air Lines subsidiary Endeavor Air.

name: kentucky
sentence: There are also a number of regional airports scattered across the state.

name: kentucky
sentence: On August 27, 2006, Blue Grass Airport was the site of a crash that killed 47 passengers and 2 crew members aboard a Bombardier CRJ designated Comair Flight 191, or Delta Air Lines Flight 5191, sometimes mistakenly identified by the press as Comair Flight 5191.

name: kentucky
sentence: The lone survivor was the flight's first officer, James Polehinke, who doctors determined to be brain damaged and unable to recall the crash at all.

name: kentucky
sentence: As the state is bounded by two of the largest rivers in North America, water transportation has historically played a major role in Kentucky's economy.

name: kentucky
sentence: Louisville was a major port for steamships in the nineteenth century.

name: kentucky
sentence: Today, most barge traffic on Kentucky waterways consists of coal that is shipped from both the Eastern and Western Coalfields, about half of which is used locally to power many power plants located directly off the Ohio River, with the rest being exported to other countries, most notably Japan.

name: kentucky
sentence: Many of the largest ports in the United States are located in or adjacent to Kentucky, including:

name: kentucky
sentence: As a state, Kentucky ranks 10th overall in port tonnage.

name: kentucky
sentence: The only natural obstacle along the entire length of the Ohio River is the Falls of the Ohio, located just west of Downtown Louisville.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky is subdivided into 120 counties, the largest being Pike County at 787.6 square miles (2,040 km2), and the most populous being Jefferson County (which coincides with the Louisville Metro governmental area) with 741,096 residents as of 2010.

name: kentucky
sentence: County government, under the Kentucky Constitution of 1891, is vested in the County Judge/Executive, (formerly called the County Judge) who serves as the executive head of the county, and a legislature called a Fiscal Court.

name: kentucky
sentence: Despite the unusual name, the Fiscal Court no longer has judicial functions.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky's two most populous counties, Jefferson and Fayette, have their governments consolidated with the governments of their largest cities.

name: kentucky
sentence: Louisville-Jefferson County Government (Louisville Metro) and Lexington-Fayette Urban County Government (Lexington Metro) are unique in that their city councils and county Fiscal Court structures have been merged into a single entity with a single chief executive, the Metro Mayor and Urban County Mayor, respectively.

name: kentucky
sentence: Although the counties still exist as subdivisions of the state, in reference the names Louisville and Lexington are used to refer to the entire area coextensive with the former cities and counties.

name: kentucky
sentence: Somewhat incongruously, when entering Lexington-Fayette the highway signs read "Fayette County" while most signs leading into Louisville-Jefferson simply read "Welcome to Louisville Metro".

name: kentucky
sentence: The Metro Louisville government area has a 2018 population of 1,298,990.

name: kentucky
sentence: Under United States Census Bureau methodology, the population of Louisville was 623,867.

name: kentucky
sentence: The latter figure is the population of the so-called "balance" – the parts of Jefferson County that were either unincorporated or within the City of Louisville before the formation of the merged government in 2003.

name: kentucky
sentence: In 2018 the Louisville Combined Statistical Area (CSA) had a population of 1,569,112; including 1,209,191 in Kentucky, which means more than 25% of the state's population now lives in the Louisville CSA.

name: kentucky
sentence: Since 2000, over one-third of the state's population growth has occurred in the Louisville CSA.

name: kentucky
sentence: In addition, the top 28 wealthiest places in Kentucky are in Jefferson County and seven of the 15 wealthiest counties in the state are located in the Louisville CSA.

name: kentucky
sentence: The second largest city is Lexington with a 2018 census population of 323,780, its metro had a population of 516,697, and its CSA, which includes the Frankfort and Richmond statistical areas, having a population of 746,310.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Northern Kentucky area, which comprises the seven Kentucky counties in the Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky metropolitan area, had a population of 447,457 in 2018.

name: kentucky
sentence: The metropolitan areas of Louisville, Lexington, and Northern Kentucky have a combined population of 2,402,958 as of 2018, which is 54% of the state's total population on only about 19% of the state's land.

name: kentucky
sentence: This area is often referred to as the Golden triangle as it contains a majority of the state's wealth, population, population growth, and economic growth, it is also where most of the state's largest cities by population are located.

name: kentucky
sentence: It is referred to the Golden triangle as the metro areas of Lexington, Louisville, and Northern Kentucky/Cincinnati outline a triangle shape.

name: kentucky
sentence: Interstates I-71, I-75, and I-64 form the triangle shape.

name: kentucky
sentence: Additionally all counties in Kentucky that are part of a MSA or CSA have a total population of 2,970,694, which is 67% of the state's population.

name: kentucky
sentence: As of 2017 Bowling Green had a population of 67,067, making it the third most-populous city in the state.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Bowling Green metropolitan area had an estimated population of 174,835; and the combined statistical area it shares with Glasgow has an estimated population of 228,743.

name: kentucky
sentence: The two other fast growing urban areas in Kentucky are the Bowling Green area and the "Tri Cities Region" of southeastern Kentucky, comprising Somerset, London and Corbin.

name: kentucky
sentence: Although only one town in the "Tri Cities" (Somerset) currently has more than 12,000 people, the area has been experiencing heightened population and job growth since the 1990s.

name: kentucky
sentence: Growth has been especially rapid in Laurel County, which outgrew areas such as Scott and Jessamine counties around Lexington or Shelby and Nelson Counties around Louisville.

name: kentucky
sentence: London significantly grew in population in the 2000s, from 5,692 in 2000 to 7,993 in 2010.

name: kentucky
sentence: London also landed a Wal-Mart distribution center in 1997, bringing thousands of jobs to the community.

name: kentucky
sentence: In northeast Kentucky, the greater Ashland area is an important transportation, manufacturing, and medical center.

name: kentucky
sentence: Iron and petroleum production, as well as the transport of coal by rail and barge, have been historical pillars of the region's economy.

name: kentucky
sentence: Due to a decline in the area's industrial base, Ashland has seen a sizable reduction in its population since 1990; however, the population of the area has since stabilized with the medical service industry taking a greater role in the local economy.

sentence: The Ashland area, including the counties of Boyd and Greenup, are part of the Huntington-Ashland, WV-KY-OH, Metropolitan Statistical Area (MSA).

name: kentucky

name: kentucky
sentence: More than 21,000 of those people (as of 2010) reside within the city limits of Ashland.

name: kentucky
sentence: The largest county in Kentucky by area is Pike, which contains Pikeville and suburb Coal Run Village.

sentence: The county and surrounding area is the most populated region in the state that is not part of a Micropolitan Statistical Area or a Metropolitan Statistical Area containing nearly 200,000 people in five counties: Floyd County, Martin County, Letcher County, and neighboring Mingo County, West Virginia.

name: kentucky
sentence: Pike County contains slightly more than 68,000 people.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky maintains eight public four-year universities.

name: kentucky
sentence: There are two general tiers: major research institutions (the University of Kentucky and the University of Louisville) and regional universities, which encompasses the remaining six schools.

name: kentucky
sentence: The regional schools have specific target counties that many of their programs are targeted towards (such as Forestry at Eastern Kentucky University or Cave Management at Western Kentucky University), however most of their curriculum varies little from any other public university.

name: kentucky
sentence: UK and UofL have the highest academic rankings and admissions standards although the regional schools aren't without their national recognized departments – examples being Western Kentucky University's nationally ranked Journalism Department or Morehead State University offering one of the nation's only Space Science degrees.

name: kentucky
sentence: UK is the flagship and land grant of the system and has agriculture extension services in every county.

name: kentucky
sentence: The two research schools split duties related to the medical field, UK handles all medical outreach programs in the eastern half of the state while UofL does all medical outreach in the state's western half.

name: kentucky
sentence: The state's sixteen public two-year colleges have been governed by the Kentucky Community and Technical College System since the passage of the Postsecondary Education Improvement Act of 1997, commonly referred to as House Bill 1.

name: kentucky
sentence: Before the passage of House Bill 1, most of these colleges were under the control of the University of Kentucky.

name: kentucky
sentence: Transylvania University, a liberal arts university located in Lexington, was founded in 1780 as the oldest university west of the Allegheny Mountains.

name: kentucky
sentence: Berea College, located at the extreme southern edge of the Bluegrass below the Cumberland Plateau, was the first coeducational college in the South to admit both black and white students, doing so from its very establishment in 1855.

name: kentucky
sentence: This policy was successfully challenged in the United States Supreme Court in the case of Berea College v. Kentucky in 1908.

name: kentucky
sentence: This decision effectively segregated Berea until the landmark Brown v. Board of Education in 1954.

name: kentucky
sentence: There are 173 school districts and 1,233 public schools in Kentucky.

name: kentucky
sentence: For the 2010 to 2011 school year, there were approximately 647,827 students enrolled in public school.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky has been the site of much educational reform over the past two decades.

name: kentucky
sentence: In 1989 the Kentucky Supreme Court ruled the state's education system was unconstitutional.

name: kentucky
sentence: The response of the General Assembly was passage of the Kentucky Education Reform Act (KERA) the following year.

name: kentucky
sentence: Years later, Kentucky has shown progress, but most agree that further reform is needed.

name: kentucky
sentence: The West Virginia teachers' strike in 2018 inspired teachers in other states, including Kentucky, to take similar action.

name: kentucky
sentence: Although Kentucky's culture is generally considered to be Southern, it is unique in that it is also influenced by the Midwest and Southern Appalachia in certain areas of the state.

name: kentucky
sentence: The state is known for bourbon and whiskey distilling, tobacco, horse racing, and college basketball.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky is more similar to the Upland South in terms of ancestry that is predominantly American.

name: kentucky
sentence: Nevertheless, during the 19th century, Kentucky did receive a substantial number of German immigrants, who settled mostly in the Midwest, along the Ohio River primarily in Louisville, Covington and Newport.

name: kentucky
sentence: Only Maryland, Delaware and West Virginia have higher German ancestry percentages than Kentucky among Census-defined Southern states, although Kentucky's percentage is closer to Arkansas and Virginia's than the previously named state's percentages.

name: kentucky
sentence: Scottish Americans, English Americans and Scotch-Irish Americans have heavily influenced Kentucky culture, and are present in every part of the state.

name: kentucky
sentence: As of the 1980s the only counties in the United States where more than half the population cited "English" as their only ancestry group were all in the hills of eastern Kentucky (and made up virtually every county in this region).

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky was a slave state, and blacks once comprised over one-quarter of its population; however, it lacked the cotton plantation system and never had the same high percentage of African Americans as most other slave states.

name: kentucky
sentence: While less than 8% of the total population is black, Kentucky has a relatively significant rural African American population in the Central and Western areas of the state.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky adopted the Jim Crow system of racial segregation in most public spheres after the Civil War.

name: kentucky
sentence: Louisville's 1914 ordinance for residential racial segregation was struck down by the US Supreme Court in 1917.

name: kentucky
sentence: However, in 1908 Kentucky enacted the Day Law, "An Act to Prohibit White and Colored Persons from Attending the Same School", which Berea College unsuccessfully challenged at the US Supreme Court in 1908; in 1948, Lyman T. Johnson filed suit for admission to the University of Kentucky; as a result in the summer of 1949, nearly thirty African American students entered UK graduate and professional programs.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky integrated its schools after the 1954 Brown v. Board of Education verdict, later adopting the first state civil rights act in the South in 1966.

name: kentucky
sentence: The biggest day in American horse racing, the Kentucky Derby, is preceded by the two-week Derby Festival in Louisville.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Derby Festival features many events, including Thunder Over Louisville, the Pegasus Parade, the Great Steamboat Race, Fest-a-Ville, the Chow Wagon, BalloonFest, BourbonVille, and many others leading up to the big race.

name: kentucky
sentence: Louisville also plays host to the Kentucky State Fair and the Kentucky Shakespeare Festival.

sentence: Bowling Green, the state's third-largest city and home to the only assembly plant in the world that manufactures the Chevrolet Corvette, opened the National Corvette Museum in 1994.

name: kentucky
sentence: The fourth-largest city, Owensboro, gives credence to its nickname of "Barbecue Capital of the World" by hosting the annual International Bar-B-Q Festival.

name: kentucky
sentence: Old Louisville, the largest historic preservation district in the United States featuring Victorian architecture and the third largest overall, hosts the St. James Court Art Show, the largest outdoor art show in the United States.

sentence: Hodgenville, the birthplace of Abraham Lincoln, hosts the annual Lincoln Days Celebration, and also hosted the kick-off for the National Abraham Lincoln Bicentennial Celebration in February 2008.

sentence: Bardstown celebrates its heritage as a major bourbon-producing region with the Kentucky Bourbon Festival.

name: kentucky
sentence: Winchester celebrates an original Kentucky creation, Beer Cheese, with its Beer Cheese Festival held annually in June.

sentence: Beer Cheese was developed in Clark County at some point in the 1940s along the Kentucky River.

sentence: The residents of tiny Benton pay tribute to their favorite tuber, the sweet potato, by hosting Tater Day.

name: kentucky
sentence: Residents of Clarkson in Grayson County celebrate their city's ties to the honey industry by celebrating the Clarkson Honeyfest.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Clarkson Honeyfest is held the last Thursday, Friday and Saturday in September, and is the "Official State Honey Festival of Kentucky".

name: kentucky
sentence: Renfro Valley, Kentucky is home to Renfro Valley Entertainment Center and the Kentucky Music Hall of Fame and is known as "Kentucky's Country Music Capital", a designation given it by the Kentucky State Legislature in the late 1980s.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Renfro Valley Barn Dance was where Renfro Valley's musical heritage began, in 1939, and influential country music luminaries like Red Foley, Homer & Jethro, Lily May Ledford & the Original Coon Creek Girls, Martha Carson, and many others have performed as regular members of the shows there over the years.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Renfro Valley Gatherin' is today America's second oldest continually broadcast radio program of any kind.

name: kentucky
sentence: It is broadcast on local radio station WRVK and a syndicated network of nearly 200 other stations across the United States and Canada every week.

name: kentucky
sentence: Contemporary Christian music star Steven Curtis Chapman is a Paducah native, and Rock and Roll Hall of Famers The Everly Brothers are closely connected with Muhlenberg County, where older brother Don was born.

name: kentucky
sentence: Merle Travis, Country & Western artist known for both his signature "Travis picking" guitar playing style, as well as his hit song "Sixteen Tons", was also born in Muhlenberg County.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky was also home to Mildred and Patty Hill, the Louisville sisters credited with composing the tune to the ditty Happy Birthday to You in 1893; Loretta Lynn (Johnson County), Brian Littrell and Kevin Richardson of the Backstreet Boys, and Billy Ray Cyrus (Flatwoods).

name: kentucky
sentence: However, its depth lies in its signature sound – Bluegrass music.

name: kentucky
sentence: Bill Monroe, "The Father of Bluegrass", was born in the small Ohio County town of Rosine, while Ricky Skaggs, Keith Whitley, David "Stringbean" Akeman, Louis Marshall "Grandpa" Jones, Sonny and Bobby Osborne, and Sam Bush (who has been compared to Monroe) all hail from Kentucky.

sentence: Blues legend W. C. Handy and R&B singer Wilson Pickett also spent considerable time in Kentucky.

sentence: Heavy Rock band Black Stone Cherry hails from rural Edmonton.

sentence: Rock bands Cage the Elephant, Sleeper Agent, and Morning Teleportation are also from Bowling Green.

sentence: In eastern Kentucky, old-time music carries on the tradition of ancient ballads and reels developed in historical Appalachia.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky has played a major role in Southern and American literature, producing works that often celebrate the working class, rural life, nature, and explore issues of class, extractive economy, and family.

name: kentucky
sentence: Major works from the state include Uncle Tom's Cabin (1852) by Harriet Beecher Stowe, widely seen as one of the impetuses for the American Civil War; The Little Shepherd of Kingdom Come (1908) by John Fox Jr., which was the first novel to sell a million copies in the United States; All the King's Men by Robert Penn Warren (1946), rated as the 36th best English-language novel of the 20th century; The Dollmaker (1954) by Harriette Arnow; Night Comes to the Cumberlands (1962) by Harry Caudill, which contributed to initiating the US Government's War on poverty, and others.

name: kentucky
sentence: Author Thomas Merton lived most of his life and wrote most of his books – including The Seven Storey Mountain (1948), ranked on National Review's list of the 100 best non-fiction books of the century – during his time as a monk at the Abbey of Our Lady of Gethsemani near Bardstown, Kentucky.

name: kentucky
sentence: Author Hunter S. Thompson is also a native of the state.

sentence: Well-known playwrights from Kentucky include Marsha Norman (works include 'night, Mother, 1983) and Naomi Wallace (works include One Flea Spare, 1995).

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky's cuisine is generally similar to traditional southern cooking, although in some areas of the state it can blend elements of both the South and Midwest.

name: kentucky

sentence: Harland Sanders, a Kentucky colonel, originated Kentucky Fried Chicken at his service station in North Corbin, though the first franchised KFC was located in South Salt Lake, Utah.

sentence: Kentucky is the home of several sports teams such as Minor League Baseball's Triple-A Louisville Bats and Class A Lexington Legends and the Class A Bowling Green Hot Rods.

sentence: They are also home to the Frontier League's Florence Y'alls and several teams in the MCFL.

sentence: As in many states, especially those without major league professional sport teams, college athletics are prominent.

name: kentucky
sentence: This is especially true of the state's three Division I Football Bowl Subdivision (FBS) programs, including the Kentucky Wildcats, the Western Kentucky Hilltoppers, and the Louisville Cardinals.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Wildcats, Hilltoppers, and Cardinals are among the most tradition-rich college men's basketball teams in the United States, combining for 11 National championships and 24 NCAA Final Fours; all three are high on the lists of total all-time wins, wins per season, and average wins per season.

sentence: The Kentucky Wildcats are particularly notable, leading all Division I programs in all-time wins, win percentage, NCAA tournament appearances, and being second only to UCLA in NCAA championships.

sentence: The NASCAR Cup Series has a race at the Kentucky Speedway in Sparta, Kentucky, which is within an hour driving distance from Cincinnati, Louisville and Lexington.

name: kentucky
sentence: The distinction of being named a Kentucky colonel is the highest title of honor bestowed by the Commonwealth of Kentucky.

name: kentucky
sentence: Commissions for Kentucky colonels are given by the Governor and the Secretary of State to individuals in recognition of noteworthy accomplishments and outstanding service to a community, state or the nation.

name: kentucky
sentence: The sitting governor of the Commonwealth of Kentucky bestows the honor of a colonel's commission, by issuance of letters patent.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky colonels are commissioned for life and act officially as the state's goodwill ambassadors.

name: louisiana
sentence: Louisiana is a state in the Deep South region of the South Central United States.

name: louisiana
sentence: It is the 19th-smallest by area and the 25th most populous of the 50 US states.

name: louisiana
sentence: Louisiana is bordered by the state of Texas to the west, Arkansas to the north, Mississippi to the east, and the Gulf of Mexico to the south.

name: louisiana
sentence: A large part of its eastern boundary is demarcated by the Mississippi River.

name: louisiana
sentence: Louisiana is the only US state with political subdivisions termed parishes, which are equivalent to counties.

name: louisiana
sentence: The state's capital is Baton Rouge, and its largest city is New Orleans.

name: louisiana
sentence: Much of the state's lands were formed from sediment washed down the Mississippi River, leaving enormous deltas and vast areas of coastal marsh and swamp.

name: louisiana
sentence: These contain a rich southern biota

name: louisiana
sentence: There are also many species of tree frogs, and fish such as sturgeon and paddlefish.

name: louisiana
sentence: In more elevated areas, fire is a natural process in the landscape and has produced extensive areas of longleaf pine forest and wet savannas.

name: louisiana
sentence: These support an exceptionally large number of plant species, including many species of terrestrial orchids and carnivorous plants.

name: louisiana
sentence: Louisiana has more Native American tribes than any other southern state, including four that are federally recognized, ten that are state recognized, and four that have not received recognition.

name: louisiana
sentence: Some Louisiana urban environments have a multicultural, multilingual heritage, being so strongly influenced by a mixture of 18th-century French, Italian, Haitian, Spanish, French Canadian, Native American, and African cultures that they are considered to be exceptional in the US Before the American purchase of the territory in 1803, the present-day State of Louisiana had been both a French colony and for a brief period a Spanish one.

name: louisiana
sentence: In addition, colonists imported numerous African people as slaves in the 18th century.

name: louisiana
sentence: Many came from peoples of the same region of West Africa, thus concentrating their culture.

name: louisiana
sentence: In the post-Civil War environment, Anglo-Americans increased the pressure for Anglicization, and in 1921, English was for a time made the sole language of instruction in Louisiana schools before a policy of multilingualism was revived in 1974.

name: louisiana
sentence: There has never been an official language in Louisiana, and the state constitution enumerates "the right of the people to preserve, foster, and promote their respective historic, linguistic, and cultural origins".

name: louisiana
sentence: Like other states in the Deep South region, Louisiana frequently ranks low in terms of health, education, and development, and high in measures of poverty.

name: louisiana
sentence: In 2018, Louisiana was ranked as the least healthy state in the country, with high levels of drug-related deaths and excessive alcohol consumption, while it has had the highest homicide rate in the United States since at least the 1990s.

name: louisiana
sentence: Louisiana was named after Louis XIV, King of France from 1643 to 1715.

name: louisiana
sentence: When René-Robert Cavelier, Sieur de La Salle claimed the territory drained by the Mississippi River for France, he named it La Louisiane.

name: louisiana
sentence: The suffix ‑ana (or ‑ane) is a Latin suffix that can refer to "information relating to a particular individual, subject, or place".

name: louisiana
sentence: Thus, roughly, Louis + ana carries the idea of "related to Louis".

name: louisiana
sentence: Once part of the French Colonial Empire, the Louisiana Territory stretched from present-day Mobile Bay to just north of the present-day Canada–United States border, including a small part of what is now the Canadian provinces of Alberta and Saskatchewan.

name: louisiana
sentence: Louisiana was inhabited by Native Americans for many millennia before the arrival of Europeans in the 16th century.

name: louisiana
sentence: During the Middle Archaic period, Louisiana was the site of the earliest mound complex in North America and one of the earliest dated, complex constructions in the Americas, the Watson Brake site near present-day Monroe.

name: louisiana
sentence: An 11-mound complex, it was built about 5400 BP (3500 BC).

name: louisiana
sentence: The Middle Archaic sites of Caney and Frenchman's Bend have also been securely dated to 5600–5000 BP (3700–3100 BC), demonstrating that seasonal hunter-gatherers organized to build complex earthwork constructions in present-day northern Louisiana.

name: louisiana
sentence: These discoveries overturned previous assumptions in archaeology that such complex mounds were built only by cultures of more settled peoples who were dependent on maize cultivation.

name: louisiana
sentence: The Hedgepeth Site in Lincoln Parish is more recent, dated to 5200–4500 BP (3300–2600 BC).

name: louisiana
sentence: Nearly 2,000 years later, Poverty Point was built; it is the largest and best-known Late Archaic site in the state.

name: louisiana
sentence: The city of modern-day Epps developed near it.

name: louisiana
sentence: The Poverty Point culture may have reached its peak around 1500 BC, making it the first complex culture, and possibly the first tribal culture in North America.

name: louisiana
sentence: It lasted until approximately 700 BC.

name: louisiana
sentence: The Poverty Point culture was followed by the Tchefuncte and Lake Cormorant cultures of the Tchula period, local manifestations of Early Woodland period.

name: louisiana
sentence: The Tchefuncte culture were the first people in the area of Louisiana to make large amounts of pottery.

name: louisiana
sentence: These cultures lasted until AD 200.

name: louisiana
sentence: The Middle Woodland period started in Louisiana with the Marksville culture in the southern and eastern part of the state, reaching across the Mississippi River to the east around Natchez and the Fourche Maline culture in the northwestern part of the state.

name: louisiana
sentence: The Marksville culture was named after the Marksville Prehistoric Indian Site in Avoyelles Parish.

name: louisiana
sentence: These cultures were contemporaneous with the Hopewell cultures of present-day Ohio and Illinois, and participated in the Hopewell Exchange Network.

name: louisiana
sentence: Trade with peoples to the southwest brought the bow and arrow.

name: louisiana
sentence: The first burial mounds were built at this time.

name: louisiana
sentence: Political power began to be consolidated, as the first platform mounds at ritual centers were constructed for the developing hereditary political and religious leadership.

name: louisiana
sentence: By 400 the Late Woodland period had begun with the Baytown culture, Troyville culture, and Coastal Troyville during the Baytown Period and were succeeded by the Coles Creek cultures.

name: louisiana
sentence: Where the Baytown peoples built dispersed settlements, the Troyville people instead continued building major earthwork centers.

name: louisiana
sentence: Population increased dramatically and there is strong evidence of a growing cultural and political complexity.

name: louisiana
sentence: Many Coles Creek sites were erected over earlier Woodland period mortuary mounds.

name: louisiana
sentence: Scholars have speculated that emerging elites were symbolically and physically appropriating dead ancestors to emphasize and project their own authority.

name: louisiana
sentence: The Mississippian period in Louisiana was when the Plaquemine and the Caddoan Mississippian cultures developed, and the peoples adopted extensive maize agriculture, cultivating different strains of the plant by saving seeds, selecting for certain characteristics, etc.

name: louisiana
sentence: The Plaquemine culture in the lower Mississippi River Valley in western Mississippi and eastern Louisiana began in 1200 and continued to about 1600.

name: louisiana
sentence: Examples in Louisiana include the Medora Site, the archaeological type site for the culture in West Baton Rouge Parish whose characteristics helped define the culture, the Atchafalaya Basin Mounds in St Mary Parish, the Fitzhugh Mounds in Madison Parish, the Scott Place Mounds in Union Parish, and the Sims Site in St Charles Parish.

name: louisiana
sentence: Plaquemine culture was contemporaneous with the Middle Mississippian culture that is represented by its largest settlement, the Cahokia site in Illinois east of St. Louis, Missouri.

name: louisiana
sentence: At its peak Cahokia is estimated to have had a population of more than 20,000.

name: louisiana
sentence: The Plaquemine culture is considered ancestral to the historic Natchez and Taensa peoples, whose descendants encountered Europeans in the colonial era.

name: louisiana
sentence: By 1000 in the northwestern part of the state, the Fourche Maline culture had evolved into the Caddoan Mississippian culture.

name: louisiana
sentence: The Caddoan Mississippians occupied a large territory, including what is now eastern Oklahoma, western Arkansas, northeast Texas, and northwest Louisiana.

name: louisiana
sentence: Archaeological evidence has demonstrated that the cultural continuity is unbroken from prehistory to the present.

name: louisiana
sentence: The Caddo and related Caddo-language speakers in prehistoric times and at first European contact were the direct ancestors of the modern Caddo Nation of Oklahoma of today.

name: louisiana
sentence: Significant Caddoan Mississippian archaeological sites in Louisiana include Belcher Mound Site in Caddo Parish and Gahagan Mounds Site in Red River Parish.

name: louisiana
sentence: Many current place names in Louisiana, including Atchafalaya, Natchitouches (now spelled Natchitoches), Caddo, Houma, Tangipahoa, and Avoyel (as Avoyelles), are transliterations of those used in various Native American languages.

name: louisiana
sentence: The first European explorers to visit Louisiana came in 1528 when a Spanish expedition led by Pánfilo de Narváez located the mouth of the Mississippi River.

name: louisiana
sentence: In 1542, Hernando de Soto's expedition skirted to the north and west of the state (encountering Caddo and Tunica groups) and then followed the Mississippi River down to the Gulf of Mexico in 1543.

name: louisiana
sentence: Spanish interest in Louisiana faded away for a century and a half.

name: louisiana
sentence: In the late 17th century, French and French Canadian expeditions, which included sovereign, religious and commercial aims, established a foothold on the Mississippi River and Gulf Coast.

name: louisiana
sentence: With its first settlements, France laid claim to a vast region of North America and set out to establish a commercial empire and French nation stretching from the Gulf of Mexico to Canada.

name: louisiana
sentence: In 1682, the French explorer Robert Cavelier de La Salle named the region Louisiana to honor King Louis XIV of France.

name: louisiana
sentence: The first permanent settlement, Fort Maurepas (at what is now Ocean Springs, Mississippi, near Biloxi), was founded in 1699 by Pierre Le Moyne d'Iberville, a French military officer from Canada.

name: louisiana
sentence: By then the French had also built a small fort at the mouth of the Mississippi at a settlement they named La Balise (or La Balize), "seamark" in French.

name: louisiana
sentence: By 1721 they built a 62-foot (19 m) wooden lighthouse-type structure here to guide ships on the river.

name: louisiana
sentence: A royal ordinance of 1722—following the Crown's transfer of the Illinois Country's governance from Canada to Louisiana—may have featured the broadest definition of Louisiana: all land claimed by France south of the Great Lakes between the Rocky Mountains and the Alleghenies.

name: louisiana
sentence: A generation later, trade conflicts between Canada and Louisiana led to a more defined boundary between the French colonies; in 1745, Louisiana governor general Vaudreuil set the northern and eastern bounds of his domain as the Wabash valley up to the mouth of the Vermilion River (near present-day Danville, Illinois); from there, northwest to le Rocher on the Illinois River, and from there west to the mouth of the Rock River (at present day Rock Island, Illinois).

name: louisiana
sentence: Thus, Vincennes and Peoria were the limit of Louisiana's reach; the outposts at Ouiatenon (on the upper Wabash near present-day Lafayette, Indiana), Chicago, Fort Miamis (near present-day Fort Wayne, Indiana), and Prairie du Chien, Wisconsin, operated as dependencies of Canada.

name: louisiana
sentence: The settlement of Natchitoches (along the Red River in present-day northwest Louisiana) was established in 1714 by Louis Juchereau de St. Denis, making it the oldest permanent European settlement in the modern state of Louisiana.

name: louisiana
sentence: The French settlement had two purposes: to establish trade with the Spanish in Texas via the Old San Antonio Road, and to deter Spanish advances into Louisiana.

name: louisiana
sentence: The settlement soon became a flourishing river port and crossroads, giving rise to vast cotton kingdoms along the river that were worked by imported African slaves.

name: louisiana
sentence: Over time, planters developed large plantations and built fine homes in a growing town.

name: louisiana
sentence: This became a pattern repeated in New Orleans and other places, although the commodity crop in the south was primarily sugar cane.

name: louisiana
sentence: Louisiana's French settlements contributed to further exploration and outposts, concentrated along the banks of the Mississippi and its major tributaries, from Louisiana to as far north as the region called the Illinois Country, around present-day St. Louis, Missouri.

name: louisiana
sentence: The latter was settled by French colonists from Illinois.

name: louisiana
sentence: Initially, Mobile and then Biloxi served as the capital of La Louisiane.

name: louisiana
sentence: Recognizing the importance of the Mississippi River to trade and military interests, and wanting to protect the capital from severe coastal storms, France developed New Orleans from 1722 as the seat of civilian and military authority south of the Great Lakes.

name: louisiana
sentence: From then until the United States acquired the territory in the Louisiana Purchase of 1803, France and Spain jockeyed for control of New Orleans and the lands west of the Mississippi.

name: louisiana
sentence: In the 1720s, German immigrants settled along the Mississippi River, in a region referred to as the German Coast.

name: louisiana
sentence: France ceded most of its territory to the east of the Mississippi to Great Britain in 1763, in the aftermath of Britain's victory in the Seven Years' War (generally referred to in North America as the French and Indian War).

name: louisiana
sentence: The rest of Louisiana, including the area around New Orleans and the parishes around Lake Pontchartrain, had become a colony of Spain by the Treaty of Fontainebleau (1762).

name: louisiana
sentence: The transfer of power on either side of the river would be delayed until later in the decade.

name: louisiana
sentence: In 1765, during Spanish rule, several thousand French-speaking refugees from the region of Acadia (now Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Prince Edward Island, Canada) made their way to Louisiana after having been expelled from their homelands by the British during the French and Indian War.

name: louisiana
sentence: They settled chiefly in the southwestern Louisiana region now called Acadiana.

name: louisiana
sentence: The governor Luis de Unzaga y Amézaga, eager to gain more settlers, welcomed the Acadian refugees, the ancestors of Louisiana's Cajuns.

name: louisiana
sentence: Spanish Canary Islanders, called Isleños, emigrated from the Canary Islands of Spain to Louisiana under the Spanish crown between 1778 and 1783.

name: louisiana
sentence: In 1800, France's Napoleon Bonaparte reacquired Louisiana from Spain in the Treaty of San Ildefonso, an arrangement kept secret for two years.

name: louisiana
sentence: Jean-Baptiste Le Moyne, Sieur de Bienville brought the first two African slaves to Louisiana in 1708, transporting them from a French colony in the West Indies.

name: louisiana
sentence: In 1709, French financier Antoine Crozat obtained a monopoly of commerce in La Louisiane, which extended from the Gulf of Mexico to what is now Illinois.

name: louisiana
sentence: "That concession allowed him to bring in a cargo of blacks from Africa every year," the British historian Hugh Thomas wrote.

name: louisiana
sentence: Physical conditions, including disease, were so harsh there was high mortality among both the colonists and the slaves, resulting in continuing demand and importation of slaves.

name: louisiana
sentence: Starting in 1719, traders began to import slaves in higher numbers; two French ships, the Du Maine and the Aurore, arrived in New Orleans carrying more than 500 black slaves coming from Africa.

name: louisiana
sentence: Previous slaves in Louisiana had been transported from French colonies in the West Indies.

name: louisiana
sentence: By the end of 1721, New Orleans counted 1,256 inhabitants, of whom about half were slaves.

name: louisiana
sentence: In 1724, the French government issued a law called the Code Noir ("Black Code" in English) which "regulate[d] the interaction of whites [blancs] and blacks [noirs] in its colony of Louisiana (which was much larger than the current state of Louisiana).

name: louisiana
sentence: The law consisted of 57 articles, which regulated religion in the colony, outlawed "interracial" marriages (those between people of different skin color, the varying shades of which were also defined by law), restricted manumission, outlined legal punishment of slaves for various offenses, and defined some obligations of owners to their slaves.

name: louisiana
sentence: The main intent of the French government was to assert control over the slave system of agriculture in Louisiana and to impose restrictions on slaveowners there.

name: louisiana
sentence: In practice, the Code Noir was exceedingly difficult to enforce from afar.

name: louisiana
sentence: Some priests continued to perform interracial marriage ceremonies, for example, and some slaveholders continued to manumit slaves without permission while others punished slaves brutally.

name: louisiana
sentence: Article II of the Code Noir of 1724 required owners to provide their slaves with religious education in the state religion, Roman Catholicism.

name: louisiana
sentence: Sunday was to be a day of rest for slaves.

name: louisiana
sentence: On days off, slaves were expected to feed and take care of themselves.

name: louisiana
sentence: During the 1740s economic crisis in the colony, owners had trouble feeding their slaves and themselves.

name: louisiana
sentence: Giving them time off also effectively gave more power to slaves, who started cultivating their own gardens and crafting items for sale as their own property.

name: louisiana
sentence: They began to participate in the economic development of the colony while at the same time increasing independence and self-subsistence.

name: louisiana
sentence: Article VI of the Code Noir forbade mixed marriages, forbade but did little to protect slave women from rape by their owners, overseers or other slaves.

name: louisiana
sentence: On balance, the Code benefitted the owners but had more protections and flexibility than did the institution of slavery in the southern Thirteen Colonies.

name: louisiana
sentence: The Louisiana Black Code of 1806 made the cruel punishment of slaves a crime, but owners and overseers were seldom prosecuted for such acts.

name: louisiana
sentence: Fugitive slaves, called maroons, could easily hide in the backcountry of the bayous and survive in small settlements.

name: louisiana
