sentence: Influenced by a changing economy, revolutionary ideals, and preaching by ministers, numerous planters in Maryland freed their slaves in the 20 years after the Revolutionary War.

name: maryland
sentence: Across the Upper South the free black population increased from less than 1% before the war to 14% by 1810.

name: maryland
sentence: Abolitionist Harriet Tubman was born a slave during this time in Dorchester County, Maryland.

name: maryland
sentence: During the War of 1812, the British military attempted to capture Baltimore, which was protected by Fort McHenry.

name: maryland
sentence: During this bombardment the song "Star Spangled Banner" was written by Francis Scott Key; it was later adopted as the national anthem.

name: maryland
sentence: The National Road (US Hwy 40 today) was authorized in 1817 and ran from Baltimore to St. Louis—the first federal highway.

name: maryland
sentence: The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad (B&O) was the first chartered railroad in the United States.

name: maryland
sentence: It opened its first section of track for regular operation in 1830 between Baltimore and Ellicott City, and in 1852 it became the first rail line to reach the Ohio River from the eastern seaboard.

name: maryland
sentence: The state remained with the Union during the Civil War, due in significant part to demographics and Federal intervention.

name: maryland
sentence: The 1860 census, held shortly before the outbreak of the civil war, showed that 49% of Maryland's African Americans were free blacks.

name: maryland
sentence: Governor Thomas Holliday Hicks suspended the state legislature, and to help ensure the election of a new pro-union governor and legislature, President Abraham Lincoln had a number of its pro-slavery politicians arrested, including the Mayor of Baltimore, George William Brown; suspended several civil liberties, including habeas corpus; and ordered artillery placed on Federal Hill overlooking Baltimore.

name: maryland
sentence: Historians debate the constitutionality of these wartime actions, and the suspension of civil liberties was later deemed illegal by the US Supreme Court.

name: maryland
sentence: In April 1861 Federal units and state regiments were attacked as they marched through Baltimore, sparking the Baltimore riot of 1861, the first bloodshed in the Civil War.

name: maryland
sentence: Of the 115,000 men from Maryland who joined the military during the Civil War, 85,000, or 77%, joined the Union army, while the remainder joined the Confederate Army.

name: maryland
sentence: The largest and most significant battle in the state was the Battle of Antietam on September 17, 1862, near Sharpsburg.

name: maryland
sentence: Although a tactical draw, the battle was considered a strategic Union victory and a turning point of the war.

name: maryland
sentence: A new state constitution in 1864 abolished slavery and Maryland was first recognized as a "Free State" in that context.

name: maryland
sentence: Following passage of constitutional amendments that granted voting rights to freedmen, in 1867 the state extended suffrage to non-white males.

name: maryland
sentence: The Democratic Party rapidly regained power in the state from Republicans.

name: maryland
sentence: Democrats replaced the Constitution of 1864 with the Constitution of 1867.

name: maryland
sentence: Following the end of Reconstruction in 1877, Democrats devised means of disenfranchising blacks, initially by physical intimidation and voter fraud, later by constitutional amendments and laws.

name: maryland
sentence: Blacks and immigrants, however, resisted Democratic Party disfranchisement efforts in the state.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland blacks were part of a biracial Republican coalition elected to state government in 1896–1904 and comprised 20% of the electorate.

name: maryland
sentence: Compared to some other states, blacks were better established both before and after the civil war.

name: maryland
sentence: Nearly half the black population was free before the war, and some had accumulated property.

name: maryland
sentence: Half the population lived in cities.

name: maryland
sentence: Literacy was high among blacks and, as Democrats crafted means to exclude them, suffrage campaigns helped reach blacks and teach them how to resist.

name: maryland
sentence: Whites did impose racial segregation in public facilities and Jim Crow laws, which effectively lasted until passage of federal civil rights legislation in the mid-1960s.

name: maryland
sentence: Baltimore grew significantly during the Industrial Revolution, due in large part to its seaport and good railroad connections, attracting European immigrant labor.

name: maryland
sentence: Many manufacturing businesses were established in the Baltimore area after the Civil War.

name: maryland
sentence: Baltimore businessmen, including Johns Hopkins, Enoch Pratt, George Peabody, and Henry Walters, founded notable city institutions that bear their names, including a university, library, music school and art museum.

name: maryland
sentence: Cumberland was Maryland's second-largest city in the 19th century.

name: maryland
sentence: Nearby supplies of natural resources along with railroads fostered its growth into a major manufacturing center.

name: maryland
sentence: The Progressive Era of the late 19th and early 20th centuries brought political reforms.

name: maryland
sentence: In a series of laws passed between 1892 and 1908, reformers worked for standard state-issued ballots (rather than those distributed and marked by the parties); obtained closed voting booths to prevent party workers from "assisting" voters; initiated primary elections to keep party bosses from selecting candidates; and had candidates listed without party symbols, which discouraged the illiterate from participating.

name: maryland
sentence: These measures worked against ill-educated whites and blacks.

name: maryland
sentence: Blacks resisted such efforts, with suffrage groups conducting voter education.Blacks defeated three efforts to disenfranchise them, making alliances with immigrants to resist various Democratic campaigns.

name: maryland
sentence: Disenfranchisement bills in 1905, 1907, and 1911 were rebuffed, in large part because of black opposition.

name: maryland
sentence: Blacks comprised 20% of the electorate and immigrants comprised 15%, and the legislature had difficulty devising requirements against blacks that did not also disadvantage immigrants.

name: maryland
sentence: The Progressive Era also brought reforms in working conditions for Maryland's labor force.

name: maryland
sentence: In 1902, the state regulated conditions in mines; outlawed child laborers under the age of 12; mandated compulsory school attendance; and enacted the nation's first workers' compensation law.

name: maryland
sentence: The workers' compensation law was overturned in the courts, but was redrafted and finally enacted in 1910.

name: maryland
sentence: The Great Baltimore Fire of 1904 burned for more than 30 hours, destroying 1,526 buildings and spanning 70 city blocks.

name: maryland
sentence: More than 1,231 firefighters worked to bring the blaze under control.

name: maryland
sentence: With the nation's entry into World War I in 1917, new military bases such as Camp Meade, the Aberdeen Proving Ground, and the Edgewood Arsenal were established.

name: maryland
sentence: Existing facilities, including Fort McHenry, were greatly expanded.

name: maryland
sentence: After Georgia congressman William D. Upshaw criticized Maryland openly in 1923 for not passing Prohibition laws, Baltimore Sun editor Hamilton Owens coined the "Free State" nickname for Maryland in that context, which was popularized by H. L. Mencken in a series of newspaper editorials.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland's urban and rural communities had different experiences during the Great Depression.

name: maryland
sentence: The "Bonus Army" marched through the state in 1932 on its way to Washington, D.C. Maryland instituted its first income tax in 1937 to generate revenue for schools and welfare.

name: maryland
sentence: Passenger and freight steamboat service, once important throughout Chesapeake Bay and its many tributary rivers, ended in 1962.

name: maryland
sentence: Baltimore was a major war production center during World War II.

name: maryland
sentence: The biggest operations were Bethlehem Steel's Fairfield Yard, which built Liberty ships; and Glenn Martin, an aircraft manufacturer.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland experienced population growth following World War II.

name: maryland
sentence: Beginning in the 1960s, as suburban growth took hold around Washington, D.C. and Baltimore, the state began to take on a more mid-Atlantic culture as opposed to the traditionally Southern and Tidewater culture that previously dominated most of the state.

name: maryland
sentence: Agricultural tracts gave way to residential communities, some of them carefully planned such as Columbia, St. Charles, and Montgomery Village.

name: maryland
sentence: Concurrently the Interstate Highway System was built throughout the state, most notably I-95, I-695, and the Capital Beltway, altering travel patterns.

name: maryland
sentence: In 1952, the eastern and western halves of Maryland were linked for the first time by the Chesapeake Bay Bridge, which replaced a nearby ferry service.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland's regions experienced economic changes following WWII.

name: maryland
sentence: Heavy manufacturing declined in Baltimore.

name: maryland
sentence: In Maryland's four westernmost counties, industrial, railroad, and coal mining jobs declined.

name: maryland
sentence: On the lower Eastern Shore, family farms were bought up by major concerns and large-scale poultry farms and vegetable farming became prevalent.

name: maryland
sentence: In Southern Maryland, tobacco farming nearly vanished due to suburban development and a state tobacco buy-out program in the 1990s.

name: maryland
sentence: In an effort to reverse depopulation due to the loss of working-class industries, Baltimore initiated urban renewal projects in the 1960s with Charles Center and the Baltimore World Trade Center.

name: maryland
sentence: Some resulted in the break-up of intact residential neighborhoods, producing social volatility, and some older residential areas around the harbor have had units renovated and have become popular with new populations.

name: maryland
sentence: The United States Census Bureau estimates that the population of Maryland was 6,045,680 on July 1, 2019, a 4.71% increase since the 2010 United States Census and an increase of 2,962, from the prior year.

name: maryland
sentence: This includes a natural increase since the last census of 269,166 (464,251 births minus 275,093 deaths) and an increase due to net migration of 116,713 people into the state.

name: maryland
sentence: Immigration from outside the United States resulted in a net increase of 129,730 people, and migration within the country produced a net loss of 13,017 people.

name: maryland
sentence: The center of population of Maryland is located on the county line between Anne Arundel County and Howard County, in the unincorporated community of Jessup.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland's history as a border state has led it to exhibit characteristics of both the Northern and the Southern regions of the United States.

name: maryland
sentence: Generally, rural Western Maryland between the West Virginian Panhandle and Pennsylvania has an Appalachian culture; the Southern and Eastern Shore regions of Maryland embody a Southern culture,while densely populated Central Maryland—radiating outward from Baltimore and Washington, D.C.—has more in common with that of the Northeast.The US Census Bureau designates Maryland as one of the South Atlantic States, but it is commonly associated with the Mid-Atlantic States and/or Northeastern United States by other federal agencies, the media, and some residents.

name: maryland
sentence: As of 2011, 58.0 percent of Maryland's population younger than age 1 were minority background.

name: maryland
sentence: Note: Births in table don't add up because Hispanics are counted both by their ethnicity and by their race, giving a higher overall number.

name: maryland
sentence: Spanish (including Spanish Creole) is the second most spoken language in Maryland, after English.

name: maryland
sentence: The third and fourth most spoken languages are French (including Patois and Cajun) and Chinese.

name: maryland
sentence: Other commonly spoken languages include various African languages, Korean, German, Tagalog, Russian, Vietnamese, Italian, various Asian languages, Persian, Hindi and other Indic languages, Greek and Arabic.

name: maryland
sentence: Most of the population of Maryland lives in the central region of the state, in the Baltimore metropolitan area and Washington metropolitan area, both of which are part of the Baltimore–Washington metropolitan area.The majority of Maryland's population is concentrated in the cities and suburbs surrounding Washington, D.C., as well as in and around Maryland's most populous city, Baltimore.

name: maryland
sentence: Historically, these and many other Maryland cities developed along the Fall Line, the line along which rivers, brooks, and streams are interrupted by rapids and/or waterfalls.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland's capital city, Annapolis, is one exception to this pattern, since it lies along the banks of the Severn River, close to where it empties into the Chesapeake Bay.

name: maryland
sentence: The Eastern Shore is less populous and more rural, as are the counties of western Maryland.

name: maryland
sentence: The two westernmost counties of Maryland, Allegany and Garrett, are mountainous and sparsely populated, resembling West Virginia and Appalachia more than they do the rest of the state.

name: maryland
sentence: Both eastern and western Maryland are, however, dotted with cities of regional importance, such as Ocean City, Princess Anne, and Salisbury on the Eastern Shore and Cumberland, Frostburg, and Hancock in Western Maryland.Southern Maryland is still somewhat rural, but suburbanization from Washington, D.C. has encroached significantly since the 1960s; important local population centers include Lexington Park, Prince Frederick, California, and Waldorf.

name: maryland
sentence: In 1970 the Census Bureau reported Maryland's population as 17.8 percent African-American and 80.4 percent non-Hispanic White.

name: maryland
sentence: African Americans form a sizable portion of the state's population, nearly 30 percent in 2010.

name: maryland
sentence: Most are descendants of people transported to the area as slaves from West Africa, and many are of mixed race, including European and Native American ancestry.

name: maryland
sentence: Concentrations of African Americans live in Baltimore City, Prince George's County, a suburb of Washington, D.C., where many work; Charles County, western parts of Baltimore County, and the southern Eastern Shore.

name: maryland
sentence: New residents of African descent include 20th-century and later immigrants from Nigeria, particularly of the Igbo and Yoruba tribes.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland also hosts populations from other African and Caribbean nations.

name: maryland
sentence: Many immigrants from the Horn of Africa have settled in Maryland, with large communities existing in the suburbs of Washington, D.C. (particularly Montgomery County and Prince George's County) and the city of Baltimore.

name: maryland
sentence: The Greater Washington area has the largest population of Ethiopians outside of Africa.

name: maryland
sentence: The Ethiopian community of Greater DC was historically based in Washington, D.C.'s Adams Morgan and Shaw neighborhoods, but as the community has grown, many Ethiopians have settled in Silver Spring.

name: maryland
sentence: The Washington, D.C. metropolitan area is also home to large Eritrean and Somali communities.

name: maryland
sentence: The top reported ancestries by Maryland residents are: German (15%), Irish (11%), English (8%), American (7%), Italian (6%), and Polish (3%).

name: maryland
sentence: Irish American populations can be found throughout the Baltimore area, and the Northern and Eastern suburbs of Washington, D.C. in Maryland (descendants of those who moved out to the suburbs of Washington's once predominantly Irish neighborhoods), as well as Western Maryland, where Irish immigrant laborers helped to build the B & O Railroad.

name: maryland
sentence: Smaller but much older Irish populations can be found in Southern Maryland, with some roots dating as far back as the early Maryland colony.

name: maryland
sentence: This population, however, still remains culturally very active and yearly festivals are held.

name: maryland
sentence: A large percentage of the population of the Eastern Shore and Southern Maryland are descendants of British American ancestry.

name: maryland
sentence: The Eastern Shore was settled by Protestants, chiefly Methodist and the southern counties were initially settled by English Catholics.

name: maryland
sentence: Western and northern Maryland have large German-American populations.

name: maryland
sentence: More recent European immigrants of the late 19th and early 20th century settled first in Baltimore, attracted to its industrial jobs.

name: maryland
sentence: Many of their ethnic Italian, Polish, Czech, Lithuanian, and Greek descendants still live in the area.

name: maryland
sentence: Large ethnic minorities include Eastern Europeans such as Croatians, Belarusians, Russians and Ukrainians.

name: maryland
sentence: The shares of European immigrants born in Eastern Europe increased significantly between 1990 and 2010.

name: maryland
sentence: Following the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Yugoslavia, and Czechoslovakia, many immigrants from Eastern Europe came to the United States—12 percent of whom currently reside in Maryland.

name: maryland
sentence: Hispanic immigrants of the later 20th century have settled in Aspen Hill, Hyattsville/Langley Park, Glenmont/Wheaton, Bladensburg, Riverdale Park, Gaithersburg, as well as Highlandtown and Greektown in East Baltimore.

name: maryland
sentence: Salvadorans are the largest Hispanic group in Maryland.

name: maryland
sentence: Other Hispanic groups with significant populations in the state include Mexicans and Puerto Ricans and Hondurans.

name: maryland
sentence: Though the Salvadoran population is more concentrated in the area around Washington, D.C., and the Puerto Rican population is more concentrated in the Baltimore area, all other major Hispanic groups in the state are evenly dispersed between these two areas.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland has one of the most diverse Hispanic populations in the country, with significant populations from various Caribbean and Central American nations.

name: maryland
sentence: Asian Americans are concentrated in the suburban counties surrounding Washington, D.C. and in Howard County, with Korean American and Taiwanese American communities in Rockville, Gaithersburg, and Germantown and a Filipino American community in Fort Washington.

name: maryland
sentence: Numerous Indian Americans live across the state, especially in central Maryland.

name: maryland
sentence: Attracting educated Asians and Africans to the professional jobs in the region, Maryland has the fifth-largest proportions of racial minorities in the country.

name: maryland
sentence: In 2006 645,744 were counted as foreign born, which represents mainly people from Latin America and Asia.

name: maryland
sentence: About four percent are undocumented immigrants.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland also has a large Korean American population.

name: maryland
sentence: In fact, 1.7 percent are Korean, while as a whole, almost 6.0 percent are Asian.

name: maryland
sentence: According to The Williams Institute's analysis of the 2010 US Census, 12,538 same-sex couples are living in Maryland, representing 5.8 same-sex couples per 1,000 households.

name: maryland
sentence: As of 2019, non-Hispanic white Americans were 49.8% of Maryland's population (White Americans, including White Hispanics, were 57.3%), making Maryland a majority minority state.

name: maryland
sentence: 50.2% of Maryland's population is non-white and/or Hispanic/Latino, the highest percentage of any state on the East Coast and the highest percentage after the majority minority states of Hawaii, New Mexico, Texas, California and Nevada.

name: maryland
sentence: By 2031, minorities are projected to become the majority of voting eligible residents of Maryland.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland has been historically prominent to American Catholic tradition because the English colony of Maryland was intended by George Calvert as a haven for English Catholics.

name: maryland
sentence: Baltimore was the seat of the first Catholic bishop in the US (1789), and Emmitsburg was the home and burial place of the first American-born citizen to be canonized, St. Elizabeth Ann Seton.

name: maryland
sentence: Georgetown University, the first Catholic University, was founded in 1789 in what was then part of Maryland.

name: maryland
sentence: The Basilica of the National Shrine of the Assumption of the Virgin Mary in Baltimore was the first Roman Catholic cathedral built in the United States, and the Archbishop of Baltimore is, albeit without formal primacy, the United States' quasi-primate, and often a cardinal.

name: maryland
sentence: Among the immigrants of the 19th and 20th century from eastern and southern Europe were many Catholics.

name: maryland
sentence: Despite its historic relevance to the Catholic Church in the United States, the percentage of Catholics in the state of Maryland is below the national average of 20%.

name: maryland
sentence: Demographically, both Protestants and those identifying no religion are more numerous than Catholics.

name: maryland
sentence: According to Pew Research Center, 69 percent of Maryland's population identifies themselves as Christian.

name: maryland
sentence: Nearly 52% of the adult population are Protestants.

name: maryland
sentence: Following Protestantism, Catholicism is the second largest religious affiliation, comprising 15% percent of the population.

name: maryland
sentence: Amish/Mennonite communities are found in St. Mary's, Garrett, and Cecil counties.

name: maryland
sentence: Judaism is the largest non-Christian religion in Maryland with 241,000 adherents, or four percent of the total population.

name: maryland
sentence: Jews are numerous throughout Montgomery County and in Pikesville and Owings Mills northwest of Baltimore.

name: maryland
sentence: An estimated 81,500 Jewish Americans live in Montgomery County, constituting approximately 10% of the total population.

name: maryland
sentence: The Seventh-day Adventist Church's world headquarters and Ahmadiyya Muslims' national headquarters are located in Silver Spring, just outside the District of Columbia.

name: maryland
sentence: The Bureau of Economic Analysis estimates that Maryland's gross state product in 2016 was $382.4 billion.

name: maryland
sentence: However, Maryland has been using Genuine Progress Indicator, an indicator of well-being, to guide the state's development, rather than relying only on growth indicators like GDP.

name: maryland
sentence: According to the US Census Bureau, Maryland households are currently the wealthiest in the country, with a 2013 median household income of $72,483 which puts it ahead of New Jersey and Connecticut, which are second and third respectively.

name: maryland
sentence: Two of Maryland's counties, Howard and Montgomery, are the second and eleventh wealthiest counties in the nation respectively.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland has the most millionaires per capita in 2013, with a ratio of 7.7 percent.

name: maryland
sentence: Also, the state's poverty rate of 7.8 percent is the lowest in the country.

name: maryland
sentence: per capita personal income in 2006 was $43,500, fifth in the nation.

name: maryland
sentence: As of February 2018, the state's unemployment rate was 4.2 percent.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland's economy benefits from the state's proximity to the federal government in Washington, D.C. with an emphasis on technical and administrative tasks for the defense/aerospace industry and bio-research laboratories, as well as staffing of satellite government headquarters in the suburban or exurban Baltimore/Washington area.

name: maryland
sentence: Ft. Meade serves as the headquarters of the Defense Information Systems Agency, United States Cyber Command, and the National Security Agency/Central Security Service.

name: maryland
sentence: In addition, a number of educational and medical research institutions are located in the state.

name: maryland
sentence: In fact, the various components of The Johns Hopkins University and its medical research facilities are now the largest single employer in the Baltimore area.

name: maryland
sentence: Altogether, white collar technical and administrative workers comprise 25 percent of Maryland's labor force, attributable in part to nearby Maryland being a part of the Washington Metro Area where the federal government office employment is relatively high.

name: maryland
sentence: Manufacturing, while large in dollar value, is highly diversified with no sub-sector contributing over 20 percent of the total.

name: maryland
sentence: Typical forms of manufacturing include electronics, computer equipment, and chemicals.

name: maryland
sentence: The once mighty primary metals sub-sector, which once included what was then the largest steel factory in the world at Sparrows Point, still exists, but is pressed with foreign competition, bankruptcies, and mergers.

name: maryland
sentence: During World War II the Glenn Martin Company (now part of Lockheed Martin) airplane factory employed some 40,000 people.

name: maryland
sentence: Mining other than construction materials is virtually limited to coal, which is located in the mountainous western part of the state.

name: maryland
sentence: The brownstone quarries in the east, which gave Baltimore and Washington much of their characteristic architecture in the mid-19th century, were once a predominant natural resource.

name: maryland
sentence: Historically, there used to be small gold-mining operations in Maryland, some near Washington, but these no longer exist.

name: maryland
sentence: One major service activity is transportation, centered on the Port of Baltimore and its related rail and trucking access.

name: maryland
sentence: The port ranked 17th in the US by tonnage in 2008.

name: maryland
sentence: Although the port handles a wide variety of products, the most typical imports are raw materials and bulk commodities, such as iron ore, petroleum, sugar, and fertilizers, often distributed to the relatively close manufacturing centers of the inland Midwest via good overland transportation.

name: maryland
sentence: The port also receives several brands of imported motor vehicles and is the number one auto port in the US

name: maryland
sentence: Baltimore City is among the top 15 largest ports in the nation, and was one of six major US ports that were part of the February 2006 controversy over the Dubai Ports World deal.

name: maryland
sentence: The state as a whole is heavily industrialized, with a booming economy and influential technology centers.

name: maryland
sentence: Its computer industries are some of the most sophisticated in the United States, and the federal government has invested heavily in the area.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland is home to several large military bases and scores of high-level government jobs.

name: maryland
sentence: The Chesapeake and Delaware Canal is a 14 miles (23 km) canal on the Eastern Shore that connects the waters of the Delaware River with those of the Chesapeake Bay, and in particular with the Port of Baltimore, carrying 40 percent of the port's ship traffic.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland has a large food-production sector.

name: maryland
sentence: A large component of this is commercial fishing, centered in the Chesapeake Bay, but also including activity off the short Atlantic seacoast.

name: maryland
sentence: The largest catches by species are the blue crab, oysters, striped bass, and menhaden.

name: maryland
sentence: The Bay also has overwintering waterfowl in its wildlife refuges.

name: maryland
sentence: The waterfowl support a tourism sector of sportsmen.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland has large areas of fertile agricultural land in its coastal and Piedmont zones, though this land use is being encroached upon by urbanization.

name: maryland
sentence: Agriculture is oriented to dairy farming (especially in foothill and piedmont areas) for nearby large city milksheads plus specialty perishable horticulture crops, such as cucumbers, watermelons, sweet corn, tomatoes, muskmelons, squash, and peas (Source:USDA Crop Profiles).

name: maryland
sentence: The southern counties of the western shoreline of Chesapeake Bay are warm enough to support a tobacco cash crop zone, which has existed since early Colonial times but declined greatly after a state government buyout in the 1990s.

name: maryland
sentence: There is also a large automated chicken-farming sector in the state's southeastern part

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland's food-processing plants are the most significant type of manufacturing by value in the state.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland is a major center for life sciences research and development.

name: maryland
sentence: With more than 400 biotechnology companies located there, Maryland is the fourth-largest nexus in this field in the United States.

name: maryland
sentence: Institutions and government agencies with an interest in research and development located in Maryland include the Johns Hopkins University, the Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory, more than one campus of the University System of Maryland, Goddard Space Flight Center, the United States Census Bureau, the National Institutes of Health (NIH), the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH), the Walter Reed National Military Medical Center, the federal Food and Drug Administration (FDA), the Howard Hughes Medical Institute, the Celera Genomics company, the J. Craig Venter Institute (JCVI), and AstraZeneca (formerly MedImmune).

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland is home to defense contractor Emergent BioSolutions, which manufactures and provides an anthrax vaccine to US government military personnel.

name: maryland
sentence: Tourism is popular in Maryland.

name: maryland
sentence: Many tourists visit Baltimore, the beaches of the Eastern Shore, and the nature of western Maryland.

name: maryland
sentence: Attractions in Baltimore include the Harborplace, the Baltimore Aquarium, Fort McHenry, as well as the Camden Yards baseball stadium.Ocean City on the Atlantic Coast has been a popular beach destination in summer, particularly since the Chesapeake Bay Bridge was built in 1952 connecting the Eastern Shore to the more populated Maryland cities.

name: maryland
sentence: The state capital of Annapolis offers sites such as the state capitol building, the historic district, and the waterfront.Maryland also has several sites of interest to military history, given Maryland's role in the American Civil War and in the War of 1812.

name: maryland
sentence: Other attractions include the historic and picturesque towns along the Chesapeake Bay, such as Saint Mary's, Maryland's first colonial settlement and original capital.

name: maryland
sentence: As of 2017, the top two health insurers including all types of insurance were CareFirst BlueCross BlueShield with 47% market share followed by UnitedHealth Group at 15%.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland has experimented with healthcare payment reforms, notably beginning in the 1970s with an all-payer rate setting program regulated by the Health Services Cost Review Commission.

name: maryland
sentence: In 2014, it switched to a global budget revenue system, whereby hospitals receive a capitated payment to care for their population.

name: maryland
sentence: The Maryland Department of Transportation oversees most transportation in the state through its various administration-level agencies.

name: maryland
sentence: The independent Maryland Transportation Authority maintains and operates the state's eight toll facilities.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland's Interstate highways include 110 miles (180 km) of Interstate 95 (I-95), which enters the northeast portion of the state, travels through Baltimore, and becomes part of the eastern section of the Capital Beltway to the Woodrow Wilson Bridge.

name: maryland
sentence: I-68 travels 81 miles (130 km), connecting the western portions of the state to I-70 at the small town of Hancock.

name: maryland
sentence: I-70 enters from Pennsylvania north of Hancock and continues east for 93 miles (150 km) to Baltimore, connecting Hagerstown and Frederick along the way.

name: maryland
sentence: I-83 has 34 miles (55 km) in Maryland and connects Baltimore to southern central Pennsylvania (Harrisburg and York, Pennsylvania).

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland also has an 11-mile (18 km) portion of I-81 that travels through the state near Hagerstown.

name: maryland
sentence: I-97, fully contained within Anne Arundel County and the shortest (17.6 miles (28.3 km)) one- or two-digit interstate highway in the contiguous US, connects the Baltimore area to the Annapolis area.

name: maryland
sentence: There are also several auxiliary Interstate highways in Maryland.

name: maryland
sentence: Among them are two beltways encircling the major cities of the region: I-695, the McKeldin (Baltimore) Beltway, which encircles Baltimore; and a portion of I-495, the Capital Beltway, which encircles Washington, D.C. I-270, which connects the Frederick area with Northern Virginia and the District of Columbia through major suburbs to the northwest of Washington, is a major commuter route and is as wide as fourteen lanes at points.

name: maryland
sentence: I-895, also known as the Harbor Tunnel Thruway, provides an alternate route to I-95 across the Baltimore Harbor.

name: maryland
sentence: Both I-270 and the Capital Beltway were extremely congested; however, the Intercounty Connector (ICC; MD 200) has alleviated some congestion over time.

name: maryland
sentence: Construction of the ICC was a major part of the campaign platform of former Governor Robert Ehrlich, who was in office from 2003 until 2007, and of Governor Martin O'Malley, who succeeded him.

name: maryland
sentence: I-595, which is an unsigned highway concurrent with US 50/US 301, is the longest unsigned interstate in the country and connects Prince George's County and Washington, D.C. with Annapolis and the Eastern Shore via the Chesapeake Bay Bridge.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland also has a state highway system that contains routes numbered from 2 through 999, however most of the higher-numbered routes are either unsigned or are relatively short.

name: maryland
sentence: Major state highways include Routes 2 (Governor Ritchie Highway/Solomons Island Road/Southern Maryland Blvd.

name: maryland
sentence: ), 4 (Pennsylvania Avenue/Southern Maryland Blvd./Patuxent Beach Road/St.

name: maryland
sentence: Andrew's Church Road), 5 (Branch Avenue/Leonardtown Road/Point Lookout Road), 32, 45 (York Road), 97 (Georgia Avenue), 100 (Paul T. Pitcher Memorial Highway), 210 (Indian Head Highway), 235 (Three Notch Road), 295 (Baltimore-Washington Parkway), 355 (Wisconsin Avenue/Rockville Pike/Frederick Road), 404 (Queen Anne Highway/ Shore Highway), and 650 (New Hampshire Avenue).

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland's largest airport is Baltimore-Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport, more commonly referred to as BWI.

name: maryland
sentence: The airport is named for the Baltimore-born Thurgood Marshall, the first African-American Supreme Court justice.

name: maryland
sentence: The only other airports with commercial service are at Hagerstown and Salisbury.

name: maryland
sentence: The Maryland suburbs of Washington, D.C. are also served by the other two airports in the region, Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport and Dulles International Airport, both in Northern Virginia.

name: maryland
sentence: The College Park Airport is the nation's oldest, founded in 1909, and is still used.

name: maryland
sentence: Wilbur Wright trained military aviators at this location.

name: maryland
sentence: Amtrak trains, including the high-speed Acela Express serve Baltimore's Penn Station, BWI Airport, New Carrollton, and Aberdeen along the Washington, D.C. to Boston Northeast Corridor.

name: maryland
sentence: In addition, train service is provided to Rockville and Cumberland by Amtrak's Washington, D.C., to Chicago Capitol Limited.

name: maryland
sentence: The WMATA's Metrorail rapid transit and Metrobus local bus systems (the 2nd and 6th busiest in the nation of their respective modes) provide service in Montgomery and Prince George's counties and connect them to Washington, D.C., with the express Metrobus Route B30 serving BWI Airport.

name: maryland
sentence: The Maryland Transit Administration (often abbreviated as "MTA Maryland"), a state agency part of the Maryland Department of Transportation also provides transit services within the state.

name: maryland
sentence: Headquartered in Baltimore, MTA's transit services are largely focused on central Maryland, as well as some portions of the Eastern Shore and Southern MD.

name: maryland
sentence: Baltimore's Light RailLink and Metro SubwayLink systems serve its densely populated inner-city and the surrounding suburbs.

name: maryland
sentence: The MTA also serves the city and its suburbs with its local bus service (the 9th largest system in the nation).

name: maryland
sentence: The MTA's Commuter Bus system provides express coach service on longer routes connecting Washington, D.C. and Baltimore to parts of Central and Southern MD as well as the Eastern Shore.

name: maryland
sentence: The commuter rail service, known as MARC, operates three lines which all terminate at Washington Union Station and provide service to Baltimore's Penn and Camden stations, Perryville, Frederick, and Martinsburg, WV.

name: maryland
sentence: In addition, many suburban counties operate local bus systems which connect to and complement the larger MTA and WMATA/Metro services.

name: maryland
sentence: The MTA will also administer the Purple Line, an under-construction light rail line that will connect the Maryland branches of the Red, Green/Yellow, and Orange lines of the Washington Metro, as well as offer transfers to all three lines of the MARC commuter rail system.

name: maryland
sentence: Freight rail transport is handled principally by two Class I railroads, as well as several smaller regional and local carriers.

name: maryland
sentence: CSX Transportation has more extensive trackage throughout the state, with 560 miles (900 km), followed by Norfolk Southern Railway.

name: maryland
sentence: Major rail yards are located in Baltimore and Cumberland, with an intermodal terminal (rail, truck and marine) in Baltimore.

name: maryland
sentence: The government of Maryland is conducted according to the state constitution.

name: maryland
sentence: The government of Maryland, like the other 49 state governments, has exclusive authority over matters that lie entirely within the state's borders, except as limited by the Constitution of the United States.

name: maryland
sentence: Power in Maryland is divided among three branches of government: executive, legislative, and judicial.

name: maryland
sentence: The Maryland General Assembly is composed of the Maryland House of Delegates and the Maryland Senatorte.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland's governor is unique in the United States as the office is vested with significant authority in budgeting.

name: maryland
sentence: The legislature may not increase the governor's proposed budget expenditures.

name: maryland
sentence: Unlike many other states, significant autonomy is granted to many of Maryland's counties.

name: maryland
sentence: Most of the business of government is conducted in Annapolis, the state capital.

name: maryland
sentence: Elections for governor and most statewide offices, as well as most county elections, are held in midterm-election years (even-numbered years not divisible by four).

name: maryland
sentence: The judicial branch of state government consists of one united District Court of Maryland that sits in every county and Baltimore City, as well as 24 Circuit Courts sitting in each County and Baltimore City, the latter being courts of general jurisdiction for all civil disputes over $30,000, all equitable jurisdiction and major criminal proceedings.

name: maryland
sentence: The intermediate appellate court is known as the Court of Special Appeals and the state supreme court is the Court of Appeals.

name: maryland
sentence: The appearance of the judges of the Maryland Court of Appeals is unique

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland imposes five income tax brackets, ranging from 2 to 6.25 percent of personal income.

name: maryland
sentence: The city of Baltimore and Maryland's 23 counties levy local "piggyback" income taxes at rates between 1.25 and 3.2 percent of Maryland taxable income.

name: maryland
sentence: Local officials set the rates and the revenue is returned to the local governments quarterly.

name: maryland
sentence: The top income tax bracket of 9.45 percent is the fifth highest combined state and local income tax rates in the country, behind New York City's 11.35 percent, California's 10.3 percent, Rhode Island's 9.9 percent, and Vermont's 9.5 percent.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland's state sales tax is six percent.

name: maryland
sentence: All real property in Maryland is subject to the property tax.

name: maryland
sentence: Generally, properties that are owned and used by religious, charitable, or educational organizations or property owned by the federal, state or local governments are exempt.

name: maryland
sentence: Property tax rates vary widely.

name: maryland
sentence: No restrictions or limitations on property taxes are imposed by the state, meaning cities and counties can set tax rates at the level they deem necessary to fund governmental services.

name: maryland
sentence: Since before the Civil War, Maryland's elections have been largely controlled by the Democrats, which account for 54.9% of all registered voters as of May 2017.

name: maryland
sentence: State elections are dominated by Baltimore and the populous suburban counties bordering Washington, D.C. and Baltimore: Montgomery, Prince George's, Anne Arundel, and Baltimore counties.

name: maryland
sentence: As of July 2017, sixty-six percent of the state's population resides in these six jurisdictions, most of which contain large, traditionally Democratic voting bloc(s): African Americans in Baltimore City and Prince George's, federal employees in Prince George's, Anne Arundel, and Montgomery, and postgraduates in Montgomery.

name: maryland
sentence: The remainder of the state, particularly Western Maryland and the Eastern Shore, is more supportive of Republicans.

name: maryland
sentence: One of Maryland's best known political figures is a Republican—former governor Spiro Agnew, who pled no contest to tax evasion and resigned in 1973.

name: maryland
sentence: In 1980, Maryland was one of six states to vote for Jimmy Carter.

name: maryland
sentence: In 1992, Bill Clinton fared better in Maryland than any other state except his home state of Arkansas.

name: maryland
sentence: In 1996, Maryland was Clinton's sixth best; in 2000, Maryland ranked fourth for Gore; and in 2004, John Kerry showed his fifth-best performance in Maryland.

name: maryland
sentence: In 2008, Barack Obama won the state's 10 electoral votes with 61.9 percent of the vote to John McCain's 36.5 percent.

name: maryland
sentence: In 2002, former Governor Robert Ehrlich was the first Republican to be elected to that office in four decades, and after one term lost his seat to Baltimore Mayor and Democrat Martin O'Malley.

name: maryland
sentence: Ehrlich ran again for governor in 2010, losing again to O'Malley.

name: maryland
sentence: The 2006 election brought no change in the pattern of Democratic dominance.

name: maryland
sentence: After Democratic Senatortor Paul Sarbanes announced that he was retiring, Democratic Congressman Benjamin Cardin defeated Republican Lieutenant Governor Michael S. Steele, with 55 percent of the vote, against Steele's 44 percent.

name: maryland
sentence: While Republicans usually win more counties, by piling up large margins in the west and east, they are also usually swamped by the more densely populated and heavily Democratic Baltimore–Washington axis.

name: maryland
sentence: In 2008, for instance, McCain won 17 counties to Obama's six; Obama also carried Baltimore City.

name: maryland
sentence: While McCain won most of the western and eastern counties by margins of 2-to-1 or more, he was almost completely shut out in the larger counties surrounding Baltimore and Washington; every large county except Anne Arundel went for Obama.

name: maryland
sentence: From 2007 to 2011, US

name: maryland
sentence: Congressman Steny Hoyer (MD-5), a Democrat, was elected as Majority Leader for the 110th Congress and 111th Congress of the House of Representatives, serving in that post again starting in 2019.

name: maryland
sentence: In addition, Hoyer served as House Minority Whip from 2003 to 2006 and 2012 to 2018.

name: maryland
sentence: His district covers parts of Anne Arundel and Prince George's counties, in addition to all of Charles, Calvert and St. Mary's counties in southern Maryland.

name: maryland
sentence: In 2010, Republicans won control of most counties.

name: maryland
sentence: The Democratic Party remained in control of eight county governments, including that of Baltimore.

name: maryland
sentence: In 2014, Larry Hogan, a Republican, was elected Governor of Maryland.

name: maryland
sentence: Hogan is the second Republican to become the Governor of Maryland since Spiro Agnew, who resigned in 1969 to become vice president.

name: maryland
sentence: In 2018, Hogan was reelected to a second term of office.

name: maryland
sentence: In February 2010, Attorney General Doug Gansler issued an opinion stating that Maryland law should honor same-sex marriages from out of state.

name: maryland
sentence: At the time, the state Supreme Court wrote a decision upholding marriage discrimination.

name: maryland
sentence: On March 1, 2012, Maryland Governor Martin O'Malley signed the freedom to marry bill into law after it passed in the state legislature.

name: maryland
sentence: Immediately after, opponents of same-sex marriage began collecting signatures to overturn the law.

name: maryland
sentence: The law was scheduled to face a referendum, as Question 6, in the November 2012 election.

name: maryland
sentence: In May 2012, Maryland's Court of Appeals ruled that the state will recognize marriages of same-sex couples who married out-of-state, no matter the outcome of the November election.

name: maryland
sentence: Voters voted 52% to 48% for Question 6 on November 6, 2012.

name: maryland
sentence: Same-sex couples began marrying in Maryland on January 1, 2013.

name: maryland
sentence: A large majority (57%) of Maryland voters said they would vote to uphold the freedom to marry at the ballot in November 2012, with 37% saying they would vote against marriage for all couples.

name: maryland
sentence: This is consistent with a January 2011 Gonzales Research & Marketing Strategies poll showing 51% support for marriage in the state.

name: maryland
sentence: A well-known newspaper is The Baltimore Sun.

name: maryland
sentence: The most populous areas are served by either Baltimore or Washington, D.C. broadcast stations.

name: maryland
sentence: The Eastern Shore is served primarily by broadcast media based around the Delmarva Peninsula

name: maryland
sentence: Garrett County, which is mountainous, is served by stations from Pittsburgh, and requires cable or satellite for reception.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland is served by statewide PBS member station Maryland Public Television (MPT).

name: maryland
sentence: Education Week ranked Maryland #1 in its nationwide 2009–2013 Quality Counts reports.

name: maryland
sentence: The College Board's 9th Annual AP Report to the Nation also ranked Maryland first.

name: maryland
sentence: Primary and secondary education in Maryland is overseen by the Maryland State Department of Education, which is headquartered in Baltimore.

name: maryland
sentence: The highest educational official in the state is the State Superintendent of Schools, who is appointed by the State Board of Education to a four-year term of office.

name: maryland
sentence: The Maryland General Assembly has given the Superintendent and State Board autonomy to make educationally related decisions, limiting its influence on the day-to-day functions of public education.

name: maryland
sentence: Each county and county-equivalent in Maryland has a local Board of Education charged with running the public schools in that particular jurisdiction.

name: maryland
sentence: The budget for education was $5.5 billion in 2009, representing about 40 percent of the state's general fund.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland has a broad range of private primary and secondary schools.

name: maryland
sentence: Many of these are affiliated with various religious sects, including parochial schools of the Catholic Church, Quaker schools, Seventh-day Adventist schools, and Jewish schools.

name: maryland
sentence: In 2003, Maryland law was changed to allow for the creation of publicly funded charter schools, although the charter schools must be approved by their local Board of Education and are not exempt from state laws on education, including collective bargaining laws.

name: maryland
sentence: In 2008, the state led the entire country in the percentage of students passing Advanced Placement examinations.

name: maryland
sentence: 23.4 percent of students earned passing grades on the AP tests given in May 2008.

name: maryland
sentence: This marks the first year that Maryland earned this honor.

name: maryland
sentence: Three Maryland high schools (in Montgomery County) were ranked among the top 100 in the country by US News in 2009, based in large part on AP test scores.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland has several historic and renowned private colleges and universities, the most prominent of which is Johns Hopkins University, founded in 1876 with a grant from Baltimore entrepreneur Johns Hopkins.

name: maryland
sentence: The first public university in the state is the University of Maryland, Baltimore, which was founded in 1807 and contains the University of Maryland's only public academic health, human services, and one of two law centers (the other being the University of Baltimore School of Law).

name: maryland
sentence: Seven professional and graduate schools train the majority of the state's physicians, nurses, dentists, lawyers, social workers, and pharmacists.

name: maryland
sentence: The flagship university and largest undergraduate institution in Maryland is the University of Maryland, College Park which was founded as the Maryland Agricultural College in 1856 and became a public land grant college in 1864.

name: maryland
sentence: Towson University, founded in 1866, is the state's second largest university.

name: maryland
sentence: In 1974, Maryland, along with seven other states, mainly in the South, submitted plans to desegregate its state universities; Maryland's plans were approved by the US Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

name: maryland
sentence: Baltimore is home to the University of Maryland, Baltimore County and the Maryland Institute College of Art.

name: maryland
sentence: The majority of public universities in the state (Bowie State University, Coppin State University, Frostburg State University, Salisbury University and the University of Maryland-Eastern Shore) are affiliated with the University System of Maryland.

name: maryland
sentence: Two state-funded institutions, Morgan State University and St. Mary's College of Maryland, as well as two federally funded institutions, the Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences and the United States Naval Academy, are not affiliated with the University System of Maryland.

name: maryland
sentence: The University of Maryland Global Campus is the largest public university in Maryland and one of the largest distance-learning institutions in the world.

name: maryland
sentence: St. John's College in Annapolis and Washington College in Chestertown, both private institutions, are the oldest colleges in the state and among the oldest in the country.

name: maryland
sentence: Other private institutions include Mount St. Mary's University, McDaniel College (formerly known as Western Maryland College), Hood College, Stevenson University (formerly known as Villa Julie College), Loyola University Maryland, and Goucher College, among others.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland's 24 public library systems deliver public education for everyone in the state of Maryland through a curriculum that comprises three pillars: Self-Directed Education (books and materials in all formats, e-resources), Research Assistance & Instruction (individualized research assistance, classes for students of all ages), and Instructive & Enlightening Experiences (e.g., Summer Reading Clubs, author events).

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland's library systems include, in part:

name: maryland
sentence: Many of the library systems have established formalized partnerships with other educational institutions in their counties and regions.

name: maryland
sentence: With two major metropolitan areas, Maryland has a number of major and minor professional sports franchises.

name: maryland
sentence: Two National Football League teams play in Maryland, the Baltimore Ravens in Baltimore and the Washington Football Team in Landover.

name: maryland
sentence: The Baltimore Colts represented the NFL in Baltimore from 1953 to 1983 before moving to Indianapolis.

name: maryland
sentence: The Baltimore Orioles are the state's Major League Baseball franchise.

name: maryland
sentence: The National Hockey League's Washington Capitals and the National Basketball Association's Washington Wizards formerly played in Maryland, until the construction of an arena in Washington, D.C. in 1997 (now known as Capital One Arena).

name: maryland
sentence: University of Maryland's team is the Maryland Terrapins.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland enjoys considerable historical repute for the talented sports players of its past, including Cal Ripken Jr. and Babe Ruth.

name: maryland
sentence: In 2012, The Baltimore Sun published a list of Maryland's top ten athletes in the state's history.

name: maryland
sentence: The list includes Babe Ruth, Cal Ripken Jr, Johnny Unitas, Brooks Robinson, Frank Robinson, Ray Lewis, Michael Phelps, Jimmie Foxx, Jim Parker, and Wes Unseld.

name: maryland
sentence: Other professional sports franchises in the state include five affiliated minor league baseball teams, one independent league baseball team, the Baltimore Blast indoor soccer team, two indoor football teams, three low-level outdoor soccer teams, and the Chesapeake Bayhawks of Major League Lacrosse.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland is also home to one of the three races in horse racing's annual Triple Crown, the Preakness Stakes, which is run every spring at Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore.

name: maryland
sentence: The Baltimore Stallions were a Canadian Football Team in the CFL.

name: maryland
sentence: They played the 1994-95 season.

name: maryland
sentence: The Congressional Country Club has hosted three golf tournaments for the US Open and a PGA Championship.

name: maryland
sentence: The official state sport of Maryland, since 1962, is jousting; the official team sport since 2004 is lacrosse.

name: maryland
sentence: The National Lacrosse Hall of Fame is located on the Johns Hopkins University campus in Baltimore.

name: maryland
sentence: In 2008, intending to promote physical fitness for all ages, walking became the official state exercise.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland is the first state with an official state exercise.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Massachusetts ( (listen), ), officially known as the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, is the most populous state in the New England region of the Northeastern United States.

name: massachusetts
sentence: It borders on the Atlantic Ocean to the east, the states of Connecticut and Rhode Island to the south, New Hampshire and Vermont to the north, and New York to the west.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The capital of Massachusetts is Boston, which is also the most populous city in New England.

name: massachusetts
sentence: It is home to the Greater Boston metropolitan area, a region influential upon American history, academia, and industry.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Originally dependent on agriculture, fishing and trade, Massachusetts was transformed into a manufacturing center during the Industrial Revolution.

name: massachusetts
sentence: During the 20th century, Massachusetts's economy shifted from manufacturing to services.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Modern Massachusetts is a global leader in biotechnology, engineering, higher education, finance, and maritime trade.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Plymouth was the site of the second colony in New England after Popham Colony in 1607 in what is now Maine.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Plymouth was founded in 1620 by the Pilgrims, passengers of the Mayflower.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In 1692, the town of Salem and surrounding areas experienced one of America's most infamous cases of mass hysteria, the Salem witch trials.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In 1777, General Henry Knox founded the Springfield Armory, which during the Industrial Revolution catalyzed numerous important technological advances, including interchangeable parts.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In 1786, Shays' Rebellion, a populist revolt led by disaffected American Revolutionary War veterans, influenced the United States Constitutional Convention.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In the 18th century, the Protestant First Great Awakening, which swept Britain and the Thirteen Colonies, originated from the pulpit of Northampton preacher Jonathan Edwards.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In the late 18th century, Boston became known as the "Cradle of Liberty" for the agitation there that later led to the American Revolution.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The entire Commonwealth of Massachusetts has played a powerful scientific, commercial, and cultural role in the history of the United States.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Before the American Civil War, Massachusetts was a center for the abolitionist, temperance, and transcendentalist movements.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In the late 19th century, the sports of basketball and volleyball were invented in the western Massachusetts cities of Springfield and Holyoke, respectively.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In 2004, Massachusetts became the first US state to legally recognize same-sex marriage as a result of the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court's decision in Goodridge v. Department of Public Health.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Many prominent American political dynasties have hailed from the state, including the Adams and Kennedy families.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Harvard University in Cambridge is the oldest institution of higher learning in the United States, with the largest financial endowment of any university, and Harvard Law School has educated a contemporaneous majority of Justices of the Supreme Court of the United States.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Kendall Square in Cambridge has been called "the most innovative square mile on the planet", in reference to the high concentration of entrepreneurial start-ups and quality of innovation which have emerged in the vicinity of the square since 2010.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Both Harvard and MIT, also in Cambridge, have been ranked among the most highly regarded academic institutions in the world.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Massachusetts' public-school students place among the top tier in the world in academic performance.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The state has been ranked as one of the top states in the United States for citizens to live in, as well as one of the most expensive.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The Massachusetts Bay Colony was named after the indigenous population, the Massachusett, whose name likely derived from a Wôpanâak word muswachasut, segmented as mus(ây) "big" + wach8 "mountain" + -s "diminutive" + -ut "locative" (the '8' in these words refers to the 'oo' sound according to the Wôpanâak orthographic chart).

name: massachusetts
sentence: It has been translated as "near the great hill", "by the blue hills", "at the little big hill", or "at the range of hills", referring to the Blue Hills, or in particular the Great Blue Hill, which is located on the boundary of Milton and Canton.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Alternatively, Massachusett has been represented as Moswetuset—from the name of the Moswetuset Hummock (meaning "hill shaped like an arrowhead") in Quincy, where Plymouth Colony commander Myles Standish (a hired English military officer) and Squanto (a member of the now disappeared Patuxet band of the Wampanoag peoples) met Chief Chickatawbut in 1621.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The official name of the state is the "Commonwealth of Massachusetts".

name: massachusetts
sentence: While the designation "Commonwealth" forms part of the state's official name, it has no practical implications.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Massachusetts has the same position and powers within the United States as other states.

name: massachusetts
sentence: John Adams in 1779 may have chosen the word for the second draft of what became the 1780 Massachusetts Constitution because unlike the word "state", "commonwealth" at the time had the connotation of a republic, in contrast to the monarchy the former American colonies were fighting against.

name: massachusetts
sentence: (The name "State of Massachusetts Bay" appeared in the first—rejected—draft.)

name: massachusetts
sentence: Massachusetts was originally inhabited by tribes of the Algonquian language family such as the Wampanoag, Narragansett, Nipmuc, Pocomtuc, Mahican, and Massachusett.

name: massachusetts
sentence: While cultivation of crops like squash and corn supplemented their diets, these tribes were generally dependent on hunting, gathering and fishing for most of their food.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Villages consisted of lodges called wigwams as well as longhouses, and tribes were led by male or female elders known as sachems.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In the early 1600s, after contact had been made with Europeans, large numbers of the indigenous peoples in the northeast of what is now the United States were killed by virgin soil epidemics such as smallpox, measles, influenza, and perhaps leptospirosis.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Between 1617 and 1619, what was possibly smallpox killed approximately 90% of the Massachusetts Bay Native Americans.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The first English settlers in Massachusetts, the Pilgrims, arrived on the Mayflower at Plymouth in 1620, and developed friendly relations with the native Wampanoag people.

name: massachusetts
sentence: This was the second successful permanent English colony in the part of North America that later became the United States, after the Jamestown Colony.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The event is known as the "First Thanksgiving" was celebrated by the Pilgrims after their first harvest in the New World, which lasted for three days.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The Pilgrims were soon followed by other Puritans, who established the Massachusetts Bay Colony at present-day Boston in 1630.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The Puritans, who believed the Church of England needed to be purified and experienced harassment from English authority because of their beliefs, came to Massachusetts intending to establish an ideal religious society.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Unlike the Plymouth colony, the bay colony was founded under a royal charter in 1629.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Both religious dissent and expansionism resulted in several new colonies being founded shortly after Plymouth and Massachusetts Bay elsewhere in New England.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The Massachusetts Bay banished dissenters such as Anne Hutchinson and Roger Williams due to religious and political disagreements.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In 1636, Williams founded the colony of Rhode Island, and Hutchinson joined him there several years later.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Religious intolerance continued.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Among those who objected to this later in the century were the English Quaker preachers Alice and Thomas Curwen, who were publicly flogged and imprisoned in Boston in 1676.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In 1641, Massachusetts expanded inland significantly, acquiring the Connecticut River Valley settlement of Springfield, which had recently disputed with, and defected from its original administrators, the Connecticut Colony.

name: massachusetts
sentence: This established Massachusetts's southern border in the west, though surveying problems resulted in disputed territory until 1803–04.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Currency was another issue in the colonies.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In 1652 the Massachusetts legislature authorized John Hull to produce coinage (mintmaster).

name: massachusetts
sentence: "The Hull Mint produced several denominations of silver coinage, including the pine tree shilling, for over 30 years until the political and economic situation made operating the mint no longer practical."

name: massachusetts
sentence: Mostly political for Charles II of England deemed the "Hull Mint" high treason in the United Kingdom which had a punishment of Hanging, drawing and quartering.

name: massachusetts
sentence: "On April 6, 1681, Randolph petitioned the king, informing him the colony was still pressing their own coins which he saw as high treason and believed it was enough to void the charter.

name: massachusetts
sentence: He asked that a writ of Quo warranto (a legal action requiring the defendant to show what authority they have for exercising some right, power, or franchise they claim to hold) be issued against Massachusetts for the violations."

name: massachusetts
sentence: In 1691, the colonies of Massachusetts Bay and Plymouth were united (along with present-day Maine, which had previously been divided between Massachusetts and New York) into the Province of Massachusetts Bay.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Shortly after the arrival of the new province's first governor, William Phips, the Salem witch trials took place, where a number of men and women were hanged for alleged witchcraft.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The most destructive earthquake yet known in New England occurred in 1755, causing considerable damage across Massachusetts.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Massachusetts was a center of the movement for independence from Great Britain; colonists in Massachusetts had long uneasy relations with the British monarchy, including open rebellion under the Dominion of New England in the 1680s.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Protests against British attempts to tax the colonies after the French and Indian War ended in 1763 led to the Boston Massacre in 1770, and the 1773 Boston Tea Party escalated tensions.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In 1774, the Intolerable Acts targeted Massachusetts with punishments for the Boston Tea Party and further decreased local autonomy, increasing local dissent.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Anti-Parliamentary activity by men such as Samuel Adams and John Hancock, followed by reprisals by the British government, were a primary reason for the unity of the Thirteen Colonies and the outbreak of the American Revolution in 1775.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The Battles of Lexington and Concord initiated the American Revolutionary War and were fought in the eponymous Massachusetts towns.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Future President George Washington took over what would become the Continental Army after the battle.

name: massachusetts
sentence: His first victory was the Siege of Boston in the winter of 1775–76, after which the British were forced to evacuate the city.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The event is still celebrated in Suffolk County as Evacuation Day.

name: massachusetts
sentence: On the coast, Salem became a center for privateering.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Although the documentation is incomplete, about 1,700 letters of marque, issued on a per-voyage basis, were granted during the American Revolution.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Nearly 800 vessels were commissioned as privateers and are credited with capturing or destroying about 600 British ships.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Bostonian John Adams, known as the "Atlas of Independence", was highly involved in both separation from Britain and the Constitution of Massachusetts, which effectively (the Elizabeth Freeman and Quock Walker cases as interpreted by William Cushing) made Massachusetts the first state to abolish slavery.

name: massachusetts
sentence: David McCullough points out that an equally important feature was its placing for the first time the courts as a co-equal branch separate from the executive.

name: massachusetts
sentence: (The Constitution of Vermont, adopted in 1777, represented the first partial ban on slavery.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Vermont became a state in 1791 but did not fully ban slavery until 1858 with the Vermont Personal Liberty Law.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The Pennsylvania Gradual Abolition Act of 1780 made Pennsylvania the first state to abolish slavery by statute.)

name: massachusetts
sentence: Later, Adams was active in early American foreign affairs and succeeded Washington as the second United States President.

name: massachusetts
sentence: His son John Quincy Adams, also from Massachusetts, would go on to become the sixth United States President.

name: massachusetts
sentence: From 1786 to 1787, an armed uprising, known as Shays' Rebellion led by Revolutionary War veteran Daniel Shays wrought havoc throughout Massachusetts and ultimately attempted to seize the Federal armory.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The rebellion was one of the major factors in the decision to draft a stronger national constitution to replace the Articles of Confederation.

name: massachusetts
sentence: On February 6, 1788, Massachusetts became the sixth state to ratify the United States Constitution.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In 1820, Maine separated from Massachusetts and entered the Union as the 23rd state as a result of the ratification of the Missouri Compromise.

name: massachusetts
sentence: During the 19th century, Massachusetts became a national leader in the American Industrial Revolution, with factories around cities such as Lowell and Boston producing textiles and shoes, and factories around Springfield producing tools, paper, and textiles.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The economy transformed from one based primarily on agriculture to an industrial one, initially making use of water-power and later the steam engine to power factories.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Canals and railroads were used for transporting raw materials and finished goods.

name: massachusetts
sentence: At first, the new industries drew labor from Yankees on nearby subsistence farms, and later relied upon immigrant labor from Europe and Canada.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Although Massachusetts was the first slave-holding colony dating back to the early 1600s, in the years leading up to the American Civil War, Massachusetts was a center of progressivist and abolitionist activity.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Horace Mann made the state's school system a national model.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Henry David Thoreau and Ralph Waldo Emerson made major contributions to American philosophy.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Members of the transcendentalist movement emphasized the importance of the natural world and emotion to humanity.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Although significant opposition to abolitionism existed early on in Massachusetts, resulting in anti-abolitionist riots between 1835 and 1837, opposition to slavery gradually increased throughout the next few decades.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Abolitionists John Brown and Sojourner Truth lived in Springfield and Northampton, respectively, while Frederick Douglass lived in Boston and Susan B. Anthony in Adams, Massachusetts.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The works of such abolitionists contributed to Massachusetts's actions during the Civil War.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Massachusetts was the first state to recruit, train, and arm a Black regiment with White officers, the 54th Massachusetts Infantry Regiment.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In 1852, Massachusetts became the first state to pass compulsory education laws.

name: massachusetts
sentence: With the departure of several manufacturing companies, the area's industrial economy began to decline during the early 20th century.

name: massachusetts
sentence: By the 1920s, competition from the South and Midwest, followed by the Great Depression, led to the collapse of the three main industries in Massachusetts: textiles, shoemaking, and precision mechanics.

name: massachusetts
sentence: This decline would continue into the latter half of the century; between 1950 and 1979, the number of Massachusetts residents involved in textile manufacturing declined from 264,000 to 63,000.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The 1969 closure of the Springfield Armory, in particular, spurred an exodus of high-paying jobs from Western Massachusetts, which suffered greatly as it de-industrialized during the last 40 years of the 20th century.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Massachusetts manufactured 3.4 percent of total United States military armaments produced during World War II, ranking tenth among the 48 states.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In Eastern Massachusetts, following World War II, the economy was transformed from one based on heavy industry into a service-based economy.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Government contracts, private investment, and research facilities led to a new and improved industrial climate, with reduced unemployment and increased per capita income.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Suburbanization flourished, and by the 1970s, the Route 128 corridor was dotted with high-technology companies who recruited graduates of the area's many elite institutions of higher education.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In 1987, the state received federal funding for the Central Artery/Tunnel Project.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Commonly known as "the Big Dig", it was, at the time, the biggest federal highway project ever approved.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The project included making the Central Artery a tunnel under downtown Boston, in addition to the re-routing of several other major highways.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Often controversial, with numerous claims of graft and mismanagement, and with its initial price tag of $2.5 billion increasing to a final tally of over $15 billion, the Big Dig nonetheless changed the face of Downtown Boston.

name: massachusetts
sentence: It connected areas that were once divided by elevated highway (much of the raised old Central Artery was replaced with the Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy Greenway), and improved traffic conditions along with several routes.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The Kennedy family was prominent in Massachusetts politics in the 20th century.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Children of businessman and ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy Sr. included John F. Kennedy, who was a senator and US president before his assassination in 1963, Robert F. Kennedy, who was a senator, US attorney general, and presidential candidate before his assassination in 1968, Ted Kennedy, a senator from 1962 until his death in 2009, and Eunice Kennedy Shriver, a co-founder of the Special Olympics.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In 1966, Massachusetts became the first state to directly elect an African American to the US senate with Edward Brooke.

name: massachusetts
sentence: George H W Bush, 41st President of the United States (1989–1993) was born in Milton in 1924.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Other notable Bay State politicians on the national level included John W. McCormack, Speaker of the House in the 1960s, and Tip O'Neill, whose service as Speaker of the House from 1977 to 1987 was the longest continuous tenure in United States history.

name: massachusetts
sentence: On May 17, 2004, Massachusetts became the first state in the US to legalize same-sex marriage after a Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court ruling in November 2003 determined that the exclusion of same-sex couples from the right to a civil marriage was unconstitutional.

name: massachusetts
sentence: This decision was eventually superseded by the US Supreme Court's affirmation of same-sex marriage in the United States in 2015.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In 2004, Massachusetts senator John Kerry who won the Democratic nomination for President of the United States narrowly lost to incumbent George W. Bush.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Eight years later, former Massachusetts governor Mitt Romney (Republican nominee) lost to Barack Obama in 2012.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Another eight years later, Massachusetts Senatortor Elizabeth Warren was a frontrunner in the Democratic primaries for the 2020 Presidential Election, but suspended her campaign and then endorsed presumptive nominee Joe Biden.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Two pressure cooker bombs exploded near the finish line of the Boston Marathon on April 15, 2013, at around 2:49 pm EDT.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The explosions killed three people and injured an estimated 264 others.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) later identified the suspects as brothers Dzhokhar Tsarnaev and Tamerlan Tsarnaev.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The ensuing manhunt ended on April 19 when thousands of law enforcement officers searched a 20-block area of nearby Watertown.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Dzhokhar later said he was motivated by extremist Islamic beliefs and learned to build explosive devices from Inspire, the online magazine of al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula.

name: massachusetts
sentence: On November 8, 2016, Massachusetts voted in favor of The Massachusetts Marijuana Legalization Initiative, also known as Question 4.

name: massachusetts
