sentence: Mississippi City Population Rankings of at least 10,000 but fewer than 20,000 (United States Census Bureau as of 2017):

name: mississippi
sentence: (See: Lists of cities, towns and villages, census-designated places, metropolitan areas, micropolitan areas, and counties in Mississippi)

name: mississippi
sentence: Mississippi has a humid subtropical climate with long, hot and humid summers, and short, mild winters.

name: mississippi
sentence: Temperatures average about 81 °F (27 °C) in July and about 42 °F (6 °C) in January.

name: mississippi
sentence: The temperature varies little statewide in the summer; however, in winter, the region near Mississippi Sound is significantly warmer than the inland portion of the state.

name: mississippi
sentence: The recorded temperature in Mississippi has ranged from −19 °F (−28 °C), in 1966, at Corinth in the northeast, to 115 °F (46 °C), in 1930, at Holly Springs in the north.

name: mississippi
sentence: Heavy snowfall rarely occurs, but isn't unheard of, such as during the New Year's Eve 1963 snowstorm.

name: mississippi
sentence: Yearly precipitation generally increases from north to south, with the regions closer to the Gulf being the most humid.

name: mississippi
sentence: Thus, Clarksdale, in the northwest, gets about 50 in (1,300 mm) of precipitation annually and Biloxi, in the south, about 61 in (1,500 mm).

name: mississippi
sentence: Small amounts of snow fall in northern and central Mississippi

name: mississippi
sentence: The late summer and fall is the seasonal period of risk for hurricanes moving inland from the Gulf of Mexico, especially in the southern part of the state.

name: mississippi
sentence: Hurricane Camille in 1969 and Hurricane Katrina in 2005, which killed 238 people in the state, were the most devastating hurricanes to hit the state.

name: mississippi
sentence: Both caused nearly total storm surge destruction of structures in and around Gulfport, Biloxi, and Pascagoula.

name: mississippi
sentence: As in the rest of the Deep South, thunderstorms are common in Mississippi, especially in the southern part of the state.

name: mississippi
sentence: On average, Mississippi has around 27 tornadoes annually; the northern part of the state has more tornadoes earlier in the year and the southern part a higher frequency later in the year.

name: mississippi
sentence: Two of the five deadliest tornadoes in United States history have occurred in the state.

name: mississippi
sentence: These storms struck Natchez, in southwest Mississippi (see The Great Natchez Tornado) and Tupelo, in the northeast corner of the state.

name: mississippi
sentence: About seven F5 tornadoes have been recorded in the state.

name: mississippi
sentence: Mississippi is heavily forested, with over half of the state's area covered by wild or cultivated trees.

name: mississippi
sentence: The southeastern part of the state is dominated by longleaf pine, in both uplands and lowland flatwoods and Sarracenia bogs.

name: mississippi
sentence: The Mississippi Alluvial Plain, or Delta, is primarily farmland and aquaculture ponds but also has sizeable tracts of cottonwood, willows, bald cypress, and oaks.

name: mississippi
sentence: A belt of loess extends north to south in the western part of the state, where the Mississippi Alluvial Plain reaches the first hills; this region is characterized by rich, mesic mixed hardwood forests, with some species disjunct from Appalachian forests.

name: mississippi
sentence: Two bands of historical prairie, the Jackson Prairie and the Black Belt, run northwest to southeast in the middle and northeastern part of the state.

name: mississippi
sentence: Although these areas have been highly degraded by conversion to agriculture, a few areas remain, consisting of grassland with interspersed woodland of eastern redcedar, oaks, hickories, osage-orange, and sugarberry.

name: mississippi
sentence: The rest of the state, primarily north of Interstate 20 not including the prairie regions, consists of mixed pine-hardwood forest, common species being loblolly pine, oaks (e.g., water oak), hickories, sweetgum, and elm.

name: mississippi
sentence: Areas along large rivers are commonly inhabited by bald cypress, water tupelo, water elm, and bitter pecan.

name: mississippi
sentence: Commonly cultivated trees include loblolly pine, longleaf pine, cherrybark oak, and cottonwood.

name: mississippi
sentence: There are approximately 3000 species of vascular plants known from Mississippi.

name: mississippi
sentence: As of 2018, a project funded by the US National Science Foundation aims to update that checklist of plants with museum (herbarium) vouchers and create an online atlas of each species's distribution.

name: mississippi
sentence: About 420 species of birds are known to inhabit Mississippi.

name: mississippi
sentence: Mississippi has one of the richest fish faunas in the United States, with 204 native fish species.

name: mississippi
sentence: Mississippi also has a rich freshwater mussel fauna, with about 90 species in the primary family of native mussels (Unionidae).

name: mississippi
sentence: Several of these species were extirpated during the construction of the Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway.

name: mississippi
sentence: Mississippi is home to 63 crayfish species, including at least 17 endemic species.

name: mississippi
sentence: Mississippi is home to eight winter stonefly species.

name: mississippi
sentence: Due to seasonal flooding, possible from December to June, the Mississippi and Yazoo rivers and their tributaries created a fertile floodplain in the Mississippi Delta.

name: mississippi
sentence: The river's flooding created natural levees, which planters had built higher to try to prevent flooding of land cultivated for cotton crops.

name: mississippi
sentence: Temporary workers built levees along the Mississippi River on top of the natural levees that formed from dirt deposited after the river flooded.

name: mississippi
sentence: From 1858 to 1861, the state took over levee building, accomplishing it through contractors and hired labor.

name: mississippi
sentence: In those years, planters considered their slaves too valuable to hire out for such dangerous work.

name: mississippi
sentence: Contractors hired gangs of Irish immigrant laborers to build levees and sometimes clear land.

name: mississippi
sentence: Many of the Irish were relatively recent immigrants from the famine years who were struggling to get established.

name: mississippi
sentence: Before the American Civil War, the earthwork levees averaged six feet in height, although in some areas they reached twenty feet.

name: mississippi
sentence: Flooding has been an integral part of Mississippi history, but clearing of the land for cultivation and to supply wood fuel for steamboats took away the absorption of trees and undergrowth.

name: mississippi
sentence: The banks of the river were denuded, becoming unstable and changing the character of the river.

name: mississippi
sentence: After the Civil War, major floods swept down the valley in 1865, 1867, 1874 and 1882.

name: mississippi
sentence: Such floods regularly overwhelmed levees damaged by Confederate and Union fighting during the war, as well as those constructed after the war.

name: mississippi
sentence: In 1877, the state created the Mississippi Levee District for southern counties.

name: mississippi
sentence: In 1879, the United States Congress created the Mississippi River Commission, whose responsibilities included aiding state levee boards in the construction of levees.

name: mississippi
sentence: Both white and black transient workers were hired to build the levees in the late 19th century.

name: mississippi
sentence: By 1882, levees averaged seven feet in height, but many in the southern Delta were severely tested by the flood that year.

name: mississippi
sentence: After the 1882 flood, the levee system was expanded.

name: mississippi
sentence: In 1884, the Yazoo-Mississippi Delta Levee District was established to oversee levee construction and maintenance in the northern Delta counties; also included were some counties in Arkansas which were part of the Delta.

name: mississippi
sentence: Flooding overwhelmed northwestern Mississippi in 1912–1913, causing heavy damage to the levee districts.

name: mississippi
sentence: Regional losses and the Mississippi River Levee Association's lobbying for a flood control bill helped gain passage of national bills in 1917 and 1923 to provide federal matching funds for local levee districts, on a scale of 2:1.

name: mississippi
sentence: Although US participation in World War I interrupted funding of levees, the second round of funding helped raise the average height of levees in the Mississippi-Yazoo Delta to 22 feet (6.7 m) in the 1920s.

name: mississippi
sentence: Scientists now understand the levees have increased the severity of flooding by increasing the flow speed of the river and reducing the area of the floodplains.

name: mississippi
sentence: The region was severely damaged due to the Great Mississippi Flood of 1927, which broke through the levees.

name: mississippi
sentence: There were losses of millions of dollars in property, stock and crops.

name: mississippi
sentence: The most damage occurred in the lower Delta, including Washington and Bolivar counties.

name: mississippi
sentence: Even as scientific knowledge about the Mississippi River has grown, upstream development and the consequences of the levees have caused more severe flooding in some years.

name: mississippi
sentence: Scientists now understand that the widespread clearing of land and building of the levees have changed the nature of the river.

name: mississippi
sentence: Such work removed the natural protection and absorption of wetlands and forest cover, strengthening the river's current.

name: mississippi
sentence: The state and federal governments have been struggling for the best approaches to restore some natural habitats in order to best interact with the original riverine ecology.

name: mississippi
sentence: Near 10,000 BC Native Americans or Paleo-Indians arrived in what today is referred to as the American South.

name: mississippi
sentence: Paleo-Indians in the South were hunter-gatherers who pursued the megafauna that became extinct following the end of the Pleistocene age.

name: mississippi
sentence: In the Mississippi Delta, Native American settlements and agricultural fields were developed on the natural levees, higher ground in the proximity of rivers.

name: mississippi
sentence: The Native Americans developed extensive fields near their permanent villages.

name: mississippi
sentence: Together with other practices, they created some localized deforestation but did not alter the ecology of the Mississippi Delta as a whole.

name: mississippi
sentence: After thousands of years, succeeding cultures of the Woodland and Mississippian culture eras developed rich and complex agricultural societies, in which surplus supported the development of specialized trades.

name: mississippi
sentence: Both were mound builder cultures.

name: mississippi
sentence: Those of the Mississippian culture were the largest and most complex, constructed beginning about 950 AD.

name: mississippi
sentence: The peoples had a trading network spanning the continent from the Great Lakes to the Gulf Coast.

name: mississippi
sentence: Their large earthworks, which expressed their cosmology of political and religious concepts, still stand throughout the Mississippi and Ohio River valleys.

name: mississippi
sentence: Descendant Native American tribes of the Mississippian culture in the Southeast include the Chickasaw and Choctaw.

name: mississippi
sentence: Other tribes who inhabited the territory of Mississippi (and whose names were honored by colonists in local towns) include the Natchez, the Yazoo, and the Biloxi.

name: mississippi
sentence: The first major European expedition into the territory that became Mississippi was that of the Spanish explorer, Hernando de Soto, who passed through the northeast part of the state in 1540, in his second expedition to the New World.

name: mississippi
sentence: In April 1699, French colonists established the first European settlement at Fort Maurepas (also known as Old Biloxi), built in the vicinity of present-day Ocean Springs on the Gulf Coast.

name: mississippi
sentence: It was settled by Pierre Le Moyne d'Iberville.

name: mississippi
sentence: In 1716, the French founded Natchez on the Mississippi River (as Fort Rosalie); it became the dominant town and trading post of the area.

name: mississippi
sentence: The French called the greater territory "New France"; the Spanish continued to claim part of the Gulf coast area (east of Mobile Bay) of present-day southern Alabama, in addition to the entire area of present-day Florida.

name: mississippi
sentence: Through the 18th century, the area was ruled variously by Spanish, French, and British colonial governments.

name: mississippi
sentence: The colonists imported African slaves as laborers.

name: mississippi
sentence: Under French and Spanish rule, there developed a class of free people of color (gens de couleur libres), mostly multiracial descendants of European men and enslaved or free black women, and their mixed-race children.

name: mississippi
sentence: In the early days the French and Spanish colonists were chiefly men.

name: mississippi
sentence: Even as more European women joined the settlements, the men had interracial unions among women of African descent (and increasingly, multiracial descent), both before and after marriages to European women.

name: mississippi
sentence: Often the European men would help their multiracial children get educated or gain apprenticeships for trades, and sometimes they settled property on them; they often freed the mothers and their children if enslaved, as part of contracts of plaçage.

name: mississippi
sentence: With this social capital, the free people of color became artisans, and sometimes educated merchants and property owners, forming a third class between the Europeans and most enslaved Africans in the French and Spanish settlements, although not so large a free community as in the city of New Orleans, Louisiana.

name: mississippi
sentence: After Great Britain's victory in the French and Indian War (Seven Years' War), the French surrendered the Mississippi area to them under the terms of the Treaty of Paris (1763).

name: mississippi
sentence: They also ceded their areas to the north that were east of the Mississippi River, including the Illinois Country and Quebec.

name: mississippi
sentence: After the Peace of Paris (1783), the lower third of Mississippi came under Spanish rule as part of West Florida.

name: mississippi
sentence: In 1819 the United States completed the purchase of West Florida and all of East Florida in the Adams–Onís Treaty, and in 1822 both were merged into the Florida Territory.

name: mississippi
sentence: After the American Revolution (1765–83), Britain ceded this area to the new United States of America.

name: mississippi
sentence: The Mississippi Territory was organized on April 7, 1798, from territory ceded by Georgia and South Carolina to the United States.

name: mississippi
sentence: Their original colonial charters theoretically extended west to the Pacific Ocean.

name: mississippi
sentence: The Mississippi Territory was later twice expanded to include disputed territory claimed by both the United States and Spain.

name: mississippi
sentence: From 1800 to about 1830, the United States purchased some lands (Treaty of Doak's Stand) from Native American tribes for new settlements of European Americans.

name: mississippi
sentence: The latter were mostly migrants from other Southern states, particularly Virginia and North Carolina, where soils were exhausted.

name: mississippi
sentence: New settlers kept encroaching on Choctaw land, and they pressed the federal government to expel the Native Americans.

name: mississippi
sentence: On September 27, 1830, the Treaty of Dancing Rabbit Creek was signed between the US Government and the Choctaw.

name: mississippi
sentence: The Choctaw agreed to sell their traditional homelands in Mississippi and Alabama, for compensation and removal to reservations in Indian Territory (now Oklahoma).

name: mississippi
sentence: This opened up land for sale to European-American migrant settlement.

name: mississippi
sentence: Article 14 in the treaty allowed those Choctaw who chose to remain in the states to become US citizens, as they were considered to be giving up their tribal membership.

name: mississippi
sentence: They were the second major Native American ethnic group to do so (some Cherokee were the first, who chose to stay in North Carolina and other areas during rather than join the removal).

name: mississippi
sentence: Today their descendants include approximately 9,500 persons identifying as Choctaw, who live in Neshoba, Newton, Leake, and Jones counties.

name: mississippi
sentence: The Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians reorganized in the 20th century and is a Federally recognized tribe.

name: mississippi
sentence: Many slaveholders brought enslaved African Americans with them or purchased them through the domestic slave trade, especially in New Orleans.

name: mississippi
sentence: Through the trade, an estimated nearly one million slaves were forcibly transported to the Deep South, including Mississippi, in an internal migration that broke up many slave families of the Upper South, where planters were selling excess slaves.

name: mississippi
sentence: The Southerners imposed slave laws in the Deep South and restricted the rights of free blacks.

name: mississippi
sentence: Beginning in 1822, slaves in Mississippi were protected by law from cruel and unusual punishment by their owners.

name: mississippi
sentence: The Southern slave codes made the willful killing of a slave illegal in most cases.

name: mississippi
sentence: For example, the 1860 Mississippi case of Oliver v. State charged the defendant with murdering his own slave.

name: mississippi
sentence: Mississippi became the 20th state on December 10, 1817.

name: mississippi
sentence: David Holmes was the first governor.

name: mississippi
sentence: The state was still occupied as ancestral land by several Native American tribes, including Choctaw, Natchez, Houma, Creek, and Chickasaw.

name: mississippi
sentence: Plantations were developed primarily along the major rivers, where the waterfront provided access to the major transportation routes.

name: mississippi
sentence: This is also where early towns developed, linked by the steamboats that carried commercial products and crops to markets.

name: mississippi
sentence: The remainder of Native American ancestral land remained largely undeveloped but was sold through treaties until 1826, when the Choctaws and Chickasaws refused to sell more land.

name: mississippi
sentence: The combination of the Mississippi state legislature's abolition of Choctaw Tribal Government in 1829, President Andrew Jackson's Indian Removal Act and the Treaty of Dancing Rabbit Creek of 1830, the Choctaw were effectively forced to sell their land and were transported to Oklahoma Territory.

name: mississippi
sentence: The forced migration of the Choctaw, together with other southeastern tribes removed as a result of the Act, became known as the Trail of Tears.

name: mississippi
sentence: When cotton was king during the 1850s, Mississippi plantation owners—especially those of the Delta and Black Belt central regions—became wealthy due to the high fertility of the soil, the high price of cotton on the international market, and free labor gained through their holding enslaved African Americans.

name: mississippi
sentence: They used some of their profits to buy more cotton land and more slaves.

name: mississippi
sentence: The planters' dependence on hundreds of thousands of slaves for labor and the severe wealth imbalances among whites, played strong roles both in state politics and in planters' support for secession.

name: mississippi
sentence: Mississippi was a slave society, with the economy dependent on slavery.

name: mississippi
sentence: The state was thinly settled, with population concentrated in the riverfront areas and towns.

name: mississippi
sentence: By 1860, the enslaved African-American population numbered 436,631 or 55% of the state's total of 791,305 persons.

name: mississippi
sentence: Fewer than 1000 were free people of color.

name: mississippi
sentence: The relatively low population of the state before the Civil War reflected the fact that land and villages were developed only along the riverfronts, which formed the main transportation corridors.

name: mississippi
sentence: Ninety percent of the Delta bottomlands were still frontier and undeveloped.

name: mississippi
sentence: The state needed many more settlers for development.

name: mississippi
sentence: The land further away from the rivers was cleared by freedmen and white migrants during Reconstruction and later.

name: mississippi
sentence: On January 9, 1861, Mississippi became the second state to declare its secession from the Union, and it was one of the founding members of the Confederate States.

name: mississippi
sentence: The first six states to secede were those with the highest number of slaves.

name: mississippi
sentence: During the war, Union and Confederate forces struggled for dominance on the Mississippi River, critical to supply routes and commerce.

name: mississippi
sentence: More than 80,000 Mississippians fought in the Civil War, and casualties were extremely heavy.

name: mississippi
sentence: Union General Ulysses S. Grant's long siege of Vicksburg finally gained the Union control of the river in 1863.

name: mississippi
sentence: In the postwar period, freedmen withdrew from white-run churches to set up independent congregations.

name: mississippi
sentence: The majority of blacks left the Southern Baptist Church, sharply reducing its membership.

name: mississippi
sentence: They created independent black Baptist congregations.

name: mississippi
sentence: By 1895 they had established numerous black Baptist state associations and the National Baptist Convention of black churches.

name: mississippi
sentence: In addition, independent black denominations, such as the African Methodist Episcopal Church (established in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania in the early 19th century) and the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church (established in New York City), sent missionaries to the South in the postwar years.

name: mississippi
sentence: They quickly attracted hundreds of thousands of converts and founded new churches across the South.

name: mississippi
sentence: Southern congregations brought their own influences to those denominations as well.

name: mississippi
sentence: During Reconstruction, the first Mississippi constitutional convention in 1868, with delegates both black and white, framed a constitution whose major elements would be maintained for 22 years.

name: mississippi
sentence: The convention was the first political organization in the state to include African-American representatives, 17 among the 100 members (32 counties had black majorities at the time).

name: mississippi
sentence: Some among the black delegates were freedmen, but others were educated free blacks who had migrated from the North.

name: mississippi
sentence: The convention adopted universal suffrage; did away with property qualifications for suffrage or for office, a change that also benefited both blacks and poor whites; provided for the state's first public school system; forbade race distinctions in the possession and inheritance of property; and prohibited limiting civil rights in travel.

name: mississippi
sentence: Under the terms of Reconstruction, Mississippi was restored to the Union on February 23, 1870.

name: mississippi
sentence: Because the Mississippi Delta contained so much fertile bottomland that had not been developed before the Civil War, 90 percent of the land was still frontier.

name: mississippi
sentence: After the Civil War, tens of thousands of migrants were attracted to the area by higher wages offered by planters trying to develop land.

name: mississippi
sentence: In addition, black and white workers could earn money by clearing the land and selling timber, and eventually advance to ownership.

name: mississippi
sentence: The new farmers included many freedmen, who by the late 19th century achieved unusually high rates of land ownership in the Mississippi bottomlands.

name: mississippi
sentence: In the 1870s and 1880s, many black farmers succeeded in gaining land ownership.

name: mississippi
sentence: Around the start of the 20th century, two-thirds of the Mississippi farmers who owned land in the Delta were African American.

name: mississippi
sentence: But many had become overextended with debt during the falling cotton prices of the difficult years of the late 19th century.

name: mississippi
sentence: Cotton prices fell throughout the decades following the Civil War.

name: mississippi
sentence: As another agricultural depression lowered cotton prices into the 1890s, numerous African-American farmers finally had to sell their land to pay off debts, thus losing the land which they had developed by hard, personal labor.

name: mississippi
sentence: Democrats had regained control of the state legislature in 1875, after a year of expanded violence against blacks and intimidation of whites in what was called the "white line" campaign, based on asserting white supremacy.

name: mississippi
sentence: Democratic whites were well armed and formed paramilitary organizations such as the Red Shirts to suppress black voting.

name: mississippi
sentence: From 1874 to the elections of 1875, they pressured whites to join the Democrats, and conducted violence against blacks in at least 15 known "riots" in cities around the state to intimidate blacks.

name: mississippi
sentence: They killed a total of 150 blacks, although other estimates place the death toll at twice as many.

name: mississippi
sentence: A total of three white Republicans and five white Democrats were reported killed.

name: mississippi
sentence: In rural areas, deaths of blacks could be covered up.

name: mississippi
sentence: Riots (better described as massacres of blacks) took place in Vicksburg, Clinton, Macon, and in their counties, as well-armed whites broke up black meetings and lynched known black leaders, destroying local political organizations.

name: mississippi
sentence: Seeing the success of this deliberate "Mississippi Plan", South Carolina and other states followed it and also achieved white Democratic dominance.

name: mississippi
sentence: In 1877 by a national compromise, the last of federal troops were withdrawn from the region.

name: mississippi
sentence: Even in this environment, black Mississippians continued to be elected to local office.

name: mississippi
sentence: However, black residents were deprived of all political power after white legislators passed a new state constitution in 1890 specifically to "eliminate the nigger from politics", according to the state's Democratic governor, James K. Vardaman.

name: mississippi
sentence: It erected barriers to voter registration and instituted electoral provisions that effectively disenfranchised most black Mississippians and many poor whites.

name: mississippi
sentence: Estimates are that 100,000 black and 50,000 white men were removed from voter registration rolls in the state over the next few years.

name: mississippi
sentence: The loss of political influence contributed to the difficulties of African Americans in their attempts to obtain extended credit in the late 19th century.

name: mississippi
sentence: Together with imposition of Jim Crow and racial segregation laws, whites increased violence against blacks, lynching mostly men, through the period of the 1890s and extending to 1930.

name: mississippi
sentence: Cotton crops failed due to boll weevil infestation and successive severe flooding in 1912 and 1913, creating crisis conditions for many African Americans.

name: mississippi
sentence: With control of the ballot box and more access to credit, white planters bought out such farmers, expanding their ownership of Delta bottomlands.

name: mississippi
sentence: They also took advantage of new railroads sponsored by the state.

name: mississippi
sentence: In 1900, blacks made up more than half of the state's population.

name: mississippi
sentence: By 1910, a majority of black farmers in the Delta had lost their land and become sharecroppers.

name: mississippi
sentence: By 1920, the third generation after freedom, most African Americans in Mississippi were landless laborers again facing poverty.

name: mississippi
sentence: Starting about 1913, tens of thousands of black Americans left Mississippi for the North in the Great Migration to industrial cities such as St. Louis, Chicago, Detroit, Cleveland, Philadelphia and New York.

name: mississippi
sentence: They sought jobs, better education for their children, the right to vote, relative freedom from discrimination, and better living.

name: mississippi
sentence: In the migration of 1910–1940, they left a society that had been steadily closing off opportunity.

name: mississippi
sentence: Most migrants from Mississippi took trains directly north to Chicago and often settled near former neighbors.

name: mississippi
sentence: Blacks also faced violence in the form of lynching, shooting, and the burning of churches.

name: mississippi
sentence: In 1923, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People stated "the Negro feels that life is not safe in Mississippi and his life may be taken with impunity at any time upon the slightest pretext or provocation by a white man".

name: mississippi
sentence: In the early 20th century, some industries were established in Mississippi, but jobs were generally restricted to whites, including child workers.

name: mississippi
sentence: The lack of jobs also drove some southern whites north to cities such as Chicago and Detroit, seeking employment, where they also competed with European immigrants.

name: mississippi
sentence: The state depended on agriculture, but mechanization put many farm laborers out of work.

name: mississippi
sentence: By 1900, many white ministers, especially in the towns, subscribed to the Social Gospel movement, which attempted to apply Christian ethics to social and economic needs of the day.

name: mississippi
sentence: Many strongly supported Prohibition, believing it would help alleviate and prevent many sins.

name: mississippi
sentence: Mississippi became a dry state in 1908 by an act of the State legislature.

name: mississippi
sentence: It remained dry until the legislature passed a local option bill in 1966.

name: mississippi
sentence: African-American Baptist churches grew to include more than twice the number of members as their white Baptist counterparts.

sentence: The African-American call for social equality resonated throughout the Great Depression in the 1930s and World War II in the 1940s.

name: mississippi
sentence: The Second Great Migration from the South started in the 1940s, lasting until 1970.

name: mississippi
sentence: Almost half a million people left Mississippi in the second migration, three-quarters of them black.

name: mississippi
sentence: Nationwide during the first half of the 20th century, African Americans became rapidly urbanized and many worked in industrial jobs.

name: mississippi
sentence: The Second Great Migration included destinations in the West, especially California, where the buildup of the defense industry offered higher-paying jobs to both African Americans and whites.

name: mississippi
sentence: Blacks and whites in Mississippi generated rich, quintessentially American music traditions: gospel music, country music, jazz, blues and rock and roll.

name: mississippi
sentence: All were invented, promulgated or heavily developed by Mississippi musicians, many of them African American, and most came from the Mississippi Delta.

name: mississippi
sentence: Many musicians carried their music north to Chicago, where they made it the heart of that city's jazz and blues.

sentence: So many African Americans left in the Great Migration that after the 1930s, they became a minority in Mississippi.

name: mississippi
sentence: In 1960 they made up 42% of the state's population.

name: mississippi
sentence: The whites maintained their discriminatory voter registration processes established in 1890, preventing most blacks from voting, even if they were well educated.

name: mississippi
sentence: Court challenges were not successful until later in the century.

name: mississippi
sentence: After World War II, African-American veterans returned with renewed commitment to be treated as full citizens of the United States and increasingly organized to gain enforcement of their constitutional rights.

name: mississippi
sentence: The Civil Rights Movement had many roots in religion, and the strong community of churches helped supply volunteers and moral purpose for their activism.

name: mississippi
sentence: Mississippi was a center of activity, based in black churches, to educate and register black voters, and to work for integration.

name: mississippi
sentence: In 1954 the state had created the Mississippi State Sovereignty Commission, a tax-supported agency, chaired by the Governor, that claimed to work for the state's image but effectively spied on activists and passed information to the local White Citizens' Councils to suppress black activism.

name: mississippi
sentence: White Citizens Councils had been formed in many cities and towns to resist integration of schools following the unanimous 1954 United States Supreme Court ruling (Brown v. Board of Education) that segregation of public schools was unconstitutional.

name: mississippi
sentence: They used intimidation and economic blackmail against activists and suspected activists, including teachers and other professionals.

name: mississippi
sentence: Techniques included loss of jobs and eviction from rental housing.

name: mississippi
sentence: In the summer of 1964 students and community organizers from across the country came to help register black voters in Mississippi and establish Freedom Schools.

name: mississippi
sentence: The Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party was established to challenge the all-white Democratic Party of the Solid South.

name: mississippi
sentence: Most white politicians resisted such changes.

name: mississippi
sentence: Chapters of the Ku Klux Klan and its sympathizers used violence against activists, most notably the murders of Chaney, Goodman, and Schwerner in 1964 during the Freedom Summer campaign.

name: mississippi
sentence: This was a catalyst for Congressional passage the following year of the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

name: mississippi
sentence: Mississippi earned a reputation in the 1960s as a reactionary state.

name: mississippi
sentence: After decades of disenfranchisement, African Americans in the state gradually began to exercise their right to vote again for the first time since the 19th century, following the passage of federal civil rights legislation in 1964 and 1965, which ended de jure segregation and enforced constitutional voting rights.

name: mississippi
sentence: Registration of African-American voters increased and black candidates ran in the 1967 elections for state and local offices.

name: mississippi
sentence: The Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party fielded some candidates.

name: mississippi
sentence: Teacher Robert G. Clark of Holmes County was the first African American to be elected to the State House since Reconstruction.

name: mississippi
sentence: He continued as the only African American in the state legislature until 1976 and was repeatedly elected into the 21st century, including three terms as Speaker of the House.

name: mississippi
sentence: In 1966, the state was the last to repeal officially statewide prohibition of alcohol.

name: mississippi
sentence: Before that, Mississippi had taxed the illegal alcohol brought in by bootleggers.

name: mississippi
sentence: Governor Paul Johnson urged repeal and the sheriff "raided the annual Junior League Mardi Gras ball at the Jackson Country Club, breaking open the liquor cabinet and carting off the Champagne before a startled crowd of nobility and high-ranking state officials".

name: mississippi
sentence: On August 17, 1969, Category 5 Hurricane Camille hit the Mississippi coast, killing 248 people and causing US$1.5 billion in damage (1969 dollars).

name: mississippi
sentence: Mississippi ratified the Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, in March 1984, which had already entered into force by August 1920; granting women the right to vote.

sentence: The end of legal segregation and Jim Crow led to the integration of some churches, but most today remain divided along racial and cultural lines, having developed different traditions.

sentence: In more diverse communities, such as Hattiesburg, some churches have multiracial congregations.

sentence: Matthew Snipp, also a demographer, commented on the increase in the 21st century in the number of people identifying as being of more than one race: "In a sense, they're rendering a more accurate portrait of their racial heritage that in the past would have been suppressed."

sentence: Many Mississippians of such ancestry identify simply as American on questionnaires, because their families have been in North America for centuries.

sentence: Due to patterns of settlement and whites putting their children in private schools, in almost all of Mississippi's public school districts, a majority of students are African American.

sentence: In 2011, Mississippi (and Arkansas) had the fewest dentists per capita in the United States.

sentence: For three years in a row, more than 30 percent of Mississippi's residents have been classified as obese.

name: mississippi
sentence: In a 2006 study, 22.8 percent of the state's children were classified as such.

name: mississippi
sentence: Mississippi had the highest rate of obesity of any US state from 2005 to 2008, and also ranks first in the nation for high blood pressure, diabetes, and adult inactivity.

name: mississippi
sentence: In a 2008 study of African-American women, contributing risk factors were shown to be: lack of knowledge about body mass index (BMI), dietary behavior, physical inactivity and lack of social support, defined as motivation and encouragement by friends.

name: mississippi
sentence: A 2002 report on African-American adolescents noted a 1999 survey which suggests that a third of children were obese, with higher ratios for those in the Delta.

name: mississippi
sentence: The study stressed that "obesity starts in early childhood extending into the adolescent years and then possibly into adulthood".

name: mississippi
sentence: It noted impediments to needed behavioral modification, including the Delta likely being "the most underserved region in the state" with African Americans the major ethnic group; lack of accessibility and availability of medical care; and an estimated 60% of residents living below the poverty level.

name: mississippi
sentence: Additional risk factors were that most schools had no physical education curriculum and nutrition education is not emphasized.

name: mississippi
sentence: Previous intervention strategies may have been largely ineffective due to not being culturally sensitive or practical.

name: mississippi
sentence: A 2006 survey found nearly 95 percent of Mississippi adults considered childhood obesity to be a serious problem.

name: mississippi
sentence: A 2017 study found that Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Mississippi was the leading health insurer with 53% followed by UnitedHealth Group at 13%.

name: mississippi
sentence: The Bureau of Economic Analysis estimates that Mississippi's total state product in 2010 was $98 billion.

name: mississippi
sentence: GDP growth was .5 percent in 2015 and is estimated to be 2.4 in 2016 according to Dr. Darrin Webb, the state's chief economist, who noted it would make two consecutive years of positive growth since the recession.

name: mississippi
sentence: Per capita personal income in 2006 was $26,908, the lowest per capita personal income of any state, but the state also has the nation's lowest living costs.

name: mississippi
sentence: 2015 data records the adjusted per capita personal income at $40,105.

name: mississippi
sentence: Mississippians consistently rank as one of the highest per capita in charitable contributions.

name: mississippi
sentence: At 56 percent, the state has one of the lowest workforce participation rates in the country.

name: mississippi
sentence: Approximately 70,000 adults are disabled, which is 10 percent of the workforce.

name: mississippi
sentence: Mississippi's rank as one of the poorest states is related to its dependence on cotton agriculture before and after the Civil War, late development of its frontier bottomlands in the Mississippi Delta, repeated natural disasters of flooding in the late 19th and early 20th century that required massive capital investment in levees, and ditching and draining the bottomlands, and slow development of railroads to link bottomland towns and river cities.

name: mississippi
sentence: In addition, when Democrats regained control of the state legislature, they passed the 1890 constitution that discouraged corporate industrial development in favor of rural agriculture, a legacy that would slow the state's progress for years.

name: mississippi
sentence: Before the Civil War, Mississippi was the fifth-wealthiest state in the nation, its wealth generated by the labor of slaves in cotton plantations along the rivers.Slaves were counted as property and the rise in the cotton markets since the 1840s had increased their value.

name: mississippi
sentence: By 1860, a majority—55 percent—of the population of Mississippi was enslaved.

name: mississippi
sentence: Ninety percent of the Delta bottomlands were undeveloped and the state had low overall density of population.

name: mississippi
sentence: Largely due to the domination of the plantation economy, focused on the production of agricultural cotton, the state's elite was reluctant to invest in infrastructure such as roads and railroads.

name: mississippi
sentence: They educated their children privately.

name: mississippi
sentence: Industrialization did not reach many areas until the late 20th century.

name: mississippi
sentence: The planter aristocracy, the elite of antebellum Mississippi, kept the tax structure low for their own benefit, making only private improvements.

name: mississippi
sentence: Before the war the most successful planters, such as Confederate President Jefferson Davis, owned riverside properties along the Mississippi and Yazoo rivers in the Mississippi Delta.

name: mississippi
sentence: Away from the riverfronts, most of the Delta was undeveloped frontier.

name: mississippi
sentence: During the Civil War, 30,000 Mississippi soldiers, mostly white, died from wounds and disease, and many more were left crippled and wounded.

name: mississippi
sentence: Changes to the labor structure and an agricultural depression throughout the South caused severe losses in wealth.

name: mississippi
sentence: In 1860 assessed valuation of property in Mississippi had been more than $500 million, of which $218 million (43 percent) was estimated as the value of slaves.

name: mississippi
sentence: By 1870, total assets had decreased in value to roughly $177 million.

name: mississippi
sentence: Poor whites and landless former slaves suffered the most from the postwar economic depression.

name: mississippi
sentence: The constitutional convention of early 1868 appointed a committee to recommend what was needed for relief of the state and its citizens.

name: mississippi
sentence: The committee found severe destitution among the laboring classes.

name: mississippi
sentence: It took years for the state to rebuild levees damaged in battles.

name: mississippi
sentence: The upset of the commodity system impoverished the state after the war.

name: mississippi
sentence: By 1868 an increased cotton crop began to show possibilities for free labor in the state, but the crop of 565,000 bales produced in 1870 was still less than half of prewar figures.

name: mississippi
sentence: Blacks cleared land, selling timber and developing bottomland to achieve ownership.

name: mississippi
sentence: In 1900, two-thirds of farm owners in Mississippi were blacks, a major achievement for them and their families.

name: mississippi
sentence: Due to the poor economy, low cotton prices and difficulty of getting credit, many of these farmers could not make it through the extended financial difficulties.

name: mississippi
sentence: Two decades later, the majority of African Americans were sharecroppers.

name: mississippi
sentence: The low prices of cotton into the 1890s meant that more than a generation of African Americans lost the result of their labor when they had to sell their farms to pay off accumulated debts.

name: mississippi
sentence: After the Civil War, the state refused for years to build human capital by fully educating all its citizens.

name: mississippi
sentence: In addition, the reliance on agriculture grew increasingly costly as the state suffered loss of cotton crops due to the devastation of the boll weevil in the early 20th century, devastating floods in 1912–1913 and 1927, collapse of cotton prices after 1920, and drought in 1930.

name: mississippi
sentence: It was not until 1884, after the flood of 1882, that the state created the Mississippi-Yazoo Delta District Levee Board and started successfully achieving longer-term plans for levees in the upper Delta.

name: mississippi
sentence: Despite the state's building and reinforcing levees for years, the Great Mississippi Flood of 1927 broke through and caused massive flooding of 27,000 square miles (70,000 km2) throughout the Delta, homelessness for hundreds of thousands, and millions of dollars in property damages.

name: mississippi
sentence: With the Depression coming so soon after the flood, the state suffered badly during those years.

name: mississippi
sentence: In the Great Migration, hundreds of thousands of African Americans migrated North and West for jobs and chances to live as full citizens.

name: mississippi
sentence: The legislature's 1990 decision to legalize casino gambling along the Mississippi River and the Gulf Coast has led to increased revenues and economic gains for the state.

name: mississippi
sentence: Gambling towns in Mississippi have attracted increased tourism: they include the Gulf Coast resort towns of Bay St. Louis, Gulfport and Biloxi, and the Mississippi River towns of Tunica (the third largest gaming area in the United States), Greenville, Vicksburg and Natchez.

name: mississippi
sentence: Before Hurricane Katrina struck the Gulf Coast, Mississippi was the second-largest gambling state in the Union, after Nevada and ahead of New Jersey.

name: mississippi
sentence: An estimated $500,000 per day in tax revenue was lost following Hurricane Katrina's severe damage to several coastal casinos in Biloxi in August 2005.

name: mississippi
sentence: Because of the destruction from this hurricane, on October 17, 2005, Governor Haley Barbour signed a bill into law that allows casinos in Hancock and Harrison counties to rebuild on land (but within 800 feet (240 m) of the water).

name: mississippi
sentence: The only exception is in Harrison County, where the new law states that casinos can be built to the southern boundary of US Route 90.

name: mississippi
sentence: In 2012, Mississippi had the sixth largest gambling revenue of any state, with $2.25 billion.

name: mississippi
sentence: The federally recognized Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians has established a gaming casino on its reservation, which yields revenue to support education and economic development.

name: mississippi
sentence: Momentum Mississippi, a statewide, public–private partnership dedicated to the development of economic and employment opportunities in Mississippi, was adopted in 2005.

sentence: It has some major automotive factories, such as the Toyota Mississippi Plant in Blue Springs and a Nissan Automotive plant in Canton.

name: mississippi
sentence: Major cotton farmers in the Delta have large, mechanized plantations, and they receive the majority of extensive federal subsidies going to the state, yet many other residents still live as poor, rural, landless laborers.

name: mississippi
sentence: The state's sizable poultry industry has faced similar challenges in its transition from family-run farms to large mechanized operations.

name: mississippi
sentence: Of $1.2 billion from 2002 to 2005 in federal subsidies to farmers in the Bolivar County area of the Delta, only 5% went to small farmers.

name: mississippi
sentence: There has been little money apportioned for rural development.

name: mississippi
sentence: With Mississippi's fiscal conservatism, in which Medicaid, welfare, food stamps, and other social programs are often cut, eligibility requirements are tightened, and stricter employment criteria are imposed, Mississippi ranks as having the second-highest ratio of spending to tax receipts of any state.

name: mississippi
sentence: In 2005, Mississippi citizens received approximately $2.02 per dollar of taxes in the way of federal spending.

name: mississippi
sentence: This ranks the state second-highest nationally, and represents an increase from 1995, when Mississippi received $1.54 per dollar of taxes in federal spending and was 3rd highest nationally.

name: mississippi
sentence: This figure is based on federal spending after large portions of the state were devastated by Hurricane Katrina, requiring large amounts of federal aid from the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA).

name: mississippi
sentence: However, from 1981 to 2005, it was at least number four in the nation for federal spending vs. taxes received.

name: mississippi
sentence: A proportion of federal spending in Mississippi is directed toward large federal installations such as Camp Shelby, John C. Stennis Space Center, Meridian Naval Air Station, Columbus Air Force Base, and Keesler Air Force Base.

name: mississippi
sentence: Three of these installations are located in the area affected by Hurricane Katrina.

name: mississippi
sentence: As with all other US states and the federal government, Mississippi's government is based on the separation of legislative, executive and judicial power.

name: mississippi
sentence: Executive authority in the state rests with the Governor, currently Tate Reeves (R).

name: mississippi
sentence: The lieutenant governor, currently Delbert Hosemann (R), is elected on a separate ballot.

name: mississippi
sentence: Both the governor and lieutenant governor are elected to four-year terms of office.

name: mississippi
sentence: Unlike the federal government, but like many other US States, most of the heads of major executive departments are elected by the citizens of Mississippi rather than appointed by the governor.

name: mississippi
sentence: Mississippi is one of five states that elects its state officials in odd-numbered years (the others are Kentucky, Louisiana, New Jersey and Virginia).

name: mississippi
sentence: Mississippi holds elections for these offices every four years, always in the year preceding presidential elections.

name: mississippi
sentence: In 2004, Mississippi voters approved a state constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage and prohibiting Mississippi from recognizing same-sex marriages performed elsewhere.

name: mississippi
sentence: The amendment passed 86% to 14%, the largest margin in any state.

name: mississippi
sentence: Same-sex marriage became legal in Mississippi on June 26, 2015, when the United States Supreme Court invalidated all state-level bans on same-sex marriage as unconstitutional in the landmark case Obergefell v. Hodges.

name: mississippi
sentence: With the passing of HB 1523 in April 2016, from July it became legal in Mississippi to refuse service to same-sex couples, based on one's religious beliefs.

name: mississippi
sentence: The bill has become the subject of controversy.

name: mississippi
sentence: A federal judge blocked the law in July, however it was challenged and a federal appeals court ruled in favor of the law in October 2017.

sentence: Mississippi has banned sanctuary cities.

name: mississippi
sentence: Mississippi is one of thirty-one states which have capital punishment (see Capital punishment in Mississippi).

name: mississippi
sentence: Section 265 of the Constitution of the State of Mississippi declares that "No person who denies the existence of a Supreme Being shall hold any office in this state."

name: mississippi
sentence: This religious test restriction was held to be unconstitutional by the US Supreme Court in Torcaso v. Watkins (1961).

name: mississippi
sentence: Mississippi led the South in developing a disenfranchising constitution, passing it in 1890.

name: mississippi
sentence: By raising barriers to voter registration, the state legislature disenfranchised most blacks and many poor whites, excluding them from politics until the late 1960s.

name: mississippi
sentence: It established a one-party state dominated by white Democrats.

name: mississippi
sentence: In the 1980s whites divided evenly between the parties.

name: mississippi
sentence: In the 1990s those voters shifted their allegiance to the Republican Party, first for national and then for state offices.

name: mississippi
sentence: Most blacks were still disenfranchised under the state's 1890 constitution and discriminatory practices, until passage of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 and concerted grassroots efforts to achieve registration and encourage voting.

sentence: In 2019, a lawsuit was filed against an 1890 election law known as The Mississippi Plan, which requires that candidates must win the popular vote and a majority of districts.

name: mississippi

name: mississippi
sentence: Until the Civil War era, Mississippi had a small number of schools and no educational institutions for African Americans.

name: mississippi
sentence: The first school for black students was not established until 1862.

name: mississippi
sentence: During Reconstruction in 1871, black and white Republicans drafted a constitution that was the first to provide for a system of free public education in the state.

name: mississippi
sentence: The state's dependence on agriculture and resistance to taxation limited the funds it had available to spend on any schools.

name: mississippi
sentence: In the early 20th century, there were still few schools in rural areas, particularly for black children.

name: mississippi
sentence: With seed money from the Julius Rosenwald Fund, many rural black communities across Mississippi raised matching funds and contributed public funds to build new schools for their children.

name: mississippi
sentence: Essentially, many black adults taxed themselves twice and made significant sacrifices to raise money for the education of children in their communities, in many cases donating land and/or labor to build such schools.

name: mississippi
sentence: Blacks and whites attended segregated and separate public schools in Mississippi until the late 1960s, although such segregation had been declared unconstitutional by the United States Supreme Court in its 1954 ruling in Brown v. Board of Education.

name: mississippi
sentence: In the majority-black Mississippi Delta counties, white parents worked through White Citizens' Councils to set up private segregation academies, where they enrolled their children.

name: mississippi
sentence: Often funding declined for the public schools.

name: mississippi
sentence: But in the state as a whole, only a small minority of white children were withdrawn from public schools.

name: mississippi
sentence: State officials believed they needed to maintain public education to attract new businesses.

name: mississippi
sentence: After several years of integration, whites often dominated local systems anyway, maintaining white supremacy.

name: mississippi
sentence: Many black parents complained that they had little representation in school administration, and that many of their former administrators and teachers had been pushed out.

name: mississippi
sentence: They have had to work to have their interests and children represented.

name: mississippi
sentence: In the late 1980s Mississippi's 954 public schools enrolled about 369,500 elementary and 132,500 secondary students.

name: mississippi
sentence: Some 45,700 students attended private schools.

name: mississippi
sentence: In the 21st century, 91% of white children and most of the black children in the state attend public schools.

name: mississippi
sentence: In 2008, Mississippi was ranked last among the fifty states in academic achievement by the American Legislative Exchange Council's Report Card on Education, with the lowest average ACT scores and sixth-lowest spending per pupil in the nation.

name: mississippi
sentence: In contrast, Mississippi had the 17th-highest average SAT scores in the nation.

name: mississippi
sentence: As an explanation, the Report noted that 92% of Mississippi high school graduates took the ACT, but only 3% of graduates took the SAT, apparently a self-selection of higher achievers.

name: mississippi
sentence: This breakdown compares to the national average of high school graduates taking the ACT and SAT, of 43% and 45%, respectively.

name: mississippi
sentence: Generally prohibited in the West at large, school corporal punishment is not unusual in Mississippi, with 31,236 public school students paddled at least one time circa 2016.

name: mississippi
sentence: A greater percentage of students were paddled in Mississippi than in any other state, according to government data for the 2011–2012 school year.

name: mississippi
sentence: In 2007, Mississippi students scored the lowest of any state on the National Assessments of Educational Progress in both math and science.

name: mississippi
sentence: Jackson, the state's capital city, is the site of the state residential school for deaf and hard of hearing students.

name: mississippi
sentence: The Mississippi School for the Deaf was established by the state legislature in 1854 before the civil war.

name: mississippi
sentence: While Mississippi has been especially known for its music and literature, it has embraced other forms of art.

sentence: Its strong religious traditions have inspired striking works by outsider artists who have been shown nationally.

sentence: George Ohr, known as the "Mad Potter of Biloxi" and the father of abstract expressionism in pottery, lived and worked in Biloxi, MS.
