sentence: Performing arts

name: nebraska
sentence: Nebraska is currently home to seven member schools of the NCAA, eight of the NAIA, seven of the NJCAA, one of the NCCAA, and one independent school.

name: nebraska
sentence: The College World Series has been held in Omaha since 1950.

name: nebraska
sentence: It was held at Rosenblatt Stadium from 1950 through 2010, and has been domiciled at TD Ameritrade Park Omaha since 2011.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada (, Spanish: [neˈβaða]) is a state in the Western United States.

name: nevada
sentence: It is bordered by Oregon to the northwest, Idaho to the northeast, California to the west, Arizona to the southeast, and Utah to the east.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada is the 7th-most extensive, the 19th-least populous, but the 9th-least densely populated of the US states.

name: nevada
sentence: Nearly three-quarters of Nevada's people live in Clark County, which contains the Las Vegas–Paradise metropolitan area, including three of the state's four largest incorporated cities.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada's capital is Carson City.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada is officially known as the "Silver State" because of the importance of silver to its history and economy.

name: nevada
sentence: It is also known as the "Battle Born State" because it achieved statehood during the Civil War (the words "Battle Born" also appear on the state flag); as the "Sagebrush State", for the native plant of the same name; and as the "Sage-hen State".

name: nevada
sentence: The name means "snow-covered" in Spanish, referring to Nevada's small overlap with the Sierra Nevada mountain range; however, the rest of Nevada is largely desert and semi-arid, much of it within the Great Basin.

name: nevada
sentence: Areas south of the Great Basin are within the Mojave Desert, while Lake Tahoe and the Sierra Nevada lie on the western edge.

name: nevada
sentence: About 86% of the state's land is managed by various jurisdictions of the US federal government, both civilian and military.

name: nevada
sentence: American Indians of the Paiute, Shoshone, and Washoe tribes inhabited what is now Nevada.

name: nevada
sentence: The first Europeans to explore the region were Spanish.

name: nevada
sentence: They called the region Nevada (snowy) because of the snow which covered the mountains in winter similar to the Sierra Nevada in Spain.

name: nevada
sentence: The area formed part of Alta California's territory within the Viceroyalty of New Spain, which gained independence as Mexico in 1821.

name: nevada
sentence: The United States annexed the area in 1848 after its victory in the Mexican–American War, and it was incorporated as part of Utah Territory in 1850.

name: nevada
sentence: The discovery of silver at the Comstock Lode in 1859 led to a population boom that became an impetus to the creation of Nevada Territory out of western Utah Territory in 1861.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada became the 36th state on October 31, 1864, as the second of two states added to the Union during the Civil War (the first being West Virginia).

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada has a reputation for its libertarian laws.

name: nevada
sentence: In 1940, with a population of just over 110,000 people, Nevada was by far the least-populated state, with less than half the population of the next least-populated state, Wyoming.

name: nevada
sentence: However, legalized gambling and lenient marriage and divorce laws transformed Nevada into a major tourist destination in the 20th century.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada is the only US state where prostitution is legal, though it is illegal in its most populated regions – Clark County (Las Vegas), Washoe County (Reno) and Carson City (which, as an independent city, is not within the boundaries of any county).

name: nevada
sentence: The tourism industry remains Nevada's largest employer, with mining continuing as a substantial sector of the economy: Nevada is the fourth-largest producer of gold in the world.

name: nevada
sentence: The name "Nevada" comes from the Spanish nevada [neˈβaða], meaning "snow-covered".

name: nevada
sentence: Nevadans pronounce the second syllable with the "a" as in "trap" () while some people from outside of the state can pronounce it with the "a" as in "palm" ().

name: nevada
sentence: Although the latter pronunciation is closer to the Spanish pronunciation, it is not the pronunciation used by Nevadans.

name: nevada
sentence: State Assemblyman Harry Mortenson proposed a bill to recognize the alternate (quasi-Spanish) pronunciation of Nevada, though the bill was not supported by most legislators and never received a vote.

name: nevada
sentence: The Nevadan pronunciation is the one used by the state legislature.

name: nevada
sentence: At one time, the state's official tourism organization, TravelNevada, stylized the name of the state as "Nevăda", with a breve over the a indicating the locally preferred pronunciation, which was also available as a license plate design until 2007.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada is almost entirely within the Basin and Range Province and is broken up by many north–south mountain ranges.

name: nevada
sentence: Most of these ranges have endorheic valleys between them, which belies the image portrayed by the term Great Basin.

name: nevada
sentence: Much of the northern part of the state is within the Great Basin, a mild desert that experiences hot temperatures in the summer and cold temperatures in the winter.

name: nevada
sentence: Occasionally, moisture from the Arizona Monsoon will cause summer thunderstorms; Pacific storms may blanket the area with snow.

name: nevada
sentence: The state's highest recorded temperature was 125 °F (52 °C) in Laughlin (elevation of 605 feet or 184 meters) on June 29, 1994.

name: nevada
sentence: The coldest recorded temperature was −52 °F (−47 °C) set in San Jacinto in 1972, in the northeastern portion of the state.

name: nevada
sentence: The Humboldt River crosses the state from east to west across the northern part of the state, draining into the Humboldt Sink near Lovelock.

name: nevada
sentence: Several rivers drain from the Sierra Nevada eastward, including the Walker, Truckee, and Carson rivers.

name: nevada
sentence: All of these rivers are endorheic basins, ending in Walker Lake, Pyramid Lake, and the Carson Sink, respectively.

name: nevada
sentence: However, not all of Nevada is within the Great Basin.

name: nevada
sentence: Tributaries of the Snake River drain the far north, while the Colorado River, which also forms much of the boundary with Arizona, drains much of southern Nevada.

name: nevada
sentence: The mountain ranges, some of which have peaks above 13,000 feet (4,000 m), harbor lush forests high above desert plains, creating sky islands for endemic species.

name: nevada
sentence: The valleys are often no lower in elevation than 3,000 feet (910 m), while some in central Nevada are above 6,000 feet (1,800 m).

name: nevada
sentence: The southern third of the state, where the Las Vegas area is situated, is within the Mojave Desert.

name: nevada
sentence: The area receives less rain in the winter but is closer to the Arizona Monsoon in the summer.

name: nevada
sentence: The terrain is also lower, mostly below 4,000 feet (1,200 m), creating conditions for hot summer days and cool to chilly winter nights.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada and California have by far the longest diagonal line (in respect to the cardinal directions) as a state boundary at just over 400 miles (640 km).

name: nevada
sentence: This line begins in Lake Tahoe nearly 4 miles (6.4 km) offshore (in the direction of the boundary), and continues to the Colorado River where the Nevada, California, and Arizona boundaries merge 12 miles (19 km) southwest of the Laughlin Bridge.

name: nevada
sentence: The largest mountain range in the southern portion of the state is the Spring Mountain Range, just west of Las Vegas.

name: nevada
sentence: The state's lowest point is along the Colorado River, south of Laughlin.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada has 172 mountain summits with 2,000 feet (610 m) of prominence.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada ranks second in the United States by the number of mountains, behind Alaska, and ahead of California, Montana, and Washington.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada is the most mountainous state in the contiguous United States.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada is the driest state in the United States.

name: nevada
sentence: It is made up of mostly desert and semi-arid climate regions, and, with the exception of the Las Vegas Valley, the average summer diurnal temperature range approaches 40 °F (22 °C) in much of the state.

name: nevada
sentence: While winters in northern Nevada are long and fairly cold, the winter season in the southern part of the state tends to be of short duration and mild.

name: nevada
sentence: Most parts of Nevada receive scarce precipitation during the year.

name: nevada
sentence: The most rain that falls in the state falls on the lee side (east and northeast slopes) of the Sierra Nevada.

name: nevada
sentence: The average annual rainfall per year is about 7 inches (180 mm); the wettest parts get around 40 inches (1,000 mm).

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada's highest recorded temperature is 125 °F (52 °C) at Laughlin on June 29, 1994 and the lowest recorded temperature is −50 °F (−46 °C) at San Jacinto on January 8, 1937.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada's 125 °F (52 °C) reading is the third highest statewide record high temperature of a US state, just behind Arizona's 128 °F (53 °C) reading and California's 134 °F (57 °C) reading.

name: nevada
sentence: The vegetation of Nevada is diverse and differs by state area.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada contains six biotic zones: alpine, sub-alpine, ponderosa pine, pinion-juniper, sagebrush and creosotebush.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada is divided into political jurisdictions designated as counties.

name: nevada
sentence: Carson City is officially a consolidated municipality; however, for many purposes under state law, it is considered to be a county.

name: nevada
sentence: As of 1919, there were 17 counties in the state, ranging from 146 to 18,159 square miles (380 to 47,030 km2).

name: nevada
sentence: Lake County, one of the original nine counties formed in 1861, was renamed Roop County in 1862.

name: nevada
sentence: Part of the county became Lassen County, California in 1864.

name: nevada
sentence: In 1883, Washoe County annexed the portion that remained in Nevada.

name: nevada
sentence: In 1969, Ormsby County was dissolved and the Consolidated Municipality of Carson City was created by the Legislature in its place coterminous with the old boundaries of Ormsby County.

name: nevada
sentence: Bullfrog County was formed in 1987 from part of Nye County.

name: nevada
sentence: After the creation was declared unconstitutional, the county was abolished in 1989.

name: nevada
sentence: Humboldt county was designated as a county in 1856 by Utah Territorial Legislature and again in 1861 by the new Nevada Legislature.

name: nevada
sentence: Clark County is the most populous county in Nevada, accounting for nearly three-quarters of its residents.

name: nevada
sentence: Las Vegas, Nevada's most populous city, has been the county seat since the county was created in 1909 from a portion of Lincoln County, Nevada.

name: nevada
sentence: Before that, it was a part of Arizona Territory.

name: nevada
sentence: Clark County attracts numerous tourists: An estimated 44 million people visited Clark County in 2014.

name: nevada
sentence: Washoe County is the second-most populous county of Nevada.

name: nevada
sentence: Its county seat is Reno.

name: nevada
sentence: Washoe County includes the Reno–Sparks metropolitan area.

name: nevada
sentence: Lyon County is the third most populous county.

name: nevada
sentence: It was one of the nine original counties created in 1861.

name: nevada
sentence: It was named after Nathaniel Lyon, the first Union General to be killed in the Civil War.

name: nevada
sentence: Its current county seat is Yerington.

name: nevada
sentence: Its first county seat was established at Dayton on November 29, 1861.

name: nevada
sentence: Francisco Garcés was the first European in the area.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada was annexed as a part of the Spanish Empire in the northwestern territory of New Spain.

name: nevada
sentence: Administratively, the area of Nevada was part of the Commandancy General of the Provincias Internas in the Viceroyalty of New Spain.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada became a part of Alta California (Upper California) province in 1804 when the Californias were split.

name: nevada
sentence: With the Mexican War of Independence won in 1821, the province of Alta California became a territory (state) of Mexico, with a small population.

name: nevada
sentence: Jedediah Smith entered the Las Vegas Valley in 1827, and Peter Skene Ogden traveled the Humboldt River in 1828.

name: nevada
sentence: When the Mormons created the State of Deseret in 1847, they laid claim to all of Nevada within the Great Basin and the Colorado watershed.

name: nevada
sentence: They also founded the first white settlement in what is now Nevada, Mormon Station (modern-day Genoa), in 1851.

name: nevada
sentence: In June 1855, William Bringhurst and 29 fellow Mormon missionaries from Utah arrived at a site just northeast of downtown Las Vegas and built a 150-foot square adobe fort, the first permanent structure erected in the valley, which remained under the control of Salt Lake City until the winter of 1858–1859.

name: nevada
sentence: As a result of the Mexican–American War and the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo, Mexico permanently lost Alta California in 1848.

name: nevada
sentence: The new areas acquired by the United States continued to be administered as territories.

name: nevada
sentence: As part of the Mexican Cession (1848) and the subsequent California Gold Rush that used Emigrant Trails through the area, the state's area evolved first as part of the Utah Territory, then the Nevada Territory (March 2, 1861; named for the Sierra Nevada).

name: nevada
sentence: See History of Utah, History of Las Vegas, and the discovery of the first major US deposit of silver ore in Comstock Lode under Virginia City, Nevada, in 1859.

name: nevada
sentence: On March 2, 1861, the Nevada Territory separated from the Utah Territory and adopted its current name, shortened from The Sierra Nevada (Spanish for "snow-covered mountain range").

name: nevada
sentence: The 1861 southern boundary is commemorated by Nevada Historical Markers 57 and 58 in Lincoln and Nye counties.

name: nevada
sentence: Eight days before the presidential election of 1864, Nevada became the 36th state in the union, despite lacking the minimum requisite 60,000 residents in order to become a state.

name: nevada
sentence: (At the time Nevada's population was little more than 10,000.)

name: nevada
sentence: Rather than sending the Nevada constitution to Washington by Pony Express, the full text was sent by telegraph at a cost of $4,303.27 – the most costly telegraph on file at the time for a single dispatch.

name: nevada
sentence: Finally, the response from Washington came on October 31, 1864: "the pain is over, the child is born, Nevada this day was admitted into the Union".

name: nevada
sentence: Statehood was rushed to the date of October 31 to help ensure Abraham Lincoln's reelection on November 8 and post-Civil War Republican dominance in Congress, as Nevada's mining-based economy tied it to the more industrialized Union.

name: nevada
sentence: As it turned out, however, Lincoln and the Republicans won the election handily and did not need Nevada's help.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada is one of only two states to significantly expand its borders after admission to the Union.

name: nevada
sentence: (The other is Missouri, which acquired additional territory in 1837 due to the Platte Purchase.)

name: nevada
sentence: In 1866 another part of the western Utah Territory was added to Nevada in the eastern part of the state, setting the current eastern boundary.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada achieved its current southern boundaries on January 18, 1867, when it absorbed the portion of Pah-Ute County in the Arizona Territory west of the Colorado River, essentially all of present-day Nevada south of the 37th parallel.

name: nevada
sentence: The transfer was prompted by the discovery of gold in the area, and officials thought Nevada would be better able to oversee the expected population boom.

name: nevada
sentence: This area includes most of what is now Clark County and the Las Vegas metropolitan area.

name: nevada
sentence: Mining shaped Nevada's economy for many years (see Silver mining in Nevada).

name: nevada
sentence: When Mark Twain lived in Nevada during the period described in Roughing It, mining had led to an industry of speculation and immense wealth.

name: nevada
sentence: Both mining and population temporarily declined in the late 19th century.

name: nevada
sentence: However, the rich silver strike at Tonopah in 1900, followed by strikes in Goldfield and Rhyolite, created a second mining boom in Nevada and Nevada's population.

name: nevada
sentence: Unregulated gambling was commonplace in the early Nevada mining towns but was outlawed in 1909 as part of a nationwide anti-gambling crusade.

name: nevada
sentence: Because of subsequent declines in mining output and the decline of the agricultural sector during the Great Depression, Nevada again legalized gambling on March 19, 1931, with approval from the legislature.

name: nevada
sentence: Governor Fred B. Balzar's signature enacted the most liberal divorce laws in the country and open gambling.

name: nevada
sentence: The reforms came just eight days after the federal government presented the $49 million construction contract for Boulder Dam (now Hoover Dam).

name: nevada
sentence: The Nevada Test Site, 65 miles (105 km) northwest of the city of Las Vegas, was founded on January 11, 1951, for the testing of nuclear weapons.

name: nevada
sentence: The site consists of about 1,350 square miles (3,500 km2) of the desert and mountainous terrain.

name: nevada
sentence: Nuclear testing at the Nevada Test Site began with a 1 kiloton of TNT (4.2 TJ) bomb dropped on Frenchman Flat on January 27, 1951.

name: nevada
sentence: The last atmospheric test was conducted on July 17, 1962, and the underground testing of weapons continued until September 23, 1992.

name: nevada
sentence: The location is known for having the highest concentration of nuclear-detonated weapons in the US

name: nevada
sentence: Over 80% of the state's area is owned by the federal government.

name: nevada
sentence: The primary reason for this is homesteads were not permitted in large enough sizes to be viable in the arid conditions that prevail throughout desert Nevada.

name: nevada
sentence: Instead, early settlers would homestead land surrounding a water source, and then graze livestock on the adjacent public land, which is useless for agriculture without access to water (this pattern of ranching still prevails).

name: nevada
sentence: The United States Census Bureau estimates the population of Nevada on July 1, 2019, was 3,080,156, an increase of 45,764 residents (1.51%) since the 2018 US Census estimate and an increase of 379,605 residents (14.06%) since the 2010 United States Census.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada had the highest percentage growth in population from 2017 to 2018.

name: nevada
sentence: At the 2010 Census, 6.9% of the state's population were reported as under 5, 24.6% were under 18, and 12.0% were 65 or older.

name: nevada
sentence: Females made up about 49.5% of the population.

name: nevada
sentence: Since the 2010 census, the population of Nevada had a natural increase of 87,581 (the net difference between 222,508 births and 134,927 deaths); and an increase due to net migration of 146,626 (of which 104,032 was due to domestic and 42,594 was due to international migration).

name: nevada
sentence: The center of population of Nevada is in southern Nye County.

name: nevada
sentence: In this county, the unincorporated town of Pahrump, 60 miles (97 km) west of Las Vegas on the California state line, has grown very rapidly from 1980 to 2010.

name: nevada
sentence: At the 2010 census, the town had 36,441 residents.

name: nevada
sentence: Las Vegas grew from a gulch of 100 people in 1900 to 10,000 by 1950 to 100,000 by 1970, and was America's fastest-growing city and metropolitan area from 1960 to 2000.

name: nevada
sentence: From about the 1940s until 2003, Nevada was the fastest-growing state in the US percentage-wise.

name: nevada
sentence: Between 1990 and 2000, Nevada's population increased by 66%, while the nation's population increased by 13%.

name: nevada
sentence: More than two-thirds of the population live in Clark County, which is coextensive with the Las Vegas metropolitan area.

name: nevada
sentence: Thus, in terms of population, Nevada is one of the most centralized states in the nation.

name: nevada
sentence: Henderson and North Las Vegas are among the top 20 fastest-growing US cities with populations over 100,000.

name: nevada
sentence: The rural community of Mesquite 65 miles (105 km) northeast of Las Vegas was an example of micropolitan growth in the 1990s and 2000s.

name: nevada
sentence: Other desert towns like Indian Springs and Searchlight on the outskirts of Las Vegas have seen some growth as well.

name: nevada
sentence: Since 1950, the rate of population born in Nevada has never peaked above 27 percent, the lowest rate of all states.

name: nevada
sentence: In 2012, only 25% of Nevadans were born in-state.

name: nevada
sentence: Most new residents in Nevada have moved from California, which has led a few Nevadans to feel their state is being "Californicated".

name: nevada
sentence: According to the 2017 American Community Survey, 28.2% of Nevada's population were of Hispanic or Latino origin (of any race): Mexican (21.4%), Puerto Rican (0.9%), Cuban (1.0%), and other Hispanic or Latino origin (4.8%).

name: nevada
sentence: The five largest non-Hispanic White ancestry groups were: German (11.3%), Irish (9.0%), English (6.9%), Italian (5.8%), and American (4.7%).

name: nevada
sentence: In 1980, non-Hispanic whites made up 83.3% of the state's population.

name: nevada
sentence: As of 2011, 63.6% of Nevada's population younger than age 1 were minorities.

name: nevada
sentence: Las Vegas is a minority majority city.

name: nevada
sentence: According to the United States Census Bureau estimates, as of July 1, 2018, non-Hispanic Whites made up 48.7% of Nevada's population.

name: nevada
sentence: In Douglas, Mineral, and Pershing counties, a plurality of residents are of Mexican ancestry.

name: nevada
sentence: In Nye County and Humboldt County, residents are mostly of German ancestry; Washoe County has many Irish Americans.

name: nevada
sentence: Americans of English descent form pluralities in Lincoln County, Churchill County, Lyon County, White Pine County, and Eureka County.

name: nevada
sentence: Asian Americans lived in the state since the California Gold Rush of the 1850s brought thousands of Chinese miners to Washoe county.

name: nevada
sentence: They were followed by a few hundred Japanese farmworkers in the late 19th century.

name: nevada
sentence: By the late 20th century, many immigrants from China, Japan, Korea, the Philippines, Bangladesh, India, and Vietnam came to the Las Vegas metropolitan area.

name: nevada
sentence: The city now has one of America's most prolific Asian American communities, with a mostly Chinese and Taiwanese area known as "Chinatown" west of I-15 on Spring Mountain Road.

name: nevada
sentence: Filipino Americans form the largest Asian American group in the state, with a population of more than 113,000.

name: nevada
sentence: They comprise 56.5% of the Asian American population in Nevada and constitute about 4.3% of the entire state's population.

name: nevada
sentence: Mining booms drew many Greek and Eastern European immigrants to Nevada.

name: nevada
sentence: Native American tribes in Nevada are the Koso, Paiute, Panamint, Shoshoni, Walapi, Washoe and Ute tribes.

name: nevada
sentence: The top countries of origin for immigrants in Nevada were Mexico (39.5 percent of immigrants), the Philippines (14.3 percent), El Salvador (5.2 percent), China (3.1 percent), and Cuba (3 percent).

name: nevada
sentence: Note: Births within the table do not add up, due to Hispanics being counted both by their ethnicity and by their race, giving a higher overall number.

name: nevada
sentence: A small percentage of Nevada's population lives in rural areas.

name: nevada
sentence: The culture of these places differs significantly from major metropolitan areas.

name: nevada
sentence: People in these rural counties tend to be native Nevada residents, unlike in the Las Vegas and Reno areas, where the vast majority of the population was born in another state.

name: nevada
sentence: The rural population is also less diverse in terms of race and ethnicity.

name: nevada
sentence: Mining plays an important role in the economies of the rural counties, with tourism being less prominent.

name: nevada
sentence: Ranching also has a long tradition in rural Nevada.

name: nevada
sentence: Church attendance in Nevada is among the lowest of all US states.

name: nevada
sentence: In a 2009 Gallup poll only 30% of Nevadans said they attended church weekly or almost weekly, compared to 42% of all Americans (only four states were found to have a lower attendance rate than Nevada's).

name: nevada
sentence: Major religious affiliations of the people of Nevada are: Protestant 35%, no religion 28%, Roman Catholic 25%, Latter-day Saint 4%, Jewish 2%, Hindu less than 1%, Buddhist 0.5% and Islam less than 0.1%.

name: nevada
sentence: Parts of Nevada (in the eastern parts of the state) are situated in the Mormon Corridor.

name: nevada
sentence: The largest denominations by number of adherents in 2010 were the Roman Catholic Church with 451,070; The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints with 175,149; and the Southern Baptist Convention with 45,535; Buddhist congregations 14,727; Baháʼí Faith 1,723; and Muslim 1,700.

name: nevada
sentence: The Jewish community is represented by The Rohr Jewish Learning Institute and Chabad.

name: nevada
sentence: The economy of Nevada is tied to tourism (especially entertainment and gambling related), mining, and cattle ranching.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada's industrial outputs are tourism, entertainment, mining, machinery, printing and publishing, food processing, and electric equipment.

name: nevada
sentence: The Bureau of Economic Analysis estimates Nevada's total state product in 2018 was $170 billion.

name: nevada
sentence: The state's per capita personal income in 2018 was $43,820, ranking 35th in the nation.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada's state debt in 2012 was calculated to be $7.5 billion, or $3,100 per taxpayer.

name: nevada
sentence: As of December 2014, the state's unemployment rate was 6.8%.

name: nevada
sentence: The economy of Nevada has long been tied to vice industries.

name: nevada
sentence: "[Nevada was] founded on mining and refounded on sin – beginning with prizefighting and easy divorce a century ago and later extending to gaming and prostitution", said the August 21, 2010 issue of The Economist.

name: nevada
sentence: In portions of the state outside of the Las Vegas and Reno metropolitan areas mining plays a major economic role.

name: nevada
sentence: By value, gold is by far the most important mineral mined.

name: nevada
sentence: In 2004, 6,800,000 ounces (190,000,000 g) of gold worth $2.84 billion were mined in Nevada, and the state accounted for 8.7% of world gold production (see Gold mining in Nevada).

name: nevada
sentence: Silver is a distant second, with 10,300,000 ounces (290,000,000 g) worth $69 million mined in 2004 (see Silver mining in Nevada).

name: nevada
sentence: Other minerals mined in Nevada include construction aggregates, copper, gypsum, diatomite and lithium.

name: nevada
sentence: Despite its rich deposits, the cost of mining in Nevada is generally high, and output is very sensitive to world commodity prices.

name: nevada
sentence: Cattle ranching is a major economic activity in rural Nevada.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada's agricultural outputs are cattle, hay, alfalfa, dairy products, onions, and potatoes.

name: nevada
sentence: As of January 1, 2006, there were an estimated 500,000 head of cattle and 70,000 head of sheep in Nevada.

name: nevada
sentence: Most of these animals forage on rangeland in the summer, with supplemental feed in the winter.

name: nevada
sentence: Calves are generally shipped to out-of-state feedlots in the fall to be fattened for the market.

name: nevada
sentence: Over 90% of Nevada's 484,000 acres (196,000 ha) of cropland is used to grow hay, mostly alfalfa, for livestock feed.

name: nevada
sentence: The largest employers in the state, as of the first fiscal quarter of 2011, are the following, according to the Nevada Department of Employment, Training and Rehabilitation:

name: nevada
sentence: Amtrak's California Zephyr train uses the Union Pacific's original transcontinental railroad line in daily service from Chicago to Emeryville, California, serving Elko, Winnemucca, and Reno.

name: nevada
sentence: Las Vegas has had no passenger train service since Amtrak's Desert Wind was discontinued in 1997.

name: nevada
sentence: Amtrak Thruway Motorcoaches provide connecting service from Las Vegas to trains at Needles, California, Los Angeles, and Bakersfield, California; and from Stateline, Nevada, to Sacramento, California.

name: nevada
sentence: There have been a number of proposals to re-introduce service to either Los Angeles or Southern California.

name: nevada
sentence: The Union Pacific Railroad has some railroads in the north and south of Nevada.

name: nevada
sentence: Greyhound Lines provide some bus service to the state.

name: nevada
sentence: Interstate 15 (I-15) passes through the southern tip of the state, serving Las Vegas and other communities.

name: nevada
sentence: I-215 and I-515 also serve the Las Vegas metropolitan area.

name: nevada
sentence: I-80 crosses through the northern part of Nevada, roughly following the path of the Humboldt River from Utah in the east and the Truckee River westward through Reno into California.

name: nevada
sentence: It has a spur route, I-580.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada also is served by several US highways: US 6, US 50, US 93, US 95 and US 395.

name: nevada
sentence: There are also 189 Nevada state routes.

name: nevada
sentence: Many of Nevada's counties have a system of county routes as well, though many are not signed or paved in rural areas.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada is one of a few states in the US that do not have a continuous interstate highway linking its two major population centers – the road connection between the Las Vegas and Reno areas is a combination of several different Interstate and US highways.

name: nevada
sentence: The Interstate 11 proposed routing may eventually remedy this.

name: nevada
sentence: The state is one of just a few in the country to allow semi-trailer trucks with three trailers – what might be called a "road train" in Australia.

name: nevada
sentence: But American versions are usually smaller, in part because they must ascend and descend some fairly steep mountain passes.

name: nevada
sentence: RTC Transit is the public transit system in the Las Vegas metropolitan area.

name: nevada
sentence: The agency is the largest transit agency in the state and operates a network of bus service across the Las Vegas Valley, including the use of The Deuce, double-decker buses, on the Las Vegas Strip and several outlying routes.

name: nevada
sentence: RTC RIDE operates a system of local transit bus service throughout the Reno-Sparks metropolitan area.

name: nevada
sentence: Other transit systems in the state include Carson City's JAC.

name: nevada
sentence: Most other counties in the state do not have public transportation at all.

name: nevada
sentence: Additionally, a 4-mile (6.4 km) monorail system provides public transportation in the Las Vegas area.

name: nevada
sentence: The Las Vegas Monorail line services several casino properties and the Las Vegas Convention Center on the east side of the Las Vegas Strip, running near Paradise Road, with a possible future extension to McCarran International Airport.

name: nevada
sentence: Several hotels also run their own monorail lines between each other, which are typically several blocks in length.

name: nevada
sentence: McCarran International Airport in Las Vegas is the busiest airport serving Nevada.

name: nevada
sentence: The Reno-Tahoe International Airport (formerly known as the Reno Cannon International Airport) is the other major airport in the state.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada has had a thriving solar energy sector.

name: nevada
sentence: An independent study in 2013 concluded that solar users created a $36 million net benefit.

name: nevada
sentence: However, in December 2015, the Public Utility Commission let the state's only power company, NV Energy, charge higher rates and fees to solar panel users, leading to an immediate collapse of rooftop solar panel use

name: nevada
sentence: In December 1987, Congress amended the Nuclear Waste Policy Act to designate Yucca Mountain nuclear waste repository as the only site to be characterized as a permanent repository for all of the nation's highly radioactive waste.

name: nevada
sentence: Under the Constitution of the State of Nevada, the powers of the Nevada government are divided among three separate departments: the executive consisting of the governor of Nevada and their cabinet along with the other elected constitutional officers; the legislative consisting of the Nevada Legislature, which includes the Assembly and the Senatorte; and the judicial consisting of the Supreme Court of Nevada and lower courts.

name: nevada
sentence: The governor is the chief magistrate of Nevada, the head of the executive department of the state's government, and the commander-in-chief of the state's military forces.

name: nevada
sentence: The current governor is Steve Sisolak, a Democrat.

name: nevada
sentence: The Nevada Legislature is a bicameral body divided into an Assembly and Senatorte.

name: nevada
sentence: Members of the Assembly serve two years, and members of the Senatorte serve four years.

name: nevada
sentence: Both houses of the Nevada Legislature will be impacted by term limits starting in 2010, as senators and assemblymen/women will be limited to a maximum of twelve years in each house (by appointment or election which is a lifetime limit) – a provision of the constitution which was recently upheld by the Supreme Court of Nevada in a unanimous decision.

name: nevada
sentence: Each session of the legislature meets for a constitutionally mandated 120 days in every odd-numbered year, or longer if the governor calls a special session.

name: nevada
sentence: On December 18, 2018, Nevada became the first in the United States with a female majority in its legislature.

name: nevada
sentence: Women hold nine of the 21 seats in the Nevada Senatorte, and 23 of the 42 seats in the Nevada Assembly.

name: nevada
sentence: The Supreme Court of Nevada is the state supreme court and the head of the Nevada Judiciary.

name: nevada
sentence: Original jurisdiction is divided between the district courts (with general jurisdiction), and justice courts and municipal courts (both of limited jurisdiction).

name: nevada
sentence: Appeals from District Courts are made directly to the Nevada Supreme Court, which under a deflective model of jurisdiction, has the discretion to send cases to the Court of Appeals for final resolution.

name: nevada
sentence: Incorporated towns in Nevada, known as cities, are given the authority to legislate anything not prohibited by law.

name: nevada
sentence: A recent movement has begun to permit home rule to incorporate Nevada cities to give them more flexibility and fewer restrictions from the Legislature.

name: nevada
sentence: Town Boards for unincorporated towns are limited local governments created by either the local county commission, or by referendum, and form a purely advisory role and in no way diminish the responsibilities of the county commission that creates them.

name: nevada
sentence: In 1900, Nevada's population was the smallest of all states and was shrinking, as the difficulties of living in a "barren desert" began to outweigh the lure of silver for many early settlers.

name: nevada
sentence: Historian Lawrence Friedman has explained what happened next:

name: nevada
sentence: With the advent of air conditioning for summertime use and Southern Nevada's mild winters, the fortunes of the state began to turn around, as it did for Arizona, making these two states the fastest growing in the Union.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada is the only state where prostitution is legal – in a licensed brothel in a county which has specifically voted to permit it.

name: nevada
sentence: It is illegal in larger jurisdictions such as Clark County (which contains Las Vegas), Washoe County (which contains Reno), and the independent city of Carson City.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada's early reputation as a "divorce haven" arose from the fact that before the no-fault divorce revolution in the 1970s, divorces were difficult to obtain in the United States.

name: nevada
sentence: Already having legalized gambling and prostitution, Nevada continued the trend of boosting its profile by adopting one of the most liberal divorce statutes in the nation.

name: nevada
sentence: This resulted in Williams v. North Carolina (1942), 317 US 287 (1942), in which the US Supreme Court ruled North Carolina had to give "full faith and credit" to a Nevada divorce.

name: nevada
sentence: The Court modified its decision in Williams v. North Carolina (1945), 325 US 226 (1945), by holding a state need not recognize a Nevada divorce unless one of the parties was domiciled there at the time the divorce was granted and the forum state was entitled to make its own determination.

name: nevada
sentence: As of 2009, Nevada's divorce rate was above the national average.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada's tax laws are intended to draw new residents and businesses to the state.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada has no personal income tax or corporate income tax.

name: nevada
sentence: Since Nevada does not collect income data it cannot share such information with the federal government, the IRS.

name: nevada
sentence: The state sales tax (similar to VAT or GST) in Nevada is variable depending upon the county.

name: nevada
sentence: The statewide tax rate is 6.85%, with five counties (Elko, Esmeralda, Eureka, Humboldt, and Mineral) charging this amount.

name: nevada
sentence: Counties may impose additional rates via voter approval or through approval of the state legislature; therefore, the applicable sales tax varies by county from 6.85% to 8.375% (Clark County).

name: nevada
sentence: Clark County, which includes Las Vegas, imposes four separate county option taxes in addition to the statewide rate: 0.25% for flood control, 0.50% for mass transit, 0.25% for infrastructure, and 0.25% for more cops.

name: nevada
sentence: In Washoe County, which includes Reno, the sales tax rate is 7.725%, due to county option rates for flood control, the ReTRAC train trench project, and mass transit, and an additional county rate approved under the Local Government Tax Act of 1991.

name: nevada
sentence: The minimum Nevada sales tax rate changed on July 1, 2009.

name: nevada
sentence: The lodging tax rate in unincorporated Clark County, which includes the Las Vegas Strip, is 12%.

name: nevada
sentence: Within the boundaries of the cities of Las Vegas and Henderson, the lodging tax rate is 13%.

name: nevada
sentence: Corporations such as Apple Inc. allegedly have set up investment companies and funds in Nevada to avoid paying taxes.

name: nevada
sentence: In 2009, the Nevada Legislature passed a bill creating a domestic partnership registry which enables gay couples to enjoy the same rights as married couples.

name: nevada
sentence: In June 2015, gay marriage became legal in Nevada.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada provides a friendly environment for the formation of corporations, and many (especially California) businesses have incorporated in Nevada to take advantage of the benefits of the Nevada statute.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada corporations offer great flexibility to the Board of Directors and simplify or avoid many of the rules that are cumbersome to business managers in some other states.

name: nevada
sentence: In addition, Nevada has no franchise tax, although it does require businesses to have a license for which the business has to pay the state.

name: nevada
sentence: Similarly, many US states have usury laws limiting the amount of interest a lender can charge, but federal law allows corporations to 'import' these laws from their home state.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada has very liberal alcohol laws.

name: nevada
sentence: Bars are permitted to remain open 24 hours, with no "last call".

name: nevada
sentence: Liquor stores, convenience stores and supermarkets may also sell alcohol 24 hours per day and may sell beer, wine and spirits.

name: nevada
sentence: In 2016, Nevada voters approved Question 2, which legalized the possession, transportation and cultivation of personal use amounts of marijuana for adults age 21 years and older, and authorized the creation of a regulated market for the sale of marijuana to adults age 21 years and older through state-licensed retail outlets.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada voters had previously approved medical marijuana in 2000, but rejected marijuana legalization in a similar referendum in 2006.

name: nevada
sentence: Marijuana in all forms remains illegal under federal law.

name: nevada
sentence: Aside from cannabis legalization, non-alcohol drug laws are a notable exception to Nevada's otherwise libertarian principles.

name: nevada
sentence: It is notable for having the harshest penalties for drug offenders in the country.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada remains the only state to still use mandatory minimum sentencing guidelines for possession of drugs.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada voters enacted a smoking ban ("The Nevada Clean Indoor Air Act") in November 2006 which became effective on December 8, 2006.

name: nevada
sentence: It outlaws smoking in most workplaces and public places.

name: nevada
sentence: Smoking is permitted in bars, but only if the bar serves no food, or the bar is inside a larger casino.

name: nevada
sentence: Smoking is also permitted in casinos, certain hotel rooms, tobacco shops, and brothels.

name: nevada
sentence: However, some businesses do not obey this law and the government tends not to enforce it.

name: nevada
sentence: In 2011, smoking restrictions in Nevada were relaxed for certain places which allow only people 21 or older inside.

name: nevada
sentence: In 2006, the crime rate in Nevada was about 24% higher than the national average rate, though crime has since decreased.

name: nevada
sentence: Property crimes accounted for about 85% of the total crime rate in Nevada, which was 21% higher than the national rate.

name: nevada
sentence: The remaining 20.3% were violent crimes.

name: nevada
sentence: A complete listing of crime data in the state for 2013 can be found here:

name: nevada
sentence: Due to heavy growth in the southern portion of the state, there is a noticeable divide between the politics of northern and southern Nevada.

name: nevada
sentence: The north has long maintained control of key positions in state government, even while the population of southern Nevada is larger than the rest of the state combined.

name: nevada
sentence: The north sees the high population south becoming more influential and perhaps commanding majority rule.

name: nevada
sentence: The south sees the north as the "old guard" trying to rule as an oligarchy.

name: nevada
sentence: This has fostered some resentment, however, due to a term limit amendment passed by Nevada voters in 1994, and again in 1996, some of the north's hold over key positions will soon be forfeited to the south, leaving northern Nevada with less power.

name: nevada
sentence: Historically, northern Nevada has been very Republican.

name: nevada
sentence: The more rural counties of the north are among the most conservative regions of the country.

name: nevada
sentence: Carson City, the state's capital, is a Republican-leaning swing city/county.

name: nevada
sentence: Washoe County, home to Reno, has historically been strongly Republican, but now has become more of a Democratic-leaning swing county.

name: nevada
sentence: Clark County, home to Las Vegas, has been a stronghold for the Democratic Party since it was founded in 1909, having voted Republican only six times and once for a third-party candidate.

name: nevada
sentence: Clark and Washoe counties have long dominated the state's politics.

name: nevada
sentence: Between them, they cast 87 percent of Nevada's vote, and elect a substantial majority of the state legislature.

name: nevada
sentence: The last Republican to carry Clark County was George H.W.

name: nevada
sentence: Bush in 1988, and the last Republican to carry Washoe County was George W. Bush in 2004.

name: nevada
sentence: The great majority of the state's elected officials are from either Las Vegas or Reno.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada has voted for the winner in nearly every presidential election from 1912 to 2020, the only exceptions being 1976 when it voted for Gerald Ford over Jimmy Carter and 2016 when the state was carried by Hillary Clinton over Donald Trump.

name: nevada
sentence: This includes Nevada supporting Democrats John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson in 1960 and 1964, respectively.

name: nevada
sentence: Republican Richard Nixon in 1968 and in 1972, Republican Ronald Reagan in 1980 and in 1984, Republican George H.W.

name: nevada
sentence: Bush in 1988, Democrat Bill Clinton in 1992 and 1996, Republican George W. Bush in 2000 and 2004, and Democrat Barack Obama winning the state in both 2008 and 2012, as well as Joe Biden in the 2020 election.

name: nevada
sentence: This gives the state status as a political bellwether.

name: nevada
sentence: From 1912 to 2020, Nevada has been carried by the presidential victor the most out of any state (27 of 29 elections).

name: nevada
sentence: In 2016, Nevada lost its bellwether status briefly when it narrowly cast its votes for Hillary Clinton.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada regained it when Biden won in 2020.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada has been carried by the winner of nearly every presidential election since its first in 1864, only being carried by the defeated candidate eight times since statehood.

name: nevada
sentence: It was one of only three states won by John F. Kennedy in the American West in the election of 1960, albeit narrowly.

name: nevada
sentence: Hillary Clinton narrowly defeated Trump in Nevada in 2016, winning 47.92% of votes to Trump's 45.5%.

name: nevada
sentence: The state's US

name: nevada
sentence: Senatortors are Democrats Catherine Cortez Masto and Jacky Rosen.

name: nevada
sentence: The Governorship is held by Steve Sisolak, a Democrat.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada is the only US state to have a none of the above option available on its ballots.

name: nevada
sentence: Officially called None of These Candidates, the option was first added to the ballot in 1975 and is used in all statewide elections, including president, US Senatorte and all state constitutional positions.

name: nevada
sentence: In the event "None of These Candidates" receives a plurality of votes in the election, the candidate with the next-highest total is elected.

name: nevada
sentence: Education in Nevada is achieved through public and private elementary, middle, and high schools, as well as colleges and universities.

name: nevada
sentence: A May 2015 educational reform law expanded school choice options to 450,000 Nevada students who are at up to 185% of the federal poverty level.

name: nevada
sentence: Education savings accounts (ESAs) are enabled by the new law to help pay the tuition for private schools.

name: nevada
sentence: Alternatively, families "can use funds in these accounts to also pay for textbooks and tutoring".

name: nevada
sentence: Approximately 86.9% of Nevada high school students graduate, putting it below the national average of 88.3%.

name: nevada
sentence: Public school districts in Nevada include:

name: nevada
sentence: The Nevada Aerospace Hall of Fame provides educational resources and promotes the aerospace and aviation history of the state.

name: nevada
sentence: There are 68 designated wilderness areas in Nevada, protecting some 6,579,014 acres (2,662,433 ha) under the jurisdiction of the National Park Service, US Forest Service, and Bureau of Land Management.

name: nevada
sentence: The Nevada state parks comprise protected areas managed by the state of Nevada, including state parks, state historic sites, and state recreation areas.

name: nevada
sentence: There are 24 state park units, including Van Sickle Bi-State Park which opened in July 2011 and is operated in partnership with the state of California.

name: nevada
sentence: Resort areas like Las Vegas, Reno, Lake Tahoe, and Laughlin attract visitors from around the nation and world.

name: nevada
sentence: In FY08 their 266 casinos (not counting ones with annual revenue under a million dollars) brought in $12 billion in gaming revenue and another $13 billion in non-gaming revenue.

name: nevada
sentence: A review of gaming statistics can be found at Nevada gaming area.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada has by far the most hotel rooms per capita in the United States.

name: nevada
sentence: According to the American Hotel and Lodging Association, there were 187,301 rooms in 584 hotels (of 15 or more rooms).

name: nevada
sentence: The state is ranked just below California, Texas, Florida, and New York in the total number of rooms, but those states have much larger populations.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada has one hotel room for every 14 residents, far above the national average of one hotel room per 67 residents.

name: nevada
sentence: Prostitution is legal in parts of Nevada in licensed brothels, but only counties with populations under 400,000 have the option to legalize it.

name: nevada
sentence: Although prostitution is not a major part of the Nevada economy, employing roughly 300 women as independent contractors, it is a very visible endeavor.

name: nevada
sentence: Of the 14 counties permitted to legalize prostitution under state law, eight have chosen to legalize brothels.

name: nevada
sentence: State law prohibits prostitution in Clark County (which contains Las Vegas), and Washoe County (which contains Reno).

name: nevada
sentence: However, prostitution is legal in Storey County, which is part of the Reno–Sparks metropolitan area.

name: nevada
sentence: The Las Vegas Valley is home to the Vegas Golden Knights of the National Hockey League who began to play in the 2017–18 NHL season at T-Mobile Arena on the Las Vegas Strip in Paradise, Nevada, the Las Vegas Raiders of the National Football League who began play at Allegiant Stadium in Las Vegas in 2020 after moving from Oakland, California, and the Las Vegas Aces of the WNBA who began playing in 2018 at Mandalay Bay Events Center.

name: nevada
sentence: Nevada takes pride in college sports, most notably its college football.

name: nevada
sentence: College teams in the state include the Nevada Wolf Pack (representing the University of Nevada, Reno) and the UNLV Rebels (representing the University of Nevada, Las Vegas), both in the Mountain West Conference (MW).

name: nevada
sentence: UNLV is most remembered for its men's basketball program, which experienced its height of supremacy in the late 1980s and early 1990s.

name: nevada
sentence: Coached by Jerry Tarkanian, the Runnin' Rebels became one of the most elite programs in the country.

name: nevada
sentence: In 1990, UNLV won the Men's Division I Championship by defeating Duke 103–73, which set tournament records for most points scored by a team and largest margin of victory in the national title game.

name: nevada
sentence: In 1991, UNLV finished the regular season undefeated, a feat that would not be matched in Division I men's basketball for more than 20 years.

name: nevada
sentence: Forward Larry Johnson won several awards, including the Naismith Award.

name: nevada
sentence: UNLV reached the Final Four yet again, but lost their national semifinal against Duke 79–77.

name: nevada
sentence: The Runnin' Rebels were the Associated Press pre-season No.

name: nevada
sentence: North Carolina is the only other team to accomplish that (2007–08, 2008–09).

name: nevada
sentence: The state's involvement in major-college sports is not limited to its local schools.

name: nevada
sentence: In the 21st century, the Las Vegas area has become a significant regional center for college basketball conference tournaments.

name: nevada
sentence: The MW, West Coast Conference, and Western Athletic Conference all hold their men's and women's tournaments in the area, and the Pac-12 holds its men's tournament there as well.

name: nevada
sentence: The Big Sky Conference, after decades of holding its men's and women's conference tournaments at campus sites, began holding both tournaments in Reno in 2016.

name: nevada
sentence: Las Vegas has hosted several professional boxing matches, most recently at the MGM Grand Garden Arena with bouts such as Mike Tyson vs. Evander Holyfield, Evander Holyfield vs. Mike Tyson II, Oscar De La Hoya vs. Floyd Mayweather and Oscar De La Hoya vs. Manny Pacquiao and at the newer T-Mobile Arena with Canelo Álvarez vs. Amir Khan.

name: nevada
sentence: Along with significant rises in popularity in mixed martial arts (MMA), a number of fight leagues such as the UFC have taken interest in Las Vegas as a primary event location due to the number of suitable host venues.

name: nevada
sentence: The Mandalay Bay Events Center and MGM Grand Garden Arena are among some of the more popular venues for fighting events such as MMA and have hosted several UFC and other MMA title fights.

name: nevada
sentence: The city has held the most UFC events with 86 events.

name: nevada
sentence: The state is also home to the Las Vegas Motor Speedway, which hosts NASCAR's Pennzoil 400 and South Point 400.

name: nevada
sentence: Two venues in the immediate Las Vegas area host major annual events in rodeo.

name: nevada
sentence: The Thomas & Mack Center, built for UNLV men's basketball, hosts the National Finals Rodeo.

name: nevada
sentence: The PBR World Finals, operated by the bull riding-only Professional Bull Riders, was also held at the Thomas & Mack Center before moving to T-Mobile Arena in 2016.

name: nevada
sentence: The state is also home to one of the most famous tennis players of all time, Andre Agassi, and current baseball superstar Bryce Harper.

name: nevada
sentence: Several United States Navy ships have been named USNevada in honor of the state.

name: nevada
sentence: They include:

sentence: Area 51 is near Groom Lake, a dry salt lake bed.

name: nevada
sentence: The much smaller Creech Air Force Base is in Indian Springs, Nevada; Hawthorne Army Depot in Hawthorne; the Tonopah Test Range near Tonopah; and Nellis AFB in the northeast part of the Las Vegas Valley.

name: nevada
sentence: Naval Air Station Fallon in Fallon; NSAWC, (pronounced "EN-SOCK") in western Nevada.

name: nevada
sentence: NSAWC consolidated three Command Centers into a single Command Structure under a flag officer on July 11, 1996.

name: nevada
sentence: The Naval Strike Warfare Center (STRIKE "U") based at NAS Fallon since 1984, was joined with the Navy Fighter Weapons School (TOPGUN) and the Carrier Airborne Early Warning Weapons School (TOPDOME) which both moved from NAS Miramar as a result of a Base Realignment and Closure (BRAC) decision in 1993 which transferred that installation back to the Marine Corps as MCAS Miramar.

name: nevada
sentence: The Seahawk Weapon School was added in 1998 to provide tactical training for Navy helicopters.

name: nevada
sentence: These bases host a number of activities including the Joint Unmanned Aerial Systems Center of Excellence, the Naval Strike and Air Warfare Center, Nevada Test and Training Range, Red Flag, the US Air Force Thunderbirds, the United States Air Force Warfare Center, the United States Air Force Weapons School, and the United States Navy Fighter Weapons School.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire () is a state in the New England region of the Northeastern United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It is bordered by Massachusetts to the south, Vermont to the west, Maine and the Atlantic Ocean to the east, and the Canadian province of Quebec to the north.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is the 5th smallest by area and the 10th least populous US state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Concord is the state capital, while Manchester is the largest city.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has no general sales tax, nor income tax other than on interest and dividends.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The New Hampshire primary is the first primary in the US presidential election cycle.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Its license plates carry the state motto, "Live Free or Die".

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state's nickname, "The Granite State", refers to its extensive granite formations and quarries.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In January 1776, it became the first of the British North American colonies to establish a government independent of the Kingdom of Great Britain's authority; it was the first to establish its own state constitution.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Six months later, it became one of the original 13 colonies that signed the United States Declaration of Independence, and in June 1788 it was the ninth state to ratify the United States Constitution, bringing that document into effect.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Historically, New Hampshire was a major center for textile manufacturing, shoemaking, and papermaking, with Amoskeag Manufacturing Company in Manchester at one time being the largest cotton textile plant in the world.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Numerous mills were located along various rivers in the state, especially the Merrimack and Connecticut rivers.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Many French Canadians migrated to New Hampshire to work the mills in the late 19th and early 20th century; New Hampshire still ranks second among states by percentage of people claiming French American ancestry, with 24.5% of the state identifying as such.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Manufacturing centers such as Manchester, Nashua and Berlin were hit hard in the 1930s–1940s as major manufacturing industries left New England and moved to the Southern United States or overseas, reflecting nationwide trends.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 1950s and 1960s, defense contractors moved into many of the former mills, such as Sanders Associates in Nashua; the population of southern New Hampshire surged beginning in the 1980s as major highways connected the region to Greater Boston and established several bedroom communities in the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: With some of the highest ski mountains on the East Coast, New Hampshire's major recreational attractions include skiing, snowmobiling, and other winter sports, hiking and mountaineering (Mount Monadnock in the state's southwestern corner is among the most climbed mountains in the US), observing the fall foliage, summer cottages along many lakes and the seacoast, motor sports at the New Hampshire Motor Speedway, and Motorcycle Week, a popular motorcycle rally held in Weirs Beach in Laconia in June.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The White Mountain National Forest links the Vermont and Maine portions of the Appalachian Trail, and has the Mount Washington Auto Road, where visitors may drive to the top of 6,288-foot (1,917 m) Mount Washington.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state was named after the southern English county of Hampshire by Captain John Mason.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is part of the six-state New England region.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It is bounded by Quebec, Canada, to the north and northwest; Maine and the Atlantic Ocean to the east; Massachusetts to the south; and Vermont to the west.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire's major regions are the Great North Woods, the White Mountains, the Lakes Region, the Seacoast, the Merrimack Valley, the Monadnock Region, and the Dartmouth-Lake Sunapee area.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has the shortest ocean coastline of any US coastal state, with a length of 18 miles (29 km), sometimes measured as only 13 miles (21 km).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The White Mountains range in New Hampshire spans the north-central portion of the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The range includes Mount Washington, the tallest in the northeastern US—site of the second-highest wind speed ever recorded—as well as Mount Adams and Mount Jefferson.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: With hurricane-force winds every third day on average, more than a hundred recorded deaths among visitors, and conspicuous krumholtz (dwarf, matted trees much like a carpet of bonsai trees), the climate on the upper reaches of Mount Washington has inspired the weather observatory on the peak to claim that the area has the "World's Worst Weather".

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The White Mountains were home to the rock formation called the Old Man of the Mountain, a face-like profile in Franconia Notch, until the formation disintegrated in May 2003.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Even after its loss, the Old Man remains an enduring symbol for the state, seen on state highway signs, automobile license plates, and many government and private entities around New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the flatter southwest corner of New Hampshire, the landmark Mount Monadnock has given its name to a class of earth-forms—a monadnock—signifying, in geomorphology, any isolated resistant peak rising from a less resistant eroded plain.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Major rivers include the 110-mile (177 km) Merrimack River, which bisects the lower half of the state north–south before passing into Massachusetts and reaching the sea in Newburyport.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Its tributaries include the Contoocook River, Pemigewasset River, and Winnipesaukee River.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The 410-mile (660 km) Connecticut River, which starts at New Hampshire's Connecticut Lakes and flows south to Connecticut, defines the western border with Vermont.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state border is not in the center of that river, as is usually the case, but at the low-water mark on the Vermont side; meaning the entire river along the Vermont border (save for areas where the water level has been raised by a dam) lies within New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Only one town—Pittsburg—shares a land border with the state of Vermont.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The "northwesternmost headwaters" of the Connecticut also define the part of Canada–US

name: new_hampshire
sentence: border.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Piscataqua River and its several tributaries form the state's only significant ocean port where they flow into the Atlantic at Portsmouth.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Salmon Falls River and the Piscataqua define the southern portion of the border with Maine.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Piscataqua River boundary was the subject of a border dispute between New Hampshire and Maine in 2001, with New Hampshire claiming dominion over several islands (primarily Seavey's Island) that include the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The US Supreme Court dismissed the case in 2002, leaving ownership of the island with Maine.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire still claims sovereignty of the base, however.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The largest of New Hampshire's lakes is Lake Winnipesaukee, which covers 71 square miles (184 km2) in the east-central part of New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Umbagog Lake along the Maine border, approximately 12.3 square miles (31.9 km2), is a distant second.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Squam Lake is the second largest lake entirely in New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has the shortest ocean coastline of any state in the United States, approximately 18 miles (29 km) long.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Hampton Beach is a popular local summer destination.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: About 7 miles (11 km) offshore are the Isles of Shoals, nine small islands (four of which are in New Hampshire) known as the site of a 19th-century art colony founded by poet Celia Thaxter, and the alleged location of one of the buried treasures of the pirate Blackbeard.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It is the state with the highest percentage of timberland area in the country.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is in the temperate broadleaf and mixed forests biome.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Much of the state, in particular the White Mountains, is covered by the conifers and northern hardwoods of the New England-Acadian forests.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The southeast corner of the state and parts of the Connecticut River along the Vermont border are covered by the mixed oaks of the Northeastern coastal forests.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state's numerous forests are popular among autumnal leaf peepers seeking the brilliant foliage of the numerous deciduous trees.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The northern third of the state is locally referred to as the "north country" or "north of the notches", in reference to White Mountain passes that channel traffic.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It contains less than 5% of the state's population, suffers relatively high poverty, and is steadily losing population as the logging and paper industries decline.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: However, the tourist industry, in particular visitors who go to northern New Hampshire to ski, snowboard, hike and mountain bike, has helped offset economic losses from mill closures.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Winter season lengths are projected to decline at ski areas across New Hampshire due to the effects of global warming, which is likely to continue the historic contraction and consolidation of the ski industry and threaten individual ski businesses and communities that rely on ski tourism.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire experiences a humid continental climate (Köppen climate classification Dfa in some southern areas, Dfb in most of the state, and Dfc subarctic in some northern highland areas), with warm, humid summers, and long, cold, and snowy winters.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Precipitation is fairly evenly distributed all year.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The climate of the southeastern portion is moderated by the Atlantic Ocean and averages relatively milder winters (for New Hampshire), while the northern and interior portions experience colder temperatures and lower humidity.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Winters are cold and snowy throughout the state, and especially severe in the northern and mountainous areas.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Average annual snowfall ranges from 60 inches (150 cm) to over 100 inches (250 cm) across the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Average daytime highs are in the mid 70s°F to low 80s°F (24–28°C) throughout the state in July, with overnight lows in the mid 50s°F to low 60s°F (13–15°C).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: January temperatures range from an average high of 34 °F (1 °C) on the coast to overnight lows below 0 °F (−18 °C) in the far north and at high elevations.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Average annual precipitation statewide is roughly 40 inches (100 cm) with some variation occurring in the White Mountains due to differences in elevation and annual snowfall.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire's highest recorded temperature was 106 °F (41 °C) in Nashua on July 4, 1911, while the lowest recorded temperature was −47 °F (−44 °C) atop Mount Washington on January 29, 1934.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Mount Washington also saw an unofficial −50 °F (−46 °C) reading on January 22, 1885, which, if made official, would tie the all-time record low for New England (also −50 °F (−46 °C) at Big Black River, Maine, on January 16, 2009, and Bloomfield, Vermont on December 30, 1933).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Extreme snow is often associated with a nor'easter, such as the Blizzard of '78 and the Blizzard of 1993, when several feet accumulated across portions of the state over 24 to 48 hours.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Lighter snowfalls of several inches occur frequently throughout winter, often associated with an Alberta Clipper.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire, on occasion, is affected by hurricanes and tropical storms although by the time they reach the state they are often extratropical, with most storms striking the southern New England coastline and moving inland or passing by offshore in the Gulf of Maine.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Most of New Hampshire averages fewer than 20 days of thunderstorms per year and an average of two tornadoes occur annually statewide.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The National Arbor Day Foundation plant hardiness zone map depicts zones 3, 4, 5, and 6 occurring throughout the state and indicates the transition from a relatively cooler to warmer climate as one travels southward across New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The 1990 USDA plant hardiness zones for New Hampshire range from zone 3b in the north to zone 5b in the south.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Metropolitan areas in the New England region are defined by the US Census Bureau as New England City and Town Areas (NECTAs).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The following is a list of NECTAs fully or partially in New Hampshire:

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Various Algonquian-speaking Abenaki tribes, largely divided between the Androscoggin and Pennacook nations, inhabited the area before European settlement.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Despite the similar language, they had a very different culture and religion from other Algonquian peoples.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: English and French explorers visited New Hampshire in 1600–1605, and David Thompson settled at Odiorne's Point in present-day Rye in 1623.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The first permanent settlement was at Hilton's Point (present-day Dover).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: By 1631, the Upper Plantation comprised modern-day Dover, Durham and Stratham; in 1679, it became the "Royal Province".

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Father Rale's War was fought between the colonists and the Wabanaki Confederacy throughout New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire was one of the thirteen colonies that rebelled against British rule during the American Revolution.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: By the time of the American Revolution, New Hampshire was a divided province.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The economic and social life of the Seacoast region revolved around sawmills, shipyards, merchants' warehouses, and established village and town centers.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Wealthy merchants built substantial homes, furnished them with the finest luxuries, and invested their capital in trade and land speculation.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: At the other end of the social scale, there developed a permanent class of day laborers, mariners, indentured servants and even slaves.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The only battle fought in New Hampshire was the raid on Fort William and Mary, December 14, 1774, in Portsmouth Harbor, which netted the rebellion sizable quantities of gunpowder, small arms and cannon.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: (General Sullivan, leader of the raid, described it as, "remainder of the powder, the small arms, bayonets, and cartouche-boxes, together with the cannon and ordnance stores") over the course of two nights.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: This raid was preceded by a warning to local patriots the previous day, by Paul Revere on December 13, 1774, that the fort was to be reinforced by troops sailing from Boston.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to unverified accounts, the gunpowder was later used at the Battle of Bunker Hill, transported there by Major Demerit, who was one of several New Hampshire patriots who stored the powder in their homes until it was transported elsewhere for use in revolutionary activities.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: During the raid, the British soldiers fired upon the rebels with cannon and muskets.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Although there were apparently no casualties, these were among the first shots in the American Revolutionary period, occurring approximately five months before the Battles of Lexington and Concord.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The United States Constitution was ratified by New Hampshire on June 21, 1788, when New Hampshire became the ninth state to do so.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire was a Jacksonian stronghold

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Industrialization took the form of numerous textile mills, which in turn attracted large flows of immigrants from Quebec (the "French Canadians") and Ireland.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The northern parts of the state produced lumber, and the mountains provided tourist attractions.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: After 1960, the textile industry collapsed, but the economy rebounded as a center of high technology and as a service provider.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Starting in 1952, New Hampshire gained national and international attention for its presidential primary held early in every presidential election year.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It immediately became the most important testing grounds for candidates for the Republican and Democratic nominations.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The media gave New Hampshire and Iowa about half of all the attention paid to all states in the primary process, magnifying the state's decision powers and spurring repeated efforts by out-of-state politicians to change the rules.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The United States Census Bureau estimates the population of New Hampshire was 1,359,711 on July 1, 2019, a 3.28% increase since the 2010 United States Census.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The center of population of New Hampshire is in Merrimack County, in the town of Pembroke.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The center of population has moved south 12 miles (19 km) since 1950, a reflection of the fact the state's fastest growth has been along its southern border, which is within commuting range of Boston and other Massachusetts cities.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The most densely populated areas generally lie within 50 miles (80 km) of the Massachusetts border, and are concentrated in two areas: along the Merrimack River Valley running from Concord to Nashua, and in the Seacoast Region along an axis stretching from Rochester to Portsmouth.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Outside of those two regions, only one community, the city of Keene, has a population over 20,000.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The four counties covering these two areas account for 72% of the state population, and one (Hillsborough) has nearly 30% of the state population, as well as the two most populous communities, Manchester and Nashua.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The northern portion of the state is very sparsely populated: the largest county by area, Coos, covers the northern one-fourth of the state and has only around 31,000 people, about a third of whom live in a single community (Berlin).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The trends over the past several decades have been for the population to shift southward, as many northern communities lack the economic base to maintain their populations, while southern communities have been absorbed by the Greater Boston metropolis.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: As of the 2010 Census, the population of New Hampshire was 1,316,470.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The gender makeup of the state was 49.3% male and 50.7% female.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: 21.8% of the population were under the age of 18

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The racial makeup of New Hampshire as of the 2010 Census was:

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Hispanic or Latino of any race were 2.8% of the population in 2010: 0.6% were of Mexican, 0.9% Puerto Rican, 0.1% Cuban, and 1.2% other Hispanic or Latino origin.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to the 2012–2017 American Community Survey, the largest ancestry groups in the state were Irish (20.6%), English (16.5%), French (14.0%), Italian (10.4%), German (9.1%), French Canadian (8.9%), and American (4.8%).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has the highest percentage (22.9%) of residents with French/French-Canadian/Acadian ancestry of any US state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to the Census Bureau's American Community Survey estimates from 2017, 2.1% of the population aged 5 and older speak Spanish at home, while 1.8% speak French.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In Coos County, 9.6% of the population speaks French at home, down from 16% in 2000.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Note: Percentages in table do not add up to 100, because Hispanics are counted both by their ethnicity and by their race, giving a higher overall number.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: A Pew survey showed that the religious affiliations of the people of New Hampshire was as follows: Protestant 30%, Catholic 26%, LDS (Mormon) 1%, Jewish 1%, Jehovah's Witness 2% and non-religious at 36%.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: A survey suggests people in New Hampshire and Vermont are less likely than other Americans to attend weekly services and only 54% say they are "absolutely certain there is a God" compared to 71% in the rest of the nation.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire and Vermont are also at the lowest levels among states in religious commitment.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2012, 23% of New Hampshire residents in a Gallup poll considered themselves "very religious", while 52% considered themselves "non-religious".

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to the Association of Religion Data Archives (ARDA) the largest denominations are the Catholic Church with 311,028 members; The United Church of Christ with 26,321 members; and the United Methodist Church with 18,029 members.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2016, a Gallup Poll found that New Hampshire was the least religious state in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
