sentence: Only 20% of respondents in New Hampshire categorized themselves as "very religious", while the nationwide average was 40%.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Bureau of Economic Analysis estimates that New Hampshire's total state product in 2018 was $86 billion, ranking 40th in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Median household income in 2017 was $74,801, the fourth highest in the country (including Washington, DC).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Its agricultural outputs are dairy products, nursery stock, cattle, apples and eggs.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Its industrial outputs are machinery, electric equipment, rubber and plastic products, and tourism is a major component of the economy.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire experienced a major shift in its economic base during the 20th century.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Historically, the base was composed of traditional New England textiles, shoe making, and small machine shops, drawing upon low-wage labor from nearby small farms and from parts of Quebec.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Today, of the state's total manufacturing dollar value, these sectors contribute only two percent for textiles, two percent for leather goods, and nine percent for machining.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: They experienced a sharp decline due to obsolete plants and the lure of cheaper wages in the Southern United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire today has a broad-based and growing economy, with a state GDP growth rate of 2.2% in 2018.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state's largest economic sectors in 2018, based on contribution to GDP, are: 15% real estate and rental and leasing; 13% professional business services; 12% manufacturing; 10% government and government services; and 9% health care and social services.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state's budget in FY2018 was $5.97 billion, including $1.79 billion in federal funds.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The issue of taxation is controversial in New Hampshire, which has a property tax (subject to municipal control) but no broad sales tax or income tax.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state does have narrower taxes on meals, lodging, vehicles, business and investment income, and tolls on state roads.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to the Energy Information Administration, New Hampshire's energy consumption and per capita energy consumption are among the lowest in the country.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Seabrook Station Nuclear Power Plant, near Portsmouth, is the largest nuclear reactor in New England and provided 57% of New Hampshire's electricity generation and 27% of its electricity consumption in 2017.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2016 and 2017, New Hampshire obtained more of its electricity generation from wind power than coal-fired power plants.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Approximately 32% of New Hampshire's electricity consumption came from renewable resources (including nuclear, hydroelectric, wind, and other renewable resources).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire was a net exporter of electricity, exporting 63 trillion British thermal units (18 TWh).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire's residential electricity use is low compared with the national average, in part because demand for air conditioning is low during the generally mild summer months and because few households use electricity as their primary energy source for home heating.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Nearly half of New Hampshire households use fuel oil for winter heating, which is one of the largest shares in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has potential for renewable energies like wind power, hydroelectricity, and wood fuel.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state has no general sales tax and no personal state income tax (the state does tax, at a five percent rate, income from dividends and interest), and the legislature has exercised fiscal restraint.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Efforts to diversify the state's general economy have been ongoing.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire's lack of a broad-based tax system has resulted in the state's local communities having some of the nation's highest property taxes.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: However, the state's overall tax burden is relatively low; in 2010 New Hampshire ranked 44th highest among states in combined average state and local tax burden.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: As of February 2010, the state's unemployment rate was 7.1%.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: By October 2010, the unemployment rate had dropped to 5.4%.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The (preliminary) seasonally unemployment rate in April 2019 was 2.4% based on a 767,500 person civilian workforce with 749,000 people in employment.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire's workforce is 90% in nonfarm employment, with 18% employed in trade, transportation, and utilities; 17% in education and health care; 12% in government; 11% in professional and business services; and 10% in leisure and hospitality.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to a 2013 study by Phoenix Marketing International, New Hampshire had the eighth-highest percentage of millionaire households in the United States, at 6.48% of all households.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2013, New Hampshire also had the nation's lowest poverty rate at just 8.7% of all residents, according to the Census Bureau.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In March 2018, 86% of New Hampshire's workforce were employed by the private sector, with 53% of those workers being employed by firms with less than 100 employees.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: About 14% of private sector employees are employed by firms with more than 1,000 employees.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to community surveys by the Economic & Labor Market Information Bureau of NH Employment Security, the following are the largest private employers in the state:

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire's state government employs approximately 6,100 people.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Additionally, the US Department of State employs approximately 1,600 people at the National Visa Center in Portsmouth, which processes United States immigrant visa petitions.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The governor of New Hampshire, since January 5, 2017, is Chris Sununu (Republican).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire's two US senators are Jeanne Shaheen and Maggie Hassan (both Democrats), both of whom are former governors.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire's two US representatives as of January 2019 are Chris Pappas and Ann McLane Kuster (both Democrats).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is an alcoholic beverage control state, and through the State Liquor Commission it takes in $100 million from the sale and distribution of liquor.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is the only state in the US that does not require adults to wear seat belts in their vehicles.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It is one of three states that have no mandatory helmet law.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The New Hampshire State Constitution of 1783 is the supreme law of the state, followed by the New Hampshire Revised Statutes Annotated and the New Hampshire Code of Administrative Rules.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: These are roughly analogous to the federal United States Constitution, United States Code and Code of Federal Regulations respectively.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has a bifurcated executive branch, consisting of the governor and a five-member executive council which votes on state contracts worth more than $5,000 and "advises and consents" to the governor's nominations to major state positions such as department heads and all judgeships and pardon requests.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire does not have a lieutenant governor; the Senatorte president serves as "acting governor" whenever the governor is unable to perform the duties.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The legislature is called the General Court.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It consists of the House of Representatives and the Senatorte.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: There are 400 representatives, making it one of the largest elected bodies in the English-speaking world, and 24 senators.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Legislators are paid a nominal salary of $200 per year, the lowest in the US by far, thus most are effectively volunteers, nearly half of which are retirees.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: (For details, see the article on Government of New Hampshire.)

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state's sole appellate court is the New Hampshire Supreme Court.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Superior Court is the court of general jurisdiction and the only court which provides for jury trials in civil or criminal cases.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The other state courts are the Probate Court, District Court, and the Family Division.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has 10 counties and 234 cities and towns.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is a "Dillon Rule" state, meaning the state retains all powers not specifically granted to municipalities.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Even so, the legislature strongly favors local control, particularly with regard to land use regulations.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire municipalities are classified as towns or cities, which differ primarily by the form of government.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Most towns generally operate on the town meeting form of government, where the registered voters in the town act as the town legislature, and a board of selectmen acts as the executive of the town.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Larger towns and the state's thirteen cities operate either on a council–manager or council–mayor form of government.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: There is no difference, from the state government's point of view, between towns and cities besides the form of government.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: All state-level statutes treat all municipalities identically.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has a small number of unincorporated areas that are titled as grants, locations, purchases, or townships.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: These locations have limited to no self-government, and services are generally provided for them by neighboring towns or the county or state where needed.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: As of the 2000 census, there were 25 of these left in New Hampshire, accounting for a total population of 173 people (as of 2000); several were entirely depopulated.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: All but two of these unincorporated areas are in Coos County.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Democratic Party and the Republican Party are the two largest parties in the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: A plurality of voters are registered as undeclared, and can choose either ballot in the primary and then regain their undeclared status after voting.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Libertarian Party had official party status from 1990 to 1996.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: There is also a program known as the Free State Project with the goal of turning New Hampshire into a libertarian stronghold by suggesting that libertarians move there so they can concentrate their power.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Libertarian Party regained ballot access after the 2016 election because the gubernatorial candidate received more than four percent of the vote.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: As of February 5, 2016, there were 882,959 registered voters, of whom 389,472 (44.1%) did not declare a political party affiliation, 262,111 (29.7%) were Republican, and 231,376 (26.2%) were Democratic.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is internationally known for the New Hampshire primary, the first primary in the quadrennial American presidential election cycle.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: State law requires that the Secretary of State schedule this election at least one week before any "similar event".

name: new_hampshire
sentence: However, the Iowa caucus has preceded the New Hampshire primary.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: This primary, as the nation's first contest that uses the same procedure as the general election, draws more attention than those in other states, and it has been decisive in shaping the national contest.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: State law permits a town with fewer than 100 residents to open its polls at midnight, and close when all registered citizens have cast their ballots.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: As such, the communities of Dixville Notch in Coos County and Hart's Location in Carroll County, among others, have chosen to implement these provisions.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Dixville Notch and Hart's Location are traditionally the first places in both New Hampshire and the US to vote in presidential primaries and elections.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Nominations for all other partisan offices are decided in a separate primary election.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In Presidential election cycles, this is the second primary election held in New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Saint Anselm College in Goffstown has become a popular campaign spot for politicians as well as several national presidential debates because of its proximity to Manchester-Boston Regional Airport.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the past, New Hampshire has often voted Republican.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Between 1856 and 1988, New Hampshire cast its electoral votes for the Democratic presidential ticket six times: Woodrow Wilson (twice), Franklin D. Roosevelt (three times), and Lyndon B. Johnson (once).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Beginning in 1992, New Hampshire became a swing state in national and local elections, and in that time has supported Democrats in all presidential elections except 2000.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It was the only state in the country to switch from supporting Republican George W. Bush in the 2000 election to supporting his Democratic challenger in the 2004 election, when John Kerry, a senator from neighboring Massachusetts, won the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Democrats dominated elections in New Hampshire in 2006 and 2008.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2006, Democrats won both congressional seats (electing Carol Shea-Porter in the first district and Paul Hodes in the second), re-elected Governor John Lynch, and gained a majority on the Executive Council and in both houses for the first time since 1911.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Democrats had not held both the legislature and the governorship since 1874.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Neither US Senatorte seat was up for a vote in 2006.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2008, Democrats retained their majorities, governorship, and Congressional seats; and former governor Jeanne Shaheen defeated incumbent Republican John E. Sununu for the US Senatorte in a rematch of the 2002 contest.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The 2008 elections resulted in women holding a majority, 13 of the 24 seats, in the New Hampshire Senatorte, a first for any legislative body in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 2010 midterm elections, Republicans made historic gains in New Hampshire, capturing veto-proof majorities in the state legislature, taking all five seats in the Executive Council, electing a new US senator, Kelly Ayotte, winning both US House seats, and reducing the margin of victory of incumbent Governor John Lynch compared to his 2006 and 2008 landslide wins.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 2012 state legislative elections, Democrats took back the New Hampshire House of Representatives and narrowed the Republican majority in the New Hampshire Senatorte to 13–11.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2012, New Hampshire became the first state in US history to elect an all-female federal delegation: Democratic Congresswomen Carol Shea-Porter of Congressional District 1 and Ann McLane Kuster of Congressional District 2 accompanied US

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Senatortors Jeanne Shaheen and Kelly Ayotte in 2013.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Further, the state elected its second female governor: Democrat Maggie Hassan.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 2014 elections, Republicans retook the New Hampshire House of Representatives with a 239–160 majority and expanded their majority in the New Hampshire Senatorte to 14 of the Senatorte's 24 seats.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: On the national level, incumbent Democratic Senatortor Jeanne Shaheen defeated her Republican challenger, former Massachusetts senator Scott Brown.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire also elected Frank Guinta (R) for its First Congressional District representative and Ann Kuster (D) for its Second Congressional District representative.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 2016 elections, Republicans held the New Hampshire House of Representatives with a majority of 220–175, and held onto their 14 seats in the New Hampshire Senatorte.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the gubernatorial race, retiring Governor Maggie Hassan was succeeded by Republican Chris Sununu, who defeated Democratic nominee Colin Van Ostern.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Sununu became the state's first Republican governor since Craig Benson, who left office in 2005 following defeat by John Lynch.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Republicans control the governor's office and both chambers of the state legislature, a governing trifecta in which the Republicans have full governing power.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the presidential race, the state voted for the Democratic nominee, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton over the Republican nominee, Donald Trump, by a margin of 2,736 votes, or 0.3%, one of the closest results the state has ever seen in a presidential race, while Libertarian nominee Gary Johnson received 4.12% of the vote.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Democrats also won a competitive race in the Second Congressional District, as well as a competitive senate race.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire's congressional delegation currently consists of exclusively Democrats.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 116th United States Congress, it is one of only eight states with an entirely Democratic delegation, five of which are in New England (the others are Delaware, Hawaii, and New Mexico).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has a well-maintained, well-signed network of Interstate highways, US highways, and state highways.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: State highway markers still depict the Old Man of the Mountain despite that rock formation's demise in 2003.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Several route numbers align with the same route numbers in neighboring states.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: State highway numbering is arbitrary, with no overall system as with US and Interstate systems.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Major routes include:

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has 25 public-use airports, three with some scheduled commercial passenger service.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The busiest airport by number of passengers handled is Manchester-Boston Regional Airport in Manchester and Londonderry, which serves the Greater Boston metropolitan area.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Long-distance intercity passenger rail service is provided by Amtrak's Vermonter and Downeaster lines.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Greyhound, Concord Coach, Vermont Translines and Dartmouth Coach all provide intercity bus connections to and from points in New Hampshire and to long-distance points beyond and in between.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: As of 2013, Boston-centered MBTA Commuter Rail services reach only as far as northern Massachusetts.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The New Hampshire Rail Transit Authority is working to extend "Capital Corridor" service from Lowell, Massachusetts, to Nashua, Concord, and Manchester, including Manchester-Boston Regional Airport; and "Coastal Corridor" service from Haverhill, Massachusetts, to Plaistow, New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Legislation in 2007 created the New Hampshire Rail Transit Authority (NHRTA) with the goal of overseeing the development of commuter rail in the state of New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2011, Governor John Lynch vetoed HB 218, a bill passed by Republican lawmakers, which would have drastically curtailed the powers and responsibilities of NHRTA.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The I-93 Corridor transit study suggested a rail alternative along the Manchester and Lawrence branch line which could provide freight and passenger service.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: This rail corridor would also have access to Manchester-Boston Regional Airport.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Eleven public transit authorities operate local and regional bus services around the state, and eight private carriers operate express bus services which link with the national intercity bus network.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The New Hampshire Department of Transportation operates a statewide ride-sharing match service, in addition to independent ride matching and guaranteed ride home programs.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Tourist railroads include the Conway Scenic Railroad, Hobo-Winnipesaukee Railroad, and the Mount Washington Cog Railway.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Freight railways in New Hampshire include Claremont & Concord Railroad (CCRR), Pan Am Railways via subsidiary Springfield Terminal Railway (ST), the New England Central Railroad (NHR, the St. Lawrence and Atlantic Railroad (SLR), and New Hampshire Northcoast Corporation (NHN).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The first public high schools in the state were the Boys' High School and the Girls' High School of Portsmouth, established either in 1827 or 1830 depending on the source.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has more than 80 public high schools, many of which serve more than one town.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The largest is Pinkerton Academy in Derry, which is owned by a private non-profit organization and serves as the public high school of a number of neighboring towns.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: There are at least 30 private high schools in the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is also the home of several prestigious university-preparatory schools, such as Phillips Exeter Academy, St. Paul's School, Proctor Academy, Brewster Academy, and Kimball Union Academy.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2008 the state tied with Massachusetts as having the highest scores on the SAT and ACT standardized tests given to high school students.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The following sports teams are based in New Hampshire:

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The New Hampshire Motor Speedway in Loudon is an oval track and road course which has been visited by national motorsport championship series such as the NASCAR Cup Series, the NASCAR Xfinity Series, the NASCAR Camping World Truck Series, NASCAR Whelen Modified Tour, American Canadian Tour (ACT), the Champ Car and the IndyCar Series.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Other motor racing venues include Star Speedway and New England Dragway in Epping, Lee Speedway in Lee, Twin State Speedway in Claremont, Monadnock Speedway in Winchester and Canaan Fair Speedway in Canaan.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has two universities competing at the NCAA Division I in all collegiate sports: the Dartmouth Big Green (Ivy League) and the New Hampshire Wildcats (America East Conference), as well as three NCAA Division II teams: Franklin Pierce Ravens, Saint Anselm Hawks and Southern New Hampshire Penmen (Northeast-10 Conference).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Most other schools compete in NCAA Division III or the NAIA.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Annually since 2002, high-school statewide all-stars compete against Vermont in ten sports during "Twin State" playoffs.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the spring, New Hampshire's many sap houses hold sugaring-off open houses.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In summer and early autumn, New Hampshire is home to many county fairs, the largest being the Hopkinton State Fair, in Contoocook.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire's Lakes Region is home to many summer camps, especially around Lake Winnipesaukee, and is a popular tourist destination.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Peterborough Players have performed every summer in Peterborough since 1933.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Barnstormers Theatre in Tamworth, founded in 1931, is one of the longest-running professional summer theaters in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In September, New Hampshire is host to the New Hampshire Highland Games.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has also registered an official tartan with the proper authorities in Scotland, used to make kilts worn by the Lincoln Police Department while its officers serve during the games.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The fall foliage peaks in mid-October.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the winter, New Hampshire's ski areas and snowmobile trails attract visitors from a wide area.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: After the lakes freeze over they become dotted with ice fishing ice houses, known locally as bobhouses.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Funspot, the world's largest video arcade (now termed a museum), is in Laconia.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Prominent individuals from New Hampshire include founding father Nicholas Gilman, Senatortor Daniel Webster, Revolutionary War hero John Stark, editor Horace Greeley, founder of the Christian Science religion Mary Baker Eddy, poet Robert Frost, astronaut Alan Shepard, rock musician Ronnie James Dio, author Dan Brown, actor Adam Sandler, inventor Dean Kamen, comedians Sarah Silverman and Seth Meyers, restaurateurs Richard and Maurice McDonald, and President of the United States Franklin Pierce.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is a state in the Mid-Atlantic region of the Northeastern United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It is bordered on the north and east by the state of New York; on the east, southeast, and south by the Atlantic Ocean; on the west by the Delaware River and Pennsylvania; and on the southwest by Delaware Bay and the State of Delaware.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is the fourth-smallest state by area but the 11th-most populous, with 8,882,190 residents as of 2019 and an area of 8,722.58 square miles, making it the most densely populated of the 50 US states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The capital is Trenton, while the largest city is Newark.

name: new_jersey
sentence: All but one county in New Jersey lie within the combined statistical areas of New York City or Philadelphia; consequently, the state's largest metropolitan area falls within Greater New York.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was first inhabited by Native Americans for at least 2,800 years, with the Lenape being the dominant group by the time Europeans arrived in the early 17th century.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Dutch and the Swedish colonists founded the first European settlements in the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The English later seized control of the region, naming it the Province of New Jersey—after the largest of the Channel Islands, Jersey—and granting it as a colony to Sir George Carteret and John Berkeley, 1st Baron Berkeley of Stratton.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was the site of several important battles during the American Revolutionary War.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the 19th century, factories in the "Big Six" cities of Camden, Paterson, Newark, Trenton, Jersey City, and Elizabeth helped drive the nation's Industrial Revolution.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey's central location in the Northeast megalopolis fueled its rapid growth and suburbanization in the second half of the 20th century.

name: new_jersey
sentence: At the turn of the 21st century, the state's economy increasingly diversified, while its multicultural populace began reverting toward more urban settings within the state, outpacing the growth in suburbs since 2008.

name: new_jersey
sentence: As of 2020, New Jersey was home to the highest number of millionaires per capita of all US states, with 9.76% of households—more than 323,000 of 3.3 million statewide—meeting the criteria.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Based on 2017 data, it was the second-wealthiest US state by median household income.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey's public school system consistently ranks at or among the top among all fifty US states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Around 180 million years ago, during the Jurassic Period, New Jersey bordered North Africa.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The pressure of the collision between North America and Africa gave rise to the Appalachian Mountains.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Around 18,000 years ago, the Ice Age resulted in glaciers that reached New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: As the glaciers retreated, they left behind Lake Passaic, as well as many rivers, swamps, and gorges.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was originally settled by Native Americans, with the Lenni-Lenape being dominant at the time of contact.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Scheyichbi is the Lenape name for the land that is now New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Lenape were several autonomous groups that practiced maize agriculture in order to supplement their hunting and gathering in the region surrounding the Delaware River, the lower Hudson River, and western Long Island Sound.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Lenape society was divided into matrilinear clans that were based upon common female ancestors.

name: new_jersey
sentence: These clans were organized into three distinct phratries identified by their animal sign: Turtle, Turkey, and Wolf.

name: new_jersey
sentence: They first encountered the Dutch in the early 17th century, and their primary relationship with the Europeans was through fur trade.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Dutch became the first Europeans to lay claim to lands in New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Dutch colony of New Netherland consisted of parts of modern Middle Atlantic states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Although the European principle of land ownership was not recognized by the Lenape, Dutch West India Company policy required its colonists to purchase the land that they settled.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The first to do so was Michiel Pauw who established a patronship called Pavonia in 1630 along the North River which eventually became the Bergen.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Peter Minuit's purchase of lands along the Delaware River established the colony of New Sweden.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The entire region became a territory of England on June 24, 1664, after an English fleet under the command of Colonel Richard Nicolls sailed into what is now New York Harbor and took control of Fort Amsterdam, annexing the entire province.

name: new_jersey
sentence: During the English Civil War, the Channel Island of Jersey remained loyal to the British Crown and gave sanctuary to the King.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It was from the Royal Square in Saint Helier that Charles II of England was proclaimed King in 1649, following the execution of his father, Charles I.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The North American lands were divided by Charles II, who gave his brother, the Duke of York (later King James II), the region between New England and Maryland as a proprietary colony (as opposed to a royal colony).

name: new_jersey
sentence: James then granted the land between the Hudson River and the Delaware River (the land that would become New Jersey) to two friends who had remained loyal through the English Civil War: Sir George Carteret and Lord Berkeley of Stratton.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The area was named the Province of New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Since the state's inception, New Jersey has been characterized by ethnic and religious diversity.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New England Congregationalists settled alongside Scots Presbyterians and Dutch Reformed migrants.

name: new_jersey
sentence: While the majority of residents lived in towns with individual landholdings of 100 acres (40 ha), a few rich proprietors owned vast estates.

name: new_jersey
sentence: English Quakers and Anglicans owned large landholdings.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Unlike Plymouth Colony, Jamestown and other colonies, New Jersey was populated by a secondary wave of immigrants who came from other colonies instead of those who migrated directly from Europe.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey remained agrarian and rural throughout the colonial era, and commercial farming developed sporadically.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Some townships, such as Burlington on the Delaware River and Perth Amboy, emerged as important ports for shipping to New York City and Philadelphia.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The colony's fertile lands and tolerant religious policy drew more settlers, and New Jersey's population had increased to 120,000 by 1775.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Settlement for the first 10 years of English rule took place along Hackensack River and Arthur Kill—settlers came primarily from New York and New England.

name: new_jersey
sentence: On March 18, 1673, Berkeley sold his half of the colony to Quakers in England, who settled the Delaware Valley region as a Quaker colony.

name: new_jersey
sentence: (William Penn acted as trustee for the lands for a time.)

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was governed very briefly as two distinct provinces, East and West Jersey, for 28 years between 1674 and 1702, at times part of the Province of New York or Dominion of New England.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 1702, the two provinces were reunited under a royal governor, rather than a proprietary one.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Edward Hyde, Lord Cornbury, became the first governor of the colony as a royal colony.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Britain believed that he was an ineffective and corrupt ruler, taking bribes and speculating on land.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 1708 he was recalled to England.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was then ruled by the governors of New York, but this infuriated the settlers of New Jersey, who accused those governors of favoritism to New York.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Judge Lewis Morris led the case for a separate governor, and was appointed governor by King George II in 1738.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was one of the Thirteen Colonies that revolted against British rule in the American Revolution.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The New Jersey Constitution of 1776 was passed July 2, 1776, just two days before the Second Continental Congress declared American Independence from Great Britain.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It was an act of the Provincial Congress, which made itself into the State Legislature.

name: new_jersey
sentence: To reassure neutrals, it provided that it would become void if New Jersey reached reconciliation with Great Britain.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey representatives Richard Stockton, John Witherspoon, Francis Hopkinson, John Hart, and Abraham Clark were among those who signed the United States Declaration of Independence on July 4, 1776.

name: new_jersey
sentence: During the American Revolutionary War, British and American armies crossed New Jersey numerous times, and several pivotal battles took place in the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Because of this, New Jersey today is often referred to as "The Crossroads of the American Revolution".

name: new_jersey
sentence: The winter quarters of the Continental Army were established there twice by General George Washington in Morristown, which has been called "The Military Capital of the American Revolution.“

name: new_jersey
sentence: On the night of December 25–26, 1776, the Continental Army under George Washington crossed the Delaware River.

name: new_jersey
sentence: After the crossing, he surprised and defeated the Hessian troops in the Battle of Trenton.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Slightly more than a week after victory at Trenton, American forces gained an important victory by stopping General Cornwallis's charges at the Second Battle of Trenton.

name: new_jersey
sentence: By evading Cornwallis's army, Washington made a surprise attack on Princeton and successfully defeated the British forces there on January 3, 1777.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Emanuel Leutze's painting of Washington Crossing the Delaware became an icon of the Revolution.

name: new_jersey
sentence: American forces under Washington met the forces under General Henry Clinton at the Battle of Monmouth in an indecisive engagement in June 1778.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Washington attempted to take the British column by surprise; when the British army attempted to flank the Americans, the Americans retreated in disorder.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The ranks were later reorganized and withstood the British charges.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the summer of 1783, the Continental Congress met in Nassau Hall at Princeton University, making Princeton the nation's capital for four months.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It was there that the Continental Congress learned of the signing of the Treaty of Paris (1783), which ended the war.

name: new_jersey
sentence: On December 18, 1787, New Jersey became the third state to ratify the United States Constitution, which was overwhelmingly popular in New Jersey, as it prevented New York and Pennsylvania from charging tariffs on goods imported from Europe.

name: new_jersey
sentence: On November 20, 1789, the state became the first in the newly formed Union to ratify the Bill of Rights.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The 1776 New Jersey State Constitution gave the vote to "all inhabitants" who had a certain level of wealth.

name: new_jersey
sentence: This included women and blacks, but not married women, because they could not own property separately from their husbands.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Both sides, in several elections, claimed that the other side had had unqualified women vote and mocked them for use of "petticoat electors", whether entitled to vote or not; on the other hand, both parties passed Voting Rights Acts.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 1807, the legislature passed a bill interpreting the constitution to mean universal white male suffrage, excluding paupers; the constitution was itself an act of the legislature and not enshrined as the modern constitution.

name: new_jersey
sentence: On February 15, 1804, New Jersey became the last northern state to abolish new slavery and enacted legislation that slowly phased out existing slavery.

name: new_jersey
sentence: This led to a gradual decrease of the slave population.

name: new_jersey
sentence: By the close of the Civil War, about a dozen African Americans in New Jersey were still held in bondage.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey voters initially refused to ratify the constitutional amendments banning slavery and granting rights to the United States' black population.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Industrialization accelerated in the northern part of the state following completion of the Morris Canal in 1831.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The canal allowed for coal to be brought from eastern Pennsylvania's Lehigh Valley to northern New Jersey's growing industries in Paterson, Newark, and Jersey City.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 1844, the second state constitution was ratified and brought into effect.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Counties thereby became districts for the state senate, and some realignment of boundaries (including the creation of Mercer County) immediately followed.

name: new_jersey
sentence: This provision was retained in the 1947 Constitution, but was overturned by the Supreme Court of the United States in 1962 by the decision Baker v. Carr.

name: new_jersey
sentence: While the Governorship was stronger than under the 1776 constitution, the constitution of 1844 created many offices that were not responsible to him, or to the people, and it gave him a three-year term, but he could not succeed himself.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was one of the few Union states (the others being Delaware and Kentucky) to select a candidate other than Abraham Lincoln twice in national elections, and sided with Stephen Douglas (1860) and George B. McClellan (1864) during their campaigns.

name: new_jersey
sentence: McClellan, a native Philadelphian, had New Jersey ties and formally resided in New Jersey at the time; he later became Governor of New Jersey (1878–81).

name: new_jersey
sentence: (In New Jersey, the factions of the Democratic party managed an effective coalition in 1860.)

name: new_jersey
sentence: During the American Civil War, the state was led first by Republican governor Charles Smith Olden, then by Democrat Joel Parker.

name: new_jersey
sentence: During the course of the war, over 80,000 from the state enlisted in the Northern army; unlike many states, including some Northern ones, no battle was fought there.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the Industrial Revolution, cities like Paterson grew and prospered.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Previously, the economy had been largely agrarian, which was problematically subject to crop failures and poor soil.

name: new_jersey
sentence: This caused a shift to a more industrialized economy, one based on manufactured commodities such as textiles and silk.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Inventor Thomas Edison also became an important figure of the Industrial Revolution, having been granted 1,093 patents, many of which for inventions he developed while working in New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Edison's facilities, first at Menlo Park and then in West Orange, are considered perhaps the first research centers in the United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Christie Street in Menlo Park was the first thoroughfare in the world to have electric lighting.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Transportation was greatly improved as locomotion and steamboats were introduced to New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Iron mining was also a leading industry during the middle to late 19th century.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Bog iron pits in the southern New Jersey Pinelands were among the first sources of iron for the new nation.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Mines such as Mt.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Hope, Mine Hill and the Rockaway Valley Mines created a thriving industry.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Mining generated the impetus for new towns and was one of the driving forces behind the need for the Morris Canal.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Zinc mines were also a major industry, especially the Sterling Hill Mine.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey prospered through the Roaring Twenties.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The first Miss America Pageant was held in 1921 in Atlantic City, the Holland Tunnel connecting Jersey City to Manhattan opened in 1927, and the first drive-in movie was shown in 1933 in Camden.

name: new_jersey
sentence: During the Great Depression of the 1930s, the state offered begging licenses to unemployed residents, the zeppelin airship Hindenburg crashed in flames over Lakehurst, and the SS Morro Castle beached itself near Asbury Park after going up in flames while at sea.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Through both World Wars, New Jersey was a center for war production, especially naval construction.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company yards in Kearny and Newark and the New York Shipbuilding Corporation yard in Camden produced aircraft carriers, battleships, cruisers, and destroyers.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey manufactured 6.8 percent of total United States military armaments produced during World War II, ranking fifth among the 48 states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In addition, Fort Dix (1917) (originally called "Camp Dix"), Camp Merritt (1917) and Camp Kilmer (1941) were all constructed to house and train American soldiers through both World Wars.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey also became a principal location for defense in the Cold War.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Fourteen Nike missile stations were constructed for the defense of the New York City and Philadelphia areas.

name: new_jersey
sentence: PT-109, a motor torpedo boat commanded by Lt.

name: new_jersey
sentence: John F. Kennedy in World War II, was built at the Elco Boatworks in Bayonne.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The aircraft carrier USEnterprise (CV-6) was briefly docked at the Military Ocean Terminal in Bayonne in the 1950s before she was sent to Kearney to be scrapped.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 1962, the world's first nuclear-powered cargo ship, the NS Savannah, was launched at Camden.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 1951, the New Jersey Turnpike opened, permitting fast travel by car and truck between North Jersey (and metropolitan New York) and South Jersey (and metropolitan Philadelphia).

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 1959, Air Defense Command deployed the CIM-10 Bomarc surface-to-air missile to McGuire Air Force Base.

name: new_jersey
sentence: On June 7, 1960, an explosion in a CIM-10 Bomarc missile fuel tank caused the accident and subsequent plutonium contamination.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the 1960s, race riots erupted in many of the industrial cities of North Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The first race riots in New Jersey occurred in Jersey City on August 2, 1964.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Several others ensued in 1967, in Newark and Plainfield.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Other riots followed the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr. in April 1968, just as in the rest of the country.

name: new_jersey
sentence: A riot occurred in Camden in 1971.

name: new_jersey
sentence: As a result of an order from the New Jersey Supreme Court to fund schools equitably, the New Jersey legislature passed an income tax bill in 1976.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Prior to this bill, the state had no income tax.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the early part of the 2000s, two light rail systems were opened: the Hudson–Bergen Light Rail in Hudson County and the River Line between Camden and Trenton.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The intent of these projects was to encourage transit-oriented development in North Jersey and South Jersey, respectively.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The HBLR in particular was credited with a revitalization of Hudson County and Jersey City in particular.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Urban revitalization has continued in North Jersey in the 21st century.

name: new_jersey
sentence: As of 2014, Jersey City's Census-estimated population was 262,146, with the largest population increase of any municipality in New Jersey since 2010, representing an increase of 5.9% from the 2010 United States Census, when the city's population was enumerated at 247,597.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Between 2000 and 2010, Newark experienced its first population increase since the 1950s.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is bordered on the north and northeast by New York (parts of which are across the Hudson River, Upper New York Bay, the Kill Van Kull, Newark Bay, and the Arthur Kill); on the east by the Atlantic Ocean; on the southwest by Delaware across Delaware Bay; and on the west by Pennsylvania across the Delaware River.

name: new_jersey
sentence: This is New Jersey's only straight border.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is often broadly divided into three geographic regions: North Jersey, Central Jersey, and South Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Some New Jersey residents do not consider Central Jersey a region in its own right, but others believe it is a separate geographic and cultural area from the North and South.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Within those regions are five distinct areas, based upon natural geography and population concentration.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Northeastern New Jersey lies closest to Manhattan in New York City, and up to a million residents commute daily into the city for work, many via public transportation.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Northwestern New Jersey is more wooded, rural, and mountainous.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Jersey Shore, along the Atlantic Coast in Central and South Jersey, has its own unique natural, residential, and cultural characteristics owing to its location by the ocean.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Delaware Valley includes the southwestern counties of the state, which reside within the Philadelphia Metropolitan Area.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Pine Barrens region is in the southern interior of New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Covered rather extensively by mixed pine and oak forest, it has a much lower population density than much of the rest of the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The federal Office of Management and Budget divides New Jersey's counties into seven Metropolitan Statistical Areas, with 16 counties included in either the New York City or Philadelphia metro areas.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Four counties have independent metro areas, and Warren County is part of the Pennsylvania-based Lehigh Valley metro area.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is also at the center of the Northeast megalopolis.

name: new_jersey
sentence: High Point, in Montague Township, Sussex County, is the state's highest elevation, at 1,803 feet (550 m) above sea level.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The state's highest prominence is Kitty Ann Mountain in Morris County, rising 892 feet.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Palisades are a line of steep cliffs on the west side of the Hudson River, in Bergen and Hudson Counties.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Major New Jersey rivers include the Hudson, Delaware, Raritan, Passaic, Hackensack, Rahway, Musconetcong, Mullica, Rancocas, Manasquan, Maurice, and Toms rivers.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Due to New Jersey's peninsular geography, both sunrise and sunset are visible over water from different points on the Jersey Shore.

name: new_jersey
sentence: There are two climatic conditions in the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The south, central, and northeast parts of the state have a humid subtropical climate, while the northwest has a humid continental climate (microthermal), with much cooler temperatures due to higher elevation.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey receives between 2,400 and 2,800 hours of sunshine annually.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Climate change is affecting New Jersey faster than much of the rest of the United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: As of 2019, New Jersey was one of the fastest-warming states in the nation.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Since 1895, average temperatures have climbed by almost 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit, double the average for the other Lower 48 states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Summers are typically hot and humid, with statewide average high temperatures of 82–87 °F (28–31 °C) and lows of 60–69 °F (16–21 °C); however, temperatures exceed 90 °F (32 °C) on average 25 days each summer, exceeding 100 °F (38 °C) in some years.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Winters are usually cold, with average high temperatures of 34–43 °F (1–6 °C) and lows of 16 to 28 °F (−9 to −2 °C) for most of the state, but temperatures can, for brief periods, fall below 10 °F (−12 °C) and sometimes rise above 50 °F (10 °C).

name: new_jersey
sentence: Northwestern parts of the state have significantly colder winters with sub-0 °F (−18 °C) being an almost annual occurrence.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Spring and autumn may feature wide temperature variations, with lower humidity than summer.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The USDA Plant Hardiness Zone classification ranges from 6 in the northwest of the state, to 7B near Cape May.

name: new_jersey
sentence: All-time temperature extremes recorded in New Jersey include 110 °F (43 °C) on July 10, 1936, in Runyon, Middlesex County and −34 °F (−37 °C) on January 5, 1904, in River Vale, Bergen County.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Average annual precipitation ranges from 43 to 51 inches (1,100 to 1,300 mm), uniformly spread through the year.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Average snowfall per winter season ranges from 10–15 inches (25–38 cm) in the south and near the seacoast, 15–30 inches (38–76 cm) in the northeast and central part of the state, to about 40–50 inches (1.0–1.3 m) in the northwestern highlands, but this often varies considerably from year to year.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Precipitation falls on an average of 120 days a year, with 25 to 30 thunderstorms, most of which occur during the summer.

name: new_jersey
sentence: During winter and early spring, New Jersey can experience "nor'easters", which are capable of causing blizzards or flooding throughout the northeastern United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Hurricanes and tropical storms (such as Tropical Storm Floyd in 1999), tornadoes, and earthquakes are rare, although New Jersey was impacted by a hurricane in 1903, and Hurricane Sandy on October 29, 2012 with the storm making landfall in the state with top winds of 90 mph (145 km/h).

name: new_jersey
sentence: The United States Census Bureau estimates that the population of New Jersey was 8,882,190 on July 1, 2019, a 1.03% increase since the 2010 United States Census.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Residents of New Jersey are most commonly referred to as "New Jerseyans" or, less commonly, as "New Jerseyites".

name: new_jersey
sentence: As of the 2010 census, there were 8,791,894 people living in the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The racial makeup of the state was:

name: new_jersey
sentence: 17.7% of the population were Hispanic or Latino (of any race).

name: new_jersey
sentence: Non-Hispanic Whites were 58.9% of the population in 2011, down from 85% in 1970.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 2010, unauthorized immigrants constituted an estimated 6.2% of the population.

name: new_jersey
sentence: This was the fourth-highest percentage of any state in the country.

name: new_jersey
sentence: There were an estimated 550,000 illegal immigrants in the state in 2010.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Among the municipalities which are considered sanctuary cities are Camden, Jersey City and Newark.

name: new_jersey
sentence: As of 2010, New Jersey was the eleventh-most populous state in the United States, and the most densely populated, at 1,185 residents per square mile (458 per km2), with most of the population residing in the counties surrounding New York City, Philadelphia, and along the eastern Jersey Shore, while the extreme southern and northwestern counties are relatively less dense overall.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It is also the second wealthiest state according to the US Census Bureau.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The center of population for New Jersey is located in Middlesex County, in the town of Milltown, just east of the New Jersey Turnpike.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is home to more scientists and engineers per square mile than anywhere else in the world.

name: new_jersey
sentence: On October 21, 2013, same-sex marriages commenced in New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is one of the most ethnically and religiously diverse states in the United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: As of 2011, 56.4% of New Jersey's children under the age of one belonged to racial or ethnic minority groups, meaning that they had at least one parent who was not non-Hispanic white.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The state has the second largest Jewish population by percentage (after New York); the second largest Muslim population by percentage (after Michigan); the largest population of Peruvians in the United States; the largest population of Cubans outside of Florida; the third highest Asian population by percentage; and the second highest Italian population, according to the 2000 Census.

name: new_jersey
sentence: African Americans, Hispanics (Puerto Ricans and Dominicans), West Indians, Arabs, and Brazilian and Portuguese Americans are also high in number.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey has the third highest Asian Indian population of any state by absolute numbers and the highest by percentage, with Bergen County home to America's largest Malayali community.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Overall, New Jersey has the third largest Korean population, with Bergen County home to the highest Korean concentration per capita of any US county (6.9% in 2011).

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey also has the fourth largest Filipino population, and fourth largest Chinese population, per the 2010 US Census.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The five largest ethnic groups in 2000 were: Italian (17.9%), Irish (15.9%), African (13.6%), German (12.6%), Polish (6.9%).

name: new_jersey
sentence: India Square, in Bombay, Jersey City, Hudson County, is home to the highest concentration of Asian Indians in the Western Hemisphere.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Meanwhile, Central New Jersey, particularly Edison and surrounding Middlesex County, is prominently known for its significant concentration of Asian Indians.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The world's largest Hindu temple was inaugurated in Robbinsville in 2014, a BAPS temple.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The growing Little India is a South Asian-focused commercial strip in Middlesex County, the US county with the highest concentration of Asian Indians.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Oak Tree Road strip runs for about one-and-a-half miles through Edison and neighboring Iselin in Woodbridge Township, near the area's sprawling Chinatown and Koreatown, running along New Jersey Route 27.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It is the largest and most diverse South Asian cultural hub in the United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Carteret's Punjabi Sikh community, variously estimated at upwards of 3,000, is the largest concentration of Sikhs in the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Monroe Township in Middlesex County has experienced a particularly rapid growth rate in its Indian American population, with an estimated 5,943 (13.6%) as of 2017, which was 23 times the 256 (0.9%) counted as of the 2000 Census; and Diwali is celebrated by the township as a Hindu holiday.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In Middlesex County, election ballots are printed in English, Spanish, Gujarati, Hindi, and Punjabi.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Newark was the fourth poorest of US cities with over 250,000 residents in 2008, but New Jersey as a whole had the second-highest median household income as of 2014.

name: new_jersey
sentence: This is largely because so much of New Jersey consists of suburbs, most of them affluent, of New York City and Philadelphia.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is also the most densely populated state, and the only state that has had every one of its counties deemed "urban" as defined by the Census Bureau's Combined Statistical Area.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 2010, 6.2% of its population was reported as under age 5, 23.5% under 18, and 13.5% were 65 or older; and females made up approximately 51.3% of the population.

name: new_jersey
sentence: A study by the Pew Research Center found that in 2013, New Jersey was the only US state in which immigrants born in India constituted the largest foreign-born nationality, representing roughly 10% of all foreign-born residents in the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: For further information on various ethnoracial groups and neighborhoods prominently featured within New Jersey, see the following articles:

name: new_jersey
sentence: As of 2011, 56.4% of New Jersey's population younger than age 1 were minorities (meaning that they had at least one parent who was not non-Hispanic white).

name: new_jersey
sentence: Note: Births in table do not add up, because Hispanics are counted both by their ethnicity and by their race, giving a higher overall number.

name: new_jersey
sentence: As of 2010, 71.31% (5,830,812) of New Jersey residents age 5 and older spoke English at home as a primary language, while 14.59% (1,193,261) spoke Spanish, 1.23% (100,217) Chinese (which includes Cantonese and Mandarin), 1.06% (86,849) Italian, 1.06% (86,486) Portuguese, 0.96% (78,627) Tagalog, and Korean was spoken as a main language by 0.89% (73,057) of the population over the age of five.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In total, 28.69% (2,345,644) of New Jersey's population age 5 and older spoke a mother language other than English.

name: new_jersey
sentence: A diverse collection of languages has since evolved amongst the state's population, given that New Jersey has become cosmopolitan and is home to ethnic enclaves of non-English-speaking communities:

name: new_jersey
sentence: By number of adherents, the largest denominations in New Jersey, according to the Association of Religion Data Archives in 2010, were the Roman Catholic Church with 3,235,290; Islam with 160,666; and the United Methodist Church with 138,052.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The world's largest Hindu temple was inaugurated in Robbinsville, Mercer County, in central New Jersey during 2014, a BAPS temple.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In January 2018, Gurbir Grewal became the first Sikh American state attorney general in the United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In January 2019, Sadaf Jaffer became the first female Muslim American mayor, first female South Asian mayor, and first female Pakistani-American mayor in the United States, of Montgomery in Somerset County.

name: new_jersey
sentence: For its overall population and nation-leading population density, New Jersey has a relative paucity of classic large cities.

name: new_jersey
sentence: This paradox is most pronounced in Bergen County, New Jersey's most populous county, whose more than 930,000 residents in 2019 inhabited 70 municipalities, the most populous being Hackensack, with 44,522 residents estimated in 2018.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Many urban areas extend far beyond the limits of a single large city, as New Jersey cities (and indeed municipalities in general) tend to be geographically small; three of the four largest cities in New Jersey by population have under 20 square miles (52 km2) of land area, and eight of the top ten, including all of the top five have land area under 30 square miles (78 km2).

name: new_jersey
sentence: As of the 2010 United States Census, only four municipalities had populations in excess of 100,000, although Edison and Woodbridge came very close.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The US Bureau of Economic Analysis estimates that New Jersey's gross state product in the fourth quarter of 2018 was $639.8 billion.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey's estimated taxpayer burden in 2015 was $59,400 per taxpayer.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is nearly $239 billion in debt.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey's per capita gross state product in 2008 was $54,699, second in the US and above the national per capita gross domestic product of $46,588.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Its per capita income was the third highest in the nation with $51,358.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 2020, New Jersey had the highest number of millionaires per capita in the United States, approximately 9.76% of households.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The state is ranked second in the nation by the number of places with per capita incomes above national average with 76.4%.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Nine of New Jersey's counties are among the 100 wealthiest US counties.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey has seven tax brackets that determine state income tax rates, which range from 1.4% (for income below $20,000) to 8.97% (for income above $500,000).

name: new_jersey
sentence: The standard sales tax rate as of January 1, 2018, is 6.625%, applicable to all retail sales unless specifically exempt by law.

name: new_jersey
sentence: This rate, which is comparably lower than that of New York City, often attracts numerous shoppers from New York City, often to suburban Paramus, New Jersey, which has five malls, one of which (the Garden State Plaza) has over two million square feet of retail space.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Tax exemptions include most food items for at-home preparation, medications, most clothing, footwear and disposable paper products for use in the home.

name: new_jersey
sentence: There are 27 Urban Enterprise Zone statewide, including sections of Paterson, Elizabeth, and Jersey City.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In addition to other benefits to encourage employment within the zone, shoppers can take advantage of a reduced 3.3125% sales tax rate (half the rate charged statewide) at eligible merchants.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey has the highest cumulative tax rate of all 50 states with residents paying a total of $68 billion in state and local taxes annually with a per capita burden of $7,816 at a rate of 12.9% of income.

name: new_jersey
sentence: All real property located in the state is subject to property tax unless specifically exempted by statute.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey does not assess an intangible personal property tax, but it does impose an inheritance tax.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey consistently ranks as having one of the highest proportional levels of disparity of any state in the United States, based upon what it receives from the federal government relative to what it gives.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 2015, WalletHub ranked New Jersey the state least dependent upon federal government aid overall and having the fourth lowest return on taxpayer investment from the federal government, at 48 cents per dollar.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey has one of the highest tax burdens in the nation.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Factors for this include the large federal tax liability which is not adjusted for New Jersey's higher cost of living and Medicaid funding formulas.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey's economy is multifaceted, but is centered on the pharmaceutical industry, biotechnology, information technology, the financial industry, chemical development, telecommunications, food processing, electric equipment, printing, publishing, and tourism.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey's agricultural outputs are nursery stock, horses, vegetables, fruits and nuts, seafood, and dairy products.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey ranks second among states in blueberry production, third in cranberries and spinach, and fourth in bell peppers, peaches, and head lettuce.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The state harvests the fourth-largest number of acres planted with asparagus.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Although New Jersey is home to many energy-intensive industries, its energy consumption is only 2.7% of the US total, and its carbon dioxide emissions are 0.8% of the US total.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Its comparatively low greenhouse gas emissions can be attributed to the state's use of nuclear power.

name: new_jersey
sentence: According to the Energy Information Administration, nuclear power dominates New Jersey's electricity market, typically supplying more than one-half of state generation.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey has three nuclear power plants, including the Oyster Creek Nuclear Generating Station, which came online in 1969 and is the oldest operating nuclear plant in the country.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey has a strong scientific economy and is home to major pharmaceutical and telecommunications firms, drawing on the state's large and well-educated labor pool.

name: new_jersey
sentence: There is also a strong service economy in retail sales, education, and real estate, serving residents who work in New York City or Philadelphia.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Shipping is a key industry in New Jersey because of the state's strategic geographic location, the Port of New York and New Jersey being the busiest port on the East Coast.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Port Newark-Elizabeth Marine Terminal was the world's first container port and today is one of the world's largest.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey hosts several business headquarters, including twenty-four Fortune 500 companies.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Paramus in Bergen County has become the top retail ZIP code (07652) in the United States, with the municipality generating over US$6 billion in annual retail sales.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Several New Jersey counties, including Somerset (7), Morris (10), Hunterdon (13), Bergen (21), and Monmouth (42), have been ranked among the highest-income counties in the United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey's location at the center of the Northeast megalopolis and its extensive transportation system have put over one-third of all United States residents and many Canadian residents within overnight distance by land.

name: new_jersey
sentence: This accessibility to consumer revenue has enabled seaside resorts such as Atlantic City and the remainder of the Jersey Shore, as well as the state's other natural and cultural attractions, to contribute significantly to the record 111 million tourist visits to New Jersey in 2018, providing US$44.7 billion in tourism revenue, directly supporting 333,860 jobs, sustaining more than 531,000 jobs overall including peripheral impacts, and generating US$5 billion in state and local tax revenue.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 1976, a referendum of New Jersey voters approved casino gambling in Atlantic City, where the first legalized casino opened in 1978.

name: new_jersey
sentence: At that time, Las Vegas was the only other casino resort in the country.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Today, several casinos lie along the Atlantic City Boardwalk, the first and longest boardwalk in the world.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Atlantic City experienced a dramatic contraction in its stature as a gambling destination after 2010, including the closure of multiple casinos since 2014, spurred by competition from the advent of legalized gambling in other northeastern US states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: On February 26, 2013, Governor Chris Christie signed online gambling into law.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Sports betting has become a growing source of gambling revenue in New Jersey since being legalized across the nation by the US Supreme Court on May 14, 2018.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Forests cover 45%, or approximately 2.1 million acres, of New Jersey's land area.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The chief tree of the northern forests is the oak.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Pine Barrens, consisting of pine forests, is in the southern part of the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Some mining activity of zinc, iron, and manganese still takes place in the area in and around the Franklin Furnace.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is second in the nation in solar power installations, enabled by one of the country's most favorable net metering policies, and the renewable energy certificates program.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The state has more than 10,000 solar installations.

name: new_jersey
sentence: As of 2010, there were 605 school districts in the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Secretary of Education Rick Rosenberg, appointed by Governor Jon Corzine, created the Education Advancement Initiative (EAI) to increase college admission rates by 10% for New Jersey's high school students, decrease dropout rates by 15%, and increase the amount of money devoted to schools by 10%.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Rosenberg retracted this plan when criticized for taking the money out of healthcare to fund this initiative.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 2010, the state government paid all teachers' premiums for health insurance, but currently all NJ public teachers pay a portion of their own health insurance premiums.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is known for the quality of its education.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 2015, the state spent more per each public school student than any other US state except New York, Alaska, and Connecticut, amounting to $18,235 spent per pupil; over 50% of the expenditure was allocated to student instruction.

name: new_jersey
sentence: According to 2011 Newsweek statistics, students of High Technology High School in Lincroft, Monmouth County and Bergen County Academies in Hackensack, Bergen County registered average SAT scores of 2145 and 2100, respectively, representing the second- and third-highest scores, respectively, of all listed US high schools.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Princeton University in Princeton, Mercer County, one of the world's most prominent research universities, is often featured at or near the top of various national and global university rankings, topping the 2020 list of US News & World Report.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 2013, Rutgers University, headquartered in New Brunswick, Middlesex County as the flagship institution of higher education in New Jersey, regained medical and dental schools, augmenting its profile as a national research university as well.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 2014, New Jersey's school systems were ranked at the top of all fifty US states by financial website Wallethub.com.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 2018, New Jersey's overall educational system was ranked second among all states to Massachusetts by US News & World Report.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In both 2019 and 2020, Education Week also ranked New Jersey public schools the best of all US states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Nine New Jersey high schools were ranked among the top 25 in the US on the Newsweek "America's Top High Schools 2016" list, more than from any other state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: A 2017 UCLA Civil Rights project found that New Jersey has the sixth-most segregated classrooms in the United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey has continued to play a prominent role as a US cultural nexus.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Like every state, New Jersey has its own cuisine, religious communities, museums, and halls of fame.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is the birthplace of modern inventions such as: FM radio, the motion picture camera, the lithium battery, the light bulb, transistors, and the electric train.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Other New Jersey creations include: the drive-in movie, the cultivated blueberry, cranberry sauce, the postcard, the boardwalk, the zipper, the phonograph, saltwater taffy, the dirigible, the seedless watermelon, the first use of a submarine in warfare, and the ice cream cone.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Diners are iconic to New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The state is home to many diner manufacturers and has over 600 diners, more than any other place in the world.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is the only state without a state song.

name: new_jersey
sentence: I'm From New Jersey is incorrectly listed on many websites as being the New Jersey state song, but it was not even a contender when in 1996 the New Jersey Arts Council submitted their suggestions to the New Jersey Legislature.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is frequently the target of jokes in American culture, especially from New York City-based television shows, such as Saturday Night Live.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Academic Michael Aaron Rockland attributes this to New Yorkers' view that New Jersey is the beginning of Middle America.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The New Jersey Turnpike, which runs between two major East Coast cities, New York City and Philadelphia, is also cited as a reason, as people who traverse through the state may only see its industrial zones.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Reality television shows like Jersey Shore and The Real Housewives of New Jersey have reinforced stereotypical views of New Jersey culture, but Rockland cited The Sopranos and the music of Bruce Springsteen as exporting a more positive image.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is known for several foods developed within the region, including Taylor Ham (also known as pork roll), cheesesteaks, and scrapple.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Several states with substantial Italian American populations take credit for the development of submarine sandwiches, including New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey has long been an important origin for both rock and rap music.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Prominent musicians from or with significant connections to New Jersey include:

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey currently has six teams from major professional sports leagues playing in the state, although one Major League Soccer team and two National Football League teams identify themselves as being from the New York metropolitan area.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The National Hockey League's New Jersey Devils, based in Newark at the Prudential Center, is the only major league sports franchise to bear the state's name.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Founded in 1974 in Kansas City, Missouri, as the Kansas City Scouts, the team played in Denver, Colorado, as the Colorado Rockies from 1976 until the spring of 1982 when naval architect, businessman, and Jersey City native John J. McMullen purchased, renamed, and moved the franchise to Brendan Byrne Arena in East Rutherford's Meadowlands Sports Complex.

name: new_jersey
sentence: While the team had mostly losing records in Kansas City, Denver, and its first years in New Jersey, the Devils began to improve in the late 1980s and early 1990s under Hall of Fame president and general manager Lou Lamoriello.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The team made the playoffs for the Stanley Cup in 2001 and 2012, and won it in 1995, 2000, and 2003.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The organization is the youngest of the nine major league teams in the New York metropolitan area.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Devils have established a following throughout the northern and central portions of the state, carving a place in a media market once dominated by the New York Rangers and Islanders.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 2018, the Philadelphia Flyers renovated and expanded their training facility, the Virtua Center Flyers Skate Zone, in Voorhees Township in the southern portion of the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The New York Metropolitan Area's two National Football League teams, the New York Giants and the New York Jets, play at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford's Meadowlands Sports Complex.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Built for about $1.6 billion, the venue is the most expensive stadium ever built.

name: new_jersey
sentence: On February 2, 2014, MetLife Stadium hosted Super Bowl XLVIII.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The New York Red Bulls of Major League Soccer play in Red Bull Arena, a soccer-specific stadium in Harrison across the Passaic River from downtown Newark.

name: new_jersey
sentence: On July 27, 2011, Red Bull Arena hosted the 2011 MLS All-Star Game.

name: new_jersey
sentence: From 1977 to 2012, New Jersey had a National Basketball Association team, the New Jersey Nets.

name: new_jersey
sentence: WNBA's New York Liberty played in New Jersey from 2011 to 2013 while their primary home arena, Madison Square Garden was undergoing renovations.

name: new_jersey
