sentence: In 2016, the Philadelphia 76ers of the NBA opened their new headquarters and training facility, the Philadelphia 76ers Training Complex, in Camden.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Meadowlands Sports Complex is home to the Meadowlands Racetrack, one of three major harness racing tracks in the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Meadowlands Racetrack and Freehold Raceway in Freehold are two of the major harness racing tracks in North America.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Monmouth Park Racetrack in Oceanport is a popular spot for thoroughbred racing in New Jersey and the northeast.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It hosted the Breeders' Cup in 2007, and its turf course was renovated in preparation.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jerseyans' collegiate allegiances are predominantly split among the three major NCAA Division I programs in the state: the Rutgers University (New Jersey's flagship state university) Scarlet Knights, members of the Big Ten Conference; the Seton Hall University (the state's largest Catholic university) Pirates, members of the Big East Conference; and the Princeton University (the state's Ivy League university) Tigers.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The intense rivalry between Rutgers and Princeton athletics began with the first intercollegiate football game in 1869.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The schools have not met on the football field since 1980, but they continue to play each other annually in all other sports offered by the two universities.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Rutgers, which fields 24 teams in various sports, is nationally known for its football program, with a 6–4 all-time bowl record; and its women's basketball programs, which appeared in a National Final in 2007.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 2008 and 2009, Rutgers expanded their football home, Rutgers Stadium, now called SHI Stadium, on the Busch Campus.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The basketball teams play at the Rutgers Athletic Center on Livingston Campus.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Both venues and campuses are in Piscataway, across the Raritan River from New Brunswick.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The university also fields men's basketball and baseball programs.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Rutgers' fans live mostly in the western parts of the state and Middlesex County

name: new_jersey
sentence: Rutgers' satellite campuses in Camden and Newark each field their own athletic programs—the Rutgers–Camden Scarlet Raptors and the Rutgers–Newark Scarlet Raiders—which both compete in NCAA Division III.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Seton Hall fields no football team, but its men's basketball team is one of the Big East's storied programs.

name: new_jersey
sentence: No New Jersey team has won more games in the NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament, and it is the state's only men's basketball program to reach a modern National Final.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Pirates play their home games at Prudential Center in downtown Newark, about four miles from the university's South Orange campus.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Their fans hail largely from in the predominantly Roman Catholic areas of the northern part of the state and the Jersey Shore.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The annual inter-conference rivalry game between Seton Hall and Rutgers, whose venue alternates between Newark and Piscataway, the Garden State Hardwood Classic, is planned through 2026.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The state's other Division I schools include the Monmouth University Hawks (West Long Branch), the New Jersey Institute of Technology (NJIT) Highlanders (Newark), the Rider University Broncs (Lawrenceville), and the Saint Peter's University Peacocks and Peahens (Jersey City).

name: new_jersey
sentence: Fairleigh Dickinson University competes in both Division I and Division III.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It has two campuses, each with its own sports teams.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The teams at the Metropolitan Campus are known as the FDU Knights, and compete in the Northeast Conference and NCAA Division I.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The college at Florham (FDU-Florham) teams are known as the FDU-Florham Devils and compete in the Middle Atlantic Conferences' Freedom Conference and NCAA Division III.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Among the various Division III schools in the state, the Stevens Institute of Technology Ducks have fielded the longest continuously running collegiate men's lacrosse program in the country.

name: new_jersey
sentence: 2009 marked the 125th season.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey high schools are divided into divisions under the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association (NJSIAA).'

name: new_jersey
sentence: Founded in 1918, the NJSIAA currently represents 22,000 schools, 330,000 coaches, and almost 4.5 million athletes.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Motion picture technology was developed by Thomas Edison, with much of his early work done at his West Orange laboratory.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Edison's Black Maria was the first motion picture studio.

name: new_jersey
sentence: America's first motion picture industry started in 1907 in Fort Lee and the first studio was constructed there in 1909.

name: new_jersey
sentence: DuMont Laboratories in Passaic developed early sets and made the first broadcast to the private home.

name: new_jersey
sentence: A number of television shows and films have been filmed in New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Since 1978, the state has maintained a Motion Picture and Television Commission to encourage filming in-state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey has long offered tax credits to television producers.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Governor Chris Christie suspended the credits in 2010, but the New Jersey State Legislature in 2011 approved the restoration and expansion of the tax credit program.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Under bills passed by both the state Senatorte and Assembly, the program offers 20 percent tax credits (22% in urban enterprise zones) to television and film productions that shoot in the state and meet set standards for hiring and local spending.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The New Jersey Turnpike is one of the most prominent and heavily trafficked roadways in the United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: This toll road, which overlaps with Interstate 95 for much of its length, carries traffic between Delaware and New York, and up and down the East Coast in general.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Commonly referred to as simply "the Turnpike", it is known for its numerous rest areas named after prominent New Jerseyans.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Garden State Parkway, or simply "the Parkway", carries relatively more in-state traffic than interstate traffic and runs from New Jersey's northern border to its southernmost tip at Cape May.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It is the main route that connects the New York metropolitan area to the Jersey Shore.

name: new_jersey
sentence: With a total of fifteen travel and six shoulder lanes, the Driscoll Bridge on the Parkway, spanning the Raritan River in Middlesex County, is the widest motor vehicle bridge in the world by number of lanes as well as one of the busiest.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is connected to New York City via various key bridges and tunnels.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The double-decked George Washington Bridge carries the heaviest load of motor vehicle traffic of any bridge in the world, at 102 million vehicles per year, across fourteen lanes.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It connects Fort Lee, New Jersey to the Washington Heights neighborhood of Upper Manhattan, and carries Interstate 95 and US Route 1/9 across the Hudson River.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Lincoln Tunnel connects to Midtown Manhattan carrying New Jersey Route 495, and the Holland Tunnel connects to Lower Manhattan carrying Interstate 78.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is also connected to Staten Island by three bridges—from north to south, the Bayonne Bridge, the Goethals Bridge, and the Outerbridge Crossing.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey has interstate compacts with all three of its neighboring states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the Delaware River Port Authority (with Pennsylvania), the Delaware River Joint Toll Bridge Commission (with Pennsylvania), and the Delaware River and Bay Authority (with Delaware) operate most of the major transportation routes in and out of the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Bridge tolls are collected only from traffic exiting the state, with the exception of the private Dingman's Ferry Bridge over the Delaware River, which charges a toll in both directions.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It is unlawful for a customer to serve themselves gasoline in New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It became the last remaining US state where all gas stations are required to sell full-service gasoline to customers at all times in 2016, after Oregon's introduction of restricted self-service gasoline availability took effect.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Newark Liberty International Airport (EWR) is one of the busiest airports in the United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Operated by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, it is one of the three main airports serving the New York metropolitan area.

name: new_jersey
sentence: United Airlines is the airport's largest tenant, operating an entire terminal there, which it uses as one of its primary hubs.

name: new_jersey
sentence: FedEx Express operates a large cargo terminal at EWR as well.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The adjacent Newark Airport railroad station provides access to Amtrak and NJ Transit trains along the Northeast Corridor Line.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Two smaller commercial airports, Atlantic City International Airport and rapidly growing Trenton-Mercer Airport, also operate in other parts of the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Teterboro Airport in Bergen County, and Millville Municipal Airport in Cumberland County, are general aviation airports popular with private and corporate aircraft due to their proximity to New York City and the Jersey Shore, respectively.

name: new_jersey
sentence: NJ Transit operates extensive rail and bus service throughout the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: A state-run corporation, it began with the consolidation of several private bus companies in North Jersey in 1979.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the early 1980s, it acquired Conrail's commuter train operations that connected suburban towns to New York City.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Today, NJ Transit has eleven commuter rail lines that run through different parts of the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Most of the lines end at either Penn Station in New York City or Hoboken Terminal in Hoboken.

name: new_jersey
sentence: One line provides service between Atlantic City and Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

name: new_jersey
sentence: NJ Transit also operates three light rail systems in the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Hudson-Bergen Light Rail connects Bayonne to North Bergen, through Hoboken and Jersey City.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Newark Light Rail is partially underground, and connects downtown Newark with other parts of the city and its suburbs, Belleville and Bloomfield.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The River Line connects Trenton and Camden.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The PATH is a rapid transit system consisting of four lines operated by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It links Hoboken, Jersey City, Harrison and Newark with New York City.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The PATCO Speedline is a rapid transit system that links Camden County to Philadelphia.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Both the PATCO and the PATH are two of only five rapid transit systems in the United States to operate 24 hours a day.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Amtrak operates numerous long-distance passenger trains in New Jersey, both to and from neighboring states and around the country.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In addition to the Newark Airport connection, other major Amtrak railway stations include Trenton Transit Center, Metropark, and the historic Newark Penn Station.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority, or SEPTA, has two commuter rail lines that operate into New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Trenton Line terminates at the Trenton Transit Center, and the West Trenton Line terminates at the West Trenton Rail Station in Ewing.

name: new_jersey
sentence: AirTrain Newark is a monorail connecting the Amtrak/NJ Transit station on the Northeast Corridor to the airport's terminals and parking lots.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Some private bus carriers still remain in New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Most of these carriers operate with state funding to offset losses and state owned buses are provided to these carriers, of which Coach USA companies make up the bulk.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Other carriers include private charter and tour bus operators that take gamblers from other parts of New Jersey, New York City, Philadelphia, and Delaware to the casino resorts of Atlantic City.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New York Waterway has ferry terminals at Belford, Jersey City, Hoboken, Weehawken, and Edgewater, with service to different parts of Manhattan.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Liberty Water Taxi in Jersey City has ferries from Paulus Hook and Liberty State Park to Battery Park City in Manhattan.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Statue Cruises offers service from Liberty State Park to the Statue of Liberty National Monument, including Ellis Island.

name: new_jersey
sentence: SeaStreak offers services from the Raritan Bayshore to Manhattan, Martha's Vineyard, and Nantucket.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Delaware River and Bay Authority operates the Cape May–Lewes Ferry on Delaware Bay, carrying both passengers and vehicles between New Jersey and Delaware.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The agency also operates the Forts Ferry Crossing for passengers across the Delaware River.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Delaware River Port Authority operates the RiverLink Ferry between the Camden waterfront and Penn's Landing in Philadelphia.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The position of Governor of New Jersey has been considered one of the most powerful in the nation.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Until 2010, the governor was the only statewide elected executive official in the state and appointed numerous government officials.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Formerly, an acting governor was even more powerful as he simultaneously served as president of the New Jersey State Senatorte, thus directing half of the legislative and all of the executive process.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 2002 and 2007, president of the state senate Richard Codey held the position of acting governor for a short time, and from 2004 to 2006 Codey became a long-term acting governor due to Jim McGreevey's resignation.

name: new_jersey
sentence: A 2005 amendment to the state Constitution prevents the Senatorte President from becoming acting governor in the event of a permanent gubernatorial vacancy without giving up her or his seat in the state Senatorte.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Phil Murphy (D) is the governor.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The governor's mansion is Drumthwacket, located in Princeton.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Before 2010, New Jersey was one of the few states without a lieutenant governor.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Republican Kim Guadagno was elected the first lieutenant governor of New Jersey and took office on January 19, 2010.

name: new_jersey
sentence: She was elected on the Republican ticket with Governor-Elect Chris Christie in the November 2009 NJ gubernatorial election.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The position was created as the result of a Constitutional amendment to the New Jersey State Constitution passed by the voters on November 8, 2005, and effective as of January 17, 2006.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The current version of the New Jersey State Constitution was adopted in 1947.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It provides for a bicameral New Jersey Legislature, consisting of an upper house Senatorte of 40 members and a lower house General Assembly of 80 members.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Each of the 40 legislative districts elects one state senator and two Assembly members.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Assembly members are elected for a two-year term in all odd-numbered years; state senators are elected in the years ending in 1, 3, and 7 and thus serve either four- or two-year terms.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is one of only five states that elects its state officials in odd-numbered years.

name: new_jersey
sentence: (The others are Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi, and Virginia.)

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey holds elections for these offices every four years, in the year following each federal Presidential election year.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Thus, the last year when New Jersey elected a governor was 2017; the next gubernatorial election will occur in 2021.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The New Jersey Supreme Court consists of a chief justice and six associate justices.

name: new_jersey
sentence: All are appointed by the governor with the advice and consent of a majority of the membership of the state senate.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Justices serve an initial seven-year term, after which they can be reappointed to serve until age 70.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Most of the day-to-day work in the New Jersey courts is carried out in the Municipal Court, where simple traffic tickets, minor criminal offenses, and small civil matters are heard.

name: new_jersey
sentence: More serious criminal and civil cases are handled by the Superior Court for each county.

name: new_jersey
sentence: All Superior Court judges are appointed by the governor with the advice and consent of a majority of the membership of the state senate.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Each judge serves an initial seven-year term, after which he or she can be reappointed to serve until age 70.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey's judiciary is unusual in that it still has separate courts of law and equity, like its neighbor Delaware but unlike most other US states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The New Jersey Superior Court is divided into Law and Chancery Divisions at the trial level; the Law Division hears both criminal cases and civil lawsuits where the plaintiff's primary remedy is damages, while the Chancery Division hears family cases, civil suits where the plaintiff's primary remedy is equitable relief, and probate trials.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Superior Court also has an Appellate Division, which functions as the state's intermediate appellate court.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Superior Court judges are assigned to the Appellate Division by the Chief Justice.

name: new_jersey
sentence: There is also a Tax Court, which is a court of limited jurisdiction.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Tax Court judges hear appeals of tax decisions made by County Boards of Taxation.

name: new_jersey
sentence: They also hear appeals on decisions made by the director of the Division of Taxation on such matters as state income, sales and business taxes, and homestead rebates.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Appeals from Tax Court decisions are heard in the Appellate Division of Superior Court.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Tax Court judges are appointed by the governor for initial terms of seven years, and upon reappointment are granted tenure until they reach the mandatory retirement age of 70.

name: new_jersey
sentence: There are 12 Tax Court judgeships.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is divided into 21 counties

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was completely divided into counties by 1692

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is the only state in the nation where elected county officials are called "Freeholders", governing each county as part of its own Board of Chosen Freeholders.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The number of freeholders in each county is determined by referendum, and must consist of three, five, seven or nine members.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Depending on the county, the executive and legislative functions may be performed by the Board of Chosen Freeholders or split into separate branches of government.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 16 counties, members of the Board of Chosen Freeholders perform both legislative and executive functions on a commission basis, with each freeholder assigned responsibility for a department or group of departments.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the other five counties (Atlantic, Bergen, Essex, Hudson and Mercer), there is a directly elected County Executive who performs the executive functions while the Board of Chosen Freeholders retains a legislative and oversight role.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In counties without an Executive, a County Administrator (or County Manager) may be hired to perform day-to-day administration of county functions.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey currently has 565 municipalities; the number was 566 before Princeton Township and Princeton Borough merged to form the municipality of Princeton on January 1, 2013.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Unlike other states, all New Jersey land is part of a municipality.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 2008, Governor Jon Corzine proposed cutting state aid to all towns under 10,000 people, to encourage mergers to reduce administrative costs.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In May 2009, the Local Unit Alignment Reorganization and Consolidation Commission began a study of about 40 small communities in South Jersey to decide which ones might be good candidates for consolidation.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Starting in the 20th century, largely driven by reform-minded goals, a series of six modern forms of government was implemented.

name: new_jersey
sentence: This began with the Walsh Act, enacted in 1911 by the New Jersey Legislature, which provided for a three- or five-member commission elected on a non-partisan basis.

name: new_jersey
sentence: This was followed by the 1923 Municipal Manager Law, which offered a non-partisan council, provided for a weak mayor elected by and from the members of the council, and introduced a Council-manager government structure with an appointed manager responsible for day-to-day administration of municipal affairs.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Faulkner Act, originally enacted in 1950 and substantially amended in 1981, offers four basic plans: Mayor-Council, Council-Manager, Small Municipality, and Mayor-Council-Administrator.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The act provides many choices for communities with a preference for a strong executive and professional management of municipal affairs and offers great flexibility in allowing municipalities to select the characteristics of its government: the number of seats on the council; seats selected at-large, by wards, or through a combination of both; staggered or concurrent terms of office; and a mayor chosen by the council or elected directly by voters.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Most large municipalities and a majority of New Jersey's residents are governed by municipalities with Faulkner Act charters.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Municipalities can also formulate their own unique form of government and operate under a Special Charter with the approval of the New Jersey Legislature.

name: new_jersey
sentence: While municipalities retain their names derived from types of government, they may have changed to one of the modern forms of government, or further in the past to one of the other traditional forms, leading to municipalities with formal names quite baffling to the general public.

name: new_jersey
sentence: For example, though there are four municipalities that are officially of the village type, Loch Arbour is the only one remaining with the village form of government.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The other three villages—Ridgefield Park (now with a Walsh Act form), Ridgewood (now with a Faulkner Act Council-Manager charter) and South Orange (now operates under a Special Charter)—have all migrated to other non-village forms.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Socially, New Jersey is considered one of the more liberal states in the nation.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Polls indicate that 60% of the population are self-described as pro-choice, although a majority are opposed to late trimester and intact dilation and extraction and public funding of abortion.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In a 2009 Quinnipiac University Polling Institute poll, a plurality supported same-sex marriage 49% to 43% opposed, On October 18, 2013, the New Jersey Supreme Court rendered a provisional, unanimous (7–0) order authorizing same-sex marriage in the state, pending a legal appeal by Governor Chris Christie, who then withdrew this appeal hours after the inaugural same-sex marriages took place on October 21, 2013.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey also has some of the most stringent gun control laws in the US

name: new_jersey
sentence: These include bans on assault firearms, hollow-nose bullets and slingshots.

name: new_jersey
sentence: No gun offense in New Jersey is graded less than a felony.

name: new_jersey
sentence: BB guns and black-powder guns are all treated as modern firearms.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey does not recognize out-of-state gun licenses and aggressively enforces its own gun laws.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In past elections, New Jersey was a Republican bastion, but recently has become a Democratic stronghold.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Currently, New Jersey Democrats have majority control of both houses of the New Jersey Legislature (Senatorte, 26–14, and Assembly, 54–26), a 10–2 split of the state's twelve seats in the US House of Representatives, and both US Senatorte seats.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Although the Democratic Party is very successful statewide, the state has had Republican governors; from 1994 to 2002, Christine Todd Whitman won twice with 47% and 49% of the votes, respectively, and in the 2009 gubernatorial election, Republican Chris Christie defeated incumbent Democrat Jon Corzine with 48% of the vote.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the 2013 gubernatorial election, Christie won reelection with over 60% of the votes.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Because each candidate for lieutenant governor runs on the same ticket as the party's candidate for governor, the current governor and lieutenant governor are members of the Democratic Party.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The governor's appointments to cabinet and non-cabinet positions may be from either party; for instance, the attorney general is a Democrat.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In federal elections, the state leans heavily towards the Democratic Party.

name: new_jersey
sentence: For many years in the past, however, it was a Republican stronghold, having given comfortable margins of victory to the Republican candidate in the close elections of 1948, 1968, and 1976.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was a crucial swing state in the elections of 1960, 1968, and 1992.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The last elected Republican to hold a Senatorte seat from New Jersey was Clifford P. Case in 1979.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Newark Mayor Cory Booker was elected in October 2013 to join Robert Menendez to make New Jersey the first state with concurrent serving black and Latino US senators.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The state's Democratic strongholds include Camden County, Essex County (typically the state's most Democratic county—it includes Newark, the state's largest city), Hudson County (the second-strongest Democratic county, including Jersey City, the state's second-largest city); Mercer County (especially around Trenton and Princeton), Middlesex County, and Union County (including Elizabeth, the state's fourth-largest city).

name: new_jersey
sentence: The suburban northwestern and southeastern counties of the state are reliably Republican: Republicans have support along the coast in Ocean County and in the mountainous northwestern part of the state, especially Morris County, Sussex County, and Warren County.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Other suburban counties, especially Bergen County and Burlington County had the majority of votes go to the Democratic Party.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the 2008 election, President Barack Obama won New Jersey with approximately fifty-seven percent of the vote, compared to McCain's forty-one percent.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Independent candidate Ralph Nader garnered less than one percent of the vote.

name: new_jersey
sentence: About one-third of the state's counties are considered "swing" counties, but some go more one way than others.

name: new_jersey
sentence: For example, Salem County, the same is true with Passaic County, with a highly populated Hispanic Democratic south (including Paterson, the state's third-largest city) and a rural, Republican north; with the "swing" township of Wayne in the middle.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Other "swing" counties like Monmouth County, Somerset County, and Cape May County tend to go Republican, as they also have population in conservative areas, although Somerset has recently trended Democratic.

name: new_jersey
sentence: To be eligible to vote in a US election, all New Jerseyans are required to start their residency in the state 30 days prior to an election and register 21 days prior to election day.

name: new_jersey
sentence: On December 17, 2007, Governor Jon Corzine signed into law a bill that would eliminate the death penalty in New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is the first state to pass such legislation since Iowa and West Virginia eliminated executions in 1965.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Corzine also signed a bill that would downgrade the Death Row prisoners' sentences from "Death" to "Life in Prison with No Parole".

name: new_jersey
sentence: There is also a mineral museum Ogdensburg in Sussex County.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Visitors and residents take advantage of and contribute to performances at the numerous music, theater, and dance companies and venues located throughout the state, including:

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is the location of most of the boardwalks in the US, with nearly every town and city along the Jersey Shore area each having a boardwalk with various attractions, entertainment, shopping, dining, miniature golf, arcades, water parks with various water rides, including water slides, lazy rivers, wave pools, etc., and amusement parks hosting rides and attractions including roller coasters, carousels, Ferris wheels, bumper cars, teacups, etc.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico (Spanish: Nuevo México [ˈnweβo ˈmexiko] (listen); Navajo: Yootó Hahoodzo [joː˩tʰo˥ ha˩hoː˩tso˩]) is a state in the Southwestern region of the United States of America; its capital is Santa Fe, which was founded in 1610 as capital of Nuevo México (itself established as a province of New Spain in 1598), while its largest city is Albuquerque with its accompanying metropolitan area.

name: new_mexico
sentence: It is one of the Mountain States and shares the Four Corners region with Utah, Colorado, and Arizona.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico is also bordered by the state of Texas to the east-southeast, Oklahoma to the northeast, and the Mexican states of Chihuahua to the south and Sonora to the southwest.

name: new_mexico
sentence: With an estimated population of 2,096,829 as of the July 1, 2019, US Census Bureau estimate, New Mexico is the 36th largest state by population.

name: new_mexico
sentence: With a total area of 121,590 sq mi (314,900 km2), it is the fifth-largest and sixth-least densely populated of the 50 states.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Due to their geographic locations, northern and eastern New Mexico exhibit a colder, alpine climate, while western and southern New Mexico exhibit a warmer, arid climate.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The economy of New Mexico is dependent on oil drilling, mineral extraction, dryland farming, cattle ranching, acequia and landrace agriculture, lumber milling, retail trade, scientific research laboratories, technological development, as well as the arts, especially textiles and visual arts.

name: new_mexico
sentence: As of 2018, its total gross domestic product (GDP) was $101 billion with a GDP per capita of $45,465.

name: new_mexico
sentence: State tax policy results in low to moderate taxation of resident personal income compared to most US states, with special consideration for military personnel, and gives tax credits and exemptions to favorable industries.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Because of this, its film industry has grown and contributed $1.23 billion to its overall economy.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Due to its large area and economic climate, New Mexico has a large US military presence marked notably with the White Sands Missile Range.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Various US national security agencies base their research and testing arms in New Mexico, such as the Sandia and Los Alamos National Laboratories.

name: new_mexico
sentence: During the 1940s, Project Y of the Manhattan Project developed and built the country's first atomic bomb and nuclear test, Trinity.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Inhabited by Native Americans for many thousands of years before European exploration, it was colonized by the Spanish in 1598 as part of the Imperial Spanish viceroyalty of New Spain.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In 1563, it was named Nuevo México after the Aztec Valley of Mexico by Spanish settlers, more than 250 years before the establishment and naming of the present-day country of Mexico; thus, the present-day state of New Mexico was not named after the country today known as Mexico.

name: new_mexico
sentence: After Mexican independence in 1821, New Mexico became a Mexican territory with considerable autonomy.

name: new_mexico
sentence: This autonomy was threatened, however, by the centralizing tendencies of the Mexican government from the 1830s onward, with rising tensions eventually leading to the Revolt of 1837.

name: new_mexico
sentence: At the same time, the region became more economically dependent on the United States.

name: new_mexico
sentence: At the conclusion of the Mexican–American War in 1848, the United States annexed New Mexico as the US New Mexico Territory.

name: new_mexico
sentence: It was admitted to the Union as the 47th state on January 6, 1912.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Its history has given New Mexico the highest percentage of Hispanic and Latino Americans, and the second-highest percentage of Native Americans as a population proportion (after Alaska).

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico is home to part of the Navajo Nation, 19 federally recognized Pueblo communities of Puebloan peoples, and three different federally recognized Apache tribes.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In prehistoric times, the area was home to Ancestral Puebloans, Mogollon, and the modern extant Comanche and Utes inhabited the state.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The largest Hispanic and Latino groups represented include the Hispanos of New Mexico, Chicanos, and Mexicans.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The New Mexican flag features the state's Spanish origins with the same scarlet and gold coloration as Spain's Cross of Burgundy, along with the ancient sun symbol of the Zia, a Puebloan tribe.

name: new_mexico
sentence: These indigenous, Hispanic, Mexican, Latin, and American frontier roots are reflected in the eponymous New Mexican cuisine and the New Mexico music genre.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico received its name long before the present-day nation of Mexico won independence from Spain and adopted that name in 1821.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Though the name "Mexico" itself derives from Nahuatl, and in that language it originally referred to the heartland of the Empire of the Mexicas (Aztec Empire) in the Valley of Mexico far from the area of New Mexico, Spanish explorers also used the term "Mexico" to name the region of New Mexico (Nuevo México in Spanish) in 1563.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In 1581, the Chamuscado and Rodríguez Expedition named the region north of the Rio Grande "San Felipe del Nuevo México".

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Spaniards had hoped to find wealthy indigenous Mexica (Aztec) cultures there similar to those of the Aztec (Mexica) Empire of the Valley of Mexico.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The indigenous cultures of New Mexico, however, proved to be unrelated to the Mexicas, and they were not wealthy, but the name persisted.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Before statehood, the name "New Mexico" applied to various configurations of a former US New Mexico Territory and, even prior to its former Mexican territorial status, a former provincial kingdom of New Spain called Nuevo México, all in the same general area, but of varying extensions.

name: new_mexico
sentence: With a total area of 121,590 square miles (314,900 km2), New Mexico is the fifth-largest state.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico's eastern border lies along 103°W longitude with the state of Oklahoma, and (due to a 19th-century surveying error) 2.2 miles (3.5 kilometres) west of 103°W longitude with Texas.

name: new_mexico
sentence: On the southern border, Texas makes up the eastern two-thirds, while the Mexican states of Chihuahua and Sonora make up the western third, with Chihuahua making up about 90% of that.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The western border with Arizona runs along the 109° 03'W longitude.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The southwestern corner of the state is known as the Bootheel.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The 37°N parallel forms the northern boundary with Colorado.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The states of New Mexico, Colorado, Arizona, and Utah come together at the Four Corners in New Mexico's northwestern corner.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Its surface water area is about 292 square miles (760 km2).

name: new_mexico
sentence: The New Mexican landscape ranges from wide, rose-colored deserts to broken mesas to high, snow-capped peaks.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Despite New Mexico's arid image, heavily forested mountain wildernesses cover a significant portion of the state, especially towards the north.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Sangre de Cristo Mountains, the southernmost part of the Rocky Mountains, run roughly north–south along the east side of the Rio Grande in the rugged, pastoral north.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The most important of New Mexico's rivers are the Rio Grande, Pecos, Canadian, San Juan, and Gila.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Rio Grande is tied for the fourth-longest river in the United States.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The US government protects millions of acres of New Mexico as national forests, including:

name: new_mexico
sentence: Areas managed by the National Park Service include:

name: new_mexico
sentence: Areas managed by the New Mexico State Parks Division:

name: new_mexico
sentence: Visitors also frequent the surviving native pueblos of New Mexico.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Tourists visiting these sites bring significant money to the state.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Other areas of geographical and scenic interest include Kasha-Katuwe Tent Rocks National Monument and the Gila Wilderness in the southwest of the state.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico's climate is generally semiarid to arid, though areas of continental and alpine climates exist, and its territory is mostly covered by mountains, high plains, and desert.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Great Plains (High Plains) are in eastern New Mexico, similar to the Colorado high plains in eastern Colorado.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The two states share similar terrain, with both having plains, mountains, basins, mesas, and desert lands.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico's statewide average precipitation is 12.9 inches (330 mm) a year, with average monthly amounts peaking in the summer, as at Albuquerque, and Las Cruces in the south.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The average annual temperatures can range from 65 °F (18 °C) in the southeast to below 40 °F (4 °C) in the northern mountains.

name: new_mexico
sentence: During the summer, daytime temperatures can often exceed 100 °F (38 °C) at elevations below 5,000 feet (1,500 m), the average high temperature in July ranges from 99 °F (37 °C) at the lower elevations down to 78 °F (26 °C) at the higher elevations.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In the colder months of November to March, many cities in New Mexico can have nighttime temperature lows in the teens above zero, or lower.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The highest temperature recorded in New Mexico was 122 °F (50 °C) at the Waste Isolation Pilot Plant (WIPP) near Loving on June 27, 1994, and the lowest recorded temperature is −50 °F (−46 °C) at Gavilan (near Lindrith) on February 1, 1951.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Astronomical observatories in New Mexico take advantage of unusually clear skies, including the Apache Point Observatory, the Very Large Array, the Magdalena Ridge Observatory, and others.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico has five unique floristic zones, providing diverse sets of habitats for many plants and animals.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Llano Estacado (or Shortgrass Prairie) in the eastern part of the state is characterized by sod-forming short grasses such as blue grama, and it used to sustain bison.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Chihuahuan Desert extends through the south of the state and is characterized by shrubby creosote.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Colorado Plateau in the northwest corner of New Mexico is high desert with cold winters, and is characterized by sagebrush, shadescale, greasewood, and other plants adapted to the saline and seleniferous soil.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The mountainous Mogollon Plateau in the west-central of the state and southern Rocky Mountains in the north-central, have a wide range in elevation (4,000 to 13,000 ft or 1,200 to 4,000 m), with vegetation types corresponding to elevation gradients, such as piñon-juniper woodlands near the base, through evergreen conifers, spruce-fir and aspen forests, Krummholz, and alpine tundra.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Apachian zone tucked into the southwestern bootheel of the state has high-calcium soil, oak woodlands, and Arizona cypress, and other plants that are not found in other parts of the state.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Some of the native wildlife includes black bears, bighorn sheep, bobcats, cougars, coyotes, deer, elk, jackrabbits, kangaroo rats, javelina, porcupines, pronghorn antelope, roadrunners, western diamondbacks, wild turkeys, and the endangered Mexican gray wolf and Rio Grande silvery minnow.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In January 2016, New Mexico sued the United States Environmental Protection Agency over negligence after the 2015 Gold King Mine waste water spill.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The spill had caused heavy metals such as cadmium and lead and toxins such as arsenic to flow into the Animas River, polluting water basins of several states

name: new_mexico
sentence: The first known inhabitants of New Mexico were members of the Clovis culture of Paleo-Indians.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Later inhabitants include American Indians of the Mogollon and Ancestral Pueblo peoples cultures.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Francisco Vásquez de Coronado assembled an enormous expedition at Compostela in 1540–1542 to explore and find the mythical Seven Golden Cities of Cibola as described by Fray Marcos de Niza.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The name New Mexico was first used by a seeker of gold mines named Francisco de Ibarra, who explored far to the north of New Spain in 1563 and reported his findings as being in "a New Mexico".

name: new_mexico
sentence: Juan de Oñate officially established the name when he was appointed the first governor of the new Province of New Mexico in 1598.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The same year, he founded the San Juan de los Caballeros (modern Española, New Mexico) capital at San Gabriel de Yungue-Ouinge (near modern Ohkay Owingeh, New Mexico), the first permanent European settlement in New Mexico, on the Rio Grande near Ohkay Owingeh Pueblo.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Oñate extended El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro, Royal Road of the Interior, by 700 miles (1,100 km) from Santa Bárbara, Chihuahua, to his remote colony.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The settlement of La Villa Real de la Santa Fe de San Francisco de Asís was established as a more permanent capital at the foot of the Sangre de Cristo Mountains in 1610.

name: new_mexico
sentence: As a result of the Pueblo Revolt, the only successful revolt against European expansion by Native Americans, these early cities were occupied by the Puebloan peoples until the Spanish returned with an offer of better cultural and religious liberties for the Pueblos.

name: new_mexico
sentence: After the death of the Pueblo leader Popé, Diego de Vargas restored the area to Spanish rule.

name: new_mexico
sentence: While developing Santa Fe as a trade center, the returning settlers founded Albuquerque in 1706 from existing surrounding communities, naming it for the viceroy of New Spain, Francisco Fernández de la Cueva, 10th Duke of Alburquerque.

name: new_mexico
sentence: As a part of New Spain, the claims for the province of New Mexico passed to independent Mexico in 1821 following the Mexican War of Independence.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Republic of Texas claimed the portion east of the Rio Grande when it seceded from Mexico in 1836 when it incorrectly assumed the older Hispanic settlements of the upper Rio Grande were the same as the newly established Mexican settlements of Texas.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Texas's only attempt to establish a presence or control in the claimed territory was the failed Texan Santa Fe Expedition.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Their entire army was captured and jailed by the Hispanic New Mexico militia.

name: new_mexico
sentence: At the turn of the 19th century, the extreme northeastern part of New Mexico, north of the Canadian River and east of the Sangre de Cristo Mountains was still claimed by France, which sold it in 1803 as part of the Louisiana Purchase.

name: new_mexico
sentence: When the Louisiana Territory was admitted as a state in 1812, the US reclassified it as part of the Missouri Territory.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The region (along with territory that makes up present-day southeastern Colorado, the Texas and Oklahoma Panhandles, and southwestern Kansas) was ceded to Spain under the Adams-Onis Treaty in 1819.

name: new_mexico
sentence: By 1800, the population of New Mexico had reached 25,000.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Following the victory of the United States in the Mexican–American War (1846–48), under the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo in 1848, Mexico ceded its northern holdings including the territories of California, Texas, and New Mexico, to the United States of America.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The United States vowed to accept the residents' claims to their lands and to accept them as full citizens with rights of suffrage.

name: new_mexico
sentence: After Texas was admitted as a state to the Union, it continued to claim a northeastern portion of New Mexico.

name: new_mexico
sentence: It was forced by the US government to drop these claims, in the Compromise of 1850, Texas ceded these claims to the United States of the area in New Mexico lying east of the Rio Grande, in exchange for $10 million from the federal government.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Congress established the separate New Mexico Territory in September 1850.

name: new_mexico
sentence: It included most of the present-day states of Arizona and New Mexico, and part of Colorado.

name: new_mexico
sentence: When the boundary was fixed, a surveyor's error awarded the Permian Basin to the State of Texas.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico dropped its claims to the Permian in a bid to gain statehood in 1911.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In 1853, the United States acquired the mostly desert southwestern bootheel of the state and southern Arizona south of the Gila River in the Gadsden Purchase.

name: new_mexico
sentence: It wanted to control lands needed for the right-of-way to encourage construction of a transcontinental railroad.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico played a role in the Trans-Mississippi Theater of the American Civil War.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Both Confederate and Union governments claimed ownership and territorial rights over New Mexico Territory.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In 1861, the Confederacy claimed the southern tract as its own Arizona Territory and waged the ambitious New Mexico Campaign in an attempt to control the American Southwest and open up access to Union California.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Confederate power in the New Mexico Territory was effectively broken after the Battle of Glorieta Pass in 1862.

name: new_mexico
sentence: However, the Confederate territorial government continued to operate out of Texas, and Confederate troops marched under the Arizona flag until the end of the war.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Additionally, more than 8,000 men from New Mexico Territory served in the Union Army.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In the late 19th century, the majority of officially European-descended residents in New Mexico were ethnic Mexicans, many of whom had deep roots in the area from early Spanish colonial times.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Politically, they still controlled most of the town and county offices through area elections, and wealthy sheepherder families commanded considerable influence.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Anglo-Americans tended to have more ties to the territorial governor and judges, who were appointed by officials out of the region.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The two groups struggled for power and the future of the territory.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Anglo minority was "outnumbered, but well-organized and growing".

name: new_mexico
sentence: Anglo-Americans made distinctions between the wealthy Mexicans and poor, ill-educated laborers.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The United States Congress admitted New Mexico as the 47th state on January 6, 1912.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico was eligible for statehood 60 years earlier but was kept out of the union for more than a half-century because it had a majority "alien" (i.e.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Mexican-American) population.

name: new_mexico
sentence: European-American settlers in the state had an uneasy relationship with the large Native American tribes, most of whose members lived on reservations at the beginning of the 20th century.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Although Congress passed a law in 1924 that granted all Native Americans US citizenship, as well as the right to vote in federal and state elections, New Mexico was among several states with Jim Crow laws, e.g.

name: new_mexico
sentence: those who do not pay taxes cannot vote.

name: new_mexico
sentence: A major oil discovery in 1928 brought wealth to the state, especially Lea County and the town of Hobbs.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The town was named after James Hobbs, a homesteader there in 1907.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Midwest State No.

name: new_mexico
sentence: 1 well, begun in late 1927 with a standard cable-tool drilling rig, revealed the first signs of oil from the Hobbs field on June 13, 1928.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Drilled to 4,330 feet and completed a few months later, the well-produced 700 barrels of oil per day on state land.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Midwest Refining Company's Hobbs well-produced oil until 2002.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The New Mexico Bureau of Mines and Mineral Resources called it "the most important single discovery of oil in New Mexico's history".

name: new_mexico
sentence: During World War II, the first atomic bombs were designed and manufactured at Los Alamos, a site developed by the federal government specifically to support a high-intensity scientific effort to rapidly complete research and testing of this weapon.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The first bomb was tested at Trinity site in the desert between Socorro and Alamogordo on what is now White Sands Missile Range.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Native Americans from New Mexico fought for the United States in both the First and Second World Wars.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Veterans were disappointed to return and find their civil rights limited by state discrimination.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In Arizona and New Mexico, veterans challenged state laws or practices prohibiting them from voting.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In 1948, after veteran Miguel Trujillo, Sr. of Isleta Pueblo was told by the county registrar that he could not register to vote, he filed suit against the county in federal district court.

name: new_mexico
sentence: A three-judge panel overturned as unconstitutional New Mexico's provisions that Indians who did not pay taxes (and could not document if they had paid taxes) could not vote.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Judge Phillips wrote:

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico has received large amounts of federal government spending on major military and research institutions in the state.

name: new_mexico
sentence: It is home to three Air Force bases, White Sands Missile Range, and the federal research laboratories Los Alamos National Laboratory and Sandia National Laboratories.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The state's population grew rapidly after World War II, growing from 531,818 in 1940 to 1,819,046 in 2000.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Both residents and businesses moved to the state

name: new_mexico
sentence: On May 22, 1957, a B-36 accidentally dropped a nuclear bomb 4.5 miles from the control tower while landing at Kirtland Air Force Base.

name: new_mexico
sentence: (Only its conventional "trigger" detonated.)

name: new_mexico
sentence: In the late 20th century, Native Americans were authorized by federal law to establish gaming casinos on their reservations under certain conditions, in states which had authorized such gaming.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Such facilities have helped tribes close to population centers to generate revenues for reinvestment in economic development and welfare of their peoples.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In the 21st century, employment growth areas in New Mexico include electronic circuitry, scientific research, call centers, and Indian casinos.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The United States Census Bureau estimates that the population of New Mexico was 2,096,829 on July 1, 2019, a 1.83% increase since the 2010 census.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The 2000 census recorded the population of New Mexico to be 1,819,046; ten years later it was 2,059,179—an 11.7% increase.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Of the people residing in New Mexico 51.4% were born there; 37.9% were born in another state; 1.1% were born in Puerto Rico, US Island areas, or abroad to American parent(s); and 9.7% were foreign born.

name: new_mexico
sentence: As of May 1, 2010, 7.5% of New Mexico's population was reported as under 5 years of age, 25% under 18, and 13% were 65 or older.

name: new_mexico
sentence: As of 2000, 8% of the residents of the state were foreign-born.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Among US states, New Mexico has the highest percentage of Hispanic ancestry, at 47% (as of July 1, 2012).

name: new_mexico
sentence: This classification covers people of very different cultures and histories, including descendants of Spanish colonists with deep roots in the region, and recent immigrants from a variety of nations in Latin America, each with their own cultures.

name: new_mexico
sentence: According to the United States Census Bureau Model-based Small Area Income and Poverty Estimates, the number of persons in poverty has increased to 400,779 (19.8% of the population) persons in 2010 from 2000.

name: new_mexico
sentence: At that time, the estimated number of persons in poverty was recorded at 309,193 (17.3% of the population).

name: new_mexico
sentence: The latest available data for 2014 estimate the number of persons in poverty at 420,388 (20.6% of the population).

name: new_mexico
sentence: Note: Births in table do not add up, because Hispanics are counted both by their ethnicity and by their race, giving a higher overall number.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico is a majority-minority state.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The US Census Bureau estimated that 48% of the total 2015 population was Hispanic or Latino of any race, the highest of any state.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The majority of Hispanics in New Mexico claim to be descendants of Spanish colonists who settled here during the 16th, 17th, and 18th centuries.

name: new_mexico
sentence: They speak New Mexican Spanish or English at home.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The state also has a large Native American population, second in percentage behind that of Alaska.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The 2018 racial composition of the population was estimated to be:

name: new_mexico
sentence: According to the United States Census Bureau, 1.5% of the population identifies as multiracial/mixed-race, a population larger than both the Asian and NHPI population groups.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In 2008, New Mexico had the highest percentage (47%) of Hispanics (of any race) of any state, with 83% native-born and 17% foreign-born.

name: new_mexico
sentence: According to the 2000 United States Census,the most commonly claimed ancestry groups in New Mexico were:

name: new_mexico
sentence: According to the 2010 US Census, 28.45% of the population age 5 and older speak Spanish at home, while 3.50% speak Navajo.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Some speakers of New Mexican Spanish are descendants of Spanish settlers who arrived in New Mexico in the 16th, 17th, and 18th centuries.

name: new_mexico
sentence: While it is a common folk belief that New Mexican Spanish is an archaic form of 17th-century Castilian Spanish, and archaisms do exist, research reveals that traditional New Mexican Spanish "is neither more Iberian nor more archaic than other New World Spanishes".

name: new_mexico
sentence: Besides Navajo, which is also spoken in Arizona, a few other Native American languages are spoken by smaller groups in New Mexico, most of which are only spoken in the state.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Native New Mexican languages include Mescalero Apache, Jicarilla Apache, Tewa, Southern Tiwa, Northern Tiwa, Towa, Keres (Eastern and Western), and Zuni.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Mescalero and Jicarilla Apache are closely related Southern Athabaskan languages, and both are also related to Navajo.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Tewa, the Tiwa languages, and Towa belong to the Kiowa-Tanoan language family, and thus all descend from a common ancestor.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Keres and Zuni are language isolates, and have no relatives outside of New Mexico.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The original state constitution of 1912 provided for a bilingual government with laws being published in both English and Spanish; this requirement was renewed twice, in 1931 and 1943.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Nonetheless, the constitution does not declare any language as "official".

name: new_mexico
sentence: While Spanish was permitted in the legislature until 1935, all state officials are required to have a good knowledge of English.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Cobarrubias and Fishman therefore argue that New Mexico cannot be considered a bilingual state as not all laws are published in both languages.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Others, such as Juan Perea, claim that the state was officially bilingual until 1953.

name: new_mexico
sentence: With regard to the judiciary, witnesses have the right to testify in either of the two languages, and monolingual speakers of Spanish have the same right to be considered for jury duty as do speakers of English.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In public education, the state has the constitutional obligation to provide bilingual education and Spanish-speaking instructors in school districts where the majority of students are Hispanophone.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In 1995, the state adopted an official bilingual song, "New Mexico – Mi Lindo Nuevo México".

name: new_mexico
sentence: In 1989, New Mexico became the first state to officially adopt the English Plus resolution, and in 2008, the first to officially adopt a Navajo textbook for use in public schools.

name: new_mexico
sentence: According to Association of Religion Data Archives (ARDA), the largest denominations in 2010 were the Catholic Church with 684,941; the Southern Baptist Convention with 113,452; The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints with 67,637, and the United Methodist Church with 36,424 adherents.

name: new_mexico
sentence: According to a 2008 survey by the Pew Research Center, the most common self-reported religious affiliation of New Mexico residents are mentioned in reference.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Within the hierarchy of the Catholic Church, New Mexico belongs to the Ecclesiastical Province of Santa Fe.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico has three dioceses, one of which is an archdiocese:Archdiocese of Santa Fe,Diocese of Gallup,Diocese of Las Cruces.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Oil and gas production, tourism, and federal government spending are important drivers of the state economy.

name: new_mexico
sentence: State government has an elaborate system of tax credits and technical assistance to promote job growth and business investment, especially in new technologies.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In 2010, New Mexico's gross domestic product was $80 billion, and an estimated $85 billion for 2013.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In 2007, the per capita personal income was $31,474 (ranked 43rd in the nation).

name: new_mexico
sentence: In 2005, the percentage of persons below the poverty level was 18.4%.The New Mexico Tourism Department estimates that in Fiscal Year 2006, the travel industry in New Mexico generated expenditures of $6.5 billion.

name: new_mexico
sentence: As of April 2012, the state's unemployment rate was 7.2%.

name: new_mexico
sentence: During the late-2000s recession, New Mexico's unemployment rate peaked at 8.0% for the period June–October 2010.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico is the third-largest crude oil and ninth-largest natural gas producer in the United States.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Permian and San Juan Basins, which are located partly in New Mexico, account for some of these natural resources.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In 2000 the value of oil and gas produced was $8.2 billion, and in 2006, New Mexico accounted for 3.4% of the crude oil, 8.5% of the dry natural gas, and 10.2% of the natural gas liquids produced in the United States.

name: new_mexico
sentence: However, the boom in hydraulic fracturing and horizontal drilling beginning in the mid-2010s led to a large increase in the production of crude oil from the Permian Basin and other US sources; these developments allowed the United States to again become the world's largest producer of crude oil in 2018.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico's oil and gas operations contribute to the state's above-average release of the greenhouse gas methane, including from a national methane hot spot in the Four Corners area.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Federal government spending is a major driver of the New Mexico economy.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In 2005, the federal government spent $2.03 on New Mexico for every dollar of tax revenue collected from the state.

name: new_mexico
sentence: This rate was higher than any other state in the Union.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico is currently the second most dependent tax dollar state.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Many of the federal jobs relate to the military; the state hosts three air force bases (Kirtland Air Force Base, Holloman Air Force Base, and Cannon Air Force Base); a testing range (White Sands Missile Range); and an army proving ground (Fort Bliss's McGregor Range).

name: new_mexico
sentence: A May 2005 estimate by New Mexico State University is that 11.65% of the state's total employment arises directly or indirectly from military spending.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Other federal installations include the technology labs of Los Alamos National Laboratory and Sandia National Laboratories.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico provides a number of economic incentives to businesses operating in the state, including various types of tax credits and tax exemptions.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Most of the incentives are based on job creation.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico law allows governments to provide land, buildings, and infrastructure to businesses to promote job creation.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Several municipalities have imposed an Economic Development Gross Receipts Tax (a form of Municipal Infrastructure GRT) that is used to pay for these infrastructure improvements and for marketing their areas.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The state provides financial incentives for film production.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The New Mexico Film Office estimated at the end of 2007 that the incentive program had brought more than 85 film projects to the state since 2003 and had added $1.2 billion to the economy.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Since 2008, personal income tax rates for New Mexico have ranged from 1.7% to 4.9%, within four income brackets.

name: new_mexico
sentence: As of 2007, active-duty military salaries are exempt from state income tax.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico is one of the largest tax havens in the US, offering numerous economic incentives and tax breaks on personal and corporate income.

name: new_mexico
sentence: It does not have inheritance tax, estate tax, or sales taxes.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico imposes a Gross Receipts Tax (GRT) on many transactions, which may even include some governmental receipts.

name: new_mexico
sentence: This resembles a sales tax but, unlike the sales taxes in many states, it applies to services as well as tangible goods.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Normally, the provider or seller passes the tax on to the purchaser, however legal incidence and burden apply to the business, as an excise tax.

name: new_mexico
sentence: GRT is imposed by the state and there may an additional locality component to produce a total tax rate.

name: new_mexico
sentence: As of July 1, 2013 the combined tax rate ranged from 5.125% to 8.6875%.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Property tax is imposed on real property by the state, by counties, and by school districts.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In general, personal-use personal property is not subject to property taxation.

name: new_mexico
sentence: On the other hand, property tax is levied on most business-use personal property.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The taxable value of property is 1/3 of the assessed value.

name: new_mexico
sentence: A tax rate of about 30 mills is applied to the taxable value, resulting in an effective tax rate of about 1%.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In the 2005 tax year, the average millage was about 26.47 for residential property, and 29.80 for non-residential property.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Assessed values of residences cannot be increased by more than 3% per year unless the residence is remodeled or sold.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Property tax deductions are available for military veterans and heads of household.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico has long been an important corridor for trade and migration.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The builders of the ruins at Chaco Canyon also created a radiating network of roads from the mysterious settlement.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Chaco Canyon's trade function shifted to Casas Grandes in the present-day Mexican state of Chihuahua, however, north–south trade continued.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The pre-Columbian trade with Mesoamerican cultures included northbound exotic birds, seashells and copper.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Turquoise, pottery, and salt were some of the goods transported south along the Rio Grande.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Present-day New Mexico's pre-Columbian trade is especially remarkable for being undertaken on foot.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The north–south trade route later became a path for colonists with horses arriving from New Spain as well as trade and communication.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The route was called El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Santa Fe Trail was the 19th-century territory's vital commercial and military highway link to the Eastern United States.

name: new_mexico
sentence: All with termini in Northern New Mexico, the Camino Real, the Santa Fe Trail and the Old Spanish Trail are all recognized as National Historic Trails.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico's latitude and low passes made it an attractive east–west transportation corridor.

name: new_mexico
sentence: As a territory, the Gadsden Purchase increased New Mexico's land area for the purpose of the constructing a southern transcontinental railroad, that of the Southern Pacific Railroad.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Another transcontinental railroad was completed by the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The railroads essentially replaced the earlier trails but brought on a population boom.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Early transcontinental auto trails later crossed the state bringing more migrants.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Railroads were later supplemented or replaced by a system of highways and airports.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Today, New Mexico's Interstate Highways approximate the earlier land routes of the Camino Real, the Santa Fe Trail and the transcontinental railroads.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico has only three Interstate Highways.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In Albuquerque, I-25 and I-40 meet at a stack interchange called The Big I.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Interstate 10 travels in the southwest portion of New Mexico starting from the Arizona stateline near Lordsburg to the area in between Las Cruces and Anthony, near El Paso, Texas.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Interstate 25 is a major north–south interstate highway starting from Las Cruces to the Colorado stateline near Raton.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Interstate 40 is a major east–west interstate highway starting from the Arizona stateline west of Gallup to the Texas stateline east from Tucumcari.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico currently has 15 United States Highways.

name: new_mexico
sentence: This includes US 54, US 56, US 60, US 62, US 64, US 70, US 82, US 84, US 87, US 160, US 180, US 285, US 380, US 491, and US 550.

name: new_mexico
sentence: US 66, The Mother Road, was replaced by I-40 in 1985.

name: new_mexico
sentence: US 85 is currently unsigned by the NMDOT, but the AASHTO still recognize it.

name: new_mexico
sentence: It runs in the same trace with I-10 and I-25.

name: new_mexico
sentence: US 666, The Devils Highway, was replaced by US 491 in 2003 because the number "666" is the "Number of the Beast".

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico has had a problem with drunk driving, but that has lessened.

name: new_mexico
sentence: According to the Los Angeles Times, for years the state had the highest alcohol-related crash rates in the US, but ranked 25th in alcohol-related fatal crash rates, as of July 2009.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico had 59,927 route miles of highway as of 2000, of which 7,037 receive federal aid.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In that same year there were 1,003 miles (1,614 km) of freeways, of which a thousand were the route miles of Interstate Highways 10, 25 and 40.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The former number has increased with the upgrading of roads near Pojoaque, Santa Fe and Las Cruces to freeways.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The highway traffic fatality rate was 1.9 fatalities per million miles traveled in 2000, the 13th highest rate among US states.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Notable bridges include the Rio Grande Gorge Bridge near Taos.

name: new_mexico
sentence: As of 2001, 703 highway bridges, or one percent, were declared "structurally deficient" or "structurally obsolete".

name: new_mexico
sentence: Rural and intercity public transportation by road is provided by Americanos USA, LLC, Greyhound Lines and several government operators.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The New Mexico Rail Runner Express is a commuter rail system serving the metropolitan area of Albuquerque, New Mexico.

name: new_mexico
sentence: It began operation on July 14, 2006.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The system runs from Belen to downtown Santa Fe.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Larger cities in New Mexico typically have some form of public transportation by road

name: new_mexico
sentence: There were 2,354 route miles of railroads in the year 2000; this number increased with the opening of the Rail Runner's extension to Santa Fe.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In addition to local railroads and other tourist lines, the state jointly owns and operates a heritage narrow-gauge steam railroad, the Cumbres and Toltec Scenic Railway, with the state of Colorado.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Narrow gauge railroads once connected many communities in the northern part of the state, from Farmington to Santa Fe.

name: new_mexico
sentence: No fewer than 100 railroads of various names and lineage have operated in the jurisdiction at some point.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico's rail transportation system reached its height in terms of length following admission as a state

name: new_mexico
sentence: Railroad surveyors arrived in New Mexico in the 1850s.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The first railroads incorporated in 1869.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The first operational railroad, the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railway (ATSF), entered the territory by way of the lucrative and contested Raton Pass in 1878.

name: new_mexico
sentence: It eventually reached El Paso, Texas in 1881 and with the Southern Pacific Railroad created the nation's second transcontinental railroad with a junction at Deming.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Southern Pacific Railroad entered the territory from the Territory of Arizona in 1880.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Denver & Rio Grande Railway, who would generally use narrow gauge equipment in New Mexico, entered the territory from Colorado and began service to Española on December 31, 1880.

name: new_mexico
sentence: These first railroads were built as long-distance corridors, later railroad construction also targeted resource extraction.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico is served by two class I railroads, the BNSF Railway and the Union Pacific Railroad.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Combined, they operate 2,200 route miles of railway in the state.

name: new_mexico
sentence: A commuter rail operation, the New Mexico Rail Runner Express, connects the state's capital, its largest city, and other communities.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The privately operated state owned railroad began operations in July 2006.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The BNSF Railway's entire line from Belen to Raton, New Mexico was sold to the state, partially for the construction of phase II of this operation, which opened in December 2008.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Phase II of Rail Runner extended the line northward to Santa Fe from the Sandoval County station, the northernmost station under Phase I service.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The service now connects Santa Fe, Sandoval, Bernalillo, and Valencia counties.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The trains connect Albuquerque's population base and central business district to downtown Santa Fe with up to eight roundtrips in a day.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The section of the line running south to Belen is served less frequently.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Rail Runner operates scheduled service seven days per week.

name: new_mexico
sentence: With the rise of rail transportation many settlements grew or were founded and the territory became a tourist destination.

name: new_mexico
sentence: As early as 1878, the ATSF promoted tourism in the region with emphasis on Native American imagery.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Named trains often reflected the territory they traveled: Super Chief, the streamlined successor to the Chief; Navajo, an early transcontinental tourist train; and Cavern, a through car operation connecting Clovis and Carlsbad (by the early 1950s as train 23–24), were some of the named passenger trains of the ATSF that connoted New Mexico.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Passenger train service once connected nine of New Mexico's present ten most populous cities (the exception is Rio Rancho), while today passenger train service connects two: Albuquerque and Santa Fe.

name: new_mexico
sentence: With the decline of most intercity rail service in the United States in the late 1960s, New Mexico was left with minimal services.

name: new_mexico
sentence: No less than six daily long-distance roundtrip trains supplemented by many branch line and local trains served New Mexico in the early 1960s.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Declines in passenger revenue, but not necessarily ridership, prompted many railroads to turn over their passenger services in truncated form to Amtrak, a state owned enterprise.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Amtrak, also known as the National Passenger Railroad Corporation, began operating the two extant long-distance routes in May 1971.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Resurrection of passenger rail service from Denver to El Paso, a route once plied in part by the ATSF's El Pasoan, has been proposed over the years.

name: new_mexico
sentence: As early as the 1980s, former Governor Toney Anaya proposed building a high-speed rail line connecting the two cities with New Mexico's major cities.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Front Range Commuter Rail is a project to connect Wyoming and New Mexico with high-speed rail.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Amtrak's Southwest Chief passes through daily at stations in Gallup, Albuquerque, Lamy, Las Vegas, and Raton, offering connections to Los Angeles, Chicago and intermediate points.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Southwest Chief is a fast Amtrak long-distance train, being permitted a maximum speed of 90 mph (140 km/h) in various places on the tracks of the BNSF Railway.

name: new_mexico
sentence: It also operates on New Mexico Rail Runner Express trackage.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Southwest Chief is the successor to the Super Chief and El Capitan.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The streamliner Super Chief, a favorite of early Hollywood stars, was one of the most famous named trains in the United States and one of the most esteemed for its luxury and exoticness—train cars were named for regional Native American tribes and outfitted with the artwork of many local artists—but also for its speed: as few as 39 hours 45 minutes westbound.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Sunset Limited makes stops three times a week in both directions at Lordsburg, and Deming, serving Los Angeles, New Orleans and intermediate points.

name: new_mexico
