sentence: The Sunset Limited is the successor to the Southern Pacific Railroad's train of the same name and operates exclusively on Union Pacific trackage in New Mexico.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Albuquerque International Sunport is the state's primary port of entry for air transportation.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Upham, near Truth or Consequences, is the location of the world's first operational and purpose-built commercial spaceport, Spaceport America.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Rocket launches began in April 2007.

name: new_mexico
sentence: It is undeveloped and has one tenant, UP Aerospace, launching small payloads.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Virgin Galactic, a space tourism company, plans to make this their primary operating base.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Constitution of New Mexico established New Mexico's governmental structure.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The executive branch of government is fragmented as outlined in the state constitution.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The executive is composed of the governor and other statewide elected officials including the lieutenant governor (elected on the same ticket as the governor), attorney general, secretary of state, state auditor, state treasurer, and commissioner of public lands.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The governor appoints a cabinet who lead agencies statutorily designated under their jurisdiction.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The New Mexico Legislature consists of the House of Representatives and Senatorte.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The judiciary is composed of the New Mexico Supreme Court and lower courts.

name: new_mexico
sentence: There is also local government, consisting of counties, municipalities and special districts.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Current Governor Michelle Lujan Grisham (D) and Lieutenant Governor Howie Morales (D) were first elected in 2018.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Terms for both the governor and lieutenant governor expire in January 2023.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Governors serve a term of four years, and may seek re-election for one additional term (limit of two terms).

name: new_mexico
sentence: Other constitutional officers, all of whose terms also expire in January 2023, include Secretary of State Maggie Toulouse Oliver (D), Attorney General Hector Balderas (D), State Auditor Brian Colón (D), State Land Commissioner Stephanie Garcia Richard (D), and State Treasurer Tim Eichenberg (D).

name: new_mexico
sentence: Currently, both chambers of the New Mexico State Legislature have Democratic majorities.

name: new_mexico
sentence: There are 26 Democrats and 16 Republicans in the Senatorte, and 47 Democrats and 23 Republicans in the House of Representatives.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico's members of the United States Senatorte are Democrats Martin Heinrich and Ben Ray Luján.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The state's three United States House of Representatives members are Democrat Deb Haaland, Republican Yvette Herrell, and Democrat Teresa Leger Fernandez representing the first, second, and third districts respectively.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico has traditionally been considered a swing state, whose population has favored both Democratic and Republican presidential candidates, but it has become more of a Democratic stronghold beginning with the presidential election of 2008.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The governor is Michelle Lujan Grisham (D), who succeeded Susana Martinez (R) on January 1, 2019 after she served two terms as governor from 2011 to 2019.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Gary Johnson served as governor from 1995 to 2003.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Johnson served as a Republican, but in 2012 and 2016, he ran for president from the Libertarian Party.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In previous presidential elections, Al Gore carried the state (by 366 votes) in 2000; George W. Bush won New Mexico's five electoral votes in 2004, and the state's electoral votes were won by Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton in 2008, 2012, and 2016.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Since achieving statehood in 1912, New Mexico has been carried by the national popular vote victor in every presidential election of the past 104 years, except 1976, when Gerald Ford won the state by 2%, but lost the national popular vote by 2%.

name: new_mexico
sentence: It has also awarded its electoral votes to the candidate who would ultimately win, with the exception of 1976, 2000, and 2016.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Democrats in the state are usually strongest in the Santa Fe Area, various areas of the Albuquerque Metro Area (such as the southeast and central areas, including the affluent Nob Hill neighborhood and the vicinity of the University of New Mexico), Northern and West Central New Mexico, and most of the Native American reservations, particularly the Navajo Nation.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Republicans have traditionally had their strongholds in the eastern and southern parts of the state, the Farmington area, Rio Rancho, and the newly developed areas in the Northwest mesa.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Albuquerque's Northeast Heights have historically leaned Republican, but have become a key swing area for Democrats in recent election cycles.

name: new_mexico
sentence: While registered Democrats outnumber registered Republicans by nearly 200,000, New Mexico voters have favored moderate to conservative candidates of both parties at the state and federal levels.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico abolished its death penalty statute, though not retroactively, effective July 1, 2009.

name: new_mexico
sentence: This means individuals on New Mexico's Death Row can still be executed.

name: new_mexico
sentence: On March 18, 2009, then Governor Bill Richardson signed the law abolishing the death penalty in New Mexico following the assembly and senate vote the week before, thus becoming the 15th US state to abolish the penalty.

name: new_mexico
sentence: On gun control, New Mexico arguably has some of the least restrictive firearms laws in the country.

name: new_mexico
sentence: State law pre-empts all local gun control ordinances.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico residents may purchase any firearm deemed legal under federal law.

name: new_mexico
sentence: There are no waiting periods under state law for picking up a firearm after it has been purchased, and there are no restrictions on magazine capacity.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Additionally, New Mexico is a "shall-issue" state for concealed carry permits.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Before December 2013, New Mexico law neither explicitly allowed nor prohibited same-sex marriage.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Policy concerning the issuance of marriage licenses to same-sex couples was determined at the county level; that is, some county clerks issued marriage licenses to same-sex couples while others did not.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In December 2013, the New Mexico Supreme Court issued a unanimous ruling directing all county clerks to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, thereby making New Mexico the 17th state to recognize same-sex marriage at the statewide level.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Due to its relatively low population, in combination with numerous federally funded research facilities, New Mexico had the highest concentration of PhD holders of any state in 2000.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Despite this, the state routinely ranks near the bottom in surveys of the quality of primary and secondary school education.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In a landmark decision, a state judge ruled in 2018 that "New Mexico is violating the constitutional rights of at-risk students by failing to provide them with sufficient education," and ordered that the governor and Legislature provide an adequate system by April 2019.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico has a higher concentration of persons who do not finish high school or have some college without a degree than the nation as a whole.

name: new_mexico
sentence: For the state, 23.9% of people over 25 have gone to college but not earned a degree.

name: new_mexico
sentence: This is compared with 21.0% of the nation as a whole according to United States Census Bureau 2014 American Community Survey estimates.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Los Alamos County has the highest number percent of post secondary degree holders of any county in New Mexico with 38.7% of the population (4,899 persons) estimated by the 2010-2014 American Community Survey.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The New Mexico Public Education Department oversees the operation of primary and secondary schools

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico is one of eight states that fund college scholarships through the state lottery.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The state of New Mexico requires that the lottery put 30% of its gross sales into the scholarship fund.The scholarship is available to residents who graduated from a state high school, and attend a state university full-time while maintaining a 2.5 GPA or higher.It covered 100% of tuition when it was first instated in 1996, decreased to 90%, then dropped to 60% in 2017.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The value slightly increased in 2018, and new legislation was passed to outline what funds are available per type of institution.

name: new_mexico
sentence: With a Native American population of 134,000 in 1990, New Mexico ranks as an important center of Native American culture.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Both the Navajo and Apache share Athabaskan origin.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Apache and some Ute live on federal reservations within the state.

name: new_mexico
sentence: With 16 million acres (6,500,000 ha), mostly in neighboring Arizona, the reservation of the Navajo Nation ranks as the largest in the United States.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The prehistorically agricultural Pueblo Indians live in pueblos scattered throughout the state.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Almost half of New Mexicans claim Hispanic origin

name: new_mexico
sentence: They settled in the state's northern portion.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Most of the Mexican immigrants reside in the southern part of the state.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Also 10-15% of the population, mainly in the north, may contain Hispanic Jewish ancestry.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Many New Mexicans speak a unique dialect of Spanish.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Because of the historical isolation of New Mexico from other speakers of the Spanish language, some of the vocabulary of New Mexican Spanish is unknown to other Spanish speakers.

name: new_mexico
sentence: It uses numerous Native American words for local features and includes anglicized words that express American concepts and modern inventions.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Albuquerque has the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science, the National Hispanic Cultural Center, and the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History, as well as hosts the famed annual Albuquerque International Balloon Fiesta every fall.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The earliest New Mexico artists whose work survives today are the Mimbres Indians, whose black and white pottery could be mistaken for modern art, except for the fact that it was produced before 1130 CE.

name: new_mexico
sentence: See Mimbres culture.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Many examples of this work can be seen at the Deming Luna Mimbres Museum and at the Western New Mexico University Museum.

name: new_mexico
sentence: A large artistic community thrives in Santa Fe, and has included such people as Bruce Nauman, Richard Tuttle, John Connell and Steina Vasulka.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The capital city has several art museums, including the New Mexico Museum of Art, Museum of Spanish Colonial Art, Museum of International Folk Art, Museum of Indian Arts and Culture, Museum of Contemporary Native Arts, SITE Santa Fe and others.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Colonies for artists and writers thrive, and the small city teems with art galleries.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In August, the city hosts the annual Santa Fe Indian Market, which is the oldest and largest juried Native American art showcase in the world.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Performing arts include the renowned Santa Fe Opera which presents five operas in repertory each July to August, the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival held each summer, and the restored Lensic Theater a principal venue for many kinds of performances.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Santa Fe is also home to Frogville Records, an indie record label.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The weekend after Labor Day boasts the burning of Zozobra, a fifty-foot (15 m) marionette, during Fiestas de Santa Fe.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Art is also a frequent theme in Albuquerque, New Mexico's largest city.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The National Hispanic Cultural Center has held hundreds of performing arts events, art showcases, and other events related to Spanish culture in New Mexico and worldwide in the centerpiece Roy E Disney Center for the Performing Arts or in other venues at the 53 acre facility.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico residents and visitors alike can enjoy performing art from around the world at Popejoy Hall on the campus of the University of New Mexico.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Popejoy Hall hosts singers, dancers, Broadway shows, other types of acts, and Shakespeare.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Albuquerque also has the unique and memorable KiMo Theater built in 1927 in the Pueblo Revival Style architecture.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The KiMo presents live theater and concerts as well as movies and simulcast operas.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In addition to other general interest theaters, Albuquerque also has the African American Performing Arts Center and Exhibit Hall which showcases achievements by people of African descent and the Indian Pueblo Cultural Center which highlights the cultural heritage of the First Nations people of New Mexico.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico holds strong to its Spanish heritage.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Old Spanish traditions such zarzuelas and flamenco are popular in New Mexico.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Flamenco dancer and native New Mexican María Benítez founded the Maria Benítez Institute for Spanish Arts "to present programs of the highest quality of the rich artistic heritage of Spain, as expressed through music, dance, visual arts, and other art forms".

name: new_mexico
sentence: There is also the Festival Flamenco Internacional de Alburquerque held each year in which native Spanish and New Mexican flamenco dancers perform at the University of New Mexico.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In the mid-20th century there was a thriving Hispano school of literature and scholarship being produced in both English and Spanish.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Among the more notable authors were: Angélico Chávez, Nina Otero-Warren, Fabiola Cabeza de Baca, Aurelio Espinosa, Cleofas Jaramillo, Juan Bautista Rael, and Aurora Lucero-White Lea.

name: new_mexico
sentence: As well, writer D. H. Lawrence lived near Taos in the 1920s, at the D. H. Lawrence Ranch, where there is a shrine said to contain his ashes.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico's strong Spanish, Native American, and Wild West frontier motifs have provided material for many authors in the state, including internationally recognized Rudolfo Anaya and Tony Hillerman.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Silver City, in the southwestern mountains of the state, was originally a mining town, and at least one nearby mine still operates.

name: new_mexico
sentence: It is perhaps better known now as the home of or exhibition center for large numbers of artists, visual and otherwise.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Another former mining town turned art haven is Madrid, New Mexico.

name: new_mexico
sentence: It was brought to national fame as the filming location for the movie Wild Hogs in 2007.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The City of Las Cruces, in southern New Mexico, has a museum system affiliated with the Smithsonian Institution Affiliations Program.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Las Cruces also has a variety of cultural and artistic opportunities for residents and visitors.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Aside from the aforementioned Wild Hogs, other movies filmed in New Mexico include Sunshine Cleaning and Vampires.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The various seasons of the A&E/Netflix series Longmire have been filmed in several New Mexico locations, including Las Vegas, Santa Fe, Eagle Nest, and Red River.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The widely acclaimed TV show Breaking Bad and its spin-off Better Call Saul were both set and filmed in and around Albuquerque.

name: new_mexico
sentence: No major league professional sports teams are based in New Mexico, but the Albuquerque Isotopes are a Pacific Coast League Triple-A baseball affiliate of the MLB Colorado Rockies.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico is home to several baseball teams of the Pecos League: the Roswell Invaders, Ruidoso Osos, Santa Fe Fuego and the White Sands Pupfish.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Duke City Gladiators of the Indoor Football League (IFL) plays their home games at Tingley Coliseum in Albuquerque.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico United, also based in Albuquerque, began play in the second tier of the American soccer pyramid, the USL Championship, in 2019.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Another soccer team from that city, Albuquerque Sol FC, plays in the fourth-tier USL League Two.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Collegiate athletics in New Mexico involve various New Mexico Lobos and New Mexico State Aggies teams in many sports.

name: new_mexico
sentence: For many years the two universities have had a rivalry often referred to as the "Rio Grande Rivalry" or the "Battle of I-25" in recognition of the campuses' both being located along that highway.

name: new_mexico
sentence: NMSU also has a rivalry with the University of Texas at El Paso which is called "The Battle of I-10".

name: new_mexico
sentence: The winner of the NMSU-UTEP football game receives the Silver Spade trophy.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Olympic gold medalist Tom Jager, who is an advocate of controversial high-altitude training for swimming, has conducted training camps in Albuquerque at 5,312 feet (1,619 m) and Los Alamos at 7,320 feet (2,231 m).

name: new_mexico
sentence: NRA Whittington Center in Raton is the United States' largest and most comprehensive competitive shooting range and training facility.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is a state in the northeastern United States.

name: new_york
sentence: It was one of the original thirteen colonies, forming the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: With a total area of 54,555 square miles (141,300 km2), New York is the 27th largest state.

name: new_york
sentence: Its population of more than 19 million as of 2019 makes it the fourth most populous.

name: new_york
sentence: Sometimes referred to as New York State, it is the home of New York City.

name: new_york
sentence: Two-thirds of the state's population lives in the New York metropolitan area.

name: new_york
sentence: With an estimated population of 8.34 million in 2019, New York City is the most populous city in the United States and the premier gateway for immigration to the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York metropolitan area is one of the most populous in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: A global city, New York City is home to the United Nations Headquarters, and has been described as the cultural, financial, and media capital of the world, as well as the world's most economically powerful city.

name: new_york
sentence: The next four most populous cities in the state are Buffalo, Rochester, Yonkers, and Syracuse, while the state capital is Albany.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has a diverse geography.

name: new_york
sentence: The state is bordered by New Jersey and Pennsylvania to the south and Connecticut, Massachusetts, and Vermont to the east.

name: new_york
sentence: The state has a maritime border with Rhode Island, east of Long Island, as well as an international border with the Canadian provinces of Quebec to the north and Ontario to the northwest.

name: new_york
sentence: The southern part of the state is in the Atlantic coastal plain and includes Long Island and several smaller associated islands, as well as New York City and the lower Hudson River Valley.

name: new_york
sentence: The large Upstate New York region comprises several ranges of the wider Appalachian Mountains, and the Adirondack Mountains in the northeastern lobe of the state.

name: new_york
sentence: The north–south Hudson River Valley and the east–west Mohawk River Valley bisect these more mountainous regions.

name: new_york
sentence: Western New York is considered part of the Great Lakes region and borders on Lake Ontario, Lake Erie, and Niagara Falls.

name: new_york
sentence: The central part of the state is dominated by the Finger Lakes, a popular vacation and tourist destination.

name: new_york
sentence: New York had been inhabited by tribes of Algonquian and Iroquoian-speaking Native Americans for several hundred years by the time the earliest Europeans came to New York.

name: new_york
sentence: French colonists and Jesuit missionaries arrived southward from Montreal for trade and proselytizing.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1609, the region was visited by Henry Hudson sailing for the Dutch East India Company.

name: new_york
sentence: The Dutch built Fort Nassau in 1614 at the confluence of the Hudson and Mohawk rivers, where the present-day capital of Albany later developed.

name: new_york
sentence: The Dutch soon also settled New Amsterdam and parts of the Hudson Valley, establishing the multicultural colony of New Netherland, a center of trade and immigration.

name: new_york
sentence: England seized the colony from the Dutch in 1664.

name: new_york
sentence: During the American Revolutionary War (1775–1783), a group of colonists of the Province of New York attempted to take control of the British colony and eventually succeeded in establishing independence.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 19th century, New York's development of the interior, beginning with the Erie Canal, gave it incomparable advantages over other regions of the east coast and built its political and cultural ascendancy.

name: new_york
sentence: Many landmarks in New York are well known, including four of the world's ten most-visited tourist attractions in 2013: Times Square, Central Park, Niagara Falls, and Grand Central Terminal.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is home to the Statue of Liberty.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 21st century, New York has emerged as a global node of creativity and entrepreneurship, social tolerance, and environmental sustainability.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has approximately 200 colleges and universities, including the State University of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: Several have been ranked among the top 100 in the nation and world.

name: new_york
sentence: The tribes in what is now New York were predominantly Haudenosaunee and Algonquian.

name: new_york
sentence: Long Island was divided roughly in half between the Wampanoag and Lenape.

name: new_york
sentence: The Lenape also controlled most of the region surrounding New York Harbor.

name: new_york
sentence: North of the Lenape was a third Algonquian nation, the Mohicans.

name: new_york
sentence: Starting north of them, from east to west, were three Iroquoian nations: the Mohawk, the original Iroquois and the Petun.

name: new_york
sentence: South of them, divided roughly along Appalachia, were the Susquehannock and the Erie.

name: new_york
sentence: Many of the Wampanoag and Mohican peoples were caught up in King Philip's War, a joint effort of many New England tribes to push Europeans off their land.

name: new_york
sentence: After the death of their leader, Chief Philip Metacomet, most of those peoples fled inland, splitting into the Abenaki and the Schaghticoke.

name: new_york
sentence: Many of the Mohicans remained in the region until the 1800s, however, a small group known as the Ouabano migrated southwest into West Virginia at an earlier time.

name: new_york
sentence: They may have merged with the Shawnee.

name: new_york
sentence: The Mohawk and Susquehannock were the most militaristic.

name: new_york
sentence: Trying to corner trade with the Europeans, they targeted other tribes.

name: new_york
sentence: The Mohawk were also known for refusing white settlement on their land and banishing any of their people who converted to Christianity.

name: new_york
sentence: They posed a major threat to the Abenaki and Mohicans, while the Susquehannock briefly conquered the Lenape in the 1600s.

name: new_york
sentence: The most devastating event of the century, however, was the Beaver Wars.

name: new_york
sentence: From approximately 1640–1680, Iroquoian peoples waged campaigns which extended from modern-day Michigan to Virginia against Algonquian and Siouan tribes, as well as each other.

name: new_york
sentence: The aim was to control more land for animal trapping, a career most natives had turned to in hopes of trading with whites first.

name: new_york
sentence: This completely changed the ethnography of the region, and most large game was hunted out before whites ever fully explored the land.

name: new_york
sentence: Still, afterward, the Iroquois Confederacy offered shelter to refugees of the Mascouten, Erie, Chonnonton, Tutelo, Saponi, and Tuscarora nations.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 1700s, they would also merge with the Mohawk during the French-Indian War and take in the remaining Susquehannock of Pennsylvania after they were decimated in war.

name: new_york
sentence: Most of these other groups blended in until they ceased to exist.

name: new_york
sentence: Then, after the Revolution, a large group of them split off and returned to Ohio, becoming known as the Mingo Senatorca.

name: new_york
sentence: The current six tribes of the Iroquois Confederacy are the Senatorca, Cayuga, Onondaga, Oneida, Tuscarora and Mohawk.

name: new_york
sentence: The Iroquois fought for both sides during the Revolutionary War

name: new_york
sentence: Today, the Iroquois still live in several reservations in upstate New York.

name: new_york
sentence: Meanwhile, the Lenape formed a close relationship with William Penn.

name: new_york
sentence: However, upon Penn's death, his sons managed to take over much of their lands and banish them to Ohio.

name: new_york
sentence: When the US drafted the Indian Removal Act, the Lenape were further moved to Missouri, whereas their cousins, the Mohicans, were sent to Wisconsin.

name: new_york
sentence: Also, in 1778, the United States relocated the Nanticoke from the Delmarva Peninsula to the former Iroquois lands south of Lake Ontario, though they did not stay long.

name: new_york
sentence: Mostly, they chose to migrate into Canada and merge with the Iroquois, although some moved west and merged with the Lenape.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1524, Giovanni da Verrazzano, an Italian explorer in the service of the French crown, explored the Atlantic coast of North America between the Carolinas and Newfoundland, including New York Harbor and Narragansett Bay.

name: new_york
sentence: On April 17, 1524, Verrazzano entered New York Bay, by way of the strait now called the Narrows into the northern bay which he named Santa Margherita, in honor of the King of France's sister.

name: new_york
sentence: Verrazzano described it as "a vast coastline with a deep delta in which every kind of ship could pass" and he adds: "that it extends inland for a league and opens up to form a beautiful lake.

name: new_york
sentence: This vast sheet of water swarmed with native boats."

name: new_york
sentence: He landed on the tip of Manhattan and possibly on the furthest point of Long Island.

name: new_york
sentence: Verrazzano's stay was interrupted by a storm which pushed him north towards Martha's Vineyard.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1540, French traders from New France built a chateau on Castle Island, within present-day Albany; it was abandoned the following year due to flooding.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1614, the Dutch, under the command of Hendrick Corstiaensen, rebuilt the French chateau, which they called Fort Nassau.

name: new_york
sentence: Fort Nassau was the first Dutch settlement in North America, and was located along the Hudson River, also within present-day Albany.

name: new_york
sentence: The small fort served as a trading post and warehouse.

name: new_york
sentence: Located on the Hudson River flood plain, the rudimentary "fort" was washed away by flooding in 1617, and abandoned for good after Fort Orange (New Netherland) was built nearby in 1623.

name: new_york
sentence: Henry Hudson's 1609 voyage marked the beginning of European involvement with the area.

name: new_york
sentence: Sailing for the Dutch East India Company and looking for a passage to Asia, he entered the Upper New York Bay on September 11 of that year.

name: new_york
sentence: Word of his findings encouraged Dutch merchants to explore the coast in search for profitable fur trading with local Native American tribes.

name: new_york
sentence: During the 17th century, Dutch trading posts established for the trade of pelts from the Lenape, Iroquois, and other tribes were founded in the colony of New Netherland.

name: new_york
sentence: The first of these trading posts were Fort Nassau (1614, near present-day Albany); Fort Orange (1624, on the Hudson River just south of the current city of Albany and created to replace Fort Nassau), developing into settlement Beverwijck (1647), and into what became Albany; Fort Amsterdam (1625, to develop into the town New Amsterdam which is present-day New York City); and Esopus, (1653, now Kingston).

name: new_york
sentence: The success of the patroonship of Rensselaerswyck (1630), which surrounded Albany and lasted until the mid-19th century, was also a key factor in the early success of the colony.

name: new_york
sentence: The English captured the colony during the Second Anglo-Dutch War and governed it as the Province of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The city of New York was recaptured by the Dutch in 1673 during the Third Anglo-Dutch War (1672–1674) and renamed New Orange.

name: new_york
sentence: It was returned to the English under the terms of the Treaty of Westminster a year later.

name: new_york
sentence: The Sons of Liberty were organized in New York City during the 1760s, largely in response to the oppressive Stamp Act passed by the British Parliament in 1765.

name: new_york
sentence: The Stamp Act Congress met in the city on October 19 of that year, composed of representatives from across the Thirteen Colonies who set the stage for the Continental Congress to follow.

name: new_york
sentence: The Stamp Act Congress resulted in the Declaration of Rights and Grievances, which was the first written expression by representatives of the Americans of many of the rights and complaints later expressed in the United States Declaration of Independence.

name: new_york
sentence: This included the right to representative government.

name: new_york
sentence: At the same time, given strong commercial, personal and sentimental links to Britain, many New York residents were Loyalists.

name: new_york
sentence: The Capture of Fort Ticonderoga provided the cannon and gunpowder necessary to force a British withdrawal from the Siege of Boston in 1775.

name: new_york
sentence: New York was the only colony not to vote for independence, as the delegates were not authorized to do so.

name: new_york
sentence: New York then endorsed the Declaration of Independence on July 9, 1776.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York State Constitution was framed by a convention which assembled at White Plains on July 10, 1776, and after repeated adjournments and changes of location, finished its work at Kingston on Sunday evening, April 20, 1777, when the new constitution drafted by John Jay was adopted with but one dissenting vote.

name: new_york
sentence: It was not submitted to the people for ratification.

name: new_york
sentence: On July 30, 1777, George Clinton was inaugurated as the first Governor of New York at Kingston.

name: new_york
sentence: About a third of the battles of the American Revolutionary War took place in New York; the first major one (and largest of the entire war) was the Battle of Long Island, a.k.a.

name: new_york
sentence: Battle of Brooklyn, in August 1776.

name: new_york
sentence: After their victory, the British occupied New York City, making it their military and political base of operations in North America for the duration of the conflict, and consequently the focus of General George Washington's intelligence network.

name: new_york
sentence: On the notorious British prison ships of Wallabout Bay, more American combatants died of intentional neglect than were killed in combat in every battle of the war combined.

name: new_york
sentence: Both sides of combatants lost more soldiers to disease than to outright wounds.

name: new_york
sentence: The first of two major British armies were captured by the Continental Army at the Battle of Saratoga in 1777, a success that influenced France to ally with the revolutionaries.The state constitution was enacted in 1777.

name: new_york
sentence: New York became the 11th state to ratify the United States Constitution, on July 26, 1788.

name: new_york
sentence: In an attempt to retain their sovereignty and remain an independent nation positioned between the new United States and British North America, four of the Iroquois Nations fought on the side of the British; only the Oneida and their dependents, the Tuscarora, allied themselves with the Americans.

name: new_york
sentence: In retaliation for attacks on the frontier led by Joseph Brant and Loyalist Mohawk forces, the Sullivan Expedition of 1779 destroyed nearly 50 Iroquois villages, adjacent croplands and winter stores, forcing many refugees to British-held Niagara.

name: new_york
sentence: As allies of the British, the Iroquois were forced out of New York, although they had not been part of treaty negotiations.

name: new_york
sentence: They resettled in Canada after the war and were given land grants by the Crown.

name: new_york
sentence: In the treaty settlement, the British ceded most Indian lands to the new United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Because New York made treaty with the Iroquois without getting Congressional approval, some of the land purchases have been subject to land claim suits since the late 20th century by the federally recognized tribes.

name: new_york
sentence: New York put up more than 5 million acres (20,000 km2) of former Iroquois territory for sale in the years after the Revolutionary War, leading to rapid development in upstate New York.

name: new_york
sentence: As per the Treaty of Paris, the last vestige of British authority in the former Thirteen Colonies—their troops in New York City—departed in 1783, which was long afterward celebrated as Evacuation Day.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City was the national capital under the Articles of Confederation and Perpetual Union, the first national government.

name: new_york
sentence: That organization was found to be insufficient, and prominent New Yorker Alexander Hamilton advocated a new government that would include an executive, national courts, and the power to tax.

name: new_york
sentence: Hamilton led the Annapolis Convention (1786) that called for the Philadelphia Convention, which drafted the United States Constitution, in which he also took part.

name: new_york
sentence: The new government was to be a strong federal national government to replace the relatively weaker confederation of individual states.

name: new_york
sentence: Following heated debate, which included the publication of the now quintessential constitutional interpretation—The Federalist Papers—as a series of installments in New York City newspapers, New York was the 11th state to ratify the United States Constitution, on July 26, 1788.

name: new_york
sentence: New York remained the national capital under the new constitution until 1790, and was the site of the inauguration of President George Washington, the drafting of the United States Bill of Rights, and the first session of the United States Supreme Court.

name: new_york
sentence: Hamilton's revival of the heavily indebted United States economy after the war and the creation of a national bank significantly contributed to New York City becoming the financial center of the new nation.

name: new_york
sentence: Both the Dutch and the British imported African slaves as laborers to the city and colony; New York had the second-highest population of slaves after Charleston, South Carolina.

name: new_york
sentence: Slavery was extensive in New York City and some agricultural areas.

name: new_york
sentence: The state passed a law for the gradual abolition of slavery soon after the Revolutionary War, but the last slave in New York was not freed until 1827.

name: new_york
sentence: Transportation in western New York was by expensive wagons on muddy roads before canals opened up the rich farm lands to long-distance traffic.

name: new_york
sentence: Governor DeWitt Clinton promoted the Erie Canal, which connected New York City to the Great Lakes by the Hudson River, the new canal, and the rivers and lakes.

name: new_york
sentence: Work commenced in 1817, and the Erie Canal opened in 1825.

name: new_york
sentence: Packet boats pulled by horses on tow paths traveled slowly over the canal carrying passengers and freight.

name: new_york
sentence: Farm products came in from the Midwest, and finished manufactured goods moved west.

name: new_york
sentence: It was an engineering marvel which opened up vast areas of New York to commerce and settlement.

name: new_york
sentence: It enabled Great Lakes port cities such as Buffalo and Rochester to grow and prosper.

name: new_york
sentence: It also connected the burgeoning agricultural production of the Midwest and shipping on the Great Lakes, with the port of New York City.

name: new_york
sentence: Improving transportation, it enabled additional population migration to territories west of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: After 1850, railroads largely replaced the canal.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City was a major ocean port and had extensive traffic importing cotton from the South and exporting manufacturing goods.

name: new_york
sentence: Nearly half of the state's exports were related to cotton.

name: new_york
sentence: Southern cotton factors, planters and bankers visited so often that they had favorite hotels.

name: new_york
sentence: At the same time, activism for abolitionism was strong upstate, where some communities provided stops on the Underground Railroad.

name: new_york
sentence: Upstate, and New York City, gave strong support for the American Civil War, in terms of finances, volunteer soldiers, and supplies.

name: new_york
sentence: The state provided more than 370,000 soldiers to the Union armies.

name: new_york
sentence: Over 53,000 New Yorkers died in service, roughly one of every seven who served.

name: new_york
sentence: However, Irish draft riots in 1862 were a significant embarrassment.

name: new_york
sentence: Since the early 19th century, New York City has been the largest port of entry for legal immigration into the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: In the United States, the federal government did not assume direct jurisdiction for immigration until 1890.

name: new_york
sentence: Prior to this time, the matter was delegated to the individual states, then via contract between the states and the federal government.

name: new_york
sentence: Most immigrants to New York would disembark at the bustling docks along the Hudson and East Rivers, in the eventual Lower Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: On May 4, 1847, the New York State Legislature created the Board of Commissioners of Immigration to regulate immigration.

name: new_york
sentence: The first permanent immigration depot in New York was established in 1855 at Castle Garden, a converted War of 1812 era fort located within what is now Battery Park, at the tip of Lower Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: The first immigrants to arrive at the new depot were aboard three ships that had just been released from quarantine.

name: new_york
sentence: Castle Garden served as New York's immigrant depot until it closed on April 18, 1890, when the federal government assumed control over immigration.

name: new_york
sentence: During that period, more than eight million immigrants passed through its doors (two of every three US immigrants).

name: new_york
sentence: When the federal government assumed control, it established the Bureau of Immigration, which chose the three-acre Ellis Island in Upper New York Harbor for an entry depot.

name: new_york
sentence: Already federally controlled, the island had served as an ammunition depot.

name: new_york
sentence: It was chosen due its relative isolation with proximity to New York City and the rail lines of Jersey City, New Jersey, via a short ferry ride.

name: new_york
sentence: While the island was being developed and expanded via land reclamation, the federal government operated a temporary depot at the Barge Office at the Battery.

name: new_york
sentence: Ellis Island opened on January 1, 1892, and operated as a central immigration center until the National Origins Act was passed in 1924, reducing immigration.

name: new_york
sentence: After that date, the only immigrants to pass through were displaced persons or war refugees.

name: new_york
sentence: The island ceased all immigration processing on November 12, 1954, when the last person detained on the island, Norwegian seaman Arne Peterssen, was released.

name: new_york
sentence: He had overstayed his shore leave and left on the 10:15 a.m. Manhattan-bound ferry to return to his ship.

name: new_york
sentence: More than twelve million immigrants passed through Ellis Island between 1892 and 1954.

name: new_york
sentence: More than a hundred million Americans across the United States can trace their ancestry to these immigrants.

name: new_york
sentence: Ellis Island was the subject of a contentious and long-running border and jurisdictional dispute between New York State and the State of New Jersey, as both claimed it.

name: new_york
sentence: The issue was settled in 1998 by the US Supreme Court which ruled that the original 3.3-acre (1.3 ha) island was New York State territory and that the balance of the 27.5 acres (11 ha) added after 1834 by landfill was in New Jersey.

name: new_york
sentence: The island was added to the National Park Service system in May 1965 by President Lyndon B. Johnson and is still owned by the federal government as part of the Statue of Liberty National Monument.

name: new_york
sentence: Ellis Island was opened to the public as a museum of immigration in 1990.

name: new_york
sentence: On September 11, 2001, two of four hijacked planes were flown into the Twin Towers of the original World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan, and the towers collapsed.

name: new_york
sentence: 7 World Trade Center also collapsed due to damage from fires.

name: new_york
sentence: The other buildings of the World Trade Center complex were damaged beyond repair and demolished soon thereafter.

name: new_york
sentence: The collapse of the Twin Towers caused extensive damage and resulted in the deaths of 2,753 victims, including 147 aboard the two planes.

name: new_york
sentence: Since September 11, most of Lower Manhattan has been restored.

name: new_york
sentence: In the years since, over 7,000 rescue workers and residents of the area have developed several life-threatening illnesses, and some have died.

name: new_york
sentence: A memorial at the site, the National September 11 Memorial & Museum, was opened to the public on September 11, 2011.

name: new_york
sentence: A permanent museum later opened at the site on March 21, 2014.

name: new_york
sentence: Upon its completion in 2014, the new One World Trade Center became the tallest skyscraper in the Western Hemisphere, at 1,776 feet (541 m), meant to symbolize the year America gained its independence, 1776.

name: new_york
sentence: From 2006 to 2018, 3 World Trade Center, 4 World Trade Center, 7 World Trade Center, the World Trade Center Transportation Hub, Liberty Park, and Fiterman Hall were completed.

name: new_york
sentence: St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church and Ronald O. Perelman Performing Arts Center are under construction at the World Trade Center site.

name: new_york
sentence: On October 29 and 30, 2012, Hurricane Sandy caused extensive destruction of the state's shorelines, ravaging portions of New York City, Long Island, and southern Westchester with record-high storm surge, with severe flooding and high winds causing power outages for hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers, and leading to gasoline shortages and disruption of mass transit systems.

name: new_york
sentence: The storm and its profound effects have prompted the discussion of constructing seawalls and other coastal barriers around the shorelines of New York City and Long Island to minimize the risk from another such future event.

name: new_york
sentence: Such risk is considered highly probable due to global warming and rising sea levels.

name: new_york
sentence: On March 1, 2020, New York had its first confirmed case of COVID-19.

name: new_york
sentence: Since March 28, New York had the highest number of confirmed cases of any state in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Nearly 50 percent of known national cases were in the state, with one-third of total known US cases being in New York City.

name: new_york
sentence: From May 19–20, Western New York and the Capital Region entered Phase 1 of reopening.

name: new_york
sentence: On May 26, the Hudson Valley began Phase 1, and New York City partially reopened on June 8.

name: new_york
sentence: During the pandemic, a federal judge ruled Cuomo and De Blasio exceeded authority by limiting religious gatherings to 25% when others operated at 50% capacity.

name: new_york
sentence: New York's government released a new seal, coat of arms, and flag in April during the pandemic, adding "E pluribus unum" below the state's motto.

name: new_york
sentence: A bill utilizing newly designed flag, arms and seal went into effect in September.

name: new_york
sentence: The state of New York covers 54,555 square miles (141,300 km2) and ranks as the 27th largest state by size.

name: new_york
sentence: The highest elevation in New York is Mount Marcy in the Adirondacks, at 5,344 feet (1,629 meters) above sea level; while the state's lowest point is at sea level, on the Atlantic Ocean.

name: new_york
sentence: In contrast with New York City's urban landscape, the vast majority of the state's geographic area is dominated by meadows, forests, rivers, farms, mountains, and lakes.

name: new_york
sentence: Most of the southern part of the state rests on the Allegheny Plateau, which extends from the southeastern United States to the Catskill Mountains; the section in New York State is known as the Southern Tier.

name: new_york
sentence: The rugged Adirondack Mountains, with vast tracts of wilderness, lie west of the Lake Champlain Valley.

name: new_york
sentence: The Great Appalachian Valley dominates eastern New York and contains the Lake Champlain Valley as its northern half and the Hudson Valley as its southern half within the state.

name: new_york
sentence: The Tug Hill region arises as a cuesta east of Lake Ontario.

name: new_york
sentence: Upstate and downstate are often used informally to distinguish New York City or its greater metropolitan area from the rest of New York State.

name: new_york
sentence: The placement of a boundary between the two is a matter of great contention.

name: new_york
sentence: Unofficial and loosely defined regions of Upstate New York include the Southern Tier, which often includes the counties along the border with Pennsylvania, and the North Country, which can mean anything from the strip along the Canada–US

name: new_york
sentence: border to everything north of the Mohawk River.

name: new_york
sentence: New York contains a part of the Marcellus shale, which extends into Ohio and Pennsylvania.

name: new_york
sentence: Of New York State's total area, 13.6% consists of water.

name: new_york
sentence: Much of New York's boundaries are in water, as is true for New York City: four of its five boroughs are situated on three islands at the mouth of the Hudson River: Manhattan Island; Staten Island; and Long Island, which contains Brooklyn and Queens at its western end.

name: new_york
sentence: The state's borders include a water boundary in (clockwise from the west) two Great Lakes (Lake Erie and Lake Ontario, which are connected by the Niagara River); the provinces of Ontario and Quebec in Canada, with New York and Ontario sharing the Thousand Islands archipelago within the Saint Lawrence River, while most of its border with Quebec is on land; it shares Lake Champlain with the New England state of Vermont; the New England state of Massachusetts has mostly a land border; New York extends into Long Island Sound and the Atlantic Ocean, sharing a water border with Rhode Island, while Connecticut has land and sea borders.

name: new_york
sentence: Except for areas near the New York Harbor and the Upper Delaware River, New York has a mostly land border with two Mid-Atlantic states, New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is the only state that includes within its borders parts of the Great Lakes and the Atlantic Ocean.

name: new_york
sentence: The Hudson River begins near Lake Tear of the Clouds and flows south through the eastern part of the state, without draining Lakes George or Champlain.

name: new_york
sentence: Lake George empties at its north end into Lake Champlain, whose northern end extends into Canada, where it drains into the Richelieu River and then ultimately the Saint Lawrence River.

name: new_york
sentence: The western section of the state is drained by the Allegheny River and rivers of the Susquehanna and Delaware River systems.

name: new_york
sentence: Niagara Falls is shared between New York and Ontario as it flows on the Niagara River from Lake Erie to Lake Ontario.

name: new_york
sentence: The Delaware River Basin Compact, signed in 1961 by New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware, and the federal government, regulates the utilization of water of the Delaware system.

name: new_york
sentence: In general, New York has a humid continental climate, though under the Köppen climate classification, New York City has a humid subtropical climate.

name: new_york
sentence: Weather in New York is heavily influenced by two continental air masses: a warm, humid one from the southwest and a cold, dry one from the northwest.

name: new_york
sentence: Downstate New York, comprising New York City, Long Island, and lower portions of the Hudson Valley, has rather hot summers with some periods of high humidity and cold, damp winters which are relatively mild compared to temperatures in Upstate New York due to the downstate region's lower elevation, proximity to the Atlantic Ocean, and relatively lower latitude.

name: new_york
sentence: Upstate New York experiences warm summers, marred by only occasional, brief intervals of sultry conditions, with long and cold winters.

name: new_york
sentence: Western New York, particularly the Tug Hill region, receives heavy lake-effect snows, especially during the earlier portions of winter, before the surface of Lake Ontario itself is covered by ice.

name: new_york
sentence: The summer climate is cool in the Adirondacks, Catskills, and at higher elevations of the Southern Tier.

name: new_york
sentence: Buffalo and its metropolitan area are described as climate change havens for their weather pattern in Western New York.

name: new_york
sentence: Summer daytime temperatures range from the high 70s to low 80s (25 to 28 °C), over most of the state.

name: new_york
sentence: In the majority of winter seasons, a temperature of −13 °F (−25 °C) or lower can be expected in the northern highlands (Northern Plateau) and 5 °F (−15 °C) or colder in the southwestern and east-central highlands of the Southern Tier.

name: new_york
sentence: New York had a record-high temperature of 108 °F (42.2 °C) on July 22, 1926.

name: new_york
sentence: Its record-lowest temperature during the winter was −52 °F (−46.7 °C) in 1979.

name: new_york
sentence: Some species that can be found in this state are american ginseng, starry stonewort, waterthyme, water chestnut, eastern poison ivy, poison sumac, giant hogweed, cow parsnip and common nettle.

name: new_york
sentence: There are more than 20 mammal species, more than 20 bird species, some species of amphibians, and several reptile species.

name: new_york
sentence: Species of mammals that are part of New York are white-footed mouse, North American least shrew, little brown bat, muskrat, eastern gray squirrel, eastern cottontail, stoat, groundhog, striped skunk, fisher, North American river otter, raccoon, bobcat, coyote, red fox, white-tailed deer, moose, and American black bear.

name: new_york
sentence: Some species of birds in New York are the ring-necked pheasant, northern bobwhite, ruffed grouse, wild turkey, blue jay, eastern bluebird, American robin, and black-capped chickadee.

name: new_york
sentence: Birds of prey that are present in the state are great horned owls, bald eagles, red-tailed hawks, American kestrels, and northern harriers.

name: new_york
sentence: Waterfowl like mallards, wood ducks, canvasbacks, American black ducks, Canada geese, and blue-winged teals can be found in the region.

name: new_york
sentence: Maritime or shore birds of New York are great blue heron, killdeers, northern cardinals, American herring gulls, and common terns.

name: new_york
sentence: Reptiles species that can be seen in land areas of New York are queen snake, massasauga, hellbender, diamondback terrapin, spotted turtle, and Blanding's turtle.

name: new_york
sentence: Species of turtles that can be found in the sea are green sea turtle, loggerhead sea turtle, leatherback sea turtle and Kemp's ridley sea turtle.

name: new_york
sentence: New York Harbor and the Hudson River constitute an estuary, making New York state home to a rich array of marine life including shellfish—such as oysters and clams—as well as fish, microorganisms, and sea-birds.

name: new_york
sentence: Due to its long history, New York has several overlapping and often conflicting definitions of regions within the state.

name: new_york
sentence: The regions are also not fully definable due to colloquial use of regional labels.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York State Department of Economic Development provides two distinct definitions of these regions.

name: new_york
sentence: It divides the state into ten economic regions, which approximately correspond to terminology used by residents:

name: new_york
sentence: The department also groups the counties into eleven regions for tourism purposes:

name: new_york
sentence: New York has many state parks and two major forest preserves.

name: new_york
sentence: Niagara Falls State Park, established in 1885, is the oldest state park in the United States and the first to be created via eminent domain.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1892, Adirondack Park, roughly the size of the state of Vermont and the largest state park in the United States, was established and given state constitutional protection to remain "forever wild" in 1894.

name: new_york
sentence: The park is larger than Yellowstone, Everglades, Glacier, and Grand Canyon national parks combined.

name: new_york
sentence: It is larger than the Yellowstone, Yosemite, Grand Canyon, Glacier, and Olympic National Parks combined.

name: new_york
sentence: The Catskill Park was protected in legislation passed in 1885, which declared that its land was to be conserved and never put up for sale or lease.

name: new_york
sentence: Consisting of 700,000 acres (2,800 km2) of land, the park is a habitat for deer, minks, and fishers.

name: new_york
sentence: There are some 400 black bears living in the region.

name: new_york
sentence: The state operates numerous campgrounds, and there are over 300 miles (480 km) of multi-use trails in the Park.

name: new_york
sentence: The 1797 Montauk Lighthouse, commissioned under President George Washington, is a major tourist attraction in Montauk State Park at the easternmost tip of Long Island.

name: new_york
sentence: Hither Hills State Park, also on the South Fork of Long Island, offers camping and is a popular destination with surfcasting sport fishermen.

name: new_york
sentence: The State of New York is well represented in the National Park System with 22 national parks, which received 16,349,381 visitors in 2011.

name: new_york
sentence: In addition, there are four National Heritage Areas, 27 National Natural Landmarks, 262 National Historic Landmarks, and 5,379 listings on the National Register of Historic Places.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is divided into 62 counties.

name: new_york
sentence: Aside from the five counties of New York City, each of these counties is subdivided into towns and cities, incorporated under state law.

name: new_york
sentence: Towns can contain incorporated villages or unincorporated hamlets.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City is divided into five boroughs, each coterminous with a county.

name: new_york
sentence: The major cities of the state developed along the key transportation and trade routes of the early 19th century, including the Erie Canal and railroads paralleling it.

name: new_york
sentence: Today, the New York Thruway acts as a modern counterpart to commercial water routes.

name: new_york
sentence: Downstate New York (New York City, Long Island, and the southern portion of the Hudson Valley) can be considered to form the central core of the Northeast megalopolis, an urbanized region stretching from New Hampshire to Virginia.

name: new_york
sentence: There are 62 cities in New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The largest city in the state and the most populous city in the United States is New York City, which comprises five counties (each coextensive with a borough): Bronx, New York County (Manhattan), Queens, Kings County (Brooklyn), and Richmond County (Staten Island).

name: new_york
sentence: New York City is home to more than two-fifths of the state's population.

name: new_york
sentence: Albany, the state capital, is the sixth-largest city in New York State.

name: new_york
sentence: The smallest city is Sherrill, New York, in Oneida County.

name: new_york
sentence: Hempstead is the most populous town in the state; if it were a city, it would be the second largest in New York State, with more than 700,000 residents.

name: new_york
sentence: New York contains 13 metropolitan areas, as defined by the US Census Bureau.

name: new_york
sentence: Major metro areas include New York City, Buffalo, Rochester, the Capital District (Albany, Schenectady, and Troy), Poughkeepsie, Syracuse, Utica, and Binghamton.

name: new_york
sentence: The nation's most populous state until the 1960s, New York is now the fourth most-populous state.

name: new_york
sentence: The distribution of change in population growth is uneven in New York State; the New York City metropolitan area is growing, along with Saratoga County, while cities such as Buffalo, Rochester, and Syracuse and several others having been losing population for decades.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City gained more residents between April 2010 and July 2018 (223,615) than any other US city.

name: new_york
sentence: Conversely, outside of the Ithaca area, population growth in much of Western New York is nearly stagnant.

name: new_york
sentence: According to immigration statistics, the state is a leading recipient of migrants from around the globe.

name: new_york
sentence: Between 2000 and 2005, immigration failed to surpass out-migration to other parts of the United States, a trend that has been reversing since 2006.

name: new_york
sentence: New York State lost two House seats in the 2011 congressional reapportionment, secondary to relatively slow growth when compared to the rest of the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2000 and 2005, more people moved from New York to Florida than from any one state to another, contributing to New York's becoming the fourth most populous state in 2015 behind Florida, Texas, and California.

name: new_york
sentence: However, New York State has the second-largest international immigrant population in the country among the American states, at 4.2 million as of 2008; most reside in and around New York City, due to its size, high profile, vibrant economy, and cosmopolitan culture.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has a pro-sanctuary city law.

name: new_york
sentence: The United States Census Bureau estimates that the population of New York was 19,453,561 on July 1, 2019, a 0.39% increase since the 2010 United States Census.

name: new_york
sentence: Despite the open land in the state, New York's population is very urban, with 92% of residents living in an urban area, predominantly in the New York City metropolitan area.

name: new_york
sentence: Two-thirds of New York State's population resides in New York City metropolitan area.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City is the most populous city in the United States, with an estimated record high population of 8,622,698 in 2017, incorporating more immigration into the city than emigration since the 2010 United States Census.

name: new_york
sentence: At least twice as many people live in New York City as in the second-most populous US city (Los Angeles), and within a smaller area.

name: new_york
sentence: Long Island alone accounted for a Census-estimated 7,838,722 residents in 2015, representing 39.6% of New York State's population.

name: new_york
sentence: 6.5% of New York's population were under five years of age, 24.7% under 18, and 12.9% were 65 or older.

name: new_york
sentence: Hispanic or Latino of any race were 17.6% of the population in 2010: 2.4% were of Mexican, 5.5% Puerto Rican, 0.4% Cuban, and 9.4% other Hispanic or Latino origin.

name: new_york
sentence: According to the 2010–2015 American Community Survey, the largest ancestry groups were Italian (13.0%), Irish (12.1%), German (10.3%), American (5.4%), and English (5.2%).

name: new_york
sentence: The state's most populous racial group, non-Hispanic white, has declined as a proportion of the state population from 94.6% in 1940 to 58.3% in 2010.

name: new_york
sentence: As of 2011, 55.6% of New York's population younger than age 1 were minorities.

name: new_york
sentence: New York's robustly increasing Jewish population, the largest outside of Israel, was the highest among states both by percentage and by absolute number in 2012.

name: new_york
sentence: It is driven by the high reproductive rate of Orthodox Jewish families, particularly in Brooklyn and communities of the Hudson Valley.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is home to the largest African American population and the second largest Asian-American population (after California) in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: New York's Black population increased by 2.0% between 2000 and 2010, to 3,073,800.

name: new_york
sentence: The Black population is in a state of flux, as New York is the largest recipient of immigrants from Africa, while established African Americans are migrating out of New York to the southern United States.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York City neighborhood of Harlem has historically been a major cultural capital for African-Americans of sub-Saharan descent, and Bedford-Stuyvesant in Brooklyn has the largest such population in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Meanwhile, New York's Asian population increased by a notable 36% from 2000 to 2010, to 1,420,244.

name: new_york
sentence: Queens, in New York City, is home to the state's largest Asian-American population and is the most ethnically diverse county in the United States and the most ethnically diverse urban area in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: New York's growing Hispanic-or-Latino population numbered 3,416,922 in 2010, a 19% increase from the 2,867,583 enumerated in 2000.

name: new_york
sentence: Queens is home to the largest Andean (Colombian, Ecuadorian, Peruvian, and Bolivian) populations in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: In addition, New York has the largest Puerto Rican, Dominican, and Jamaican American populations in the continental United States.The Chinese population constitutes the fastest-growing nationality in New York State, which is the top destination for new Chinese immigrants, and large-scale Chinese immigration continues into the state.

name: new_york
sentence: Multiple satellites of the original Manhattan Chinatown, in Brooklyn, and around Flushing, Queens, are thriving as traditionally urban enclaves, while also expanding rapidly eastward into suburban Nassau County, on Long Island.

name: new_york
sentence: Long Island, including Queens and Nassau County, is also home to several Little Indias (लघु भारत) and a large Koreatown (롱 아일랜드 코리아타운), with large and growing attendant populations of Indian Americans and Korean Americans, respectively.

name: new_york
sentence: Brooklyn has been a destination for West Indian immigrants of African descent, as well as Asian Indian immigrants.

name: new_york
sentence: The annual New York City India Day Parade, held on or approximately every August 15 since 1981, is the world's largest Indian Independence Day parade outside of India.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 2000 Census, New York had the largest Italian American population, composing the largest self-identified ancestral group in Staten Island and Long Island, followed by Irish Americans.

name: new_york
sentence: Albany and the Mohawk Valley also have large communities of ethnic Italians and Irish Americans, reflecting 19th and early 20th-century immigration.

name: new_york
sentence: According to the American Community Survey, New York had the largest Greek American population too, which counts 148,637 people (0.7% of the state).

name: new_york
sentence: In Buffalo and western New York, German Americans comprise the largest ancestry.

name: new_york
sentence: In the North Country of New York, French Canadians represent the leading ethnicity, given the area's proximity to Quebec.

name: new_york
sentence: Americans of English ancestry are present throughout all of upstate New York, reflecting early colonial and later immigrants.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2010, the most common American English dialects spoken in New York, besides General American English, were the New York City area dialect (including New York Latino English and North Jersey English), the Western New England accent around Albany, and Inland Northern American English in Buffalo and western New York State.

name: new_york
sentence: As many as 800 languages are spoken in New York City, making it the most linguistically diverse city in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: As of 2010, 70.72% (12,788,233) of New York residents aged five and older reported speaking only English at home, while 14.44% (2,611,903) spoke Spanish, 2.61% (472,955) Chinese (which includes Cantonese and Mandarin), 1.20% (216,468) Russian, 1.18% (213,785) Italian, 0.79% (142,169) French Creole, 0.75% (135,789) French, 0.67% (121,917) Yiddish, 0.63% (114,574) Korean, and Polish was spoken by 0.53% (95,413) of the population over the age of five.

name: new_york
sentence: In total, 29.28% (5,295,016) of New York's population aged five and older reported speaking a language other than English.

name: new_york
sentence: At the American Community Survey's 2017 estimates, nearly six million residents spoke a language other than English.

name: new_york
sentence: Approximately 1,249,541 New York residents spoke Spanish, 386,290 Chinese, 122,150 Russian, 63,615 Haitian Creole, 62,219 Bengali, and 60,405 Korean.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2018, 12,756,975 aged 5 years and older spoke English alone and 10,415,395 aged 18 and older only spoke English.

name: new_york
sentence: Spanish-speaking households by majority were not limited English-speaking.

name: new_york
sentence: An estimated 2.7 million households with residents aged 5 and older spoke Spanish.

name: new_york
sentence: Chinese, Slavic, and French languages were the following largest household languages spoken in 2018.

name: new_york
sentence: The majority of New York's religious population are Christian (60%), followed by the irreligious (27%), Judaism (7%), Islam (2%), Buddhism and Hinduism (1% each), and other faiths (0.5%).

name: new_york
sentence: Before the 1800s, Protestant sects dominated the religious life of New York, although religion did not play as large a role in the public life of New Netherland as it did in New England, with its Puritan population.

name: new_york
sentence: Historically, New York served as the foundation for new Christian denominations in the Second Great Awakening.

name: new_york
sentence: Non-Western Christian traditions and non-Christian religions did not grow for much of the state's history because immigration was predominantly from Western Europe (which at the time was dominated by Western Christianity and favored by the quotas in federal immigration law).

name: new_york
sentence: The Immigration and Nationality Act of 1965 removed the quotas, allowing for the growth of other religious groups.

name: new_york
sentence: The Roman Catholic Church is the largest Christian denomination in New York (31%).

name: new_york
sentence: The largest Roman Catholic diocese is the Latin Church's Archdiocese of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The largest Eastern Catholic diocese is the Ruthenian Catholic Eparchy of Passaic of the Ruthenian Greek Catholic Church.

name: new_york
sentence: The United Methodist Church is the largest Mainline Protestant denomination and second largest overall, followed by the Episcopal Church in the US and other Continuing Anglican bodies.

name: new_york
sentence: The Presbyterian Church (USA), Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, and American Baptist Churches USA were the following largest Mainline denominations.

name: new_york
sentence: Mainline Protestants together make up 11% of Christians in the state.

name: new_york
sentence: In Evangelical Protestantism the Baptists, non-denominational Protestants, and Pentecostals were the largest groups.

name: new_york
sentence: The National Baptist Convention (USA) and Progressive National Baptist Convention were the largest historically-black Protestant churches in New York.

name: new_york
sentence: Roughly 10% of Christians in New York are Evangelical Protestants.

name: new_york
sentence: The Eastern and Oriental Orthodox collectively comprised 1% of the religious demographic alongside Jehovah's Witnesses and other Christians.

name: new_york
sentence: Non-Christian faiths accounted for 12% of the religious population.

name: new_york
sentence: Judaism is the second largest religion as of 2014.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2010, 588,500 practiced Orthodox Judaism.

name: new_york
sentence: A little over 392,953 professed Islam.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is home to the oldest Zoroastrian fire temple in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Less than 1% of New York's population practice New Age and contemporary paganism.

name: new_york
sentence: Native American religions are also a prominent minority.

name: new_york
sentence: The irreligious are a growing community in the New York City metropolitan area.

name: new_york
sentence: Statewide, 17% practice nothing in particular and 5% each are atheists and agnostic.

name: new_york
sentence: Roughly 3.8 percent of the state's adult population self-identifies as lesbian, gay, bisexual, or transgender.

name: new_york
sentence: This constitutes a total LGBT adult population of 570,388 individuals.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2010, the number of same-sex couple households stood at roughly 48,932.

name: new_york
sentence: New York was the fifth state to license same-sex marriages, after New Hampshire.

name: new_york
sentence: Michael Bloomberg, the Mayor of New York City, said "same-sex marriages in New York City have generated an estimated $259 million in economic impact and $16 million in City revenues" in the first year after enactment of the Marriage Equality Act.

name: new_york
sentence: Same-sex marriages in New York were legalized on June 24, 2011, and were authorized to take place beginning thirty days thereafter.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City is also home to the largest transgender population in the United States, estimated at 25,000 in 2016.

name: new_york
sentence: The annual New York City Pride March (or gay pride parade) traverses southward down Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, ending at Greenwich Village, and rivals the Sao Paulo Gay Pride Parade as the largest pride parade in the world, attracting tens of thousands of participants and millions of sidewalk spectators each June.

name: new_york
sentence: The Stonewall riots were a series of spontaneous, violent demonstrations by members of the gay community against a police raid that took place in the early morning hours of June 28, 1969, at the Stonewall Inn in the Greenwich Village neighborhood within Lower Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: They are widely considered to constitute the single most important event leading to the gay liberation movement and the modern fight for LGBT rights.

name: new_york
sentence: In June 2017, plans were announced for the first official monument to LGBT individuals commissioned by the State of New York, in contrast to the Stonewall National Monument, which was commissioned by the US federal government.

name: new_york
sentence: The State monument is planned to be built in Hudson River Park in Manhattan, near the waterfront Hudson River piers which have served as historically significant symbols of New York's central role as a meeting place and a safe haven for LGBT communities.

name: new_york
sentence: Also as of 2017, plans were advancing by the State of New York to host the largest international LGBT pride celebration in 2019, known as Stonewall 50 – WorldPride NYC 2019, to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Stonewall Riots.

name: new_york
sentence: In New York City, the Stonewall 50–WorldPride NYC 2019 events produced by Heritage of Pride were enhanced through a partnership made with the I LOVE NY program's LGBT division and included a welcome center during the weeks surrounding the Stonewall 50 / WorldPride events that was open to all.

name: new_york
sentence: Additional commemorative arts, cultural, and educational programing to mark the 50th anniversary of the rebellion at the Stonewall Inn took place throughout the city and the world; Stonewall 50 – WorldPride NYC 2019 was the largest LGBT pride celebration held in history, drawing an estimated five million people.

name: new_york
sentence: Brooklyn Liberation March, the largest transgender-rights demonstration in LGBTQ history, took place on June 14, 2020 stretching from Grand Army Plaza to Fort Greene, Brooklyn, focused on supporting Black transgender lives, drawing an estimated 15,000 to 20,000 participants.

name: new_york
sentence: New York's gross state product in 2018 was $1.7 trillion.

name: new_york
sentence: If New York State were an independent nation, it would rank as the 11th largest economy in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: However, in 2013, the multi-state, New York City-centered metropolitan statistical area produced a gross metropolitan product (GMP) of nearly $1.4 trillion, while in 2012, the corresponding combined statistical area generated a GMP of over $1.7 trillion, both ranking first nationally by a wide margin and behind the GDP of only nine nations.

name: new_york
sentence: Anchored by Wall Street in the Financial District of Lower Manhattan, New York City has been called both the most economically powerful city and the leading financial center of the world.

name: new_york
sentence: Lower Manhattan is the third-largest central business district in the United States and is home to the New York Stock Exchange, on Wall Street, and the NASDAQ, at 165 Broadway, representing the world's largest and second largest stock exchanges, respectively, as measured both by overall average daily trading volume and by total market capitalization of their listed companies in 2013.

name: new_york
sentence: Investment banking fees on Wall Street totaled approximately $40 billion in 2012, while in 2013, senior New York City bank officers who manage risk and compliance functions earned as much as $324,000 annually.

name: new_york
sentence: In fiscal year 2013–14, Wall Street's securities industry generated 19% of New York State's tax revenue.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City remains the largest global center for trading in public equity and debt capital markets, driven in part by the size and financial development of the US economy.

name: new_york
sentence: New York also leads in hedge fund management

name: new_york
sentence: Several investment banks and investment managers headquartered in Manhattan are important participants in other global financial centers.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is also the principal commercial banking center of the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Many of the world's largest media conglomerates are also based in the city.

name: new_york
sentence: Manhattan contained approximately 520 million square feet (48.1 million m2) of office space in 2013, making it the largest office market in the United States, while Midtown Manhattan is the largest central business district in the nation.

name: new_york
sentence: Silicon Alley, centered in New York City, has evolved into a metonym for the sphere encompassing the New York City metropolitan region's high technology and entrepreneurship ecosystem; in 2015, Silicon Alley generated over $7.3 billion in venture capital investment.

name: new_york
sentence: High tech industries including digital media, biotechnology, software development, game design, and other fields in information technology are growing, bolstered by New York City's position at the terminus of several transatlantic fiber optic trunk lines, its intellectual capital, as well as its growing outdoor wireless connectivity.

name: new_york
sentence: In December 2014, New York State announced a $50 million venture-capital fund to encourage enterprises working in biotechnology and advanced materials; according to Governor Andrew Cuomo, the seed money would facilitate entrepreneurs in bringing their research into the marketplace.

name: new_york
sentence: On December 19, 2011, then Mayor Michael R.
