Bloomberg announced his choice of Cornell University and Technion-Israel Institute of Technology to build a two billion dollar graduate school of applied sciences on Roosevelt Island in Manhattan, with the goal of transforming New York City into the world's premier technology capital.

name: new_york
sentence: Albany, Saratoga County, Rensselaer County, and the Hudson Valley, collectively recognized as eastern New York's Tech Valley, have experienced significant growth in the computer hardware side of the high-technology industry, with great strides in the nanotechnology sector, digital electronics design, and water- and electricity-dependent integrated microchip circuit manufacturing, involving companies including IBM and its Thomas J. Watson Research Center, and the three foreign-owned firms, GlobalFoundries, Samsung, and Taiwan Semiconductor, among others.

name: new_york
sentence: The area's high technology ecosystem is supported by technologically focused academic institutions including Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and the SUNY Polytechnic Institute.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2015, Tech Valley, straddling both sides of the Adirondack Northway and the New York Thruway, generated over $163 million in venture capital investment.

name: new_york
sentence: The Rochester area is important in the field of photographic processing and imaging as well as incubating an increasingly diverse high technology sphere encompassing STEM fields, similarly in part the result of private startup enterprises collaborating with major academic institutions, including the University of Rochester and Cornell University.

name: new_york
sentence: Westchester County has developed a burgeoning biotechnology sector in the 21st century, with over a billion dollars in planned private investment as of 2016.

name: new_york
sentence: Creative industries, which are concerned with generating and distributing knowledge and information, such as new media, digital media, film and television production, advertising, fashion, design, and architecture, account for a growing share of employment, with New York City possessing a strong competitive advantage in these industries.

name: new_york
sentence: As of 2014, New York State was offering tax incentives of up to $420 million annually for filmmaking within the state, the most generous such tax rebate among the US states.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has also attracted higher-wage visual-effects employment by further augmenting its tax credit to a maximum of 35% for performing post-film production work in Upstate New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The filmed entertainment industry has been growing in New York, contributing nearly $9 billion to the New York City economy alone as of 2015.

name: new_york
sentence: I Love New York (stylized I ❤ NY) is a slogan, a logo and state song that are the basis of an advertising campaign and has been used since 1977 to promote tourism in the state of New York, including New York City.

name: new_york
sentence: The trademarked logo is owned by New York State Empire State Development.

name: new_york
sentence: The Broadway League reported that Broadway shows sold approximately $1.27 billion worth of tickets in the 2013–2014 season, an 11.4% increase from $1.139 billion in the 2012–2013 season.

name: new_york
sentence: Attendance in 2013–2014 stood at 12.21 million, representing a 5.5% increase from the 2012–2013 season's 11.57 million.

name: new_york
sentence: New York exports a wide variety of goods such as prepared foods, computers and electronics, cut diamonds, and other commodities.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2007, the state exported a total of $71.1 billion worth of goods, with the five largest foreign export markets being Canada ($15 billion), the United Kingdom ($6 billion), Switzerland ($5.9 billion), Israel ($4.9 billion), and Hong Kong ($3.4 billion).

name: new_york
sentence: New York's largest imports are oil, gold, aluminum, natural gas, electricity, rough diamonds, and lumber.

name: new_york
sentence: The state also has a large manufacturing sector that includes printing and the production of garments, mainly in New York City; and furs, railroad equipment, automobile parts, and bus line vehicles, concentrated in Upstate regions.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is the nation's third-largest grape producing state, and second-largest wine producer by volume, behind California.

name: new_york
sentence: The southern Finger Lakes hillsides, the Hudson Valley, the North Fork of Long Island, and the southern shore of Lake Erie are the primary grape- and wine-growing regions in New York, with many vineyards.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2012, New York had 320 wineries and 37,000 grape bearing acres, generating full-time employment for nearly 25,000 and annual wages over $1.1 billion, and yielding $4.8 billion in direct economic impact from New York grapes, grape juice, and wine and grape products.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York Agriculture industry is a major producer overall, ranking among the top five states for agricultural products including maple syrup, apples, cherries, cabbage, dairy products, onions, and potatoes.

name: new_york
sentence: The state is the largest producer of cabbage in the US

name: new_york
sentence: The state has about a quarter of its land in farms and produced $3.4 billion in agricultural products in 2001.

name: new_york
sentence: The south shore of Lake Ontario provides the right mix of soils and microclimate for many apple, cherry, plum, pear and peach orchards.

name: new_york
sentence: Apples are also grown in the Hudson Valley and near Lake Champlain.

name: new_york
sentence: A moderately sized saltwater commercial fishery is located along the Atlantic side of Long Island.

name: new_york
sentence: The principal catches by value are clams, lobsters, squid, and flounder.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2017, New York State consumed 156,370-gigawatthours (GWh) of electrical energy.

name: new_york
sentence: Downstate regions (Hudson Valley, New York City, and Long Island) consumed 66% of that amount.

name: new_york
sentence: Upstate regions produced 50% of that amount.

name: new_york
sentence: The peak load in 2017 was 29,699 MW.

name: new_york
sentence: The resource capability in 2017 was 42,839 MW.

name: new_york
sentence: The NYISO's market monitor described the average all-in wholesale electric price as a range (a single value was not provided) from $25 per MWh to $53 per MWh for 2017.

name: new_york
sentence: At the level of post-secondary education, the statewide public university system is the State University of New York (SUNY).

name: new_york
sentence: The SUNY system consists of 64 community colleges, technical colleges, undergraduate colleges, and doctoral-granting institutions, including several universities.

name: new_york
sentence: New York's flagship university is the University at Buffalo, which was founded by US President Millard Fillmore.

name: new_york
sentence: Along with the University at Buffalo, Binghamton University also ranks highly in the rankings of top public universities in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City has its own City University of New York (CUNY) system, which is funded by the city.

name: new_york
sentence: Columbia University, Cornell University and New York University are among the most prominent of the larger higher education institutions in New York, all of them leading, world-renowned private universities and members of the Association of American Universities, the pre-eminent group of research universities in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Other notable large private universities include Syracuse University and Fordham University.

name: new_york
sentence: Smaller notable private institutions of higher education include Rockefeller University, Mercy College, New York Institute of Technology, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Yeshiva University, and Hofstra University.

name: new_york
sentence: There are also a multitude of postgraduate-level schools in New York State, including medical, law, and engineering schools.

name: new_york
sentence: West Point, the service academy of the US Army, is located just south of Newburgh, on the west bank of the Hudson River.

name: new_york
sentence: The federal Merchant Marine Academy is at Kings Point on Long Island.

name: new_york
sentence: A number of selective private liberal arts institutions are located in New York.

name: new_york
sentence: Among them are Bard College, Barnard College, Colgate University, Hamilton College, Hobart and William Smith Colleges, Marist College, Sarah Lawrence College, Skidmore College, Union College, and Vassar College.

name: new_york
sentence: Two of these schools, Barnard and Vassar, are members of the elite Seven Sisters, originally all women's colleges with ties to the Ivy League.

name: new_york
sentence: Barnard is affiliated with Columbia University, its Manhattan neighbor, and Vassar became coeducational in 1969 after declining an offer to merge with Yale University.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is also home to what is widely regarded as the best performing arts schools in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: The Juilliard School, located in the Upper West Side of Manhattan, is one of the world's leading music and dance schools.

name: new_york
sentence: The Eastman School of Music, a professional school within the University of Rochester, was ranked first among US music schools by US News & World Report for five consecutive years.

name: new_york
sentence: The University of the State of New York accredits and sets standards for elementary, middle-level, and secondary education in the state, while the New York State Education Department oversees public schools and controls their standardized tests.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York City Department of Education manages the New York City Public Schools system.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1894, reflecting general racial discrimination then, the state passed a law that allowed communities to set up separate schools for children of African-American descent.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1900, the state passed another law requiring integrated schools.

name: new_york
sentence: During the 2013 fiscal year, New York spent more on public education per pupil than any other state, according to US Census Bureau statistics.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has one of the most extensive and one of the oldest transportation infrastructures in the country.

name: new_york
sentence: Engineering challenges posed by the complex terrain of the state and the unique infrastructural issues of New York City brought on by urban crowding have had to be overcome perennially.

name: new_york
sentence: Population expansion of the state has followed the path of the early waterways, first the Hudson River and Mohawk River, then the Erie Canal.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 19th century, railroads were constructed along the river valleys, followed by the New York State Thruway in the 20th century.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York State Department of Transportation (NYSDOT) is the department of the government of New York responsible for the development and operation of highways, railroads, mass transit systems, ports, waterways, and aviation facilities within New York State.

name: new_york
sentence: The NYSDOT is headquartered at 50 Wolf Road in Colonie, Albany County.

name: new_york
sentence: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey (PANYNJ) is a joint venture between the States of New York and New Jersey and authorized by the US Congress, established in 1921 through an interstate compact, that oversees much of the regional transportation infrastructure, including bridges, tunnels, airports, and seaports, within the geographical jurisdiction of the Port of New York and New Jersey.

name: new_york
sentence: This 1,500 sq mi (3,900 km2) port district is generally encompassed within a 25 mi (40 km) radius of the Statue of Liberty National Monument.

name: new_york
sentence: The Port Authority is headquartered at 4 World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: In addition to the well known New York City Subway system—which is confined within New York City—four suburban commuter railroad systems enter and leave the city: the Long Island Rail Road, Metro-North Railroad, Port Authority Trans-Hudson, and five of New Jersey Transit's rail lines.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York City Department of Transportation (NYCDOT) is the agency of the government of New York City responsible for the management of much of New York City's own transportation infrastructure.

name: new_york
sentence: Other cities and towns in New York have urban and regional public transportation.

name: new_york
sentence: In Buffalo, the Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority runs the Buffalo Metro Rail light-rail system; in Rochester, the Rochester Subway operated from 1927 until 1956, but fell into disuse as state and federal investment went to highways.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York State Department of Motor Vehicles (NYSDMV or DMV) is the governmental agency responsible for registering and inspecting automobiles and other motor vehicles, as well as licensing drivers in the State of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: As of 2008, the NYSDMV has 11,284,546 drivers licenses on file and 10,697,644 vehicle registrations in force.

name: new_york
sentence: All gasoline-powered vehicles registered in New York State are required to have an emissions inspection every 12 months, in order to ensure that environmental quality controls are working to prevent air pollution.

name: new_york
sentence: Diesel-powered vehicles with a gross weight rating over 8,500 pounds that are registered in most Downstate New York counties must get an annual emissions inspection.

name: new_york
sentence: All vehicles registered in New York State must get an annual safety inspection.

name: new_york
sentence: Portions of the transportation system are intermodal, allowing travelers to switch easily from one mode of transportation to another.

name: new_york
sentence: One of the most notable examples is AirTrain JFK which allows rail passengers to travel directly to terminals at John F. Kennedy International Airport as well as to the underground New York City Subway system.

name: new_york
sentence: The Government of New York embodies the governmental structure of the State of New York as established by the New York State Constitution.

name: new_york
sentence: It is composed of three branches: executive, legislative, and judicial.

name: new_york
sentence: The governor is the state's chief executive and is assisted by the lieutenant governor.

name: new_york
sentence: Both are elected on the same ticket.

name: new_york
sentence: Additional elected officers include the attorney general and the comptroller.

name: new_york
sentence: The secretary of state, formerly an elected officer, is currently appointed by the governor.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York State Legislature is bicameral and consists of the New York State Senatorte and the New York State Assembly.

name: new_york
sentence: The Assembly consists of 150 members, while the Senatorte varies in its number of members, currently having 63.

name: new_york
sentence: The Legislature is empowered to make laws, subject to the governor's power to veto a bill.

name: new_york
sentence: However, the veto may be overridden by the legislature if there is a two-thirds majority in favor of overriding in each house.

name: new_york
sentence: The permanent laws of a general nature are codified in the Consolidated Laws of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The highest court of appeal in the Unified Court System is the Court of Appeals whereas the primary felony trial court is the County Court (or the Supreme Court in New York City).

name: new_york
sentence: The Supreme Court also acts as the intermediate appellate court for many cases, and the local courts handle a variety of other matters including small claims, traffic ticket cases, and local zoning matters, and are the starting point for all criminal cases.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York City courts make up the largest local court system.

name: new_york
sentence: The state is divided into counties, cities, towns, and villages, all of which are municipal corporations with respect to their own governments, as well as various corporate entities that serve single purposes that are also local governments, such as school districts, fire districts, and New York state public-benefit corporations, frequently known as authorities or development corporations.

name: new_york
sentence: Each municipal corporation is granted varying home rule powers as provided by the New York Constitution.

name: new_york
sentence: The state also has 10 Indian reservations.

name: new_york
sentence: There have been several movements regarding secession from the state of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: Proposals have included a state of Long Island, consisting of everything on the island outside New York City; a state called Niagara, the western counties of New York state; the northern counties of New York state called Upstate New York; making the city of New York a state; a proposal for a new Peconic County on eastern Long Island; and for the borough of Staten Island to secede from New York City.

name: new_york
sentence: Capital punishment was reintroduced in 1995 under the Pataki administration, but the statute was declared unconstitutional in 2004, when the New York Court of Appeals ruled in People v. LaValle that it violated the state constitution.

name: new_york
sentence: The remaining death sentence was commuted by the court to life imprisonment in 2007, in People v. John Taylor, and the death row was disestablished in 2008, under executive order from Governor David Paterson.

name: new_york
sentence: No execution has taken place in New York since 1963.

name: new_york
sentence: Legislative efforts to amend the statute have failed, and death sentences are no longer sought at the state level, though certain crimes that fall under the jurisdiction of the federal government are subject to the federal death penalty.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is represented by Chuck Schumer and Kirsten Gillibrand in the United States Senatorte.

name: new_york
sentence: There are twenty-seven congressional districts, the nation's third equal highest number of congressional districts, equal with Florida and behind California's 53 and Texas's 36.

name: new_york
sentence: As of 2019, twenty-one districts are represented by members of the Democratic Party, while six are represented by Republicans.

name: new_york
sentence: Representation was reduced from 29 in 2013 due to the state's slower overall population growth relative to the overall national population growth.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has 29 electoral votes in national presidential elections, a drop from its peak of 47 votes from 1933 to 1953.

name: new_york
sentence: The state has a strong imbalance of payments with the federal government.

name: new_york
sentence: According to the Office of the New York State Comptroller, New York State received 91 cents in services for every $1 it sent in taxes to the US federal government in the 2013 fiscal year; New York ranked in 46th place in the federal balance of payments to the state on a per capita basis.

name: new_york
sentence: As of April 2016, Democrats represented a plurality of voters in New York State, constituting more than twice as many registered voters as any other political party affiliation or lack thereof.

name: new_york
sentence: Since the second half of the 20th century, New York has generally supported candidates belonging to the Democratic Party in national elections.

name: new_york
sentence: Democratic presidential candidate Barack Obama won New York State by over 25 percentage points in both 2012 and 2008.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City, as well as the state's other major urban locales, including Albany, Buffalo, Rochester, Yonkers, and Syracuse, are significant Democratic strongholds, with liberal politics.

name: new_york
sentence: Rural portions of upstate New York, however, are generally more conservative than the cities and tend to favor Republicans.

name: new_york
sentence: Heavily populated suburban areas downstate, such as Westchester County and Long Island, have swung between the major parties since the 1980s, but more often than not support Democrats.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City is the most important source of political fundraising in the United States for both major parties.

name: new_york
sentence: Four of the top five zip codes in the nation for political contributions are in Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: The top zip code, 10021 on the Upper East Side, generated the most money for the 2000 presidential campaigns of both George W. Bush and Al Gore.

name: new_york
sentence: The state of New York has the distinction of being the home state for both major-party nominees in three presidential elections.

name: new_york
sentence: The 1904 presidential election saw former New York Governor and incumbent President Theodore Roosevelt face Alton B. Parker, chief judge of the New York Court of Appeals.

name: new_york
sentence: The 1944 presidential election had Franklin D. Roosevelt, following in his cousin Theodore's footsteps as former New York Governor and incumbent president running for re-election against then-current New York Governor Thomas E. Dewey.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 2016 presidential election, former United States Senatortor from New York Hillary Clinton, a resident of Chappaqua, was the Democratic Party nominee.

name: new_york
sentence: The Republican Party nominee was businessman Donald Trump, a resident of Manhattan and a native of Queens.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City is an important center for international diplomacy.

name: new_york
sentence: The United Nations Headquarters has been situated on the East Side of Midtown Manhattan since 1952.

name: new_york
sentence: New York State is geographically home to one National Football League team, the Buffalo Bills, based in the Buffalo suburb of Orchard Park.

name: new_york
sentence: Although the New York Giants and New York Jets represent the New York metropolitan area and were previously located in New York City, they play in MetLife Stadium, located in East Rutherford, New Jersey.

name: new_york
sentence: New York also has two Major League Baseball teams, the New York Yankees (based in the Bronx) and the New York Mets (based in Queens).

name: new_york
sentence: Minor league baseball teams also play in the State of New York, including the Long Island Ducks, the Brooklyn Cyclones, and the Staten Island Yankees downstate, and the Rochester Red Wings, the Binghamton Rumble Ponies, the Syracuse Mets, the Auburn Doubledays, the Batavia Muckdogs, the Hudson Valley Renegades and the Buffalo Bisons upstate.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is home to three National Hockey League franchises: the New York Rangers in Manhattan, the New York Islanders in Brooklyn and Nassau County in Long Island, and the Buffalo Sabres in Buffalo.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has two National Basketball Association teams, the New York Knicks in Manhattan, and the Brooklyn Nets in Brooklyn.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is the home of a Major League Soccer franchise, New York City FC, currently playing in the Bronx.

name: new_york
sentence: Although the New York Red Bulls represent the New York metropolitan area, they play in Red Bull Arena in Harrison, New Jersey.

name: new_york
sentence: New York hosted the 1932 and 1980 Winter Olympics at Lake Placid.

name: new_york
sentence: The 1980 Games are known for the USA–US ice hockey match dubbed the "Miracle on Ice", in which a group of American college students and amateurs defeated the heavily favored Soviet national ice hockey team 4–3 and went on to win the gold medal against Finland.

name: new_york
sentence: Along with St. Moritz, Switzerland and Innsbruck, Austria, Lake Placid is one of the three cities to have hosted the Winter Olympic Games twice.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City bid for the 2012 Summer Olympics but lost to London.

name: new_york
sentence: Several US national sports halls of fame are or have been situated in New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum is located in Cooperstown, Otsego County.

name: new_york
sentence: The National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame in Saratoga Springs, Saratoga County, honors achievements in the sport of thoroughbred horse racing.

name: new_york
sentence: The physical facility of the National Soccer Hall of Fame in Oneonta, also in Otsego County, closed in 2010, although the organization itself has continued inductions.

name: new_york
sentence: The annual United States Open Tennis Championships is one of the world's four Grand Slam tennis tournaments and is held at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows–Corona Park in the New York City borough of Queens.

name: new_york
sentence: New York state is also home to many intercollegiate division 1 sports programs.

name: new_york
sentence: The State University of New York's flagship University at Buffalo are the Buffalo Bulls.

name: new_york
sentence: Syracuse University's intercollegiate teams are the Syracuse Orange.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina ( (listen)) is a state in the southeastern region of the United States.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is the 28th largest and 9th-most populous of the 50 United States.

name: north_carolina
sentence: It is bordered by Virginia to the north, the Atlantic Ocean to the east, Georgia and South Carolina to the south, and Tennessee to the west.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Raleigh is the state's capital and Charlotte is its largest city.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Charlotte metropolitan area, with an estimated population of 2,569,213 in 2018, is the most-populous metropolitan area in North Carolina, the 23rd-most populous in the United States, and the largest banking center in the nation after New York City.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Raleigh metropolitan area is the second-largest metropolitan area in the state, with an estimated population of 1,362,540 in 2018, and is home to the largest research park in the United States, Research Triangle Park.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina was established as a royal colony in 1729 and is one of the original Thirteen Colonies.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is named in honor of King Charles I of England who first formed the English colony, Carolus being Latin for "Charles".

name: north_carolina
sentence: On November 21, 1789, North Carolina became the 12th state to ratify the United States Constitution.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the run-up to the American Civil War, North Carolina declared its secession from the Union on May 20, 1861, becoming the last of eleven states to join the Confederate States.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Following the Civil War, the state was restored to the Union on June 25, 1868.

name: north_carolina
sentence: On December 17, 1903, Orville and Wilbur Wright successfully piloted the world's first controlled, sustained flight of a powered, heavier-than-air aircraft at Kill Devil Hills in North Carolina's Outer Banks.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina uses the slogan "First in Flight" on state license plates to commemorate this achievement, alongside a newer alternative design bearing the slogan "First in Freedom" in reference to the Mecklenburg Declaration and Halifax Resolves.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is defined by a wide range of elevations and landscapes.

name: north_carolina
sentence: From west to east, North Carolina's elevation descends from the Appalachian Mountains to the Piedmont and Atlantic coastal plain.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina's Mount Mitchell at 6,684 feet (2,037 m) is the highest-point in North America east of the Mississippi River.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Most of the state falls in the humid subtropical climate zone; however, the western, mountainous part of the state has a subtropical highland climate.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina was inhabited for at least ten thousand years by succeeding prehistoric indigenous cultures.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Hardaway Site saw major periods of occupation dating to 10,000 years BP.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Before 200 AD, the people were building earthwork platform mounds, which were used for ceremonial and religious purposes.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Succeeding peoples, including those of the South Appalachian Mississippian culture, established by 1000 AD in the Piedmont and mountain region, continued to build this style of mounds.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In contrast to some of the larger centers of the classic Mississippian culture (as noted below), in what became known as the western Carolinas, northeastern Georgia and southeastern Tennessee, most of the larger towns had only one central platform mound.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The smaller settlements had none but developed close to the more prominent towns.

name: north_carolina
sentence: This area became known as the homelands of the historic Cherokee people, who are believed to have migrated over time from the Great Lakes area.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the 500–700 years preceding European contact, the Mississippian culture built large, complex cities and maintained far-flung regional trading networks.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Its largest city was Cahokia, which had numerous mounds for different purposes, a highly stratified society, and was located in present-day southwestern Illinois near the Mississippi River.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Native polities of the Mississippian culture fell apart and reformed as new groups, such as the Catawba, due to a series of destabilizing events known as the "Mississippian shatter zone".

name: north_carolina
sentence: As described by anthropologist Robbie Ethridge, the Mississippian shatter zone was an area of great instability, in what is now the American South, caused by the instability of Mississippian chiefdoms, high mortality from new Eurasian diseases, construction of a global capitalistic economy based on trading of Native American slaves, and the emergence of Native "militaristic slaving societies".

name: north_carolina
sentence: Historically documented tribes in the North Carolina region include the Carolina Algonquian-speaking tribes of the coastal areas, such as the Chowanoke, Roanoke, Pamlico, Machapunga, Coree, and Cape Fear Indians, who were the first encountered by the English; the Iroquoian-speaking Meherrin, Cherokee, and Tuscarora of the interior; and Southeastern Siouan tribes, such as the Cheraw, Waxhaw, Saponi, Waccamaw, and Catawba of the Piedmont.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the late 16th century, the first Spanish explorers traveling inland recorded meeting Mississippian culture people at Joara, a regional chiefdom near what later developed as Morganton.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Records of Hernando de Soto attested to his meeting with them in 1540.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 1567, Captain Juan Pardo led an expedition to claim the area for the Spanish colony and to establish another route to reach silver mines in Mexico.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Pardo made a winter base at Joara, which he renamed Cuenca.

name: north_carolina
sentence: His expedition built Fort San Juan and left a contingent of 30 men there, while Pardo traveled further.

name: north_carolina
sentence: His forces built and garrisoned five other forts.

name: north_carolina
sentence: He returned by a different route to Santa Elena on Parris Island, South Carolina, then a center of Spanish Florida.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the spring of 1568, natives killed all but one of the Spanish soldiers and burned the six forts in the interior, including the one at Fort San Juan.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Although the Spanish never returned to the interior, this effort marked the first European attempt at colonization of the interior of what became the United States.

name: north_carolina
sentence: A 16th-century journal by Pardo's scribe Bandera, and archaeological findings since 1986 at Joara, have confirmed the settlement.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 1584, Elizabeth I granted a charter to Sir Walter Raleigh, for whom the state capital is named, for land in present-day North Carolina (then part of the territory of Virginia).

name: north_carolina
sentence: It was the second American territory which the English attempted to colonize.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Raleigh established two colonies on the coast in the late 1580s, but both failed.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The fate of the "Lost Colony" of Roanoke Island remains one of the most widely debated mysteries of American history.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Virginia Dare, the first English child to be born in North America, was born on Roanoke Island on August 18, 1587; Dare County is named for her.

name: north_carolina
sentence: As early as 1650, settlers from the Virginia colony moved into the area of Albemarle Sound.

name: north_carolina
sentence: By 1663, King Charles II of England granted a charter to start a new colony on the North American continent; it generally established North Carolina's borders.

name: north_carolina
sentence: He named it Carolina in honor of his father, Charles I.

name: north_carolina
sentence: By 1665, a second charter was issued to attempt to resolve territorial questions.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 1710, owing to disputes over governance, the Carolina colony began to split into North Carolina and South Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The latter became a crown colony in 1729.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Later in the 1700s, a series of smallpox epidemics swept the South, causing high fatalities among the Native Americans, who had no immunity to the new disease (it had become endemic over centuries in Europe).

name: north_carolina
sentence: According to the historian Russell Thornton, "The 1738 epidemic was said to have killed one-half of the Cherokee, with other tribes of the area suffering equally."

name: north_carolina
sentence: After the Spanish in the 16th century, the first permanent European settlers of North Carolina were English colonists who migrated south from Virginia.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The latter had grown rapidly and land was less available.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Nathaniel Batts was documented as one of the first of these Virginian migrants.

name: north_carolina
sentence: He settled south of the Chowan River and east of the Great Dismal Swamp in 1655.

name: north_carolina
sentence: By 1663, this northeastern area of the Province of Carolina, known as the Albemarle Settlements, was undergoing full-scale English settlement.

name: north_carolina
sentence: During the same period, the English monarch Charles II gave the province to the Lords Proprietors, a group of noblemen who had helped restore him to the throne in 1660.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The new Province of Carolina was named in honor and memory of his father, Charles I (Latin: Carolus).

name: north_carolina
sentence: A large revolt happened in the state in 1711, known as Cary's Rebellion.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 1712, North Carolina became a separate colony.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Except for the Earl Granville holdings, it became a royal colony seventeen years later.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In June 1718, the pirate Blackbeard ran his flagship, the Queen Anne's Revenge, aground at Beaufort Inlet, North Carolina, in present-day Carteret County.

name: north_carolina
sentence: After the grounding her crew and supplies were transferred to smaller ships.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In November, after appealing to the governor of North Carolina, who promised safe-haven and a pardon, Blackbeard was killed in an ambush by troops from Virginia.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 1996 Intersal, Inc., a private firm, discovered the remains of a vessel likely to be the Queen Anne's Revenge, which was added to the US National Register of Historic Places.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina became one of the English Thirteen Colonies and with the territory of South Carolina was originally known as the Province of North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The northern and southern parts of the original province separated in 1729.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Originally settled by small farmers, sometimes having a few slaves, who were oriented toward subsistence agriculture, the colony lacked cities or towns.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Pirates menaced the coastal settlements, but by 1718 the pirates had been captured and killed.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Growth was strong in the middle of the 18th century, as the economy attracted Scots-Irish, Quaker, English and German immigrants.

name: north_carolina
sentence: A majority of the colonists generally supported the American Revolution, and a smaller number of Loyalists than in some other colonies such as Georgia, South Carolina, Delaware, and New York.

name: north_carolina
sentence: During colonial times, Edenton served as the state capital beginning in 1722, and New Bern was selected as the capital in 1766.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Construction of Tryon Palace, which served as the residence and offices of the provincial governor William Tryon, began in 1767 and was completed in 1771.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 1788 Raleigh was chosen as the site of the new capital, as its central location protected it from coastal attacks.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Officially established in 1792 as both county seat and state capital, the city was named after Sir Walter Raleigh, sponsor of Roanoke, the "lost colony" on Roanoke Island.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The population of the colony more than quadrupled from 52,000 in 1740 to 270,000 in 1780 from high immigration from Virginia, Maryland and Pennsylvania plus immigrants from abroad.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Differences in the settlement patterns of eastern and western North Carolina, or the Tidewater and uplands, affected the political, economic, and social life of the state from the 18th until the 20th century.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Tidewater in eastern North Carolina was settled chiefly by immigrants from rural England and the Scottish Highlands.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The upcountry of western North Carolina was settled chiefly by Scots-Irish, English, and German Protestants, the so-called "cohee".

name: north_carolina
sentence: Arriving during the mid- to late 18th century, the Scots-Irish from what is today Northern Ireland were the largest non-English immigrant group before the Revolution; English indentured servants were overwhelmingly the largest immigrant group before the Revolution.

name: north_carolina
sentence: During the American Revolutionary War, the English and Highland Scots of eastern North Carolina tended to remain loyal to the British Crown, because of longstanding business and personal connections with Great Britain.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The English, Welsh, Scots-Irish, and German settlers of western North Carolina tended to favor American independence from Britain.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Most of the English colonists had arrived as indentured servants, hiring themselves out as laborers for a fixed period to pay for their passage.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the early years the line between indentured servants and African slaves or laborers was fluid.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Some Africans were allowed to earn their freedom before slavery became a lifelong status.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Most of the free colored families formed in North Carolina before the Revolution were descended from unions or marriages between free white women and enslaved or free African or African-American men.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Because the mothers were free, their children were born free.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Many had migrated or were descendants of migrants from colonial Virginia.

name: north_carolina
sentence: As the flow of indentured laborers to the colony decreased with improving economic conditions in Great Britain, planters imported more slaves, and the state's legal delineations between free and slave status tightened, effectively hardening the latter into a racial caste.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The economy's growth and prosperity was based on slave labor, devoted primarily to the production of tobacco.

name: north_carolina
sentence: On April 12, 1776, the colony became the first to instruct its delegates to the Continental Congress to vote for independence from the British Crown, through the Halifax Resolves passed by the North Carolina Provincial Congress.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The date of this event is memorialized on the state flag and state seal.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Throughout the Revolutionary War, fierce guerrilla warfare erupted between bands of pro-independence and pro-British colonists.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In some cases the war was also an excuse to settle private grudges and rivalries.

name: north_carolina
sentence: During the Revolutionary War, North Carolina had around 7,800 men join the Continental Army under General George Washington; and an additional 10,000 served in local militia units under such leaders as General Nathanael Greene.

name: north_carolina
sentence: There was some military action, especially in 1780–81.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Many Carolinian frontiersmen had moved west over the mountains, into the Washington District (later known as Tennessee), but in 1789, following the Revolution, the state was persuaded to relinquish its claim to the western lands.

name: north_carolina
sentence: It ceded them to the national government so the Northwest Territory could be organized and managed nationally.

name: north_carolina
sentence: A major American victory in the war took place at King's Mountain along the North Carolina–South Carolina border; on October 7, 1780, a force of 1,000 mountain men from western North Carolina (including what is today the state of Tennessee) and southwest Virginia overwhelmed a force of some 1,000 British troops led by Major Patrick Ferguson.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Most of the soldiers fighting for the British side in this battle were Carolinians who had remained loyal to the Crown (they were called "Tories" or Loyalists).

name: north_carolina
sentence: The American victory at Kings Mountain gave the advantage to colonists who favored American independence, and it prevented the British Army from recruiting new soldiers from the Tories.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The road to Yorktown and America's independence from Great Britain led through North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: As the British Army moved north from victories in Charleston and Camden, South Carolina, the Southern Division of the Continental Army and local militia prepared to meet them.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Following General Daniel Morgan's victory over the British Cavalry Commander Banastre Tarleton at the Battle of Cowpens on January 17, 1781, southern commander Nathanael Greene led British Lord Charles Cornwallis across the heartland of North Carolina, and away from the latter's base of supply in Charleston, South Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: This campaign is known as "The Race to the Dan" or "The Race for the River".

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the Battle of Cowan's Ford, Cornwallis met resistance along the banks of the Catawba River at Cowan's Ford on February 1, 1781, in an attempt to engage General Morgan's forces during a tactical withdrawal.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Morgan had moved to the northern part of the state to combine with General Greene's newly recruited forces.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Generals Greene and Cornwallis finally met at the Battle of Guilford Courthouse in present-day Greensboro on March 15, 1781.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Although the British troops held the field at the end of the battle, their casualties at the hands of the numerically superior Continental Army were crippling.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Following this "Pyrrhic victory", Cornwallis chose to move to the Virginia coastline to get reinforcements, and to allow the Royal Navy to protect his battered army.

name: north_carolina
sentence: This decision would result in Cornwallis' eventual defeat at Yorktown, Virginia, later in 1781.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Patriots' victory there guaranteed American independence.

name: north_carolina
sentence: On November 21, 1789, North Carolina became the twelfth state to ratify the Constitution.

name: north_carolina
sentence: After 1800, cotton and tobacco became important export crops.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The eastern half of the state, especially the Tidewater region, developed a slave society based on a plantation system and slave labor.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Besides slaves, there were a number of free people of color in the state.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Most were descendants from free African Americans who had migrated along with neighbors from Virginia during the 18th century.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The majority were the descendants of unions in the working classes between white women, indentured servants or free, and African men, indentured, slave or free.

name: north_carolina
sentence: After the Revolution, Quakers and Mennonites worked to persuade slaveholders to free their slaves.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Some were inspired by their efforts and the language of the Revolution to arrange for manumission of their slaves.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The number of free people of color rose markedly in the first couple of decades after the Revolution.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Many free people of color migrated to the frontier, along with their European-American neighbors, where the social system was looser.

name: north_carolina
sentence: By 1810, nearly three percent of the free population consisted of free people of color, who numbered slightly more than 10,000.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The western areas were dominated by white families, especially Scots-Irish, who operated small subsistence farms.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the early national period, the state became a center of Jeffersonian and Jacksonian democracy, with a strong Whig presence, especially in the western part of the state.

name: north_carolina
sentence: After Nat Turner's slave uprising in 1831, North Carolina and other southern states reduced the rights of free blacks.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 1835, the legislature withdrew their right to vote.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Southern slave codes criminalized willful killing of a slave in most cases.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Planters owning large estates wielded significant political and socio-economic power in antebellum North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: They placed their interests above those of the generally non-slave-holding "yeoman" farmers of western North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In mid-century, the state's rural and commercial areas were connected by the construction of a 129 mi (208 km) wooden plank road, known as a "farmer's railroad", from Fayetteville in the east to Bethania (northwest of Winston-Salem).

name: north_carolina
sentence: On October 25, 1836, construction began on the Wilmington and Raleigh Railroad to connect the port city of Wilmington with the state capital of Raleigh.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 1840, the state capitol building in Raleigh was completed, and still stands today.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 1849, the North Carolina Railroad was created by act of the legislature to extend that railroad west to Greensboro, High Point, and Charlotte.

name: north_carolina
sentence: During the Civil War, the Wilmington-to-Raleigh stretch of the railroad would be vital to the Confederate war effort; supplies shipped into Wilmington would be moved by rail through Raleigh to the Confederate capital of Richmond, Virginia.

name: north_carolina
sentence: While slaveholding was slightly less concentrated than in some Southern states, according to the 1860 census, more than 330,000 people, or 33% of the population of 992,622, were enslaved African Americans.

name: north_carolina
sentence: They lived and worked chiefly on plantations in the eastern Tidewater.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In addition, 30,463 free people of color lived in the state.

name: north_carolina
sentence: They were also concentrated in the eastern coastal plain, especially at port cities such as Wilmington and New Bern, where a variety of jobs were available.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The decades of tensions over issues of slavery, would lead to the main cause of the Civil War.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina was known as a 'Slave State' by 1860, in which one-third of the population was enslaved.

name: north_carolina
sentence: This was a smaller proportion than in many other Southern states.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The state did not vote to join the Confederacy until President Abraham Lincoln called on it to invade its sister state, South Carolina, becoming the last or penultimate state to officially join the Confederacy.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The title of "last to join the Confederacy" has been disputed; although Tennessee's informal secession on May 7, 1861, preceded North Carolina's official secession on May 20, the Tennessee legislature did not formally vote to secede until June 8, 1861.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Around 125,000 troops from North Carolina served in the Confederate Army, and about 15,000 North Carolina troops served in Union Army regiments, with many other men leaving the state to join Union regiments elsewhere.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Over 30,000 North Carolina troops died from disease, battlefield wounds, or starvation.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Elected in 1862, Governor Zebulon Baird Vance tried to maintain state autonomy against Confederate President Jefferson Davis in Richmond.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The state government was reluctant to support the demands of the national government in Richmond, and the state was the scene of only small battles.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 1865, Durham County saw the largest single surrender of Confederate soldiers when Joseph E. Johnston surrendered the Army of Tennessee and all remaining Confederate forces still active in North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, and Florida, totalling 89,270 soldiers.

name: north_carolina
sentence: After secession, some North Carolinians refused to support the Confederacy.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Some of the yeoman farmers in the state's mountains and western Piedmont region remained neutral during the Civil War, while some covertly supported the Union cause during the conflict.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Approximately 15,000 North Carolinians from across the state enlisted in the Union Army and fought for the North in the war.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Numerous slaves would also escape to Union lines, where they became essentially free.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Confederate troops from all parts of North Carolina served in virtually all the major battles of the Army of Northern Virginia, the Confederacy's most famous army.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The largest battle fought in North Carolina was at Bentonville, which was a futile attempt by Confederate General Joseph Johnston to slow Union General William Tecumseh Sherman's advance through the Carolinas in the spring of 1865.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In April 1865, after losing the Battle of Morrisville, Johnston surrendered to Sherman at Bennett Place, in what is today Durham.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina's port city of Wilmington was the last Confederate port to fall to the Union, in February 1865, after the Union won the nearby Second Battle of Fort Fisher, its major defense downriver.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The first Confederate soldier to be killed in the Civil War was Private Henry Wyatt from North Carolina, in the Battle of Big Bethel in June 1861.

name: north_carolina
sentence: At the Battle of Gettysburg in July 1863, the 26th North Carolina Regiment participated in Pickett/Pettigrew's Charge and advanced the farthest into the Northern lines of any Confederate regiment.

name: north_carolina
sentence: During the Battle of Chickamauga, the 58th North Carolina Regiment advanced farther than any other regiment on Snodgrass Hill to push back the remaining Union forces from the battlefield.

name: north_carolina
sentence: At Appomattox Court House in Virginia in April 1865, the 75th North Carolina Regiment, a cavalry unit, fired the last shots of the Confederate Army of Northern Virginia in the Civil War.

name: north_carolina
sentence: For many years, North Carolinians proudly boasted that they had been "First at Bethel, Farthest at Gettysburg and Chickamauga, and Last at Appomattox".

name: north_carolina
sentence: Following the collapse of the Confederacy in 1865, North Carolina, along with the rest of the former Confederate States, was put under direct control by the US military and was relieved of its constitutional government and representation within the United States Congress in what is now referred to as the Reconstruction era.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In order to earn back its rights, the state had to make concessions to Washington, one of which was ratifying the Thirteenth Amendment.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Congressional Republicans during Reconstruction, commonly referred to as "radical Republicans", constantly pushed for new constitutions for each of the Southern states that emphasized on equal rights for African-Americans.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 1868, a constitutional convention restored the state government of North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Though the Fifteenth Amendment was also adopted that same year, it remained in most cases ineffective for almost a century, not to mention paramilitary groups and their lynching with impunity.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The elections in April 1868 following the constitutional convention led to a narrow victory for a Republican-dominated government, with 19 African-Americans holding positions in the North Carolina State Legislature.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In attempt to put the reforms into effect, the new Republican Governor William W. Holden declared martial law on any county allegedly not complying with law and order using the passage of the Shoffner Act.

name: north_carolina
sentence: A Republican Party coalition of black freedmen, northern carpetbaggers and local scalawags controlled state government for three years.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The white conservative Democrats regained control of the state legislature in 1870, in part by Ku Klux Klan violence and terrorism at the polls, to suppress black voting.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Republicans were elected to the governorship until 1876, when the Red Shirts, a paramilitary organization that arose in 1874 and was allied with the Democratic Party, helped suppress black voting.

name: north_carolina
sentence: More than 150 black Americans were murdered in electoral violence in 1876.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Post civil war-debt cycles pushed people to switch from subsistence agriculture to commodity agriculture.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Among this time the notorious Crop-Lien system developed and was financially difficult on landless whites and blacks, due to high amounts of usury.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Also due to the push for commodity agriculture, the free range was ended.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Prior to this time people fenced in their crops and had their livestock feeding on the free range areas.

name: north_carolina
sentence: After the ending of the free range people now fenced their animals and had their crops in the open.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Democrats were elected to the legislature and governor's office, but the Populists attracted voters displeased with them.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 1896 a biracial, Populist-Republican Fusionist coalition gained the governor's office and passed laws that would extend the voting franchise to blacks and poor whites.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Democrats regained control of the legislature in 1896 and passed laws to impose Jim Crow and racial segregation of public facilities.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Voters of North Carolina's 2nd congressional district elected a total of four African-American congressmen through these years of the late 19th century.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Political tensions ran so high a small group of white Democrats in 1898 planned to take over the Wilmington government if their candidates were not elected.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the Wilmington Insurrection of 1898, more than 1,500 white men attacked the black newspaper and neighborhood, killed numerous men, and ran off the white Republican mayor and aldermen.

name: north_carolina
sentence: They installed their own people and elected Alfred M. Waddell as mayor, in the only coup d'état in United States history.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 1899, the state legislature passed a new constitution, with requirements for poll taxes and literacy tests for voter registration which disenfranchised most black Americans in the state.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Exclusion from voting had wide effects: it meant black Americans could not serve on juries or in any local office.

name: north_carolina
sentence: After a decade of white supremacy, many people forgot North Carolina had ever had thriving middle-class black Americans.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Black citizens had no political voice in the state until after the federal Civil Rights Act of 1964 and Voting Rights Act of 1965 were passed to enforce their constitutional rights.

name: north_carolina
sentence: It was not until 1992 that another African American was elected as a US Representative from North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: After the reconstruction era, North Carolina had become a one-party state, dominated by the Democratic Party.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The state mainly continued with an economy based on tobacco, cotton textiles and commodity agriculture.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Large towns and cities remained in few numbers.

name: north_carolina
sentence: However, a major industrial base emerged in the late 19th and early 20th century, in the counties of the Piedmont Triad, based on cotton mills established at the fall line.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Railroads were built to connect the new industrializing cities.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The state was the site of the first successful controlled, powered and sustained heavier-than-air flight, by the Wright brothers, near Kitty Hawk on December 17, 1903.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the first half of the 20th century, many African Americans left the state to go North for better opportunities, in the Great Migration.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Their departure changed the demographic characteristics of many areas.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina was hard hit by the Great Depression, but the New Deal programs of Franklin D. Roosevelt for cotton and tobacco significantly helped the farmers.

name: north_carolina
sentence: After World War II, the state's economy grew rapidly, highlighted by the growth of such cities as Charlotte, Raleigh, and Durham in the Piedmont region.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Raleigh, Durham, and Chapel Hill form the Research Triangle, a major area of universities and advanced scientific and technical research.

name: north_carolina
sentence: By the late 1960s, spurred in part by the increasingly leftward tilt of national Democrats, conservative whites began to vote for Republican national candidates and gradually for more Republicans locally.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Greensboro Sit-ins played a crucial role in the Civil Rights Movement to bring full equality to American blacks.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Since the 1970s, North Carolina has seen steady increases in population growth.

name: north_carolina
sentence: This growth has largely occurred in metropolitan areas located within the Piedmont Crescent, in places such as Charlotte, Raleigh, Greensboro, Winston-Salem, and Durham.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Charlotte metro has experienced large growth mainly due to its finance, banking, and tech industries.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina State, Duke University, and University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, have helped the Raleigh region (Research Triangle) attract an educated workforce and develop more jobs.

name: north_carolina
sentence: By the 1990s, Charlotte had become a major regional and national banking center.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Tourism has also been a boom for the North Carolina economy, as people flock to the Outer Banks coastal areas and the Appalachian Mountains anchored by Asheville.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is bordered by South Carolina on the south, Georgia on the southwest, Tennessee on the west, Virginia on the north, and the Atlantic Ocean on the east.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The United States Census Bureau places North Carolina in the South Atlantic division of the southern region.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina consists of three main geographic regions: the Atlantic coastal plain, occupying the eastern portion of the state; the central Piedmont region, and the Mountain region in the west, which is part of the Appalachian Mountains.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The coastal plain consists of more specifically-defined areas known as the Outer Banks, a string of sandy, narrow barrier islands separated from the mainland by sounds or inlets, including Albemarle Sound and Pamlico Sound, the tidewater region, the native home of the venus flytrap, and the inner coastal plain, where longleaf pine trees are native.

name: north_carolina
sentence: So many ships have been lost off Cape Hatteras that the area is known as the "Graveyard of the Atlantic"; more than a thousand ships have sunk in these waters since records began in 1526.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The most famous of these is the Queen Anne's Revenge (flagship of the pirate Blackbeard), which went aground in Beaufort Inlet in 1718.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The coastal plain transitions to the Piedmont region along the Atlantic Seaboard fall line, the elevation at which waterfalls first appear on streams and rivers.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Piedmont region of central North Carolina is the state's most populous region, containing the six largest cities in the state by population.

name: north_carolina
sentence: It consists of gently rolling countryside frequently broken by hills or low mountain ridges.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Small, isolated, and deeply eroded mountain ranges and peaks are located in the Piedmont, including the Sauratown Mountains, Pilot Mountain, the Uwharrie Mountains, Crowder's Mountain, King's Pinnacle, the Brushy Mountains, and the South Mountains.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Piedmont ranges from about 300 feet (91 m) in elevation in the east to about 1,500 feet (460 m) in the west.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The western section of the state is part of the Appalachian Mountain range.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Among the subranges of the Appalachian Mountains located in the state are the Great Smoky Mountains, Blue Ridge Mountains, and Black Mountains.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Black Mountains are the highest in the eastern United States, and culminate in Mount Mitchell at 6,684 feet (2,037 m), the highest point east of the Mississippi River.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has 17 major river basins.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The five basins west of the Blue Ridge Mountains flow to the Gulf of Mexico, while the remainder flow to the Atlantic Ocean.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Of the 17 basins, 11 originate within the state of North Carolina, but only four are contained entirely within the state's border—the Cape Fear, the Neuse, the White Oak, and the Tar–Pamlico basin.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Elevation above sea level is most responsible for temperature change across the state, with the mountain area being coolest year-round.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The climate is also influenced by the Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf Stream, especially in the coastal plain.

name: north_carolina
sentence: These influences tend to cause warmer winter temperatures along the coast, where temperatures only occasionally drop below the freezing point at night.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The coastal plain averages around 1 inch (2.5 cm) of snow or ice annually, and in many years, there may be no snow or ice at all.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Atlantic Ocean exerts less influence on the climate of the Piedmont region, which has hotter summers and colder winters than along the coast, though the average daily maximum is still below 90 °F (32 °C) in most locations.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina experiences severe weather both in summer and in winter, with summer bringing threat of hurricanes, tropical storms, heavy rain, and flooding.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Destructive hurricanes that have hit North Carolina include Hurricane Fran, Hurricane Florence, Hurricane Floyd, Hurricane Hugo, and Hurricane Hazel, the latter being the strongest storm ever to make landfall in the state, as a Category 4 in 1954.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Hurricane Isabel ranks as the most destructive of the 21st century.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina averages fewer than 20 tornadoes per year, many of them produced by hurricanes or tropical storms along the coastal plain.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Tornadoes from thunderstorms are a risk, especially in the eastern part of the state.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The western Piedmont is often protected by the mountains, which tend to break up storms as they try to cross over; the storms will often re-form farther east.

name: north_carolina
sentence: A phenomenon known as "cold-air damming" often occurs in the northwestern part of the state, which can weaken storms but can also lead to major ice events in winter.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In April 2011, the worst tornado outbreak in North Carolina's history occurred.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Thirty confirmed tornadoes touched down, mainly in the Eastern Piedmont and Sandhills, killing at least 24 people.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In September 2019 Hurricane Dorian hit the area.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The United States Census Bureau estimates that the population of North Carolina was 10,488,084 on July 1, 2019, an 9.99% increase since the 2010 Census.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Of the people residing in North Carolina 58.5% were born there; 33.1% were born in another state; 1.0% were born in Puerto Rico, US Island areas, or born abroad to American parent(s); and 7.4% were foreign-born.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Demographics of North Carolina covers the variety of ethnic groups who reside in North Carolina, along with the relevant trends.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The state's racial composition in the 2010 Census:

name: north_carolina
sentence: As of 2010, 89.66% (7,750,904) of North Carolina residents age five and older spoke English at home as a primary language, while 6.93% (598,756) spoke Spanish, 0.32% (27,310) French, 0.27% (23,204) German, and Chinese (which includes Mandarin) was spoken as a main language by 0.27% (23,072) of the population five and older.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In total, 10.34% (893,735) of North Carolina's population age five and older spoke a mother language other than English.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is also home to a spectrum of different dialects of Southern American English and Appalachian English.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina residents since the colonial era, have historically been overwhelmingly Protestant – first Anglican, then Baptist and Methodist.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 1845, the Baptists split into regional associations of the North and South, over the issue of slavery.

name: north_carolina
sentence: By the late 19th century, the largest Protestant denomination in North Carolina were Baptists.

name: north_carolina
sentence: After emancipation, black Baptists quickly set up their own independent congregations in North Carolina and other states of the South, as they wanted to be free of white supervision.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Black Baptists developed their own state and national associations, such as the National Baptist Convention USA, Inc..

name: north_carolina
sentence: While Baptists have maintained the majority Protestant denomination in this part of the country (known as the Bible Belt), a wide variety of faiths are practiced by other residents in the state, including: Judaism, Islam, Baháʼí, Buddhism, and Hinduism.

name: north_carolina
sentence: As of 2010, the Southern Baptist Convention was the biggest denomination, with 4,241 churches and 1,513,000 members.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The second largest was the United Methodist Church, with 660,000 members and 1,923 churches.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The third was the Roman Catholic Church, with 428,000 members in 190 parishes.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The fourth greatest was the Presbyterian Church (USA), with 186,000 members and 710 congregations; this denomination was brought by Scots-Irish immigrants who settled the backcountry in the colonial era.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The state also has a special history with the Moravian Church, as settlers of this faith (largely of German origin) settled in the Winston-Salem area in the 18th and 19th centuries.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Presbyterians, historically Scots-Irish, have had a strong presence in Charlotte and in Scotland County.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Currently, the rapid influx of northerners and immigrants from Latin America, is steadily increasing ethnic and religious diversity.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The number of Roman Catholics and Jews in the state has increased, as well as general religious diversity.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The second-largest Protestant denomination in North Carolina, after Baptist traditions, is Methodism.

name: north_carolina
sentence: This tends to be strong in the northern Piedmont, especially in populous Guilford County.

name: north_carolina
sentence: There are also a substantial number of Quakers in Guilford County and northeastern North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Many universities and colleges in the state have been founded on religious traditions, and some currently maintain that affiliation, including:

name: north_carolina
sentence: The state also has several major seminaries, including the Southeastern Baptist Theological Seminary in Wake Forest, and the Hood Theological Seminary (AME Zion) in Salisbury.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2020, the US Census Bureau released its annual population estimate counts for North Carolina's counties.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Wake County has the largest population, while Mecklenburg County has the second largest population in North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2018, the US Census Bureau released 2018 population estimate counts for North Carolina's cities with populations above 70,000.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Charlotte has the largest population in the state, while Raleigh has the highest population density of North Carolina's largest cities.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has three major Combined Statistical Areas with populations of more than 1.6 million (US Census Bureau 2018 estimates):

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina's 2018 total gross state product was $496 billion.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Based on American Community Survey 2010–2014 data, North Carolina's median household income was $46,693.

name: north_carolina
sentence: It ranked forty-first out of fifty states plus the District of Columbia for median household income.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina had the fourteenth highest poverty rate in the nation at 17.6%.

name: north_carolina
sentence: 13% of families were below the poverty line.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The state has a very diverse economy because of its great availability of hydroelectric power, its pleasant climate, and its wide variety of soils.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The state ranks third among the South Atlantic states in population, but leads the region in industry and agriculture.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina leads the nation in the production of tobacco, textiles, and furniture.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Charlotte, the state's largest city, is a major textile and trade center.

name: north_carolina
sentence: According to a Forbes article written in 2013 Employment in the "Old North State" has gained many different industry sectors.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) industries in the area surrounding North Carolina's capital have grown 17.9 percent since 2001, placing Raleigh-Cary at No.

name: north_carolina
sentence: 5 among the 51 largest metro areas in the country where technology is booming.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2010, North Carolina's total gross state product was $424.9 billion, while the state debt in November 2012, according to one source, totalled $2.4 billion, while according to another, was in 2012 $57.8 billion.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2011, the civilian labor force was at around 4.5 million with employment near 4.1 million.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is the leading US state in production of flue-cured tobacco and sweet potatoes, and comes second in the farming of pigs and hogs, trout, and turkeys.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the three most recent USDA surveys (2002, 2007, 2012), North Carolina also ranked second in the production of Christmas trees.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has 15 metropolitan areas, and in 2010 was chosen as the third-best state for business by Forbes Magazine, and the second-best state by Chief Executive Officer Magazine.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Since 2000, there has been a clear division in the economic growth of North Carolina's urban and rural areas.

name: north_carolina
sentence: While North Carolina's urban areas have enjoyed a prosperous economy with steady job growth, low unemployment, and rising wages, many of the state's rural counties have suffered from job loss, rising levels of poverty, and population loss as their manufacturing base has declined.

name: north_carolina
sentence: According to one estimate, one-half of North Carolina's 100 counties have lost population since 2010, primarily due to the poor economy in many of North Carolina's rural areas.

name: north_carolina
sentence: However, the population of the state's urban areas is steadily increasing.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The residents of North Carolina have a lower life expectancy than the national average of life expectancy.

name: north_carolina
sentence: According to the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation, in 2014 males in North Carolina lived an average of 75.4 years compared to a national average of 76.7 years.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Females in North Carolina lived an average of 80.2 years compared to a national average of 81.5 years.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Male life expectancy in North Carolina between 1980 and 2014 increased by an average of 6.9 years, compared to the national average of a 6.7 year increase in life expectancy for males.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Life expectancy for females in North Carolina between 1980 and 2014 increased by 4.0 years, identical to the national average of a 4.0 year increase in life expectancy for females.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Using 2016–2018 data, the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation calculated that life expectancy for North Carolina counties ranged from 73.2 years in Robeson County to 82.1 years in Orange County.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Life expectancy for both sexes in the state was 78.0 years compared to 78.7 years for the United States as a whole.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Transportation systems in North Carolina consist of air, water, road, rail, and public transportation including intercity rail via Amtrak and light rail in Charlotte.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has the second-largest state highway system in the country as well as the largest ferry system on the east coast.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina's airports serve destinations throughout the United States and international destinations in Canada, Europe, Central America, and the Caribbean.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2013 Charlotte Douglas International Airport, which serves as the second busiest hub for American Airlines, ranked as the 23rd busiest airport in the world.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has a growing passenger rail system with Amtrak serving most major cities.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Charlotte is also home to North Carolina's only light rail system known as the Lynx.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The government of North Carolina is divided into three branches: executive, legislative, and judicial.

name: north_carolina
sentence: These consist of the Council of State (led by the Governor), the bicameral legislature (called the General Assembly), and the state court system (headed by the North Carolina Supreme Court).

name: north_carolina
sentence: The state constitution delineates the structure and function of the state government.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has 13 seats in the US House of Representatives and two seats in the US Senatorte.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina's party loyalties have undergone a series of important shifts in the last few years: While the 2010 midterms saw Tar Heel voters elect a bicameral Republican majority legislature for the first time in more than a century, North Carolina has also become a Southern swing state in presidential races.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Since Southern Democrat Jimmy Carter's comfortable victory in the state in 1976, the state had consistently leaned Republican in presidential elections until Democrat Barack Obama narrowly won the state in 2008.
