name: north_carolina
sentence: In the 1990s, Democrat Bill Clinton came within a point of winning the state in 1992 and also only narrowly lost the state in 1996.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the early 2000s, Republican George W. Bush easily won the state by more than 12 points.

name: north_carolina
sentence: By 2008, demographic shifts, population growth, and increased liberalization in densely populated areas such as the Research Triangle, Charlotte, Greensboro, Winston-Salem, Fayetteville, and Asheville, propelled Barack Obama to victory in North Carolina, the first Democrat to win the state since 1976.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2012, North Carolina was again considered a competitive swing state, with the Democrats even holding their 2012 Democratic National Convention in Charlotte.

name: north_carolina
sentence: However, Republican Mitt Romney ultimately eked out a two-point win in North Carolina, the only 2012 swing state Obama lost, and one of only two states (along with Indiana) to flip from Obama in 2008 to the GOP in 2012.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2012, the state elected a Republican governor (Pat McCrory) and lieutenant governor (Dan Forest) for the first time in more than two decades, while also giving the Republicans veto-proof majorities in both the State House of Representatives and the State Senatorte.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Several US House of Representatives seats flipped control in 2012, with the Republicans holding nine seats to the Democrats' four.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the 2014 mid-term elections, Republican David Rouzer won the state's seventh congressional district seat, increasing the congressional delegation party split to 10–3 in favor of the GOP.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina Republicans won 10 of the 13 seats in 2016, when Democrats got 47 percent of the statewide vote.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2018 Republicans took nine, with one seat undecided, even though Democrats got 48 percent of the overall vote.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The undecided election in North Carolina's 9th congressional district was because the bipartisan State Election Board refused in February 2019 to certify the results, after an investigation found evidence of widespread ballot fraud committed by Republican operatives.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Because of gerrymandering in redistricting after the 2010 census, Democrats have been underrepresented in the state and Congressional delegations since 2012, although they have sometimes represented more than half the state's population.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The state was sued for racially gerrymandering the districts, which resulted in minority voting power being diluted in some areas, resulting in skewed representation.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The federal court ordered redistricting in 2015.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Two suits challenging the state congressional district map were led by "two dozen voters, the state Democratic Party, the state chapter of the League of Women Voters, and the interest group Common Cause".

name: north_carolina
sentence: They contend that the redistricting resulted in deliberate under-representation of a substantial portion of voters.

name: north_carolina
sentence: This case reached the United States Supreme Court in March 2019, which also heard a related partisan gerrymandering case from Maryland.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Elementary and secondary public schools are overseen by the North Carolina Department of Public Instruction.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The North Carolina Superintendent of Public Instruction is the secretary of the North Carolina State Board of Education, but the board, rather than the superintendent, holds most of the legal authority for making public education policy.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2009, the board's chairman also became the "chief executive officer" for the state's school system.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has 115 public school systems, each of which is overseen by a local school board.

name: north_carolina
sentence: A county may have one or more systems within it.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The largest school systems in North Carolina are the Wake County Public School System, Charlotte-Mecklenburg Schools, Guilford County Schools, Winston-Salem/Forsyth County Schools, and Cumberland County Schools.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In total there are 2,425 public schools in the state, including over 200 charter schools.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina Schools were segregated until the Brown v. Board of Education trial and the release of the Pearsall Plan.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 1795, North Carolina opened the first public university in the United States—the University of North Carolina (now named the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill).

name: north_carolina
sentence: More than 200 years later, the University of North Carolina system encompasses 17 public universities including North Carolina State University, North Carolina A&T State University, North Carolina Central University, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, the University of North Carolina at Greensboro, East Carolina University, Western Carolina University, Winston-Salem State University, the University of North Carolina at Asheville, the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, the University of North Carolina at Pembroke, UNC Wilmington, Elizabeth City State University, Appalachian State University, Fayetteville State University, and UNC School of the Arts, and .

name: north_carolina
sentence: Along with its public universities, North Carolina has 58 public community colleges in its community college system.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The largest university in North Carolina is currently North Carolina State University, with more than 34,000 students.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is also home to many well-known private colleges and universities, including Duke University, Wake Forest University, Pfeiffer University, Lees-McRae College, Davidson College, Barton College, North Carolina Wesleyan College, Elon University, Guilford College, Livingstone College, Salem College, Shaw University (the first historically black college or university in the South), Laurel University, William Peace University, Meredith College, Methodist University, Belmont Abbey College (the only Catholic college in the Carolinas), Campbell University, University of Mount Olive, Montreat College, High Point University, Lenoir-Rhyne University (the only Lutheran university in North Carolina) and Wingate University.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Early newspapers were established in the eastern part of North Carolina in the mid-18th century.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Fayetteville Observer, established in 1816, is the oldest newspaper still in publication in North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Wilmington Star-News, established 1867, is the oldest continuously running newspaper.

name: north_carolina
sentence: As of January 1, 2020, there were approximately 240 North Carolina newspapers in publication in the state of North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is home to four major league sports franchises: the Carolina Panthers of the National Football League, the Charlotte Hornets of the National Basketball Association, and Charlotte FC of Major League Soccer are based in Charlotte, while the Raleigh-based Carolina Hurricanes play in the National Hockey League.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Panthers and Hurricanes are the only two major professional sports teams that have the same geographical designation while playing in different metropolitan areas.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Hurricanes are the only major professional team from North Carolina to have won a league championship, having captured the Stanley Cup in 2006.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is also home to two other top-level professional teams in less prominent sports—the Charlotte Hounds of Major League Lacrosse and the North Carolina Courage of the National Women's Soccer League.

name: north_carolina
sentence: While North Carolina has no Major League Baseball team, it does have numerous minor league baseball teams, with the highest level of play coming from the AAA-affiliated Charlotte Knights and Durham Bulls.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Additionally, North Carolina has minor league teams in other team sports including soccer and ice hockey, most notably North Carolina FC and the Charlotte Checkers, both of which play in the second tier of their respective sports.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In addition to professional team sports, North Carolina has a strong affiliation with NASCAR and stock-car racing, with Charlotte Motor Speedway in Concord hosting two Cup Series races every year.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Charlotte also hosts the NASCAR Hall of Fame, while Concord is the home of several top-flight racing teams, including Hendrick Motorsports, Roush Fenway Racing, Richard Petty Motorsports, Stewart-Haas Racing, and Chip Ganassi Racing.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Numerous other tracks around North Carolina host races from low-tier NASCAR circuits as well.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Golf is a popular summertime leisure activity, and North Carolina has hosted several important professional golf tournaments.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Pinehurst Resort in Pinehurst has hosted a PGA Championship, Ryder Cup, two US

name: north_carolina
sentence: Opens, and one US Women's Open.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Wells Fargo Championship is a regular stop on the PGA Tour and is held at Quail Hollow Club in Charlotte, and Quail Hollow has also played host to the PGA Championship.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Wyndham Championship is played annually in Greensboro at Sedgefield Country Club.

name: north_carolina
sentence: College sports are also popular in North Carolina, with 18 schools competing at the Division I level.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC) is headquartered in Greensboro, and both the ACC Football Championship Game (Charlotte) and the ACC Men's Basketball Tournament (Greensboro) were most recently held in North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Additionally, the city of Charlotte is home to the National Junior College Athletics Association's (NJCAA) headquarters.

name: north_carolina
sentence: College basketball is very popular in North Carolina, buoyed by the Tobacco Road rivalries between ACC members North Carolina, Duke, North Carolina State, and Wake Forest.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The ACC Championship Game and the Duke's Mayo Bowl are held annually in Charlotte's Bank of America Stadium, featuring teams from the ACC and the Southeastern Conference.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Additionally, the state has hosted the NCAA Men's Basketball Final Four on two occasions, in Greensboro in 1974 and in Charlotte in 1994.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Charlotte is the most-visited city in the state, attracting 28.3 million visitors in 2018.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Area attractions include Carolina Panthers NFL football team and Charlotte Hornets basketball team, Carowinds amusement park, Charlotte Motor Speedway, US National Whitewater Center, Discovery Place, Great Wolf Lodge, Sea Life Aquarium, Bechtler Museum of Modern Art, Billy Graham Library, Carolinas Aviation Museum, Harvey B. Gantt Center for African-American Arts + Culture, Levine Museum of the New South, McColl Center for Art + Innovation, Mint Museum, and the NASCAR Hall of Fame.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Every year the Appalachian Mountains attract several million tourists to the western part of the state, including the historic Biltmore Estate.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The scenic Blue Ridge Parkway and Great Smoky Mountains National Park are the two most visited national park and unit in the United States with more than 25 million visitors in 2013.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The City of Asheville is consistently voted as one of the top places to visit and live in the United States, known for its rich art deco architecture, mountain scenery and outdoor activities.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In Raleigh, many tourists visit the Capital, African American Cultural Complex, Contemporary Art Museum of Raleigh, Gregg Museum of Art & Design at NCSU, Haywood Hall House & Gardens, Marbles Kids Museum, North Carolina Museum of Art, North Carolina Museum of History, North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences, North Carolina Sports Hall of Fame, Raleigh City Museum, J. C. Raulston Arboretum, Joel Lane House, Mordecai House, Montfort Hall, and the Pope House Museum.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Carolina Hurricanes NHL hockey team is also located in the city.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the Conover–Hickory area, Hickory Motor Speedway, RockBarn Golf and Spa, home of the Greater Hickory Classic at Rock Barn; Catawba County Firefighters Museum, and SALT Block attract many tourists to Conover.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Hickory which has Valley Hills Mall.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Piedmont Triad, or center of the state, is home to Krispy Kreme, Mayberry, Texas Pete, the Lexington Barbecue Festival, and Moravian cookies.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The internationally acclaimed North Carolina Zoo in Asheboro attracts visitors to its animals, plants, and a 57-piece art collection along five miles of shaded pathways in the world's largest-land-area natural-habitat park.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Seagrove, in the central portion of the state, attracts many tourists along Pottery Highway (NC Hwy 705).

name: north_carolina
sentence: MerleFest in Wilkesboro attracts more than 80,000 people to its four-day music festival; and Wet 'n Wild Emerald Pointe water park in Greensboro is another attraction.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Outer Banks and surrounding beaches attract millions of people to the Atlantic beaches every year.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The mainland northeastern part of the state, having recently adopted the name the Inner Banks, is also known as the Albemarle Region, for the Albemarle Settlements, some of the first settlements on North Carolina's portion of the Atlantic Coastal Plain.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The regions historic sites are connected by the Historic Albemarle Tour.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina provides a large range of recreational activities, from swimming at the beach to skiing in the mountains.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina offers fall colors, freshwater and saltwater fishing, hunting, birdwatching, agritourism, ATV trails, ballooning, rock climbing, biking, hiking, skiing, boating and sailing, camping, canoeing, caving (spelunking), gardens, and arboretums.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has theme parks, aquariums, museums, historic sites, lighthouses, elegant theaters, concert halls, and fine dining.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolinians enjoy outdoor recreation utilizing numerous local bike paths, 34 state parks, and 14 national parks.

name: north_carolina
sentence: National Park Service units include the Appalachian National Scenic Trail, the Blue Ridge Parkway, Cape Hatteras National Seashore, Cape Lookout National Seashore, Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site at Flat Rock, Fort Raleigh National Historic Site at Manteo, Great Smoky Mountains National Park, Guilford Courthouse National Military Park in Greensboro, Moores Creek National Battlefield near Currie in Pender County, the Overmountain Victory National Historic Trail, Old Salem National Historic Site in Winston-Salem, the Trail of Tears National Historic Trail, and Wright Brothers National Memorial in Kill Devil Hills.

name: north_carolina
sentence: National Forests include Uwharrie National Forest in central North Carolina, Croatan National Forest in Eastern North Carolina, Pisgah National Forest in the western mountains, and Nantahala National Forest in the southwestern part of the state.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has traditions in art, music, and cuisine.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The nonprofit arts and culture industry generates $1.2 billion in direct economic activity in North Carolina, supporting more than 43,600 full-time equivalent jobs and generating $119 million in revenue for local governments and the state of North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina established the North Carolina Museum of Art as the first major museum collection in the country to be formed by state legislation and funding and continues to bring millions into the NC economy.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Also see this list of museums in North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: One of the more famous arts communities in the state is Seagrove, the handmade-pottery capital of the US, where artisans create handcrafted pottery inspired by the same traditions that began in this community more than two hundred years ago.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina boasts a large number of noteworthy jazz musicians, some among the most important in the history of the genre.

name: north_carolina
sentence: These include: John Coltrane, (Hamlet, High Point); Thelonious Monk (Rocky Mount); Billy Taylor (Greenville); Woody Shaw (Laurinburg); Lou Donaldson (Durham); Max Roach (Newland); Tal Farlow (Greensboro); Albert, Jimmy and Percy Heath (Wilmington); Nina Simone (Tryon); and Billy Strayhorn (Hillsborough).

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is also famous for its tradition of old-time music, and many recordings were made in the early 20th century by folk-song collector Bascom Lamar Lunsford.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Musicians such as the North Carolina Ramblers helped solidify the sound of country music in the late 1920s, while the influential bluegrass musician Doc Watson also hailed from North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Both North and South Carolina are hotbeds for traditional rural blues, especially the style known as the Piedmont blues.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Ben Folds Five originated in Winston-Salem, and Ben Folds still records and resides in Chapel Hill.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The British band Pink Floyd is named, in part, after Chapel Hill bluesman Floyd Council.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Research Triangle area has long been a well-known center for folk, rock, metal, jazz and punk.

name: north_carolina
sentence: James Taylor grew up around Chapel Hill, and his 1968 song "Carolina in My Mind" has been called an unofficial anthem for the state.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Other famous musicians from North Carolina include J. Cole, Shirley Caesar, Roberta Flack, Clyde McPhatter, Nnenna Freelon, Warren Haynes, Jimmy Herring, Michael Houser, Eric Church, Future Islands, Randy Travis, Ryan Adams, Ronnie Milsap, Anthony Hamilton, The Avett Brothers and Luke Combs.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Metal and punk acts such as Corrosion of Conformity, Between the Buried and Me, and Nightmare Sonata are native to North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: EDM producer Porter Robinson hails from Chapel Hill.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is the home of more American Idol finalists than any other state: Clay Aiken (season two), Fantasia Barrino (season three), Chris Daugherty (season five), Kellie Pickler (season five), Bucky Covington (season five), Anoop Desai (season eight), Scotty McCreery (season ten), and Caleb Johnson (season thirteen).

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina also has the most American Idol winners with Barrino, McCreery, and Johnson.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the mountains, the Brevard Music Center hosts choral, operatic, orchestral, and solo performances during its annual summer schedule.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has five professional opera companies: Opera Carolina in Charlotte, NC Opera in Raleigh, Greensboro Opera in Greensboro, Piedmont Opera in Winston-Salem, and Asheville Lyric Opera in Asheville.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Academic conservatories and universities also produce fully staged operas, such as the A. J. Fletcher Opera Institute of the University of North Carolina School of the Arts in Winston-Salem, the Department of Music of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and UNC Greensboro.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Among others, there are three high-level symphonic orchestras: NC Symphony in Raleigh, Charlotte Symphony, and Winston-Salem Symphony.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The NC Symphony holds the North Carolina Master Chorale.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Carolina Ballet is headquartered in Raleigh, and there is also the Charlotte Ballet.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The state boasts three performing arts centers: DPAC in Durham, Duke Energy Center for the Performing Arts in Raleigh, and the Blumenthal Performing Art Centers in Charlotte.

name: north_carolina
sentence: They feature concerts, operas, recitals, and traveling Broadway musicals.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Hip-hop artists DaBaby and J. Cole hail from North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Also, see the North Carolina Music Hall of Fame.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has a variety of shopping choices.

name: north_carolina
sentence: SouthPark Mall in Charlotte is currently the largest in the Carolinas, with almost two million square feet.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Other major malls in Charlotte include Northlake Mall and Carolina Place Mall in nearby suburb Pineville.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Other major malls throughout the state include Hanes Mall in Winston-Salem, North Carolina, The Thruway Center in Winston-Salem, North Carolina, Crabtree Valley Mall, North Hills Mall, and Triangle Town Center in Raleigh; Friendly Center and Four Seasons Town Centre in Greensboro; Oak Hollow Mall in High Point; Concord Mills in Concord; Valley Hills Mall in Hickory; Cross Creek Mall in Fayetteville; and The Streets at Southpoint and Northgate Mall in Durham and Independence Mall in Wilmington, North Carolina, and Tanger Outlets in Charlotte, Nags Head, Blowing Rock, and Mebane, North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: A culinary staple of North Carolina is pork barbecue.

name: north_carolina
sentence: There are strong regional differences and rivalries over the sauces and methods used in making the barbecue.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The common trend across Western North Carolina is the use of premium grade Boston butt.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Western North Carolina pork barbecue uses a tomato-based sauce, and only the pork shoulder (dark meat) is used.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Western North Carolina barbecue is commonly referred to as Lexington barbecue after the Piedmont Triad town of Lexington, home of the Lexington Barbecue Festival, which attracts more than 100,000 visitors each October.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Eastern North Carolina pork barbecue uses a vinegar-and-red-pepper-based sauce and the "whole hog" is cooked, thus integrating both white and dark meat.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Krispy Kreme, an international chain of doughnut stores, was started in North Carolina; the company's headquarters are in Winston-Salem.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Pepsi-Cola was first produced in 1898 in New Bern.

name: north_carolina
sentence: A regional soft drink, Cheerwine, was created and is still based in the city of Salisbury.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Despite its name, the hot sauce Texas Pete was created in North Carolina; its headquarters are also in Winston-Salem.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Hardee's fast-food chain was started in Rocky Mount.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Another fast-food chain, Bojangles', was started in Charlotte, and has its corporate headquarters there.

name: north_carolina
sentence: A popular North Carolina restaurant chain is Golden Corral.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Started in 1973, the chain was founded in Fayetteville, with headquarters located in Raleigh.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Popular pickle brand Mount Olive Pickle Company was founded in Mount Olive in 1926.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Fast casual burger chain Hwy 55 Burgers, Shakes & Fries also makes its home in Mount Olive.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Cook Out, a popular fast-food chain featuring burgers, hot dogs, and milkshakes in a wide variety of flavors, was founded in Greensboro in 1989 and has begun expanding outside of North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2013, Southern Living named Durham–Chapel Hill the South's "Tastiest City".

name: north_carolina
sentence: Over the last decade, North Carolina has become a cultural epicenter and haven for internationally prize-winning wine (Noni Bacca Winery), internationally prized cheeses (Ashe County), "L'institut International aux Arts Gastronomiques: Conquerront Les Yanks les Truffes, January 15, 2010" international hub for truffles (Garland Truffles), and beer making, as tobacco land has been converted to grape orchards while state laws regulating alcohol by volume (ABV) in beer allowed a jump from six to fifteen percent.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Yadkin Valley in particular has become a strengthening market for grape production, while Asheville recently won the recognition of being named "Beer City USA".

name: north_carolina
sentence: Asheville boasts the largest number of breweries per capita of any city in the United States.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Recognized and marketed brands of beer in North Carolina include Highland Brewing, Duck Rabbit Brewery, Mother Earth Brewery, Weeping Radish Brewery, Big Boss Brewing, Foothills Brewing, Carolina Brewing Company, Lonerider Brewing, and White Rabbit Brewing Company.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has large grazing areas for beef and dairy cattle.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Truck farms can be found in North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: A truck farm is a small farm where fruits and vegetables are grown to be sold at local markets.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The state's shipping, commercial fishing, and lumber industries are important to its economy.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Service industries, including education, health care, private research, and retail trade, are also important.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Research Triangle Park, a large industrial complex located in the Raleigh-Durham area, is one of the major centers in the country for electronics and medical research.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Tobacco was one of the first major industries to develop after the Civil War.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Many farmers grew some tobacco, and the invention of the cigarette made the product especially popular.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Winston-Salem is the birthplace of R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company (RJR), founded by R. J. Reynolds in 1874 as one of sixteen tobacco companies in the town.

name: north_carolina
sentence: By 1914 it was selling 425 million packs of Camels a year.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Today it is the second-largest tobacco company in the US (behind Altria Group).

name: north_carolina
sentence: RJR is an indirect wholly owned subsidiary of Reynolds American Inc., which in turn is 42% owned by British American Tobacco.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Several ships have been named after the state, most famously USNorth Carolina in the Pacific Ocean theater of World War II.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Now decommissioned, she is part of the USNorth Carolina Battleship Memorial in Wilmington.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Another USNorth Carolina, a nuclear attack submarine, was commissioned in Wilmington on May 3, 2008.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The state maintains a group of protected areas known as the North Carolina State Park System, which is managed by the North Carolina Division of Parks & Recreation (NCDPR), an agency of the North Carolina Department of Environment and Natural Resources (NCDENR).

name: north_carolina
sentence: Fort Bragg, near Fayetteville and Southern Pines, is a large and comprehensive military base and is the headquarters of the XVIII Airborne Corps, 82nd Airborne Division, and the US Army Special Operations Command.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Serving as the air wing for Fort Bragg is Pope Field, also located near Fayetteville.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Located in Jacksonville, Marine Corps Base Camp Lejeune, combined with nearby bases Marine Corps Air Station (MCAS) Cherry Point, MCAS New River, Camp Geiger, Camp Johnson, Stone Bay and Courthouse Bay, makes up the largest concentration of Marines and sailors in the world.

name: north_carolina
sentence: MCAS Cherry Point is home of the 2nd Marine Aircraft Wing.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Located in Goldsboro, Seymour Johnson Air Force Base is home of the 4th Fighter Wing and 916th Air Refueling Wing.

name: north_carolina
sentence: One of the busiest air stations in the United States Coast Guard is located at the Coast Guard Air Station in Elizabeth City.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Also stationed in North Carolina is the Military Ocean Terminal Sunny Point in Southport.

name: north_carolina
sentence: On January 24, 1961, a B-52G broke up in midair and crashed after suffering a severe fuel loss, near Goldsboro, dropping two nuclear bombs in the process without detonation.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2013, it was revealed that three safety mechanisms on one bomb had failed, leaving just one low-voltage switch preventing detonation.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota ( (listen)) is a state in the Midwestern United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is named after the Lakota and Dakota Sioux Native American tribes, who comprise a large portion of the population and historically dominated the territory.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is the nineteenth largest in area, the fourth least populous, and the fourth most sparsely populated of the 50 states.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Its capital is Bismarck, and its largest city is Fargo.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota was admitted to the Union on November 2, 1889, along with its neighboring state, South Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They were the 39th and 40th states admitted to the union.

name: north_dakota
sentence: President Benjamin Harrison shuffled the statehood papers before signing them so that no one could tell which became a state first.

name: north_dakota
sentence: For convenience, the two states are officially numbered in alphabetical order.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the 21st century, North Dakota's natural resources have played a major role in its economic performance, particularly with the oil extraction from the Bakken formation, which lies beneath the northwestern part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Such development has led to population growth and reduced unemployment, resulting in North Dakota's having the second lowest unemployment rate in the nation (after Hawaii).

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is home to the tallest man-made structure in the Western Hemisphere, the KVLY-TV mast.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is located in the Upper Midwest region of the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It lies at the center of the North American continent and borders Canada to the north.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The geographic center of North America is near the town of Center.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Bismarck is the capital of North Dakota, and Fargo is the largest city.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Soil is North Dakota's most precious resource.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is the base of the state's great agricultural wealth.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota also has enormous mineral resources.

name: north_dakota
sentence: These mineral resources include billions of tons of lignite coal.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition, North Dakota has large oil reserves.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Petroleum was discovered in the state in 1951 and quickly became one of North Dakota's most valuable mineral resources.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the early 2000s, the emergence of hydraulic fracturing technologies enabled mining companies to extract huge amounts of oil from the Bakken shale rock formation in the western part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota's economy is based more heavily on farming than the economies of most other states.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many North Dakota factories process farm products or manufacture farm equipment.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many of the state's merchants also rely on agriculture.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Farms and ranches cover nearly all of North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They stretch from the flat Red River Valley in the east, across rolling plains, to the rugged Badlands in the west.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The chief crop, wheat, is grown in nearly every county.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota harvests more than 90 percent of the nation's canola and flaxseed.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is also the country's top producer of barley and sunflower seeds and a leader in the production of beans, honey, lentils, oats, peas, and sugar beets.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Few white settlers came to the North Dakota region before the 1870s because railroads had not yet entered the area.

name: north_dakota
sentence: During the early 1870s, the Northern Pacific Railroad began to push across the Dakota Territory.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Large-scale farming also began during the 1870s.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Eastern corporations and some families established huge wheat farms covering large areas of land in the Red River Valley.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The farms made such enormous profits they were called bonanza farms.

name: north_dakota
sentence: White settlers, attracted by the success of the bonanza farms, flocked to North Dakota, rapidly increasing the territory's population.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 1870, North Dakota had 2,405 people.

name: north_dakota
sentence: By 1890, the population had grown to 190,983.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota was named for the Sioux people who once lived in the territory.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Sioux called themselves Dakota or Lakota, meaning allies or friends.

name: north_dakota
sentence: One of North Dakota's nicknames is the Peace Garden State.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This nickname honors the International Peace Garden, which lies on the state's border with Manitoba, Canada.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is also called the Flickertail State because of the many flickertail ground squirrels (Richardson's ground squirrel) that live in the central part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is in the US region known as the Great Plains.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state shares the Red River of the North with Minnesota to the east.

name: north_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is to the south, Montana is to the west, and the Canadian provinces of Saskatchewan and Manitoba are to the north.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is near the middle of North America with a stone marker in Rugby, North Dakota marking the "Geographic Center of the North American Continent".

name: north_dakota
sentence: With an area of 70,762 square miles (183,273 km2), 69,001 square miles (178,712 km2) of which is land, North Dakota is the 19th largest state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The western half of the state consists of the hilly Great Plains as well as the northern part of the Badlands, which are to the west of the Missouri River.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state's high point, White Butte at 3,506 feet (1,069 m), and Theodore Roosevelt National Park are in the Badlands.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The region is abundant in fossil fuels including natural gas, crude oil and lignite coal.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Missouri River forms Lake Sakakawea, the third largest artificial lake in the United States, behind the Garrison Dam.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The central region of the state is divided into the Drift Prairie and the Missouri Plateau.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The eastern part of the state consists of the flat Red River Valley, the bottom of glacial Lake Agassiz.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Its fertile soil, drained by the meandering Red River flowing northward into Lake Winnipeg, supports a large agriculture industry.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Devils Lake, the largest natural lake in the state, is also found in the east.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Most of the state is covered in grassland

name: north_dakota
sentence: Natural trees in North Dakota are found usually where there is good drainage, such as the ravines and valley near the Pembina Gorge and Killdeer Mountains, the Turtle Mountains, the hills around Devil's Lake, in the dunes area of McHenry County in central North Dakota, and along the Sheyenne Valley slopes and the Sheyenne delta.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This diverse terrain supports nearly 2,000 species of plants.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has a continental climate with warm summers and cold winters.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The temperature differences are significant because of its far inland position and being in the center of the Northern Hemisphere, with roughly equal distances to the North Pole and the Equator.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Native American peoples lived in what is now North Dakota for thousands of years before the coming of Europeans.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The known tribes included the Mandan people (from around the 11th century), while the first Hidatsa group arrived a few hundred years later.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They both assembled in villages on tributaries of the Missouri River in what would become west-central North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Crow Indians traveled the plains from the west to visit and trade with the related Hidatsas after the split between them, probably in the 17th century.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Later came divisions of the Dakota people—the Lakota, the Santee and the Yanktonai.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Assiniboine and the Plains Cree undertook southward journeys to the village Indians, either for trade or for war.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Shoshone Indians in present-day Wyoming and Montana may have carried out attacks on Indian enemies as far east as the Missouri.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A group of Cheyennes lived in a village of earth lodges at the lower Sheyenne River (Biesterfeldt Site) for decades in the 18th century.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Due to attacks by Crees, Assiniboines and Chippewas armed with fire weapons, they left the area around 1780 and crossed Missouri some time after.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A band of the few Sotaio Indians lived east of Missouri River and met the uprooted Cheyennes before the end of the century.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They soon followed the Cheyennes across Missouri and lived among them south of Cannonball River.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Eventually, the Cheyenne and the Sutaio became one tribe and turned into mounted buffalo hunters with ranges mainly outside North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Before the middle of the 19th century, the Arikara entered the future state from the south and joined the Mandan and Hidatsa.

name: north_dakota
sentence: With time, a number of Indians entered into treaties with the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many of the treaties defined the territory of a specific tribe (see the map).

name: north_dakota
sentence: The first European to reach the area was the French-Canadian trader Pierre Gaultier, sieur de La Vérendrye, who led an exploration and trading party to the Mandan villages in 1738. guided by Assiniboine Indians.

name: north_dakota
sentence: From 1762 to 1802, the region formed part of Spanish Louisiana.

name: north_dakota
sentence: European Americans settled in Dakota Territory only sparsely until the late 19th century, when railroads opened up the region.

name: north_dakota
sentence: With the advantage of grants of land, they vigorously marketed their properties, extolling the region as ideal for agriculture.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Congress passed an omnibus bill for statehood for North Dakota, South Dakota, Montana, and Washington, titled the Enabling Act of 1889, on February 22, 1889 during the administration of President Grover Cleveland.

name: north_dakota
sentence: His successor, Benjamin Harrison, signed the proclamations formally admitting North Dakota and South Dakota to the Union on November 2, 1889.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The rivalry between the two new states presented a dilemma of which was to be admitted first.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Harrison directed Secretary of State James G. Blaine to shuffle the papers and obscure from him which he was signing first.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The actual order went unrecorded, thus no one knows which of the Dakotas was admitted first.

name: north_dakota
sentence: However, since North Dakota alphabetically appears before South Dakota, its proclamation was published first in the Statutes At Large.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Unrest among wheat farmers, especially among Norwegian immigrants, led to a populist political movement centered in the Non Partisan League ("NPL") around the time of World War I.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The NPL ran candidates on the Republican ticket (but merged into the Democratic Party after World War II).

name: north_dakota
sentence: It tried to insulate North Dakota from the power of out-of-state banks and corporations.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition to founding the state-owned Bank of North Dakota and North Dakota Mill and Elevator (both still in existence), the NPL established a state-owned railroad line (later sold to the Soo Line Railroad).

name: north_dakota
sentence: Anti-corporate laws virtually prohibited a corporation or bank from owning title to land zoned as farmland.

name: north_dakota
sentence: These laws, still in force today, after having been upheld by state and federal courts, make it almost impossible to foreclose on farmland, as even after foreclosure, the property title cannot be held by a bank or mortgage company.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Furthermore, the Bank of North Dakota, having powers similar to a Federal Reserve branch bank, exercised its power to limit the issuance of subprime mortgages and their collateralization in the form of derivative instruments, and so prevented a collapse of housing prices within the state in the wake of 2008's financial crisis.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The original North Dakota State Capitol in Bismarck burned to the ground on December 28, 1930.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It was replaced by a limestone-faced art-deco skyscraper that still stands today.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A round of federal investment and construction projects began in the 1950s, including the Garrison Dam and the Minot and Grand Forks Air Force bases.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Western North Dakota saw a boom in oil exploration in the late 1970s and early 1980s, as rising petroleum prices made development profitable.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This boom came to an end after petroleum prices declined.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In recent years, the state has had lower rates of unemployment than the national average, and increased job and population growth.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Much of the growth has been based on development of the Bakken oil fields in the western part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Estimates as to the remaining amount of oil in the area vary, with some estimating over 100 years' worth.

name: north_dakota
sentence: For decades, North Dakota's annual murder rate and the violent crime rate was regularly the lowest in the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In recent years, however, while still below the national average, crime has risen sharply.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2016, the violent crime rate was three times higher than in 2004, with the rise occurring mostly in the late 2000s, coinciding with the oil boom era.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This happened at a time when the national violent crime rate declined slightly.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Workers in the oil boom towns have been blamed for much of the increase.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The United States Census Bureau estimates North Dakota's population was 762,062 on July 1, 2019, a 13.30% increase since the 2010 United States Census.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This makes North Dakota the US state with the largest percentage in population growth since 2011.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is the fourth least-populous state in the country; only Alaska, Vermont, and Wyoming have fewer residents.

name: north_dakota
sentence: From fewer than 2,000 people in 1870, North Dakota's population grew to near 680,000 by 1930.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Growth then slowed, and the population has fluctuated slightly over the past seven decades, hitting a low of 617,761 in the 1970 census, with 642,200 in the 2000 census.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Except for Native Americans, the North Dakota population has a lesser percentage of minorities than in the nation as a whole.

name: north_dakota
sentence: As of 2011, 20.7% of North Dakota's population younger than age 1 were minorities.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The center of population of North Dakota is in Wells County, near Sykeston.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Note: Births in table don't add up, because Hispanics are counted both by their ethnicity and by their race, giving a higher overall number.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Throughout the latter half of the nineteenth century and into the early twentieth century, North Dakota, along with most of the midwest, experienced a mass influx of newcomers from both the eastern United States and immigrants from Europe.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota was a known popular destination for immigrant farmers and general laborers and their families, mostly from Norway, Iceland, Sweden, Germany and the United Kingdom.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Much of this settlement gravitated throughout the western side of the Red River Valley, as was similarly seen in South Dakota and in a parallel manner in Minnesota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This area is well known for its fertile lands.

name: north_dakota
sentence: By the outbreak of the First World War, this was among North America's richest farming regions.

name: north_dakota
sentence: But a period of higher rainfall ended, and many migrants weren't successful in the arid conditions.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many family plots were too small to farm successfully.

name: north_dakota
sentence: From the 1930s until the end of the 20th century, North Dakota's population gradually declined, interrupted by a couple of brief increases.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Young adults with university degrees were particularly likely to leave the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: With the advancing process of mechanization of agricultural practices, and environmental conditions requiring larger landholdings for successful agriculture, subsistence farming proved to be too risky for families.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many people moved to urban areas for jobs.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Since the late 20th century, one of the major causes of migration from North Dakota is the lack of skilled jobs for college graduates.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Expansion of economic development programs has been urged to create skilled and high-tech jobs, but the effectiveness of such programs has been open to debate.

name: north_dakota
sentence: During the first decade of the 21st century, the population increased in large part because of jobs in the oil industry related to development of tight oil (shale oil) fields.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Elsewhere, the Native American population has increased as some reservations have attracted people back from urban areas.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Immigration

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is one of the top resettlement locations for refugees proportionally.

name: north_dakota
sentence: According to the US Office of Refugee Resettlement, in 2013–2014 "more than 68 refugees" per 100,000 North Dakotans were settled in the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In fiscal year 2014, 582 refugees settled in the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Fargo Mayor Mahoney said North Dakota accepting the most refugees per capita should be celebrated given the benefits they bring to the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2015, Lutheran Social Services of North Dakota, the state's only resettlement agency, was "awarded $458,090 in federal funding to improve refugee services".

name: north_dakota
sentence: Immigration from outside the United States resulted in a net increase of 3,323 people, and migration within the country produced a net loss of 21,110 people.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Of the residents of North Dakota, 69.8% were born in North Dakota, 27.2% were born in a different state, 0.6% were born in Puerto Rico, US Island areas, or born abroad to American parent(s), and 2.4% were born in another country.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The age and gender distributions approximate the national average.

name: north_dakota
sentence: According to the 2010 Census, the racial and ethnic composition of North Dakota was as follows:

name: north_dakota
sentence: Throughout the mid-19th century, Dakota Territory was still dominated by Native Americans.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Warfare and disease reduced their population at the same time Europeans and Americans were settling in the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the 21st century, most North Dakotans are of Northern European descent.

name: north_dakota
sentence: As of 2009, the seven largest European ancestry groups in North Dakota are:

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has the most churches per capita of any state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Additionally, North Dakota has the highest percentage of church-going population of any state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A 2001 survey indicated 35% of North Dakota's population was Lutheran, and 30% was Catholic.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Other religious groups represented were Methodists (7%), Baptists (6%), the Assemblies of God (3%), Presbyterians (1.27%), and Jehovah's Witnesses (1%).

name: north_dakota
sentence: Christians with unstated or other denominational affiliations, including other Protestants and The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS Church), totaled 3%, bringing the total Christian population to 86%.

name: north_dakota
sentence: There were an estimated 920 Muslims and 730 Jews in the state in 2000.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Three percent of respondents answered "no religion" on the survey, and 6% declined to answer.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The largest church bodies by number of adherents in 2010 were the Roman Catholic Church with 167,349; the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America with 163,209; and the Lutheran Church–Missouri Synod with 22,003.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2010, 94.86% (584,496) of North Dakotans over 5 years old spoke English as their primary language.

name: north_dakota
sentence: 5.14% (31,684) of North Dakotans spoke a language other than English.

name: north_dakota
sentence: 1.39% (8,593) spoke German, 1.37% (8,432) spoke Spanish, and 0.30% (1,847) spoke Norwegian.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Other languages spoken included Serbo-Croatian (0.19%), Chinese and Japanese (both 0.15%), and Native American languages and French (both 0.13%).

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2000, 2.5% of the population spoke German in addition to English, reflecting early 20th century immigration.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the 21st century, North Dakota has an increasing population of Native Americans, who in 2010 made up 5.44% of the population.

name: north_dakota
sentence: By the early 19th century the territory was dominated by Siouan-speaking peoples, whose territory stretched west from the Great Lakes area.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The word "Dakota" is a Sioux (Lakota/Dakota) word meaning "allies" or "friends".

name: north_dakota
sentence: The primary historic tribal nations in or around North Dakota, are the Lakota and the Dakota ("The Great Sioux Nation" or "Oceti Sakowin", meaning the seven council fires), the Blackfoot, the Cheyenne, the Chippewa (known as Ojibwe in Canada), and the Mandan.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The federally recognized tribes have Indian reservations in the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Social gatherings known as "powwows" (or wacipis in Lakota/Dakota) continue to be an important part of Native American culture and are held regularly throughout the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Throughout Native American history, powwows were held, usually in the spring, to rejoice at the beginning of new life and the end of the winter cold.

name: north_dakota
sentence: These events brought Native American tribes together for singing and dancing and allowed them to meet with old friends and acquaintances, as well as to make new ones.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many powwows also held religious significance for some tribes.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Today, powwows are still a part of the Native American culture and are attended by Natives and non-Natives alike.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In North Dakota, the United Tribes International Powwow held each September in the capital of Bismarck, is one of the largest powwows in the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A pow wow is an occasion for parades and Native American dancers in regalia, with many dancing styles presented.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is traditional for male dancers to wear regalia decorated with beads, quills, and eagle feathers; male grass dancers wear colorful fringe regalia, and male fancy dancers wear brightly colored feathers.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Female dancers dance much more subtly than the male dancers.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Fancy female dancers wear cloth, beaded moccasins, and jewelry, while the jingle dress dancer wears a dress made of metal cones.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Inter-tribal dances during the powwow, allow everyone (even spectators) can take part in the dancing.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Around 1870 many European immigrants from Norway settled in North Dakota's northeastern corner, especially near the Red River.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Icelanders also arrived from Canada.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Pembina was a town of many Norwegians when it was founded

name: north_dakota
sentence: They started Lutheran churches and schools, greatly outnumbering other denominations in the area.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This group has unique foods such as lefse and lutefisk.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The continent's largest Scandinavian event, Norsk Høstfest, is celebrated each September in Minot's North Dakota State Fair Center, a local attraction featuring art, architecture, and cultural artifacts from all five Nordic countries.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Icelandic State Park in Pembina County and an annual Icelandic festival reflect immigrants from that country, who are also descended from Scandinavians.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Old World folk customs have persisted for decades in North Dakota, with the revival of techniques in weaving, silver crafting, and wood carving.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Traditional turf-roof houses are displayed in parks

name: north_dakota
sentence: A stave church is a landmark in Minot.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Norwegian-Americans constitute nearly one-third or 32.3% of Minot's total population and 30.8% of North Dakota's total population.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Ethnic Germans who had settled in Russia for several generations since the reign of Catherine the Great grew dissatisfied in the nineteenth century because of economic problems and because of the revocation of religious freedoms for Mennonites and Hutterites, in particular the revocation of exemption from military service in 1871.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Most Mennonites and Hutterites migrated to America in the late 1870s.

name: north_dakota
sentence: By 1900, about 100,000 had immigrated to the US, settling primarily in North Dakota, South Dakota, Kansas, and Nebraska.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The south-central part of North Dakota became known as "the German-Russian triangle".

name: north_dakota
sentence: By 1910, about 60,000 ethnic Germans from Russia lived in Central North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: These individuals were Lutherans, Mennonites, Hutterites and Roman Catholics who had kept most of their German customs of the time when their ancestors immigrated to Russia.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They were committed to agriculture.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Traditional iron cemetery grave markers are a famous art form practiced by ethnic Germans.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota's major fine art museums and venues include the Chester Fritz Auditorium, Empire Arts Center, the Fargo Theatre, North Dakota Museum of Art, and the Plains Art Museum.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Bismarck-Mandan Symphony Orchestra, Fargo-Moorhead Symphony Orchestra, Greater Grand Forks Symphony Orchestra, Minot Symphony Orchestra and Great Plains Harmony Chorus are full-time professional and semi-professional musical ensembles who perform concerts and offer educational programs to the community.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakotan musicians of many genres include blues guitarist Jonny Lang, country music singer Lynn Anderson, jazz and traditional pop singer and songwriter Peggy Lee, big band leader Lawrence Welk, and pop singer Bobby Vee.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state is also home to Indie rock June Panic (of Fargo, signed to Secretly Canadian).

name: north_dakota
sentence: Ed Schultz was known around the country until his death in July 2018 as the host progressive talk radio show, The Ed Schultz Show, and The Ed Show on MSNBC.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Shadoe Stevens hosted American Top 40 from 1988 to 1995.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Josh Duhamel is an Emmy Award-winning actor known for his roles in All My Children and Las Vegas.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Nicole Linkletter and CariDee English were winning contestants of Cycles 5 and 7, respectively, of America's Next Top Model.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Kellan Lutz has appeared in movies such as Stick It, Accepted, Prom Night, and Twilight.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Bismarck was home of the Dakota Wizards of the NBA Development League, and currently hosts the Bismarck Bucks of the Indoor Football League.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has two NCAA Division I teams, the North Dakota Fighting Hawks and North Dakota State Bison, and two Division II teams, the Mary Marauders and Minot State Beavers.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Fargo is home to the USHL Ice Hockey team the Fargo Force.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The North Dakota High School Activities Association features more than 25,000 participants.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Outdoor activities such as hunting and fishing are hobbies for many North Dakotans.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Ice fishing, skiing, and snowmobiling are also popular during the winter months.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Residents of North Dakota may own or visit a cabin along a lake.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Popular sport fish include walleye, perch, and northern pike.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The western terminus of the North Country National Scenic Trail is on Lake Sakakawea, where it abuts the Lewis and Clark Trail.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Agriculture is North Dakota's largest industry, although petroleum, food processing, and technology are also major industries.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Its growth rate is about 4.1%.

name: north_dakota
sentence: According to the Bureau of Economic Analysis the economy of North Dakota had a gross domestic product of $55.180 billion in the second quarter of 2018.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The per capita income was $34,256, when measured from 2013–2017 by the United States Department of Commerce.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The three-year median household income from 2013–2017 was $61,285.

name: north_dakota
sentence: According to Gallup data, North Dakota led the US in job creation in 2013 and has done so since 2009.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state has a Job Creation Index score of 40, nearly 10 points ahead of its nearest competitors.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has added 56,600 private-sector jobs since 2011, creating an annual growth rate of 7.32 percent.

name: north_dakota
sentence: According to statistics released on March 25, 2014 by the Bureau of Economic Analysis, North Dakota's personal income grew 7.6 percent in 2013 to $41.3 billion.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state has recorded the highest personal income growth among all states for the sixth time since 2007.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota's personal income growth is tied to various private business sectors such as agriculture, energy development, and construction.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Just over 21% of North Dakota's total 2013 gross domestic product (GDP) of $49.77 billion comes from natural resources and mining.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is the only state with a state-owned bank, the Bank of North Dakota in Bismarck, and a state-owned flour mill, the North Dakota Mill and Elevator in Grand Forks.

name: north_dakota
sentence: These were established by the NPL before World War II.

name: north_dakota
sentence: As of 2012, Fargo is home to the second-largest campus of Microsoft with 1,700 employees, and Amazon.com employs several hundred in Grand Forks.

name: north_dakota
sentence: As of December 2019, the state's unemployment rate is among the lowest in the nation at 2.4 percent.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It has not reached five percent since 1987.

name: north_dakota
sentence: At end of 2010, the state per capita income was ranked 17th in the nation, the biggest increase of any state in a decade from rank 38th.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The reduction in the unemployment rate and growth in per capita income is attributable to the oil boom in the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Due to a combination of oil-related development and investing in technology and service industries, North Dakota has had a budget surplus every year since the 2008 market crash.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Since 1976, the highest that North Dakota's unemployment rate has reached is just 6.2%, recorded in 1983.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Every US state except neighboring South Dakota has had a higher unemployment rate during that period.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota's earliest industries were fur trading and agriculture.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Although less than 10% of the population is employed in the agricultural sector, it remains a major part of the state's economy.

name: north_dakota
sentence: With industrial-scale farming, it ranks 9th in the nation in the value of crops and 18th in total value of agricultural products sold.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Large farms generate the most crops.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The share of people in the state employed in agriculture is comparatively high: as of 2008, only two to three percent of the population of the United States is directly employed in agriculture.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has about 90% of its land area in farms with 27,500,000 acres (111,000 km2) of cropland, the third-largest amount in the nation.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Between 2002 and 2007, total cropland increased by about a million acres (4,000 km2); North Dakota was the only state showing an increase.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Over the same period, 1,800,000 acres (7,300 km2) were shifted into soybean and corn monoculture production, the largest such shift in the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Agriculturalists are concerned about too much monoculture, as it makes the economy at risk from insect or crop diseases affecting a major crop.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition, this development has adversely affected habitats of wildlife and birds, and the balance of the ecosystem.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state is the largest producer in the US of many cereal grains, including barley (36% of US crop), durum wheat (58%), hard red spring wheat (48%), oats (17%), and combined wheat of all types (15%).

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is the second leading producer of buckwheat (20%).

name: north_dakota
sentence: As of 2007, corn became the state's largest crop produced, although it is only 2% of total US production.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Corn Belt extends to North Dakota, but is more on the edge of the region instead of in its center.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Corn yields are high in the southeast part of the state and smaller in other parts of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Most of the cereal grains are grown for livestock feed.The state is the leading producer of many oilseeds, including 92% of the US canola crop, 94% of flax seed, 53% of sunflower seeds, 18% of safflower seeds, and 62% of mustard seed.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Canola is suited to the cold winters and it matures fast.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Processing of canola for oil production produces canola meal as a by-product.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The by-product is a high-protein animal feed.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Soybeans are also an increasingly important crop, with 400,000 acres (1,600 km2) additional planted between 2002 and 2007.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Soybeans are a major crop in the eastern part of the state, and cultivation is common in the southeast part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Soybeans were not grown at all in North Dakota in the 1940s, but the crop has become especially common since 1998.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In North Dakota soybeans have to mature fast, because of the comparatively short growing season.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Soybeans are grown for livestock feed.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is the second leading producer of sugarbeets, which are grown mostly in the Red River Valley.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state is also the largest producer of honey, dry edible peas and beans, lentils, and the third-largest producer of potatoes.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota's Top Agricultural Commodities (according to the USDA as of 2011)

name: north_dakota
sentence: The energy industry is a major contributor to the economy.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has both coal and oil reserves.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Shale gas is also produced.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Lignite coal reserves in Western North Dakota are used to generate about 90% of the electricity consumed, and electricity is also exported to nearby states.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has the second largest lignite coal production in the US

name: north_dakota
sentence: However, lignite coal is the lowest grade coal.

name: north_dakota
sentence: There are larger and higher grade coal reserves (anthracite, bituminous coal and subbituminous coal) in other US states.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Oil was discovered near Tioga in 1951, generating 53 million barrels (8,400,000 m3) of oil a year by 1984.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Recoverable oil reserves have jumped dramatically recently.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The oil reserves of the Bakken Formation may hold up to 400 billion barrels (6.4×1010 m3) of oil, 25 times larger than the reserves in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A report issued in April 2008 by the US Geological Survey estimates the oil recoverable by current technology in the Bakken formation is two orders of magnitude less, in the range of 3 billion barrels (480×10^6 m3) to 4.3 billion barrels (680×10^6 m3), with a mean of 3.65 billion barrels (580×10^6 m3).

name: north_dakota
sentence: The northwestern part of the state is the center of the North Dakota oil boom.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Williston, Tioga, Stanley and Minot-Burlington communities are having rapid growth that strains housing and local services.

name: north_dakota
sentence: As of 2012, the state is the 2nd-largest oil producer in the US, with an average of 575,490 barrels per day.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Great Plains region, which includes the state of North Dakota, has been referred to as "the Saudi Arabia of wind energy".

name: north_dakota
sentence: Development of wind energy in North Dakota has been cost effective because the state has large rural expanses and wind speeds seldom go below 10 mph.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is considered the least visited state, owing, in part, to its not having a major tourist attraction.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Nonetheless, tourism is North Dakota's third largest industry, contributing more than $3 billion into the state's economy annually.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Outdoor attractions like the 144-mile Maah Daah Hey Trail and activities like fishing and hunting attract visitors.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state is known for the Lewis & Clark Trail and being the winter camp of the Corps of Discovery.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Areas popular with visitors include Theodore Roosevelt National Park in the western part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The park often exceeds 475,000 visitors each year.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Regular events in the state that attract tourists include Norsk Høstfest in Minot, billed as North America's largest Scandinavian festival; the Medora Musical; and the North Dakota State Fair.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state also receives a significant number of visitors from the neighboring Canadian provinces of Manitoba and Saskatchewan, particularly when the exchange rate is favorable.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many international tourists now also come to visit the Oscar-Zero Missile Alert Facility.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has six level-II trauma centers, 44 hospitals, 52 rural health clinics, and 80 nursing homes.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Major provider networks include Sanford, St. Alexius, Trinity, and Altru.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Blue Cross Blue Shield of North Dakota is the largest medical insurer in the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota expanded Medicaid in 2014, and its health insurance exchange is the federal site, HealthCare.gov.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota law requires pharmacies, other than hospital dispensaries and pre-existing stores, to be majority-owned by pharmacists.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Voters rejected a proposal to change the law in 2014.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The North Dakota Department of Emergency Services provides 24/7 communication and coordination for more than 50 agencies.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition, "it administers federal disaster recovery programs and the Homeland Security Grant Program".

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2011, the Department selected Geo-Comm, Inc. "for the Statewide Seamless Base Map Project", which will facilitate "identifying locations 9–1–1 callers" and route emergency calls based on locations.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 1993 the state adopted the Burkle addressing system numbering rural roads and buildings to aid in the delivery of emergency services.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Transportation in North Dakota is overseen by the North Dakota Department of Transportation.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The major Interstate highways are Interstate 29 and Interstate 94, with I-29 and I-94 meeting at Fargo, with I-29 oriented north to south along the eastern edge of the state, and I-94 bisecting the state from east to west between Minnesota and Montana.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A unique feature of the North Dakota Interstate Highway system is virtually all of it is paved in concrete, not blacktop, because of the extreme weather conditions it must endure.

name: north_dakota
sentence: BNSF and the Canadian Pacific Railway operate the state's largest rail systems.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many branch lines formerly used by BNSF and Canadian Pacific Railway are now operated by the Dakota, Missouri Valley and Western Railroad and the Red River Valley and Western Railroad.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota's principal airports are the Hector International Airport (FAR) in Fargo, Grand Forks International Airport (GFK), Bismarck Municipal Airport (BIS), Minot International Airport (MOT) and Williston Basin International Airport (XWA) in Williston.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Amtrak's Empire Builder runs through North Dakota, making stops at Fargo (2:13 am westbound, 3:35 am eastbound), Grand Forks (4:52 am westbound, 12:57 am eastbound), Minot (around 9 am westbound and around 9:30 pm eastbound), and four other stations.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is the descendant of the famous line of the same name run by the Great Northern Railway, which was built by the tycoon James J. Hill and ran from St. Paul to Seattle.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Intercity bus service is provided by Greyhound and Jefferson Lines.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Public transit in North Dakota includes daily fixed-route bus systems in Fargo, Bismarck-Mandan, Grand Forks, and Minot, paratransit service in 57 communities, along with multi-county rural transit systems.

name: north_dakota
sentence: As with the federal government of the United States, political power in North Dakota state government is divided into three branches: executive, legislative, and judicial.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Constitution of North Dakota and the North Dakota Century Code form the formal law of the state

name: north_dakota
sentence: The executive branch is headed by the elected governor.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The current governor is Doug Burgum, a Republican who took office December 15, 2016, after his predecessor, Jack Dalrymple did not seek reelection.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The current Lieutenant Governor of North Dakota is Brent Sanford, who is also the President of the Senatorte.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The offices of governor and lieutenant governor have four-year terms, which are next up for election in 2024.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The governor has a cabinet consisting of appointed leaders of various state government agencies, called commissioners.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The other elected constitutional offices are secretary of state, attorney general, state auditor, and state treasurer.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The North Dakota Legislative Assembly is a bicameral body consisting of the Senatorte and the House of Representatives.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state has 47 districts, each with one senator and two representatives.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Both senators and representatives are elected to four-year terms.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state's legal code is named the North Dakota Century Code.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota's court system has four levels.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Municipal courts serve the cities, and most cases start in the district courts, which are courts of general jurisdiction.

name: north_dakota
sentence: There are 42 district court judges in seven judicial districts.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Appeals from the trial courts and challenges to certain governmental decisions are heard by the North Dakota Court of Appeals, consisting of three-judge panels.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The five-justice North Dakota Supreme Court hears all appeals from the district courts and the Court of Appeals.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Historically, North Dakota was populated by the Mandan, Hidatsa, Lakota, and Ojibwe, and later by the Sanish and Métis.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Today, five federally recognized tribes within the boundaries of North Dakota have independent, sovereign relationships with the federal government and territorial reservations:

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota's United States Senatortors are John Hoeven (R) and Kevin Cramer (R).

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state has one at-large congressional district represented by Representative Kelly Armstrong (R).

name: north_dakota
sentence: Federal court cases are heard in the United States District Court for the District of North Dakota, which holds court in Bismarck, Fargo, Grand Forks, and Minot.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Appeals are heard by the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals based in St. Louis, Missouri.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The major political parties in North Dakota are the Democratic-NPL and the Republican Party.

name: north_dakota
sentence: As of 2007, the Constitution Party and the Libertarian Party are also organized parties in the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: At the state level, the governorship has been held by the Republican Party since 1992, along with a majority of the state legislature and statewide officers.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Dem-NPL showings were strong in the 2000 governor's race, and in the 2006 legislative elections, but the League has not had a major breakthrough since the administration of former state governor George Sinner.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Republican Party presidential candidate usually carries the state; in 2004, George W. Bush won with 62.9% of the vote.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Of all the Democratic presidential candidates since 1892, only Grover Cleveland (1892, one of three votes), Woodrow Wilson (1912 and 1916), Franklin D. Roosevelt (1932 and 1936), and Lyndon B. Johnson (1964) received Electoral College votes from North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: On the other hand, Dem-NPL candidates for North Dakota's federal Senatorte and House seats won every election between 1982 and 2008, and the state's federal delegation was entirely Democratic from 1987 to 2011.

name: north_dakota
sentence: However, both of the current US

name: north_dakota
sentence: Senatortors, John Hoeven and Kevin Cramer, are Republicans, as is the sole House member, Kelly Armstrong.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has a slightly progressive income tax structure; the five brackets of state income tax rates are 1.1%, 2.04%, 2.27%, 2.64%, and 2.90% as of 2017.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2005 North Dakota ranked 22nd highest by per capita state taxes.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The sales tax in North Dakota is 5% for most items.

name: north_dakota
