sentence: The state allows municipalities to institute local sales taxes and special local taxes, such as the 1.75% supplemental sales tax in Grand Forks.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Excise taxes are levied on the purchase price or market value of aircraft registered in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state imposes a use tax on items purchased elsewhere but used within North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Owners of real property in North Dakota pay property tax to their county, municipality, school district, and special taxing districts.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Tax Foundation ranks North Dakota as the state with the 20th most "business friendly" tax climate in the nation.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Tax Freedom Day arrives on April 1, 10 days earlier than the national Tax Freedom Day.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2006, North Dakota was the state with the lowest number of returns filed by taxpayers with an Adjusted Gross Income of over $1M—only 333.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Of North Dakota's 762,062 people, 56.54% live in one of the top fifteen most populated cities.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Fargo is the largest city in North Dakota and is the economic hub for the region.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Bismarck, in south-central North Dakota along the banks of the Missouri River, has been North Dakota's capital city since 1883, first as capital of the Dakota Territory, and then as state capital since 1889.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Minot is a city in northern North Dakota and is home of the North Dakota State Fair and Norsk Høstfest.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A few miles west of Bismarck on the west side of the Missouri River, the city of Mandan was named for the Mandan Indians who inhabited the area at the time of the Lewis and Clark Expedition.

name: north_dakota
sentence: New Salem is the site of the world's largest statue of a holstein cow

name: north_dakota
sentence: Grand Forks and Devils Lake are in scenic areas of North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: West Fargo, the fifth largest city in North Dakota, is one of the fastest growing cities.

name: north_dakota
sentence: and was recognized as a Playful City USA by KaBOOM!

name: north_dakota
sentence: Williston is near the confluence of the Missouri River and the Yellowstone River near Montana.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Medora in the North Dakota Badlands hosts the Medora Musical every summer and is the gateway to Theodore Roosevelt National Park.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Fort Yates, along the Missouri River on the Standing Rock Indian Reservation, claims to host the final resting place of Hunkpapa Lakota leader Sitting Bull (Mobridge, South Dakota also claims his gravesite).

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state has 11 public colleges and universities, five tribal community colleges, and four private schools.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The largest institutions are North Dakota State University and the University of North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The higher education system consists of the following institutions:

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota University System (public institutions):

name: north_dakota
sentence: Tribal institutions:

name: north_dakota
sentence: Private institutions:

name: north_dakota
sentence: "The Flickertail State" is one of North Dakota's nicknames and is derived from Richardson's ground squirrel (Spermophilus richardson ii), a very common animal in the region.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The ground squirrel constantly flicks its tail in a distinctive manner.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 1953, legislation to make the ground squirrel the state emblem was voted down in the state legislature.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state has 10 daily newspapers, the largest being The Forum of Fargo-Moorhead.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Other weekly and monthly publications (most of which are fully supported by advertising) are also available.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The most prominent of these is the alternative weekly High Plains Reader.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state's oldest radio station, WDAY-AM, was launched on May 23, 1922.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota's three major radio markets center around Fargo, Bismarck, and Grand Forks, though stations broadcast in every region of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Several new stations were built in Williston in the early 2010s.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has 34 AM and 88 FM radio stations.

name: north_dakota
sentence: KFGO in Fargo has the largest audience.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Broadcast television in North Dakota started on April 3, 1953, when KCJB-TV (now KXMC-TV) in Minot started operations.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota's television media markets are Fargo-Grand Forks, (117th largest nationally), including the eastern half of the state, and Minot-Bismarck (152nd), making up the western half of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: There are currently 31 full-power television stations, arranged into 10 networks, with 17 digital subchannels.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Public broadcasting in North Dakota is provided by Prairie Public, with statewide television and radio networks affiliated with PBS and NPR.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Public access television stations open to community programming are offered on cable systems in Bismarck, Dickinson, Fargo, and Jamestown.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio (listen) is a state in the East North Central region of the Midwestern United States.

name: ohio
sentence: Of the fifty states, it is the 34th-largest by area, and with a population of nearly 11.7 million, is the seventh-most populous and tenth-most densely populated.

name: ohio
sentence: The state's capital and largest city is Columbus, with the Columbus metro area, Greater Cincinnati, and Greater Cleveland being the largest metropolitan areas.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is bordered by Lake Erie to the north, Pennsylvania to the east, West Virginia to the southeast, Kentucky to the southwest, Indiana to the west, and Michigan to the northwest.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is historically known as the "Buckeye State" after its Ohio buckeye trees, and Ohioans are also known as "Buckeyes".

name: ohio
sentence: The state takes its name from the Ohio River, whose name in turn originated from the Senatorca word ohiːyo', meaning "good river", "great river", or "large creek".

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio arose from the lands west of Appalachia that were contested from colonial times through the Northwest Indian Wars of the late 18th century.

name: ohio
sentence: It was partitioned from the resulting Northwest Territory, which was the first frontier of the new United States, and became the 17th state admitted to the Union on March 1, 1803, and the first under the Northwest Ordinance.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio was the first post-colonial free state admitted to the union, and became one of the earliest and most influential industrial powerhouses in the 20th century; although it has transitioned to a more information and service based economy in the 21st century, Ohio remains an industrial state, ranking seventh in GDP as of 2019, with the third largest manufacturing sector and second largest automobile production.

name: ohio
sentence: The government of Ohio is composed of the executive branch, led by the governor; the legislative branch, consisting of the bicameral Ohio General Assembly; and the judicial branch, led by the state Supreme Court.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio occupies 16 seats in the United States House of Representatives.

name: ohio
sentence: The state is known for its status as both a swing state and a bellwether in national elections.

name: ohio
sentence: Eight presidents of the United States have come from Ohio, the most of any state; this has led to it receiving the moniker "the Mother of Presidents".

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's geographic location has proven to be an asset for economic growth and expansion.

name: ohio
sentence: Because Ohio links the Northeast to the Midwest, much cargo and business traffic passes through its borders along its well-developed highways.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has the nation's 10th largest highway network and is within a one-day drive of 50% of North America's population and 70% of North America's manufacturing capacity.

name: ohio
sentence: To the north, Lake Erie gives Ohio 312 miles (502 km) of coastline, which allows for numerous cargo ports.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's southern border is defined by the Ohio River (with the border being at the 1792 low-water mark on the north side of the river), and much of the northern border is defined by Lake Erie.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's neighbors are Pennsylvania to the east, Michigan to the northwest, Lake Erie to the north, Indiana to the west, Kentucky on the south, and West Virginia on the southeast.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's borders were defined by metes and bounds in the Enabling Act of 1802 as follows:

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is bounded by the Ohio River, but nearly all of the river itself belongs to Kentucky and West Virginia.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1980, the US Supreme Court held that, based on the wording of the cessation of territory by Virginia (which at the time included what is now Kentucky and West Virginia), the boundary between Ohio and Kentucky (and, by implication, West Virginia) is the northern low-water mark of the river as it existed in 1792.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has only that portion of the river between the river's 1792 low-water mark and the present high-water mark.

name: ohio
sentence: The border with Michigan has also changed, as a result of the Toledo War, to angle slightly northeast to the north shore of the mouth of the Maumee River.

name: ohio
sentence: Much of Ohio features glaciated till plains, with an exceptionally flat area in the northwest being known as the Great Black Swamp.

name: ohio
sentence: This glaciated region in the northwest and central state is bordered to the east and southeast first by a belt known as the glaciated Allegheny Plateau, and then by another belt known as the unglaciated Allegheny Plateau.

name: ohio
sentence: Most of Ohio is of low relief, but the unglaciated Allegheny Plateau features rugged hills and forests.

name: ohio
sentence: The rugged southeastern quadrant of Ohio, stretching in an outward bow-like arc along the Ohio River from the West Virginia Panhandle to the outskirts of Cincinnati, forms a distinct socio-economic unit.

name: ohio
sentence: Geologically similar to parts of West Virginia and southwestern Pennsylvania, this area's coal mining legacy, dependence on small pockets of old manufacturing establishments, and distinctive regional dialect set this section off from the rest of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1965 the United States Congress passed the Appalachian Regional Development Act, an attempt to "address the persistent poverty and growing economic despair of the Appalachian Region".

name: ohio
sentence: This act defines 29 Ohio counties as part of Appalachia.

name: ohio
sentence: While 1/3 of Ohio's land mass is part of the federally defined Appalachian region, only 12.8% of Ohioans live there (1.476 million people.)

name: ohio
sentence: Significant rivers within the state include the Cuyahoga River, Great Miami River, Maumee River, Muskingum River, and Scioto River.

name: ohio
sentence: The rivers in the northern part of the state drain into the northern Atlantic Ocean via Lake Erie and the St. Lawrence River, and the rivers in the southern part of the state drain into the Gulf of Mexico via the Ohio River and then the Mississippi.

name: ohio
sentence: The worst weather disaster in Ohio history occurred along the Great Miami River in 1913.

name: ohio
sentence: Known as the Great Dayton Flood, the entire Miami River watershed flooded, including the downtown business district of Dayton.

name: ohio
sentence: As a result, the Miami Conservancy District was created as the first major flood plain engineering project in Ohio and the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: Grand Lake St. Marys in the west-central part of the state was constructed as a supply of water for canals in the canal-building era of 1820–1850.

name: ohio
sentence: For many years this body of water, over 20 square miles (52 km2), was the largest artificial lake in the world.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's canal-building projects were not the economic fiasco that similar efforts were in other states.

name: ohio
sentence: Some cities, such as Dayton, owe their industrial emergence to location on canals, and as late as 1910 interior canals carried much of the bulk freight of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: The climate of Ohio is a humid continental climate (Köppen climate classification Dfa/Dfb) throughout most of the state, except in the extreme southern counties of Ohio's Bluegrass region section, which are located on the northern periphery of the humid subtropical climate (Cfa) and Upland South region of the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: Summers are typically hot and humid throughout the state, while winters generally range from cool to cold.

name: ohio
sentence: Precipitation in Ohio is moderate year-round.

name: ohio
sentence: Severe weather is not uncommon in the state, although there are typically fewer tornado reports in Ohio than in states located in what is known as the Tornado Alley.

name: ohio
sentence: Severe lake effect snowstorms are also not uncommon on the southeast shore of Lake Erie, which is located in an area designated as the Snowbelt.

name: ohio
sentence: Although predominantly not in a subtropical climate, some warmer-climate flora and fauna do reach well into Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: For instance, some trees with more southern ranges, such as the blackjack oak, Quercus marilandica, are found at their northernmost in Ohio just north of the Ohio River.

name: ohio
sentence: Also evidencing this climatic transition from a subtropical to continental climate, several plants such as the Southern magnolia (Magnolia grandiflora), Albizia julibrissin (mimosa), Crape Myrtle, and even the occasional Needle Palm are hardy landscape materials regularly used as street, yard, and garden plantings in the Bluegrass region of Ohio; but these same plants will simply not thrive in much of the rest of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: This interesting change may be observed while traveling through Ohio on Interstate 75 from Cincinnati to Toledo; the observant traveler of this diverse state may even catch a glimpse of Cincinnati's common wall lizard, one of the few examples of permanent "subtropical" fauna in Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Due to flooding resulting in severely damaged highways, Governor Mike DeWine declared a state of emergency in 37 Ohio counties in 2019.

name: ohio
sentence: The highest recorded temperature was 113 °F (45 °C), near Gallipolis on July 21, 1934.

name: ohio
sentence: The lowest recorded temperature was −39 °F (−39 °C), at Milligan on February 10, 1899, during the Great Blizzard of 1899.

name: ohio
sentence: Although few have registered as noticeable to the average resident, more than 200 earthquakes with a magnitude of 2.0 or higher have occurred in Ohio since 1776.

name: ohio
sentence: The Western Ohio Seismic Zone and a portion of the Southern Great Lakes Seismic Zone are located in the state, and numerous faults lie under the surface.

name: ohio
sentence: The most substantial known earthquake in Ohio history was the Anna (Shelby County) earthquake, which occurred on March 9, 1937.

name: ohio
sentence: It was centered in western Ohio, and had a magnitude of 5.4, and was of intensity VIII.

name: ohio
sentence: Other significant earthquakes in Ohio include: one of magnitude 4.8 near Lima on September 19, 1884; one of magnitude 4.2 near Portsmouth on May 17, 1901; and one of 5.0 in LeRoy Township in Lake County on January 31, 1986, which continued to trigger 13 aftershocks of magnitude 0.5 to 2.4 for two months.

name: ohio
sentence: Notable Ohio earthquakes in the 21st century include one occurring on December 31, 2011, approximately 4 kilometers (2.5 mi) northwest of Youngstown, and one occurring on June 10, 2019, approximately 5 kilometers (3.1 mi) north-northwest of Eastlake under Lake Erie; both registered a 4.0 magnitude.

name: ohio
sentence: Columbus is the capital of Ohio, located near the geographic center of the state and well known for The Ohio State University.

name: ohio
sentence: However, other Ohio cities function as economic and cultural centers of metropolitan areas.

name: ohio
sentence: Akron, Canton, Cleveland, Mansfield, and Youngstown are in the Northeast, known for major industrial companies Goodyear Tire and Rubber and Timken, top ranked colleges Case Western Reserve University and Kent State University, the Cleveland Clinic, and cultural attractions including the Cleveland Museum of Art, Big Five group Cleveland Orchestra, Playhouse Square, the Pro Football Hall of Fame, and the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.

name: ohio
sentence: Lima and Toledo are the major cities in Northwest Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Northwest Ohio is known for its glass making industry, and is home to Owens Corning and Owens-Illinois, two Fortune 500 corporations.

name: ohio
sentence: Dayton and Springfield are located in the Miami Valley, which is home to the University of Dayton, the Dayton Ballet, and the extensive Wright-Patterson Air Force Base.

name: ohio
sentence: Cincinnati anchors Southwest Ohio and is the largest economy in the state.

name: ohio
sentence: It is home of Miami University and the University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati Union Terminal, Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, and various Fortune 500 companies including Procter & Gamble, Kroger, Macy's, Inc., and Fifth Third Bank.

name: ohio
sentence: Steubenville is the only metropolitan city in Appalachian Ohio, which is home to Hocking Hills State Park.

name: ohio
sentence: The Cincinnati metropolitan area extends into Kentucky and Indiana, the Steubenville metropolitan area extends into West Virginia, the Toledo metropolitan area extends into Michigan, and the Youngstown metropolitan area extends into Pennsylvania.

name: ohio
sentence: Other metropolitan areas that contain cities in Ohio include:

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio cities that function as centers of United States micropolitan areas include:

name: ohio
sentence: Archeological evidence of spear points of both the Folsom and Clovis types indicate that the Ohio Valley was inhabited by nomadic people as early as 13,000 BC.

name: ohio
sentence: These early nomads disappeared from Ohio by 1,000 BC.

name: ohio
sentence: Between 1,000 and 800 BC, the sedentary Adena culture emerged.

name: ohio
sentence: The Adena were able to establish "semi-permanent" villages because they domesticated plants, including, sunflowers, and "grew squash and possibly corn"; with hunting and gathering, this cultivation supported more settled, complex villages.

name: ohio
sentence: The most notable remnant of the Adena culture is the Great Serpent Mound, located in Adams County, Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Around 100 BC, the Adena evolved into the Hopewell people who were also mound builders.

name: ohio
sentence: Their complex, large and technologically sophisticated earthworks can be found in modern-day Marietta, Newark, and Circleville.

name: ohio
sentence: They were also a prolific trading society, their trading network spanning a third of the continent.

name: ohio
sentence: The Hopewell disappeared from the Ohio Valley about 600 AD.

name: ohio
sentence: The Mississippian Culture rose as the Hopewell Culture declined.

name: ohio
sentence: Many Siouan-speaking peoples from the plains and east coast claim them as ancestors and say they lived throughout the Ohio region until approximately the 13th century.

name: ohio
sentence: There were three other cultures contemporaneous with the Mississippians: the Fort Ancient people, the Whittlesey Focus people and the Monongahela Culture.

name: ohio
sentence: All three cultures disappeared in the 17th century.

name: ohio
sentence: Their origins are unknown.

name: ohio
sentence: The Shawnees may have absorbed the Fort Ancient people.

name: ohio
sentence: It is also possible that the Monongahela held no land in Ohio during the Colonial Era.

name: ohio
sentence: The Mississippian Culture were close to and traded extensively with the Fort Ancient people.

name: ohio
sentence: Indians in the Ohio Valley were greatly affected by the aggressive tactics of the Iroquois Confederation, based in central and western New York.

name: ohio
sentence: After the Beaver Wars in the mid-17th century, the Iroquois claimed much of the Ohio country as hunting and, more importantly, beaver-trapping ground.

name: ohio
sentence: After the devastation of epidemics and war in the mid-17th century, which largely emptied the Ohio country of indigenous people by the mid-to-late 17th century, the land gradually became repopulated by the mostly Algonquian.

name: ohio
sentence: Many of these Ohio-country nations were multi-ethnic (sometimes multi-linguistic) societies born out of the earlier devastation brought about by disease, war, and subsequent social instability.

name: ohio
sentence: They subsisted on agriculture (corn, sunflowers, beans, etc.)

name: ohio
sentence: supplemented by seasonal hunts.

name: ohio
sentence: By the 18th century, they were part of a larger global economy brought about by European entry into the fur trade.

name: ohio
sentence: The indigenous nations to inhabit Ohio in the historical period included the Iroquoian, the Algonquian & the Siouan.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio country was also the site of Indian massacres, such as the Yellow Creek Massacre, Gnadenhutten and Pontiac's Rebellion school massacre.

name: ohio
sentence: Most Native Peoples who remained in Ohio were slowly bought out and convinced to leave, or ordered to do so by law, in the early 19th century with the Indian Removal Act of 1830.

name: ohio
sentence: During the 18th century, the French set up a system of trading posts to control the fur trade in the region.

name: ohio
sentence: Beginning in 1754, France and Great Britain fought the French and Indian War.

name: ohio
sentence: As a result of the Treaty of Paris, the French ceded control of Ohio and the remainder of the Old Northwest to Great Britain.

name: ohio
sentence: In the Treaty of Paris in 1783, Britain ceded all claims to Ohio country to the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: The United States created the Northwest Territory under the Northwest Ordinance of 1787.

name: ohio
sentence: Slavery was not permitted in the new territory.

name: ohio
sentence: Settlement began with the founding of Marietta by the Ohio Company of Associates, which had been formed by a group of American Revolutionary War veterans.

name: ohio
sentence: Following the Ohio Company, the Miami Company (also referred to as the "Symmes Purchase") claimed the southwestern section, and the Connecticut Land Company surveyed and settled the Connecticut Western Reserve in present-day Northeast Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Territorial surveyors from Fort Steuben began surveying an area of eastern Ohio called the Seven Ranges at about the same time.

name: ohio
sentence: The old Northwest Territory originally included areas previously known as Ohio Country and Illinois Country.

name: ohio
sentence: As Ohio prepared for statehood, the Indiana Territory was created, reducing the Northwest Territory to approximately the size of present-day Ohio plus the eastern half of the Lower Peninsula of Michigan and the eastern tip of the Upper Peninsula and a sliver of southeastern Indiana called "The Gore".

name: ohio
sentence: The coalition of Native American tribes, known as the Western Confederacy, was forced to cede extensive territory, including much of present-day Ohio, in the Treaty of Greenville in 1795.

name: ohio
sentence: Under the Northwest Ordinance, areas could be defined and admitted as states once their population reached 60,000.

name: ohio
sentence: Although Ohio's population was only 45,000 in December 1801, Congress determined that it was growing rapidly and had already begun the path to statehood.

name: ohio
sentence: In regards to the Leni Lenape natives, Congress decided that 10,000 acres on the Muskingum River in the present state of Ohio would "be set apart and the property thereof be vested in the Moravian Brethren ... or a society of the said Brethren for civilizing the Indians and promoting Christianity".

name: ohio
sentence: Rufus Putnam served in important capacities in both the French and Indian War and the American Revolutionary War.

name: ohio
sentence: He was one of the most highly respected men in the early years of the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1776, Putnam created a method of building portable fortifications, which enabled the Continental Army to drive the British from Boston.

name: ohio
sentence: George Washington was so impressed that he made Putnam his chief engineer.

name: ohio
sentence: After the war, Putnam and Manasseh Cutler were instrumental in creating the Northwest Ordinance, which opened up the Northwest Territory for settlement.

name: ohio
sentence: This land was used to serve as compensation for what was owed to Revolutionary War veterans.

name: ohio
sentence: It was also at Putnam's recommendation that the land would be surveyed and laid out in townships of six miles square.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam organized and led the first group of veterans to the territory.

name: ohio
sentence: They settled at Marietta, Ohio, where they built a large fort called Campus Martius.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam and Cutler insisted that the Northwest Territory would be free territory – no slavery.

name: ohio
sentence: They were both from Puritan New England, and the Puritans strongly believed that slavery was morally wrong.

name: ohio
sentence: The Northwest Territory doubled the size of the United States, and establishing it as free of slavery proved to be of tremendous importance in the following decades.

name: ohio
sentence: It encompassed what became Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Michigan, Wisconsin and part of Minnesota.

name: ohio
sentence: Had those states been slave states, and their electoral votes gone to Abraham Lincoln's main competitor, Lincoln would not have been elected president.

name: ohio
sentence: The Civil War would not have been fought.

name: ohio
sentence: And, even if eventually there had been a civil war, the North would probably have lost.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam, in the Puritan tradition, was influential in establishing education in the Northwest Territory.

name: ohio
sentence: Substantial amounts of land were set aside for schools.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam had been one of the primary benefactors in the founding of Leicester Academy in Massachusetts, and similarly, in 1798, he created the plan for the construction of the Muskingum Academy (now Marietta College) in Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1780, the directors of the Ohio Company appointed him superintendent of all its affairs relating to settlement north of the Ohio River.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1796, he was commissioned by President George Washington as Surveyor-General of United States Lands.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1788, he served as a judge in the Northwest Territory's first court.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1802, he served in the convention to form a constitution for the State of Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: On February 19, 1803, US president Thomas Jefferson signed an act of Congress that approved Ohio's boundaries and constitution.

name: ohio
sentence: However, Congress had never passed a resolution formally admitting Ohio as the 17th state.

name: ohio
sentence: The current custom of Congress declaring an official date of statehood did not begin until 1812, with Louisiana's admission as the 18th state.

name: ohio
sentence: Although no formal resolution of admission was required, when the oversight was discovered in 1953, as Ohio began preparations for celebrating its sesquicentennial, Ohio congressman George H. Bender introduced a bill in Congress to admit Ohio to the Union retroactive to March 1, 1803, the date on which the Ohio General Assembly first convened.

name: ohio
sentence: At a special session at the old state capital in Chillicothe, the Ohio state legislature approved a new petition for statehood which was delivered to Washington, D.C., on horseback.

name: ohio
sentence: On August 7, 1953 (the year of Ohio's 150th anniversary), President Eisenhower signed a congressional joint resolution that officially declared March 1, 1803, the date of Ohio's admittance into the Union.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has had three capital cities: Chillicothe, Zanesville, and Columbus.

name: ohio
sentence: Chillicothe was the capital from 1803 to 1810.

name: ohio
sentence: The capital was then moved to Zanesville for two years, as part of a state legislative compromise to get a bill passed.

name: ohio
sentence: The capital was then moved back to Chillicothe, which was the capital from 1812 to 1816.

name: ohio
sentence: Finally, the capital was moved to Columbus, to have it near the geographic center of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: Although many Native Americans had migrated west to evade American encroachment, others remained settled in the state, sometimes assimilating in part.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1830 under President Andrew Jackson, the US government forced Indian Removal of most tribes to the Indian Territory west of the Mississippi River.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1835, Ohio fought with Michigan in the Toledo War, a mostly bloodless boundary war over the Toledo Strip.

name: ohio
sentence: Only one person was injured in the conflict.

name: ohio
sentence: Congress intervened, making Michigan's admittance as a state conditional on ending the conflict.

name: ohio
sentence: In exchange for giving up its claim to the Toledo Strip, Michigan was given the western two-thirds of the Upper Peninsula, in addition to the eastern third which was already considered part of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's central position and its population gave it an important place during the Civil War.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio River was a vital artery for troop and supply movements, as were Ohio's railroads.

name: ohio
sentence: The industry of Ohio made the state one of the most important states in the Union during the Civil war.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio contributed more soldiers per-capita than any other state in the Union.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1862, the state's morale was badly shaken in the aftermath of the Battle of Shiloh, a costly victory in which Ohio forces suffered 2,000 casualties.

name: ohio
sentence: Later that year, when Confederate troops under the leadership of Stonewall Jackson threatened Washington, D.C., Ohio governor David Tod still could recruit 5,000 volunteers to provide three months of service.

name: ohio
sentence: From July 12 to July 23, 1863, Southern Ohio and Indiana were attacked in Morgan's Raid.

name: ohio
sentence: While this raid was insignificant and small, it aroused fear among people in Ohio and Indiana.

name: ohio
sentence: Almost 35,000 Ohioans died in the conflict, and 30,000 were physically wounded.

name: ohio
sentence: By the end of the Civil War, the Union's top three generals–Ulysses S. Grant, William Tecumseh Sherman, and Philip Sheridan–were all from Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1912 a Constitutional Convention was held with Charles Burleigh Galbreath as secretary.

name: ohio
sentence: The result reflected the concerns of the Progressive Era.

name: ohio
sentence: It introduced the initiative and the referendum.

name: ohio
sentence: Also, it allowed the General Assembly to put questions on the ballot for the people to ratify laws and constitutional amendments originating in the Legislature.

name: ohio
sentence: Under the Jeffersonian principle that laws should be reviewed once a generation, the constitution provided for a recurring question to appear on Ohio's general election ballots every 20 years.

name: ohio
sentence: The question asks whether a new convention is required.

name: ohio
sentence: Although the question has appeared in 1932, 1952, 1972, and 1992, it has never been approved.

name: ohio
sentence: Instead, constitutional amendments have been proposed by petition to the legislature hundreds of times and adopted in a majority of cases.

name: ohio
sentence: From just over 45,000 residents in 1800, Ohio's population grew faster than 10% per decade (except for the 1940 census) until the 1970 census, which recorded just over 10.65 million Ohioans.

name: ohio
sentence: Growth then slowed for the next four decades.

name: ohio
sentence: The United States Census Bureau estimates that the population of Ohio was 11,689,100 on July 1, 2019, a 1.32% increase since the 2010 United States Census.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's population growth lags that of the entire United States, and whites are found in a greater density than the US average.

name: ohio
sentence: As of 2000, Ohio's center of population is located in Morrow County, in the county seat of Mount Gilead.

name: ohio
sentence: This is approximately 6,346 feet (1,934 m) south and west of Ohio's population center in 1990.

name: ohio
sentence: As of 2011, 27.6% of Ohio's children under the age of 1 belonged to minority groups.

name: ohio
sentence: 6.2% of Ohio's population is under five years of age, 23.7 percent under 18 years of age, and 14.1 percent were 65 or older.

name: ohio
sentence: Females made up approximately 51.2 percent of the population.

name: ohio
sentence: Note: Births in table do not add up because Hispanics are counted both by their ethnicity and by their race, giving a higher overall number.

name: ohio
sentence: According to the 2010 United States Census, the racial composition of Ohio was the following:

name: ohio
sentence: In 2010, there were 469,700 foreign-born residents in Ohio, corresponding to 4.1% of the total population.

name: ohio
sentence: Of these, 229,049 (2.0%) were naturalized US citizens and 240,699 (2.1%) were not.

name: ohio
sentence: The largest groups were: Mexico (54,166), India (50,256), China (34,901), Germany (19,219), Philippines (16,410), United Kingdom (15,917), Canada (14,223), Russia (11,763), South Korea (11,307), and Ukraine (10,681).

name: ohio
sentence: Though predominantly white, Ohio has large black populations in all major metropolitan areas throughout the state, Ohio has a significant Hispanic population made up of Mexicans in Toledo and Columbus, and Puerto Ricans in Cleveland and Columbus, and also has a significant and diverse Asian population in Columbus.

name: ohio
sentence: The largest ancestry groups (which the Census defines as not including racial terms) in the state are:

name: ohio
sentence: Ancestries claimed by less than 1% of the population include Sub-Saharan African, Puerto Rican, Swiss, Swedish, Arab, Greek, Norwegian, Romanian, Austrian, Lithuanian, Finnish, West Indian, Portuguese and Slovene.

name: ohio
sentence: About 6.7% of the population age 5 years and older reported speaking a language other than English, with 2.2% of the population speaking Spanish, 2.6% speaking other Indo-European languages, 1.1% speaking Asian and Austronesian languages, and 0.8% speaking other languages.

name: ohio
sentence: Numerically: 10,100,586 spoke English, 239,229 Spanish, 55,970 German, 38,990 Chinese, 33,125 Arabic, and 32,019 French.

name: ohio
sentence: In addition 59,881 spoke a Slavic language and 42,673 spoke another West Germanic language according to the 2010 Census.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio also had the nation's largest population of Slovene speakers, second largest of Slovak speakers, second largest of Pennsylvania Dutch (German) speakers, and the third largest of Serbian speakers.

name: ohio
sentence: According to a Pew Forum poll, as of 2008, 76% of Ohioans identified as Christian.

name: ohio
sentence: Specifically, 26% of Ohio's population identified as Evangelical Protestant, 22% as Mainline Protestant, and 21% as Catholic.

name: ohio
sentence: 17% of the population is unaffiliated with any religious body.

name: ohio
sentence: Small minorities of Jews (1%), Jehovah's Witnesses (1%), Muslims (1%), Hindus (<1%), Buddhists (1%), Mormons (1%), and other faiths (1-1.5%) exist.

name: ohio
sentence: According to the Association of Religion Data Archives (ARDA), in 2010 the largest denominations by adherents were the Catholic Church with 1,992,567; the United Methodist Church with 496,232; the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America with 223,253, the Southern Baptist Convention with 171,000, the Christian Churches and Churches of Christ with 141,311, the United Church of Christ with 118,000, and the Presbyterian Church (USA) with 110,000.

name: ohio
sentence: With about 70,000 people in 2015 Ohio had the second largest Amish population of all states of the US.

name: ohio
sentence: According to the same data, a majority of Ohioans, 55%, feel religion is "very important", 30% that it is "somewhat important", and 15% that religion is "not too important/not important at all".

name: ohio
sentence: 36% of Ohioans indicate that they attend religious services at least once weekly, 35% occasionally, and 27% seldom or never.

name: ohio
sentence: According to the US Census Bureau, the total number for employment in 2016 was 4,790,178.

name: ohio
sentence: The total number of unique employer establishments was 252,201, while the total number of nonemployer establishments was 785,833.

name: ohio
sentence: In 2010, Ohio was ranked second in the country for best business climate by Site Selection magazine, based on a business-activity database.

name: ohio
sentence: The state has also won three consecutive Governor's Cup awards from the magazine, based on business growth and developments.

name: ohio
sentence: As of 2016, Ohio's gross domestic product (GDP) was $626 billion.

name: ohio
sentence: This ranks Ohio's economy as the seventh-largest of all fifty states and the District of Columbia.

name: ohio
sentence: The Small Business & Entrepreneurship Council ranked the state No.

name: ohio
sentence: 10 for best business-friendly tax systems in their Business Tax Index 2009, including a top corporate tax and capital gains rate that were both ranked No.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio was ranked No.

name: ohio
sentence: 11 by the council for best friendly-policy states according to their Small Business Survival Index 2009.

name: ohio
sentence: The Directorship's Boardroom Guide ranked the state No.

name: ohio
sentence: 13 overall for best business climate, including No.

name: ohio
sentence: 7 for best litigation climate.

name: ohio
sentence: Forbes ranked the state No.

name: ohio
sentence: 8 for best regulatory environment in 2009.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has five of the top 115 colleges in the nation, according to US News and World Report's 2010 rankings, and was ranked No.

name: ohio
sentence: 8 by the same magazine in 2008 for best high schools.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's unemployment rate stands at 4.5% as of February 2018, down from 10.7% in May 2010.

name: ohio
sentence: The state still lacks 45,000 jobs compared to the pre-recession numbers of 2007.

name: ohio
sentence: The labor force participation as of April 2015 is 63%, slightly above the national average.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's per capita income stands at $34,874.

name: ohio
sentence: As of 2016, Ohio's median household income is $52,334, and 14.6% of the population is below the poverty line

name: ohio
sentence: The manufacturing and financial activities sectors each compose 18.3% of Ohio's GDP, making them Ohio's largest industries by percentage of GDP.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has the third largest manufacturing workforce behind California and Texas.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has the largest bioscience sector in the Midwest, and is a national leader in the "green" economy.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is the largest producer in the country of plastics, rubber, fabricated metals, electrical equipment, and appliances.

name: ohio
sentence: 5,212,000 Ohioans are currently employed by wage or salary.

name: ohio
sentence: By employment, Ohio's largest sector is trade/transportation/utilities, which employs 1,010,000 Ohioans, or 19.4% of Ohio's workforce, while the health care and education sector employs 825,000 Ohioans (15.8%).

name: ohio
sentence: Government employs 787,000 Ohioans (15.1%), manufacturing employs 669,000 Ohioans (12.9%), and professional and technical services employs 638,000 Ohioans (12.2%).

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's manufacturing sector is the third-largest of all fifty United States states in terms of gross domestic product.

name: ohio
sentence: Fifty-nine of the United States' top 1,000 publicly traded companies (by revenue in 2008) are headquartered in Ohio, including Procter & Gamble, Goodyear Tire & Rubber, AK Steel, Timken, Abercrombie & Fitch, and Wendy's.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is also one of 41 states with its own lottery, the Ohio Lottery.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio Lottery has contributed over $15.5 billion to public education in its 34-year history.

name: ohio
sentence: Many major east–west transportation corridors go through Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: One of those pioneer routes, known in the early 20th century as "Main Market Route 3", was chosen in 1913 to become part of the historic Lincoln Highway which was the first road across America, connecting New York City to San Francisco.

name: ohio
sentence: In Ohio, the Lincoln Highway linked many towns and cities together, including Canton, Mansfield, Wooster, Lima, and Van Wert.

name: ohio
sentence: The arrival of the Lincoln Highway to Ohio was a major influence on the development of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: Upon the advent of the federal numbered highway system in 1926, the Lincoln Highway through Ohio became US Route 30.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio also is home to 228 miles (367 km) of the Historic National Road, now US Route 40.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has a highly developed network of roads and interstate highways.

name: ohio
sentence: Major east-west through routes include the Ohio Turnpike (I-80/I-90) in the north, I-76 through Akron to Pennsylvania, I-70 through Columbus and Dayton, and the Appalachian Highway (State Route 32) running from West Virginia to Cincinnati.

name: ohio
sentence: Major north–south routes include I-75 in the west through Toledo, Dayton, and Cincinnati, I-71 through the middle of the state from Cleveland through Columbus and Cincinnati into Kentucky, and I-77 in the eastern part of the state from Cleveland through Akron, Canton, New Philadelphia and Marietta south into West Virginia.

name: ohio
sentence: Interstate 75 between Cincinnati and Dayton is one of the heaviest traveled sections of interstate in Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio also has a highly developed network of signed state bicycle routes.

name: ohio
sentence: Many of them follow rail trails, with conversion ongoing.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio to Erie Trail (route 1) connects Cincinnati, Columbus, and Cleveland.

name: ohio
sentence: US

name: ohio
sentence: Bicycle Route 50 traverses Ohio from Steubenville to the Indiana state line outside Richmond.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has several long-distance hiking trails, the most prominent of which is the Buckeye Trail which extends 1,444 mi (2,324 km) in a loop around the state of Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Part of it is on roads and part is on wooded trail.

name: ohio
sentence: Additionally, the North Country Trail (the longest of the eleven National Scenic Trails authorized by Congress) and the American Discovery Trail (a system of recreational trails and roads that collectively form a coast-to-coast route across the mid-tier of the United States) pass through Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Much of these two trails coincide with the Buckeye Trail.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has extensive railroads, though today most are only utilized by freight companies.

name: ohio
sentence: Major cities in the north and south of Ohio lie on Amtrak intercity rail lines.

name: ohio
sentence: The Capitol Limited and the Lake Shore Limited serve Toledo, Cleveland and other northern Ohio cities.

name: ohio
sentence: The Cardinal serves Cincinnati.

name: ohio
sentence: Columbus is the largest city in the United States without any form of passenger rail.

name: ohio
sentence: Its Union Station last had an inter-city train in 1979 with the National Limited.

name: ohio
sentence: Mass transit exists in many forms in Ohio cities, primarily through bus systems, though Cleveland has light and heavy rail through the GCRTA, and Cincinnati reestablished a streetcar line in 2016.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has four international airports, four commercial, and two military.

name: ohio
sentence: The four international include Cleveland Hopkins International Airport, John Glenn Columbus International Airport, Dayton International Airport, and Rickenbacker International Airport (one of two military airfields).

name: ohio
sentence: The other military airfield is Wright Patterson Air Force Base which is one of the largest Air Force bases in the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: Other major airports are located in Toledo and Akron.

name: ohio
sentence: Cincinnati's primary airport, Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky International Airport, is in Hebron, Kentucky, and therefore is not included in Ohio airport lists.

name: ohio
sentence: The state government of Ohio consists of the executive, judicial, and legislative branches.

name: ohio
sentence: The executive branch is headed by the governor of Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: The current governor is Mike DeWine since 2019, a member of the Republican Party.

name: ohio
sentence: A lieutenant governor succeeds the governor in the event of any removal from office, and performs any duties assigned by the governor.

name: ohio
sentence: The current lieutenant governor is Jon A. Husted.

name: ohio
sentence: The other elected constitutional offices in the executive branch are the secretary of state (Frank LaRose), auditor (Keith Faber), treasurer (Robert Sprague), and attorney general (Dave Yost).

name: ohio
sentence: There are three levels of the Ohio state judiciary.

name: ohio
sentence: The lowest level is the court of common pleas: each county maintains its own constitutionally mandated court of common pleas, which maintain jurisdiction over "all justiciable matters".

name: ohio
sentence: The intermediate-level court system is the district court system.

name: ohio
sentence: Twelve courts of appeals exist, each retaining jurisdiction over appeals from common pleas, municipal, and county courts in a set geographical area.

name: ohio
sentence: A case heard in this system is decided by a three-judge panel, and each judge is elected.

name: ohio
sentence: The state's highest-ranking court is the Ohio Supreme Court.

name: ohio
sentence: A seven-justice panel composes the court, which, by its own discretion, hears appeals from the courts of appeals, and retains original jurisdiction over limited matters.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio General Assembly is a bicameral legislature consisting of the Senatorte and House of Representatives.

name: ohio
sentence: The Senatorte is composed of 33 districts, each of which is represented by one senator.

name: ohio
sentence: Each senator represents approximately 330,000 constituents.

name: ohio
sentence: The House of Representatives is composed of 99 members.

name: ohio
sentence: Eight US presidents hailed from Ohio at the time of their elections, giving rise to its nickname "mother of presidents", a sobriquet it shares with Virginia.

name: ohio
sentence: It is also termed "modern mother of presidents", in contrast to Virginia's status as the origin of presidents earlier in American history.

name: ohio
sentence: Seven presidents were born in Ohio, making it second to Virginia's eight.

name: ohio
sentence: Virginia-born William Henry Harrison lived most of his life in Ohio and is also buried there.

name: ohio
sentence: Harrison conducted his political career while living on the family compound, founded by his father-in-law, John Cleves Symmes, in North Bend, Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: The seven presidents born in Ohio were Ulysses S. Grant, Rutherford B. Hayes, James A. Garfield, Benjamin Harrison (grandson of William Henry Harrison), William McKinley, William Howard Taft and Warren G. Harding.

name: ohio
sentence: All seven were Republicans.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is considered a swing state, being won by either the Democratic or Republican candidates reasonably each election.

name: ohio
sentence: As a swing state, Ohio is usually targeted by both major-party campaigns, especially in competitive elections.

name: ohio
sentence: Pivotal in the election of 1888, Ohio has been a regular swing state since 1980.

name: ohio
sentence: Additionally, Ohio is considered a bellwether.

name: ohio
sentence: Historian R. Douglas Hurt asserts that not since Virginia "had a state made such a mark on national political affairs".

name: ohio
sentence: The Economist notes that "This slice of the mid-west contains a bit of everything American—part north-eastern and part southern, part urban and part rural, part hardscrabble poverty and part boomingsuburb", Since 1896, Ohio has had only three misses in the general election (Thomas E. Dewey in 1944, Richard Nixon in 1960, and Donald Trump in 2020) and had the longest perfect streak of any state, voting for the winning presidential candidate in each election from 1964 to 2016, and in 33 of the 38 held since the Civil War.

name: ohio
sentence: No Republican has ever won the presidency without winning Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: As of 2019, there are more than 7.8 million registered Ohioan voters, with 1.3 million Democrats and 1.9 million Republicans.

name: ohio
sentence: They are disproportionate in age, with a million more over 65 than there are 18- to 24-year-olds.

name: ohio
sentence: Since the 2010 midterm elections, Ohio's voter demographic has leaned towards the Republican Party.

name: ohio
sentence: The governor, Mike DeWine, is Republican, as well as all other non-judicial statewide elected officials, including Lieutenant Governor Jon A. Husted, Attorney General Dave Yost, State Auditor Keith Faber, Secretary of State Frank LaRose and State Treasurer Robert Sprague.

name: ohio
sentence: In the Ohio State Senatorte the Republicans are the majority, 24–9, and in the Ohio House of Representatives the Republicans control the delegation 61–38.

name: ohio
sentence: Losing two seats in the US House of Representatives following the 2010 Census, Ohio has had 16 seats for the three presidential elections of the decade in 2012, 2016 and 2020.

name: ohio
sentence: As of the 2018 midterms, twelve federal representatives are Republicans while four are Democrats.

name: ohio
sentence: Marcy Kaptur (D-09) is the most senior member of the Ohio delegation to the US House of Representatives.

name: ohio
sentence: The senior US senator, Sherrod Brown, is a Democrat, while the junior, Rob Portman, is a Republican.

name: ohio
sentence: Since 1994, the state has had a policy of purging infrequent voters from its rolls.

name: ohio
sentence: In April 2016, a lawsuit was filed, challenging this policy on the grounds that it violated the National Voter Registration Act (NVRA) of 1993 and the Help America Vote Act of 2002.

name: ohio
sentence: In June, the federal district court ruled for the plaintiffs and entered a preliminary injunction applicable only to the November 2016 election.

name: ohio
sentence: The preliminary injunction was upheld in September by the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.

name: ohio
sentence: Had it not been upheld, thousands of voters would have been purged from the rolls just a few weeks before the election.

name: ohio
sentence: Still, it has been estimated that the state has removed up to two million voters since 2011.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's system of public education is outlined in Article VI of the state constitution, and in Title XXXIII of the Ohio Revised Code.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio University, the first university in the Northwest Territory, was also the first public institution in Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Substantively, Ohio's system is similar to those found in other states.

name: ohio
sentence: At the State level, the Ohio Department of Education, which is overseen by the Ohio State Board of Education, governs primary and secondary educational institutions.

name: ohio
sentence: At the municipal level, there are approximately 700 school districts statewide.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio Board of Regents coordinates and assists with Ohio's institutions of higher education which have recently been reorganized into the University System of Ohio under Governor Strickland.

name: ohio
sentence: The system averages an annual enrollment of more than 400,000 students, making it one of the five largest state university systems in the US

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio schools consistently ranking in the top 50 nationally of the US News & World Report of liberal arts colleges are Kenyon College, Oberlin College, and Denison University.

name: ohio
sentence: Ranking in the top 100 nationally of the US News & World Report of national research universities are Case Western Reserve University, Ohio State University and Miami University.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is home to some of the nation's highest-ranked public libraries.

name: ohio
sentence: The 2008 study by Thomas J. Hennen Jr. ranked Ohio as number one in a state-by-state comparison.

name: ohio
sentence: For 2008, 31 of Ohio's library systems were all ranked in the top ten for American cities of their population category.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio Public Library Information Network (OPLIN) is an organization that provides Ohio residents with internet access to their 251 public libraries.

name: ohio
sentence: OPLIN also provides Ohioans with free home access to high-quality, subscription research databases.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio also offers the OhioLINK program, allowing Ohio's libraries (particularly those from colleges and universities) access to materials for the other libraries.

name: ohio
sentence: The program is largely successful in allowing researchers for access to books and other media that might not be otherwise available.

name: ohio
sentence: The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and the Rhythm and Blues Music Hall of Fame are both located in Cleveland.

name: ohio
sentence: Cleveland disc jockey Alan Freed is credited with coining the term and promoting rock and roll in the early 1950s.

name: ohio
sentence: Cincinnati is home to the American Classical Music Hall of Fame and Museum.

name: ohio
sentence: Popular musicians from Ohio include Mamie Smith, Dean Martin, Dave Grohl, Tyler Joseph and Josh Dun of Twenty One Pilots, Frankie Yankovic, Doris Day, The McGuire Sisters, The Isley Brothers, Bobby Womack, Howard Hewett, Shirley Murdock, Boz Scaggs, John Legend, Marilyn Manson, Nine Inch Nails, Dan Auerbach and Patrick Carney of The Black Keys, Griffin Layne, Joe Dolce, Kid Cudi, Benjamin Orr of The Cars, Chrissie Hynde of The Pretenders, William "Bootsy" Collins, Stephanie Eulinberg of Kid Rock's Twisted Brown Trucker Band, and Devo.

name: ohio
sentence: Five Ohio musicians are Rock and Roll Hall of Fame members.

name: ohio
sentence: Playhouse Square in downtown Cleveland is the second largest performing arts center in the United States, home to ten theaters.

name: ohio
sentence: The Cleveland Orchestra is one of the historic Big Five orchestras in the US, and is considered one of the best worldwide.

name: ohio
sentence: Many other Ohio cities are home to their own orchestras, including Akron, Blue Ash, Canton, Cincinnati, Columbus, Dayton, Toledo, and Youngstown.

name: ohio
sentence: Cincinnati is home to its own ballet, symphony orchestra, pops orchestra, and opera, all housed at the Cincinnati Music Hall.

name: ohio
sentence: Dayton is also home to a ballet, orchestra, and opera, collectively known as the Dayton Performing Arts Alliance.

name: ohio
sentence: The Columbus Association for the Performing Arts manages seven historic Columbus area theaters.

name: ohio
sentence: Winter Guard International has hosted national championships at the University of Dayton from 1983–1989, 1991–1996, 1998–2000, 2002–2003, and from 2005 to present.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is home to 30 art institutions, including the Columbus Museum of Art, Cincinnati Art Museum, Cleveland Museum of Art, and other entities.

name: ohio
sentence: The full list includes:

name: ohio
sentence: The Cincinnati Art Museum holds over 100,000 works spanning 6,000 years of human history, being among the most comprehensive collections in the Midwest.

name: ohio
sentence: Among its notable collections are works by Master of San Baudelio, Jorge Ingles, Sandro Botticelli (Judith with Head of Holofernes), Matteo di Giovanni, Domenico Tintoretto (Portrait of Venetian dux Marino Grimani), Mattia Preti, Bernardo Strozzi, Frans Hals, Bartolomé Esteban Murillo (St. Thomas of Villanueva), Peter Paul Rubens (Samson and Delilah) and Aert van der Neer.

name: ohio
sentence: The collection also includes works by Jean-Baptiste-Camille Corot, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Camille Pissarro, Claude Monet (Rocks At Belle Isle), and Pablo Picasso.

name: ohio
sentence: The museum also has a large collection of paintings by American painter Frank Duveneck (Elizabeth B. Duveneck).

name: ohio
sentence: The Cleveland Museum of Art is internationally renowned for its substantial holdings of Asian and Egyptian art, and has a permanent collection of more than 61,000 works from around the world.

name: ohio
sentence: It is the fourth-wealthiest art museum in the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: The Columbus Museum of Art holds nineteenth and early twentieth-century American and European art, including early Cubist paintings by Pablo Picasso and Juan Gris, works by François Boucher, Paul Cézanne, Mary Cassatt, Jean Auguste Dominique Ingres, Edgar Degas, Henri Matisse, Claude Monet, Edward Hopper, and Norman Rockwell, and installations by Mel Chin, Josiah McElheny, Susan Philipsz, and Allan Sekula.

name: ohio
sentence: Also in Columbus, the Billy Ireland Cartoon Library & Museum collection includes 450,000 original cartoons, 36,000 books, 51,000 serial titles, and 3,000 feet (910 m) of manuscript materials, plus 2.5 million comic strip clippings and tear sheets, making it the largest research library for cartoon art.

name: ohio
sentence: Youngstown's Butler Institute of American Art was the first museum to be dedicated exclusively to American art.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is home to eight professional sports teams across the five different major leagues in the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: Current teams include the Cincinnati Reds and Cleveland Indians of Major League Baseball, the Columbus Crew SC and FC Cincinnati of Major League Soccer, the Cleveland Cavaliers of the National Basketball Association, the Cincinnati Bengals and Cleveland Browns of the National Football League, and the Columbus Blue Jackets of the National Hockey League.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has brought home seven World Series titles (Reds 1919, 1940, 1975, 1976, 1990; Indians 1920, 1948), two MLS Cups (Crew 2008, 2020), one NBA Championship (Cavaliers 2016), and nine NFL Championships (Pros 1920; Bulldogs 1922, 1923, 1924; Rams 1945; Browns 1950, 1954, 1955, 1964).

name: ohio
sentence: Despite this success in the NFL in the first half of the 20th century, no Ohio team has won the Super Bowl since its inception in 1967 or made an appearance since 1989.

name: ohio
sentence: No Ohio team has made an appearance in the Stanley Cup Finals.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio played a central role in the development of both Major League Baseball and the National Football League.

name: ohio
sentence: Baseball's first fully professional team, the Cincinnati Red Stockings of 1869, were organized in Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: An informal early-20th-century American football association, the Ohio League, was the direct predecessor of the NFL, although neither of Ohio's modern NFL franchises trace their roots to an Ohio League club.

name: ohio
sentence: The Pro Football Hall of Fame is located in Canton.

name: ohio
sentence: On a smaller scale, Ohio hosts minor league baseball, arena football, indoor football, mid-level hockey, and lower division soccer.

name: ohio
sentence: The Mid-Ohio Sports Car Course has hosted several auto racing championships, including CART World Series, IndyCar Series, NASCAR Nationwide Series, Can-Am, Formula 5000, IMSA GT Championship, American Le Mans Series and Rolex Sports Car Series.The Grand Prix of Cleveland also hosted CART races from 1982 to 2007.

name: ohio
sentence: The Eldora Speedway is a major dirt oval that hosts NASCAR Camping World Truck Series, World of Outlaws Sprint Cars and USAC Silver Crown Series races.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio hosts two PGA Tour events, the WGC-Bridgestone Invitational and Memorial Tournament.The Cincinnati Masters is an ATP World Tour Masters 1000 and WTA Premier 5 tennis tournament.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has eight NCAA Division I Football Bowl Subdivision college football teams, divided among three different conferences.

name: ohio
sentence: It has also experienced considerable success in the secondary and tertiary tiers of college football divisions.

name: ohio
sentence: There is only one program in the Power Five conferences, the Ohio State Buckeyes, who play in the Big Ten Conference.

name: ohio
sentence: The football team is second in all-time winning percentage, with a 931–327–53 overall record and a 25–26 bowl record as of 2020.

name: ohio
sentence: The program has produced seven Heisman Trophy winners, forty conference titles, and eight undisputed national championships.

name: ohio
sentence: The men's basketball program has appeared in the NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament 27 times.

name: ohio
sentence: In the Group of Five conferences, the Cincinnati Bearcats play as a member of the American Athletic Conference.

name: ohio
sentence: Their men's basketball team has over 1,800 wins, 33 March Madness appearances, and is currently on a nine-year streak of appearances as of 2019.

name: ohio
sentence: Six teams are represented in the Mid-American Conference: the Akron Zips, Bowling Green Falcons, Kent State Golden Flashes, Miami RedHawks, Ohio Bobcats and the Toledo Rockets.

name: ohio
sentence: The MAC headquarters are in Cleveland.

name: ohio
sentence: The Cincinnati–Miami rivalry game has been played in southwest Ohio every year since 1888, and is the oldest current non-conference NCAA football rivalry.

name: ohio
sentence: Other Division I schools, either part of the NCAA Division I Football Championship Subdivision or not fielding in football include the Cleveland State Vikings, Xavier Musketeers, Wright State Raiders, and Youngstown State Penguins.

name: ohio
sentence: Xavier's men's basketball has performed particularly well, with 27 March Madness appearances.

name: ohio
sentence: Youngstown State's football has the third most NCAA Division I Football Championship wins, with 3.

name: ohio
sentence: There are 12 NCAA Division II universities and 22 NCAA Division III universities in Ohio.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma ( (listen)) is a state in the South Central region of the United States, bordered by the state of Texas on the south and west, Kansas on the north, Missouri on the northeast, Arkansas on the east, New Mexico on the west, and Colorado on the northwest.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Partially in the western extreme of the Upland South, it is the 20th-most extensive and the 28th-most populous of the 50 United States.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Its residents are known as Oklahomans (or colloquially "Okies"), and its capital and largest city is Oklahoma City.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state's name is derived from the Choctaw words okla and humma, meaning "red people".

name: oklahoma
sentence: It is also known informally by its nickname, "The Sooner State", in reference to the non-Native settlers who staked their claims on land before the official opening date of lands in the western Oklahoma Territory or before the Indian Appropriations Act of 1889, which increased European-American settlement in the eastern Indian Territory.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma Territory and Indian Territory were merged into the State of Oklahoma when it became the 46th state to enter the union on November 16, 1907.

name: oklahoma
sentence: With ancient mountain ranges, prairie, mesas, and eastern forests, most of Oklahoma lies in the Great Plains, Cross Timbers, and the US

name: oklahoma
sentence: Interior Highlands, all regions prone to severe weather.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is on a confluence of three major American cultural regions and historically served as a route for cattle drives, a destination for Southern settlers, and a government-sanctioned territory for Native Americans.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Twenty-five Native American languages are spoken in Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: A major producer of natural gas, oil, and agricultural products, Oklahoma relies on an economic base of aviation, energy, telecommunications, and biotechnology.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma City and Tulsa serve as Oklahoma's primary economic anchors, with nearly two-thirds of Oklahomans living within their metropolitan statistical areas.

name: oklahoma
sentence: These cities, collectively known as the Oklahoma Metropolitan Corridor, are included in the Texas Triangle megaregion.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The name Oklahoma comes from the Choctaw language phrase okla humma, literally meaning red people.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Choctaw Nation Chief Allen Wright suggested the name in 1866 during treaty negotiations with the federal government on the use of Indian Territory, in which he envisioned an all-Indian state controlled by the United States Superintendent of Indian Affairs.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Equivalent to the English word Indian, okla humma was a phrase in the Choctaw language that described Native American people as a whole.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma later became the de facto name for Oklahoma Territory, and it was officially approved in 1890, two years after the area was opened to white settlers.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In the Chickasaw language, the state is known as Oklahomma', in Arapaho as bo'oobe' (literally meaning red earth), Pawnee: Uukuhuúwa, and Cayuga: Gahnawiyoˀgeh.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is the 20th-largest state in the United States, covering an area of 69,899 square miles (181,040 km2), with 68,595 square miles (177,660 km2) of land and 1,304 square miles (3,380 km2) of water.

name: oklahoma
sentence: It lies partly in the Great Plains near the geographical center of the 48 contiguous states.

name: oklahoma
sentence: It is bounded on the east by Arkansas and Missouri, on the north by Kansas, on the northwest by Colorado, on the far west by New Mexico, and on the south and near-west by Texas.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is between the Great Plains and the Ozark Plateau in the Gulf of Mexico watershed, generally sloping from the high plains of its western boundary to the low wetlands of its southeastern boundary.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Its highest and lowest points follow this trend, with its highest peak, Black Mesa, at 4,973 feet (1,516 m) above sea level, situated near its far northwest corner in the Oklahoma Panhandle.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state's lowest point is on the Little River near its far southeastern boundary near the town of Idabel, which dips to 289 feet (88 m) above sea level.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Among the most geographically diverse states, Oklahoma is one of four to harbor more than 10 distinct ecological regions, with 11 in its borders—more per square mile than in any other state.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Its western and eastern halves, however, are marked by extreme differences in geographical diversity: Eastern Oklahoma touches eight ecological regions and its western half contains three.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Although having fewer ecological regions Western Oklahoma contains many rare, relic species.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has four primary mountain ranges: the Ouachita Mountains, the Arbuckle Mountains, the Wichita Mountains, and the Ozark Mountains.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Contained within the US

name: oklahoma
sentence: Interior Highlands region, the Ozark and Ouachita Mountains are the only major mountainous region between the Rocky Mountains and the Appalachians.

name: oklahoma
sentence: A portion of the Flint Hills stretches into north-central Oklahoma, and near the state's eastern border, The Oklahoma Tourism & Recreation Department regards Cavanal Hill as the world's tallest hill; at 1,999 feet (609 m), it fails their definition of a mountain by one foot.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The semi-arid high plains in the state's northwestern corner harbor few natural forests

name: oklahoma
sentence: Partial plains interrupted by small, sky island mountain ranges like the Antelope Hills and the Wichita Mountains dot southwestern Oklahoma; transitional prairie and oak savannas cover the central portion of the state.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Ozark and Ouachita Mountains rise from west to east over the state's eastern third, gradually increasing in elevation in an eastward direction.

name: oklahoma
sentence: More than 500 named creeks and rivers make up Oklahoma's waterways, and with 200 lakes created by dams, it holds the nation's highest number of artificial reservoirs.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Most of the state lies in two primary drainage basins belonging to the Red and Arkansas rivers, though the Lee and Little rivers also contain significant drainage basins.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Due to Oklahoma's location at the confluence of many geographic regions, the state's climatic regions have a high rate of biodiversity.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Forests cover 24 percent of Oklahoma and prairie grasslands composed of shortgrass, mixed-grass, and tallgrass prairie, harbor expansive ecosystems in the state's central and western portions, although cropland has largely replaced native grasses.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Where rainfall is sparse in the state's western regions, shortgrass prairie and shrublands are the most prominent ecosystems, though pinyon pines, red cedar (junipers), and ponderosa pines grow near rivers and creek beds in the panhandle's far western reaches.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Southwestern Oklahoma contains many rare, disjunct species including sugar maple, bigtooth maple, nolina and Texas live oak.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Marshlands, cypress forests and mixtures of shortleaf pine, loblolly pine, blue palmetto, and deciduous forests dominate the state's southeastern quarter, while mixtures of largely post oak, elm, red cedar (Juniperus virginiana) and pine forests cover northeastern Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state holds populations of white-tailed deer, mule deer, antelope, coyotes, mountain lions, bobcats, elk, and birds such as quail, doves, cardinals, bald eagles, red-tailed hawks, and pheasants.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In prairie ecosystems, American bison, greater prairie chickens, badgers, and armadillo are common, and some of the nation's largest prairie dog towns inhabit shortgrass prairie in the state's panhandle.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Cross Timbers, a region transitioning from prairie to woodlands in Central Oklahoma, harbors 351 vertebrate species.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Ouachita Mountains are home to black bear, red fox, gray fox, and river otter populations, which coexist with 328 vertebrate species in southeastern Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Also, in southeastern Oklahoma lives the American alligator.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has fifty one state parks, six national parks or protected regions, two national protected forests or grasslands, and a network of wildlife preserves and conservation areas.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Six percent of the state's 10 million acres (40,000 km2) of forest is public land, including the western portions of the Ouachita National Forest, the largest and oldest national forest in the Southern United States.

name: oklahoma
sentence: With 39,000 acres (160 km2), the Tallgrass Prairie Preserve in north-central Oklahoma is the largest protected area of tallgrass prairie in the world and is part of an ecosystem that encompasses only ten percent of its former land area, once covering fourteen states.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In addition, the Black Kettle National Grassland covers 31,300 acres (127 km2) of prairie in southwestern Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Wichita Mountains Wildlife Refuge is the oldest and largest of nine National Wildlife Refuges in the state and was founded in 1901, encompassing 59,020 acres (238.8 km2).

name: oklahoma
sentence: Of Oklahoma's federally protected parks or recreational sites, the Chickasaw National Recreation Area is the largest, with 9,898.63 acres (40.0583 km2).

name: oklahoma
sentence: Other sites include the Santa Fe and Trail of Tears national historic trails, the Fort Smith and Washita Battlefield national historic sites, and the Oklahoma City National Memorial.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is in a humid subtropical region.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma lies in a transition zone between semi-arid further to the west, humid continental to the north, and humid subtropical to the east and southeast.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Most of the state lies in an area known as Tornado Alley characterized by frequent interaction between cold, dry air from Canada, warm to hot, dry air from Mexico and the Southwestern US, and warm, moist air from the Gulf of Mexico.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The interactions between these three contrasting air currents produces severe weather (severe thunderstorms, damaging thunderstorm winds, large hail and tornadoes) with a frequency virtually unseen anywhere else on planet Earth.

name: oklahoma
sentence: An average 62 tornadoes strike the state per year—one of the highest rates in the world.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Because of Oklahoma's position between zones of differing prevailing temperature and winds, weather patterns within the state can vary widely over relatively short distances, and they can change drastically in a short time.

name: oklahoma
sentence: On November 11, 1911, the temperature at Oklahoma City reached 83 °F (28 °C) (the record high for that date), then a cold front of unprecedented intensity slammed across the state, causing the temperature to reach 17 °F (−8 °C) (the record low for that date) by midnight.

name: oklahoma
sentence: This type of phenomenon is also responsible for many of the tornadoes in the area, such as the 1912 Oklahoma tornado outbreak when a warm front traveled along a stalled cold front, resulting in an average of about one tornado per hour.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The humid subtropical climate (Koppen Cfa) of central, southern and eastern Oklahoma is influenced heavily by southerly winds bringing moisture from the Gulf of Mexico.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Traveling westward, the climate transitions progressively toward a semi-arid zone (Koppen BSk) in the high plains of the Panhandle and other western areas from about Lawton westward, less frequently touched by southern moisture.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Precipitation and temperatures decline from east to west accordingly, with areas in the southeast averaging an annual temperature of 62 °F (17 °C) and an annual rainfall of generally over 40 in (1,020 mm) and up to 56 in (1,420 mm), while areas of the (higher-elevation) panhandle average 58 °F (14 °C), with an annual rainfall under 17 in (430 mm).

name: oklahoma
sentence: Over almost all of Oklahoma, winter is the driest season.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Average monthly precipitation increases dramatically in the spring to a peak in May, the wettest month over most of the state, with its frequent and not uncommonly severe thunderstorm activity.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Early June can still be wet, but most years see a marked decrease in rainfall during June and early July.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Mid-summer (July and August) represents a secondary dry season over much of Oklahoma, with long stretches of hot weather with only sporadic thunderstorm activity not uncommon many years.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Severe drought is common in the hottest summers, such as those of 1934, 1954, 1980 and 2011, all of which featured weeks on end of virtual rainlessness and highs well over 100 °F (38 °C).

name: oklahoma
sentence: Average precipitation rises again from September to mid-October, representing a secondary wetter season, then declines from late October through December.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The entire state frequently experiences temperatures above 100 °F (38 °C) or below 0 °F (−18 °C), though below-zero temperatures are rare in south-central and southeastern Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Snowfall ranges from an average of less than 4 in (102 mm) in the south to just over 20 in (508 mm) on the border of Colorado in the panhandle.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state is home to the Storm Prediction Center, the National Severe Storms Laboratory, and the Warning Decision Training Division, all part of the National Weather Service and in Norman.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Evidence suggests indigenous peoples traveled through Oklahoma as early as the last ice age.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Ancestors of the Wichita, Kichai, Teyas, Escanjaques, and Caddo lived in what is now Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Southern Plains villagers lived in the central and west of the state, with a subgroup, the Panhandle culture people living in the panhandle region.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Caddoan Mississippian culture peoples lived in the eastern part of the state.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Spiro Mounds, in what is now Spiro, Oklahoma, was a major Mississippian mound complex that flourished between AD 850 and 1450.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Spaniard Francisco Vázquez de Coronado traveled through the state in 1541, but French explorers claimed the area in the 1700s.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In the 18th century, Kiowa, Apache, and Comanche entered the region from the west and Quapaw and Osage peoples moved into what is now eastern Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: French colonists claimed the region until 1803, when all the French territory west of the Mississippi River was acquired by the United States in the Louisiana Purchase.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The territory was a part of the Arkansas Territory from 1819 until 1828.

name: oklahoma
sentence: During the 19th century, thousands of Native Americans were expelled from their ancestral homelands from across North America and transported to the area including and surrounding present-day Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Choctaw was the first of the Five Civilized Tribes to be removed from the Southeastern United States.
