name: oklahoma
sentence: The phrase "Trail of Tears" originated from a description of the removal of the Choctaw Nation in 1831, although the term is usually used for the Cherokee removal.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Seventeen thousand Cherokees and 2,000 of their black slaves were deported.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The area, already occupied by Osage and Quapaw tribes, was called for the Choctaw Nation until revised Native American and then later American policy redefined the boundaries to include other Native Americans.

name: oklahoma
sentence: By 1890, more than 30 Native American nations and tribes had been concentrated on land within Indian Territory or "Indian Country".

name: oklahoma
sentence: All Five Civilized Tribes supported and signed treaties with the Confederate military during the American Civil War.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Cherokee Nation had an internal civil war.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Slavery in Indian Territory was not abolished until 1866.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In the period between 1866 and 1899, cattle ranches in Texas strove to meet the demands for food in eastern cities and railroads in Kansas promised to deliver in a timely manner.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Cattle trails and cattle ranches developed as cowboys either drove their product north or settled illegally in Indian Territory.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 1881, four of five major cattle trails on the western frontier traveled through Indian Territory.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Increased presence of white settlers in Indian Territory prompted the United States Government to establish the Dawes Act in 1887, which divided the lands of individual tribes into allotments for individual families, encouraging farming and private land ownership among Native Americans but expropriating land to the federal government.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In the process, railroad companies took nearly half of Indian-held land within the territory for outside settlers and for purchase.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Major land runs, including the Land Run of 1889, were held for settlers where certain territories were opened to settlement starting at a precise time.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Usually land was open to settlers on a first come first served basis.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Those who broke the rules by crossing the border into the territory before the official opening time were said to have been crossing the border sooner, leading to the term sooners, which eventually became the state's official nickname.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Deliberations to make the territory into a state began near the end of the 19th century, when the Curtis Act continued the allotment of Indian tribal land.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Attempts to create an all-Indian state named Oklahoma and a later attempt to create an all-Indian state named Sequoyah failed but the Sequoyah Statehood Convention of 1905 eventually laid the groundwork for the Oklahoma Statehood Convention, which took place two years later.

name: oklahoma
sentence: On June 16, 1906, Congress enacted a statute authorizing the people of the Oklahoma and Indian Territories (as well what would become the states of Arizona and New Mexico) to form a constitution and state government in order to be admitted as a state.

name: oklahoma
sentence: On November 16, 1907, President Theodore Roosevelt issued Presidential Proclamation no.

name: oklahoma
sentence: 780, establishing Oklahoma as the 46th state in the Union.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The new state became a focal point for the emerging oil industry, as discoveries of oil pools prompted towns to grow rapidly in population and wealth.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Tulsa eventually became known as the "Oil Capital of the World" for most of the 20th century and oil investments fueled much of the state's early economy.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 1927, Oklahoman businessman Cyrus Avery, known as the "Father of Route 66", began the campaign to create US Route 66.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Using a stretch of highway from Amarillo, Texas to Tulsa, Oklahoma to form the original portion of Highway 66, Avery spearheaded the creation of the US Highway 66 Association to oversee the planning of Route 66, based in his hometown of Tulsa.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma also has a rich African-American history.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Many Black towns, founded by the Freedmen of the Five Tribes during Reconstruction, thrived in the early 20th century with the arrival of Black Exodusters who migrated from neighboring states, especially Kansas.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The politician Edward P. McCabe encouraged Black settlers to come to what was then Indian Territory.

name: oklahoma
sentence: McCabe discussed with President Theodore Roosevelt the possibility of making Oklahoma a majority-Black state.

name: oklahoma
sentence: By the early 20th century, the Greenwood district of Tulsa was one of the most prosperous African-American communities in the United States.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Jim Crow laws had established racial segregation since before the start of the 20th century, but Tulsa's Black residents had created a thriving area.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Social tensions were exacerbated by the revival of the Ku Klux Klan after 1915.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Tulsa race massacre broke out in 1921, with White mobs attacking Black people and carrying out a pogrom in Greenwood.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In one of the costliest episodes of racist violence in American history, sixteen hours of rioting resulted in 35 city blocks destroyed, $1.8 million in property damage, and a death toll estimated to be as high as 300 people.

name: oklahoma
sentence: By the late 1920s, the Ku Klux Klan had declined to negligible influence within the state.

name: oklahoma
sentence: During the 1930s, parts of the state began suffering the consequences of poor farming practice.

name: oklahoma
sentence: This period was known as the Dust Bowl, throughout which areas of Kansas, Texas, New Mexico and northwestern Oklahoma were hampered by long periods of little rainfall, strong winds, and abnormally high temperatures, sending thousands of farmers into poverty and forcing them to relocate to more fertile areas of the western United States.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Over a twenty-year period ending in 1950, the state saw its only historical decline in population, dropping 6.9 percent as impoverished families migrated out of the state after the Dust Bowl.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Soil and water conservation projects markedly changed practices in the state and led to the construction of massive flood control systems and dams

name: oklahoma
sentence: By the 1960s, Oklahoma had created more than 200 lakes, the most in the nation.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 1995, Oklahoma City was the site of one of the most destructive act of domestic terrorism in American history.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Oklahoma City bombing of April 19, 1995, in which Timothy McVeigh detonated a large, crude explosive device outside the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building, killed 168 people, including 19 children.

name: oklahoma
sentence: For his crime, McVeigh was executed by the federal government on June 11, 2001.

name: oklahoma
sentence: His accomplice, Terry Nichols, is serving life in prison without parole for helping plan the attack and prepare the explosive.

name: oklahoma
sentence: On May 31, 2016, several cities experienced record setting flooding.

name: oklahoma
sentence: On July 9, 2020, the Supreme Court of the United States determined in McGirt v. Oklahoma that the reservations of the Five Tribes, comprising much of Eastern Oklahoma, were never disestablished by Congress and thus are still "Indian Country" for the purposes of criminal law.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The United States Census Bureau estimates Oklahoma's population was 3,956,971 on July 1, 2019, a 5.48% increase since the 2010 United States Census.

name: oklahoma
sentence: At the 2010 Census, 68.7% of the population was non-Hispanic white, down from 88% in 1970, 8.2% non-Hispanic American Indian and Alaska Native, 7.3% non-Hispanic black or African American, 1.7% non-Hispanic Asian, 0.1% non-Hispanic Native Hawaiian and Other Pacific Islander, 0.1% from some other race (non-Hispanic) and 5.1% of two or more races (non-Hispanic).

name: oklahoma
sentence: 8.9% of Oklahoma's population was of Hispanic, Latino, or Spanish origin (they may be of any race).

name: oklahoma
sentence: As of 2011, 47.3% of Oklahoma's population younger than age 1 were minorities, meaning they had at least one parent who was not non-Hispanic white.

name: oklahoma
sentence: As of 2005 Oklahoma's estimated ancestral makeup was 14.5% German, 13.1% American, 11.8% Irish, 9.6% English, 8.1% African American, and 11.4% Native American (including 7.9% Cherokee) though the percentage of people claiming American Indian as their only race was 8.1%.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Most people from Oklahoma who self-identify as having American ancestry are of overwhelmingly English and Scots-Irish ancestry with significant amounts of Scottish and Welsh inflection as well.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state had the second-highest number of Native Americans in 2002, estimated at 395,219, as well as the second-highest percentage among all states (behind Alaska).

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2011, US Census Bureau American Community Survey data from 2005 to 2009 indicated about 5% of Oklahoma's residents were born outside the United States.

name: oklahoma
sentence: This is lower than the national figure (about 12.5% of US residents were foreign-born).

name: oklahoma
sentence: The center of population of Oklahoma is in Lincoln County near the town of Sparks.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state's 2006 per capita personal income ranked 37th at $32,210, though it has the third-fastest-growing per capita income in the US Oklahoma ranks consistently among the lowest states in cost of living index.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Oklahoma City suburb Nichols Hills is first on Oklahoma locations by per capita income at $73,661, though Tulsa County holds the highest average.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2011, 7.0% of Oklahomans were under the age of 5, 24.7% under 18, and 13.7% were 65 or older.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Females made up 50.5% of the population.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state is in the US Census' Southern region.

name: oklahoma
sentence: According to the 2010 United States Census, Oklahoma is the 28th-most populous state with 3,751,616 inhabitants but the 19th-largest by land area spanning 68,594.92 square miles (177,660.0 km2) of land.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is divided into 77 counties and contains 597 incorporated municipalities consisting of cities and towns.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In Oklahoma, cities are all those incorporated communities which are 1,000 or more in population and are incorporated as cities.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Towns are limited to town board type of municipal government.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Cities may choose among aldermanic, mayoral, council-manager, and home-rule charter types of government.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Cities may also petition to incorporate as towns.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The English language has been official in the state of Oklahoma since 2010.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The variety of North American English spoken is called Oklahoma English, and this dialect is quite diverse with its uneven blending of features of North Midland, South Midland, and Southern dialects.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2000, 2,977,187 Oklahomans—92.6% of the resident population five years or older—spoke only English at home, a decrease from 95% in 1990.

name: oklahoma
sentence: 238,732 Oklahoma residents reported speaking a language other than English in the 2000 census, about 7.4% of the state's population.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The two most commonly spoken native North American languages are Cherokee and Choctaw with 10,000 Cherokee speakers living within the Cherokee Nation tribal jurisdiction area of eastern Oklahoma, and another 10,000 Choctaw speakers living in the Choctaw Nation directly south of the Cherokees.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Cherokee is an official language in the Cherokee Nation tribal jurisdiction area and in the United Keetoowah Band of Cherokee Indians.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Twenty-five Native American languages are spoken in Oklahoma, second only to California.

name: oklahoma
sentence: However, only Cherokee, if any, exhibits some language vitality at present.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Ethnologue sees Cherokee as moribund because the only remaining active users of the language are members of the grandparent generation and older.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Spanish is the second-most commonly spoken language in the state, with 141,060 speakers counted in 2000.

name: oklahoma
sentence: German has 13,444 speakers representing about 0.4% of the state's population, and Vietnamese is spoken by 11,330 people, or about 0.4% of the population, many of whom live in the Asia District of Oklahoma City.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Other languages include French with 8,258 speakers (0.3%), Chinese with 6,413 (0.2%), Korean with 3,948 (0.1%), Arabic with 3,265 (0.1%), other Asian languages with 3,134 (0.1%), Tagalog with 2,888 (0.1%), Japanese with 2,546 (0.1%), and African languages with 2,546 (0.1%).

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is part of a geographical region characterized by conservative and Evangelical Christianity known as the "Bible Belt".

name: oklahoma
sentence: Spanning the southern and eastern parts of the United States, the area is known for politically and socially conservative views, with the Republican Party having the greater number of voters registered between the two parties.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Tulsa, the state's second-largest city, home to Oral Roberts University, is sometimes called the "buckle of the Bible Belt".

name: oklahoma
sentence: According to the Pew Research Center, the majority of Oklahoma's religious adherents are Christian, accounting for about 80 percent of the population.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The percentage of Catholics is half the national average, while the percentage of Evangelical Protestants is more than twice the national average (tied with Arkansas for the largest percentage of any state).

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2010, the state's largest church memberships were in the Southern Baptist Convention (886,394 members), the United Methodist Church (282,347), the Roman Catholic Church (178,430), and the Assemblies of God (85,926) and The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (47,349).

name: oklahoma
sentence: Other religions represented in the state include Buddhism, Hinduism, and Islam.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2000, there were about 5,000 Jews and 6,000 Muslims, with ten congregations to each group.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma religious makeup:

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has been described as "the world's prison capital", with 1,079 of every 100,000 residents imprisoned in 2018, the highest incarceration rate of any state, and by comparison, higher than the incarceration rates of any country in the world.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is host to a diverse range of sectors including aviation, energy, transportation equipment, food processing, electronics, and telecommunications.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is an important producer of natural gas, aircraft, and food.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state ranks third in the nation for production of natural gas, is the 27th-most agriculturally productive state, and also ranks 5th in production of wheat.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Four Fortune 500 companies and six Fortune 1000 companies are headquartered in Oklahoma, and it has been rated one of the most business-friendly states in the nation, with the 7th-lowest tax burden in 2007.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2010, Oklahoma City-based Love's Travel Stops & Country Stores ranked 18th on the Forbes list of largest private companies, Tulsa-based QuikTrip ranked 37th, and Oklahoma City-based Hobby Lobby ranked 198th in 2010 report.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma's gross domestic product grew from $131.9 billion in 2006 to $147.5 billion in 2010, a jump of 10.6 percent.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma's gross domestic product per capita was $35,480 in 2010, which was ranked 40th among the states.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Though oil has historically dominated the state's economy, a collapse in the energy industry during the 1980s led to the loss of nearly 90,000 energy-related jobs between 1980 and 2000, severely damaging the local economy.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oil accounted for 35 billion dollars in Oklahoma's economy in 2007, and employment in the state's oil industry was outpaced by five other industries in 2007.

name: oklahoma
sentence: As of September 2020, the state's unemployment rate is 5.3%.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In mid-2011, Oklahoma had a civilian labor force of 1.7 million and non-farm employment fluctuated around 1.5 million.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The government sector provides the most jobs, with 339,300 in 2011, followed by the transportation and utilities sector, providing 279,500 jobs, and the sectors of education, business, and manufacturing, providing 207,800, 177,400, and 132,700 jobs, respectively.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Among the state's largest industries, the aerospace sector generates $11 billion annually.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Tulsa is home to the largest airline maintenance base in the world, which serves as the global maintenance and engineering headquarters for American Airlines.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In total, aerospace accounts for more than 10 percent of Oklahoma's industrial output, and it is one of the top 10 states in aerospace engine manufacturing.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Because of its position in the center of the United States, Oklahoma is also among the top states for logistic centers, and a major contributor to weather-related research.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state is the top manufacturer of tires in North America and contains one of the fastest-growing biotechnology industries in the nation.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2005, international exports from Oklahoma's manufacturing industry totaled $4.3 billion, accounting for 3.6 percent of its economic impact.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Tire manufacturing, meat processing, oil and gas equipment manufacturing, and air conditioner manufacturing are the state's largest manufacturing industries.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is the nation's third-largest producer of natural gas, and its fifth-largest producer of crude oil.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state also has the second-greatest number of active drilling rigs, and it is even ranked fifth in crude oil reserves.

name: oklahoma
sentence: While the state was ranked eighth for installed wind energy capacity in 2011, it still was at the bottom of states in usage of renewable energy in 2009, with 94% of its electricity being generated by non-renewable sources in 2009, including 25% from coal and 46% from natural gas.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Ten years later in 2019, 53.5 % of electricity was produced from natural gas and 34.6 % from wind power.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has no nuclear power plant.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Ranking 13th for total energy consumption per capita in 2009, the state's energy costs were eighth-lowest in the nation.

name: oklahoma
sentence: As a whole, the oil energy industry contributes $35 billion to Oklahoma's gross domestic product (GDP), and employees of the state's oil-related companies earn an average of twice the state's typical yearly income.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2009, the state had 83,700 commercial oil wells churning 65.374 million barrels (10,393,600 m3) of crude oil.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Eight and a half percent of the nation's natural gas supply is held in Oklahoma, with 1.673 trillion cubic feet (47.4 km3) being produced in 2009.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Oklahoma Stack Play is a geographic referenced area in the Anadarko Basin.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The oil field "Sooner Trend", Anadarko basin and the counties of Kingfisher and Canadian make up the basis for the "Oklahoma STACK".

name: oklahoma
sentence: Other Plays such as the Eagle Ford are geological rather than geographical.

name: oklahoma
sentence: According to Forbes magazine, Oklahoma City-based Devon Energy Corporation, Chesapeake Energy Corporation, and SandRidge Energy Corporation are the largest private oil-related companies in the nation, and all Oklahoma's Fortune 500 companies are energy-related.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Tulsa's ONEOK and Williams Companies are the state's largest and second-largest companies respectively, also ranking as the nation's second- and third-largest companies in the field of energy, according to Fortune magazine.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The magazine also placed Devon Energy as the second-largest company in the mining and crude oil-producing industry in the nation, while Chesapeake Energy ranks seventh respectively in that sector and Oklahoma Gas & Electric ranks as the 25th-largest gas and electric utility company.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma Gas & Electric, commonly referred to as OG&E (NYSE: OGE) operates four base electric power plants in Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Two of them are coal-fired power plants: one in Muskogee, and the other in Red Rock.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Two are gas-fired power plants: one in Harrah and the other in Konawa.

name: oklahoma
sentence: OG&E was the first electric company in Oklahoma to generate electricity from wind farms in 2003.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The 27th-most agriculturally productive state, Oklahoma is fifth in cattle production and fifth in production of wheat.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Approximately 5.5 percent of American beef comes from Oklahoma, while the state produces 6.1 percent of American wheat, 4.2 percent of American pig products, and 2.2 percent of dairy products.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state had 85,500 farms in 2012, collectively producing $4.3 billion in animal products and fewer than one billion dollars in crop output with more than $6.1 billion added to the state's gross domestic product.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Poultry and swine are its second- and third-largest agricultural industries.

name: oklahoma
sentence: With an educational system made up of public school districts and independent private institutions, Oklahoma had 638,817 students enrolled in 1,845 public primary, secondary, and vocational schools in 533 school districts as of 2008.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has the highest enrollment of Native American students in the nation with 126,078 students in the 2009–10 school year.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma spent $7,755 for each student in 2008, and was 47th in the nation in expenditures per student, though its growth of total education expenditures between 1992 and 2002 ranked 22nd.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state is among the best in pre-kindergarten education, and the National Institute for Early Education Research rated it first in the United States with regard to standards, quality, and access to pre-kindergarten education in 2004, calling it a model for early childhood schooling.

name: oklahoma
sentence: High school dropout rate decreased from 3.1 to 2.5 percent between 2007 and 2008 with Oklahoma ranked among 18 other states with 3 percent or less dropout rate.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2004, the state ranked 36th in the nation for the relative number of adults with high school diplomas, though at 85.2 percent, it had the highest rate among Southern states.

name: oklahoma
sentence: According to a study conducted by the Pell Institute, Oklahoma ranks 48th in college-participation for low-income students.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The University of Oklahoma, Oklahoma State University, the University of Central Oklahoma, and Northeastern State University are the largest public institutions of higher education in Oklahoma, operating through one primary campus and satellite campuses throughout the state.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The two state universities, along with Oklahoma City University and the University of Tulsa, rank among the country's best in undergraduate business programs.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma City University School of Law, University of Oklahoma College of Law, and University of Tulsa College of Law are the state's only ABA-accredited institutions.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Both University of Oklahoma and University of Tulsa are Tier 1 institutions, with the University of Oklahoma ranked 68th and the University of Tulsa ranked 86th in the nation.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma holds eleven public regional universities, including Northeastern State University, the second-oldest institution of higher education west of the Mississippi River, also containing the only College of Optometry in Oklahoma and the largest enrollment of Native American students in the nation by percentage and amount.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Langston University is Oklahoma's only historically black college.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Six of the state's universities were placed in the Princeton Review's list of best 122 regional colleges in 2007, and three made the list of top colleges for best value.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state has 55 post-secondary technical institutions operated by Oklahoma's CareerTech program for training in specific fields of industry or trade.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In the 2007–2008 school year, there were 181,973 undergraduate students, 20,014 graduate students, and 4,395 first-professional degree students enrolled in Oklahoma colleges.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Of these students, 18,892 received a bachelor's degree, 5,386 received a master's degree, and 462 received a first professional degree.

name: oklahoma
sentence: This means the state of Oklahoma produces an average of 38,278-degree-holders per completions component (i.e.

name: oklahoma
sentence: National average is 68,322 total degrees awarded per completions component.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Beginning on April 2, 2018, tens of thousands of K–12 public school teachers went on strike due to lack of funding.

name: oklahoma
sentence: According to the National Education Association, teachers in Oklahoma had ranked 49th out of the 50 states in terms of teacher pay in 2016.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Oklahoma Legislature had passed a measure a week earlier to raise teacher salaries by $6,100, but it fell short of the $10,000 raise for teachers, $5,000 raise for other school employees, and $200 million increase in extra education funding many had sought.

name: oklahoma
sentence: A survey in 2019 found that the pay raise obtained by the strike lifted the State's teacher pay ranking to 34th in the nation.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Cherokee Nation instigated a ten-year plan in 2005 that involved growing new speakers of the Cherokee language from childhood as well as speaking it exclusively at home.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The plan was part of an ambitious goal that in fifty years would have at least 80% of their people fluent.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Cherokee Preservation Foundation has invested $3 million into opening schools, training teachers, and developing curricula for language education, as well as initiating community gatherings where the language can be actively used.A Cherokee language immersion school in Tahlequah, Oklahoma educates students from pre-school through eighth grade.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is placed in the South by the United States Census Bureau, but other definitions place the state at least partly in the Southwest, Midwest, Upland South, and Great Plains.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahomans have a high rate of English, Scotch-Irish, German, and Native American ancestry, with 25 different native languages spoken.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Because many Native Americans were forced to move to Oklahoma when White settlement in North America increased, Oklahoma has much linguistic diversity.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Mary Linn, an associate professor of anthropology at the University of Oklahoma and the associate curator of Native American languages at the Sam Noble Museum, notes Oklahoma also has high levels of language endangerment.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Sixty-seven Native American tribes are represented in Oklahoma, including 39 federally recognized tribes, who are headquartered and have tribal jurisdictional areas in the state.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Western ranchers, Native American tribes, Southern settlers, and eastern oil barons have shaped the state's cultural predisposition, and its largest cities have been named among the most underrated cultural destinations in the United States.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Residents of Oklahoma are associated with traits of Southern hospitality—the 2006 Catalogue for Philanthropy (with data from 2004) ranks Oklahomans 7th in the nation for overall generosity.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state has also been associated with a negative cultural stereotype first popularized by John Steinbeck's 1939 novel The Grapes of Wrath, which described the plight of uneducated, poverty-stricken Dust Bowl-era farmers deemed "Okies".

name: oklahoma
sentence: However, the term is often used in a positive manner by Oklahomans.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In the state's largest urban areas, pockets of jazz culture flourish, and Native American, Mexican American, and Asian American communities produce music and art of their respective cultures.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Oklahoma Mozart Festival in Bartlesville is one of the largest classical music festivals on the southern plains, and Oklahoma City's Festival of the Arts has been named one of the top fine arts festivals in the nation.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state has a rich history in ballet with five Native American ballerinas attaining worldwide fame.

name: oklahoma
sentence: These were Yvonne Chouteau, sisters Marjorie and Maria Tallchief, Rosella Hightower and Moscelyne Larkin, known collectively as the Five Moons.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The New York Times rates the Tulsa Ballet as one of the top ballet companies in the United States.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Oklahoma City Ballet and University of Oklahoma's dance program were formed by ballerina Yvonne Chouteau and husband Miguel Terekhov.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The University program was founded in 1962 and was the first fully accredited program of its kind in the United States.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In Sand Springs, an outdoor amphitheater called "Discoveryland!"

name: oklahoma
sentence: is the official performance headquarters for the musical Oklahoma!

name: oklahoma
sentence: Ridge Bond, native of McAlester, Oklahoma, starred in the Broadway and International touring productions of Oklahoma!, playing the role of "Curly McClain" in more than 2,600 performances.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 1953 he was featured along with the Oklahoma!

name: oklahoma
sentence: cast on a CBS Omnibus television broadcast.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Bond was instrumental in the Oklahoma!

name: oklahoma
sentence: title song becoming the Oklahoma state song and is also featured on the US postage stamp commemorating the musical's 50th anniversary.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Historically, the state has produced musical styles such as The Tulsa Sound and western swing, which was popularized at Cain's Ballroom in Tulsa.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The building, known as the "Carnegie Hall of Western Swing", served as the performance headquarters of Bob Wills and the Texas Playboys during the 1930s.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Stillwater is known as the epicenter of Red Dirt music, the best-known proponent of which is the late Bob Childers.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Prominent theatre companies in Oklahoma include, in the capital city, Oklahoma City Theatre Company, Carpenter Square Theatre, Oklahoma Shakespeare in the Park, and CityRep.

name: oklahoma
sentence: CityRep is a professional company affording equity points to those performers and technical theatre professionals.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In Tulsa, Oklahoma's oldest resident professional company is American Theatre Company, and Theatre Tulsa is the oldest community theatre company west of the Mississippi.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Other companies in Tulsa include Heller Theatre and Tulsa Spotlight Theater.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The cities of Norman, Lawton, and Stillwater, among others, also host well-reviewed community theatre companies.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is in the nation's middle percentile in per capita spending on the arts, ranking 17th, and contains more than 300 museums.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Philbrook Museum of Tulsa is considered one of the top 50 fine art museums in the United States, and the Sam Noble Oklahoma Museum of Natural History in Norman, one of the largest university-based art and history museums in the country, documents the natural history of the region.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The collections of Thomas Gilcrease are housed in the Gilcrease Museum of Tulsa, which also holds the world's largest, most comprehensive collection of art and artifacts of the American West.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Egyptian art collection at the Mabee-Gerrer Museum of Art in Shawnee is considered to be the finest Egyptian collection between Chicago and Los Angeles.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Oklahoma City Museum of Art contains the most comprehensive collection of glass sculptures by artist Dale Chihuly in the world, and Oklahoma City's National Cowboy & Western Heritage Museum documents the heritage of the American Western frontier.

name: oklahoma
sentence: With remnants of the Holocaust and artifacts relevant to Judaism, the Sherwin Miller Museum of Jewish Art of Tulsa preserves the largest collection of Jewish art in the Southwest United States.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma's centennial celebration was named the top event in the United States for 2007 by the American Bus Association, and consisted of multiple celebrations saving with the 100th anniversary of statehood on November 16, 2007.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Annual ethnic festivals and events take place throughout the state such as Native American powwows and ceremonial events, and include festivals (as examples) in Scottish, Irish, German, Italian, Vietnamese, Chinese, Czech, Jewish, Arab, Mexican and African-American communities depicting cultural heritage or traditions.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma City is home to a few reoccurring events and festivals.

name: oklahoma
sentence: During a ten-day run in Oklahoma City, the State Fair of Oklahoma attracts roughly one million people along with the annual Festival of the Arts.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Large national pow wows, various Latin and Asian heritage festivals, and cultural festivals such as the Juneteenth celebrations are held in Oklahoma City each year.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Oklahoma City Pride Parade has been held annually in late June since 1987 in the gay district of Oklahoma City on 39th and Penn.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The First Friday Art Walk in the Paseo Arts District is an art appreciation festival held the first Friday of every month.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Additionally, an annual art festival is held in the Paseo on Memorial Day Weekend.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Tulsa State Fair attracts more than a million people each year during its ten-day run, and the city's Mayfest festival entertained more than 375,000 in four days during 2007.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2006, Tulsa's Oktoberfest was named one of the top 10 in the world by USA Today and one of the top German food festivals in the nation by Bon Appétit magazine.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Norman plays host to the Norman Music Festival, a festival that highlights native Oklahoma bands and musicians.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Norman is also host to the Medieval Fair of Norman, which has been held annually since 1976 and was Oklahoma's first medieval fair.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Fair was held first on the south oval of the University of Oklahoma campus and in the third year moved to the Duck Pond in Norman until the Fair became too big and moved to Reaves Park in 2003.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Medieval Fair of Norman is Oklahoma's "largest weekend event and the third-largest event in Oklahoma, and was selected by Events Media Network as one of the top 100 events in the nation".

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has teams in basketball, football, arena football, baseball, soccer, hockey, and wrestling in Oklahoma City, Tulsa, Enid, Norman, and Lawton.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Oklahoma City Thunder of the National Basketball Association (NBA) is the state's only major league sports franchise.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state had a team in the Women's National Basketball Association, the Tulsa Shock, from 2010 through 2015, but the team relocated to Dallas–Fort Worth after that season and became the Dallas Wings.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has teams in several minor leagues, including Minor League Baseball at the AAA and AA levels (Oklahoma City Dodgers and Tulsa Drillers, respectively), hockey's ECHL with the Tulsa Oilers, and a number of indoor football leagues.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In the last-named sport, the state's most notable team was the Tulsa Talons, which played in the Arena Football League until 2012, when the team was moved to San Antonio.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Oklahoma Defenders replaced the Talons as Tulsa's only professional arena football team, playing the CPIFL.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Oklahoma City Blue, of the NBA G League, relocated to Oklahoma City from Tulsa in 2014, where they were formerly known as the Tulsa 66ers.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Tulsa is the base for the Tulsa Revolution, which plays in the American Indoor Soccer League.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Enid and Lawton host professional basketball teams in the USBL and the CBA.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The NBA's New Orleans Hornets became the first major league sports franchise based in Oklahoma when the team was forced to relocate to Oklahoma City's Ford Center, now known as Chesapeake Energy Arena, for two seasons following Hurricane Katrina in 2005.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In July 2008, the Seattle SuperSonics relocated to Oklahoma City and began to play at the Ford Center as the Oklahoma City Thunder for the 2008–09 season, becoming the state's first permanent major league franchise.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Collegiate athletics are a popular draw in the state.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state has four schools that compete at the highest level of college sports, NCAA Division I.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The most prominent are the state's two members of the Big 12 Conference, one of the so-called Power Five conferences of the top tier of college football, Division I FBS.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The University of Oklahoma and Oklahoma State University average well over 50,000 fans attending their football games, and Oklahoma's football program ranked 12th in attendance among American colleges in 2010, with an average of 84,738 people attending its home games.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The two universities meet several times each year in rivalry matches known as the Bedlam Series, which are some of the greatest sporting draws to the state.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Sports Illustrated magazine rates Oklahoma and Oklahoma State among the top colleges for athletics in the nation.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Two private institutions in Tulsa, the University of Tulsa and Oral Roberts University; are also Division I members.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Tulsa competes in FBS football and other sports in the American Athletic Conference, while Oral Roberts, which does not sponsor football, is a member of the Summit League.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In addition, 12 of the state's smaller colleges and universities compete in NCAA Division II as members of three different conferences, and eight other Oklahoma institutions participate in the NAIA, mostly within the Sooner Athletic Conference.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Regular LPGA tournaments are held at Cedar Ridge Country Club in Tulsa, and major championships for the PGA or LPGA have been played at Southern Hills Country Club in Tulsa, Oak Tree Country Club in Oklahoma City, and Cedar Ridge Country Club in Tulsa.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Rated one of the top golf courses in the nation, Southern Hills has hosted four PGA Championships, including one in 2007, and three US

name: oklahoma
sentence: Opens, the most recent in 2001.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Rodeos are popular throughout the state, and Guymon, in the state's panhandle, hosts one of the largest in the nation.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma was the 21st-largest recipient of medical funding from the federal government in 2005, with health-related federal expenditures in the state totaling $75,801,364; immunizations, bioterrorism preparedness, and health education were the top three most funded medical items.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Instances of major diseases are near the national average in Oklahoma, and the state ranks at or slightly above the rest of the country in percentage of people with asthma, diabetes, cancer, and hypertension.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2000, Oklahoma ranked 45th in physicians per capita and slightly below the national average in nurses per capita, but was slightly above the national average in hospital beds per 100,000 people and above the national average in net growth of health services over a twelve-year period.

name: oklahoma
sentence: One of the worst states for percentage of insured people, nearly 25 percent of Oklahomans between the age of 18 and 64 did not have health insurance in 2005, the fifth-highest rate in the nation.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahomans are in the upper half of Americans in terms of obesity prevalence, and the state is the 5th most obese in the nation, with 30.3 percent of its population at or near obesity.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma ranked last among the 50 states in a 2007 study by the Commonwealth Fund on health care performance.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The OU Medical Center, Oklahoma's largest collection of hospitals, is the only hospital in the state designated a Level I trauma center by the American College of Surgeons.

name: oklahoma
sentence: OU Medical Center is on the grounds of the Oklahoma Health Center in Oklahoma City, the state's largest concentration of medical research facilities.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Cancer Treatment Centers of America at Southwestern Regional Medical Center in Tulsa is one of four such regional facilities nationwide, offering cancer treatment to the entire southwestern United States, and is one of the largest cancer treatment hospitals in the country.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The largest osteopathic teaching facility in the nation, Oklahoma State University Medical Center at Tulsa, also rates as one of the largest facilities in the field of neuroscience.On June 26, 2018, Oklahoma made marijuana legal for medical purposes, making it one of the most conservative states to approve medical marijuana.=

name: oklahoma
sentence: The residents of Oklahoma have a lower life expectancy than average compared to many other states.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2014, males in Oklahoma lived an average of 73.7 years compared to a national average of 76.7 years and females lived an average of 78.5 years compared to a national average of 81.5 years.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Moreover, increases in life expectancy have been below the national average.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Male life expectancy in Oklahoma between 1980 and 2014 increased by an average of 4.0 years, compared to a national average of a 6.7 year increase in life expectancy for males.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Life expectancy for females in Oklahoma between 1980 and 2014 increased by 1.0 years compared to a national average of a 4.0 year increase in life expectancy for females.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Using 2016-2018 data, the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation calculated that life expectancy for Oklahoma counties ranged from 71.2 years for Okfuskee County to 79.7 years for Cimarron and Logan counties.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Life expectancy for the state as a whole was 76.0 years.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma City and Tulsa are the 45th- and 61st-largest media markets in the United States as ranked by Nielsen Media Research.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state's third-largest media market, Lawton-Wichita Falls, Texas, is ranked 149th nationally by the agency.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Broadcast television in Oklahoma began in 1949 when KFOR-TV (then WKY-TV) in Oklahoma City and KOTV-TV in Tulsa began broadcasting a few months apart.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Currently, all major American broadcast networks have affiliated television stations in the state.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state has two primary newspapers.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Oklahoman, based in Oklahoma City, is the largest newspaper in the state and 54th-largest in the nation by circulation, with a weekday readership of 138,493 and a Sunday readership of 202,690.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Tulsa World, the second-most widely circulated newspaper in Oklahoma and 79th in the nation, holds a Sunday circulation of 132,969 and a weekday readership of 93,558.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma's first newspaper was established in 1844, called the Cherokee Advocate, and was written in both Cherokee and English.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2006, there were more than 220 newspapers in the state, including 177 with weekly publications and 48 with daily publications.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state's first radio station, WKY in Oklahoma City, began broadcasting in 1920.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2006, there were more than 500 radio stations in Oklahoma broadcasting with various local or nationally owned networks.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Five universities in Oklahoma operate non-commercial, public radio stations/networks.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has a few ethnic-oriented TV stations broadcasting in Spanish and Asian languages, and there is some Native American programming.

name: oklahoma
sentence: TBN, a Christian religious television network, has a studio in Tulsa, and built its first entirely TBN-owned affiliate in Oklahoma City in 1980.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Transportation in Oklahoma is generated by an anchor system of Interstate Highways, inter-city rail lines, airports, inland ports, and mass transit networks.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Situated along an integral point in the United States Interstate network, Oklahoma contains three primary Interstate highways and four auxiliary Interstate Highways.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In Oklahoma City, Interstate 35 intersects with Interstate 44 and Interstate 40, forming one of the most important intersections along the United States highway system.

name: oklahoma
sentence: More than 12,000 miles (19,000 km) of roads make up the state's major highway skeleton, including state-operated highways, ten turnpikes or major toll roads, and the longest drivable stretch of Route 66 in the nation.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2008, Interstate 44 in Oklahoma City was Oklahoma's busiest highway, with a daily traffic volume of 123,300 cars.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2010, the state had the nation's third-highest number of bridges classified as structurally deficient, with nearly 5,212 bridges in disrepair, including 235 National Highway System Bridges.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma's largest commercial airport is Will Rogers World Airport in Oklahoma City, averaging a yearly passenger count of more than 3.5 million (1.7 million boardings) in 2010.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Tulsa International Airport, the state's second-largest commercial airport, served more than 1.3 million boardings in 2010.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Between the two, six airlines operate in Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In terms of traffic, R. L. Jones Jr. (Riverside) Airport in Tulsa is the state's busiest airport, with 335,826 takeoffs and landings in 2008.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has more than 150 public-use airports.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is connected to the nation's rail network via Amtrak's Heartland Flyer, its only regional passenger rail line.

name: oklahoma
sentence: It currently stretches from Oklahoma City to Fort Worth, Texas, though lawmakers began seeking funding in early 2007 to connect the Heartland Flyer to Tulsa.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Two inland ports on rivers serve Oklahoma: the Port of Muskogee and the Tulsa Port of Catoosa.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Tulsa Port of Catoosa is the one of the United States' most inland international ports, at head of navigation of the McClellan–Kerr Arkansas River Navigation System, which connects barge traffic from Tulsa and Muskogee to the Mississippi River.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The port ships over two million tons of goods annually and is a designated foreign trade zone.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is a constitutional republic with a government modeled after the Federal government of the United States, with executive, legislative, and judicial branches.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state has 77 counties with jurisdiction over most local government functions within each respective domain, five congressional districts, and a voting base with a plurality in the Republican Party.

name: oklahoma
sentence: State officials are elected by plurality voting in the state of Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has capital punishment as a legal sentence, and the state has had (between 1976 through mid-2011) the highest per capita execution rate in the nation.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Legislature of Oklahoma consists of the Senatorte and the House of Representatives.

name: oklahoma
sentence: As the lawmaking branch of the state government, it is responsible for raising and distributing the money necessary to run the government.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Senatorte has 48 members serving four-year terms, while the House has 101 members with two-year terms.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state has a term limit for its legislature that restricts any one person to twelve cumulative years service between both legislative branches.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma's judicial branch consists of the Oklahoma Supreme Court, the Oklahoma Court of Criminal Appeals, and 77 District Courts that each serve one county.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Oklahoma judiciary also contains two independent courts: a Court of Impeachment and the Oklahoma Court on the Judiciary.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has two courts of last resort: the state Supreme Court hears civil cases, and the state Court of Criminal Appeals hears criminal cases (this split system exists only in Oklahoma and neighboring Texas).

name: oklahoma
sentence: Judges of those two courts, as well as the Court of Civil Appeals are appointed by the Governor upon the recommendation of the state Judicial Nominating Commission, and are subject to a non-partisan retention vote on a six-year rotating schedule.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The executive branch consists of the Governor, their staff, and other elected officials.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The principal head of government, the Governor is the chief executive of the Oklahoma executive branch, serving as the ex officio Commander-in-chief of the Oklahoma National Guard when not called into Federal use and reserving the power to veto bills passed through the Legislature.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The responsibilities of the Executive branch include submitting the budget, ensuring state laws are enforced, and ensuring peace within the state is preserved.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state is divided into 77 counties that govern locally, each headed by a three-member council of elected commissioners, a tax assessor, clerk, court clerk, treasurer, and sheriff.

name: oklahoma
sentence: While each municipality operates as a separate and independent local government with executive, legislative and judicial power, county governments maintain jurisdiction over both incorporated cities and non-incorporated areas within their boundaries, but have executive power but no legislative or judicial power.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Both county and municipal governments collect taxes, employ a separate police force, hold elections, and operate emergency response services within their jurisdiction.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Other local government units include school districts, technology center districts, community college districts, rural fire departments, rural water districts, and other special use districts.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Thirty-nine Native American tribal governments are based in Oklahoma, each holding limited powers within designated areas.

name: oklahoma
sentence: While Indian reservations typical in most of the United States are not present in Oklahoma, tribal governments hold land granted during the Indian Territory era, but with limited jurisdiction and no control over state governing bodies such as municipalities and counties.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Tribal governments are recognized by the United States as quasi-sovereign entities with executive, judicial, and legislative powers over tribal members and functions, but are subject to the authority of the United States Congress to revoke or withhold certain powers.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The tribal governments are required to submit a constitution and any subsequent amendments to the United States Congress for approval.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has 11 substate districts including the two large Councils of Governments, INCOG in Tulsa (Indian Nations Council of Governments) and ACOG (Association of Central Oklahoma Governments).

name: oklahoma
sentence: During the first half-century of statehood, Oklahoma was considered a Democratic stronghold, being carried by the Republican Party in only two presidential elections (1920 and 1928).

name: oklahoma
sentence: After the 1948 election, the state turned firmly Republican.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Although registered Republicans were a minority in the state until 2015, Oklahoma has been carried by Republican presidential candidates in all but one election since 1952: Lyndon B. Johnson's 1964 landslide victory.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Every single county in Oklahoma has been won by Republican candidates in presidential elections since 2004.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Generally, Republicans are strongest in the suburbs of Oklahoma City and Tulsa, as well as the Panhandle.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Democrats are strongest in the eastern part of the state and Little Dixie, as well as the most heavily African American and inner parts of Oklahoma City and Tulsa.

name: oklahoma
sentence: With a population of 8.6% Native American in the state, it is also worth noting that most Native American precincts vote Democratic in margins exceeded only by African Americans.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Following the 2000 census, the Oklahoma delegation to the US House of Representatives was reduced from six to five representatives, each serving one congressional district.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In the current Congress, Republicans comprise Oklahoma's entire delegation.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma had 598 incorporated places in 2010, including four cities over 100,000 in population and 43 over 10,000.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Two of the fifty largest cities in the United States are in Oklahoma, Oklahoma City and Tulsa, and sixty-five percent of Oklahomans live within their metropolitan areas, or spheres of economic and social influence defined by the United States Census Bureau as a metropolitan statistical area.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma City, the state's capital and largest city, had the largest metropolitan area in the state in 2010, with 1,252,987 people, and the metropolitan area of Tulsa had 937,478 residents.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Between 2000 and 2010, the leading cities in population growth were Blanchard (172.4%), Elgin (78.2%), Jenks (77.0%), Piedmont (56.7%), Bixby (56.6%), and Owasso (56.3%).

name: oklahoma
sentence: In descending order of population, Oklahoma's largest cities in 2010 were: Oklahoma City (579,999, +14.6%), Tulsa (391,906, −0.3%), Norman (110,925, +15.9%), Broken Arrow (98,850, +32.0%), Lawton (96,867, +4.4%), Edmond (81,405, +19.2%), Moore (55,081, +33.9%), Midwest City (54,371, +0.5%), Enid (49,379, +5.0%), and Stillwater (45,688, +17.0%).

name: oklahoma
sentence: Of the state's ten largest cities, three are outside the metropolitan areas of Oklahoma City and Tulsa, and only Lawton has a metropolitan statistical area of its own as designated by the United States Census Bureau, though the metropolitan statistical area of Fort Smith, Arkansas extends into the state.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Under Oklahoma law, municipalities are divided into two categories: cities, defined as having more than 1,000 residents, and towns, with under 1,000 residents.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Both have legislative, judicial, and public power within their boundaries, but cities can choose between a mayor–council, council–manager, or strong mayor form of government, while towns operate through an elected officer system.

name: oklahoma
sentence: State law codifies Oklahoma's state emblems and honorary positions

name: oklahoma
sentence: In 2012 the House passed HR1024, which would change the state motto from "Labor Omnia Vincit" to "Oklahoma—In God We Trust!"

name: oklahoma
sentence: The author of the resolution stated a constituent researched the Oklahoma Constitution and found no "official" vote regarding "Labor Omnia Vincit", therefore opening the door for an entirely new motto.

name: oregon
sentence: Oregon ( (listen) ORR-(ih)-gən) is a state in the Pacific Northwest region on the West Coast of the United States.

name: oregon
sentence: The Columbia River delineates much of Oregon's northern boundary with Washington, while the Snake River delineates much of its eastern boundary with Idaho.

name: oregon
sentence: The 42° north parallel delineates the southern boundary with California and Nevada.

name: oregon
sentence: Oregon has been home to many indigenous nations for thousands of years.

name: oregon
sentence: The first European traders, explorers, and settlers began exploring what is now Oregon's Pacific coast in the early-mid 1500s.

name: oregon
sentence: As early as 1565, the Spanish began sending vessels northeast from the Philippines, riding the Kuroshio Current in a sweeping circular route across the northern part of the Pacific.

name: oregon
sentence: In 1592, Juan de Fuca undertook detailed mapping and studies of ocean currents in the Pacific Northwest, including the Oregon coast as well as the strait now bearing his name.

name: oregon
sentence: Spanish ships – 250 in as many years – would typically not land before reaching Cape Mendocino in California, but some landed or wrecked in what is now Oregon.

name: oregon
sentence: Nehalem tales recount strangers and the discovery of items like chunks of beeswax and a lidded silver vase, likely connected to the 1707 wreck of the San Francisco Xavier.

name: oregon
sentence: In 1843, an autonomous government was formed in the Oregon Country, and the Oregon Territory was created in 1848.

name: oregon
sentence: Oregon became the 33rd state of the US on February 14, 1859.

name: oregon
sentence: Today, with 4 million people over 98,000 square miles (250,000 km2), Oregon is the ninth largest and 27th most populous US state.

name: oregon
sentence: The capital, Salem, is the second-most populous city in Oregon, with 169,798 residents.

name: oregon
sentence: Portland, with 647,805, ranks as the 26th among US cities.

name: oregon
sentence: The Portland metropolitan area, which also includes the city of Vancouver, Washington, to the north, ranks the 25th largest metro area in the nation, with a population of 2,453,168.

name: oregon
sentence: Oregon is one of the most geographically diverse states in the US, marked by volcanoes, abundant bodies of water, dense evergreen and mixed forests, as well as high deserts and semi-arid shrublands.

name: oregon
sentence: At 11,249 feet (3,429 m), Mount Hood, a stratovolcano, is the state's highest point.

name: oregon
sentence: Oregon's only national park, Crater Lake National Park, comprises the caldera surrounding Crater Lake, the deepest lake in the United States.

name: oregon
sentence: The state is also home to the single largest organism in the world, Armillaria ostoyae, a fungus that runs beneath 2,200 acres (8.9 km2) of the Malheur National Forest.

name: oregon
sentence: Because of its diverse landscapes and waterways, Oregon's economy is largely powered by various forms of agriculture, fishing, and hydroelectric power.

name: oregon
sentence: Oregon is also the top timber producer of the contiguous United States, and the timber industry dominated the state's economy in the 20th century.

name: oregon
sentence: Technology is another one of Oregon's major economic forces, beginning in the 1970s with the establishment of the Silicon Forest and the expansion of Tektronix and Intel.

name: oregon
sentence: Sportswear company Nike, Inc., headquartered in Beaverton, is the state's largest public corporation with an annual revenue of $30.6 billion.

name: oregon
sentence: The earliest evidence of the name Oregon has Spanish origins.

name: oregon
sentence: The term "orejón" (meaning "big ear") comes from the historical chronicle Relación de la Alta y Baja California (1598) written by the new Spaniard Rodrigo Montezuma and made reference to the Columbia River when the Spanish explorers penetrated into the actual North American territory that became part of the Viceroyalty of New Spain.

name: oregon
sentence: This chronicle is the first topographical and linguistic source with respect to the place name Oregon.

name: oregon
sentence: There are also two other sources with Spanish origins, such as the word oregano, referring to a plant which grows in the southern part of the region.

name: oregon
sentence: It is possible that the American territory was named by the Spaniards, as there is a stream in Spain called the "Arroyo del Oregón" (which is located in the province of Ciudad Real); it is also possible that the "j" in the Spanish phrase "El Orejón" was later corrupted into a "g", and in context might refer to the 'earful' of the massive Columbia River at its mouth.

name: oregon
sentence: Another early use of the name, spelled Ouragon, was by Major Robert Rogers in a 1765 petition to the Kingdom of Great Britain.

name: oregon
sentence: The term referred to the then-mythical River of the West (the Columbia River).

name: oregon
sentence: By 1778, the spelling had shifted to Oregon.

name: oregon
sentence: Rogers wrote:

name: oregon
sentence: One theory is that the name comes from the French word ouragan ("windstorm" or "hurricane"), which was applied to the River of the West based on Native American tales of powerful Chinook winds on the lower Columbia River, or perhaps from firsthand French experience with the Chinook winds of the Great Plains.

name: oregon
sentence: At the time, the River of the West was thought to rise in western Minnesota and flow west through the Great Plains.

name: oregon
sentence: Joaquin Miller explained in Sunset magazine, in 1904, how Oregon's name was derived:

name: oregon
sentence: Another account, endorsed as the "most plausible explanation" in the book Oregon Geographic Names, was advanced by George R. Stewart in a 1944 article in American Speech.

name: oregon
sentence: According to Stewart, the name came from an engraver's error in a French map published in the early 18th century, on which the Ouisiconsink (Wisconsin) River was spelled "Ouaricon-sint", broken on two lines with the -sint below, so there appeared to be a river flowing to the west named "Ouaricon".

name: oregon
sentence: According to the Oregon Tourism Commission, present-day Oregonians pronounce the state's name as "or-uh-gun, never or-ee-gone".

name: oregon
sentence: After being drafted by the Detroit Lions in 2002, former Oregon Ducks quarterback Joey Harrington distributed "Orygun" stickers to members of the media as a reminder of how to pronounce the name of his home state.

name: oregon
sentence: The stickers are sold by the University of Oregon Bookstore.

name: oregon
sentence: Oregon is 295 miles (475 km) north to south at longest distance, and 395 miles (636 km) east to west.

name: oregon
sentence: With an area of 98,381 square miles (254,810 km2), Oregon is slightly larger than the United Kingdom.

name: oregon
sentence: It is the ninth largest state in the United States.

name: oregon
sentence: Oregon's highest point is the summit of Mount Hood, at 11,249 feet (3,429 m), and its lowest point is the sea level of the Pacific Ocean along the Oregon Coast.

name: oregon
sentence: Oregon's mean elevation is 3,300 feet (1,006 m).

name: oregon
sentence: Crater Lake National Park, the state's only national park, is the site of the deepest lake in the United States at 1,943 feet (592 m).

name: oregon
sentence: Oregon claims the D River as the shortest river in the world, though the state of Montana makes the same claim of its Roe River.

name: oregon
sentence: Oregon is also home to Mill Ends Park (in Portland), the smallest park in the world at 452 square inches (0.29 m2).

name: oregon
sentence: Oregon is split into eight geographical regions.

name: oregon
sentence: In Western Oregon: Oregon Coast (west of the Coast Range), the Willamette Valley, Rogue Valley, Cascade Range and Klamath Mountains; and in Central and Eastern Oregon: the Columbia Plateau, the High Desert, and the Blue Mountains.

name: oregon
sentence: Oregon lies in two time zones.

name: oregon
sentence: Most of Malheur County is in the Mountain Time Zone, while the rest of the state lies in the Pacific Time Zone.

name: oregon
sentence: Western Oregon's mountainous regions, home to three of the most prominent mountain peaks of the United States including Mount Hood, were formed by the volcanic activity of the Juan de Fuca Plate, a tectonic plate that poses a continued threat of volcanic activity and earthquakes in the region.

name: oregon
sentence: The most recent major activity was the 1700 Cascadia earthquake.

name: oregon
sentence: Washington's Mount St. Helens erupted in 1980, an event visible from northern Oregon and affecting some areas there.

name: oregon
sentence: The Columbia River, which forms much of Oregon's northern border, also played a major role in the region's geological evolution, as well as its economic and cultural development.

name: oregon
sentence: The Columbia is one of North America's largest rivers, and one of two rivers to cut through the Cascades (the Klamath River in southern Oregon is the other).

name: oregon
sentence: About 15,000 years ago, the Columbia repeatedly flooded much of Oregon during the Missoula Floods; the modern fertility of the Willamette Valley is largely the result.

name: oregon
sentence: Plentiful salmon made parts of the river, such as Celilo Falls, hubs of economic activity for thousands of years.

name: oregon
sentence: Today, Oregon's landscape varies from rain forest in the Coast Range to barren desert in the southeast, which still meets the technical definition of a frontier.

name: oregon
sentence: Oregon's geographical center is further west than any of the other 48 contiguous states (although the westernmost point of the lower 48 states is in Washington).

name: oregon
sentence: Central Oregon's geographical features range from high desert and volcanic rock formations resulting from lava beds.

name: oregon
sentence: The Oregon Badlands Wilderness is in this region of the state.

name: oregon
sentence: Typical of a western state, Oregon is home to a unique and diverse array of wildlife.

name: oregon
sentence: Roughly 60 percent of the state is covered in forest, while the areas west of the Cascades are more densely populated by forest, making up around 80 percent of the landscape.

name: oregon
sentence: Some 60 percent of Oregon's forests are within federal land.

name: oregon
sentence: Oregon is the top timber producer of the lower 48 states.

name: oregon
sentence: Moose have not always inhabited the state but came to Oregon in the 1960s

name: oregon
sentence: Gray wolves were extirpated from Oregon around 1930 but have since found their way back; most reside in northeast Oregon, with two packs living in the south-central part.

name: oregon
sentence: Although their existence in Oregon is unconfirmed, reports of grizzly bears still turn up, and it is probable some still move into eastern Oregon from Idaho.

name: oregon
sentence: Oregon is home to what is considered the largest single organism in the world, an Armillaria solidipes fungus beneath the Malheur National Forest of eastern Oregon.

name: oregon
sentence: Oregon has several National Park System sites, including Crater Lake National Park in the southern part of the Cascades, John Day Fossil Beds National Monument east of the Cascades, Lewis and Clark National Historical Park on the north coast, and Oregon Caves National Monument near the south coast.

name: oregon
sentence: Most of Oregon has a generally mild climate, though there is significant variation given the variety of landscapes across the state.

name: oregon
sentence: The state's western region (west of the Cascade Range) has an oceanic climate, populated by dense evergreen mixed forests.

name: oregon
sentence: Western Oregon's climate is heavily influenced by the Pacific Ocean; the western third of Oregon is very wet in the winter, moderately to very wet during the spring and fall, and dry during the summer.

name: oregon
sentence: The relative humidity of Western Oregon is high except during summer days, which are semi-dry to semi-humid; Eastern Oregon typically sees low humidity year-round.

name: oregon
sentence: The state's southwestern portion, particularly the Rogue Valley, has a Mediterranean climate with drier and sunnier winters and hotter summers, similar to Northern California.

name: oregon
sentence: Oregon's northeastern portion has a steppe climate, and its high terrain regions have a subarctic climate.

name: oregon
sentence: Like Western Europe, Oregon, and the Pacific Northwest in general, is considered warm for its latitude, and the state has far milder winters at a given elevation than comparable latitudes elsewhere in North America, such as the Upper Midwest, Ontario, Quebec and New England.

name: oregon
sentence: However, the state ranks fifth for coolest summer temperatures of any state in the country, after Maine, Idaho, Wyoming, and Alaska.

name: oregon
sentence: The eastern two thirds of Oregon, which largely comprise high desert, have cold, snowy winters and very dry summers.

name: oregon
sentence: Much of the east is semiarid to arid like the rest of the Great Basin, though the Blue Mountains are wet enough to support extensive forests.

name: oregon
sentence: Most of Oregon receives significant snowfall, but the Willamette Valley, where 60 percent of the population lives, has considerably milder winters for its latitude and typically sees only light snowfall.

name: oregon
sentence: Oregon's highest recorded temperature is 119 °F (48 °C) at Pendleton on August 10, 1898, and the lowest recorded temperature is −54 °F (−48 °C) at Senatorca on February 10, 1933.

name: oregon
sentence: Humans have inhabited the area that is now Oregon for at least 15,000 years.

name: oregon
sentence: In recorded history, mentions of the land date to as early as the 16th century.

name: oregon
sentence: During the 18th and 19th centuries, European powers—and later the United States—quarreled over possession of the region until 1846, when the US and Great Britain finalized division of the region.

name: oregon
sentence: Oregon became a state on February 14, 1859, and as of 2015 has more than four million residents.

name: oregon
sentence: While there is considerable evidence that Paleo-Indians inhabited the region, the oldest evidence of habitation in Oregon was found at Fort Rock Cave and the Paisley Caves in Lake County.

name: oregon
sentence: Archaeologist Luther Cressman dated material from Fort Rock to 13,200 years ago, and there is evidence supporting inhabitants in the region at least 15,000 years ago.

name: oregon
sentence: By 8000 BC there were settlements throughout the state, with populations concentrated along the lower Columbia River, in the western valleys, and around coastal estuaries.

name: oregon
sentence: During the prehistoric period, the Willamette Valley region was flooded after the collapse of glacial dams from then Lake Missoula, located in what would later become Montana.

name: oregon
sentence: These massive floods occurred during the last glacial period and filled the valley with 300 to 400 feet (91 to 122 m) of water.

name: oregon
sentence: By the 16th century, Oregon was home to many Native American groups, including the Chinook, Coquille (Ko-Kwell), Bannock, Chasta, Kalapuya, Klamath, Klickitat, Molalla, Nez Perce, Takelma, Killamuk, Neah-kah-nie, Umatilla, and Umpqua.

name: oregon
sentence: The first Europeans to visit Oregon were Spanish explorers led by Juan Rodríguez Cabrillo, who sighted southern Oregon off the Pacific coast in 1543.

name: oregon
sentence: Sailing from Central America on the Golden Hind in 1579 in search of the Strait of Anian during his circumnavigation of the Earth, the English explorer and privateer Sir Francis Drake briefly anchored at South Cove, Cape Arago, just south of Coos Bay, before sailing for what is now California.

name: oregon
sentence: Martín de Aguilar, continuing separately from Sebastián Vizcaíno's scouting of California, reached as far north as Cape Blanco and possibly to Coos Bay in 1603.

name: oregon
sentence: Exploration continued routinely in 1774, starting with the expedition of the frigate Santiago by Juan José Pérez Hernández, and the coast of Oregon became a valuable trade route to Asia.

name: oregon
sentence: In 1778, British captain James Cook also explored the coast.

name: oregon
sentence: French Canadians, Scots, Métis and other continental natives (e.g.

name: oregon
sentence: Iroquois) trappers arrived in the late 18th and early 19th centuries, soon to be followed by Catholic clergy.

name: oregon
sentence: Some travelled as members of the Lewis and Clark and 1811 Astor expedition.

name: oregon
sentence: Few stayed permanently such as Étienne Lussier, often referred as the first "European" farmer in the state of Oregon.

name: oregon
sentence: Evidence of the French Canadian presence can be found in numerous names of French origin such as Malheur Lake, Malheur River, Grande Ronde, Deschutes rivers and the city of La Grande.

name: oregon
sentence: Furthermore, many of the early pioneers first came out West with the North West Company and the Hudson's Bay Company before heading South of the Columbia for better farmland as the fur trade declined.

name: oregon
sentence: French Prairie by the Willamette River and French Settlement by the Umpqua River are known as early mixed ancestry settlements.

name: oregon
sentence: The Lewis and Clark Expedition travelled through northern Oregon also in search of the Northwest Passage.

name: oregon
sentence: They built their winter fort in 1805–06 at Fort Clatsop, near the mouth of the Columbia River, staying at the encampment from December until March.

name: oregon
sentence: British explorer David Thompson also conducted overland exploration.

name: oregon
sentence: In 1811, while working for the North West Company, Thompson became the first European to navigate the entire Columbia River.

name: oregon
sentence: Stopping on the way, at the junction of the Snake River, he posted a claim to the region for Great Britain and the North West Company.

name: oregon
sentence: Upon returning to Montreal, he publicized the abundance of fur-bearing animals in the area.

name: oregon
sentence: Also in 1811, New Yorker John Jacob Astor financed the establishment of Fort Astoria at the mouth of the Columbia River as a western outpost to his Pacific Fur Company; this was the first permanent European settlement in Oregon.

name: oregon
sentence: In the War of 1812, the British gained control of all Pacific Fur Company posts.

name: oregon
sentence: The Treaty of 1818 established joint British and American occupancy of the region west of the Rocky Mountains to the Pacific Ocean.

name: oregon
sentence: By the 1820s and 1830s, the Hudson's Bay Company dominated the Pacific Northwest from its Columbia District headquarters at Fort Vancouver (built in 1825 by the district's chief factor, John McLoughlin, across the Columbia from present-day Portland).

name: oregon
sentence: In 1841, the expert trapper and entrepreneur Ewing Young died leaving considerable wealth and no apparent heir, and no system to probate his estate.

name: oregon
sentence: A meeting followed Young's funeral, at which a probate government was proposed.

name: oregon
sentence: Doctor Ira Babcock of Jason Lee's Methodist Mission was elected supreme judge.

name: oregon
sentence: Babcock chaired two meetings in 1842 at Champoeg, (halfway between Lee's mission and Oregon City), to discuss wolves and other animals of contemporary concern.

name: oregon
sentence: These meetings were precursors to an all-citizen meeting in 1843, which instituted a provisional government headed by an executive committee made up of David Hill, Alanson Beers, and Joseph Gale.

name: oregon
sentence: This government was the first acting public government of the Oregon Country before annexation by the government of the United States.

name: oregon
sentence: It was succeeded by a Second Executive Committee, made up of Peter G. Stewart, Osborne Russell, and William J. Bailey, and this committee was itself succeeded by George Abernethy, who was the first and only Governor of Oregon under the provisional government.

name: oregon
sentence: Also in 1841, Sir George Simpson, governor of the Hudson's Bay Company, reversed the Hudson's Bay Company's long-standing policy of discouraging settlement because it interfered with the lucrative fur trade.

name: oregon
sentence: He directed that some 200 Red River Colony settlers be relocated to HBC farms near Fort Vancouver, (the James Sinclair expedition), in an attempt to hold Columbia District.

name: oregon
sentence: Starting in 1842–43, the Oregon Trail brought many new American settlers to the Oregon Country.

name: oregon
sentence: Oregon's boundaries were disputed for a time, contributing to tensions between England and the US, but the border was defined peacefully in the 1846 Oregon Treaty.

name: oregon
sentence: The border between the United States and British North America was set at the 49th parallel.

name: oregon
sentence: The Oregon Territory was officially organized on August 13, 1848.

name: oregon
