sentence: It also has original jurisdiction to review warrants for wiretap surveillance.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The Commonwealth Court is limited to appeals from final orders of certain state agencies and certain designated cases from the Courts of Common Pleas.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The Supreme Court of Pennsylvania is the final appellate court.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: All judges in Pennsylvania are elected

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The Pennsylvania State Police is the chief law enforcement agency in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Pennsylvania is divided into 67 counties.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Counties are further subdivided into municipalities that are either incorporated as cities, boroughs, or townships.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: One county, Philadelphia County, is coterminous with the city of Philadelphia after it was consolidated in 1854.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The most populous county in Pennsylvania is Philadelphia, while the least populous is Cameron (5,085).

name: pennsylvania
sentence: There are a total of 56 cities in Pennsylvania, which are classified, by population, as either first-, second-, or third-class cities.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Philadelphia, Pennsylvania's largest city, has a population of 1,526,006 and is the state's only first-class city.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Pittsburgh (305,704) and Scranton (76,089) are second-class and second-class 'A' cities, respectively.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The rest of the cities, like the third and fourth-largest—Allentown (120,443) and Erie (98,593)—to the smallest—Parker with a population of only 820—are third-class cities.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: First- and second-class cities are governed by a "strong mayor" form of mayor–council government, whereas third-class cities are governed by either a "weak mayor" form of government or a council–manager government.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Boroughs are generally smaller than cities, with most Pennsylvania cities having been incorporated as a borough before being incorporated as a city.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: There are 958 boroughs in Pennsylvania, all of which are governed by the "weak mayor" form of mayor-council government.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The largest borough in Pennsylvania is State College (41,992) and the smallest is Centralia.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Townships are the third type of municipality in Pennsylvania and are classified as either first-class or second-class townships.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: There are 1,454 second-class townships and 93 first-class townships.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Second-class townships can become first-class townships if they have a population density greater than 300 inhabitants per square mile (120/km2) and a referendum is passed supporting the change.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Pennsylvania's largest township is Upper Darby Township (82,629), and the smallest is East Keating Township.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: There is one exception to the types of municipalities in Pennsylvania: Bloomsburg was incorporated as a town in 1870 and is, officially, the only town in the state.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: In 1975, McCandless Township adopted a home-rule charter under the name of "Town of McCandless", but is, legally, still a first-class township.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The total of 56 cities, 958 boroughs, 93 first-class townships, 1,454 second-class townships, and one town (Bloomsburg) is 2,562 municipalities.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: For most of the second half of the 20th century and into the 21st century, Pennsylvania has been a powerful swing state.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: It supported the losing candidate in a presidential election only twice from 1932 to 1988, (Herbert Hoover in 1932 and Hubert Humphrey in 1968).

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Since 1992, Pennsylvania has been trending Democratic in Presidential elections, voting for Bill Clinton twice by large margins, and slightly closer in 2000 for Al Gore.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: In the 2004 Presidential Election, Senatortor John F. Kerry beat President George W. Bush in Pennsylvania 2,938,095 (50.92%) to 2,793,847 (48.42%).

name: pennsylvania
sentence: In the 2008 Presidential Election, Democrat Barack Obama defeated Republican John McCain in Pennsylvania, 3,184,778 (54%) to 2,584,088 (44%).

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Most recently, in the 2016 presidential election, Donald Trump became the first Republican candidate to win the state since 1988, winning the state 48.6% to 47.8%.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The state, however, returned to the Democratic column in 2020 by narrowly voting for Joe Biden, the winner, over Trump.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The state holds 20 electoral votes.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: In recent national elections since 1992, Pennsylvania had leaned for the Democratic Party.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The state voted for the Democratic ticket for president in every election between 1992 and 2012.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: During the 2008 election campaign, a recruitment drive saw registered Democrats outnumber registered Republicans by 1.2 million.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: However, Pennsylvania has a history of electing Republican senators.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: From 2009 to 2011, the state was represented by two Democratic senators for the first time since 1947.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: In 2010, Republicans recaptured a US Senatorte seat as well as a majority of the state's congressional seats, control of both chambers of the state legislature and the governor's mansion.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Democrats won back the governor's mansion four years later in the 2014 election.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: It was the first time since a governor became eligible to succeed himself that an incumbent governor had been defeated for reelection.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Historically, Democratic strength was concentrated in Philadelphia in the southeast, the Pittsburgh and Johnstown areas in the southwest, and Scranton/Wilkes-Barre in the northeast.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Republican strength was concentrated in the Philadelphia suburbs, as well as the more rural areas in the central, northeastern, and western portions.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The latter counties have long been among the most conservative areas in the nation.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Since 1992, however, the Philadelphia suburbs have swung Democratic; the brand of Republicanism there was traditionally a moderate one.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The Pittsburgh suburbs, historically a Democratic stronghold, have swung more Republican since the turn of the millennium.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Democratic political consultant James Carville once pejoratively described Pennsylvania as "Philadelphia in the east, Pittsburgh in the west and Alabama in the middle".

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Political analysts and editorials refer to central Pennsylvania as the "T" in statewide elections.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The Three Valleys (Delaware, Lehigh, and Wyoming) and greater Pittsburgh generally vote for Democratic candidates, while the majority of the counties in the central part of the state vote Republican.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: As a result, maps showing the results of statewide elections invariably form a "T" shape.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Pennsylvania had the 15th-highest state and local tax burden in the United States in 2012, according to the Tax Foundation.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Residents paid a total of $83.7 billion in state and local taxes with a per capita average of $4,589 annually.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Residents share 76% of the total tax burden.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Many state politicians have tried to increase the share of taxes paid by out of state sources.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Suggested revenue sources include taxing natural gas drilling as Pennsylvania is the only state without such a tax on gas drilling.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Additional revenue prospects include trying to place tolls on interstate highways; specifically Interstate 80, which is used heavily by out of state commuters with high maintenance costs.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Sales taxes provide 39% of the Commonwealth's revenue; personal income taxes 34%; motor vehicle taxes about 12%, and taxes on cigarettes and alcoholic beverages 5%.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The personal income tax is a flat 3.07%.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: An individual's taxable income is based on the following eight types of income: compensation (salary); interest; dividends; net profits from the operation of a business, profession or farm; net gains or income from the dispositions of property; net gains or income from rents, royalties, patents and copyrights; income derived through estates or trusts; and gambling and lottery winnings (other than Pennsylvania Lottery winnings).

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Counties, municipalities, and school districts levy taxes on real estate.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: In addition, some local bodies assess a wage tax on personal income.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Generally, the total wage tax rate is capped at 1% of income but some municipalities with home rule charters may charge more than 1%.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Thirty-two of the Commonwealth's sixty-seven counties levy a personal property tax on stocks, bonds, and similar holdings.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: With the exception of the city of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, municipalities and school districts are allowed to enact a local earned income tax within the purview of Act 32.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Residents of these municipalities and school districts are required to file a local income tax return in addition to federal and state returns.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: This local return is filed with the local income tax collector, a private collection agency (e.g.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Berkheimer, Keystone Collections, and Jordan Tax Service) appointed by a particular county to collect the local earned income and local services tax (the latter a flat fee deducted from salaried employees working within a particular municipality or school district).

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The City of Philadelphia has its own local income taxation system.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Philadelphia-based employers are required to withhold the Philadelphia wage tax from the salaries of their employees.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Residents of Philadelphia working for an employer are not required to file a local return as long as their Philadelphia wage tax is fully withheld by their employer.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: If their employer does not withhold the Philadelphia wage tax, residents are required to register with the Revenue Department and file an Earnings Tax return.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Residents of Philadelphia with self-employment income are required to file a Net Profits Tax (NPT) return, while those with business income from Philadelphia sources are required to obtain a Commercial Activity License (CAL) and pay the Business Income and Receipts Tax (BIRT) and the NPT.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Residents with unearned income (except for interest from checking and savings accounts) are required to file and pay the School Income-tax (SIT).

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The complexity of Pennsylvania's local tax filing system has been criticized by experts, who note that the outsourcing of collections to private entities is akin to tax farming and that many new residents are caught off guard and end up facing "failure to file" penalties even if they did not owe any tax.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Attempts to transfer local income tax collections to the state level (i.e.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: by having a separate local section on the state income tax return, currently the method used to collect local income taxes in New York, Maryland, Indiana, and Iowa) have been unsuccessful.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Pennsylvania's two US

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Senatortors are Democrat Bob Casey, Jr. and Republican Pat Toomey.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Pennsylvania has 18 seats in the United States House of Representatives, as of the 2010 Census.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Pennsylvania has a mixed health record, and is ranked as the 29th-overall-healthiest state according to the 2013 United Health Foundation's Health Rankings.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Pennsylvania has 500 public school districts, thousands of private schools, publicly funded colleges and universities, and over 100 private institutions of higher education.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: In general, under state law, school attendance in Pennsylvania is mandatory for a child from the age of 8 until the age of 17, or until graduation from an accredited high school, whichever is earlier.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: As of 2005, 83.8% of Pennsylvania residents age 18 to 24 have completed high school.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Among residents age 25 and over, 86.7% have graduated from high school.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The following are the four-year graduation rates for students completing high school in 2016:

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Additionally, 27.5% have gone on to obtain a bachelor's degree or higher.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: State students consistently do well in standardized testing.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: In 2007, Pennsylvania ranked 14th in mathematics, 12th in reading, and 10th in writing for 8th grade students.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: In 1988, the Pennsylvania General Assembly passed Act 169, which allows parents or guardians to homeschool their children as an option for compulsory school attendance.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: This law specifies the requirements and responsibilities of the parents and the school district where the family lives.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The Pennsylvania State System of Higher Education (PASSHE) is the public university system of the Commonwealth, with 14 state-owned schools.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: West Chester University has by far the largest student body of the 14 universities.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The Commonwealth System of Higher Education is an organizing body of the four state-related schools in Pennsylvania; these schools (Pennsylvania State University, Lincoln University, the University of Pittsburgh, and Temple University) are independent institutions that receive some state funding.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: There are also 15 publicly funded two-year community colleges and technical schools that are separate from the PASSHE system.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Additionally, there are many private two- and four-year technical schools, colleges, and universities.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Carnegie Mellon University, The Pennsylvania State University, the University of Pennsylvania, and the University of Pittsburgh are members of the Association of American Universities, an invitation-only organization of leading research universities.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Lehigh University is a private research university located in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The Pennsylvania State University is the Commonwealth's land-grant university, Sea Grant College and, Space Grant College.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The University of Pennsylvania, located in Philadelphia, is considered the first university in the United States and established the country's first medical school.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The University of Pennsylvania is also the Commonwealth's only, and geographically most southern, Ivy League school.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The Lake Erie College of Osteopathic Medicine (LECOM) is a private graduate school of medicine, dentistry, and pharmacy with a main campus in Erie, Pennsylvania, and a branch campus located in Greensburg, Pennsylvania (with two other campuses outside of Pennsylvania).

name: pennsylvania
sentence: With over 2,200 enrolled medical students, the College of Osteopathic Medicine at LECOM is the largest medical school in the United States.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts is the first and oldest art school in the United States.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Philadelphia College of Pharmacy, now a part of University of the Sciences in Philadelphia, was the first pharmacy school in the United States.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Pennsylvania is home to the nation's first zoo, the Philadelphia Zoo.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Other long-accredited AZA zoos include the Erie Zoo and the Pittsburgh Zoo & PPG Aquarium.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The Lehigh Valley Zoo and ZOOAMERICA are other notable zoos.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The Commonwealth boasts some of the finest museums in the country, including the Carnegie Museums in Pittsburgh, the Philadelphia Museum of Art, and several others.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: One unique museum is the Houdini Museum in Scranton, the only building in the world devoted to the legendary magician.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Pennsylvania is also home to the National Aviary, located in Pittsburgh.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: All 121 state parks in Pennsylvania feature free admission.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Pennsylvania offers a number of notable amusement parks, including Camel Beach, Conneaut Lake Park, Dorney Park & Wildwater Kingdom, Dutch Wonderland, DelGrosso's Amusement Park, Hersheypark, Idlewild Park, Kennywood, Knoebels, Lakemont Park, Sandcastle Waterpark, Sesame Place, Great Wolf Lodge and Waldameer Park.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Pennsylvania also is home to the largest indoor waterpark resort on the East Coast, Splash Lagoon in Erie.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: There are also notable music festivals that take place in Pennsylvania.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: These include Musikfest and NEARfest in Bethlehem, the Philadelphia Folk Festival, Creation Festival, the Great Allentown Fair, and Purple Door.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: There are nearly one million licensed hunters in Pennsylvania.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Whitetail deer, black bear, cottontail rabbits, squirrel, turkey, and grouse are common game species.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Pennsylvania is considered one of the finest wild turkey hunting states in the Union, alongside Texas and Alabama.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Sport hunting in Pennsylvania provides a massive boost for the Commonwealth's economy.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: A report from The Center for Rural Pennsylvania (a Legislative Agency of the Pennsylvania General Assembly) reported that hunting, fishing, and furtaking generated a total of $9.6 billion statewide.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The Boone and Crockett Club shows that five of the ten largest (skull size) black bear entries came from the state.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The state also has a tied record for the largest hunter shot black bear in the Boone & Crockett books at 733 lb (332 kg) and a skull of 23 3/16 tied with a bear shot in California in 1993.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The largest bear ever found dead was in Utah in 1975, and the second-largest was shot by a poacher in the state in 1987.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Pennsylvania holds the second-highest number of Boone & Crockett-recorded record black bears at 183, second only to Wisconsin's 299.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The Pennsylvania Department of Transportation, abbreviated as PennDOT, owns 39,861 miles (64,150 km) of the 121,770 miles (195,970 km) of roadway in the state, making it the fifth-largest state highway system in the United States.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The Pennsylvania Turnpike system is 535 miles (861 km) long, with the mainline portion stretching from Ohio to Philadelphia and New Jersey.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: It is overseen by the Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Another major east–west route is Interstate 80, which runs primarily in the northern tier of the state from Ohio to New Jersey at the Delaware Water Gap.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Interstate 90 travels the relatively short distance between Ohio and New York through Erie County, in the extreme northwestern part of the state.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Primary north–south highways are Interstate 79 from its terminus in Erie through Pittsburgh to West Virginia, Interstate 81 from New York through Scranton, Lackawanna County and Harrisburg to Maryland and Interstate 476, which begins 7 miles (11 km) north of the Delaware border, in Chester, Delaware County and travels 132 miles (212 km) to Clarks Summit, Lackawanna County, where it joins I-81.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: All but 20 miles (32 km) of I-476 is the Northeast Extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike, while the highway south of the mainline of the Pennsylvania Turnpike is officially called the "Veterans Memorial Highway", but is commonly referred to by locals as the "Blue Route".

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority (SEPTA) is the sixth-largest transit agency in the United States and operates the commuter, heavy and light rail transit, and transit bus service in the Philadelphia metropolitan area.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: The Port Authority of Allegheny County is the 25th-largest transit agency and provides transit bus and light rail service in and around Pittsburgh.

name: pennsylvania

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Pennsylvania has been known as the Keystone State since 1802, based in part upon its central location among the original Thirteen Colonies forming the United States, and also in part because of the number of important American documents signed in the state (such as the Declaration of Independence).

name: pennsylvania
sentence: It was also a keystone state economically, having both the industry common to the North (making such wares as Conestoga wagons and rifles) and the agriculture common to the South (producing feed, fiber, food, and tobacco).

name: pennsylvania
sentence: Another one of Pennsylvania's nicknames is the Quaker State; in colonial times, it was known officially as the Quaker Province, in recognition of Quaker William Penn's First Frame of Government constitution for Pennsylvania that guaranteed liberty of conscience.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: He knew of the hostility Quakers faced when they opposed religious ritual, taking oaths, violence, war and military service, and what they viewed as ostentatious frippery.

name: pennsylvania
sentence: "The Coal State", "The Oil State", "The Chocolate State", and "The Steel State" were adopted when those were the state's greatest industries.

sentence: "The State of Independence" currently appears on many road signs entering the state.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island ( (listen), like road) is a state in the New England region of the United States.

name: rhode_island
sentence: It is the smallest US state by area and the seventh least populous (1,059,361 as of 2019), but it is also the second most densely populated behind New Jersey.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The state takes its name from Rhode Island; however, most of the state is located on the mainland.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The state has land borders with Connecticut to the west, Massachusetts to the north and east, and the Atlantic Ocean to the south via Rhode Island Sound and Block Island Sound.

name: rhode_island
sentence: It also shares a small maritime border with New York.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Providence is the state capital and most populous city in Rhode Island.

name: rhode_island
sentence: On May 4, 1776, the Colony of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations was the first of the Thirteen Colonies to renounce its allegiance to the British Crown, and it was the fourth state to ratify the Articles of Confederation, doing so on February 9, 1778.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The state boycotted the 1787 convention which drew up the United States Constitution and initially refused to ratify it; it was the last of the original 13 states to do so, on May 29, 1790.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Formally named the State of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations since its accession to the Union in 1790, voters in the state approved an amendment in November 2020 to the state constitution, renaming itself the State of Rhode Island.

name: rhode_island
sentence: This change took effect when the results were certified on November 30, 2020.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island's official nickname is "The Ocean State", a reference to the large bays and inlets that amount to about 14 percent of its total area.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Despite its name, most of Rhode Island is located on the mainland of the United States.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Prior to 2020, the state's official name was State of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations, which is derived from the merger of four Colonial settlements.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The settlements of Newport and Portsmouth were situated on what is commonly called Aquidneck Island today but was called Rhode Island in Colonial times.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Providence Plantation was the name of the colony founded by Roger Williams in the state's capital of Providence.

name: rhode_island
sentence: This was adjoined by the settlement of Warwick

name: rhode_island
sentence: It is unclear how the island came to be named Rhode Island, but two historical events may have been of influence:

name: rhode_island
sentence: The earliest documented use of the name "Rhode Island" for Aquidneck was in 1637 by Roger Williams.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The name was officially applied to the island in 1644 with these words: "Aquethneck shall be henceforth called the Isle of Rodes or Rhode-Island."

name: rhode_island
sentence: The name "Isle of Rodes" is used in a legal document as late as 1646.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Dutch maps as early as 1659 call the island "Red Island" (Roodt Eylant).

name: rhode_island
sentence: The first English settlement in Rhode Island was the town of Providence, which the Narragansett granted to Roger Williams in 1636.

name: rhode_island
sentence: At that time, Williams obtained no permission from the English crown, as he believed that the English had no legitimate claim on Narragansett and Wampanoag territory.

name: rhode_island
sentence: However, in 1643, he petitioned Charles I of England to grant Providence and neighboring towns a colonial patent, due to threats of invasion from the colonies of Boston and Plymouth.

name: rhode_island
sentence: He used the name "Providence Plantations" in his petition, plantation being the English term for a colony.

name: rhode_island
sentence: "Providence Plantations" was therefore the official name of the colony from 1643 to 1663, when a new charter was issued.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In 1790, following the American Revolution, the new state incorporated both "Rhode Island" and "Providence Plantations" becoming known as the "State of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations".

name: rhode_island
sentence: The word plantation in the state's name became a contested issue during the course of the 20th century and the increased awareness of slavery and its role in early Rhode Island history.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The General Assembly voted on June 25, 2009, to hold a general referendum scheduled for November 2010 determining whether "and Providence Plantations" would be dropped from the official name.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Advocates for excising plantation claimed that the word symbolized an alleged legacy of disenfranchisement for many Rhode Islanders, as well as the proliferation of slavery in the colonies and in the post-colonial United States.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Advocates for retaining the name argued that plantation was simply an archaic synonym for colony and bore no relation to slavery.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The referendum election was held on November 2, 2010, and the people voted overwhelmingly (78% to 22%) to retain the entire original name.

name: rhode_island
sentence: On June 19, 2020, State Senatortor Harold Metts introduced a resolution for another ballot referendum on removing the words "and Providence Plantations" from the state's name, saying, "Whatever the meaning of the term 'plantations' in the context of Rhode Island's history, it carries a horrific connotation when considering the tragic and racist history of our nation."

name: rhode_island
sentence: On June 22, 2020, Rhode Island Governor Gina Raimondo issued an executive order to remove "Providence Plantations" from a range of official documents and state websites.On July 16, 2020, amidst the George Floyd protests and nationwide calls to address systemic racism, the resolution referring the question to the voters was passed by both houses of the Rhode Island General Assembly.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The vote was 69-1 in the House of Representatives and 35-0 in the Senatorte.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The change was approved by voters 52.8% to 47.2% as part of the 2020 United States elections, and will take effect upon final certification of the election results.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In 1636, Roger Williams was banished from the Massachusetts Bay Colony for his religious views, and he settled at the top of Narragansett Bay on land sold or given to him by Narragansett sachem Canonicus.

name: rhode_island
sentence: He named the site Providence, "having a sense of God's merciful providence unto me in my distress", and it became a place of religious freedom where all were welcome.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In 1638 (after conferring with Williams), Anne Hutchinson, William Coddington, John Clarke, Philip Sherman, and other religious dissenters settled on Aquidneck Island (then known as Rhode Island), which was purchased from the local tribes who called it Pocasset.

name: rhode_island
sentence: This settlement was called Portsmouth and was governed by the Portsmouth Compact.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The southern part of the island became the separate settlement of Newport after disagreements among the founders.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Samuel Gorton purchased lands at Shawomet in 1642 from the Narragansetts, precipitating a dispute with the Massachusetts Bay Colony.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In 1644, Providence, Portsmouth, and Newport united for their common independence as the Colony of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations, governed by an elected council and "president".

name: rhode_island
sentence: Gorton received a separate charter for his settlement in 1648 which he named Warwick after his patron.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Metacomet was the Wampanoag tribe's war leader, whom the colonists called King Philip.

name: rhode_island
sentence: They invaded and burned down several of the towns in the area during King Philip's War (1675–1676), including Providence which was attacked twice.

name: rhode_island
sentence: A force of Massachusetts, Connecticut, and Plymouth militia under General Josiah Winslow invaded and destroyed the fortified Narragansett Indian village in the Great Swamp in South Kingstown, Rhode Island on December 19, 1675.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In one of the final actions of the war, an Indian associated with Benjamin Church killed King Philip in Bristol, Rhode Island.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The colony was amalgamated into the Dominion of New England in 1686, as King James II attempted to enforce royal authority over the autonomous colonies in British North America, but the colony regained its independence under the Royal Charter after the Glorious Revolution of 1688.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Slaves were introduced in Rhode Island at this time, although there is no record of any law legalizing slave-holding.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The colony later prospered under the slave trade, distilling rum to sell in Africa as part of a profitable triangular trade in slaves and sugar with the Caribbean.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island's legislative body passed an act in 1652 abolishing the holding of slaves (the first British colony to do so), but this edict was never enforced and Rhode Island continued to be heavily involved in the slave trade during the post-revolution era.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In 1774, the slave population of Rhode Island was 6.3% of the total (nearly twice the ratio of other New England colonies).

name: rhode_island
sentence: Brown University was founded in 1764 as the College in the British Colony of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations.

name: rhode_island
sentence: It was one of nine Colonial colleges granted charters before the American Revolution, but was the first college in America to accept students regardless of religious affiliation.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island's tradition of independence and dissent gave it a prominent role in the American Revolution.

name: rhode_island
sentence: At approximately 2 a.m. on June 10, 1772, a band of Providence residents attacked the grounded revenue schooner Gaspee, burning it to the waterline for enforcing unpopular trade regulations within Narragansett Bay.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island was the first of the thirteen colonies to renounce its allegiance to the British Crown on May 4, 1776.

name: rhode_island
sentence: It was also the last of the thirteen colonies to ratify the United States Constitution on May 29, 1790, and only under threat of heavy trade tariffs from the other former colonies and after assurances were made that a Bill of Rights would become part of the Constitution.

name: rhode_island
sentence: During the Revolution, the British occupied Newport in December 1776.

name: rhode_island
sentence: A combined Franco-American force fought to drive them off Aquidneck Island.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Portsmouth was the site of the first African-American military unit, the 1st Rhode Island Regiment, to fight for the US in the unsuccessful Battle of Rhode Island of August 29, 1778.

name: rhode_island
sentence: A month earlier, the appearance of a French fleet off Newport caused the British to scuttle some of their own ships in an attempt to block the harbor.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The British abandoned Newport in October 1779, concentrating their forces in New York City.

name: rhode_island
sentence: An expedition of 5,500 French troops under Count Rochambeau arrived in Newport by sea on July 10, 1780.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The celebrated march to Yorktown, Virginia, in 1781 ended with the defeat of the British at the Siege of Yorktown and the Battle of the Chesapeake.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island was also heavily involved in the Industrial Revolution, which began in America in 1787 when Thomas Somers reproduced textile machine plans which he imported from England.

name: rhode_island
sentence: He helped to produce the Beverly Cotton Manufactory, in which Moses Brown of Providence took an interest.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Moses Brown teamed up with Samuel Slater and helped to create the second cotton mill in America, a water-powered textile mill.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Industrial Revolution moved large numbers of workers into the cities, creating a permanently landless class who were therefore, by the law of the time, also voteless.

name: rhode_island
sentence: By 1829, 60% of the state's free white males were ineligible to vote.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Several attempts were unsuccessfully made to address this problem, and a new state constitution was passed in 1843 allowing landless men to vote if they could pay a $1 poll tax.

name: rhode_island
sentence: For the first several decades of statehood, Rhode Island was governed in accordance with the 1663 colonial charter.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Voting rights were restricted to landowners holding at least $134 in property, disenfranchising well over half of the state's male citizens.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The charter apportioned legislative seats equally among the state's towns, over-representing rural areas and under-representing the growing industrial centers.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Additionally, the charter disallowed landless citizens from filing civil suits without endorsement from a landowner.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Bills were periodically introduced in the legislature to expand suffrage, but they were invariably defeated.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In 1841, activists led by Thomas W. Dorr organized an extralegal convention to draft a state constitution, arguing that the charter government violated the Guarantee Clause in Article Four, Section Four of the United States Constitution.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In 1842, the charter government and Dorr's supporters held separate elections, and two rival governments claimed sovereignty over the state.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Dorr's supporters led an armed rebellion against the charter government, and Dorr was arrested and imprisoned for treason against the state.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Later that year, the legislature drafted a state constitution, removing property requirements for American-born citizens but keeping them in place for immigrants, and retaining urban under-representation in the legislature.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In the early 19th century, Rhode Island was subject to a tuberculosis outbreak which led to public hysteria about vampirism.

name: rhode_island
sentence: During the American Civil War, Rhode Island was the first Union state to send troops in response to President Lincoln's request for help from the states.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island furnished 25,236 fighting men, of whom 1,685 died.

name: rhode_island
sentence: On the home front, Rhode Island and the other northern states used their industrial capacity to supply the Union Army with the materials that it needed to win the war.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The United States Naval Academy moved to Rhode Island temporarily during the war.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In 1866, Rhode Island abolished racial segregation in the public schools throughout the state.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The 50 years following the Civil War were a time of prosperity and affluence that author William G. McLoughlin calls "Rhode Island's halcyon era."

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island was a center of the Gilded Age and provided a home or summer home to many of the country's most prominent industrialists.

name: rhode_island
sentence: This was a time of growth in textile mills and manufacturing and brought an influx of immigrants to fill those jobs, bringing population growth and urbanization.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In Newport, New York's wealthiest industrialists created a summer haven to socialize and build grand mansions.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Thousands of French-Canadian, Italian, Irish, and Portuguese immigrants arrived to fill jobs in the textile and manufacturing mills in Providence, Pawtucket, Central Falls, and Woonsocket.

name: rhode_island
sentence: During World War I, Rhode Island furnished 28,817 soldiers, of whom 612 died.

name: rhode_island
sentence: After the war, the state was hit hard by the Spanish Influenza.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In the 1920s and 1930s, rural Rhode Island saw a surge in Ku Klux Klan membership, largely in reaction to large waves of immigrants moving to the state.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Klan is believed to be responsible for burning the Watchman Industrial School in Scituate, which was a school for African-American children.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Since the Great Depression, the Rhode Island Democratic Party has dominated local politics.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island has comprehensive health insurance for low-income children and a large social safety net.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Many urban areas still have a high rate of children in poverty.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Due to an influx of residents from Boston, increasing housing costs have resulted in more homelessness in Rhode Island.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The 350th Anniversary of the founding of Rhode Island was celebrated with a free concert held on the tarmac of the Quonset State Airport on August 31, 1986.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Performers included Chuck Berry, Tommy James, and headliner Bob Hope.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In 2003, a nightclub fire in West Warwick claimed 100 lives and resulted in nearly twice as many injured, catching national attention.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The fire resulted in criminal sentences.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In March 2010, areas of the state received record flooding due to rising rivers from heavy rain.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The first period of rainy weather in mid-March caused localized flooding and, two weeks later, more rain caused more widespread flooding in many towns, especially south of Providence.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rain totals on March 29–30, 2010 exceeded 14 inches (35.5 cm) in many locales, resulting in the inundation of area rivers—especially the Pawtuxet River which runs through central Rhode Island.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The overflow of the Pawtuxet River, nearly 11 feet (3 m) above flood stage, submerged a sewage treatment plant and closed a five-mile (8 km) stretch of Interstate 95.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In addition, it flooded two shopping malls, numerous businesses, and many homes in the towns of Warwick, West Warwick, Cranston, and Westerly.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Amtrak service was also suspended between New York and Boston during this period.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Following the flood, Rhode Island was in a state of emergency for two days.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) was called in to help flood victims.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island covers an area of 1,214 square miles (3,144 km2) located within the New England region and is bordered on the north and east by Massachusetts, on the west by Connecticut, and on the south by Rhode Island Sound and the Atlantic Ocean.

name: rhode_island
sentence: It shares a narrow maritime border with New York State between Block Island and Long Island.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The mean elevation of the state is 200 feet (61 m).

name: rhode_island
sentence: It is only 37 miles (60 km) wide and 48 miles (77 km) long, yet the state has a tidal shoreline on Narragansett Bay and the Atlantic Ocean of 384 miles (618 km).

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island is nicknamed the Ocean State and has a number of oceanfront beaches.

name: rhode_island
sentence: It is mostly flat with no real mountains, and the state's highest natural point is Jerimoth Hill, 812 feet (247 m) above sea level.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The state has two distinct natural regions.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Eastern Rhode Island contains the lowlands of the Narragansett Bay, while Western Rhode Island forms part of the New England upland.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island's forests are part of the Northeastern coastal forests ecoregion.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Narragansett Bay is a major feature of the state's topography.

name: rhode_island
sentence: There are more than 30 islands within the bay; the largest is Aquidneck Island which holds the municipalities of Newport, Middletown, and Portsmouth.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The second-largest island is Conanicut, and the third is Prudence.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Block Island lies about 12 miles (19 km) off the southern coast of the mainland and separates Block Island Sound and the Atlantic Ocean proper.

name: rhode_island
sentence: A rare type of rock called Cumberlandite is found only in Rhode Island (specifically, in the town of Cumberland) and is the state rock.

name: rhode_island
sentence: There were initially two known deposits of the mineral, but it is an ore of iron, and one of the deposits was extensively mined for its ferrous content.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Most of Rhode Island has a humid continental climate, with warm summers and cold winters.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The southern coastal portions of the state are the broad transition zone into subtropical climates, with hot summers and cool winters with a mix of rain and snow.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Block Island has an oceanic climate.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The highest temperature recorded in Rhode Island was 104 °F (40 °C), recorded on August 2, 1975 in Providence.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The lowest recorded temperature in Rhode Island was −23 °F (−31 °C) on February 5, 1996 in Greene.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Monthly average temperatures range from a high of 83 °F (28 °C) to a low of 20 °F (−7 °C).

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island is vulnerable to tropical storms and hurricanes due to its location in New England, catching the brunt of many storms blowing up the eastern seaboard.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Some hurricanes that have done significant damage in the state are the 1938 New England hurricane, Hurricane Carol (1954), Hurricane Donna (1960), and Hurricane Bob (1991).

name: rhode_island
sentence: The capital of Rhode Island is Providence.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The state's current governor is Gina Raimondo (D), and the lieutenant governor is Daniel McKee (D).

name: rhode_island
sentence: Raimondo became Rhode Island's first female governor with a plurality of the vote in the November 2014 state elections.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Its United States senators are Jack Reed (D) and Sheldon Whitehouse (D).

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island's two United States representatives are David Cicilline (D-1) and Jim Langevin (D-2).

name: rhode_island
sentence: See congressional districts map.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island is one of a few states that do not have an official governor's residence.

name: rhode_island
sentence: See List of Rhode Island Governors.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The state legislature is the Rhode Island General Assembly, consisting of the 75-member House of Representatives and the 38-member Senatorte.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Both houses of the bicameral body are currently dominated by the Democratic Party; the presence of the Republican Party is minor in the state government, with Republicans holding a handful of seats in both the Senatorte and House of Representatives.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island's population barely crosses the threshold beyond the minimum of three for additional votes in both the federal House of Representatives and Electoral College; it is well represented relative to its population, with the eighth-highest number of electoral votes and second-highest number of House Representatives per resident.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Based on its area, Rhode Island has the highest density of electoral votes.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Federally, Rhode Island is a reliably Democratic state during presidential elections, usually supporting the Democratic presidential nominee.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The state voted for the Republican presidential candidate until 1908.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Since then, it has voted for the Republican nominee for president seven times, and the Democratic nominee 17 times.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The last 16 presidential elections in Rhode Island have resulted in the Democratic Party winning the Ocean State's Electoral College votes 12 times.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In the 1980 presidential election, Rhode Island was one of six states to vote against Republican Ronald Reagan.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Reagan was the last Republican to win any of the state's counties in a Presidential election until Donald Trump won Kent County in 2016.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In 1988, George H W Bush won over 40% of the state's popular vote, something that no Republican has done since.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island was the Democrats' leading state in 1988 and 2000, and second-best in 1968, 1996, and 2004.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island's most one-sided Presidential election result was in 1964, with over 80% of Rhode Island's votes going for Lyndon B. Johnson.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In 2004, Rhode Island gave John Kerry more than a 20-percentage-point margin of victory (the third-highest of any state), with 59.4% of its vote.

name: rhode_island
sentence: All but three of Rhode Island's 39 cities and towns voted for the Democratic candidate.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The exceptions were East Greenwich, West Greenwich, and Scituate.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In 2008, Rhode Island gave Barack Obama a 28-percentage-point margin of victory (the third-highest of any state), with 63% of its vote.

name: rhode_island
sentence: All but one of Rhode Island's 39 cities and towns voted for the Democratic candidate (the exception being Scituate).

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island is one of 21 states that have abolished capital punishment; it was second do so, just after Michigan, and carried out its last execution in the 1840s.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island was the second to last state to make prostitution illegal.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Until November 2009 Rhode Island law made prostitution legal provided it took place indoors.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In a 2009 study Rhode Island was listed as the 9th safest state in the country.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In 2011, Rhode Island became the third state in the United States to pass legislation to allow the use of medical marijuana.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Additionally, the Rhode Island General Assembly passed civil unions, and it was signed into law by Governor Lincoln Chafee on July 2, 2011.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island became the eighth state to fully recognize either same-sex marriage or civil unions.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Same-sex marriage became legal on May 2, 2013, and took effect August 1.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island has some of the highest taxes in the country, particularly its property taxes, ranking seventh in local and state taxes, and sixth in real estate taxes.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The United States Census Bureau estimates that the population of Rhode Island was 1,059,361 on July 1, 2019, a 0.65% increase since the 2010 United States Census.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The center of population of Rhode Island is located in Providence County, in the city of Cranston.

name: rhode_island
sentence: A corridor of population can be seen from the Providence area, stretching northwest following the Blackstone River to Woonsocket, where 19th-century mills drove industry and development.

name: rhode_island
sentence: According to the 2010 Census, 81.4% of the population was White (76.4% non-Hispanic white), 5.7% was Black or African American, 0.6% American Indian and Alaska Native, 2.9% Asian, 0.1% Native Hawaiian and other Pacific Islander, 3.3% from two or more races.

name: rhode_island
sentence: 12.4% of the total population was of Hispanic or Latino origin (they may be of any race).

name: rhode_island
sentence: Of the people residing in Rhode Island, 58.7% were born in Rhode Island, 26.6% were born in a different state, 2.0% were born in Puerto Rico, US Island areas or born abroad to American parent(s), and 12.6% were foreign born.

name: rhode_island
sentence: According to the US Census Bureau, as of 2015, Rhode Island had an estimated population of 1,056,298, which is an increase of 1,125, or 0.10%, from the prior year and an increase of 3,731, or 0.35%, since the year 2010.

name: rhode_island
sentence: This includes a natural increase since the last census of 15,220 people (that is 66,973 births minus 51,753 deaths) and an increase due to net migration of 14,001 people into the state.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Immigration from outside the United States resulted in a net increase of 18,965 people, and migration within the country produced a net decrease of 4,964 people.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Hispanics in the state make up 12.8% of the population, predominantly Dominican, Puerto Rican, and Guatemalan populations.

name: rhode_island
sentence: According to the 2000 US Census, 84% of the population aged 5 and older spoke only American English, while 8.07% spoke Spanish at home, 3.80% Portuguese, 1.96% French, 1.39% Italian and 0.78% speak other languages at home accordingly.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The state's most populous ethnic group, non-Hispanic white, has declined from 96.1% in 1970 to 76.5% in 2011.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In 2011, 40.3% of Rhode Island's children under the age of one belonged to racial or ethnic minority groups, meaning that they had at least one parent who was not non-Hispanic white.

name: rhode_island
sentence: 6.1% of Rhode Island's population were reported as under 5, 23.6% under 18, and 14.5% were 65 or older.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Females made up approximately 52% of the population.

name: rhode_island
sentence: According to the 2010–2015 American Community Survey, the largest ancestry groups were Irish (18.3%), Italian (18.0%), English (10.5%), French (10.4%), and Portuguese (9.3%).

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island has a higher percentage of Americans of Portuguese ancestry, including Portuguese Americans and Cape Verdean Americans than any other state in the nation.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Additionally, the state also has the highest percentage of Liberian immigrants, with more than 15,000 residing in the state.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Italian Americans make up a plurality in central and southern Providence County and French-Canadian Americans form a large part of northern Providence County.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Irish Americans have a strong presence in Newport and Kent counties.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Americans of English ancestry still have a presence in the state as well, especially in Washington County, and are often referred to as "Swamp Yankees."

name: rhode_island
sentence: African immigrants, including Cape Verdean Americans, Liberian Americans, Nigerian Americans and Ghanaian Americans, form significant and growing communities in Rhode Island.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Although Rhode Island has the smallest land area of all 50 states, it has the second highest population density of any state in the Union, second to that of New Jersey.

name: rhode_island
sentence: A Pew survey of Rhode Island residents' religious self-identification showed the following distribution of affiliations: Roman Catholic 42%, Protestant 30%, Jewish 1%, Jehovah's Witnesses 2%, Buddhism 1%, Mormonism 1%, Hinduism 1%, and Non-religious 20%.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The largest denominations are the Roman Catholic Church with 456,598 adherents, the Episcopal Church with 19,377, the American Baptist Churches USA with 15,220, and the United Methodist Church with 6,901 adherents.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island has the highest proportion of Roman Catholic residents of any state, mainly due to large Irish, Italian, and French-Canadian immigration in the past; recently, significant Portuguese and various Hispanic communities have also been established in the state.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Though it has the highest overall Catholic percentage of any state, none of Rhode Island's individual counties ranks among the 10 most Catholic in the United States, as Catholics are very evenly spread throughout the state.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Jewish community of Rhode Island is centered in the Providence area, and emerged during a wave of Jewish immigration predominantly from Eastern Europeans shtetls between 1880 and 1920.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The presence of the Touro Synagogue in Newport, the oldest existing synagogue in the United States, emphasizes that these second-wave immigrants did not create Rhode Island's first Jewish community; a comparatively smaller wave of Spanish and Portuguese Jews immigrated to Newport during the colonial era.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island is divided into five counties but it has no county governments.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The entire state is divided into municipalities, which handle all local government affairs.

name: rhode_island
sentence: There are 39 cities and towns in Rhode Island.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Major population centers today result from historical factors; development took place predominantly along the Blackstone, Seekonk, and Providence Rivers with the advent of the water-powered mill.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Providence is the base of a large metropolitan area.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The state's 18 largest municipalities ranked by population are :

name: rhode_island
sentence: Some of Rhode Island's cities and towns are further partitioned into villages, in common with many other New England states.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Notable villages include Kingston in the town of South Kingstown, which houses the University of Rhode Island; Wickford in the town of North Kingstown, the site of an annual international art festival; and Wakefield where the Town Hall is located for the Town of South Kingstown.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Rhode Island economy had a colonial base in fishing.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Blackstone River Valley was a major contributor to the American Industrial Revolution.

name: rhode_island
sentence: It was in Pawtucket that Samuel Slater set up Slater Mill in 1793, using the waterpower of the Blackstone River to power his cotton mill.

name: rhode_island
sentence: For a while, Rhode Island was one of the leaders in textiles.

name: rhode_island
sentence: However, with the Great Depression, most textile factories relocated to southern US states.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The textile industry still constitutes a part of the Rhode Island economy but does not have the same power that it once had.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Other important industries in Rhode Island's past included toolmaking, costume jewelry, and silverware.

name: rhode_island
sentence: An interesting by-product of Rhode Island's industrial history is the number of abandoned factories, many of them now being used for condominiums, museums, offices, and low-income and elderly housing.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Today, much of the economy of Rhode Island is based in services, particularly healthcare and education, and still manufacturing to some extent.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The state's nautical history continues in the 21st century in the form of nuclear submarine construction.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Per the 2013 American Communities Survey, Rhode Island has the highest paid elementary school teachers in the country, with an average salary of $75,028 (adjusted to inflation).

name: rhode_island
sentence: The headquarters of Citizens Financial Group is located in Providence, the 14th largest bank in the United States.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Fortune 500 companies CVS Caremark and Textron are based in Woonsocket and Providence, respectively.

name: rhode_island
sentence: FM Global, GTECH Corporation, Hasbro, American Power Conversion, Nortek, and Amica Mutual Insurance are all Fortune 1000 companies that are based in Rhode Island.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island's 2000 total gross state production was $46.18 billion (adjusted to inflation), placing it 45th in the nation.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Its 2000 per capita personal income was $41,484 (adjusted to inflation), 16th in the nation.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island has the lowest level of energy consumption per capita of any state.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Additionally, Rhode Island is rated as the 5th most energy efficient state in the country.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In December 2012, the state's unemployment rate was 10.2%.

name: rhode_island
sentence: This has gradually reduced to 3.5% in November 2019, however, the coronavirus pandemic brought the unemployment rate to a high of 18.1% in April 2020.

name: rhode_island
sentence: This has since reduced to 10.5% in September 2020 and is projected to further decrease to 7% in October 2020.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Health services are Rhode Island's largest industry.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Second is tourism, supporting 39,000 jobs, with tourism-related sales at $4.56 billion (adjusted to inflation) in the year 2000.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The third-largest industry is manufacturing.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Its industrial outputs are submarine construction, shipbuilding, costume jewelry, fabricated metal products, electrical equipment, machinery, and boatbuilding.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island's agricultural outputs are nursery stock, vegetables, dairy products, and eggs.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island's taxes were appreciably higher than neighboring states, because Rhode Island's income tax was based on 25% of the payer's federal income tax payment.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Former Governor Donald Carcieri claimed that the higher tax rate had an inhibitory effect on business growth in the state and called for reductions to increase the competitiveness of the state's business environment.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In 2010, the Rhode Island General Assembly passed a new state income tax structure that was then signed into law on June 9, 2010, by Governor Carcieri.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The income tax overhaul has now made Rhode Island competitive with other New England states by lowering its maximum tax rate to 5.99% and reducing the number of tax brackets to three.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The state's first income tax was enacted in 1971.

name: rhode_island
sentence: As of March 2011, the largest employers in Rhode Island (excluding employees of municipalities) are the following:

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Rhode Island Public Transit Authority (RIPTA) operates statewide intra- and intercity bus transport from its hubs at Kennedy Plaza in Providence, Pawtucket, and Newport.

name: rhode_island
sentence: RIPTA bus routes serve 38 of Rhode Island's 39 cities and towns.

name: rhode_island
sentence: (New Shoreham on Block Island is not served).

name: rhode_island
sentence: RIPTA currently operates 58 routes, including daytime trolley service (using trolley-style replica buses) in Providence and Newport.

name: rhode_island
sentence: From 2000 through 2008, RIPTA offered seasonal ferry service linking Providence and Newport (already connected by highway) funded by grant money from the United States Department of Transportation.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Though the service was popular with residents and tourists, RIPTA was unable to continue on after the federal funding ended.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Service was discontinued as of 2010.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The service was resumed in 2016 and has been successful.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The privately run Block Island Ferry links Block Island with Newport and Narragansett with traditional and fast-ferry service, while the Prudence Island Ferry connects Bristol with Prudence Island.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Private ferry services also link several Rhode Island communities with ports in Connecticut, Massachusetts, and New York.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Vineyard Fast Ferry offers seasonal service to Martha's Vineyard from Quonset Point with bus and train connections to Providence, Boston, and New York.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Viking Fleet offers seasonal service from Block Island to New London, Connecticut, and Montauk, New York.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The MBTA Commuter Rail's Providence/Stoughton Line links Providence and T. F. Green Airport with Boston.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The line was later extended southward to Wickford Junction, with service beginning April 23, 2012.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The state hopes to extend the MBTA line to Kingston and Westerly, as well as explore the possibility of extending Connecticut's Shore Line East to T.F.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Green Airport.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Amtrak's Acela Express stops at Providence Station (the only Acela stop in Rhode Island), linking Providence to other cities in the Northeast Corridor.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Amtrak's Northeast Regional service makes stops at Providence Station, Kingston, and Westerly.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island's primary airport for passenger and cargo transport is T. F. Green Airport in Warwick, though most Rhode Islanders who wish to travel internationally on direct flights and those who seek a greater availability of flights and destinations often fly through Logan International Airport in Boston.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Interstate 95 (I-95) runs southwest to northeast across the state, linking Rhode Island with other states along the East Coast.

name: rhode_island
sentence: I-295 functions as a partial beltway encircling Providence to the west.

name: rhode_island
sentence: I-195 provides a limited-access highway connection from Providence (and Connecticut and New York via I-95) to Cape Cod.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Initially built as the easternmost link in the (now cancelled) extension of I-84 from Hartford, Connecticut, a portion of US Route 6 (US 6) through northern Rhode Island is limited-access and links I-295 with downtown Providence.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Several Rhode Island highways extend the state's limited-access highway network.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Route 4 is a major north–south freeway linking Providence and Warwick (via I-95) with suburban and beach communities along Narragansett Bay.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Route 10 is an urban connector linking downtown Providence with Cranston and Johnston.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Route 37 is an important east–west freeway through Cranston and Warwick and links I-95 with I-295.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Route 99 links Woonsocket with Providence (via Route 146).

name: rhode_island
sentence: Route 146 travels through the Blackstone Valley, linking Providence and I-95 with Worcester, Massachusetts and the Massachusetts Turnpike.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Route 403 links Route 4 with Quonset Point.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Several bridges cross Narragansett Bay connecting Aquidneck Island and Conanicut Island to the mainland, most notably the Claiborne Pell Newport Bridge and the Jamestown-Verrazano Bridge.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The East Bay Bike Path stretches from Providence to Bristol along the eastern shore of Narragansett Bay, while the Blackstone River Bikeway will eventually link Providence and Worcester.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In 2011, Rhode Island completed work on a marked on-road bicycle path through Pawtucket and Providence, connecting the East Bay Bike Path with the Blackstone River Bikeway, completing a 33.5 miles (54 km) bicycle route through the eastern side of the state.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The William C. O'Neill Bike Path (commonly known as the South County Bike Path) is an 8 mi (13 km) path through South Kingstown and Narragansett.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The 19 mi (31 km) Washington Secondary Bike Path stretches from Cranston to Coventry, and the 2 mi (3.2 km) Ten Mile River Greenway path runs through East Providence and Pawtucket.

name: rhode_island
sentence: On May 29, 2014, Governor Lincoln D. Chafee announced that Rhode Island was one of eight states to release a collaborative Action Plan to put 3.3 million zero emission vehicles on the roads by 2025.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The goal of the plan is to reduce greenhouse gas and smog-causing emissions.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Action Plan covers promoting zero emission vehicles and investing in the infrastructure to support them.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In 2014, Rhode Island received grants from the Environmental Protection Agency in the amount of $2,711,685 to clean up Brownfield sites in eight locations.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The intent of the grants was to provide communities with the funding necessary to assess, clean up, and redevelop contaminated properties, boost local economies, and leverage jobs while protecting public health and the environment.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In 2013, the "Lots of Hope" program was established in the City of Providence to focus on increasing the city's green space and local food production, improve urban neighborhoods, promote healthy lifestyles and improve environmental sustainability.

name: rhode_island
sentence: "Lots of Hope", supported by a $100,000 grant, will partner with the City of Providence, the Southside Community Land Trust and the Rhode Island Foundation to convert city-owned vacant lots into productive urban farms.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In 2012, Rhode Island passed bill S2277/H7412, "An act relating to Health and Safety – Environmental Cleanup Objectives for Schools", informally known as the "School Siting Bill."

name: rhode_island
sentence: The bill, sponsored by Senatortor Juan Pichardo and Representative Scott Slater and signed into law by the Governor, made Rhode Island the first state in the US to prohibit school construction on Brownfield Sites where there is an ongoing potential for toxic vapors to negatively impact indoor air quality.

name: rhode_island
sentence: It also creates a public participation process whenever a city or town considers building a school on any other kind of contaminated site.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island has several colleges and universities:

name: rhode_island
sentence: Some Rhode Islanders speak with the distinctive, non-rhotic, traditional Rhode Island accent that many compare to a cross between the New York City and Boston accents (e.g., "water" sounds like "watuh" [ˈwɔəɾə]).

name: rhode_island
sentence: Many Rhode Islanders distinguish a strong aw sound [ɔə] (i.e., do not exhibit the cot–caught merger) as one might hear in New Jersey or New York City; for example, the word coffee is pronounced [ˈkʰɔəfi].

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Islanders sometimes refer to drinking fountains as "bubblers", milkshakes as "cabinets", and overstuffed foot-long sandwiches (of whatever kind) as "grinders".

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island, like the rest of New England, has a tradition of clam chowder.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Both the white New England and the red Manhattan varieties are popular, but there is also a unique clear-broth chowder known as Rhode Island Clam Chowder available in many restaurants.

name: rhode_island
sentence: A culinary tradition in Rhode Island is the clam cake (also known as a clam fritter outside of Rhode Island), a deep fried ball of buttery dough with chopped bits of clam inside.

name: rhode_island
sentence: They are sold by the half-dozen or dozen in most seafood restaurants around the state, and the quintessential summer meal in Rhode Island is chowder and clam cakes.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The quahog is a large local clam usually used in a chowder.

name: rhode_island
sentence: It is also ground and mixed with stuffing or spicy minced sausage, and then baked in its shell to form a stuffie.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Calamari (squid) is sliced into rings and fried as an appetizer in most Italian restaurants, typically served Sicilian-style with sliced banana peppers and marinara sauce on the side.

name: rhode_island
sentence: (In 2014, calamari became the official state appetizer.)

name: rhode_island
sentence: Clams Casino originated in Rhode Island, invented by Julius Keller, the maitre d' in the original Casino next to the seaside Towers in Narragansett.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Clams Casino resemble the beloved stuffed quahog but are generally made with the smaller littleneck or cherrystone clam and are unique in their use of bacon as a topping.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The official state drink of Rhode Island is coffee milk, a beverage created by mixing milk with coffee syrup.

name: rhode_island
sentence: This unique syrup was invented in the state and is sold in almost all Rhode Island supermarkets, as well as its bordering states.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Johnnycakes have been a Rhode Island staple since Colonial times, made with corn meal and water then pan-fried much like pancakes.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Submarine sandwiches are called grinders throughout Rhode Island, and the Italian grinder is especially popular, made with cold cuts such as ham, prosciutto, capicola, salami, and Provolone cheese.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Linguiça or chouriço is a spicy Portuguese sausage, frequently served with peppers among the state's large Portuguese community and eaten with hearty bread.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Farrelly brothers and Seth MacFarlane depict Rhode Island in popular culture, often making comedic parodies of the state.

name: rhode_island
sentence: MacFarlane's television series Family Guy is based in a fictional Rhode Island city named Quahog, and notable local events and celebrities are regularly lampooned.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Peter Griffin is seen working at the Pawtucket brewery, and other state locations are mentioned.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The movie High Society (starring Bing Crosby, Grace Kelly, and Frank Sinatra) was set in Newport, Rhode Island.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The 1974 film adaptation of The Great Gatsby was also filmed in Newport.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Jacqueline Bouvier and John F. Kennedy were married at St. Mary's church in Newport.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Their reception was held at Hammersmith Farm, the Bouvier summer home in Newport.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Cartoonist Don Bousquet, a state icon, has made a career out of Rhode Island culture, drawing Rhode Island-themed gags in The Providence Journal and Yankee magazine.

name: rhode_island
sentence: These cartoons have been reprinted in the Quahog series of paperbacks (I Brake for Quahogs, Beware of the Quahog, and The Quahog Walks Among Us.)

name: rhode_island
sentence: Bousquet has also collaborated with humorist and Providence Journal columnist Mark Patinkin on two books: The Rhode Island Dictionary and The Rhode Island Handbook.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The 1998 film Meet Joe Black was filmed at Aldrich Mansion in the Warwick Neck area of Warwick.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Body of Proof's first season was filmed entirely in Rhode Island.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The show premiered on March 29, 2011.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The 2007 Steve Carell and Dane Cook film Dan in Real Life was filmed in various coastal towns in the state.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The sunset scene with the entire family on the beach takes place at Napatree Point.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Jersey Shore star Pauly D filmed part of his spin-off The Pauly D Project in his hometown of Johnston.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Comedy Central cable television series Another Period is set in Newport during the Gilded Age.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island has been the first in a number of initiatives.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Colony of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations enacted the first law prohibiting slavery in America on May 18, 1652.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The first act of armed rebellion in America against the British Crown was the boarding and burning of the Revenue Schooner Gaspee in Narragansett Bay on June 10, 1772.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The idea of a Continental Congress was first proposed at a town meeting in Providence on May 17, 1774.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island elected the first delegates (Stephen Hopkins and Samuel Ward) to the Continental Congress on June 15, 1774.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Rhode Island General Assembly created the first standing army in the colonies (1,500 men) on April 22, 1775.

name: rhode_island
sentence: On June 15, 1775, the first naval engagement took place in the American Revolution between an American sloop commanded by Capt.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Abraham Whipple and an armed tender of the British Frigate Rose.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The tender was chased aground and captured.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Later in June, the General Assembly created the American Navy when it commissioned the sloops Katy and Washington, armed with 24 guns and commanded by Abraham Whipple who was promoted to Commodore.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island was the first Colony to declare independence from Britain on May 4, 1776.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Slater Mill in Pawtucket was the first commercially successful cotton-spinning mill with a fully mechanized power system in America and was the birthplace of the Industrial Revolution in the US.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The oldest Fourth of July parade in the country is still held annually in Bristol, Rhode Island.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The first Baptist church in America was founded in Providence in 1638.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Ann Smith Franklin of the Newport Mercury was the first female newspaper editor in America (August 22, 1762).

name: rhode_island
sentence: Touro Synagogue was the first synagogue in America, founded in Newport in 1763.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Pelham Street in Newport was the first in America to be illuminated by gaslight in 1806.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The first strike in the United States in which women participated occurred in Pawtucket in 1824.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Watch Hill has the nation's oldest flying horses carousel that has been in continuous operation since 1850.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The motion picture machine was patented in Providence on April 23, 1867.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The first lunch wagon in America was introduced in Providence in 1872.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The first nine-hole golf course in America was completed in Newport in 1890.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The first state health laboratory was established in Providence on September 1, 1894.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Rhode Island State House was the first building with an all-marble dome to be built in the United States (1895–1901).

name: rhode_island
sentence: The first automobile race on a track was held in Cranston on September 7, 1896.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The first automobile parade was held in Newport on September 7, 1899 on the grounds of Belcourt Castle.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island is nicknamed "The Ocean State", and the nautical nature of Rhode Island's geography pervades its culture.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Newport Harbor, in particular, holds many pleasure boats.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In the lobby of T. F. Green, the state's main airport, is a large life-sized sailboat, and the state's license plates depict an ocean wave or a sailboat.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Additionally, the large number of beaches in Washington County lures many Rhode Islanders south for summer vacation.
