name: rhode_island
sentence: The state was notorious for organized crime activity from the 1950s into the 1990s when the Patriarca crime family held sway over most of New England from its Providence headquarters.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Islanders developed a unique style of architecture in the 17th century called the stone-ender.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island is the only state to still celebrate Victory over Japan Day which is officially named "Victory Day" but is sometimes referred to as "VJ Day."

name: rhode_island
sentence: It is celebrated on the second Monday in August.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Nibbles Woodaway, more commonly referred to as "The Big Blue Bug", is a 58-foot-long termite mascot for a Providence extermination business.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Since its construction in 1980, it has been featured in several movies and television shows, and has come to be recognized as a cultural landmark by many locals.

name: rhode_island
sentence: In more recent times, the Big Blue Bug has been given a mask to remind locals and visitors to mask-up during the COVID-19 outbreak.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island has two professional sports teams, both of which are top-level minor league affiliates for teams in Boston.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Pawtucket Red Sox baseball team of the Triple-A International League are an affiliate of the Boston Red Sox.

name: rhode_island
sentence: They play at McCoy Stadium in Pawtucket and have won four league titles, the Governors' Cup, in 1973, 1984, 2012, and 2014.

name: rhode_island
sentence: McCoy Stadium also has the distinction of being home to the longest professional baseball game ever played – 33 innings.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The other professional minor league team is the Providence Bruins ice hockey team of the American Hockey League, who are an affiliate of the Boston Bruins.

name: rhode_island
sentence: They play in the Dunkin' Donuts Center in Providence and won the AHL's Calder Cup during the 1998–99 AHL season.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Providence Reds were a hockey team that played in the Canadian-American Hockey League (CAHL) between 1926 and 1936 and the American Hockey League (AHL) from 1936 to 1977, the last season of which they played as the Rhode Island Reds.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The team won the Calder Cup in 1938, 1940, 1949, and 1956.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Reds played at the Rhode Island Auditorium, located on North Main Street in Providence, Rhode Island from 1926 through 1972, when the team affiliated with the New York Rangers and moved into the newly built Providence Civic Center.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The team name came from the rooster known as the Rhode Island Red.

name: rhode_island
sentence: They moved to New York in 1977, then to Connecticut in 1997, and are now called the Hartford Wolf Pack.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Reds are the oldest continuously operating minor-league hockey franchise in North America, having fielded a team in one form or another since 1926 in the CAHL.

name: rhode_island
sentence: It is also the only AHL franchise to have never missed a season.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The AHL returned to Providence in 1992 in the form of the Providence Bruins.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Before the great expansion of athletic teams all over the country, Providence and Rhode Island in general played a great role in supporting teams.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Providence Grays won the first World Championship in baseball history in 1884.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The team played their home games at the old Messer Street Field in Providence.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Grays played in the National League from 1878 to 1885.

name: rhode_island
sentence: They defeated the New York Metropolitans of the American Association in a best of five game series at the Polo Grounds in New York.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Providence won three straight games to become the first champions in major league baseball history.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Babe Ruth played for the minor league Providence Grays of 1914 and hit his only official minor league home run for that team before being recalled by the Grays' parent club, the Boston Red Stockings.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The now-defunct professional football team the Providence Steam Roller won the 1928 NFL title.

name: rhode_island
sentence: They played in a 10,000 person stadium called the Cycledrome.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Providence Steamrollers played in the Basketball Association of America which became the National Basketball Association.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island is also home to a top semi-professional soccer club, the Rhode Island Reds, which compete in the National premier soccer league, in the fourth division of US Soccer.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island is home to one top level non-minor league team, the Rhode Island Rebellion rugby league team, a semi-professional rugby league team that competes in the USA Rugby League, the Top Competition in the United States for the Sport of Rugby League.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Rebellion play their home games at Classical High School in Providence.

name: rhode_island
sentence: There are four NCAA Division I schools in Rhode Island.

name: rhode_island
sentence: All four schools compete in different conferences.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Brown University Bears compete in the Ivy League, the Bryant University Bulldogs compete in the Northeast Conference, the Providence College Friars compete in the Big East Conference, and the University of Rhode Island Rams compete in the Atlantic-10 Conference.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Three of the schools' football teams compete in the Football Championship Subdivision, the second-highest level of college football in the United States.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Brown plays FCS football in the Ivy League, Bryant plays FCS football in the Northeast Conference, and Rhode Island plays FCS football in the Colonial Athletic Association.

name: rhode_island
sentence: All four of the Division I schools in the state compete in an intrastate all-sports competition known as the Ocean State Cup, with Bryant winning the most recent cup in 2011–12 academic year.

name: rhode_island
sentence: From 1930 to 1983, America's Cup races were sailed off Newport, and the extreme-sport X Games and Gravity Games were founded and hosted in the state's capital city.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The International Tennis Hall of Fame is in Newport at the Newport Casino, site of the first US National Championships in 1881.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Hall of Fame and Museum were established in 1954 by James Van Alen as "a shrine to the ideals of the game".

name: rhode_island
sentence: Rhode Island is also home to the headquarters of the governing body for youth rugby league in the United States, the American Youth Rugby League Association or AYRLA.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The AYRLA has started the first-ever Rugby League youth competition in Providence Middle Schools, a program at the RI Training School, in addition to starting the first High School Competition in the US in Providence Public High School.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The state capitol building is made of white Georgian marble.

name: rhode_island
sentence: On top is the world's fourth largest self-supported marble dome.

name: rhode_island
sentence: It houses the Rhode Island Charter granted by King Charles II in 1663, the Brown University charter, and other state treasures.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The First Baptist Church of Providence is the oldest Baptist church in the Americas, founded by Roger Williams in 1638.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The first fully automated post office in the country is located in Providence.

name: rhode_island
sentence: There are many historic mansions in the seaside city of Newport, including The Breakers, Marble House, and Belcourt Castle.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Also located there is the Touro Synagogue, dedicated on December 2, 1763, considered by locals to be the first synagogue within the United States (see below for information on New York City's claim), and still serving.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The synagogue showcases the religious freedoms that were established by Roger Williams, as well as impressive architecture in a mix of the classic colonial and Sephardic style.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Newport Casino is a National Historic Landmark building complex that presently houses the International Tennis Hall of Fame and features an active grass-court tennis club.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Scenic Route 1A (known locally as Ocean Road) is in Narragansett.

name: rhode_island
sentence: "The Towers" is also located in Narragansett featuring a large stone arch.

name: rhode_island
sentence: It was once the entrance to a famous Narragansett casino that burned down in 1900.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Towers now serve as an event venue and host the local Chamber of Commerce, which operates a tourist information center.

name: rhode_island
sentence: The Newport Tower has been hypothesized to be of Viking origin, although most experts believe that it was a Colonial-era windmill.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina ( (listen)) is a state in the Deep South region of the Southern United States.

name: south_carolina
sentence: It is bordered to the north by North Carolina, to the southeast by the Atlantic Ocean, and to the southwest by Georgia across the Savannah River.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is the 40th most extensive and 23rd most populous US state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2019 its GDP was $249.9 billion.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is composed of 46 counties.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The capital is Columbia with a population of 133,451 in 2018; while its largest city is Charleston with a 2018 population of 136,208.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Greenville–Anderson–Mauldin metropolitan area is the largest in the state, with a 2018 population estimate of 906,626.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina was named in honor of King Charles I of England, who first formed the English colony, with Carolus being Latin for "Charles".

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina became the eighth state to ratify the US Constitution on May 23, 1788.

name: south_carolina
sentence: It also became the first state to vote in favor of secession from the Union on December 20, 1860.

name: south_carolina
sentence: After the American Civil War, it was readmitted into the United States on June 25, 1868.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The state can be divided into three natural geographic areas which then can be subdivided into five distinct cultural regions.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The natural environment is divided from east to west by the Atlantic coastal plain, the Piedmont, and the Blue Ridge Mountains.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Culturally, the coastal plain is split into the Lowcountry and the Pee Dee region.

name: south_carolina
sentence: While, the upper Piedmont region is referred to as the Piedmont and the lower Piedmont region is referred to as the Midlands.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The area surrounding the Blue Ridge Mountains is known as the Upstate.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Atlantic Coastal Plain makes up two-thirds of the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Its eastern border is the Sea Islands, a chain of tidal and barrier islands.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The border between the lowcountry and the upcountry is defined by the Atlantic Seaboard fall line, which marks the limit of navigable rivers.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Atlantic Coastal Plain consists of sediments and sedimentary rocks that range in age from Cretaceous to Present.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The terrain is relatively flat and the soil is composed predominantly of sand, silt, and clay.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Areas with better drainage make excellent farmland, though some land is swampy.

name: south_carolina
sentence: An unusual feature of the coastal plain is a large number of low-relief topographic depressions named Carolina bays.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The bays tend to be oval, lining up in a northwest to southeast orientation.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The eastern portion of the coastal plain contains many salt marshes and estuaries, as well as natural ports such as Georgetown and Charleston.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The natural areas of the coastal plain are part of the Middle Atlantic coastal forests ecoregion.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Sandhills or Carolina Sandhills is a 10–35 mi (16–56 km) wide region within the Atlantic Coastal Plain province, along the inland margin of this province.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Carolina Sandhills are interpreted as eolian (wind-blown) sand sheets and dunes that were mobilized episodically from approximately 75,000 to 6,000 years ago.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Most of the published luminescence ages from the sand are coincident with the last glaciation, a time when the southeastern United States was characterized by colder air temperatures and stronger winds.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Much of Piedmont consists of Paleozoic metamorphic and igneous rocks, and the landscape has relatively low relief.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Due to the changing economics of farming, much of the land is now reforested in loblolly pine for the lumber industry.

name: south_carolina
sentence: These forests are part of the Southeastern mixed forests ecoregion.

name: south_carolina
sentence: At the southeastern edge of Piedmont is the fall line, where rivers drop to the coastal plain.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The fall line was an important early source of water power.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Mills built to this resource encouraged the growth of several cities, including the capital, Columbia.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The larger rivers are navigable up to the fall line, providing a trade route for mill towns.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The northwestern part of Piedmont is also known as the Foothills.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Cherokee Parkway is a scenic driving route through this area.

name: south_carolina
sentence: This is where Table Rock State Park is located.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Blue Ridge consists primarily of Precambrian metamorphic rocks, and the landscape has relatively high relief.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Blue Ridge Region contains an escarpment of the Blue Ridge Mountains that continues into North Carolina and Georgia as part of the southern Appalachian Mountains.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Sassafras Mountain, South Carolina's highest point at 3,560 feet (1,090 m), is in this area.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Also in this area is Caesars Head State Park.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The environment here is that of the Appalachian-Blue Ridge forests ecoregion.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Chattooga River, on the border between South Carolina and Georgia, is a favorite whitewater rafting destination.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina has several major lakes covering over 683 square miles (1,770 km2).

name: south_carolina
sentence: All major lakes in South Carolina are man-made.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The following are the lakes listed by size.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Charleston area, along the central coastline of the state, demonstrates the greatest frequency of earthquakes in South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina averages 10–15 earthquakes a year below magnitude 3 (FEMA).

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Charleston earthquake of 1886 was the largest quake ever to hit the eastern United States.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The 7.0–7.3 magnitude earthquake killed 60 people and destroyed much of the city.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Faults in this region are difficult to study at the surface due to thick sedimentation on top of them.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Many of the ancient faults are within plates rather than along plate boundaries.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina has a humid subtropical climate (Köppen climate classification Cfa), although high-elevation areas in the Upstate area have fewer subtropical characteristics than areas on the Atlantic coastline.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In the summer, South Carolina is hot and humid, with daytime temperatures averaging between 86–93 °F (30–34 °C) in most of the state and overnight lows averaging 70–75 °F (21–24 °C) on the coast and from 66–73 °F (19–23 °C) inland.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Winter temperatures are much less uniform in South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Coastal areas of the state have very mild winters, with high temperatures approaching an average of 60 °F (16 °C) and overnight lows around 40 °F (5–8 °C).

name: south_carolina
sentence: Inland, the average January overnight low is around 32 °F (0 °C) in Columbia and temperatures well below freezing in the Upstate.

name: south_carolina
sentence: While precipitation is abundant the entire year in almost the entire state, the coast tends to have a slightly wetter summer, while inland, the spring and autumn transitions tend to be the wettest periods and winter the driest season, with November being the driest month.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The highest recorded temperature is 113 °F (45 °C) in Johnston and Columbia on June 29, 2012, and the lowest recorded temperature is −19 °F (−28 °C) at Caesars Head on January 21, 1985.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Snowfall in South Carolina is minimal in the lower elevation areas south and east of Columbia.

name: south_carolina
sentence: It is not uncommon for areas along the southernmost coast to not receive measurable snowfall for several years.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In the Piedmont and Foothills, especially along and north of Interstate 85, measurable snowfall occurs one to three times in most years.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Annual average total amounts range from 2 to 6 inches.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Blue Ridge Escarpment receives the most average total measurable snowfall

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is also prone to tropical cyclones and tornadoes.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Two of the strongest hurricanes to strike South Carolina in recent history were Hurricane Hazel (1954) and Hurricane Hugo (1989).

name: south_carolina
sentence: The state is occasionally affected by tropical cyclones.

name: south_carolina
sentence: This is an annual concern during hurricane season, which lasts from June 1 to November 30.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The peak time of vulnerability for the southeast Atlantic coast is from early August to early October, during the Cape Verde hurricane season.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Memorable hurricanes to hit South Carolina include Hazel (1954), Florence (2018), and Hugo (1989), all Category 4 hurricanes.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina averages around 50 days of thunderstorm activity a year.

name: south_carolina
sentence: This is less than some of the states further south, and it is slightly less vulnerable to tornadoes than the states which border on the Gulf of Mexico.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Some notable tornadoes have struck South Carolina, and the state averages around 14 tornadoes annually.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Hail is common with many of the thunderstorms in the state, as there is often a marked contrast in temperature of warmer ground conditions compared to the cold air aloft.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The United States Census Bureau estimates the population of South Carolina was 5,148,714 on July 1, 2019, an 11.31 percentage increase since the 2010 census.

name: south_carolina
sentence: As of the 2017 census estimate, the racial make up of the state is 68.5% White (63.8% non-Hispanic white), 27.3% Black or African American, 0.5% American Indian and Alaska Native, 1.7% Asian, 0.1% Native Hawaiian and other Pacific Islander, 1.9% from two or more races.

name: south_carolina
sentence: 5.7% of the total population was of Hispanic or Latino origin of any race.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the United States Census Bureau, as of 2019, South Carolina had an estimated population of 5,148,714, which is an increase of 64,587 from the prior year and an increase of 523,350, or 11.31%, since the year 2010.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Immigration from outside the United States resulted in a net increase of 36,401 people, and migration within the country produced a net increase of 115,084 people.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the University of South Carolina's Arnold School of Public Health, Consortium for Latino Immigration Studies, South Carolina's foreign-born population grew faster than any other state between 2000 and 2005.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina has banned sanctuary cities.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Historical South Carolina Racial Breakdown of Population

name: south_carolina
sentence: Some Primary Statistical Areas of South Carolina overlap with neighbouring states of North Carolina and Georgia

name: south_carolina
sentence: The following table shows the major metropolitan areas of South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2019, the US Census Bureau released 2018 population estimates for South Carolina's most populous cities.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina's state government consists of the Executive, Legislative, and Judicial branches.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Also relevant are the state constitution, law enforcement agencies, federal representation, state finances, and state taxes.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina has historically had a weak executive branch and a strong legislature.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Before 1865, governors in South Carolina were appointed by the General Assembly, and held the title "President of State".

name: south_carolina
sentence: The 1865 Constitution changed this process, requiring a popular election.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Local governments were also weak.

name: south_carolina
sentence: But, the 1867 Constitution, passed during the Reconstruction era, extended democratization by establishing home rule for counties, which were established from the formerly designated districts of the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The 1895 state constitution overturned this, reducing the role of counties and strengthening the relative role of the state legislature; essentially the counties were agents of the state and ruled by the General Assembly through the legislative delegation for each county.

name: south_carolina
sentence: They are geographically comprehensive

name: south_carolina
sentence: As each county had one state senator, that position was particularly powerful.

name: south_carolina
sentence: This status continued until 1973, when the state constitution was amended to provide for home rule for the counties.

name: south_carolina
sentence: During this time the state had changed, with increasing urbanization, but rural counties retained proportionally more power as the legislature was based in representatives elected from counties rather than population districts.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The federal court case, Reynolds v. Sims (1964), "established the one-man, one-voteconcept for electoral representation at the state level.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Legislators were now supposed to representmore or less equal numbers of people."

name: south_carolina
sentence: Residents of urban areas had been found to be markedly underrepresented in the legislature under the county-based system.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Reapportionment made obvious the need for other changes to county structure, leading to the legislature passing the constitutional amendment.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Home Rule Act of 1975 implemented the amendment giving more power to the counties.

name: south_carolina
sentence: With urbanization, their governments have become increasingly important in the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Several changes to the state constitution have affected the office of the governor and the cabinet.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 1926 the governor's term was extended from two to four years

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 1993, the state passed an amendment requiring a limited cabinet (all of whom must be popularly elected).

name: south_carolina
sentence: As of January 2, 2016, there were 2,948,772 registered voters.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There is evidence of human activity in the area dating to about 40,000 years ago.

name: south_carolina
sentence: At the time Europeans arrived, marking the end of the Pre-Columbian era around 1600, there were many separate Native American tribes, the largest being the Cherokee and the Catawba, with the total population being up to 20,000.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Up the rivers of the eastern coastal plain lived about a dozen tribes of Siouan background.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Along the Savannah River were the Apalachee, Yuchi, and the Yamasee.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Further west were the Cherokee, and along the Catawba River, the Catawba.

name: south_carolina
sentence: These tribes were village-dwellers, relying on agriculture as their primary food source.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Cherokee lived in wattle and daub houses made with wood and clay, roofed with wood or thatched grass.

name: south_carolina
sentence: About a dozen separate small tribes summered on the coast harvesting oysters and fish, and cultivating corn, peas and beans.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Travelling inland as much as 50 miles (80 km) mostly by canoe, they wintered on the coastal plain, hunting deer and gathering nuts and fruit.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The names of these tribes survive in place names like Edisto Island, Kiawah Island, and the Ashepoo River.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Spanish were the first Europeans in the area.

name: south_carolina
sentence: From June 24 to July 14, 1521, they explored the land around Winyah Bay.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On October 8, 1526, they founded San Miguel de Gualdape, near present-day Georgetown, South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: It was the first European settlement in what is now the contiguous United States.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Established with five hundred settlers, it was abandoned eight months later by one hundred and fifty survivors.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 1540, Hernando de Soto explored the region and the main town of Cofitachequi, where he captured the queen of the Maskoki (Muscogee) and the Chelaque (Cherokee) who had welcomed him.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 1562 French Huguenots established a settlement at what is now the Charlesfort-Santa Elena archaeological site on Parris Island.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Many of these settlers preferred a natural life far from civilization and the atrocities of the Wars of Religion.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The garrison lacked supplies, however, and the soldiers (as in the France Antarctique) soon ran away.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The French returned two years later but settled in present-day Florida rather than South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Sixty years later, in 1629, King of England Charles I established the Province of Carolina, an area covering what is now South and North Carolina, Georgia and Tennessee.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 1663, Charles II granted the land to eight Lords Proprietors in return for their financial and political assistance in restoring him to the throne in 1660.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Anthony Ashley Cooper, one of the Lord Proprietors, planned the Grand Model for the Province of Carolina and wrote the Fundamental Constitutions of Carolina, which laid the basis for the future colony.

name: south_carolina
sentence: His utopia was inspired by John Locke, an English philosopher and physician, widely regarded as one of the most influential of Enlightenment thinkers and commonly known as the "Father of Liberalism".

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Carolina slave trade, which included both trading and direct raids by colonists, was the largest among the British colonies in North America.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Between 1670 and 1715, between 24,000 and 51,000 captive Native Americans were exported from South Carolina — more than the number of Africans imported to the colonies of the future United States during the same period.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Additional enslaved Native Americans were exported from South Carolina to other US colonies.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The historian Alan Gallay says, "the trade in Indian slaves was at the center of the English empire's development in the American South.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The trade in Indian slaves was the most important factor affecting the South in the period 1670 to 1715".

name: south_carolina
sentence: In the 1670s, English planters from Barbados established themselves near what is now Charleston.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Settlers from all over Europe built rice plantations in the South Carolina Lowcountry, east of the Atlantic Seaboard fall line.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Plantation labor was done by African slaves who formed the majority of the population by 1720.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Another cash crop was the indigo plant, a plant source of blue dye, developed by Eliza Lucas.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Meanwhile, Upstate South Carolina, west of the Fall Line, was settled by small farmers and traders, who displaced Native American tribes westward.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Colonists overthrew the proprietors' rule, seeking more direct representation.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 1719, the colony was officially made a crown colony.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 1729, North Carolina was split off into a separate colony.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina prospered from the fertility of the lowcountry and the harbors, such as at Charleston.

name: south_carolina
sentence: It allowed religious toleration, encouraging settlement, and trade in deerskin, lumber, and beef thrived.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Rice cultivation was developed on a large scale.

name: south_carolina
sentence: By the second half of the 1700s, South Carolina was one of the richest of the Thirteen Colonies.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On March 26, 1776, the colony adopted the Constitution of South Carolina, electing John Rutledge as the state's first president.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In February, 1778, South Carolina became the first state to ratify the Articles of Confederation, the initial governing document of the United States, and in May 1788, South Carolina ratified the United States Constitution, becoming the eighth state to enter the union.

name: south_carolina
sentence: During the American Revolutionary War (1775–1783), about a third of combat action took place in South Carolina, more than in any other state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Inhabitants of the state endured being invaded by British forces and an ongoing civil war between loyalists and partisans that devastated the backcountry.

name: south_carolina
sentence: It is estimated 25,000 slaves (30% of those in South Carolina) fled, migrated or died during the war.

name: south_carolina
sentence: America's first census in 1790 put the state's population at nearly 250,000.

name: south_carolina
sentence: By the 1800 census, the population had increased 38 per cent to nearly 340,000 of which 146,000 were slaves.

name: south_carolina
sentence: At that time South Carolina had the largest population of Jews in the sixteen states of the United States, mostly based in Savannah and Charleston, the latter being the country's fifth largest city.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In the Antebellum period (before the Civil War) the state's economy and population grew.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Cotton became an important crop after the invention of the cotton gin.

name: south_carolina
sentence: While nominally democratic, from 1790 until 1865, wealthy landowners were in control of South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: For example, a man was not eligible to sit in the State House of Representatives unless he possessed an estate of 500 acres of land and 10 Negroes, or at least 150 pounds sterling, diminishing the electorate.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Further, the state maintained indirect election of electors by the state legislature until 1868, the last state to do so.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Voters thus did not participate in presidential elections, other than through state-wide elections.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Columbia, the new state capital was founded in the center of the state, and the State Legislature first met there in 1790.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The town grew after it was connected to Charleston by the Santee Canal in 1800, one of the first canals in the United States.

name: south_carolina
sentence: As dissatisfaction with the federal government grew, in the 1820s John C. Calhoun became a leading proponent of states' rights, limited government, nullification of the US Constitution, and free trade.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 1832, the Ordinance of Nullification declared federal tariff laws unconstitutional and not to be enforced in the state, leading to the Nullification Crisis.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The federal Force Bill was enacted to use whatever military force necessary to enforce federal law in the state, bringing South Carolina back into line.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In the United States presidential election of 1860, voting was sharply divided, with the south voting for the Southern Democrats and the north for Abraham Lincoln's Republican Party.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Lincoln was anti-slavery, did not acknowledge the right to secession, and would not yield federal property in Southern states.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Southern secessionists believed Lincoln's election meant long-term doom for their slavery-based agrarian economy and social system.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Lincoln was elected president on November 6, 1860.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The state House of Representatives three days later passed the "Resolution to Call the Election of Abraham Lincoln as US President a Hostile Act", and within weeks South Carolina became the first state to secede.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On April 12, 1861, Confederate batteries began shelling the Union Fort Sumter in Charleston Harbor, and the American Civil War began.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In November of that year the Union attacked Port Royal Sound and soon occupied Beaufort County and the neighboring Sea Islands.

name: south_carolina
sentence: For the rest of the war this area served as a Union base and staging point for other operations.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Whites abandoned their plantations, leaving behind about ten thousand enslaved people.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Several Northern charities partnered with the federal government to help these people run the cotton farms themselves under the Port Royal Experiment.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Workers were paid by the pound harvested and thus became the first enslaved people freed by the Union forces to earn wages.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Although the state was not a major battleground, the war ruined the economy.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Under conscription, all white men aged 18–35 (later 45) were drafted for Confederate service.

name: south_carolina
sentence: More than 60,000 served, and the state lost nearly one-third of the white male population of fighting age.

name: south_carolina
sentence: At the end of the war in early 1865, the troops of General William Tecumseh Sherman marched across the state devastating plantations and most of Columbia.

name: south_carolina
sentence: After the war, South Carolina was restored to the United States during Reconstruction.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Under presidential Reconstruction (1865–66), freedmen (former slaves) were given limited rights.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Under Radical reconstruction (1867–1877), a Republican coalition of freedmen, carpetbaggers and scalawags was in control, supported by Union Army forces.

name: south_carolina
sentence: They established public education, welfare institutions, and home rule for counties, expanding democracy.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In Texas vs. White (1869), the Supreme Court ruled the ordinances of secession (including that of South Carolina) were invalid, and thus those states had never left the Union.

name: south_carolina
sentence: However, South Carolina did not regain representation in Congress until that date.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Until the 1868 presidential election, South Carolina's legislature, not the voters, chose the state's electors for the presidential election.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina was the last state to choose its electors in this manner.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On October 19, 1871, President Ulysses S. Grant suspended habeas corpus in nine South Carolina counties under the authority of the Ku Klux Klan Act.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Led by Grant's Attorney General Amos T. Akerman, hundreds of Klansmen were arrested while 2,000 Klansmen fled the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: This was done to suppress Klan violence against African-American and white voters in the South.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In the mid to late 1870s, white Democrats used paramilitary groups such as the Red Shirts to intimidate and terrorize black voters.

name: south_carolina
sentence: They regained political control of the state under conservative white "Redeemers" and pro-business Bourbon Democrats.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 1877, the federal government withdrew its troops as part of the Compromise of 1877 that ended Reconstruction.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The state became a hotbed of racial and economic tensions during the Populist and Agrarian movements of the 1890s.

name: south_carolina
sentence: A Republican-Populist biracial coalition took power away from White Democrats temporarily.

name: south_carolina
sentence: To prevent that from happening again, Democrats gained passage of a new constitution in 1895 which effectively disenfranchised almost all blacks and many poor whites by new requirements for poll taxes, residency, and literacy tests that dramatically reduced the voter rolls.

name: south_carolina
sentence: By 1896, only 5,500 black voters remained on the voter registration rolls, although they constituted a majority of the state's population.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The 1900 census demonstrated the extent of disenfranchisement: the 782,509 African American citizens comprised more than 58% of the state's population, but they were essentially without any political representation in the Jim Crow society.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The 1895 constitution overturned local representative government, reducing the role of the counties to agents of state government, effectively ruled by the General Assembly, through the legislative delegations for each county.

name: south_carolina
sentence: As each county had one state senator, that person had considerable power.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The counties lacked representative government until home rule was passed in 1975.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Governor "Pitchfork Ben Tillman", a Populist, led the effort to disenfranchise the blacks and poor whites, although he controlled Democratic state politics from the 1890s to 1910 with a base among poor white farmers.

name: south_carolina
sentence: During the constitutional convention in 1895, he supported another man's proposal that the state adopt a one-drop rule, as well as prohibit marriage between whites and anyone with any known African ancestry.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Some members of the convention realized prominent white families with some African ancestry could be affected by such legislation.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In terms similar to a debate in Virginia in 1853 on a similar proposal (which was dropped), George Dionysius Tillman said in opposition:

name: south_carolina
sentence: The state postponed such a one-drop law for years.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Virginian legislators adopted a one-drop law in 1924, forgetting that their state had many people of mixed ancestry among those who identified as white.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Early in the 20th century, South Carolina developed a thriving textile industry.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The state also converted its agricultural base from cotton to more profitable crops; attracted large military bases through its powerful Democratic congressional delegation, part of the one-party South following disfranchisement of blacks at the turn of the century; and created tourism industries.

name: south_carolina
sentence: During the early part of the 20th century, millions of African Americans left South Carolina and other southern states for jobs, opportunities and relative freedom in US cities outside the former Confederate states.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In total from 1910 to 1970, 6.5 million blacks left the South in the Great Migration.

name: south_carolina
sentence: By 1930 South Carolina had a white majority population for the first time since 1708.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina was one of several states that initially rejected the Nineteenth Amendment (1920) giving women the right to vote.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The South Carolina legislature later ratified the amendment on July 1, 1969.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The struggle of the civil rights movement took place in South Carolina as they did in other Southern states.

name: south_carolina
sentence: However, South Carolina experienced a much less violent movement than other Southern states.

name: south_carolina
sentence: This tranquil transition from a Jim Crow society occurred because the state's white and black leaders were willing to accept slow change rather than being utterly unwilling to accept change at all.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Other South Carolinians, like Senator Strom Thurmond, on the other hand, were among the nation's most radical and effective opponents of social equality and integration.

name: south_carolina
sentence: As of 2015, South Carolina had one of the lowest percentages among all states of women in state legislature, at 13.5% (only Louisiana, Oklahoma, and Wyoming had a lower percentage; the national average is 24.3%; with the highest percentage being in Colorado at 41%).

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2011, South Carolina ranked first in the country in the rate of women killed by men.

name: south_carolina
sentence: As the 21st century progresses, South Carolina has attracted new business by having a 5% corporate income tax rate, no state property tax, no local income tax, no inventory tax, no sales tax on manufacturing equipment, industrial power or materials for finished products; no wholesale tax, and no unitary tax on worldwide profits.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina was one of the first states to stop paying for 'early elective' deliveries of babies, under either Medicaid and private insurance.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The term early elective is defined as a labor induction or Cesarean section between 37–39 weeks that is not medically based.

name: south_carolina
sentence: This change is intended to result in healthier babies and fewer unnecessary costs for South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On November 20, 2014, South Carolina became the 35th state to legalize same-sex marriages, when a federal court ordered the change.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina has many venues for visual and performing arts.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Gibbes Museum of Art in Charleston, the Greenville County Museum of Art, the Columbia Museum of Art, Spartanburg Art Museum, and the South Carolina State Museum in Columbia among others provide access to visual arts to the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are also numerous historic sites and museums scattered throughout the state paying homage to many events and periods in the state's history from Native American inhabitation to the present day.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina also has performing art venues including the Peace Center in Greenville, the Koger Center for the Arts in Columbia, and the Newberry Opera House, among others to bring local, national, and international talent to the stages of South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Several large venues can house major events, including Colonial Life Arena in Columbia, Bon Secours Wellness Arena in Greenville, and North Charleston Coliseum.

name: south_carolina
sentence: One of the nation's major performing arts festivals, Spoleto Festival USA, is held annually in Charleston.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are also countless local festivals throughout the state highlighting many cultural traditions, historical events, and folklore.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the South Carolina Arts Commission, creative industries generate $9.2 billion annually and support over 78,000 jobs in the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: A 2009 statewide poll by the University of South Carolina Institute for Public Service and Policy Research found that 67% of residents had participated in the arts in some form during the past year and on average citizens had participated in the arts 14 times in the previous year.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the Association of Religion Data Archives (ARDA), in 2010, the largest religion is Christianity, of which the largest denominations were the Southern Baptist Convention with 913,763 adherents, the United Methodist Church with 274,111 adherents, and the Roman Catholic Church with 181,743 adherents.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Fourth-largest is the African Methodist Episcopal Church with 564 congregations and 121,000 members and fifth-largest is the Presbyterian Church (USA) with 320 congregations and almost 100,000 members.

name: south_carolina
sentence: As of 2010, South Carolina is the American state with the highest per capita proportion of citizens who follow the Baháʼí Faith, with 17,559 adherents, making Baháʼí the second-largest religion in the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Although no major league professional sports teams are based in South Carolina, the Carolina Panthers do have training facilities in the state and played their inaugural season's home games at Clemson's Memorial Stadium, however, they now play at Bank of America Stadium in North Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Panthers consider themselves "The Carolinas' Team" and refrained from naming themselves after Charlotte or either of the Carolinas.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The state is also home to numerous minor league professional teams.

name: south_carolina
sentence: College teams represent their particular South Carolina institutions, and are the primary options for football, basketball and baseball attendance in the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is also a top destination for golf and water sports.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is also home to one of NASCAR's first tracks and its first paved speedway, Darlington Raceway, located northwest of Florence.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2019, South Carolina's GDP was $249.9 billion, making the state the 26th largest by GDP in the United States.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the US Bureau of Economic Analysis, South Carolina's gross state product (GSP) in was $97 billion in 1997 and $153 billion in 2007.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Its per-capita real gross domestic product (GDP) in chained 2000 dollars was $26,772 in 1997 and $28,894 in 2007; which represented 85% of the $31,619 per-capita real GDP for the United States overall in 1997, and 76% of the $38,020 for the US in 2007.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The state debt in 2012 was calculated by one source to be $22.9bn, or $7,800 per taxpayer.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Industrial outputs include textile goods, chemical products, paper products, machinery, automobiles, automotive products and tourism.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Major agricultural outputs of the state are tobacco, poultry, cotton, cattle, dairy products, soybeans, hay, rice, and swine.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, as of March 2012, South Carolina had 1,852,700 nonfarm jobs of which 12% are in manufacturing, 11.5% are in leisure and hospitality, 19% are in trade, transportation, and utilities, and 11.8% are in education and health services.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The service sector accounts for 83.7% of the South Carolina economy.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Many large corporations have moved their locations to South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Boeing opened an aircraft manufacturing facility in Charleston in 2011, which serves as one of two final assembly sites for the 787 Dreamliner.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is a right-to-work state and many businesses utilize staffing agencies to temporarily fill positions.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Domtar, in Rock Hill, is the only Fortune 500 company headquartered in South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Fortune 1000 list includes SCANA, Sonoco Products and ScanSource.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina also benefits from foreign investment.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are 1,950 foreign-owned firms operating in South Carolina employing almost 135,000 people.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) brought 1.06 billion dollars to the state economy in 2010.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Since 1994, BMW has had a production facility in Spartanburg County near Greer and since 1996 the Zapp Group operates in Summerville near Charleston.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are 36 TV stations (including PBS affiliates) serving South Carolina with terrestrial, and some online streaming access.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Markets in which the stations are located include Columbia, Florence, Allendale, Myrtle Beach, Greenville, Charleston, Conway, Beaufort, Hardeeville, Spartanburg, Greenwood, Anderson and Sumter.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The state has the fourth largest state-maintained system in the country, consisting of 11 Interstates, numbered highways, state highways, and secondary roads, totalling approximately 41,500 miles.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On secondary roads, South Carolina uses a numbering system to keep track of all non-interstate and primary highways that the South Carolina Department of Transportation maintains.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Secondary roads are numbered by the number of the county followed by a unique number for the particular road.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Passenger railAmtrak operates four passenger routes in South Carolina: the Crescent, the Palmetto, the Silver Meteor, and the Silver Star.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Crescent route serves the Upstate cities, the Silver Star serves the Midlands cities, and the Palmetto and Silver Meteor routes serve the lowcountry cities.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Station stops

name: south_carolina
sentence: FreightCSX Transportation and Norfolk Southern are the only Class I railroad companies in South Carolina, as other freight companies in the state are short lines.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are seven significant airports in South Carolina, all of which act as regional airport hubs.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The busiest by passenger volume is Charleston International Airport.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Just across the border in North Carolina is Charlotte/Douglas International Airport, the 30th busiest airport in the world, in terms of passengers.

name: south_carolina
sentence: As of 2010, South Carolina is one of three states that have not agreed to use competitive international math and language standards.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2014, the South Carolina Supreme Court ruled the state had failed to provide a "minimally adequate" education to children in all parts of the state as required by the state's constitution.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina has 1,144 K–12 schools in 85 school districts with an enrollment of 712,244 as of fall 2009.

name: south_carolina
sentence: As of the 2008–2009 school year, South Carolina spent $9,450 per student which places it 31st in the country for per student spending.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2015, the national average SAT score was 1490 and the South Carolina average was 1442, 48 points lower than the national average.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is the only state which owns and operates a statewide school bus system.

name: south_carolina
sentence: As of December 2016, the state maintains a 5,582-bus fleet with the average vehicle in service being fifteen years old (the national average is six) having logged 236,000 miles.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Half of the state's school buses are more than 15 years old and some are reportedly up to 30 years old.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2017 in the budget proposal, Superintendent of Education Molly Spearman requested the state lease to purchase 1,000 buses to replace the most decrepit vehicles.

name: south_carolina
sentence: An additional 175 buses could be purchased immediately through the State Treasurer's master lease program.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On January 5, 2017, the US Environmental Protection Agency awarded South Carolina more than $1.1 million to replace 57 school buses with new cleaner models through its Diesel Emissions Reduction Act program.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina has diverse institutions from large state-funded research universities to small colleges that cultivate a liberal arts, religious or military tradition.

name: south_carolina
sentence: For overall health care, South Carolina is ranked 33rd out of the 50 states, according to the Commonwealth Fund, a private health foundation working to improve the health care system.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The state's teen birth rate was 53 births per 1,000 teens, compared to the national average of 41.9 births, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The state's infant mortality rate was 9.4 deaths per 1,000 births compared to the national average of 6.9 deaths.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There were 2.6 physicians per 1,000 people compared to the national average of 3.2 physicians.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There was $5,114 spent on health expenses per capita in the state, compared to the national average of $5,283.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There were 26 percent of children and 13 percent of elderly living in poverty in the state, compared to 23 percent and 13 percent, respectively, doing so in the US And, 34 percent of children were overweight or obese, compared to the national average of 32 percent.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota ( (listen)) is a US state in the Midwestern region of the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: It is named after the Lakota and Dakota Sioux Native American tribes, who comprise a large portion of the population and historically dominated the territory.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is the seventeenth largest by area, but the 5th least populous, and the 5th least densely populated of the 50 United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As the southern part of the former Dakota Territory, South Dakota became a state on November 2, 1889, simultaneously with North Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: It is either the 39th or 40th state admitted to the union.

name: south_dakota
sentence: President Benjamin Harrison shuffled the statehood papers before signing them so that no one could tell which became a state first.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Pierre is the state capital and Sioux Falls, with a population of about 187,200, is South Dakota's largest city.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is bordered by the states of North Dakota (to the north), Minnesota (to the east), Iowa (to the southeast), Nebraska (to the south), Wyoming (to the west), and Montana (to the northwest).

name: south_dakota
sentence: The state is bisected by the Missouri River, dividing South Dakota into two geographically and socially distinct halves, known to residents as "East River" and "West River".

name: south_dakota
sentence: Eastern South Dakota is home to most of the state's population, and the area's fertile soil is used to grow a variety of crops.

name: south_dakota
sentence: West of the Missouri River, ranching is the predominant agricultural activity, and the economy is more dependent on tourism and defense spending.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Most of the Native American reservations are in West River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Black Hills, a group of low pine-covered mountains sacred to the Sioux, are in the southwest part of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Mount Rushmore, a major tourist destination, is there.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has a temperate continental climate, with four distinct seasons and precipitation ranging from moderate in the east to semi-arid in the west.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The state's ecology features species typical of a North American grassland biome.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Humans have inhabited the area for several millennia, with the Sioux becoming dominant by the early 19th century.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the late 19th century, European-American settlement intensified after a gold rush in the Black Hills and the construction of railroads from the east.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Encroaching miners and settlers triggered a number of Indian wars, ending with the Wounded Knee Massacre in 1890.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Key events in the 20th century included the Dust Bowl and Great Depression, increased federal spending during the 1940s and 1950s for agriculture and defense, and an industrialization of agriculture that has reduced family farming.

name: south_dakota
sentence: While several Democrats have represented South Dakota for multiple terms in both chambers of Congress, the state government is largely controlled by the Republican Party, whose nominees have carried South Dakota in each of the last 13 presidential elections.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Historically dominated by an agricultural economy and a rural lifestyle, South Dakota has recently sought to diversify its economy in areas to attract and retain residents.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota's history and rural character still strongly influence the state's culture.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is in the north-central United States, and is considered a part of the Midwest by the US Census Bureau; it is also part of the Great Plains region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The culture, economy, and geography of western South Dakota have more in common with the West than the Midwest.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has a total area of 77,116 square miles (199,730 km2), making the state the 17th largest in the Union.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Black Elk Peak, formerly named Harney Peak, with an elevation of 7,242 ft (2,207 m), is the state's highest point, while the shoreline of Big Stone Lake is the lowest, with an elevation of 966 ft (294 m).

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is bordered to the north by North Dakota

name: south_dakota
sentence: The geographical center of the US is 17 miles (27 km) west of Castle Rock in Butte County.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The North American continental pole of inaccessibility is between Allen and Kyle, 1,024 mi (1,648 km) from the nearest coastline.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Missouri River is the largest and longest river in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other major South Dakota rivers include the Cheyenne, James, Big Sioux, and White Rivers.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Eastern South Dakota has many natural lakes, mostly created by periods of glaciation.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Additionally, dams on the Missouri River create four large reservoirs: Lake Oahe, Lake Sharpe, Lake Francis Case, and Lewis and Clark Lake.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota can generally be divided into three regions: eastern South Dakota, western South Dakota, and the Black Hills.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Missouri River serves as a boundary in terms of geographic, social, and political differences between eastern and western South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The geography of the Black Hills, long considered sacred by Native Americans, differs from its surroundings to such an extent it can be considered separate from the rest of western South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: At times the Black Hills are combined with the rest of western South Dakota, and people often refer to the resulting two regions divided by the Missouri River as West River and East River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Eastern South Dakota generally features higher precipitation and lower topography than the western part of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Smaller geographic regions of this area include the Coteau des Prairies, the Dissected Till Plains, and the James River Valley.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Coteau des Prairies is a plateau bordered on the east by the Minnesota River Valley and on the west by the James River Basin.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Further west, the James River Basin is mostly low, flat, highly eroded land, following the flow of the James River through South Dakota from north to south.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Dissected Till Plains, an area of rolling hills and fertile soil that covers much of Iowa and Nebraska, extends into the southeastern corner of South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Layers deposited during the Pleistocene epoch, starting around two million years ago, cover most of eastern South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: These are the youngest rock and sediment layers in the state, the product of several successive periods of glaciation which deposited a large amount of rocks and soil, known as till, over the area.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Great Plains cover most of the western two-thirds of South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: West of the Missouri River the landscape becomes more arid and rugged, consisting of rolling hills, plains, ravines, and steep flat-topped hills called buttes.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the south, east of the Black Hills, lie the South Dakota Badlands.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Erosion from the Black Hills, marine skeletons which fell to the bottom of a large shallow sea that once covered the area, and volcanic material all contribute to the geology of this area.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Black Hills are in the southwestern part of South Dakota and extend into Wyoming.

name: south_dakota
sentence: This range of low mountains covers 6,000 sq mi (16,000 km2), with peaks that rise from 2,000 to 4,000 feet (600 to 1,200 m) above their bases.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Black Hills are the location of Black Elk Peak (7,242 ft or 2,207 m above sea level), the highest point in South Dakota and also the highest point in the United States east of the Rocky Mountains.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Two-billion-year-old Precambrian formations, the oldest rocks in the state, form the central core of the Black Hills.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Formations from the Paleozoic Era form the outer ring of the Black Hills

name: south_dakota
sentence: This area features rocks such as limestone, which were deposited here when the area formed the shoreline of an ancient inland sea.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Much of South Dakota (except for the Black Hills area) is dominated by a temperate grassland biome.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Although grasses and crops cover most of this region, deciduous trees such as cottonwoods, elms, and willows are common near rivers and in shelter belts.Mammals in this area include bison, deer, pronghorn, coyotes, and prairie dogs.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The state bird, the ring-necked pheasant, has adapted well to the area after being introduced from China.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Growing populations of bald eagles are spread throughout the state, especially near the Missouri River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Rivers and lakes of the grasslands support populations of walleye, carp, pike, bass, and other species.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Missouri River also contains the pre-historic paddlefish.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Due to a higher elevation and level of precipitation, the Black Hills ecology differs significantly from that of the plains.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The mountains are thickly blanketed by various types of pines, including ponderosa and lodgepole pines, as well as spruces.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Black Hills mammals include deer, elk (wapiti), bighorn sheep, mountain goats, pine marten, and mountain lions, while the streams and lakes contain several species of trout.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has a continental climate with four distinct seasons, ranging from cold, dry winters to warm and semi-humid summers.

name: south_dakota
sentence: During the summers, the state's average high temperature is often close to 90 °F (32 °C), although it cools to near 60 °F (16 °C) at night.

name: south_dakota
sentence: It is not unusual for South Dakota to have severe hot, dry spells in the summer with the temperature climbing above 100 °F (38 °C) several times a year.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Winters are cold with January high temperatures averaging below freezing and low temperatures averaging below 10 °F (−12 °C) in most of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The highest recorded temperature is 120 °F (49 °C) at Usta on July 15, 2006 and the lowest recorded temperature is −58 °F (−50 °C) at McIntosh on February 17, 1936.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Average annual precipitation in South Dakota ranges from semi-arid conditions in the northwestern part of the state (around 15 inches or 380 mm) to semi-humid around the southeast portion of the state (around 25 inches or 640 mm), although a small area centered on Lead in the Black Hills has the highest precipitation at nearly 30 inches (760 mm) per year.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota summers bring frequent, sometimes severe, thunderstorms with high winds, thunder, and hail.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The state's eastern part is often considered part of Tornado Alley, and South Dakota experiences an average of 30 tornadoes each year.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Severe blizzards and ice storms often occur during winter.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has several sites administered by the National Park Service.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Two national parks have been established in the state, both in its southwestern region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Wind Cave National Park, established in 1903 in the Black Hills, has an extensive cave network and is home to a large herd of bison.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Badlands National Park was established in 1978, and features an eroded, brightly colored landscape surrounded by semi-arid grasslands.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Mount Rushmore National Memorial in the Black Hills was established in 1925.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The sculpture of four US Presidents was carved into the mountainside by sculptor Gutzon Borglum.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other areas managed by the National Park Service include Jewel Cave National Monument near Custer, the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail, the Minuteman Missile National Historic Site, which features a decommissioned nuclear missile silo and a separate missile control area several miles away, and the Missouri National Recreational River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Crazy Horse Memorial is a large mountainside sculpture near Mount Rushmore being built using private funds.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Mammoth Site near Hot Springs is another privately owned attraction in the Black Hills.

name: south_dakota
sentence: It is a working paleontological dig and has one of the world's largest concentrations of mammoth remains.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Humans have lived in what is today South Dakota for several thousand years.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The first inhabitants were Paleoindian hunter-gatherers, and disappeared from the area around 5000 BC.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Between 500 AD and 800 AD, a semi-nomadic people known as the Mound Builders lived in central and eastern South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the 14th century, the Crow Creek Massacre occurred, in which several hundred men, women, and children were killed near the Missouri River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: By 1500, the Arikara (or Ree) had settled in much of the Missouri River valley.

name: south_dakota
sentence: European contact with the area began in 1743, when the LaVérendrye brothers explored the region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The LaVérendrye group buried a plate near the site of modern-day Pierre, claiming the region for France as part of greater Louisiana.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1762 the entire region became part of the Spanish Louisiana until 1802.

name: south_dakota
sentence: By the early 19th century, the Sioux had largely replaced the Arikara as the dominant group in the area.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1803, the United States purchased the Louisiana Territory, an area that included most of South Dakota, from Napoleon Bonaparte, and President Thomas Jefferson organized a group commonly referred to as the "Lewis and Clark Expedition" to explore the region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1817, an American fur trading post was set up at present-day Fort Pierre, beginning continuous American settlement of the area.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1855, the US Army bought Fort Pierre but abandoned it in 1857 in favor of Fort Randall to the south.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Settlement by Americans and Europeans was by this time increasing rapidly, and in 1858 the Yankton Sioux signed the 1858 Treaty, ceding most of present-day eastern South Dakota to the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Land speculators founded two of eastern South Dakota's largest present-day cities: Sioux Falls in 1856 and Yankton in 1859.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1861, the Dakota Territory was established by the United States government (this initially included North Dakota, South Dakota, and parts of Montana and Wyoming).

name: south_dakota
sentence: Settlement of the area, mostly by people from the eastern United States as well as western and northern Europe, increased rapidly, especially after the completion of an eastern railway link to Yankton in 1873.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1874, gold was discovered in the Black Hills during a military expedition led by George A. Custer and miners and explorers began illegally entering land promised to the Lakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Custer's expedition took place despite the fact that the Sioux had been granted the entire western half of present-day South Dakota (West River) in 1868 by the Treaty of Laramie as part of the Great Sioux Reservation.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Sioux declined to grant mining rights or land in the Black Hills, and war broke out after the US failed to stop white miners and settlers from entering the region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Eventually the US won and broke up the Great Sioux Reservation into five reservations, settling the Lakota there.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1980 the Supreme Court and Congress ordered compensation but the Lakota still refuse to accept it, insisting on return of their land.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A growing population and political concerns (admitting two states meant having four new senators for the Republican Party) caused Dakota Territory to be divided in half and President Benjamin Harrison signed proclamations formally admitting South Dakota and North Dakota to the union on November 2, 1889.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Harrison had the papers shuffled to obscure which one was signed first and the order went unrecorded.

name: south_dakota
sentence: On December 29, 1890, the Wounded Knee Massacre occurred on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Commonly cited as the last major armed conflict between the United States and the Lakota Sioux Nation, the massacre resulted in the deaths of at least 146 Sioux, many of them women and children.

name: south_dakota
sentence: 31 US soldiers were also killed in the conflict.

name: south_dakota
sentence: During the 1930s, several economic and climatic conditions combined with disastrous results for South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A lack of rainfall, extremely high temperatures and inappropriate cultivation techniques produced what was known as the Dust Bowl in South Dakota and several other plains states.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Fertile topsoil was blown away in massive dust storms, and several harvests were completely ruined.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The experiences of the Dust Bowl, coupled with local bank foreclosures and the general economic effects of the Great Depression, resulted in many South Dakotans leaving the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The population of South Dakota declined by more than 7% between 1930 and 1940.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Economic stability returned with the US entry into World War II in 1941, when demand for the state's agricultural and industrial products grew as the nation mobilized for war.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1944, the Pick–Sloan Plan was passed as part of the Flood Control Act of 1944 by the US Congress, resulting in the construction of six large dams on the Missouri River, four of which are at least partially in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Flood control, hydroelectricity, and recreational opportunities such as boating and fishing are provided by the dams and their reservoirs.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In recent decades, South Dakota has been transformed from a state dominated by agriculture to one with a more diversified economy.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The tourism industry has grown considerably since the completion of the interstate system in the 1960s, with the Black Hills becoming more important as a destination.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The financial service industry began to grow in the state as well, with Citibank moving its credit card operations from New York to Sioux Falls in 1981, a move that has been followed by several other financial companies.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota was the first state to eliminate caps on interest rates.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2007, the site of the recently closed Homestake gold mine near Lead was chosen as the location of a new underground research facility, the Deep Underground Science and Engineering Laboratory.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Despite a growing state population and recent economic development, many rural areas have been struggling over the past 50 years with locally declining populations and the emigration of educated young adults to larger South Dakota cities, such as Rapid City or Sioux Falls, or to other states.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Mechanization and consolidation of agriculture has contributed greatly to the declining number of smaller family farms and the resulting economic and demographic challenges facing rural towns.

name: south_dakota
sentence: However, the state often ranks highly for its way of life, and Gallup's well-being index in 2018 named South Dakota the happiest, healthiest state in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The United States Census Bureau estimates the population of South Dakota was 884,659 on July 1, 2019, an 8.66% increase since the 2010 United States Census, only North Dakota, Alaska, Vermont, and Wyoming have fewer residents.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As of 2019, South Dakota had an estimated population of 884,659, an increase of 70,479, or 8.66%, since the year 2010.

name: south_dakota
sentence: 7.3% of South Dakota's population was reported as under 5, 24% under 18, and 14.3% were 65 or older.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Females made up approximately 50.2% of the population.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As of the 2000 census, South Dakota ranked fifth-lowest in the nation in population and population density.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Of the people residing in South Dakota, 65.7% were born in South Dakota, 31.4% were born in another US state, 0.6% were born in Puerto Rico, US Island areas, or born abroad to American parent(s), and 2.3% were born in another country.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The center of population of South Dakota is in Buffalo County, in the unincorporated county seat of Gann Valley.

name: south_dakota
sentence: According to the 2010 Census, the racial composition of the population was:

name: south_dakota
sentence: Ethnically, 2.7% of South Dakota's population was of Hispanic, Latino, or Spanish origin (they may be of any race).

name: south_dakota
sentence: As of 2011, 25.4% of South Dakota's population younger than age 1 were minorities, meaning they had at least one parent who was not non-Hispanic white.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As of 2000, the five largest ancestry groups in South Dakota are German (40.7%), Norwegian (15.3%), Irish (10.4%), Native American (8.3%), and English (7.1%).

name: south_dakota
sentence: German Americans are the largest ancestry group in most parts of the state, especially in East River (east of the Missouri River), although there are also large Scandinavian-descended populations in some counties.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has the nation's largest population of Hutterites, a communal Anabaptist group which emigrated in 1874 from Europe, primarily from German-speaking areas.

name: south_dakota
sentence: American Indians, largely Lakota, Dakota, and Nakota (Sioux), are predominant in several counties and constitute 20 per cent of the population in West River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The seven large Indian reservations in the state occupy an area much diminished from their former Great Sioux Reservation of West River, which the federal government had once allocated to the Sioux tribes.

name: south_dakota
