sentence: South Dakota has the third-highest proportion of Native Americans of any state, behind Alaska and New Mexico.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Five of the state's counties are wholly within the boundaries of sovereign Indian reservations.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Because of the limitations of climate and land, and isolation from urban areas with more employment opportunities, living standards on many South Dakota reservations are often far below the national average; Ziebach County ranked as the poorest county in the nation in 2009.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The unemployment rate in Fort Thompson, on the Crow Creek Reservation, is 70%, and 21% of households lack plumbing or basic kitchen appliances.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A 1995 study by the US Census Bureau found 58% of homes on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation did not have a telephone.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The reservations' isolation also inhibits their ability to generate revenue from gaming casinos, an avenue that has proved profitable for many tribes closer to urban centers.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1995 the legislature passed a law to make English the "common language" of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Since 2019, "the language of the Great Sioux Nation, comprised of three dialects, Dakota, Lakota, and Nakota" is an official language.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As of the 2000 census, 1.90% of the population age 5 or older speak German at home, while 1.51% speak Lakota or Dakota, and 1.43% Spanish.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As of 2010, 93.46% (692,504) of South Dakota residents age 5 and older spoke English as their primary language.

name: south_dakota
sentence: 6.54% of the population spoke a language other than English.

name: south_dakota
sentence: 2.06% (15,292) of the population spoke Spanish, 1.39% (10,282) spoke Dakota, and 1.37% (10,140) spoke German.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other languages spoken included Vietnamese (0.16%), Chinese (0.12%), and Russian (0.10%).

name: south_dakota
sentence: Over the last several decades, the population in many rural areas has declined in South Dakota, in common with other Great Plains states.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The change has been characterized as "rural flight" as family farming has declined.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Young people have moved to cities for other employment.

name: south_dakota
sentence: This trend has continued in recent years, with 30 of South Dakota's counties losing population between the 1990 and the 2000 census.

name: south_dakota
sentence: During that time, nine counties had a population loss of greater than 10%, with Harding County, in the northwest corner of the state, losing nearly 19% of its population.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Low birth rates and a lack of younger immigration has caused the median age of many of these counties to increase.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 24 counties, at least 20% of the population is over the age of 65, compared with a national rate of 12.8%.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The effect of rural flight has not been spread evenly through South Dakota, however.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Although most rural counties and small towns have lost population, the Sioux Falls area, the larger counties along Interstate 29, the Black Hills, and many Indian reservations have all gained population.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As the reservations have exercised more sovereignty, some Sioux have returned to them from urban areas.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Lincoln County near Sioux Falls was the seventh fastest-growing county (by percentage) in the United States in 2010.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The growth in these areas has compensated for losses in the rest of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota's total population continues to increase steadily, albeit at a slower rate than the national average.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The largest denominations by number of adherents in 2010 were the Roman Catholic Church with 148,883 members; the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America (ELCA) with 112,649 members; and the United Methodist Church (UMC) with 36,020 members.

name: south_dakota
sentence: (The ELCA and UMC are specific denominations within the broader terms 'Lutheran' and 'Methodist', respectively.

name: south_dakota
sentence: )The results of a 2001 survey, in which South Dakotans were asked to identify their religion, include:

name: south_dakota
sentence: The current-dollar gross state product of South Dakota was $39.8 billion as of 2010, the fifth-smallest total state output in the US

name: south_dakota
sentence: The per capita personal income was $38,865 in 2010, ranked 25th in the US, and 12.5% of the population was below the poverty line in 2008.CNBC's list of "Top States for Business for 2010" has recognized South Dakota as the seventh best state in the nation.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In July 2011, the state's unemployment rate was 4.7%.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The service industry is the largest economic contributor in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: This sector includes the retail, finance, and health care industries.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Citibank, which was the largest bank holding company in the United States at one time, established national banking operations in South Dakota in 1981 to take advantage of favorable banking regulations.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Government spending is another important segment of the state's economy, providing over ten percent of the gross state product.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Ellsworth Air Force Base, near Rapid City, is the second-largest single employer in the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Agriculture has historically been a key component of the South Dakota economy.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Although other industries have expanded rapidly in recent decades, agricultural production is still very important to the state's economy, especially in rural areas.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The five most valuable agricultural products in South Dakota are cattle, corn (maize), soybeans, wheat, and hogs.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Agriculture-related industries such as meat packing and ethanol production also have a considerable economic impact on the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is the sixth leading ethanol-producing state in the nation.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Another important sector in South Dakota's economy is tourism.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Many travel to view the attractions of the state, particularly those in the Black Hills region, such as historic Deadwood, Mount Rushmore, and the nearby state and national parks.

name: south_dakota
sentence: One of the largest tourist events in the state is the annual Sturgis Motorcycle Rally.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The five-day event drew over 739,000 attendees in 2015; significant considering the state has a total population of 850,000.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2006, tourism provided an estimated 33,000 jobs in the state and contributed over two billion dollars to the economy of South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has 83,609 miles (134,556 km) of highways, roads, and streets, along with 679 miles (1,093 km) of interstate highways.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Two major interstates pass through South Dakota: Interstate 90, which runs east and west through the southern half of the state; and Interstate 29, running north and south in the eastern portion of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The I-29 corridor features generally higher rates of population and economic growth than areas in eastern South Dakota further from the interstate.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Also in the state are the shorter Interstates 190, a spur into central Rapid City, and 229, a loop around southern and eastern Sioux Falls.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Several major US highways pass through the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: US routes 12, 14, 16, 18 and 212 travel east and west, while US routes 81, 83, 85 and 281 run north and south.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota and Montana are the only states sharing a land border which is not traversed by a paved road.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota contains two National Scenic Byways.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Peter Norbeck National Scenic Byway is in the Black Hills, while the Native American Scenic Byway runs along the Missouri River in the north-central part of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other scenic byways include the Badlands Loop Scenic Byway, the Spearfish Canyon Scenic Byway, and the Wildlife Loop Road Scenic Byway.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Railroads have played an important role in South Dakota transportation since the mid-19th century.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Some 4,420 miles (7,110 km) of railroad track were built in South Dakota during the late 19th century and early 20th century, but only 1,839 miles (2,960 km) are active.

name: south_dakota
sentence: BNSF Railway is the largest railroad in South Dakota; the Rapid City, Pierre and Eastern Railroad (formerly the Dakota, Minnesota and Eastern) is the state's other major carrier.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other state carriers include Dakota Southern Railway, Dakota and Iowa Railroad, Ellis and Eastern Railroad, Sunflour Railroad, Canadian Pacific Railway, and the Sisseton Milbank Railroad.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Rail transportation in the state is mostly freight, but there are two passenger heritage railroads: the Black Hills Central and the Prairie Village, Herman, and Milwaukee.

name: south_dakota
sentence: However, South Dakota is one of the two contiguous states that lack Amtrak service.

name: south_dakota
sentence: (South Dakota is the only contiguous state that never had Amtrak—Wyoming used to be served by the San Francisco Zephyr and the Pioneer.)

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota's largest commercial airports in terms of passenger traffic are the Sioux Falls Regional Airport and Rapid City Regional Airport.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Delta Air Lines, Frontier Airlines, and Allegiant Airlines, as well as commuter airlines using the brand affiliation with major airlines serve the two largest airports.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Several other cities in the state also have commercial air service: Aberdeen Regional Airport, Pierre Regional Airport, and Watertown Regional Airport, some of which is subsidized by the Essential Air Service program.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Like other US states, the structure of the government of South Dakota follows the same separation of powers as the federal government, with executive, legislative, and judicial branches.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The structure of the state government is laid out in the Constitution of South Dakota, the highest law in the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The constitution may be amended by a majority vote of both houses of the legislature, or by voter initiative.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Governor of South Dakota occupies the executive branch of the state government.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The current governor is Kristi Noem, a Republican.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The state constitution gives the governor the power to sign into law or veto bills passed by the state legislature, to serve as commander-in-chief of the South Dakota National Guard, to appoint a cabinet, and to commute criminal sentences or to pardon those convicted of crimes.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The governor serves for a four-year term, and may not serve more than two consecutive terms.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The state legislature is made up of two bodies, the Senatorte, which has 35 members, and the House of Representatives, with 70 members.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is divided into 35 legislative districts, with voters electing two representatives and one senator per district.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The legislature meets for an annual session which begins on the second Tuesday in January and lasts for 30 days

name: south_dakota
sentence: The judicial branch is made up of several levels.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The state supreme court, with four justices and a chief justice, is the highest court in the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Below the supreme court are the circuit courts

name: south_dakota
sentence: Below the circuit courts are the magistrate courts, which deal with lesser criminal and civil actions.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As of 2005, South Dakota has the lowest per capita total state tax rate in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The state does not levy personal or corporate income taxes, inheritance taxes, or taxes on intangible personal property.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The state sales tax rate is 4.5 percent.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Various localities have local levies so in some areas the rate is six percent.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The state sales tax does not apply to sales to Indians on Indian reservations, but many reservations have a compact with the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Businesses on the reservation collect the tax and the state refunds to the Indian Tribes the percentage of sales tax collections relating to the ratio of Indian population to total population in the county or area affected.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Ad valorem property taxes are local taxes and are a large source of funding for school systems, counties, municipalities and other local government units.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The South Dakota Special Tax Division regulates some taxes including cigarette and alcohol-related taxes.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is represented at the federal level by Senatortor John Thune, Senatortor Mike Rounds, and Representative Dusty Johnson.

name: south_dakota
sentence: All three are Republicans.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is one of seven states with only one seat in the US House of Representatives.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In United States presidential elections, South Dakota is allotted three of 538 votes in the Electoral College.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As in all other states except Maine and neighboring Nebraska, South Dakota's electoral votes are granted in a winner-take-all system.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota politics are generally dominated by the Republican Party.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Since statehood, Republicans have carried the state's electoral votes in all but five presidential elections: 1896, 1912 (by Theodore Roosevelt's Progressive Party), 1932, 1936 and 1964.

name: south_dakota
sentence: (Democrat George McGovern—a native South Dakotan—failed to carry his home state in 1972.)

name: south_dakota
sentence: Only Alaska has been carried fewer times by a Democrat.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Additionally, a Democrat has not won the governorship since 1974.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As of 2016, Republicans hold a 15% voter registration advantage over Democrats and hold large majorities in both the state House and the state Senatorte.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Despite the state's general Republican and conservative leanings, Democrats have found success in various statewide elections, most notably in those involving South Dakota's congressional representatives in Washington.

name: south_dakota
sentence: American Indians have been becoming more active in state and county electoral politics.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the 2002 election, American Indian voting carried Tim Johnson as the Democratic candidate by a margin of 532 votes.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Until his electoral defeat in 2004, Senatortor Tom Daschle was the Senatorte minority leader (and briefly its majority leader during Democratic control of the Senatorte in 2001–02).

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other prominent South Dakota Democrats include former presidential nominees George McGovern and Hubert Humphrey.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2016, South Dakota voted for Republican nominee Donald Trump over Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton by a margin of 30%.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2018, Republican congresswoman Kristi Noem defeated Democrat Billie Sutton in the gubernatorial election by a small margin, and Republican Dusty Johnson defeated Democrat Tim Bjorkman for the state's at-large seat in the US House of Representatives.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Contemporary political issues in South Dakota include the costs and benefits of the state lottery, South Dakota's relatively low rankings in education spending (particularly teacher pay—recently the State Sales Tax was increased from 4% to 4.5% to finance an increase in teacher pay), and recent legislative and electoral attempts to ban abortion in the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A Republican-supported bill passed in March 2019 requires that all public schools display "In God We Trust" in a prominent location.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota's culture reflects the state's American Indian, rural, Western, and European roots.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A number of annual events celebrating the state's ethnic and historical heritage take place around the state, such as Days of '76 in Deadwood, Czech Days in Tabor, and the annual St. Patrick's Day and Cinco de Mayo festivities in Sioux Falls.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The various tribes hold many annual pow wows at their reservations throughout the state, to which non-Native Americans are sometimes invited.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Custer State Park holds an annual Buffalo Roundup, in which volunteers on horseback gather the park's herd of around 1,500 bison.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Black Elk (Lakota) was a medicine man and heyokha, whose life spanned the transition to reservations.

name: south_dakota
sentence: His accounts of the 19th-century Indian Wars and Ghost Dance movement, and his deep thoughts on personal visions and Native American religion, form the basis of the book Black Elk Speaks, first published in 1932.

name: south_dakota
sentence: (Among several editions, a premier annotated edition was published in 2008.)

name: south_dakota
sentence: Paul Goble, an award-winning children's book author and illustrator, was based in the Black Hills from 1977.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Laura Ingalls Wilder, whose semi-autobiographical books are based on her experiences as a child and young adult on the frontier, is one of South Dakota's best-known writers.

name: south_dakota
sentence: She drew from her life growing up on a homestead near De Smet as the basis for five of her novels: By the Shores of Silver Lake, The Long Winter, Little Town on the Prairie, These Happy Golden Years, and The First Four Years.

name: south_dakota
sentence: These gained renewed popularity in the United States when Little House on the Prairie was adapted and produced as a television series in 1974.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Wilder's daughter, Rose Wilder Lane, who became a well-known writer in her own right, was born near De Smet in 1886.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has also produced several notable artists.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Harvey Dunn grew up on a homestead near Manchester in the late 19th century.

name: south_dakota
sentence: While Dunn worked most of his career as a commercial illustrator, his most famous works showed various scenes of frontier life; he completed these near the end of his career.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Oscar Howe (Crow) was born on the Crow Creek Indian Reservation and won fame for his watercolor paintings.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Howe was one of the first Native American painters to adopt techniques and style heavily influenced by the mid-20th century abstraction movement, rather than relying on traditional Native American styles.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Terry Redlin, originally from Watertown, was an accomplished painter of rural and wildlife scenes.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Many of his works are on display at the Redlin Art Center in Watertown.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Sioux Falls is the largest city in South Dakota, with a 2010 population of 153,888,and a metropolitan area population of 238,122.The city, founded in 1856, is in the southeast corner of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Retail, finance, and healthcare have assumed greater importance in Sioux Falls, where the economy was originally centered on agri-business and quarrying.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Rapid City, with a 2010 population of 67,956, and a metropolitan area population of 124,766, is the second-largest city in the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: It is on the eastern edge of the Black Hills, and was founded in 1876.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Rapid City's economy is largely based on tourism and defense spending, because of the proximity of many tourist attractions in the Black Hills and Ellsworth Air Force Base.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The next eight largest cities in the state, in order of descending 2010 population, are Aberdeen (26,091), Brookings (22,056), Watertown (21,482), Mitchell (15,254), Yankton (14,454), Pierre (13,646), Huron (12,592), and Vermillion (10,571).

name: south_dakota
sentence: Pierre is the state capital, and Brookings and Vermillion are the locations of the state's two largest universities (South Dakota State University and University of South Dakota, respectively).

name: south_dakota
sentence: With a population of about 14,000, Pierre is the second smallest state capital in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Of the ten largest cities in the state, only Rapid City is west of the Missouri River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota's first newspaper, the Dakota Democrat, began publishing in Yankton in 1858.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Today, the state's largest newspaper is the Sioux Falls Argus Leader, with a Sunday circulation of 63,701 and a weekday circulation of 44,334.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Rapid City Journal, with a Sunday circulation of 32,638 and a weekday circulation of 27,827, is South Dakota's second largest newspaper.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The next four largest newspapers in the state are the Aberdeen American News, the Watertown Public Opinion, the Huron Plainsman, and the Brookings Register.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1981, Tim Giago founded the Lakota Times as a newspaper for the local American Indian community on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The newspaper, now published in New York and known as Indian Country Today, is available in every state in the country.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Sioux City Journal also covers parts of South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: There are nine television stations broadcasting in South Dakota; South Dakota Public Television broadcasts from a number of locations around the state, while the other stations broadcast from Sioux Falls or Rapid City.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The two largest television media markets in South Dakota are Sioux Falls-Mitchell, with a viewership of 246,020, and Rapid City, with a viewership of 91,070.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The two markets rank as 114th and 177th largest in the United States, respectively.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The state's first television station, KELO-TV, began airing in Sioux Falls in 1953.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Among KELO's early programs was Captain 11, an afternoon children's program.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Captain 11 ran from 1955 until 1996, making it the nation's longest continuously running children's television program.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A number of South Dakotans are famous for their work in television and publishing.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Former NBC Nightly News anchor and author Tom Brokaw is from Webster and Yankton, USA Today founder Al Neuharth was from Eureka and Alpena, gameshow host Bob Barker spent much of his childhood in Mission, and entertainment news hosts Pat O'Brien and Mary Hart are from Sioux Falls.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As of 2006, South Dakota has a total primary and secondary school enrollment of 136,872, with 120,278 of these students being educated in the public school system.

name: south_dakota
sentence: There are 703 public schools in 168 school districts, giving South Dakota the highest number of schools per capita in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The current high school graduation rate is 89.9%, and the average ACT score is 21.8, slightly above the national average of 21.1.

name: south_dakota
sentence: 89.8% of the adult population has earned at least a high school diploma, and 25.8% has earned a bachelor's degree or higher.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota's 2008 average public school teacher salary of $36,674 was the lowest in the nation (national average was $52,308).

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2007 South Dakota passed legislation modeled after Montana's Indian Education for All Act (1999), mandating education about Native American tribal history, culture, and heritage in all the schools, from pre-school through college, in an effort to increase knowledge and appreciation about Indian culture among all residents of the state, as well as to reinforce Indian students' understanding of their own cultures' contributions.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The South Dakota Board of Regents, whose members are appointed by the governor, controls the six public universities in the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota State University (SDSU), in Brookings, is the state's largest university, with an enrollment of 12,831.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The University of South Dakota (USD), in Vermillion, is the state's oldest university, and has South Dakota's only law school and medical school.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota also has several private universities, the largest of which is Augustana University in Sioux Falls.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Because of its low population, South Dakota does not host any major league professional sports franchises.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The state has minor league and independent league teams, all of which play in Sioux Falls or Rapid City.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Sioux Falls is home to four teams: the Sioux Falls Canaries (baseball), the Sioux Falls Skyforce (basketball), the Sioux Falls Stampede (hockey), and the Sioux Falls Storm (indoor American football).

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Canaries play in the American Association, and their home field is Sioux Falls Stadium.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Skyforce play in the NBA G League, and are owned by the NBA's Miami Heat.

name: south_dakota
sentence: They play at the Sanford Pentagon.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Stampede and Storm share the Denny Sanford Premier Center.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Stampede play in the USHL, and the Storm play in the IFL.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Rapid City has a hockey team named the Rapid City Rush that plays in the ECHL.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Rush began their inaugural season in 2008 at the Rushmore Plaza Civic Center.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Universities in South Dakota host a variety of sports programs.

name: south_dakota
sentence: For many years, South Dakota was one of the only states in the country without an NCAA Division I football or basketball team.

name: south_dakota
sentence: However, several years ago SDSU decided to move their teams from Division II to Division I, a move followed by the University of South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other universities in the state compete at the NCAA's Division II or III levels, or in the NAIA.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Famous South Dakota athletes include Billy Mills, Mike Miller, Mark Ellis, Becky Hammon, Brock Lesnar, Chad Greenway, and Adam Vinatieri.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Mills is from the town of Pine Ridge and competed at the 1964 Summer Olympic Games in Tokyo, becoming the only American to win a gold medal in the 10,000-meter event.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Miller, of Mitchell, is a two-time NBA champion who played college basketball at the University of Florida, leading them to the 2000 NCAA Championship game his sophomore year, and won the 2001 NBA rookie of the year award.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Ellis, of Rapid City, played for the University of Florida and four MLB teams before retiring in 2015.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Hammon, of Rapid City, played for the WNBA's New York Liberty and San Antonio Silver Stars before becoming an assistant coach for the NBA's San Antonio Spurs in 2014.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Lesnar, of Webster, is a former heavy-weight champion in the UFC and WWE.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Vinatieri is an NFL placekicker who grew up in Rapid City and attended SDSU.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Fishing and hunting are popular outdoor activities in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Fishing contributes over $224 million to South Dakota's economy, and hunting contributes over $303 million.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2007, over 275,000 hunting licences and 175,000 fishing licences were sold in the state; around half of the hunting licences and over two-thirds of the fishing licences were purchased by South Dakotans.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Popular species of game include pheasants, white-tailed deer, mule deer, and turkeys, as well as waterfowl such as Canada geese, snow geese, and mallards.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Targets of anglers include walleye in the eastern glacial lakes and Missouri River reservoirs, Chinook salmon in Lake Oahe, and trout in the Black Hills.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other sports, such as cycling and running, are also popular in the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1991, the state opened the George S. Mickelson Trail, a 109-mile (175 km) rail trail in the Black Hills.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Besides being used by cyclists, the trail is also the site of a portion of the annual Mount Rushmore marathon; the marathon's entire course is at an elevation of over 4,000 feet (1,200 m).

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other events in the state include the Tour de Kota, a 478-mile (769 km), six-day cycling event that covers much of eastern and central South Dakota, and the annual Sturgis Motorcycle Rally, which draws hundreds of thousands of participants from around the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Some of South Dakota's official state symbols include:

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee ( (listen), locally ), officially the State of Tennessee, is a state in the southeastern United States.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee is the 36th largest by area and the 16th most populous of the 50 states.

name: tennessee
sentence: It is bordered by eight states, with Kentucky to the north, Virginia to the northeast, North Carolina to the east, Georgia, Alabama, and Mississippi to the south, Arkansas to the west, and Missouri to the northwest.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Appalachian Mountains dominate the eastern part of the state, and the Mississippi River forms its western border.

name: tennessee
sentence: Nashville is the state's capital and largest city, with a 2019 population of 670,820 and a 2019 metro population of 1,934,317.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee's second largest city is Memphis, which had a population of 651,073 and metro population of 1,346,045 in 2019.

name: tennessee
sentence: The state of Tennessee is rooted in the Watauga Association, a 1772 frontier pact generally regarded as the first constitutional government west of the Appalachians.

name: tennessee
sentence: What is now Tennessee was initially part of North Carolina, and later part of the Southwest Territory.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee was admitted to the Union as the 16th state on June 1, 1796.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee was the last state to leave the Union and join the Confederacy at the outbreak of the American Civil War in 1861.

name: tennessee
sentence: Occupied by Union forces from 1862, it was the first state to be readmitted to the Union at the end of the war.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee furnished more soldiers for the Confederate Army than any other state besides Virginia, and more soldiers for the Union Army than the rest of the Confederacy combined.

name: tennessee
sentence: Beginning during Reconstruction, it had competitive party politics, but a Democratic takeover in the late 1880s resulted in passage of disenfranchisement laws that excluded most blacks and many poor whites from voting.

name: tennessee
sentence: This reduced competition in politics in the state until after passage of civil rights legislation in the mid-20th century, although unlike in the Deep South, Tennessee Republicans always expected at least a third of the vote in statewide elections via East Tennessee and Highland Rim Unionists.

name: tennessee
sentence: In the 20th century, Tennessee transitioned from an agrarian economy to a more diversified economy, aided by massive federal investment in the Tennessee Valley Authority and, in the early 1940s, the city of Oak Ridge.

name: tennessee
sentence: This city was established just outside of Knoxville to house the Manhattan Project's uranium enrichment facilities, helping to build the world's first atomic bombs, two of which were dropped on Imperial Japan near the end of World War II.

name: tennessee
sentence: After the war, the Oak Ridge National Laboratory became and remains a key center for scientific research.

name: tennessee
sentence: In 2016, the element tennessine was named for the state, largely in recognition of the roles played by Oak Ridge, Vanderbilt University, and the University of Tennessee in the element’s discovery.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee's major industries include agriculture, manufacturing, and tourism.

name: tennessee
sentence: Poultry, soybeans, and cattle are the state's primary agricultural products, and major manufacturing exports include chemicals, transportation equipment, and electrical equipment.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Great Smoky Mountains National Park, the nation's most visited national park, is located in the eastern part of the state, and a section of the Appalachian Trail roughly follows the Tennessee–North Carolina border.

name: tennessee
sentence: Other major tourist attractions include the Tennessee Aquarium and Chattanooga Choo-Choo Hotel in Chattanooga; Dollywood in Pigeon Forge; Ripley's Aquarium of the Smokies and Ober Gatlinburg in Gatlinburg; the Parthenon, the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, and Ryman Auditorium in Nashville; the Jack Daniel's Distillery in Lynchburg; Elvis Presley's Graceland residence and tomb, the Memphis Zoo, the National Civil Rights Museum in Memphis; and Bristol Motor Speedway in Bristol.

name: tennessee
sentence: The earliest variant of the name that became Tennessee was recorded by Captain Juan Pardo, the Spanish explorer, when he and his men passed through an American Indian village named "Tanasqui" in 1567 while traveling inland from South Carolina.

name: tennessee
sentence: In the early 18th century, British traders encountered a Cherokee town named Tanasi (or "Tanase", in syllabary: ᏔᎾᏏ) in present-day Monroe County, Tennessee.

name: tennessee
sentence: The town was located on a river of the same name (now known as the Little Tennessee River), and appears on maps as early as 1725.

name: tennessee
sentence: It is not known whether this was the same town as the one encountered by Juan Pardo, although recent research suggests that Pardo's "Tanasqui" was located at the confluence of the Pigeon River and the French Broad River, near modern Newport.

name: tennessee
sentence: The meaning and origin of the word are uncertain.

name: tennessee
sentence: Some accounts suggest it is a Cherokee modification of an earlier Yuchi word.

name: tennessee
sentence: It has been said to mean "meeting place", "winding river", or "river of the great bend".

name: tennessee
sentence: According to ethnographer James Mooney, the name "can not be analyzed" and its meaning is lost.

name: tennessee
sentence: The modern spelling, Tennessee, is attributed to James Glen, the governor of South Carolina, who used this spelling in his official correspondence during the 1750s.

name: tennessee
sentence: The spelling was popularized by the publication of Henry Timberlake's "Draught of the Cherokee Country" in 1765.

name: tennessee
sentence: In 1788, North Carolina created "Tennessee County", the third county to be established in what is now Middle Tennessee.

name: tennessee
sentence: (Tennessee County was the predecessor to present-day Montgomery and Robertson counties.)

name: tennessee
sentence: When a constitutional convention met in 1796 to organize a new state out of the Southwest Territory, it adopted "Tennessee" as the name of the state.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee is known as The Volunteer State, a nickname some claimed was earned during the War of 1812 because of the prominent role played by volunteer soldiers from Tennessee, especially during the Battle of New Orleans.

name: tennessee
sentence: Other sources differ on the origin of the state nickname; according to The Columbia Encyclopedia, the name refers to volunteers for the Mexican–American War from 1846 to 1848.

name: tennessee
sentence: This explanation is more likely, because President Polk's call for 2,600 nationwide volunteers at the beginning of the Mexican–American War resulted in 30,000 volunteers from Tennessee alone, largely in response to the death of Davy Crockett and appeals by former Tennessee Governor and then Texas politician, Sam Houston.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee borders eight other states: Kentucky and Virginia to the north; North Carolina to the east; Georgia, Alabama, and Mississippi on the south; Arkansas and Missouri on the Mississippi River to the west.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee is tied with Missouri as the state bordering the most other states.

name: tennessee
sentence: The state is trisected by the Tennessee River.

name: tennessee
sentence: The highest point in the state is Clingmans Dome at 6,643 feet (2,025 m).

name: tennessee
sentence: Clingmans Dome, which lies on Tennessee's eastern border, is the highest point on the Appalachian Trail, and is the third highest peak in the United States east of the Mississippi River.

name: tennessee
sentence: The state line between Tennessee and North Carolina crosses the summit.

name: tennessee
sentence: The state's lowest point is the Mississippi River at the Mississippi state line: 178 feet (54 m).

name: tennessee
sentence: The geographical center of the state is located in Murfreesboro.

name: tennessee
sentence: The state of Tennessee is geographically, culturally, economically, and legally divided into three Grand Divisions: East Tennessee, Middle Tennessee, and West Tennessee.

name: tennessee
sentence: The state constitution allows no more than two justices of the five-member Tennessee Supreme Court to be from one Grand Division and a similar rule applies to certain commissions and boards.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee features six principal physiographic regions: the Blue Ridge, the Appalachian Ridge and Valley Region, the Cumberland Plateau, the Highland Rim, the Nashville Basin, and the Gulf Coastal Plain.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee is home to the most caves in the United States, with more than ten thousand documented.

name: tennessee
sentence: About half the state is in the Tennessee Valley drainage basin of the Tennessee River.

name: tennessee
sentence: Approximately the northern half of Middle Tennessee, including Nashville and Clarksville, and a small portion of East Tennessee is in the Cumberland River basin.

name: tennessee
sentence: A small part of north-central Tennessee in Sumner, Macon, and Clay counties is in the Green River watershed.

name: tennessee
sentence: All three of these basins are tributaries of the Ohio River watershed.

name: tennessee
sentence: Most of West Tennessee is in the Lower Mississippi River watershed.

name: tennessee
sentence: The entirety of the state is in the Mississippi River watershed, except for a small area in Bradley and Polk counties traversed by the Conasauga River, which is part of the Mobile Bay watershed.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Blue Ridge area lies on the eastern edge of Tennessee, which borders North Carolina.

name: tennessee
sentence: This region of Tennessee is characterized by the high mountains and rugged terrain of the western Blue Ridge Mountains, which are subdivided into several subranges, namely the Great Smoky Mountains, the Bald Mountains, the Unicoi Mountains, the Unaka Mountains and Roan Highlands, and the Iron Mountains.

name: tennessee
sentence: The average elevation of the Blue Ridge area is 5,000 feet (1,500 m) above sea level.

name: tennessee
sentence: Clingmans Dome, the state's highest point, is located in this region.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Blue Ridge area was never more than sparsely populated, and today much of it is protected by the Cherokee National Forest, the Great Smoky Mountains National Park, and several federal wilderness areas and state parks.

name: tennessee
sentence: Stretching west from the Blue Ridge for approximately 55 miles (89 km) is the Ridge and Valley region, in which numerous tributaries join to form the Tennessee River in the Tennessee Valley.

name: tennessee
sentence: This area of Tennessee is covered by fertile valleys separated by wooded ridges, such as Bays Mountain and Clinch Mountain.

name: tennessee
sentence: The western section of the Tennessee Valley, where the depressions become broader and the ridges become lower, is called the Great Valley.

name: tennessee
sentence: In this valley are numerous towns and two of the region's three urban areas, Knoxville, the third largest city in the state, and Chattanooga, the fourth largest city in the state.

name: tennessee
sentence: The third urban area, the Tri-Cities, comprising Bristol, Johnson City, and Kingsport and their environs, is located to the northeast of Knoxville.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Cumberland Plateau rises to the west of the Tennessee Valley

name: tennessee
sentence: The elevation of the Cumberland Plateau ranges from 1,500 to about 2,000 feet (460 to about 610 m) above sea level.

name: tennessee
sentence: East Tennessee has several important transportation links with Middle and West Tennessee, as well as the rest of the nation and the world, including several major airports and interstates.

name: tennessee
sentence: Knoxville's McGhee Tyson Airport (TYS) and Chattanooga's Chattanooga Metropolitan Airport (CHA), as well as the Tri-Cities' Tri-Cities Regional Airport (TRI), provide air service to numerous destinations.

name: tennessee
sentence: I-24, I-81, I-40, I-75, and I-26 along with numerous state highways and other important roads, traverse the Grand Division and connect Chattanooga, Knoxville, and the Tri-Cities, along with other cities and towns such as Cleveland, Athens, and Sevierville.

name: tennessee
sentence: West of the Cumberland Plateau is the Highland Rim, an elevated plain that surrounds the Nashville Basin.

name: tennessee
sentence: The northern section of the Highland Rim, known for its high tobacco production, is sometimes called the Pennyroyal Plateau; it is located primarily in Southwestern Kentucky.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Nashville Basin is characterized by rich, fertile farm country and great diversity of natural wildlife.

name: tennessee
sentence: Middle Tennessee was a common destination of settlers crossing the Appalachians from Virginia in the late 18th century and early 19th century.

name: tennessee
sentence: An important trading route called the Natchez Trace, created and used for many generations by American Indians, connected Middle Tennessee to the lower Mississippi River town of Natchez.

name: tennessee
sentence: The route of the Natchez Trace was used as the basis for a scenic highway called the Natchez Trace Parkway.

name: tennessee
sentence: Some of the last remaining large American chestnut trees grow in this region.

name: tennessee
sentence: They are being used to help breed blight-resistant trees.

name: tennessee
sentence: Middle Tennessee is one of the primary state population and transportation centers along with the heart of state government.

name: tennessee
sentence: Nashville (the capital), Clarksville, and Murfreesboro are its largest cities.

name: tennessee
sentence: Interstates 24, 40, 65, and 840 service the Division, with the first three meeting in Nashville.

name: tennessee
sentence: West of the Highland Rim and Nashville Basin is the Gulf Coastal Plain, which includes the Mississippi embayment.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Gulf Coastal Plain is, in terms of area, the predominant land region in Tennessee.

name: tennessee
sentence: It is part of the large geographic land area that begins at the Gulf of Mexico and extends north into southern Illinois.

name: tennessee
sentence: In Tennessee, the Gulf Coastal Plain is divided into three sections that extend from the Tennessee River in the east to the Mississippi River in the west.

name: tennessee
sentence: The easternmost section, about 10 miles (16 km) in width, consists of hilly land that runs along the western bank of the Tennessee River.

name: tennessee
sentence: To the west of this narrow strip of land is a wide area of rolling hills and streams that stretches all the way to the Mississippi River

name: tennessee
sentence: In Memphis, the Tennessee Bottoms end in steep bluffs overlooking the river.

name: tennessee
sentence: To the west of the Tennessee Bottoms is the Mississippi Alluvial Plain, less than 300 feet (91 m) above sea level.

name: tennessee
sentence: This area of lowlands, flood plains, and swamp land is sometimes referred to as the Delta region.

name: tennessee
sentence: Memphis is the economic center of West Tennessee.

name: tennessee
sentence: Most of West Tennessee remained Indian land until the Chickasaw Cession of 1818, when the Chickasaw ceded their land between the Tennessee River and the Mississippi River.

name: tennessee
sentence: The portion of the Chickasaw Cession that lies in Kentucky is known today as the Jackson Purchase.

name: tennessee
sentence: Areas under the control and management of the National Park Service include the following:

name: tennessee
sentence: Fifty-four state parks, covering some 132,000 acres (530 km2) as well as parts of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park and Cherokee National Forest, and Cumberland Gap National Historical Park are in Tennessee.

name: tennessee
sentence: Sportsmen and visitors are attracted to Reelfoot Lake, originally formed by the 1811–12 New Madrid earthquakes; stumps and other remains of a once dense forest, together with the lotus bed covering the shallow waters, give the lake an eerie beauty.

name: tennessee
sentence: Most of the state has a humid subtropical climate, with the exception of some of the higher elevations in the Appalachians, which are classified as having a mountain temperate or humid continental climate due to cooler temperatures.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Gulf of Mexico is the dominant factor in the climate of Tennessee, with winds from the south being responsible for most of the state's annual precipitation.

name: tennessee
sentence: Generally, the state has hot summers and mild to cool winters with generous precipitation throughout the year, with highest average monthly precipitation generally in the winter and spring months, between December and April.

name: tennessee
sentence: The driest months, on average, are August to October.

name: tennessee
sentence: On average the state receives 50 inches (130 cm) of precipitation annually.

name: tennessee
sentence: Snowfall ranges from 5 inches (13 cm) in West Tennessee to over 80 inches (200 cm) in the highest mountains in East Tennessee.

name: tennessee
sentence: Summers in the state are generally hot and humid, with most of the state averaging a high of around 90 °F (32 °C) during the summer months.

name: tennessee
sentence: Winters tend to be mild to cool, increasing in coolness at higher elevations.

name: tennessee
sentence: Generally, for areas outside the highest mountains, the average overnight lows are near freezing for most of the state.

name: tennessee
sentence: The highest recorded temperature is 113 °F (45 °C) at Perryville on August 9, 1930, while the lowest recorded temperature is −32 °F (−36 °C) at Mountain City on December 30, 1917.

name: tennessee
sentence: While the state is far enough from the coast to avoid any direct impact from a hurricane, the location of the state makes it likely to be impacted from the remnants of tropical cyclones which weaken over land and can cause significant rainfall, such as Tropical Storm Chris in 1982 and Hurricane Opal in 1995.

name: tennessee
sentence: The state averages about fifty days of thunderstorms per year, some of which can be severe with large hail and damaging winds.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tornadoes are possible throughout the state, with West and Middle Tennessee the most vulnerable.

name: tennessee
sentence: Occasionally, strong or violent tornadoes occur, such as the devastating April 2011 tornadoes that killed twenty people in North Georgia and Southeast Tennessee.

name: tennessee
sentence: On average, the state has 15 tornadoes per year.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tornadoes in Tennessee can be severe, and Tennessee leads the nation in the percentage of total tornadoes which have fatalities.

name: tennessee
sentence: Winter storms are an occasional problem, such as the infamous Blizzard of 1993, although ice storms are a more likely occurrence.

name: tennessee
sentence: Fog is a persistent problem in parts of the state, especially in East Tennessee.

name: tennessee
sentence: The capital and largest city is Nashville, though Knoxville, Kingston, and Murfreesboro have all served as state capitals in the past.

name: tennessee
sentence: Nashville's 13-county metropolitan area has been the state's largest since c. 1990.

name: tennessee
sentence: Memphis was the largest city in the state until 2018 when it was surpassed by Nashville.

name: tennessee
sentence: Chattanooga and Knoxville, both in the east near the Great Smoky Mountains, are about a third that size.

name: tennessee
sentence: The city of Clarksville is a fifth significant population center, 45 miles (72 km) northwest of Nashville.

name: tennessee
sentence: Murfreesboro is the sixth-largest city in Tennessee, consisting of 146,900 residents.

name: tennessee
sentence: The area now known as Tennessee was first inhabited by Paleo-Indians nearly 12,000 years ago.

name: tennessee
sentence: The names of the cultural groups who inhabited the area between first settlement and the time of European contact are unknown, but several distinct cultural phases have been named by archaeologists, including Archaic (8000–1000 BC), Woodland (1000 BC – 1000 AD), and Mississippian (1000–1600 AD), whose chiefdoms were the cultural predecessors of the Muscogee people who inhabited the Tennessee River Valley before Cherokee migration into the river's headwaters.

name: tennessee
sentence: The first recorded European excursions into what is now called Tennessee were three expeditions led by Spanish explorers, namely Hernando de Soto in 1540, Tristan de Luna in 1559, and Juan Pardo in 1567.

name: tennessee
sentence: Pardo recorded the name "Tanasqui" from a local Indian village, which evolved to the state's current name.

name: tennessee
sentence: At that time, Tennessee was inhabited by tribes of Muscogee and Yuchi people.

name: tennessee
sentence: Possibly because of European diseases devastating the Indian tribes, which would have left a population vacuum, and also from expanding European settlement in the north, the Cherokee moved south from the area now called Virginia.

name: tennessee
sentence: As European colonists spread into the area, the Indian populations were forcibly displaced to the south and west, including all Muscogee and Yuchi peoples, the Chickasaw and Choctaw, and ultimately, the Cherokee in 1838.

name: tennessee
sentence: The first British settlement in what is now Tennessee was built in 1756 by settlers from the colony of South Carolina at Fort Loudoun, near present-day Vonore.

name: tennessee
sentence: Fort Loudoun became the westernmost British outpost to that date.

name: tennessee
sentence: The fort was designed by John William Gerard de Brahm and constructed by forces under British Captain Raymond Demeré.

name: tennessee
sentence: After its completion, Captain Raymond Demeré relinquished command on August 14, 1757, to his brother, Captain Paul Demeré.

name: tennessee
sentence: Hostilities erupted between the British and the neighboring Overhill Cherokees, and a siege of Fort Loudoun ended with its surrender on August 7, 1760.

name: tennessee
sentence: The following morning, Captain Paul Demeré and a number of his men were killed in an ambush nearby, and most of the rest of the garrison was taken prisoner.

name: tennessee
sentence: In the 1760s, long hunters from Virginia explored much of East and Middle Tennessee, and the first permanent European settlers began arriving late in the decade.

name: tennessee
sentence: The majority of 18th century settlers were English or of primarily English descent but nearly 20% of them were also Scotch-Irish.

name: tennessee
sentence: These settlers formed the Watauga Association, a community built on lands leased from the Cherokee peoples.

name: tennessee
sentence: During the American Revolutionary War, Fort Watauga at Sycamore Shoals (in present-day Elizabethton) was attacked (1776) by Dragging Canoe and his warring faction of Cherokee who were aligned with the British Loyalists.

name: tennessee
sentence: These renegade Cherokee were referred to by settlers as the Chickamauga.

name: tennessee
sentence: They opposed North Carolina's annexation of the Washington District and the concurrent settling of the Transylvania Colony further north and west.

name: tennessee
sentence: The lives of many settlers were spared from the initial warrior attacks through the warnings of Dragging Canoe's cousin, Nancy Ward.

name: tennessee
sentence: The frontier fort on the banks of the Watauga River later served as a 1780 staging area for the Overmountain Men in preparation to trek over the Appalachian Mountains, to engage, and to later defeat the British Army at the Battle of Kings Mountain in South Carolina.

name: tennessee
sentence: Three counties of the Washington District (now part of Tennessee) broke off from North Carolina in 1784 and formed the State of Franklin.

name: tennessee
sentence: Efforts to obtain admission to the Union failed, and the counties (now numbering eight) had re-joined North Carolina by 1789.

name: tennessee
sentence: North Carolina ceded the area to the federal government in 1790, after which it was organized into the Southwest Territory.

name: tennessee
sentence: In an effort to encourage settlers to move west into the new territory, in 1787 the mother state of North Carolina ordered a road to be cut to take settlers into the Cumberland Settlements—from the south end of Clinch Mountain (in East Tennessee) to French Lick (Nashville).

name: tennessee
sentence: The Trace was called the "North Carolina Road" or "Avery's Trace", and sometimes "The Wilderness Road" (although it should not be confused with Daniel Boone's "Wilderness Road" through the Cumberland Gap).

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee was admitted to the Union on June 1, 1796 as the 16th state.

name: tennessee
sentence: It was the first state created from territory under the jurisdiction of the United States federal government.

name: tennessee
sentence: Apart from the former Thirteen Colonies only Vermont and Kentucky predate Tennessee's statehood, and neither was ever a federal territory.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Constitution of the State of Tennessee, Article I, Section 31, states that the beginning point for identifying the boundary is the extreme height of the Stone Mountain, at the place where the line of Virginia intersects it, and basically runs the extreme heights of mountain chains through the Appalachian Mountains separating North Carolina from Tennessee past the Native American towns of Cowee and Old Chota, thence along the main ridge of the said mountain (Unicoi Mountain) to the southern boundary of the state; all the territory, lands and waters lying west of said line are included in the boundaries and limits of the newly formed state of Tennessee.

name: tennessee
sentence: Part of the provision also stated that the limits and jurisdiction of the state would include future land acquisition, referencing possible land trade with other states, or the acquisition of territory from west of the Mississippi River.

name: tennessee
sentence: As more white settlers moved into Tennessee, they came into increasing conflict with Native American tribes.

name: tennessee
sentence: During the administration of US President Martin Van Buren, nearly 17,000 Cherokees and about 2,000 Black people enslaved by the Cherokees were uprooted from their homes between 1838 and 1839.

name: tennessee
sentence: US troops forced them to march from "emigration depots" in Eastern Tennessee, such as Fort Cass, toward the more distant Indian Territory west of Arkansas, now the state of Oklahoma.

name: tennessee
sentence: During this relocation an estimated 4,000 Cherokees died along the way west.

name: tennessee
sentence: In the Cherokee language, the event is called Nunna daul Isunyi,"the Trail Where We Cried".

name: tennessee
sentence: The Cherokees were not the only Native Americans forced to emigrate as a result of the Indian removal efforts of the United States, and so the phrase "Trail of Tears" is sometimes used to refer to similar events endured by other American Indian peoples, especially among the "Five Civilized Tribes".

name: tennessee
sentence: The phrase originated as a description of the earlier emigration of the Choctaw nation.

name: tennessee
sentence: In February 1861, secessionists in Tennessee's state government—led by Governor Isham Harris—sought voter approval for a convention to sever ties with the United States, but Tennessee voters rejected the referendum by a 54–46% margin.

name: tennessee
sentence: The strongest opposition to secession came from East Tennessee, which later tried to form a separate Union-aligned state.

name: tennessee
sentence: Following the Confederate attack upon Fort Sumter in April and Lincoln's call for troops from Tennessee and other states in response, Governor Isham Harris began military mobilization, submitted an ordinance of secession to the General Assembly, and made direct overtures to the Confederate government.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Tennessee legislature ratified an agreement to enter a military league with the Confederate States on May 7, 1861.

name: tennessee
sentence: On June 8, 1861, with people in Middle Tennessee having significantly changed their position, voters approved a second referendum calling for secession, becoming the last state to do so.

name: tennessee
sentence: But the Union-backing State of Scott was also established at this time, and remained a de facto enclave of the United States throughout the war.

name: tennessee
sentence: Many major battles of the American Civil War were fought in Tennessee—most of them Union victories.

name: tennessee
sentence: Ulysses S. Grant and the US Navy captured control of the Cumberland and Tennessee rivers in February 1862.

name: tennessee
sentence: They held off the Confederate counterattack at Shiloh in April.

name: tennessee
sentence: Memphis fell to the Union in June, following a naval battle on the Mississippi River in front of the city.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Capture of Memphis and Nashville gave the Union control of the western and middle sections.

name: tennessee
sentence: This control was confirmed at the Battle of Murfreesboro in early January 1863 and by the subsequent Tullahoma Campaign.

name: tennessee
sentence: Despite the strength of Unionist sentiment in East Tennessee (with the exception of Sullivan County, which was heavily pro-Confederate), Confederates held the area.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Confederates, led by General James Longstreet, did attack General Burnside's Fort Sanders at Knoxville and lost.

name: tennessee
sentence: It was a big blow to East Tennessee Confederate momentum, but Longstreet won the Battle of Bean's Station a few weeks later.

name: tennessee
sentence: The Confederates besieged Chattanooga during the Chattanooga Campaign in early fall 1863, but were driven off by Grant in November.

name: tennessee
sentence: Many of the Confederate defeats can be attributed to the poor strategic vision of General Braxton Bragg, who led the Army of Tennessee from Perryville, Kentucky, to another Confederate defeat at Chattanooga.

name: tennessee
sentence: The last major battles came when the Confederates invaded Middle Tennessee in November 1864 and were checked at Franklin, then completely dispersed by George Thomas at Nashville in December.

name: tennessee
sentence: Meanwhile, President Abraham Lincoln appointed displaced senator and native Tennessean Andrew Johnson military governor of the state.

name: tennessee
sentence: When the Emancipation Proclamation was announced, Tennessee was largely held by Union forces.

name: tennessee
sentence: Thus it was not among the states enumerated in the Proclamation, and the Proclamation did not free any slaves there.

name: tennessee
sentence: Nonetheless, enslaved African Americans escaped to Union lines to gain freedom without waiting for official action.

name: tennessee
sentence: Old and young, men, women, and children camped near Union troops.

name: tennessee
sentence: Thousands of former slaves ended up fighting on the Union side, nearly 200,000 in total across the South.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee's legislature approved an amendment to the state constitution prohibiting slavery on February 22, 1865.

name: tennessee
sentence: Voters in the state approved the amendment in March.

name: tennessee
sentence: It also ratified the Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution (abolishing slavery in every state) on April 7, 1865.

name: tennessee
sentence: In 1864, Andrew Johnson, a War Democrat from Tennessee, was elected Vice President under Abraham Lincoln.

name: tennessee
sentence: He became President after Lincoln's assassination in 1865.

name: tennessee
sentence: Under Johnson's lenient re-admission policy, Tennessee was the first of the seceding states to have its elected members readmitted to the US Congress, on July 24, 1866.

name: tennessee
sentence: Because Tennessee had ratified the Fourteenth Amendment, it was the only one of the formerly secessionist states that did not have a military governor during the Reconstruction period.

name: tennessee
sentence: After the formal end of Reconstruction, the struggle over power in Southern society continued.

name: tennessee
sentence: Through violence and intimidation against freedmen and their allies, White Democrats regained political power in Tennessee and other states across the South in the late 1870s and 1880s.

name: tennessee
sentence: Over the next decade, the state legislature passed increasingly restrictive laws to control African Americans.

name: tennessee
sentence: In 1889 the General Assembly passed four laws described as electoral reform, with the cumulative effect of essentially disfranchising most African Americans in rural areas and small towns, as well as many poor Whites.

name: tennessee
sentence: Legislation included implementation of a poll tax, timing of registration, and recording requirements.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tens of thousands of taxpaying citizens were without representation for decades into the 20th century.

name: tennessee
sentence: Disfranchising legislation accompanied Jim Crow laws passed in the late 19th century, which imposed segregation in the state.

name: tennessee
sentence: In 1900, African Americans made up nearly 24% of the state's population, and numbered 480,430 citizens who lived mostly in the central and western parts of the state.

name: tennessee
sentence: In 1897, Tennessee celebrated its centennial of statehood (though one year late of the 1896 anniversary) with a great exposition in Nashville.

name: tennessee
sentence: A full-scale replica of the Parthenon was constructed for the celebration, located in what is now Nashville's Centennial Park.

name: tennessee
sentence: On August 18, 1920, Tennessee became the thirty-sixth and final state necessary to ratify the Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, which provided women the right to vote.

name: tennessee
sentence: Disenfranchising voter registration requirements continued to keep most African Americans and many poor whites, both men and women, off the voter rolls.

name: tennessee
sentence: The need to create work for the unemployed during the Great Depression, a desire for rural electrification, the need to control annual spring flooding and improve shipping capacity on the Tennessee River were all factors that drove the federal creation of the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) in 1933.

name: tennessee
sentence: Through the power of the TVA projects, Tennessee quickly became the nation's largest public utility supplier.

name: tennessee
sentence: During World War II, the availability of abundant TVA electrical power led the Manhattan Project to locate one of the principal sites for production and isolation of weapons-grade fissile material in East Tennessee.

name: tennessee
sentence: The planned community of Oak Ridge was built from scratch to provide accommodations for the facilities and workers.

name: tennessee
sentence: These sites are now Oak Ridge National Laboratory, the Y-12 National Security Complex, and the East Tennessee Technology Park.

name: tennessee
sentence: Despite recognized effects of limiting voting by poor whites, successive legislatures expanded the reach of the disfranchising laws until they covered the state.

name: tennessee
sentence: Political scientist V. O.

name: tennessee
sentence: Key, Jr. argued in 1949:

name: tennessee
sentence: In 1953 state legislators amended the state constitution, removing the poll tax.

name: tennessee
sentence: In many areas both blacks and poor whites still faced subjectively applied barriers to voter registration that did not end until after passage of national civil rights legislation, including the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee celebrated its bicentennial in 1996.

name: tennessee
sentence: With a yearlong statewide celebration entitled "Tennessee 200", it opened a new state park (Bicentennial Mall) at the foot of Capitol Hill in Nashville.

name: tennessee
sentence: The state has had major disasters, such as the Great Train Wreck of 1918, one of the worst train accidents in US history, and the Sultana explosion on the Mississippi River near Memphis, the deadliest maritime disaster in US history.

name: tennessee
sentence: In 2002, businessman Phil Bredesen was elected to become the 48th governor in January 2003.

name: tennessee
sentence: Also in 2002, Tennessee amended the state constitution to allow for the establishment of a lottery.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee's Bob Corker was the only freshman Republican elected to the United States Senatorte in the 2006 midterm elections.

name: tennessee
sentence: The state constitution was amended to reject same-sex marriage.

name: tennessee
sentence: In January 2007, Ron Ramsey became the first Republican elected as Speaker of the State Senatorte since Reconstruction, as a result of the realignment of the Democratic and Republican parties in the South since the late 20th century, with Republicans now elected by conservative voters, who previously had supported Democrats.

name: tennessee
sentence: In 2010, during the 2010 midterm elections, Bill Haslam was elected to succeed Bredesen, who was term-limited, to become the 49th Governor of Tennessee in January 2011.

name: tennessee
sentence: In April and May 2010, flooding in Middle Tennessee devastated Nashville and other parts of Middle Tennessee.

name: tennessee
sentence: In 2011, parts of East Tennessee, including Hamilton and Bradley counties, were devastated by the April 2011 tornado outbreak.

name: tennessee
sentence: In 2018, Republican businessman Bill Lee was elected to succeed term-limited Haslam, and he became the 50th Governor of Tennessee.

name: tennessee
sentence: The United States Census Bureau estimates that the population of Tennessee was 6,829,174 on July 1, 2019, an increase of 483,069 people since the 2010 United States Census, or 7.61%.

name: tennessee
sentence: This includes a natural increase since the last census of 124,385 (584,236 births minus 459,851 deaths), and an increase from net migration of 244,537 people into the state.

name: tennessee
sentence: Immigration from outside the United States resulted in a net increase of 66,412, and migration within the country produced a net increase of 178,125.

name: tennessee
sentence: Twenty percent of Tennesseans were born outside the South in 2008, compared to a figure of 13.5% in 1990.

name: tennessee
sentence: In recent years, Tennessee has received an influx of people relocating from California, Florida, New York, New Jersey and the New England States for the low cost of living, and the booming healthcare and automobile industries.

name: tennessee
sentence: Metropolitan Nashville is one of the fastest-growing areas in the country due in part to these factors.

name: tennessee
sentence: The center of population of Tennessee is located in Rutherford County, in the city of Murfreesboro.

name: tennessee
sentence: In 2010, 4.6% of the total population was of Hispanic or Latino origin (they may be of any race), up from 2.2% in 2000.

name: tennessee
sentence: Between 2000 and 2010, the Hispanic population in Tennessee grew by 134.2%, the third highest of any state.

name: tennessee
sentence: That same year Non-Hispanic whites were 75.6% of the population, compared to 63.7% of the population nationwide.

name: tennessee
sentence: In 2010, approximately 4.4% of Tennessee's population was foreign-born, an increase of about 118.5% since 2000.

name: tennessee
sentence: Of the foreign-born population, approximately 31.0% were naturalized citizens and 69.0% non-citizens.

name: tennessee
sentence: The foreign-born population was approximately 49.9% from Latin America, 27.1% from Asia, 11.9% from Europe, 7.7% from Africa, 2.7% from Northern America, and 0.6% from Oceania.

name: tennessee
sentence: In 2010, the five most common self-reported ethnic groups in the state were: American (26.5%), English (8.2%), Irish (6.6%), German (5.5%), and Scotch-Irish (2.7%).

name: tennessee
sentence: Most Tennesseans who self-identify as having American ancestry are of English and Scotch-Irish ancestry.

name: tennessee
sentence: An estimated 21–24% of Tennesseans are of predominantly English ancestry.

name: tennessee
sentence: In the 1980 census 1,435,147 Tennesseans claimed "English" or "mostly English" ancestry out of a state population of 3,221,354 making them 45% of the state at the time.

name: tennessee
sentence: According to the 2010 census, 6.4% of Tennessee's population were reported as under age 5, 23.6% under 18, and 13.4% were 65 or older.

name: tennessee
sentence: On June 19, 2010, the Tennessee Commission of Indian Affairs granted state recognition to six Native American tribes, which was later repealed by the state's Attorney General because the action by the commission was illegal.

name: tennessee
sentence: The tribes were as follows:

name: tennessee
sentence: As of 2011, 36.3% of Tennessee's population younger than age 1 were minorities.

name: tennessee
sentence: Note: Births in table do not add up, because Hispanics are counted both by their ethnicity and by their race, giving a higher overall number.

name: tennessee
sentence: The religious affiliations of the people of Tennessee as of 2014:

name: tennessee
sentence: The largest denominations by number of adherents in 2010 were the Southern Baptist Convention with 1,483,356; the United Methodist Church with 375,693; the Roman Catholic Church with 222,343; and the Churches of Christ with 214,118.

name: tennessee
sentence: As of January 1, 2009, The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS Church) reported 43,179 members, 10 stakes, 92 Congregations (68 wards and 24 branches), two missions, and two temples in Tennessee.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee is home to several Protestant denominations, such as the National Baptist Convention (headquartered in Nashville); the Church of God in Christ and the Cumberland Presbyterian Church (both headquartered in Memphis); the Church of God and The Church of God of Prophecy (both headquartered in Cleveland).

name: tennessee
sentence: The Free Will Baptist denomination is headquartered in Antioch

name: tennessee
sentence: The Southern Baptist Convention maintains its general headquarters in Nashville.

name: tennessee
sentence: Publishing houses of several denominations are located in Nashville.

name: tennessee
sentence: According to the US Bureau of Economic Analysis, in 2011 Tennessee's real gross state product was $233.997 billion.In 2003, the per capita personal income was $28,641, 36th in the nation, and 91% of the national per capita personal income of $31,472.

name: tennessee
sentence: In 2004, the median household income was $38,550, 41st in the nation, and 87% of the national median of $44,472.

name: tennessee
sentence: For 2012, the state held an asset surplus of $533 million, one of only eight states in the nation to report a surplus.

name: tennessee
sentence: Major outputs for the state include textiles, cotton, cattle, and electrical power.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee has more than 82,000 farms, roughly 59 percent of which accommodate beef cattle.

name: tennessee
sentence: Although cotton was an early crop in Tennessee, large-scale cultivation of the fiber did not begin until the 1820s with the opening of the land between the Tennessee and Mississippi Rivers.

name: tennessee
sentence: The upper wedge of the Mississippi Delta extends into southwestern Tennessee, and it was in this fertile section that cotton took hold.

name: tennessee
sentence: Soybeans are also heavily planted in West Tennessee, focusing on the northwest corner of the state.

name: tennessee
sentence: Large corporations with headquarters in Tennessee include FedEx, AutoZone and International Paper, all based in Memphis; Pilot Corporation and Regal Entertainment Group, based in Knoxville; Eastman Chemical Company, based in Kingsport; Hospital Corporation of America and Caterpillar Financial, based in Nashville; and Unum, based in Chattanooga.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee is also a major hub for the automotive industry.

name: tennessee
sentence: Four automobile manufacturers have factories in Tennessee: Nissan in Smyrna, General Motors in Spring Hill, Van Hool in Morristown, and Volkswagen in Chattanooga.

name: tennessee
sentence: Nissan moved its North American corporate headquarters from California to Franklin, Tennessee in 2005, and Mitsubishi Motors did the same in 2019.

name: tennessee
sentence: Other major manufacturers include a $2 billion polysilicon production facility owned by Wacker Chemie in Bradley County and a $1.2 billion polysilicon production facility owned by Hemlock Semiconductor in Clarksville.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee is a right to work state, as are most of its Southern neighbors.

name: tennessee
sentence: Unionization has historically been low and continues to decline as in most of the US generally.

name: tennessee
sentence: As of August 2019, the state has an unemployment rate of 3.5%, which is ranked 28th in the country.

name: tennessee
sentence: As of 2015, 16.7% of the population of Tennessee lives below the poverty line, which is higher than the national average of 14.7%.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tennessee has a reputation as low-tax state and is usually ranked as one of the five states with the lowest tax burden on residents.

name: tennessee
sentence: It is one of nine states that do not have a general income tax

name: tennessee
sentence: The Hall income tax is a tax imposed on most dividends and interest.

name: tennessee
sentence: The tax rate was 6% from 1937 to 2016, but is in the process of being completely phased out by January 1, 2021.

name: tennessee
sentence: The first $1,250 of individual income and $2,500 of joint income is exempt from this tax.

name: tennessee
sentence: The state's sales and use tax rate for most items is 7%, the second-highest in the nation, along with Mississippi, Rhode Island, New Jersey, and Indiana.

name: tennessee
sentence: Food is taxed at a lower rate of 4%, but candy, dietary supplements and prepared food are taxed at 7%.

name: tennessee
sentence: Local sales taxes are collected in most jurisdictions at rates varying from 1.5% to 2.75%, bringing the total sales tax to between 8.5% and 9.75%, with an average rate of about 9.5%, the nation's highest average sales tax.

name: tennessee
sentence: Intangible property tax is assessed on the shares of stock of stockholders of any loan, investment, insurance, or for-profit cemetery companies.

name: tennessee
sentence: The assessment ratio is 40% of the value times the jurisdiction's tax rate.

name: tennessee
sentence: Since January 1, 2016, Tennessee has had no inheritance tax.

name: tennessee
sentence: While sales tax remains the main source of state government funding, property taxes are the primary source of revenue for local governments.

name: tennessee
sentence: Tourism contributes billions of dollars every year to the state's economy, and Tennessee is ranked among the Top 10 destinations in the nation.

name: tennessee
sentence: In 2014 a record 100 million people visited the state resulting in $17.7 billion in tourism related spending within the state, an increase of 6.3% over 2013; tax revenue from tourism equaled $1.5 billion.

name: tennessee
sentence: Each county in Tennessee saw at least $1 million from tourism while 19 counties received at least $100 million (Davidson, Shelby, and Sevier counties were the top three).

name: tennessee
sentence: Tourism-generated jobs for the state reached 152,900, a 2.8% increase.

name: tennessee
sentence: International travelers to Tennessee accounted for $533 million in spending.

name: tennessee
sentence: In 2013 tourism within the state from local citizens accounted for 39.9% of tourists, the second highest originating location for tourists to Tennessee is the state of Georgia, accounting for 8.4% of tourists.

name: tennessee
sentence: Forty-four percent of stays in the state were "day trips", 25% stayed one night, 15% stayed two nights, and 11% stayed four or more nights.

name: tennessee
sentence: The average stay was 2.16 nights, compared to 2.03 nights for the US as a whole.

name: tennessee
