sentence: The office of the Texas Attorney General stated, in 2011, that Texas had about 2,294 colonias and estimates about 500,000 lived in the colonias.

name: texas
sentence: Hidalgo County, as of 2011, has the largest number of colonias.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has the largest number of people of all states, living in colonias.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has 254 counties, which is more than any other state by 95 (Georgia).

name: texas
sentence: Each county runs on Commissioners' Court system consisting of four elected commissioners (one from each of four precincts in the county, roughly divided according to population) and a county judge elected at large from the entire county.

name: texas
sentence: County government runs similar to a "weak" mayor-council system; the county judge has no veto authority, but votes along with the other commissioners.

name: texas
sentence: Although Texas permits cities and counties to enter "interlocal agreements" to share services, the state does not allow consolidated city-county governments, nor does it have metropolitan governments.

name: texas
sentence: Counties are not granted home rule status

name: texas
sentence: The state does not have townships—areas within a county are either incorporated or unincorporated.

name: texas
sentence: Incorporated areas are part of a municipality.

name: texas
sentence: The county provides limited services to unincorporated areas and to some smaller incorporated areas.

name: texas
sentence: Municipalities are classified either "general law" cities or "home rule".

name: texas
sentence: A municipality may elect home rule status once it exceeds 5,000 population with voter approval.

name: texas
sentence: Texas also permits the creation of "special districts", which provide limited services.

name: texas
sentence: The most common is the school district, but can also include hospital districts, community college districts, and utility districts (one utility district near Austin was the plaintiff in a landmark Supreme Court case involving the Voting Rights Act).

name: texas
sentence: Municipal, school district, and special district elections are nonpartisan, though the party affiliation of a candidate may be well-known.

name: texas
sentence: County and state elections are partisan.

name: texas
sentence: In 2010, Texas had a census population of 25,145,561.

name: texas
sentence: The United States Census Bureau estimated the population of Texas was 29,360,759 on July 1, 2020, a 16.76% increase since the 2010 United States Census.

name: texas
sentence: The 2015 Texas Population Estimate Program determined the population was 27,469,114 on July 1, 2015.

name: texas
sentence: Texas is the second-most populous state in the United States after California.

name: texas
sentence: In 2015, Texas had 4.7 million foreign-born residents, about 17% of the population and 21.6% of the state workforce.

name: texas
sentence: The major countries of origin for Texan immigrants were Mexico (55.1% of immigrants), India (5%), El Salvador (4.3%), Vietnam (3.7%), and China (2.3%).

name: texas
sentence: Of immigrant residents, some 35.8 percent were naturalized US citizens.

name: texas
sentence: As of 2018, the population increased to 4.9 million foreign-born residents or 17.2% of the state population, up from 2,899,642 in 2000.

name: texas
sentence: In 2014, there were an estimated 1.7 million undocumented immigrants in Texas, making up 35% of the total Texas immigrant population and 6.1% of the total state population.

name: texas
sentence: In addition to the state's foreign-born population, an additional 4.1 million Texans (15% of the state's population) were born in the United States and had at least one immigrant parent.

name: texas
sentence: According to the American Community Survey's 2016 estimates, 1,597,000 residents were undocumented immigrants, a decrease of 103,000 since 2014.

name: texas
sentence: Of the undocumented immigrant population, 960,000 have resided in Texas from less than 5 up to 14 years.

name: texas
sentence: An estimated 637,000 lived in Texas from 15 to 19 and 20 years or more.

name: texas
sentence: Texas's Rio Grande Valley has seen significant migration from across the US–Mexico border.

name: texas
sentence: During the 2014 crisis, many Central Americans, including unaccompanied minors traveling alone from Guatemala, Honduras, and El Salvador, reached the state, overwhelming Border Patrol resources for a time.

name: texas
sentence: Many sought asylum in the United States.

name: texas
sentence: Texas's population density is 90.5 people per square mile (34.9/km2) which is slightly higher than the average population density of the US as a whole, at 80.6 people per square mile (31.1/km2).

name: texas
sentence: In contrast, while Texas and France are similarly sized geographically, the European country has a population density of 301.8 people per square mile (116.5/km2).

name: texas
sentence: Two-thirds of all Texans live in major metropolitan areas such as Houston.

name: texas
sentence: The Dallas–Fort Worth metropolitan area is the largest in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: While Houston is the largest city in Texas and the fourth-largest city in the United States by population, the Dallas–Fort Worth metropolitan area is larger than the city and metropolitan area of Houston.

name: texas
sentence: In 2015 non-Hispanic whites made up 11,505,371 (41.9%) of the population, followed by Black Americans at 3,171,043 (11.5%); other races 1,793,580 (6.5%); and Hispanics and Latinos (of any race) 10,999,120 (40.0%).

name: texas
sentence: According to the 2010 United States census, the racial composition of Texas was the following: White American 70.4 percent, (Non-Hispanic whites 45.3 percent), Black or African American 11.8 percent, American Indian 0.7 percent, Asian 3.8 percent (1.0 percent Indian, 0.8 percent Vietnamese, 0.6 percent Chinese, 0.4 percent Filipino, 0.3 percent Korean, 0.1 percent Japanese, 0.6 percent other Asian), Pacific Islander 0.1 percent, some other race 10.5 percent, and two or more races 2.7 percent.

name: texas
sentence: In addition, 37.6 percent of the population was Hispanic or Latino (of any race) (31.6 percent Mexican, 0.9 percent Salvadoran, 0.5 percent Puerto Rican, 0.4 percent Honduran, 0.3 percent Guatemalan 0.3 percent Spaniard, 0.2 percent Colombian, 0.2 percent Cuban).

name: texas
sentence: In 2011, 69.8% of the population of Texas younger than age 1 were minorities (meaning they had at least one parent who was not non-Hispanic white).

name: texas
sentence: In 2019, non-Hispanic whites represented 41.2% of Texas's population, reflecting a national demographic shift.

name: texas
sentence: Blacks or African Americans made up 12.9%, American Indians or Alaska Natives 1.0%, Asian Americans 5.2%, Native Hawaiians and other Pacific Islanders 0.1%, some other race 0.2%, and two or more races 1.8%.

name: texas
sentence: Hispanics or Latin Americans of any race made up 39.7% of the estimated population.

name: texas
sentence: As of 1980 German, Irish, and English Americans have made the three largest European ancestry groups in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: German Americans make up 11.3 percent of the population and number over 2.7 million members.

name: texas
sentence: Irish Americans make up 8.2 percent of the population and number over 1.9 million.

name: texas
sentence: There are roughly 600,000 French Americans, 472,000 Italian Americans, 369,161 Scottish Americans, and 288,610 Polish Americans residing in Texas; these four ethnic groups make up 2.5 percent, 2.0 percent, 1.5 percent, and 1.0 percent of the population respectively.

name: texas
sentence: In the 1980 United States Census the largest ancestry group reported in Texas was English with 3,083,323 Texans citing they were of English or mostly English ancestry, making them 27 percent of the state at the time.

name: texas
sentence: Their ancestry primarily goes back to the original thirteen colonies (the census of 1790 gives 48% of the population of English ancestry, together with 12% Scots and Scots-Irish, 4.5% other Irish, and 3% Welsh, for a total of 67.5% British and Irish; 13% were German, Swiss, Dutch, and French Huguenots; 19% were African American), thus many of them today identify as "American" in ancestry, though they are of predominantly British stock.

name: texas
sentence: In 2012 there were nearly 200,000 Czech Americans living in Texas, the largest number of any state.

name: texas
sentence: Hispanics and Latinos are the second-largest groups in Texas after non-Hispanic European Americans.

name: texas
sentence: More than 8.5 million people claim Hispanic or Latino ethnicity.

name: texas
sentence: This group forms over 37 percent of Texas's population.

name: texas
sentence: People of Mexican descent alone number over 7.9 million, and make up 31.6 percent of the population.

name: texas
sentence: The vast majority of the Hispanic/Latino population in the state is of Mexican descent, the next two largest groups are Salvadorans and Puerto Ricans.

name: texas
sentence: There are more than 222,000 Salvadorans and more than 130,000 Puerto Ricans in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: Other groups with large numbers in Texas include Hondurans, Guatemalans, Nicaraguans and Cubans, among others.

name: texas
sentence: The Hispanics in Texas are more likely than in some other states (such as California) to identify as white; according to the 2010 US Census, Texas is home to 6,304,207 White Hispanics and 2,594,206 Hispanics of "some other race" (usually mestizo).

name: texas
sentence: African Americans are the racial minority in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: Their proportion of the population has declined since the early 20th century after many left the state in the Great Migration.

name: texas
sentence: Blacks of both Hispanic and non-Hispanic origin made up 11.5 percent of the population in 2015

name: texas
sentence: African Americans of both Hispanic and non-Hispanic origin numbered at roughly 2.7 million individuals, increasing in 2018 to 3,908,287.

name: texas
sentence: Native Americans are a smaller minority in the state.

name: texas
sentence: Native Americans made up 0.5 percent of Texas's population and number over 118,000 individuals as of 2015.

name: texas
sentence: Native Americans of non-Hispanic origin make up 0.3 percent of the population and number over 75,000 individuals.

name: texas
sentence: Cherokee made up 0.1 percent of the population, and numbered over 19,400.

name: texas
sentence: In contrast, only 583 identified as Chippewa.

name: texas
sentence: Asian Americans are a sizable minority group in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: Americans of Asian descent formed 4.5 percent of the population in 2015.

name: texas
sentence: They total more than 1.2 million individuals.

name: texas
sentence: Over 200,000 Indian Americans make Texas their home.

name: texas
sentence: Texas is also home to more than 187,000 Vietnamese and 136,000 Chinese.

name: texas
sentence: In addition to 92,000 Filipinos and 62,000 Koreans, there are 18,000 Japanese Americans living in the state.

name: texas
sentence: Lastly, more than 111,000 people are of other Asian ancestry groups, such as Cambodian, Thai, and Hmong.

name: texas
sentence: Sugar Land, a city within the Houston metropolitan area, and Plano, within the Dallas–Fort Worth metropolitan area, both have high concentrations of ethnic Chinese and Korean residents.

name: texas
sentence: The Houston and Dallas areas, and to a lesser extent, the Austin metropolitan area, all contain substantial Vietnamese communities.

name: texas
sentence: Americans with origins from the Pacific Islands are the smallest minority in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: According to the 2019 American Community Survey, only 21,484 Texans are Pacific Islanders.

name: texas
sentence: The city of Euless, a suburb of Fort Worth, contains a sizable population of Tongan Americans, at nearly 900 people, over one percent of the city's population.

name: texas
sentence: Killeen has a sufficient population of Samoans and Guamanian, and people of Pacific Islander descent surpass one percent of the city's population.

name: texas
sentence: Multiracial individuals are also a visible minority in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: People identifying as multiracial form 2.9 percent of the population, and number over 800,000 people.

name: texas
sentence: Over 80,000 Texans claim African and European heritage.

name: texas
sentence: People of European and American Indian ancestry number over 108,800.

name: texas
sentence: People of European and Asian ancestry number over 57,600.

name: texas
sentence: People of African and Native American ancestry were even smaller in number at 15,300.

name: texas
sentence: German descendants inhabit much of central and southeast-central Texas.

name: texas
sentence: Over one-third of Texas residents are of Hispanic origin; while many have recently arrived, some Tejanos have ancestors with multi-generational ties to 18th century Texas.

name: texas
sentence: The African American population in Texas is increasing due to the New Great Migration.

name: texas
sentence: In addition to the descendants of the state's former slave population, many African American college graduates have come to the state for work recently in the New Great Migration.

name: texas
sentence: Since the early 21st century, the Asian population in Texas has grown—primarily in Houston and Dallas.

name: texas
sentence: Other communities with a significantly growing Asian American population is in Austin, Corpus Christi, San Antonio, and the Sharyland area next McAllen, Texas.

name: texas
sentence: Three federally recognized Native American tribes reside in Texas: the Alabama-Coushatta Tribe, the Kickapoo Traditional Tribe, and the Ysleta del Sur Pueblo.

name: texas
sentence: In 2010, 49 percent of all births were Hispanics; 35 percent were non-Hispanic whites; 11.5 percent were non-Hispanic blacks, and 4.3 percent were Asians/Pacific Islanders.

name: texas
sentence: Based on Census Bureau data released in February 2011, for the first time in recent history, Texas's white population is below 50 percent (45 percent) and Hispanics grew to 38 percent.

name: texas
sentence: Between 2000 and 2010, the total population growth by 20.6 percent, but Hispanics growth by 65 percent, whereas non-Hispanic whites grew by only 4.2 percent.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has the fifth highest rate of teenage births in the nation and a plurality of these are to Hispanics.

name: texas
sentence: The most common accent or dialect spoken by natives throughout Texas is sometimes referred to as Texan English, which itself is a sub-variety of a broader category of American English known as Southern American English.

name: texas
sentence: Creole language is spoken in some parts of East Texas.

name: texas
sentence: In some areas of the state—particularly in the large cities—Western American English and General American English, is increasingly common.

name: texas
sentence: Chicano English—due to a growing Hispanic population—is widespread in South Texas, while African-American English is especially notable in historically minority areas of urban Texas.

name: texas
sentence: At the 2019 American Community Survey's estimates, 64.4% of the population spoke only English, and 35.6% spoke a language other than English.

name: texas
sentence: Roughly 30% of the total population spoke Spanish.

name: texas
sentence: Approximately 50,742 Texans spoke French or a French-creole language.

name: texas
sentence: German and other West Germanic languages were spoken by 47,098 residents; Russian, Polish, and other Slavic languages by 27,956; Korean by 31,581; Chinese 22,616; Vietnamese 81,022; Tagalog 43,360; and Arabic by 26,281 Texans.

name: texas
sentence: At the census of 2010, 65.8% (14,740,304) of Texas residents age 5 and older spoke only English at home, while 29.2% (6,543,702) spoke Spanish, 0.75 percent (168,886) Vietnamese, and Chinese (which includes Cantonese and Mandarin) was spoken by 0.56% (122,921) of the population over five.

name: texas
sentence: Other languages spoken include German (including Texas German) by 0.33% (73,137), Tagalog with 0.29% (64,272) speakers, and French (including Cajun French) was spoken by 0.25% (55,773) of Texans.

name: texas
sentence: Reportedly, Cherokee is the most widely spoken Native American language in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: In total, 34.2% (7,660,406) of Texas's population aged five and older spoke a language at home other than English as of 2006.

name: texas
sentence: The majority of Texas's population have been and remain predominantly Christian, influenced by Spanish Catholic and American Protestant colonialism and missionary work (77%).

name: texas
sentence: Texas's large Christian population is also influenced due to its location within the Bible Belt.

name: texas
sentence: The following largest groups were the irreligious (18%), nothing in particular (13%), Judaism (1%), Islam (1%), Buddhism (1%) and Hinduism and other religions at less than 1 percent each.

name: texas
sentence: The largest Christian denomination as of 2014 is the Catholic Church (23%).

name: texas
sentence: The largest Catholic jurisdictions in Texas are the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Galveston-Houston, the dioceses of Dallas, Fort Worth, and the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of San Antonio.

name: texas
sentence: In Protestantism, Evangelicals form the largest theological branch (31%) followed by Mainline Protestants (13%) and historically African American Protestant churches (6%).

name: texas
sentence: Baptists formed the largest Evangelical Protestant group in Texas (14%)

name: texas
sentence: Nondenominational and interdenominational Christians were the second largest Evangelical group (7%) followed by Pentecostals (4%).

name: texas
sentence: The largest Evangelical Baptists in the state were the Southern Baptist Convention (9%) and independent Baptists (3%).

name: texas
sentence: The Assemblies of God made the largest Evangelical Pentecostal denomination at the 2014 study.

name: texas
sentence: Among Mainline Protestants, the United Methodist Church was the largest denomination (4%).

name: texas
sentence: American Baptist Churches USA comprised the second largest Mainline Protestant group (2%).

name: texas
sentence: According to the Pew Research Center, the largest historically African American Christian denominations are the National Baptist Convention (USA) and the Church of God in Christ.

name: texas
sentence: Black Methodists and other Christians made up less than 1 percent each of the Christian demographic.

name: texas
sentence: Other Christians made up 1 percent of the total Christian population, and the Eastern and Oriental Orthodox formed less than 1 percent of the statewide Christian populace.

name: texas
sentence: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints is the largest nontrinitarian Christian group in Texas alongside the Jehovah's Witnesses.

name: texas
sentence: Non-Christian faiths accounted for 4% of the religious population in 2014.

name: texas
sentence: Adherents of many other religions reside predominantly in the urban centers of Texas.

name: texas
sentence: Judaism, Islam, and Buddhism were tied as the second largest religion as of 2014.

name: texas
sentence: In 1990, the Islamic population was about 140,000 with more recent figures putting the current number of Muslims between 350,000 and 400,000 as of 2012.

name: texas
sentence: The Jewish population was around 128,000 in 2008.

name: texas
sentence: In 2020, the Jewish population grew to over 176,000.

name: texas
sentence: Around 146,000 adherents of religions such as Hinduism and Sikhism lived in Texas as of 2004.

name: texas
sentence: Texas is the fifth-largest Muslim-populated state in the country.

name: texas
sentence: Of the unaffiliated, an estimated 2% were atheists and 3% agnostic.

name: texas
sentence: As of 2019, Texas had a gross state product (GSP) of $1.9 trillion, the second highest in the US Its GSP is greater than the GDPs of Brazil, Canada, Russia, South Korea and Spain, which are the world's 9th-, 10th-, 11th-, 12th- and 13th-largest economies, respectively.

name: texas
sentence: Texas's economy is the second-largest of any country subdivision globally, behind California.

name: texas
sentence: Its per capita personal income in 2009 was $36,484, ranking 29th in the nation.

name: texas
sentence: Texas's large population, an abundance of natural resources, thriving cities and leading centers of higher education have contributed to a large and diverse economy.

name: texas
sentence: Since oil was discovered, the state's economy has reflected the state of the petroleum industry.

name: texas
sentence: In recent times, urban centers of the state have increased in size, containing two-thirds of the population in 2005.

name: texas
sentence: The state's economic growth has led to urban sprawl and its associated symptoms.

name: texas
sentence: As of May 2020, during the COVID-19 pandemic, the state's unemployment rate was 13 percent.

name: texas
sentence: In 2010, Site Selection Magazine ranked Texas as the most business-friendly state in the nation, in part because of the state's three-billion-dollar Texas Enterprise Fund.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has the joint-highest number of Fortune 500 company headquarters in the United States, along with California.

name: texas
sentence: In 2010, there were 346,000 millionaires in Texas, constituting the second-largest population of millionaires in the nation.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has a "low taxes, low services" reputation.

name: texas
sentence: According to the Tax Foundation, Texans' state and local tax burdens rank among the lowest in the nation, 7th lowest nationally; state and local taxes cost $3,580 per capita, or 8.4 percent of resident incomes.

name: texas
sentence: Texas is one of seven states that lack a state income tax.

name: texas
sentence: Instead, the state collects revenue from property taxes (though these are collected at the county, city, and school district level; Texas has a state constitutional prohibition against a state property tax) and sales taxes.

name: texas
sentence: The state sales tax rate is 6.25 percent, but local taxing jurisdictions (cities, counties, special purpose districts, and transit authorities) may also impose sales and use tax up to 2 percent for a total maximum combined rate of 8.25 percent.

name: texas
sentence: Texas is a "tax donor state"; in 2005, for every dollar Texans paid to the federal government in federal income taxes, the state got back about $0.94 in benefits.

name: texas
sentence: To attract business, Texas has incentive programs worth $19 billion per year (2012); more than any other US state.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has the most farms and the highest acreage in the United States.

name: texas
sentence: The state is ranked No.

name: texas
sentence: 1 for revenue generated from total livestock and livestock products.

name: texas
sentence: It is ranked No.

name: texas
sentence: 2 for total agricultural revenue, behind California.

name: texas
sentence: At $7.4 billion or 56.7 percent of Texas's annual agricultural cash receipts, beef cattle production represents the largest single segment of Texas agriculture.

name: texas
sentence: This is followed by cotton at $1.9 billion (14.6 percent), greenhouse/nursery at $1.5 billion (11.4 percent), broilers at $1.3 billion (10 percent), and dairy products at $947 million (7.3 percent).

name: texas
sentence: Texas leads the nation in the production of cattle, horses, sheep, goats, wool, mohair and hay.

name: texas
sentence: The state also leads the nation in production of cotton which is the number one crop grown in the state in terms of value.

name: texas
sentence: The state grows significant amounts of cereal crops and produce.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has a large commercial fishing industry.

name: texas
sentence: With mineral resources, Texas leads in creating cement, crushed stone, lime, salt, sand and gravel.

name: texas
sentence: Texas throughout the 21st century has been hammered by drought.

name: texas
sentence: This has cost the state billions of dollars in livestock and crops.

name: texas
sentence: Ever since the discovery of oil at Spindletop, energy has been a dominant force politically and economically within the state.

name: texas
sentence: If Texas were its own country it would be the sixth largest oil producer in the world according to a 2014 study.

name: texas
sentence: The Railroad Commission of Texas, contrary to its name, regulates the state's oil and gas industry, gas utilities, pipeline safety, safety in the liquefied petroleum gas industry, and surface coal and uranium mining.

name: texas
sentence: Until the 1970s, the commission controlled the price of petroleum because of its ability to regulate Texas's oil reserves.

name: texas
sentence: The founders of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) used the Texas agency as one of their models for petroleum price control.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has known petroleum deposits of about 5 billion barrels (790,000,000 m3), which makes up about one-fourth of the known US reserves.

name: texas
sentence: The state's refineries can process 4.6 million barrels (730,000 m3) of oil a day.

name: texas
sentence: The Port Arthur Refinery in Southeast Texas is the largest refinery in the US Texas also leads in natural gas production, producing one-fourth of the nation's supply.

name: texas
sentence: Several petroleum companies are based in Texas such as: Occidental Petroleum, ConocoPhillips, ExxonMobil, Halliburton, Marathon Oil, Tesoro, Valero Energy, and Western Refining.

name: texas
sentence: According to the Energy Information Administration, Texans consume, on average, the fifth most energy (of all types) in the nation per capita and as a whole, following behind Wyoming, Alaska, Louisiana, North Dakota, and Iowa.

name: texas
sentence: Unlike the rest of the nation, most of Texas is on its own alternating current power grid, the Texas Interconnection.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has a deregulated electric service.

name: texas
sentence: Texas leads the nation in total net electricity production, generating 437,236 MWh in 2014, 89% more MWh than Florida, which ranked second.

name: texas
sentence: As an independent nation, Texas would rank as the world's eleventh-largest producer of electricity, after South Korea, and ahead of the United Kingdom.

name: texas
sentence: The state is a leader in renewable energy commercialization

name: texas
sentence: In 2014, 10.6% of the electricity consumed in Texas came from wind turbines.

name: texas
sentence: The Roscoe Wind Farm in Roscoe, Texas, is one of the world's largest wind farms with a 781.5 megawatt (MW) capacity.

name: texas
sentence: The Energy Information Administration states the state's large agriculture and forestry industries could give Texas an enormous amount biomass for use in biofuels.

name: texas
sentence: The state also has the highest solar power potential for development in the nation.

name: texas
sentence: With large universities systems coupled with initiatives like the Texas Enterprise Fund and the Texas Emerging Technology Fund, a wide array of different high tech industries have developed in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: The Austin area is nicknamed the "Silicon Hills" and the north Dallas area the "Silicon Prairie".

name: texas
sentence: Many high-tech companies are located in or have their headquarters in Texas (and Austin in particular), including Dell, Inc., Borland, Forcepoint, Indeed.com, Texas Instruments, Perot Systems, Rackspace and AT&T.

name: texas
sentence: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center (NASA JSC) in Southeast Houston, sits as the crown jewel of Texas's aeronautics industry.

name: texas
sentence: Both SpaceX and Blue Origin have their test facilities in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: Fort Worth hosts both Lockheed Martin's Aeronautics division and Bell Helicopter Textron.

name: texas
sentence: Lockheed builds the F-16 Fighting Falcon, the largest Western fighter program, and its successor, the F-35 Lightning II in Fort Worth.

name: texas
sentence: Texas's affluence stimulates a strong commercial sector consisting of retail, wholesale, banking and insurance, and construction industries.

name: texas
sentence: Examples of Fortune 500 companies not based on Texas traditional industries are AT&T, Kimberly-Clark, Blockbuster, J. C. Penney, Whole Foods Market, and Tenet Healthcare.

name: texas
sentence: Nationally, the Dallas–Fort Worth area, home to the second shopping mall in the United States, has the most shopping malls per capita of any American metropolitan statistical area.

name: texas
sentence: Mexico, the state's largest trading partner, imports a third of the state's exports because of the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA).

name: texas
sentence: NAFTA has encouraged the formation of controversial maquiladoras on the Texas–Mexico border.

name: texas
sentence: Historically, Texas culture comes from a blend of Southern (Dixie), Western (frontier), and Southwestern (Mexican/Anglo fusion) influences, varying in degrees of such from one intrastate region to another.

name: texas
sentence: Texas is placed in the Southern United States by the United States Census Bureau.

name: texas
sentence: A popular food item, the breakfast burrito, draws from all three, having a soft flour tortilla wrapped around bacon and scrambled eggs or other hot, cooked fillings.

name: texas
sentence: Adding to Texas's traditional culture, established in the 18th and 19th centuries, immigration has made Texas a melting pot of cultures from around the world.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has made a strong mark on national and international pop culture.

name: texas
sentence: The entire state is strongly associated with the image of the cowboy shown in westerns and in country western music.

name: texas
sentence: The state's numerous oil tycoons are also a popular pop culture topic as seen in the hit TV series Dallas.

name: texas
sentence: The internationally known slogan "Don't Mess with Texas" began as an anti-littering advertisement.

name: texas
sentence: Since the campaign's inception in 1986, the phrase has become "an identity statement, a declaration of Texas swagger".

name: texas
sentence: "Texas-sized" is an expression that can be used in two ways: to describe something that is about the size of the US state of Texas, or to describe something (usually but not always originating from Texas) that is large compared to other objects of its type.

name: texas
sentence: Texas was the largest US state, until Alaska became a state in 1959.

name: texas
sentence: The phrase "everything is bigger in Texas" has been in regular use since at least 1950; and was used as early as 1913.

name: texas
sentence: Houston is one of only five American cities with permanent professional resident companies in all the major performing arts disciplines: the Houston Grand Opera, the Houston Symphony Orchestra, the Houston Ballet, and The Alley Theatre.

name: texas
sentence: Known for the vibrancy of its visual and performing arts, the Houston Theater District—a 17-block area in the heart of Downtown Houston—ranks second in the country in the number of theater seats in a concentrated downtown area, with 12,948 seats for live performances and 1,480 movie seats.

name: texas
sentence: Founded in 1892, Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth, also called "The Modern", is Texas's oldest art museum.

name: texas
sentence: Fort Worth also has the Kimbell Art Museum, the Amon Carter Museum, the National Cowgirl Museum and Hall of Fame, the Will Rogers Memorial Center, and the Bass Performance Hall downtown.

name: texas
sentence: The Arts District of Downtown Dallas has arts venues such as the Dallas Museum of Art, the Morton H. Meyerson Symphony Center, the Margot and Bill Winspear Opera House, the Trammell & Margaret Crow Collection of Asian Art, and the Nasher Sculpture Center.

name: texas
sentence: The Deep Ellum district within Dallas became popular during the 1920s and 1930s as the prime jazz and blues hotspot in the Southern United States.

name: texas
sentence: The name Deep Ellum comes from local people pronouncing "Deep Elm" as "Deep Ellum".

name: texas
sentence: Artists such as Blind Lemon Jefferson, Robert Johnson, Huddie "Lead Belly" Ledbetter, and Bessie Smith played in early Deep Ellum clubs.

name: texas
sentence: Austin, The Live Music Capital of the World, boasts "more live music venues per capita than such music hotbeds as Nashville, Memphis, Los Angeles, Las Vegas or New York City".

name: texas
sentence: The city's music revolves around the nightclubs on 6th Street; events like the film, music, and multimedia festival South by Southwest; the longest-running concert music program on American television, Austin City Limits; and the Austin City Limits Music Festival held in Zilker Park.

name: texas
sentence: Since 1980, San Antonio has evolved into "The Tejano Music Capital Of The World".

name: texas
sentence: The Tejano Music Awards have provided a forum to create greater awareness and appreciation for Tejano music and culture.

name: texas
sentence: The second president of the Republic of Texas, Mirabeau B. Lamar, is the Father of Texas Education.

name: texas
sentence: During his term, the state set aside three leagues of land in each county for equipping public schools.

name: texas
sentence: An additional 50 leagues of land set aside for the support of two universities would later become the basis of the state's Permanent University Fund.

name: texas
sentence: Lamar's actions set the foundation for a Texas-wide public school system.

name: texas
sentence: Between 2006 and 2007, Texas spent $7,275 per pupil, ranking it below the national average of $9,389.

name: texas
sentence: The pupil/teacher ratio was 14.9, below the national average of 15.3.

name: texas
sentence: Texas paid instructors $41,744, below the national average of $46,593.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Education Agency (TEA) administers the state's public school systems.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has over 1,000 school districts; all districts except the Stafford Municipal School District are independent from municipal government and many cross city boundaries.

name: texas
sentence: School districts have the power to tax their residents and to assert eminent domain over privately owned property.

name: texas
sentence: Due to court-mandated equitable school financing for school districts, the state has a controversial tax redistribution system called the "Robin Hood plan".

name: texas
sentence: This plan transfers property tax revenue from wealthy school districts to poor ones.

name: texas
sentence: The TEA has no authority over private or home school activities.

name: texas
sentence: Students in Texas take the State of Texas Assessments of Academic Readiness (STAAR) in primary and secondary school.

name: texas
sentence: STAAR assess students' attainment of reading, writing, mathematics, science, and social studies skills required under Texas education standards and the No Child Left Behind Act.

name: texas
sentence: The test replaced the Texas Assessment of Knowledge and Skills (TAKS) test in the 2011–2012 school year.

name: texas
sentence: Generally prohibited in the West at large, school corporal punishment is not unusual in the more conservative, rural areas of the state, with 28,569 public school students paddled at least one time, according to government data for the 2011–2012 school year.

name: texas
sentence: The rate of school corporal punishment in Texas is surpassed only by Mississippi, Alabama, and Arkansas.

name: texas
sentence: The state's two most widely recognized flagship universities are The University of Texas at Austin and Texas A&M University, ranked as the 21st and 41st best universities in the nation according to 2020's latest Center for World University Rankings report, respectively.

name: texas
sentence: Some observers also include the University of Houston and Texas Tech University as tier one flagships alongside UT Austin and A&M.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Higher Education Coordinating Board (THECB) ranks the state's public universities into three distinct tiers:

name: texas
sentence: Texas's controversial alternative affirmative action plan, Texas House Bill 588, guarantees Texas students who graduated in the top 10 percent of their high school class automatic admission to state-funded universities.

name: texas
sentence: The bill encourages demographic diversity while attempting to avoid problems stemming from the Hopwood v. Texas (1996) case.

name: texas
sentence: Thirty-six (36) separate and distinct public universities exist in Texas, of which 32 belong to one of the six state university systems.

name: texas
sentence: Discovery of minerals on Permanent University Fund land, particularly oil, has helped fund the rapid growth of the state's two largest university systems: the University of Texas System and the Texas A&M System.

name: texas
sentence: The four other university systems: the University of Houston System, the University of North Texas System, the Texas State System, and the Texas Tech System are not funded by the Permanent University Fund.

name: texas
sentence: The Carnegie Foundation classifies four of Texas's universities as Tier One research institutions: The University of Texas at Austin, the Texas A&M University, the University of Houston and Texas Tech University.

name: texas
sentence: The University of Texas at Austin and Texas A&M University are the flagship universities of the University of Texas System and Texas A&M University System, respectively.

name: texas
sentence: Both were established by the Texas Constitution and hold stakes in the Permanent University Fund.

name: texas
sentence: The state has sought to expand the number of flagship universities by elevating some of its seven institutions designated as "emerging research universities".

name: texas
sentence: The two expected to emerge first are the University of Houston and Texas Tech University, likely in that order according to discussions on the House floor of the 82nd Texas Legislature.

name: texas
sentence: The state is home to various private institutions of higher learning—ranging from liberal arts colleges to a nationally recognized top-tier research university.

name: texas
sentence: Rice University in Houston is one of the leading teaching and research universities of the United States and is ranked the nation's 17th-best overall university by US News & World Report.

name: texas
sentence: Trinity University, a private, primarily undergraduate liberal arts university in San Antonio, has ranked first among universities granting primarily bachelor's and select master's degrees in the Western United States for 20 consecutive years by US News.

name: texas
sentence: Private universities include Abilene Christian University, Austin College, Baylor University, University of Mary Hardin–Baylor, and Southwestern University.

name: texas
sentence: Universities in Texas host three presidential libraries: George Bush Presidential Library at Texas A&M University, the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library and Museum at The University of Texas at Austin, and the George W. Bush Presidential Library at Southern Methodist University.

name: texas
sentence: Notwithstanding the concentration of elite medical centers in the state, The Commonwealth Fund ranks the Texas healthcare system the third worst in the nation.

name: texas
sentence: Texas ranks close to last in access to healthcare, quality of care, avoidable hospital spending, and equity among various groups.

name: texas
sentence: Causes of the state's poor rankings include politics, a high poverty rate, and the highest rate of illegal immigration in the nation.

name: texas
sentence: In May 2006, Texas initiated the program "code red" in response to the report the state had 25.1 percent of the population without health insurance, the largest proportion in the nation.

name: texas
sentence: The Trust for America's Health ranked Texas 15th highest in adult obesity, with 27.2 percent of the state's population measured as obese.

name: texas
sentence: The 2008 Men's Health obesity survey ranked four Texas cities among the top 25 fattest cities in America; Houston ranked 6th, Dallas 7th, El Paso 8th, and Arlington 14th.

name: texas
sentence: Texas had only one city (Austin, ranked 21st) in the top 25 among the "fittest cities" in America.

name: texas
sentence: The same survey has evaluated the state's obesity initiatives favorably with a "B+".

name: texas
sentence: The state is ranked forty-second in the percentage of residents who engage in regular exercise according to a 2007 study.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has the highest maternal mortality rate in the developed world, and the rate by which Texas women died from pregnancy-related complications doubled from 2010 to 2014, to 23.8 per 100,000.

name: texas
sentence: A rate unmatched in any other US state or economically developed country.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has many elite research medical centers.

name: texas
sentence: The state has nine medical schools, three dental schools, and two optometry schools.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has two Biosafety Level 4 (BSL-4) laboratories: one at The University of Texas Medical Branch (UTMB) in Galveston, and the other at the Southwest Foundation for Biomedical Research in San Antonio—the first privately owned BSL-4 lab in the United States.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Medical Center in Houston, holds the world's largest concentration of research and healthcare institutions, with 47 member institutions.

name: texas
sentence: Texas Medical Center performs the most heart transplants in the world.

name: texas
sentence: The University of Texas M. D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston is a highly regarded academic institution that centers around cancer patient care, research, education and prevention.

name: texas
sentence: San Antonio's South Texas Medical Center facilities rank sixth in clinical medicine research impact in the United States.

name: texas
sentence: The University of Texas Health Science Center is another highly ranked research and educational institution in San Antonio.

name: texas
sentence: Both the American Heart Association and the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center call Dallas home.

name: texas
sentence: The institution's medical school employs the most medical school Nobel laureates in the world.

name: texas
sentence: Texans have historically had difficulties traversing Texas due to the state's large size and rough terrain.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has compensated by building America's largest highway and railway systems.

name: texas
sentence: The regulatory authority, the Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT), maintains the state's immense highway system, regulates aviation, and public transportation systems.

name: texas
sentence: The state is an important transportation hub.

name: texas
sentence: From the Dallas/Fort Worth area, trucks can reach 93 percent of the nation's population within 48 hours, and 37 percent within 24 hours.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has 33 foreign trade zones (FTZ), the most in the nation.

name: texas
sentence: In 2004, a combined total of $298 billion of goods passed through Texas FTZs.

name: texas
sentence: The first Texas freeway was the Gulf Freeway opened in 1948 in Houston.

name: texas
sentence: As of 2005, 79,535 miles (127,999 km) of public highway crisscrossed Texas (up from 71,000 miles (114,263 km) in 1984).

name: texas
sentence: To fund recent growth in the state highways, Texas has 17 toll roads (see list) with several additional tollways proposed.

name: texas
sentence: In central Texas, the southern section of the State Highway 130 toll road has a speed limit of 85 miles per hour (137 km/h), the highest in the nation.

name: texas
sentence: All federal and state highways in Texas are paved.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has 730 airports, second-most of any state in the nation.

name: texas
sentence: Largest in Texas by size and passengers served, Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport (DFW) is the second-largest by area in the United States, and fourth in the world with 18,076 acres (73.15 km2).

name: texas
sentence: In traffic, DFW airport is the busiest in the state, the fourth busiest in the United States, and sixth worldwide.

name: texas
sentence: American Airlines Group's American / American Eagle, the world's largest airline in total passengers-miles transported and passenger fleet size, uses DFW as its largest and main hub.

name: texas
sentence: It ranks as the largest airline in the United States by number of passengers carried domestically per year and the largest airline in the world by number of passengers carried.Southwest Airlines, headquartered in Dallas, has its operations at Dallas Love Field.

name: texas
sentence: Texas's second-largest air facility is Houston's George Bush Intercontinental Airport (IAH).

name: texas
sentence: It served as the largest hub for the former Continental Airlines, which was based in Houston; it serves as the largest hub for United Airlines, the world's third-largest airline, by passenger-miles flown.

name: texas
sentence: IAH offers service to the most Mexican destinations of any US airport.

name: texas
sentence: The next five largest airports in the state all serve more than three million passengers annually; they include Austin-Bergstrom International Airport, William P. Hobby Airport, San Antonio International Airport, Dallas Love Field and El Paso International Airport.

name: texas
sentence: The smallest airport in the state to be designated an international airport is Del Rio International Airport.

name: texas
sentence: Around 1,150 seaports dot Texas's coast with over 1,000 miles (1,600 km) of channels.

name: texas
sentence: Ports employ nearly one-million people and handle an average of 317 million metric tons.

name: texas
sentence: Texas ports connect with the rest of the US Atlantic seaboard with the Gulf section of the Intracoastal Waterway.

name: texas
sentence: The Port of Houston today is the busiest port in the United States in foreign tonnage, second in overall tonnage, and tenth worldwide in tonnage.

name: texas
sentence: The Houston Ship Channel spans 530 feet (160 m) wide by 45 feet (14 m) deep by 50 miles (80 km) long.

name: texas
sentence: Part of the state's tradition of cowboys is derived from the massive cattle drives which its ranchers organized in the nineteenth century to drive livestock to railroads and markets in Kansas, for shipment to the East.

name: texas
sentence: Towns along the way, such as Baxter Springs, the first cow town in Kansas, developed to handle the seasonal workers and tens of thousands of head of cattle being driven.

name: texas
sentence: The first railroad to operate in Texas was the Buffalo Bayou, Brazos and Colorado Railway, opening in August 1853.

name: texas
sentence: The first railroad to enter Texas from the north, completed in 1872, was the Missouri–Kansas–Texas Railroad.

name: texas
sentence: With increasing railroad access, the ranchers did not have to take their livestock up to the Midwest and shipped beef out from Texas.

name: texas
sentence: This caused a decline in the economies of the cow towns.

name: texas
sentence: Since 1911, Texas has led the nation in length of railroad miles within the state.

name: texas
sentence: Texas railway length peaked in 1932 at 17,078 miles (27,484 km), but declined to 14,006 miles (22,540 km) by 2000.

name: texas
sentence: While the Railroad Commission of Texas originally regulated state railroads, in 2005 the state reassigned these duties to TxDOT.

name: texas
sentence: In the Dallas–Fort Worth area, three public transit agencies provide rail service: Dallas Area Rapid Transit (DART), Denton County Transportation Authority (DCTA), and Trinity Metro.

name: texas
sentence: DART began operating the first light rail system in the Southwest United States in 1996.

name: texas
sentence: The Trinity Railway Express (TRE) commuter rail service, which connects Fort Worth and Dallas, is provided by Trinity Metro and DART.

name: texas
sentence: Trinity Metro also operates the TEXRail commuter rail line, connecting downtown Fort Worth and Northeast Tarrant County to DFW Airport.

name: texas
sentence: The A-train commuter rail line, operated by DCTA, acts as an extension of the DART Green line into Denton County.

name: texas
sentence: In the Austin area, Capital Metropolitan Transportation Authority operates a commuter rail service known as Capital MetroRail to the northwestern suburbs.

name: texas
sentence: The Metropolitan Transit Authority of Harris County, Texas (METRO) operates light rail lines in the Houston area.

name: texas
sentence: Amtrak provides Texas with limited intercity passenger rail service.

name: texas
sentence: Three scheduled routes serve the state: the daily Texas Eagle (Chicago–San Antonio); the tri-weekly Sunset Limited (New Orleans–Los Angeles), with stops in Texas; and the daily Heartland Flyer (Fort Worth–Oklahoma City).

name: texas
sentence: Texas may get one of the nation's first high-speed rail line.

name: texas
sentence: Plans for a privately funded high-speed rail line between Dallas and Houston have been planned by the Texas Central Railway company.

name: texas
sentence: The current Texas Constitution was adopted in 1876.

name: texas
sentence: Like many states, it explicitly provides for a separation of powers.

name: texas
sentence: The state's Bill of Rights is much larger than its federal counterpart, and has provisions unique to Texas.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has a plural executive branch system limiting the power of the governor, which is a weak executive compared to some other states.

name: texas
sentence: Except for the secretary of state, voters elect executive officers independently; thus candidates are directly answerable to the public, not the governor.

name: texas
sentence: This election system has led to some executive branches split between parties and reduced the ability of the governor to carry out a program.

name: texas
sentence: When Republican president George W. Bush served as Texas's governor, the state had a Democratic lieutenant governor, Bob Bullock.

name: texas
sentence: The executive branch positions consist of the governor, lieutenant governor, comptroller of public accounts, land commissioner, attorney general, agriculture commissioner, the three-member Texas Railroad Commission, the State Board of Education, and the secretary of state.

name: texas
sentence: The bicameral Texas Legislature consists of the House of Representatives, with 150 members, and a Senatorte, with 31 members.

name: texas
sentence: The Speaker of the House leads the House, and the lieutenant governor, the Senatorte.

name: texas
sentence: The Legislature meets in regular session biennially for just over a hundred days, but the governor can call for special sessions as often as desired (notably, the Legislature cannot call itself into session).

name: texas
sentence: The state's fiscal year begins September 1.

name: texas
sentence: The judiciary of Texas is one of the most complex in the United States, with many layers and overlapping jurisdictions.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has two courts of last resort: the Texas Supreme Court, for civil cases, and the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals.

name: texas
sentence: Except for some municipal benches, partisan elections select judges at all levels of the judiciary; the governor fills vacancies by appointment.

name: texas
sentence: Texas is notable for its use of capital punishment, having led the country in executions since capital punishment was reinstated in the Gregg v. Georgia case (see Capital punishment in Texas).

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Ranger Division of the Texas Department of Public Safety is a law enforcement agency with statewide jurisdiction.

name: texas
sentence: Over the years, the Texas Rangers have investigated crimes ranging from murder to political corruption.

name: texas
sentence: They have acted as riot police and as detectives, protected the Texas governor, tracked down fugitives, and functioned as a paramilitary force both for the republic and for the state.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Rangers were unofficially created by Stephen F. Austin in 1823 and formally constituted in 1835.

name: texas
sentence: The Rangers were integral to several important events of Texas history and some of the best-known criminal cases in the history of the Old West.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas constitution defines the responsibilities of county governments, which serve as agents of the state.

name: texas
sentence: What are called commissioners court and court judges are elected to serve as the administrative arm.

name: texas
sentence: Most cities in the state, those over 5,000 in population, have home-rule governments.

name: texas
sentence: The vast majority of these have charters for council-manager forms of government, by which voters elect council members, who hire a professional city manager as an operating officer.

name: texas
sentence: In the 1870s, white Democrats wrested power back in the state legislature from the biracial coalition at the end of Reconstruction.

name: texas
sentence: In the early 20th century, the legislature passed bills to impose poll taxes, followed by white primaries; these measures effectively disfranchised most blacks, poor whites and Mexican Americans.

name: texas
sentence: In the 1890s, 100,000 blacks voted in the state; by 1906, only 5,000 could vote.

name: texas
sentence: As a result, the Democratic Party dominated Texas politics from the turn of the century, imposing racial segregation and white supremacy.

name: texas
sentence: It held power until after passage in the mid-1960s of national civil rights legislation enforcing constitutional rights of all citizens.

name: texas
sentence: Although Texas was essentially a one-party state during this time and the Democratic primary was viewed as "the real election", the Democratic Party had conservative and liberal factions, which became more pronounced after the New Deal.

name: texas
sentence: Additionally, several factions of the party briefly split during the 1930s and 1940s.

name: texas
sentence: The state's conservative white voters began to support Republican presidential candidates by the mid-20th century.

name: texas
sentence: After this period, they supported Republicans for local and state offices as well, and most whites became Republican Party members.

name: texas
sentence: The party also attracted some minorities, but many have continued to vote for Democratic candidates.

name: texas
sentence: The shift to the Republican Party is much-attributed to the fact the Democratic Party became increasingly liberal during the 20th century, and thus increasingly out-of-touch with the average Texas voter.

name: texas
sentence: As Texas was always a conservative state, voters switched to the GOP, which now more closely reflected their beliefs.

name: texas
sentence: Commentators have also attributed the shift to Republican political consultant Karl Rove, who managed numerous political campaigns in Texas in the 1980s and 1990s.

name: texas
sentence: Other stated reasons included court-ordered redistricting and the demographic shift in relation to the Sun Belt that favored the Republican Party and conservatism.

name: texas
sentence: The 2003 Texas redistricting of Congressional districts led by Republican Tom DeLay, was called by The New York Times "an extreme case of partisan gerrymandering".

name: texas
sentence: A group of Democratic legislators, the "Texas Eleven", fled the state in a quorum-busting effort to prevent the legislature from acting, but was unsuccessful.

name: texas
sentence: The state had already redistricted following the 2000 census.

name: texas
sentence: Despite these efforts, the legislature passed a map heavily in favor of Republicans, based on 2000 data and ignoring the estimated nearly one million new residents in the state since then.

name: texas
sentence: Career attorneys and analysts at the Department of Justice objected to the plan as diluting the votes of African American and Hispanic voters, but political appointees overrode them and approved it.

name: texas
sentence: Legal challenges to the redistricting reached the national Supreme Court in the case League of United Latin American Citizens v. Perry (2006), but the court ruled in favor of the state (and Republicans).

name: texas
sentence: In the 2014 Texas elections, the Tea Party movement made large gains, with numerous Tea Party favorites being elected into office, including Dan Patrick as lieutenant governor, Ken Paxton as attorney general, in addition to numerous other candidates including conservative Republican Greg Abbott as governor.

name: texas
sentence: Texas voters lean toward fiscal conservatism, while enjoying the benefits of huge federal investment in the state in military and other facilities achieved by the power of the Solid South in the 20th century.

name: texas
sentence: They also tend to have socially conservative values.

name: texas
sentence: Since 1980, most Texas voters have supported Republican presidential candidates.

name: texas
sentence: In 2000 and 2004, Republican George W. Bush won Texas with respectively 59.3 and 60.1 percent of the vote, partly due to his "favorite son" status as a former governor of the state.

name: texas
sentence: John McCain won the state in 2008, but with a smaller margin of victory compared to Bush at 55 percent of the vote.

name: texas
sentence: Austin, Dallas, Houston, and San Antonio consistently lean Democratic in both local and statewide elections.

name: texas
sentence: The state's changing demographics may result in a change in its overall political alignment, as a majority population of Black and Hispanic/Latino voters support the Democratic Party.

name: texas
sentence: Residents of counties along the Rio Grande closer to the Mexico–United States border, where there are many Latino residents, generally vote for Democratic Party candidates, while most other rural and suburban areas of Texas have shifted to voting for Republican Party candidates.

name: texas
sentence: As of the general elections of 2014, a large majority of the members of Texas's US House delegation are Republican, along with both US

name: texas
sentence: Senatortors.

name: texas
sentence: In the 114th United States Congress, of the 36 Congressional districts in Texas, 24 are held by Republicans and 11 by Democrats.

name: texas
sentence: One seat is vacant.

name: texas
sentence: Texas's Senatortors are John Cornyn and Ted Cruz.

name: texas
sentence: Since 1994, Texans have not elected a Democrat to a statewide office.

name: texas
sentence: The state's Democratic voters are made up primarily by liberal and minority groups in Austin, Beaumont, Dallas, El Paso, Houston, and San Antonio as well as minority voters in East and South Texas.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has banned sanctuary cities, but Houston Mayor Sylvester Turner has vowed that the city will not assist ICE agents.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has a reputation of very harsh criminal punishment for criminal offenses.

name: texas
sentence: It is one of the 32 states that practice capital punishment, and since the US Supreme Court allowed capital punishment to resume in 1976, 40% of all US.executions have taken place in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: As of 2008, Texas had the 4th highest incarceration rate in the US Texas also has strong self defense laws, allowing citizens to use lethal force to defend themselves, their families, or their property.

name: texas
sentence: While American football has long been considered "king" in the state, Texans enjoy a wide variety of sports.

name: texas
sentence: Texans can cheer for a plethora of professional sports teams.

name: texas
sentence: Within the "Big Four" professional leagues, Texas has two NFL teams (the Dallas Cowboys and the Houston Texans), two Major League Baseball teams (the Houston Astros and the Texas Rangers), three NBA teams (the San Antonio Spurs, the Houston Rockets, and the Dallas Mavericks), and one National Hockey League team (the Dallas Stars).

name: texas
sentence: The Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex is one of only twelve American metropolitan areas that host sports teams from all the "Big Four" professional leagues.

name: texas
sentence: Outside the "Big Four", Texas also has a WNBA team, (the Dallas Wings) and two Major League Soccer teams (the Houston Dynamo and FC Dallas).

name: texas
sentence: Collegiate athletics have deep significance in Texas culture, especially football.

name: texas
sentence: The state has twelve Division I-FBS schools, the most in the nation.

name: texas
sentence: Four of the state's universities, the Baylor Bears, Texas Longhorns, TCU Horned Frogs, and Texas Tech Red Raiders, compete in the Big 12 Conference.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas A&M Aggies left the Big 12 and joined the Southeastern Conference in 2012, which led the Big 12 to invite TCU to join; TCU was previously in the Mountain West Conference.

name: texas
sentence: The Houston Cougars and the SMU Mustangs compete in the American Athletic Conference.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas State Bobcats and the UT Arlington Mavericks compete in the Sun Belt Conference.

name: texas
sentence: Four of the state's schools claim at least one national championship in football: the Texas Longhorns, the Texas A&M Aggies, the TCU Horned Frogs, and the SMU Mustangs.

name: texas
sentence: According to a survey of Division I-A coaches the rivalry between the University of Oklahoma and the University of Texas at Austin, the Red River Shootout, ranks the third-best in the nation.

name: texas
sentence: The TCU Horned Frogs and SMU Mustangs also share a rivalry and compete annually in the Battle for the Iron Skillet.

name: texas
sentence: A fierce rivalry, the Lone Star Showdown, also exists between the state's two largest universities, Texas A&M University and the University of Texas at Austin.

name: texas
sentence: The athletics portion of the Lone Star Showdown rivalry has been put on hold after the Texas A&M Aggies joined the Southeastern Conference.

name: texas
sentence: The University Interscholastic League (UIL) organizes most primary and secondary school competitions.

name: texas
sentence: Events organized by UIL include contests in athletics (the most popular being high school football) as well as artistic and academic subjects.

name: texas
sentence: Texans also enjoy the rodeo.

name: texas
sentence: The world's first rodeo was hosted in Pecos, Texas.

name: texas
sentence: The annual Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo is the largest rodeo in the world.

name: texas
sentence: It begins with trail rides from several points throughout the state that convene at Reliant Park.

name: texas
sentence: The Southwestern Exposition and Livestock Show in Fort Worth is the oldest continuously running rodeo incorporating many of the state's most historic traditions into its annual events.

name: texas
sentence: Dallas hosts the State Fair of Texas each year at Fair Park.

name: texas
sentence: Texas Motor Speedway hosts annual NASCAR Cup Series and IndyCar Series auto races since 1997.

name: texas
sentence: Since 2012, Austin's Circuit of the Americas plays host to a round of the Formula 1 World Championship— the first at a permanent road circuit in the United States since the 1980 Grand Prix at Watkins Glen International—, as well as Grand Prix motorcycle racing, FIA World Endurance Championship and United SportsCar Championship races.

name: utah
sentence: Utah ( YOO-tah, (listen) YOO-taw) is a state in the Western United States.

name: utah
sentence: It is bordered by Colorado to the east, Wyoming to the northeast, Idaho to the north, Arizona to the south and Nevada to the west.

name: utah
sentence: It also touches a corner of New Mexico in the southeast.

name: utah
sentence: Of the fifty US states, Utah is the 13th-largest by area; with a population over three million, it is the 30th-most-populous and 11th-least-densely populated.

name: utah
sentence: Urban development is mostly concentrated in two areas: the Wasatch Front in the north-central part of the state, which is home to roughly two-thirds of the population and includes the capital city, Salt Lake City; and Washington County in the south, with more than 170,000 residents.

name: utah
sentence: Most of the western half of Utah lies in the Great Basin.

name: utah
sentence: The territory of modern Utah has been inhabited by various indigenous groups for thousands of years, including the ancient Puebloans, the Navajo and the Ute.

name: utah
sentence: The Spanish were the first Europeans to arrive in the mid-16th century, though the region's difficult geography and climate made it a peripheral part of New Spain and later Mexico.

name: utah
sentence: Even while it was part of Mexico, many of Utah's earliest settlers were American, particularly Mormons fleeing marginalization and persecution from the United States.

name: utah
sentence: Following the Mexican–American War, it became part of the Utah Territory, which included what is now Colorado and Nevada.

name: utah
sentence: Disputes between the dominant Mormon community and the federal government delayed Utah's admission as a state; only after the outlawing of polygamy was it admitted as the 45th, in 1896.

name: utah
sentence: A little more than half of all Utahns are Mormons, the vast majority of whom are members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS Church), which has its world headquarters in Salt Lake City.

name: utah
sentence: Utah is the only state where a majority of the population belongs to a single church.

name: utah
sentence: The LDS Church greatly influences Utahn culture, politics, and daily life, though since the 1990s the state has become more religiously diverse as well as secular.

name: utah
sentence: The state has a highly diversified economy, with major sectors including transportation, education, information technology and research, government services, mining; it is also a major tourist destination for outdoor recreation.

name: utah
sentence: In 2013, the US Census Bureau estimated that Utah had the second-fastest-growing population of any state.

name: utah
sentence: St. George was the fastest-growing metropolitan area in the United States from 2000 to 2005.

name: utah
sentence: Utah also has the 14th-highest median average income and the least income inequality of any US state.

name: utah
sentence: A 2012 Gallup national survey found Utah overall to be the "best state to live in the future" based on 13 forward-looking measurements including various economic, lifestyle, and health-related outlook metrics.

name: utah
sentence: The name Utah is said to derive from the name of the Ute tribe, meaning "people of the mountains".

name: utah
sentence: However, no such word actually exists in the Utes' language, and the Utes refer to themselves as Noochee.

name: utah
sentence: The meaning of Utes as "the mountain people" has been attributed to the neighboring Pueblo Indians, as well as to the Apache word Yuttahih, which means "one that is higher up" or "those that are higher up".

name: utah
sentence: In Spanish it was pronounced Yuta

name: utah
sentence: Thousands of years before the arrival of European explorers, the Ancestral Puebloans and the Fremont people lived in what is now known as Utah, some of which spoke languages of the Uto-Aztecan group.

name: utah
sentence: Ancestral Pueblo peoples built their homes through excavations in mountains, and the Fremont people built houses of straw before disappearing from the region around the 15th century.

name: utah
sentence: Another group of Native Americans, the Navajo, settled in the region around the 18th century.

name: utah
sentence: In the mid-18th century, other Uto-Aztecan tribes, including the Goshute, the Paiute, the Shoshone, and the Ute people, also settled in the region.

name: utah
sentence: These five groups were present when the first European explorers arrived.

name: utah
sentence: The southern Utah region was explored by the Spanish in 1540, led by Francisco Vázquez de Coronado, while looking for the legendary Cíbola.

name: utah
sentence: A group led by two Catholic priests—sometimes called the Domínguez–Escalante expedition—left Santa Fe in 1776, hoping to find a route to the coast of California.

name: utah
sentence: The expedition traveled as far north as Utah Lake and encountered the native residents.

name: utah
sentence: The Spanish made further explorations in the region but were not interested in colonizing the area because of its desert nature.

name: utah
sentence: In 1821, the year Mexico achieved its independence from Spain, the region became known as part of its territory of Alta California.

name: utah
sentence: European trappers and fur traders explored some areas of Utah in the early 19th century from Canada and the United States.

name: utah
sentence: The city of Provo, Utah was named for one, Étienne Provost, who visited the area in 1825.

name: utah
sentence: The city of Ogden, Utah was named after Peter Skene Ogden, a Canadian explorer who traded furs in the Weber Valley.

name: utah
sentence: In late 1824, Jim Bridger became the first known English-speaking person to sight the Great Salt Lake.

name: utah
sentence: Due to the high salinity of its waters, He thought he had found the Pacific Ocean; he subsequently learned this body of water was a giant salt lake.

name: utah
sentence: After the discovery of the lake, hundreds of American and Canadian traders and trappers established trading posts in the region.

name: utah
sentence: In the 1830s, thousands of migrants traveling from the Eastern United States to the American West began to make stops in the region of the Great Salt Lake, then known as Lake Youta.

name: utah
sentence: Following the death of Joseph Smith in 1844, Brigham Young, as president of the Quorum of the Twelve, became the effective leader of the LDS Church in Nauvoo, Illinois.

name: utah
sentence: To address the growing conflicts between his people and their neighbors, Young agreed with Illinois Governor Thomas Ford in October 1845 that the Mormons would leave by the following year.

name: utah
sentence: Young and the first band of Mormon pioneers reached the Salt Lake Valley on July 24, 1847.

name: utah
sentence: Over the next 22 years, more than 70,000 pioneers crossed the plains and settled in Utah.

name: utah
sentence: For the first few years, Brigham Young and the thousands of early settlers of Salt Lake City struggled to survive.

name: utah
sentence: The arid desert land was deemed by the Mormons as desirable as a place where they could practice their religion without harassment.

name: utah
sentence: Settlers buried thirty-six Native Americans in one grave after an outbreak of measles occurred during the winter of 1847.

name: utah
sentence: The first group of settlers brought African slaves with them, making Utah the only place in the western United States to have African slavery.

name: utah
sentence: Three slaves, Green Flake, Hark Lay, and Oscar Crosby, came west with the first group of settlers in 1847.

name: utah
sentence: The settlers also began to purchase Indian slaves in the well-established Indian slave trade, as well as enslaving Indian prisoners of war.

name: utah
sentence: Utah was Mexican territory when the first pioneers arrived in 1847.

name: utah
sentence: Early in the Mexican–American War in late 1846, the United States had taken control of New Mexico and California.

name: utah
sentence: The entire Southwest became US territory upon the signing of the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo, February 2, 1848.

name: utah
sentence: The treaty was ratified by the United States Senatorte on March 11.

name: utah
sentence: Learning that California and New Mexico were applying for statehood, the settlers of the Utah area (originally having planned to petition for territorial status) applied for statehood with an ambitious plan for a State of Deseret.

name: utah
sentence: The Mormon settlements provided pioneers for other settlements in the West.

name: utah
sentence: Salt Lake City became the hub of a "far-flung commonwealth" of Mormon settlements.

name: utah
sentence: With new church converts coming from the East and around the world, Church leaders often assigned groups of church members as missionaries to establish other settlements throughout the West.

name: utah
sentence: They developed irrigation to support fairly large pioneer populations along Utah's Wasatch front (Salt Lake City, Bountiful and Weber Valley, and Provo and Utah Valley).

name: utah
sentence: Throughout the remainder of the 19th century, Mormon pioneers established hundreds of other settlements in Utah, Idaho, Nevada, Arizona, Wyoming, California, Canada, and Mexico—including in Las Vegas, Nevada; Franklin, Idaho (the first European settlement in Idaho); San Bernardino, California; Mesa, Arizona; Star Valley, Wyoming; and Carson Valley, Nevada.

name: utah
sentence: Prominent settlements in Utah included St. George, Logan, and Manti (where settlers completed the first three temples in Utah, each started after but finished many years before the larger and better known temple built in Salt Lake City was completed in 1893), as well as Parowan, Cedar City, Bluff, Moab, Vernal, Fillmore (which served as the territorial capital between 1850 and 1856), Nephi, Levan, Spanish Fork, Springville, Provo Bench (now Orem), Pleasant Grove, American Fork, Lehi, Sandy, Murray, Jordan, Centerville, Farmington, Huntsville, Kaysville, Grantsville, Tooele, Roy, Brigham City, and many other smaller towns and settlements.

name: utah
sentence: Young had an expansionist's view of the territory that he and the Mormon pioneers were settling, calling it Deseret—which according to the Book of Mormon was an ancient word for "honeybee".

name: utah
sentence: This is symbolized by the beehive on the Utah flag, and the state's motto, "Industry".

name: utah
sentence: The Utah Territory was much smaller than the proposed state of Deseret, but it still contained all of the present states of Nevada and Utah as well as pieces of modern Wyoming and Colorado.

name: utah
sentence: It was created with the Compromise of 1850, and Fillmore, named after President Millard Fillmore, was designated the capital.

name: utah
sentence: The territory was given the name Utah after the Ute tribe of Native Americans.

name: utah
sentence: Salt Lake City replaced Fillmore as the territorial capital in 1856.

name: utah
sentence: By 1850, there were around 100 black people in the territory, the majority of whom were slaves.

name: utah
sentence: In Salt Lake County, 26 slaves were counted.

name: utah
sentence: In 1852, the territorial legislature passed the Act in Relation to Service and the Act for the relief of Indian Slaves and Prisoners formally legalizing slavery in the territory.

name: utah
sentence: Slavery was abolished in the territory during the Civil War.

name: utah
sentence: In 1850, Salt Lake City sent out a force known as the Nauvoo Legion and engaged the Timpanogos in the Battle at Fort Utah.

name: utah
sentence: Disputes between the Mormon inhabitants and the US government intensified due to the practice of plural marriage, or polygamy, among members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

name: utah
sentence: The Mormons were still pushing for the establishment of a State of Deseret with the new borders of the Utah Territory.

name: utah
sentence: Most, if not all, of the members of the US government opposed the polygamous practices of the Mormons.

name: utah
sentence: Members of the LDS Church were viewed as un-American and rebellious when news of their polygamous practices spread.

name: utah
sentence: In 1857, particularly heinous accusations of abdication of government and general immorality were leveled by former associate justice William W. Drummond, among others.

name: utah
sentence: The detailed reports of life in Utah caused the administration of James Buchanan to send a secret military "expedition" to Utah.

name: utah
sentence: When the supposed rebellion should be quelled, Alfred Cumming would take the place of Brigham Young as territorial governor.

name: utah
sentence: The resulting conflict is known as the Utah War, nicknamed "Buchanan's Blunder" by the Mormon leaders.

name: utah
sentence: In September 1857, about 120 American settlers of the Baker–Fancher wagon train, en route to California from Arkansas, were murdered by Utah Territorial Militia and some Paiute Native Americans in the Mountain Meadows massacre.

name: utah
sentence: Before troops led by Albert Sidney Johnston entered the territory, Brigham Young ordered all residents of Salt Lake City to evacuate southward to Utah Valley and sent out the Nauvoo Legion to delay the government's advance.

name: utah
sentence: Although wagons and supplies were burned, eventually the troops arrived in 1858, and Young surrendered official control to Cumming, although most subsequent commentators claim that Young retained true power in the territory.

name: utah
sentence: A steady stream of governors appointed by the president quit the position, often citing the traditions of their supposed territorial government.

name: utah
sentence: By agreement with Young, Johnston established Camp Floyd, 40 miles (60 km) away from Salt Lake City, to the southwest.

name: utah
sentence: Salt Lake City was the last link of the First Transcontinental Telegraph, completed in October 1861.

name: utah
sentence: Brigham Young was among the first to send a message, along with Abraham Lincoln and other officials.

name: utah
sentence: Because of the American Civil War, federal troops were pulled out of Utah Territory in 1861.

name: utah
sentence: This was a boon to the local economy as the army sold everything in camp for pennies on the dollar before marching back east to join the war.

name: utah
sentence: The territory was then left in LDS hands until Patrick E. Connor arrived with a regiment of California volunteers in 1862.

name: utah
sentence: Connor established Fort Douglas just 3 miles (4.8 km) east of Salt Lake City and encouraged his people to discover mineral deposits to bring more non-Mormons into the territory.

name: utah
sentence: Minerals were discovered in Tooele County and miners began to flock to the territory.

name: utah
sentence: Beginning in 1865, Utah's Black Hawk War developed into the deadliest conflict in the territory's history.

name: utah
sentence: Chief Antonga Black Hawk died in 1870, but fights continued to break out until additional federal troops were sent in to suppress the Ghost Dance of 1872.

name: utah
sentence: The war is unique among Indian Wars because it was a three-way conflict, with mounted Timpanogos Utes led by Antonga Black Hawk fighting federal and LDS authorities.

name: utah
