sentence: According to Bloomberg News, lost wages, revenue, and other economic harm from the chemical spill could top $500 million.

name: west_virginia
sentence: and West Virginia's Marshall University Center for Business and Economic Research estimated that about $61 million was lost by businesses in the first four days alone after the spill.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In 2012, West Virginia's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) grew by 3.3%.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The state issued a report highlighting the state's GDP as indicating a fast-growing economy, but did not address employment indicators.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In 2009–2013, the US real GDP increased 9.6% and total employment increased 3.9%.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In West Virginia during the same time period, its real GDP increased about 11%, while total employment decreased by 1,000 jobs from 746,000 to 745,000.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In 2013, West Virginia ranked last in the nation with an employment-to-population ratio of only 50%, compared to the national average of 59%.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The state lost 5,600 jobs in its labor force in four critical economic sectors: construction (1,900), manufacturing (1,100), retail (1,800), and education (800), while gaining just 400 in mining and logging.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The state's Civilian Labor Force dropped by 15,100.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Personal income growth in West Virginia during 2013 was only 1.5%—the lowest in the nation—and about half the national average (2.6%).

name: west_virginia
sentence: Overall income growth in West Virginia in the last thirty years has been only 13%—about a third the national average (37%).

name: west_virginia
sentence: Wages of the impoverished bottom 1% income earners decreased by 3%, compared to the national average, which increased 19%.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia's poverty rate is one of the highest in the nation.

name: west_virginia
sentence: 2017 estimates indicate that 19% of the state's population lives in poverty, exceeding the national average of 13%.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The West Virginia teachers' strike in 2018 inspired teachers in other states to take similar action.

name: west_virginia
sentence: United Van Lines 37th Annual Migration Study showed in 2013 that 60% more people moved out of the Mountain State than moved in.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia's population is expected to decline by more than 19,000 residents by 2030, and West Virginia could lose one of its three seats in the United States House of Representatives.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia is the only state where death rates exceeds birth rates.

name: west_virginia
sentence: During 2010–2013, about 21,000 babies per year were born in West Virginia, but over these three years West Virginia had 3,000 more deaths than births.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Gallup-Healthways annual "State of American Well-Being" rankings reports that 1,261 concerned West Virginians rated themselves as "suffering" in categories such as Quality of Life, Physical Health, and Access to Basic Needs.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Overall, West Virginia citizens rated themselves as being more miserable than people in all other states—for five years running.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In addition, the Gallup Well-Being Index for 2013 ranked Charleston, the state capital, and Huntington last and next-to-last out of 189 US Metropolitan Statistical Areas.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Annie E. Casey Foundation's National Index of Children's Progress ranked West Virginia 43rd in the nation for all kids, and last for white kids.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Annie E. Casey Foundation's 2013 KIDS COUNT Data Book also ranked West Virginia's education system 47th in the nation for the second straight year.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Charleston, West Virginia has the worst divorce rate among 100 cities in the nation.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Stephen Smith, the executive director of the West Virginia Healthy Kids and Families Coalition, said poor employment prospects are to blame: "The pressure to make a good living puts strain on a marriage, and right now it is infinitely harder to make a living here than it was 40 years ago."

name: west_virginia
sentence: United Health Foundation's "America's Health Rankings" for 2013 found that Americans are making considerable progress in key health measures.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia, however, ranked either last or second-to-last in twenty categories, including cancer, child immunization, diabetes, disabilities, drug deaths, teeth loss, low birth weight, missed work days due to health, prescription drug overdose, preventable hospitalizations, and senior clinical care.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Wisconsin Population Health Institute annual "Health Rankings" for 2012 showed West Virginia spends $9,671 per capita on health care annually.

name: west_virginia
sentence: El Salvador spends just $467, yet both have the same life expectancy.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In 2012, according to the Census Bureau, West Virginia was the only state where death rates exceeds birth rates.

name: west_virginia
sentence: During 2010–2013, about 21,000 babies per year were born in West Virginia, but there were 24,000 deaths.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In demographics, this is called a "net mortality society".

name: west_virginia
sentence: The National Center for Health Statistics says national birth rates for teenagers are at historic lows—during 2007–2010, teen birth rates fell 17% nationally;.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia, however, ranked last with a 3% increase in birth rates for teenagers.

name: west_virginia
sentence: A study by West Virginia's Marshall University showed that 19% of babies born in the state have evidence of drug or alcohol exposure.

name: west_virginia
sentence: This is several times the national rate, where studies show that about 5.9% of pregnant women in the US use illicit drugs, and about 8.5% consume any alcohol.

name: west_virginia
sentence: An Institute for Health Policy Research study determined that mortality rates in Appalachia are correlated with coal production.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In twenty West Virginia coal counties mining more than a million tons of coal per year and having a total population of 850,000, there are about 10,100 deaths per year, with 1,400 of those statistically attributed to deaths from heart, respiratory and kidney disease from living in an Appalachian coal county.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In 2015, McDowell County had the highest rate of drug-induced deaths of any county in the United States, with a rate of 141 deaths per 100,000 people.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Four of the five counties with the highest rates of drug-induced deaths are in West Virginia (McDowell, Wyoming, Cabell and Raleigh Counties).

name: west_virginia
sentence: The residents of West Virginia have a lower life expectancy than the national average.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In 2014 life expectancy for both sexes in the state was 76.0 years compared to 79.1 years for the United States as a whole.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In 2014, males in West Virginia lived an average of 73.6 years compared to a national average of 76.7 years and females lived an average of 77.5 years compared to a national average of 81.5 years.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Male life expectancy in West Virginia between 1980 and 2014 increased by 4.7 years, compared to a national average of a 6.7 year increase.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Life expectancy for females in West Virginia between 1980 and 2014 increased by 1.7 years, compared to a national average of a 4.0 year increase.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Life expectancy for both sexes is among the lowest of all states.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Life expectancies in 2014 for both sexes in West Virginia counties ranged from a low of 70.3 years in McDowell County to a high of 79.3 years in Pendleton County.

name: west_virginia
sentence: McDowell and several other West Virginia counties are among the counties in the US with the lowest life expectancies.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The West Virginia Legislature is bicameral.

name: west_virginia
sentence: It consists of the House of Delegates and the Senatorte, both housed in the West Virginia State Capitol.

name: west_virginia
sentence: It is a citizen's legislature, meaning that legislative office is not a full-time occupation, but rather a part-time position.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Consequently, the legislators often hold a full-time job in their community of residence.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Typically, the legislature is in session for 60 days between January and early April.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The final day of the regular session ends in a bewildering fury of last-minute legislation to meet a constitutionally imposed midnight deadline.

name: west_virginia
sentence: During the remainder of the year, monthly interim sessions are held in preparation for the regular session.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Legislators also gather periodically for 'special' sessions when called by the governor.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The title of Lieutenant Governor is assigned by statute to the senate president.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The governor, elected every four years on the same day as the US presidential election, is sworn in during the following January.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Governors of West Virginia can serve two consecutive terms but must sit out a term before serving a third term in office.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The title of Lieutenant Governor is assigned by statute to the senate president.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia is one of nineteen states that do not have a death penalty, and it is the only state in the southeastern United States to have abolished it.

name: west_virginia
sentence: For the purpose of courts of general jurisdiction, the state is divided into 31 judicial circuits.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Each circuit is made up of one or more counties.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Circuit judges are elected in non-partisan elections to serve eight-year terms.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia's highest court is the Supreme Court of Appeals.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia is the busiest appellate court of its type in the United States.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia is one of 11 states with a single appellate court.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The state constitution allows for the creation of an intermediate court of appeals, but the Legislature has never created one.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Supreme Court is made up of five justices, elected in non-partisan elections to 12-year terms.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia is an alcoholic beverage control state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: However, unlike most such states, it does not operate retail outlets, having exited that business in 1990.

name: west_virginia
sentence: It retains a monopoly on wholesaling of distilled spirits only.

name: west_virginia
sentence: At the state level, West Virginia's politics were largely dominated by the Democratic Party from the Great Depression through the 2000s.

name: west_virginia
sentence: This was a legacy of West Virginia's very strong tradition of union membership.

name: west_virginia
sentence: After the 2014 midterm elections Democrats controlled the governorship, the majority of statewide offices, and one US Senatorte seat, while Republicans held one US Senatorte seat, all three of the state's US House seats, and a majority in both houses of the West Virginia Legislature.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In the 2016 elections, the Republicans held on to their seats and made gains in the State Senatorte and gained three statewide offices.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Since 2000, West Virginians have supported the Republican candidate in every presidential election.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The state is regarded as a "deep red" state at the federal level.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In 2012 Republican Mitt Romney won the state, defeating Democrat Barack Obama with 62% of the vote to 35% for Obama.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In the 2016 presidential election, Republican Donald Trump won the state with 67.86% of the popular vote, with West Virginia being the second-highest percentage voting for Trump of any state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Evangelical Christians comprised 52% of the state's voters in 2008.

name: west_virginia
sentence: A poll in 2005 showed that 53% of West Virginia voters are anti-abortion, the seventh highest in the country.

name: west_virginia
sentence: A 2014 poll by Pew Research found that 35% of West Virginians supported legal abortion in "all or most cases" while 58% wanted it to be banned "in all or most cases".

name: west_virginia
sentence: A September 2011 Public Policy Polling survey found that 19% of West Virginia voters thought same-sex marriage should be legal, while 71% thought it should be illegal and 10% were not sure.

name: west_virginia
sentence: A separate question on the same survey found that 43% of West Virginia voters supported the legal recognition of same-sex couples, with 17% supporting same-sex marriage, 26% supporting civil unions but not marriage, 54% favoring no legal recognition and 3% not sure.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In 2008, 58% favored troop withdrawal from Iraq while just 32% wanted troops to remain.

name: west_virginia
sentence: On fiscal policy in 2008, 52% said raising taxes on the wealthier individuals would benefit the economy, while 45% disagreed.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The West Virginia Department of Commerce is a government agency responsible for overseeing West Virginia's economy, workforce, natural resources, and tourism, the department oversees nine subsidiary agencies.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Highways form the backbone of transportation systems in West Virginia, with over 37,300 miles (60,000 km) of public roads in the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Airports, railroads, and rivers complete the commercial transportation modes for West Virginia.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Commercial air travel is facilitated by airports in Charleston, Huntington, Morgantown, Beckley, Lewisburg, Clarksburg, and Parkersburg.

name: west_virginia
sentence: All but Charleston and Huntington are subsidized by the federal Department of Transportation's Essential Air Service program.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The cities of Charleston, Huntington, Beckley, Wheeling, Morgantown, Clarksburg, Parkersburg and Fairmont have bus-based public transit systems.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia University in Morgantown boasts the PRT (personal rapid transit) system, the state's only single-rail public transit system.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Developed by Boeing, the WVUShool of Engineering and the Department of Transportation, it was a model for low-capacity light transport designed for smaller cities.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Recreational transportation opportunities abound in West Virginia, including hiking trails, rail trails, ATV off-road trails, white water rafting rivers, and two tourist railroads, the Cass Scenic Railroad and the Potomac Eagle Scenic Railroad.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia is crossed by seven Interstate Highways.

name: west_virginia
sentence: I-64 enters the state near White Sulphur Springs in the mountainous east, and exits for Kentucky in the west, near Huntington.

name: west_virginia
sentence: I-77 enters from Virginia in the south, near Bluefield.

name: west_virginia
sentence: It runs north past Parkersburg before it crosses into Ohio.

name: west_virginia
sentence: I-64 and I-77 between Charleston and Beckley are merged as toll road known as the West Virginia Turnpike, which continues as I-77 alone from Beckley to Princeton.

name: west_virginia
sentence: It was constructed beginning in 1952 as a two lane road, but rebuilt beginning in 1974 to Interstate standards.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Today almost nothing of the original construction remains.

name: west_virginia
sentence: I-68's western terminus is in Morgantown.

name: west_virginia
sentence: From there it runs east into Maryland.

name: west_virginia
sentence: At the I-68 terminus in Morgantown, it meets I-79, which enters from Pennsylvania and runs through the state to its southern terminus in Charleston.

name: west_virginia
sentence: I-70 briefly runs through West Virginia, crossing the northern panhandle through Wheeling, while I-470 is a bypass of Wheeling (making Wheeling among the smallest cities with an interstate bypass).

name: west_virginia
sentence: I-81 also briefly runs in West Virginia through the Eastern Panhandle where it goes through Martinsburg.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The interstates are supplemented by roads constructed under the Appalachian Corridor system.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Four Corridors are complete.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Corridor D, carrying US 50, runs from the Ohio River, and I-77, at Parkersburg to I-79 at Clarksburg.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Corridor G, carrying US 119, runs from Charleston to the Kentucky border at Williamson.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Corridor L, carrying US 19, runs from the Turnpike at Beckley to I-79 near Sutton (and provides a short cut of about 40 miles (64 km) and bypasses Charleston's urban traffic for traveler heading to and from Florida).

name: west_virginia
sentence: Corridor Q, carrying US 460, runs through Mercer County, entering the state from Giles County, Virginia and then reentering Virginia at Tazewell County.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Work continues on the long delayed Corridor H, which will carry US 48 from Weston to the Virginia line near Wardensville.

name: west_virginia
sentence: As of 2018, a section from Weston to Kerens just past Elkins, and another section from Wardensville to Davis are complete.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Other projects under development are a four-lane upgrade of US 35 from Scott Depot to the Ohio River at Point Pleasant, which is about two-thirds complete; a four lane upgrade of WV 10 from Logan to Man and then of WV 80 from Man to Gilbert, which is about half completed; and four lane upgrades to US 52 from Bluefield to Williamson, known as the "King Coal Highway" and from Williamson to Huntington, known as the "Tolsia Highway" which are many years from completion.

name: west_virginia
sentence: A project known as the "Coalfields Expressway" is also ongoing, and will carry US 121 from Beckley west across Raleigh, Wyoming, and McDowell counties, entering Virginia near Bishop.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Rail lines in the state used to be more prevalent, but many lines have been discontinued because of increased automobile traffic.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Many old tracks have been converted to rail trails for recreational use, although the coal producing areas still have railroads running at near capacity.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Amtrak's Cardinal roughly parallels I-64's path through the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: MARC trains serve commuters in the eastern panhandle.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In 2006 Norfolk Southern along with the West Virginia and US Government approved a plan to modify many of the rail tunnels in West Virginia, especially in the southern half of the state, to allow for double stacked cars (see inter-modal freight).

name: west_virginia
sentence: This is expected to also help bring economic growth to the southern half of the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: An Intermodal Freight Facility is located at Prichard, just south of Huntington.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Because of the mountainous nature of the entire state, West Virginia has several notable tunnels and bridges.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The most famous of these is the New River Gorge Bridge, which was at a time the longest steel single-arch bridge in the world with a 3,031-foot (924 m) span.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The bridge is also pictured on the West Virginia state quarter.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Fort Steuben Bridge (Weirton-Steubenville Bridge) was at the time of its construction one of only three cable-stayed steel girder trusses in the United States.

name: west_virginia
sentence: "The Veterans Memorial Bridge was designed to handle traffic from the Fort Steuben Bridge as well as its own traffic load", to quote the Weirton Daily Times newspaper.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The 80-year-old Fort Steuben Bridge (Weirton-Steubenville Bridge) was permanently closed on January 8, 2009.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Wheeling Suspension Bridge was the first bridge built across the Ohio River in 1849 and for a time was the longest suspension bridge in the world.

name: west_virginia
sentence: It is still the oldest vehicular suspension bridge in the United States still in use.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Originally, the state capital was in Wheeling, from 1863 to 1870.

name: west_virginia
sentence: It was then moved to Charleston, a more central city, from 1870 to 1875, when it returned to Wheeling.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In 1885 the capitol burned down and it was moved back to Charleston that year, where it has remained ever since.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia is home to college sports teams from two schools—West Virginia and Marshall—that play in NCAA Division I.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia is also home to several professional minor league baseball, football, soccer, and other sports teams.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia's folk heritage is a part of the Appalachian folk music tradition, and includes styles of fiddling, ballad singing, and other styles that draw on Scots-Irish music.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Camp Washington-Carver, a Mountain Cultural Arts Center located at Clifftop in Fayette County, hosts an annual Appalachian String Band Festival.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Capitol Complex in Charleston hosts The Vandalia Gathering, where traditional Appalachian musicians compete in contests and play in impromptu jam sessions and evening concerts over the weekend.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Augusta Heritage Center sponsored by Davis & Elkins College in Elkins in Randolph County produces the annual Augusta Heritage Festival, which includes intensive week-long workshops in the summer that help preserve Appalachian heritage and traditions.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The West Virginia Symphony Orchestra was founded in 1939, as the Charleston Civic Orchestra, before becoming the Charleston Symphony Orchestra in 1943.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The first conductor was William R. Wiant, followed by the conductor Antonio Modarelli, who was written about in the November 7, 1949 Time Magazine for his composition of the River Saga, a six-section program piece about the Kanawha River according to the Charleston Gazette's November 6, 1999 photo essay, "Snapshots of the 20th Century".

name: west_virginia
sentence: Before coming to Charleston, Modarelli had conducted the Wheeling Symphony Orchestra and the Philadelphia Orchestra, according to the orchestra's website.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Pulitzer Prize-winning 20th-century composer George Crumb was born in Charleston and earned his bachelor's degree there before moving outside the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: There had also been a series of operatic style concerts performed in Wheeling during mid-century as well.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The West Virginia Cultural Center in Charleston is home to the West Virginia Division of Culture and History, which helps underwrite and coordinate a large number of musical activities.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The center is also home to Mountain Stage, an internationally broadcast live-performance music radio program established in 1983 which is carried by many affiliates of National Public Radio.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The program also travels to other venues in the state such as the West Virginia University Creative Arts Center in Morgantown.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The center hosts concerts sponsored by the Friends of Old Time Music and Dance, which brings an assortment of acoustic roots music to West Virginians.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The center also hosts the West Virginia Dance Festival, which features classical and modern dance.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Huntington's historic Keith-Albee Theatre, built by brothers A.B.

name: west_virginia
sentence: and S.J.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Hyman, was originally opened to the public on May 7, 1928, and hosts a variety of performing arts and music attractions.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The theatre was eventually gifted to Marshall University and is currently going through renovation to restore it to its original splendor.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Every summer Elkins hosts the Augusta Heritage Festival, which brings folk musicians from around the world.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The town of Glenville has long been home to the annual West Virginia State Folk Festival.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Mountaineer Opera House in Milton hosts a variety of musical acts.

name: west_virginia
sentence: John Denver's hit song "Take Me Home, Country Roads" describes the experience of driving through West Virginia.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The song mentions the Shenandoah River and the Blue Ridge Mountains, both features traversing the easternmost extremity of the state's "eastern panhandle", in Jefferson County.

name: west_virginia
sentence: On March 8, 2014, West Virginia governor Earl Ray Tomblin signed House Concurrent Resolution 40 naming "Take Me Home, Country Roads" the fourth official state song of West Virginia.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Symphony Sunday is an annual event hosted by the West Virginia Symphony Orchestra held in June.

name: west_virginia
sentence: It is a day full day of music by community groups, food, and family fun, culminating in a free performance by the West Virginia Symphony Orchestra with a fireworks display following.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The event began in 1982 and is held on the front lawn of the University of Charleston.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Daily Mail Kanawha County Majorette and Band Festival is West Virginia's longest-running music festival.

name: west_virginia
sentence: It is for the eight public high schools in Kanawha County.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The festival began in 1947.

name: west_virginia
sentence: It is held at the University of Charleston Stadium at Laidley Field in downtown Charleston.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin ( (listen)) is a state in the Great Lakes region of the Midwestern United States, bordered by Minnesota to the west; Iowa to the southwest; Illinois to the south; Lake Michigan to the east; Michigan to the northeast; and Lake Superior to the north.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin is the 23rd-largest state by total area and the 20th-most populous.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The state capital is Madison, and its largest city is Milwaukee, which is on the western shore of Lake Michigan.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The state is divided into 72 counties.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin's geography is diverse, having been greatly impacted by glaciers during the Ice Age with the exception of the Driftless Area.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Northern Highland and Western Upland along with a part of the Central Plain occupies the western part of the state, with lowlands stretching to the shore of Lake Michigan.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin is third to Ontario and Michigan in the length of its Great Lakes coastline.

name: wisconsin
sentence: At the time of European contact, the area that is now Wisconsin was inhabited by Algonquian and Siouan nations.

name: wisconsin
sentence: During the 19th and early 20th centuries, many European settlers entered the state, many of whom emigrated from Germany and Scandinavia.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Like neighboring Minnesota, the state remains a center of German American and Scandinavian American culture.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The state is one of the nation's leading dairy producers and is known as "America's Dairyland"; it is particularly famous for its cheese.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Manufacturing (especially paper products), information technology, cranberries, ginseng, and tourism are also major contributors to the state's economy.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The word Wisconsin originates from the name given to the Wisconsin River by one of the Algonquian-speaking Native American groups living in the region at the time of European contact.

name: wisconsin
sentence: French explorer Jacques Marquette was the first European to reach the Wisconsin River, arriving in 1673 and calling the river Meskousing (likely ᒣᔅᑯᐤᓯᣙ meskowsin) in his journal.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Subsequent French writers changed the spelling from Meskousing to Ouisconsin, and over time this became the name for both the Wisconsin River and the surrounding lands.

name: wisconsin
sentence: English speakers anglicized the spelling from Ouisconsin to Wisconsin when they began to arrive in large numbers during the early 19th century.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The legislature of Wisconsin Territory made the current spelling official in 1845.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Algonquian word for Wisconsin and its original meaning have both grown obscure.

name: wisconsin
sentence: While interpretations vary, most implicate the river and the red sandstone that lines its banks.

name: wisconsin
sentence: One leading theory holds that the name originated from the Miami word Meskonsing, meaning "it lies red", a reference to the setting of the Wisconsin River as it flows through the reddish sandstone of the Wisconsin Dells.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Other theories include claims that the name originated from one of a variety of Ojibwa words meaning "red stone place", "where the waters gather", or "great rock".

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin has been home to a wide variety of cultures over the past 14,000 years.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The first people arrived around 10,000 BCE during the Wisconsin Glaciation.

name: wisconsin
sentence: These early inhabitants, called Paleo-Indians, hunted now-extinct ice age animals such as the Boaz mastodon, a prehistoric mastodon skeleton unearthed along with spear points in southwest Wisconsin.

name: wisconsin
sentence: After the ice age ended around 8000 BCE, people in the subsequent Archaic period lived by hunting, fishing, and gathering food from wild plants.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Agricultural societies emerged gradually over the Woodland period between 1000 BCE to 1000 CE.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Toward the end of this period, Wisconsin was the heartland of the "Effigy Mound culture", which built thousands of animal-shaped mounds across the landscape.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Later, between 1000 and 1500 CE, the Mississippian and Oneota cultures built substantial settlements including the fortified village at Aztalan in southeast Wisconsin.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Oneota may be the ancestors of the modern Ioway and Ho-Chunk nations who shared the Wisconsin region with the Menominee at the time of European contact.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Other Native American groups living in Wisconsin when Europeans first settled included the Ojibwa, Sauk, Fox, Kickapoo, and Pottawatomie, who migrated to Wisconsin from the east between 1500 and 1700.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The first European to visit what became Wisconsin was probably the French explorer Jean Nicolet.

name: wisconsin
sentence: He canoed west from Georgian Bay through the Great Lakes in 1634, and it is traditionally assumed that he came ashore near Green Bay at Red Banks.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Pierre Radisson and Médard des Groseilliers visited Green Bay again in 1654–1666 and Chequamegon Bay in 1659–1660, where they traded for fur with local Native Americans.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In 1673, Jacques Marquette and Louis Jolliet became the first to record a journey on the Fox-Wisconsin Waterway all the way to the Mississippi River near Prairie du Chien.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Frenchmen like Nicholas Perrot continued to ply the fur trade across Wisconsin through the 17th and 18th centuries, but the French made no permanent settlements in Wisconsin before Great Britain won control of the region following the French and Indian War in 1763.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Even so, French traders continued to work in the region after the war, and some, beginning with Charles de Langlade in 1764, settled in Wisconsin permanently, rather than returning to British-controlled Canada.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The British gradually took over Wisconsin during the French and Indian War, taking control of Green Bay in 1761 and gaining control of all of Wisconsin in 1763.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Like the French, the British were interested in little but the fur trade.

name: wisconsin
sentence: One notable event in the fur trading industry in Wisconsin occurred in 1791, when two free African Americans set up a fur trading post among the Menominee at present day Marinette.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The first permanent settlers, mostly French Canadians, some Anglo-New Englanders and a few African American freedmen, arrived in Wisconsin while it was under British control.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Charles Michel de Langlade is generally recognized as the first settler, establishing a trading post at Green Bay in 1745, and moving there permanently in 1764.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Settlement began at Prairie du Chien around 1781.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The French residents at the trading post in what is now Green Bay, referred to the town as "La Baye", however British fur traders referred to it as "Green Bay", because the water and the shore assumed green tints in early spring.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The old French title was gradually dropped, and the British name of "Green Bay" eventually stuck.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The region coming under British rule had virtually no adverse effect on the French residents as the British needed the cooperation of the French fur traders and the French fur traders needed the goodwill of the British.

name: wisconsin
sentence: During the French occupation of the region licenses for fur trading had been issued scarcely and only to select groups of traders, whereas the British, in an effort to make as much money as possible from the region, issued licenses for fur trading freely, both to British and to French residents.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The fur trade in what is now Wisconsin reached its height under British rule, and the first self-sustaining farms in the state were established as well.

name: wisconsin
sentence: From 1763 to 1780, Green Bay was a prosperous community which produced its own foodstuff, built graceful cottages and held dances and festivities.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin became a territorial possession of the United States in 1783 after the American Revolutionary War.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In 1787, it became part of the Northwest Territory.

name: wisconsin
sentence: As territorial boundaries subsequently developed, it was then part of Indiana Territory from 1800 to 1809, Illinois Territory from 1809 to 1818, and Michigan Territory from 1818 to 1836.

name: wisconsin
sentence: However, the British remained in control until after the War of 1812, the outcome of which finally established an American presence in the area.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Under American control, the economy of the territory shifted from fur trading to lead mining.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The prospect of easy mineral wealth drew immigrants from throughout the US and Europe to the lead deposits located at Mineral Point, Dodgeville, and nearby areas.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Some miners found shelter in the holes they had dug, and earned the nickname "badgers", leading to Wisconsin's identity as the "Badger State".

name: wisconsin
sentence: The sudden influx of white miners prompted tension with the local Native American population.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Winnebago War of 1827 and the Black Hawk War of 1832 culminated in the forced removal of Native Americans from most parts of the state.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Following these conflicts, Wisconsin Territory was created by an act of the United States Congress on April 20, 1836.

name: wisconsin
sentence: By fall of that year, the best prairie groves of the counties surrounding what is now Milwaukee were occupied by farmers from the New England states.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Erie Canal facilitated the travel of both Yankee settlers and European immigrants to Wisconsin Territory.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Yankees from New England and upstate New York seized a dominant position in law and politics, enacting policies that marginalized the region's earlier Native American and French-Canadian residents.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Yankees also speculated in real estate, platted towns such as Racine, Beloit, Burlington, and Janesville, and established schools, civic institutions, and Congregationalist churches.

name: wisconsin
sentence: At the same time, many Germans, Irish, Norwegians, and other immigrants also settled in towns and farms across the territory, establishing Catholic and Lutheran institutions.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The growing population allowed Wisconsin to gain statehood on May 29, 1848, as the 30th state.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Between 1840 and 1850, Wisconsin's non-Indian population had swollen from 31,000 to 305,000.

name: wisconsin
sentence: More than a third of residents (110,500) were foreign born, including 38,000 Germans, 28,000 British immigrants from England, Scotland, and Wales, and 21,000 Irish.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Another third (103,000) were Yankees from New England and western New York state.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Only about 63,000 residents in 1850 had been born in Wisconsin.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Nelson Dewey, the first governor of Wisconsin, was a Democrat.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Dewey oversaw the transition from the territorial to the new state government.

name: wisconsin
sentence: He encouraged the development of the state's infrastructure, particularly the construction of new roads, railroads, canals, and harbors, as well as the improvement of the Fox and Wisconsin Rivers.

name: wisconsin
sentence: During his administration, the State Board of Public Works was organized.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Dewey, an abolitionist, was the first of many Wisconsin governors to advocate against the spread of slavery into new states and territories.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Politics in early Wisconsin were defined by the greater national debate over slavery.

name: wisconsin
sentence: A free state from its foundation, Wisconsin became a center of northern abolitionism.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The debate became especially intense in 1854 after Joshua Glover, a runaway slave from Missouri, was captured in Racine.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Glover was taken into custody under the Federal Fugitive Slave Law, but a mob of abolitionists stormed the prison where Glover was held and helped him escape to Canada.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In a trial stemming from the incident, the Wisconsin Supreme Court ultimately declared the Fugitive Slave Law unconstitutional.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Republican Party, founded on March 20, 1854, by anti-slavery expansion activists in Ripon, Wisconsin, grew to dominate state politics in the aftermath of these events.

name: wisconsin
sentence: During the Civil War, around 91,000 troops from Wisconsin fought for the Union.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin's economy also diversified during the early years of statehood.

name: wisconsin
sentence: While lead mining diminished, agriculture became a principal occupation in the southern half of the state.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Railroads were built across the state to help transport grains to market, and industries like J.I.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Case & Company in Racine were founded to build agricultural equipment.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin briefly became one of the nation's leading producers of wheat during the 1860s.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Meanwhile, the lumber industry dominated in the heavily forested northern sections of Wisconsin, and sawmills sprang up in cities like La Crosse, Eau Claire, and Wausau.

name: wisconsin
sentence: These economic activities had dire environmental consequences.

name: wisconsin
sentence: By the close of the 19th century, intensive agriculture had devastated soil fertility, and lumbering had deforested most of the state.

name: wisconsin
sentence: These conditions forced both wheat agriculture and the lumber industry into a precipitous decline.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Beginning in the 1890s, farmers in Wisconsin shifted from wheat to dairy production in order to make more sustainable and profitable use of their land.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Many immigrants carried cheese-making traditions that, combined with the state's suitable geography and dairy research led by Stephen Babcock at the University of Wisconsin, helped the state build a reputation as "America's Dairyland".

name: wisconsin
sentence: Meanwhile, conservationists including Aldo Leopold helped re-establish the state's forests during the early 20th century, paving the way for a more renewable lumber and paper milling industry as well as promoting recreational tourism in the northern woodlands.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Manufacturing also boomed in Wisconsin during the early 20th century, driven by an immense immigrant workforce arriving from Europe.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Industries in cities like Milwaukee ranged from brewing and food processing to heavy machine production and tool-making, leading Wisconsin to rank 8th among US states in total product value by 1910.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The early 20th century was also notable for the emergence of progressive politics championed by Robert M. La Follette.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Between 1901 and 1914, Progressive Republicans in Wisconsin created the nation's first comprehensive statewide primary election system, the first effective workplace injury compensation law, and the first state income tax, making taxation proportional to actual earnings.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The progressive Wisconsin Idea also promoted the statewide expansion of the University of Wisconsin through the UW-Extension system at this time.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Later, UW economics professors John R. Commons and Harold Groves helped Wisconsin create the first unemployment compensation program in the United States in 1932.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In the immediate aftermath of World War II, citizens of Wisconsin were divided over things such as creation of the United Nations, support for the European recovery, and the growth of the Soviet Union's power.

name: wisconsin
sentence: However, when Europe divided into Communist and capitalist camps and the Communist revolution in China succeeded in 1949, public opinion began to move towards support for the protection of democracy and capitalism against Communist expansion.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin took part in several political extremes in the mid to late 20th century, ranging from the anti-communist crusades of Senatortor Joseph McCarthy in the 1950s to the radical antiwar protests at UW-Madison that culminated in the Sterling Hall bombing in August 1970.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The state undertook welfare reform under Republican Governor Tommy Thompson during the 1990s.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The state's economy also underwent further transformations towards the close of the 20th century, as heavy industry and manufacturing declined in favor of a service economy based on medicine, education, agribusiness, and tourism.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Two US Navy battleships, BB-9 and BB-64, were named for the state.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In 2011, Wisconsin became the focus of some controversy when newly elected governor Scott Walker proposed, successfully passed, and enacted the 2011 Wisconsin Act 10, which made large changes in the areas of collective bargaining, compensation, retirement, health insurance, and sick leave of public sector employees, among other changes.

name: wisconsin
sentence: A series of major protests by union supporters took place that year in response to the changes, and Walker survived a recall election held the next year, becoming the first governor in United States history to do so.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Walker enacted other bills promoting conservative governance, such as a right-to-work law, abortion restrictions, and legislation removing certain gun controls.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin is bordered by the Montreal River

name: wisconsin
sentence: A border dispute with Michigan was settled by two cases, both Wisconsin v. Michigan, in 1934 and 1935.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The state's boundaries include the Mississippi River and St. Croix River in the west, and the Menominee River in the northeast.

name: wisconsin
sentence: With its location between the Great Lakes and the Mississippi River, Wisconsin is home to a wide variety of geographical features.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The state is divided into five distinct regions.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In the north, the Lake Superior Lowland occupies a belt of land along Lake Superior.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Just to the south, the Northern Highland has massive mixed hardwood and coniferous forests including the 1,500,000 acres (6,100 km2) Chequamegon-Nicolet National Forest, as well as thousands of glacial lakes, and the state's highest point, Timms Hill.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In the middle of the state, the Central Plain has some unique sandstone formations like the Dells of the Wisconsin River in addition to rich farmland.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Eastern Ridges and Lowlands region in the southeast is home to many of Wisconsin's largest cities.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The ridges include the Niagara Escarpment that stretches from New York, the Black River Escarpment and the Magnesian Escarpment.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In the southwest, the Western Upland is a rugged landscape with a mix of forest and farmland, including many bluffs on the Mississippi River.

name: wisconsin
sentence: This region is part of the Driftless Area, which also includes portions of Iowa, Illinois, and Minnesota.

name: wisconsin
sentence: This area was not covered by glaciers during the most recent ice age, the Wisconsin Glaciation.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Overall, 46% of Wisconsin's land area is covered by forest.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Langlade County has a soil rarely found outside of the county called Antigo silt loam.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin has sister-state relationships with Germany's Hesse, Japan's Chiba Prefecture, Mexico's Jalisco, China's Heilongjiang, and Nicaragua.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Most of Wisconsin is classified as warm-summer humid continental climate (Köppen Dfb), while southern and southwestern portions are classified as hot-summer humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa).

name: wisconsin
sentence: The highest temperature ever recorded in the state was in the Wisconsin Dells, on July 13, 1936, where it reached 114 °F (46 °C).

name: wisconsin
sentence: The lowest temperature ever recorded in Wisconsin was in the village of Couderay, where it reached −55 °F (−48 °C) on both February 2 and 4, 1996.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin also receives a large amount of regular snowfall averaging around 40 inches (100 cm) in the southern portions with up to 160 inches (410 cm) annually in the Lake Superior snowbelt each year.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The United States Census Bureau estimates that the population of Wisconsin was 5,822,434 on July 1, 2019, a 2.4% increase since the 2010 United States Census.

name: wisconsin
sentence: This includes a natural increase since the last census of 150,659 people (i.e., 614,771 births minus 464,112 deaths) and an decrease due to net migration of 12,755 people.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Immigration resulted in a net increase of 59,251 people, and migration from within the US resulted in a net decrease of 72,006 people.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The table below shows the racial composition of Wisconsin's population as of 2016.

name: wisconsin
sentence: According to the 2016 American Community Survey, 6.5% of Wisconsin's population were of Hispanic or Latino origin (of any race): Mexican (4.7%), Puerto Rican (0.9%), Cuban (0.1%), and other Hispanic or Latino origin (0.7%).

name: wisconsin
sentence: The five largest ancestry groups were: German (40.5%), Irish (10.8%), Polish (8.8%), Norwegian (7.7%), and English (5.7%).

name: wisconsin
sentence: German is the most common ancestry in every county in the state, except Menominee, Trempealeau, and Vernon.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin has the highest percentage of residents of Polish ancestry of any state.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Since its founding, Wisconsin has been ethnically heterogeneous.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Following the period of French fur traders, the next wave of settlers were miners, many of whom were Cornish, who settled the southwestern area of the state.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The next wave was dominated by "Yankees", migrants of English descent from New England and upstate New York; in the early years of statehood, they dominated the state's heavy industry, finance, politics, and education.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Between 1850 and 1900, the immigrants were mostly Germans, Scandinavians (the largest group being Norwegian), Irish, and Poles.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In the 20th century, a number of African Americans and Mexicans settled in Milwaukee; and after the end of the Vietnam War came an influx of Hmongs.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The various ethnic groups settled in different areas of the state.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Although German immigrants settled throughout the state, the largest concentration was in Milwaukee.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Norwegian immigrants settled in lumbering and farming areas in the north and west.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Irish, Italian, and Polish immigrants settled primarily in urban areas.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Menominee County is the only county in the eastern United States with a Native American majority.

name: wisconsin
sentence: African Americans came to Milwaukee, especially from 1940 on.

name: wisconsin
sentence: 86% of Wisconsin's African-American population live in four cities: Milwaukee, Racine, Beloit, Kenosha, with Milwaukee home to nearly three-fourths of the state's black Americans.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In the Great Lakes region, only Detroit and Cleveland have a higher percentage of African-American residents.

name: wisconsin
sentence: 33% of Wisconsin's Asian population is Hmong, with significant communities in Milwaukee, Wausau, Green Bay, Sheboygan, Appleton, Madison, La Crosse, Eau Claire, Oshkosh, and Manitowoc.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Of the residents of Wisconsin, 71.7% were born in Wisconsin, 23.0% were born in a different US state, 0.7% were born in Puerto Rico, US Island areas, or born abroad to American parent(s), and 4.6% were foreign born.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Note: Births in table add to over 100%, because Hispanics are counted both by their ethnicity and by their race, giving a higher overall number.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The percentage of Wisconsin residents who belong to various affiliations are Christian 81% (Protestant 50%, Roman Catholic 29%), Mormon 0.5%, Jewish 0.5%, Muslim 0.5%, Buddhist 0.5%, Hindu 0.5%, and unaffiliated 15%.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Christianity is the predominant religion of Wisconsin.

name: wisconsin
sentence: As of 2008, the three largest denominational groups in Wisconsin were Catholic, Evangelical Protestant, and Mainline Protestant.

name: wisconsin
sentence: As of 2010, the Catholic Church had the highest number of adherents in Wisconsin (at 1,425,523), followed by the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America with 414,326 members, and the Lutheran Church–Missouri Synod with 223,279 adherents.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Wisconsin Evangelical Lutheran Synod, the synod with the fourth highest numbers of adherents in Wisconsin, has their headquarters in Waukesha, Wisconsin.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Statewide FBI Crime statistics for 2009 include 144 murders/non-negligent manslaughter; 1,108 rapes; 4,850 robberies; 8,431 aggravated assaults; and 147,486 property crimes.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin also publishes its own statistics through the Office of Justice Assistance.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The OJA reported 14,603 violent crimes in 2009, with a clearance rate (% solved) of 50%.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The OJA reported 4,633 sexual assaults in 2009, with an overall clearance rate for sexual assaults of 57%.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin's Constitution outlines the structure and function of state government, which is organized into three branches: executive, legislative, and judicial.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Wisconsin Blue Book is the primary published reference about the government and politics of the state.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Re-published every two years, copies are available from state legislators.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The executive branch is headed by the governor.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The current governor, Tony Evers, assumed office on January 7, 2019.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In addition to the governor, the executive branch includes five other elected constitutional officers: Lieutenant Governor, Secretary of State, Attorney General, Treasurer, and State Superintendent of Public Instruction.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Four members of the Wisconsin executive branch are Democrats.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Superintendent of Public Instruction of Wisconsin is a non-partisan position.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Wisconsin State Legislature is Wisconsin's legislative branch.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Legislature is a bicameral body consisting of the Assembly and the Senatorte.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin's court system has four levels: municipal courts, circuit courts, the Court of Appeals, and the Supreme Court.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Municipal courts typically handle cases involving local ordinance matters.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The circuit courts are Wisconsin's trial courts, they have original jurisdiction in all civil and criminal cases within the state.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Challenges to circuit court rulings are heard by the Wisconsin Court of Appeals, consisting of sixteen judges who typically sit in three-judge panels.

name: wisconsin
sentence: As the state's highest appellate court, the Wisconsin Supreme Court may hear both appeals from lower courts and original actions.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In addition to deciding cases, the Supreme Court is responsible for administering the state's court system and regulating the practice of law in Wisconsin.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In the United States Senatorte Wisconsin is represented by Ron Johnson and Tammy Baldwin.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin is divided into eight congressional districts.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin collects personal income taxes (based on five income brackets) which range from 4% to 7.65%.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The state sales and use tax rate is 5.0%.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Fifty-nine counties have an additional sales/use tax of 0.5%.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Milwaukee County and four surrounding counties have an additional temporary 0.1% tax that helps fund the Miller Park baseball stadium, which was completed in 2001.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The most common property tax assessed on Wisconsin residents is the real property tax, or their residential property tax.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin does not impose a property tax on vehicles, but does levy an annual registration fee.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Property taxes are the most important tax revenue source for Wisconsin's local governments, as well as major methods of funding school districts, vocational technical colleges, special purpose districts and tax incremental finance districts.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Equalized values are based on the full market value of all taxable property in the state, except for agricultural land.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In order to provide property tax relief for farmers, the value of agricultural land is determined by its value for agricultural uses, rather than for its possible development value.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Equalized values are used to distribute state aid payments to counties, municipalities, and technical colleges.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Assessments prepared by local assessors are used to distribute the property tax burden within individual municipalities.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin does not assess a tax on intangible property.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin does not collect inheritance taxes.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Until January 1, 2008, Wisconsin's estate tax was decoupled from the federal estate tax laws; therefore the state imposed its own estate tax on certain large estates.

name: wisconsin
sentence: There are no toll roads in Wisconsin; highway construction and maintenance are funded in part by motor fuel tax revenues, and the remaining balance is drawn from the State General Fund.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Non-highway road construction and maintenance are funded by local governments (municipalities or counties).

name: wisconsin
sentence: A Mexican consulate opened in Milwaukee on July 1, 2016.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin has had a diplomatic relationship with the Japanese prefecture of Chiba since 1990.

name: wisconsin
sentence: During the Civil War, Wisconsin was a Republican state; in fact it is the state that gave birth to the Republican Party, although ethno-religious issues in the late 19th century caused a brief split in the coalition.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Bennett Law campaign of 1890 dealt with foreign language teaching in schools.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Many Germans switched to the Democratic Party because of the Republican Party's support of the law.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin's political history encompasses, on the one hand, "Fighting Bob" La Follette and the Progressive movement; and on the other, the Republican and anti-Communist Joe McCarthy.

name: wisconsin
sentence: From the early 20th century, the Socialist Party of America had a base in Milwaukee.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The phenomenon was referred to as "sewer socialism" because the elected officials were more concerned with public works and reform than with revolution (although revolutionary socialism existed in the city as well).

name: wisconsin
sentence: Its influence faded in the late 1950s, largely because of the red scare and racial tensions.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The first Socialist mayor of a large city in the United States was Emil Seidel, elected mayor of Milwaukee in 1910; another Socialist, Daniel Hoan, was mayor of Milwaukee from 1916 to 1940; and a third, Frank P. Zeidler, from 1948 to 1960.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Succeeding Frank Zeidler, the last of Milwaukee's Socialist mayors, (Henry Maier), a former Wisconsin State Senatortor and member of the Democratic Party was elected mayor of Milwaukee in 1960.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Maier remained in office for 28 years, the longest-serving mayor in Milwaukee history.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Socialist newspaper editor Victor Berger was repeatedly elected as a US Representative, although he was prevented from serving for some time because of his opposition to the First World War.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Through the first half of the 20th century, Wisconsin's politics were dominated by Robert La Follette and his sons, originally of the Republican Party, but later of the revived Progressive Party.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Since 1945, the state has maintained a close balance between Republicans and Democrats.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Recent leading Republicans include former Governor Tommy Thompson and Congressman Jim Senatorenbrenner; prominent Democrats include Senatortors Herb Kohl and Russ Feingold, the only Senatortor to vote against the Patriot Act in 2001, and Congressman David Obey.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In 2020, Wisconsin leaned back in the Democratic party's direction as Joe Biden won the state by an even narrower margin of 0.7%.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Biden's win was largely carried by Milwaukee and Dane County with the rural areas of the state being carried by Trump.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin has leaned Democratic in recent presidential elections, although Donald Trump managed to win the state in 2016 by a narrow margin of 0.8%.

name: wisconsin
sentence: This marked the first time Wisconsin voted for a Republican presidential candidate since 1984, when every state except Minnesota and Washington D.C. went Republican.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In 2012, Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney chose Wisconsin Congressman Paul Ryan, a native of Janesville, as his running mate against incumbent Democratic President Barack Obama and Vice President Joe Biden.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Obama nevertheless carried Wisconsin by a margin of 53% to 46%.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Both the 2000 and 2004 presidential elections were quite close, with Wisconsin receiving heavy doses of national advertising, in accord with its status as a "swing", or pivot, state.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Al Gore carried the presidential vote in 2000 by 5,700 votes, and John Kerry won Wisconsin in 2004 by 11,000 votes.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Barack Obama carried the state in 2008 by 381,000 votes (56%).

name: wisconsin
sentence: Republicans had a stronghold in the Fox Valley, but elected a Democrat, Steve Kagen, of Appleton, for the 8th Congressional District in 2006.

name: wisconsin
sentence: However, Kagen survived only two terms and was replaced by Republican Reid Ribble in the Republican Party's sweep of Wisconsin in November 2010, the first time the Republican Party had taken back both chambers of the state legislature and the governorship in the same election.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The City of Milwaukee heads the list of Wisconsin's Democratic strongholds, which also includes Madison and the state's Native American reservations.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin's largest Congressional district, the 7th, had voted Democratic since 1969.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Its representative, David Obey, chaired the powerful House Appropriations Committee.

name: wisconsin
sentence: However, Obey retired and the once-Democratic seat was taken by Republican Sean Duffy in November 2010.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The 2010 elections saw a huge Republican resurgence in Wisconsin.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Republicans took control of the governor's office and both houses of the state legislature.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Republican Ron Johnson defeated Democratic incumbent US

name: wisconsin
sentence: Senatortor Russ Feingold and Republicans took two previously Democratic-held House seats, creating a 5–3 Republican majority House delegation.

name: wisconsin
sentence: At the statewide level, Wisconsin is competitive, with control regularly alternating between the two parties.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In 2006, Democrats gained in a national sweep of opposition to the Bush administration, and the Iraq War.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The retiring GOP 8th District Congressman, Mark Green, of Green Bay, ran against the incumbent Governor Jim Doyle.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Green lost by 8% statewide, making Doyle the first Democratic governor to be re-elected in 32 years.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Republicans lost control of the state Senatorte.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Although Democrats gained eight seats in the state Assembly, Republicans retained a five-vote majority.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In 2008, Democrats regained control of the State Assembly by a 52–46 margin, marking the first time since 1986 that the governor and state legislature were both Democratic.

name: wisconsin
sentence: With the election of Scott Walker in 2010, Republicans won both chambers of the legislature and the governorship, the first time all three changed partisan control in the same election.

name: wisconsin
sentence: His first year in office saw the introduction of the 2011 Wisconsin Act 10, which removed collective bargaining rights for state employees.

name: wisconsin
sentence: On February 14, 2011, the Wisconsin State Capitol erupted with protests when the Legislature took up a bill that would end most collective bargaining rights for state employees, except for wages, to address the $3.6 bil.

name: wisconsin
sentence: deficit.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The protests attracted tens of thousands of people each day, and garnered international attention.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Assembly passed the bill 53–42 on March 10 after the State Senatorte passed it the night before, and sent it to the Governor for his signature.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In response to the bill, enough signatures were gathered to force a recall election against Governor Walker.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Tom Barrett, the mayor of Milwaukee and Walker's 2010 opponent, won the Democratic primary and faced Walker again.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Walker won the election by 53% to 46% and became the first governor in United States history to retain his seat after a recall election.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Following the 2014 general election on November 4, 2014, the Governor, Lieutenant Governor, State Attorney General and State Treasurer were all Republicans, while the Secretary of State was a Democrat.

name: wisconsin
sentence: However, Walker was defeated for a third term in 2018 by Democrat Tony Evers.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In 2010 Wisconsin's gross state product was $248.3 billion, making it 21st among US states.

sentence: The economy of Wisconsin is driven by manufacturing, agriculture, and health care.

sentence: Manufacturing accounts for about 20% of the state's gross domestic product, a proportion that is third among all states.

sentence: The per capita personal income was $35,239 in 2008.

sentence: In March 2017, the state's unemployment rate was 3.4% (seasonally adjusted).

sentence: Wisconsin produces about a quarter of America's cheese, leading the nation in cheese production.

name: wisconsin
sentence: It is second in milk production, after California, and third in per-capita milk production, behind California and Vermont.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin is second in butter production, producing about one-quarter of the nation's butter.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The state ranks first nationally in the production of corn for silage, cranberries ginseng, and snap beans for processing.

sentence: It grows more than half the national crop of cranberries.

name: wisconsin
sentence: and 97% of the nation's ginseng.
