sentence: Wisconsin is also a leading producer of oats, potatoes, carrots, tart cherries, maple syrup, and sweet corn for processing.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The significance of the state's agricultural production is exemplified by the depiction of a Holstein cow, an ear of corn, and a wheel of cheese on Wisconsin's state quarter design.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The state annually selects an "Alice in Dairyland" to promote the state's agricultural products around the world.

name: wisconsin
sentence: A large part of the state's manufacturing sector includes commercial food processing, including well-known brands such as Oscar Mayer, Tombstone frozen pizza, Johnsonville brats, and Usinger's sausage.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Kraft Foods alone employs more than 5,000 people in the state.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Milwaukee is a major producer of beer and was formerly headquarters for Miller Brewing Company—the nation's second-largest brewer—until it merged with Coors.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Formerly, Schlitz, Blatz, and Pabst were cornerstone breweries in Milwaukee.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin is home to a very large and diversified manufacturing economy, with special focus on transportation and capital equipment.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Major Wisconsin companies in these categories include the Kohler Company

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin is a major producer of paper, packaging, and other consumer goods.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Major consumer products companies based in the state include SC Johnson & Co., and Diversey, Inc. Wisconsin also ranks first nationwide in the production of paper products; the lower Fox River from Lake Winnebago to Green Bay has 24 paper mills along its 39 miles (63 km) stretch.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The development and manufacture of health care devices and software is a growing sector of the state's economy, with key players such as GE Healthcare, Epic Systems, and TomoTherapy.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Tourism is a major industry in Wisconsin—the state's third largest, according to the Department of Tourism.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Tourist destinations such as the House on the Rock near Spring Green, Circus World Museum in Baraboo, and The Dells of the Wisconsin River draw thousands of visitors annually, and festivals such as Summerfest and the EAA Oshkosh Airshow draw international attention, along with hundreds of thousands of visitors.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Given the large number of lakes and rivers in the state, water recreation is very popular.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In the North Country, what had been an industrial area focused on timber has largely been transformed into a vacation destination.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Popular interest in the environment and environmentalism, added to traditional interests in hunting and fishing, has attracted a large urban audience within driving range.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The distinctive Door Peninsula, which extends off the eastern coast of the state, contains one of the state's tourist destinations, Door County.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Door County is a popular destination for boaters because of the large number of natural harbors, bays, and boat launches on both the Green Bay and Lake Michigan sides of the peninsula that forms the county.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The area draws more than two million visitors yearly to its quaint villages, seasonal cherry picking, and fish boils.

name: wisconsin
sentence: On January 1, 2008, a new tax incentive for the film industry came into effect.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The first major production to take advantage was Michael Mann's Public Enemies.

name: wisconsin
sentence: While the producers spent $18 million on the film, it was reported that most of it went to out-of-state workers and for out-of-state services; Wisconsin taxpayers had provided $4.6 million in subsidies, and derived only $5 million in revenues from the film's making.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin has no production of oil, gas, or coal.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Its in-state electrical generation is mostly from coal.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Other important electricity sources are natural gas and nuclear.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The state has a mandate that ten percent of its electrical energy come from renewable sources by the end of 2015.

name: wisconsin
sentence: This goal has been met, but not with in-state sources.

name: wisconsin
sentence: A third of that ten percent comes from out of state sources, mostly wind generated electricity from Minnesota and Iowa.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The state has agnostic policies for developing wind power in state.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin is served by eight commercial service airports, in addition to a number of general aviation airports.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Milwaukee Mitchell International Airport is the only international commercial airport located in Wisconsin.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Wisconsin Department of Transportation is responsible for planning, building and maintaining the state's highways.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Eight Interstate Highways are located in the state.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Amtrak provides daily passenger rail service between Chicago and Milwaukee through the Hiawatha Service.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Also provided is cross-country service via the Empire Builder with stops in several cities across Wisconsin.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Commuter rail provider Metra's Union Pacific North (UP-N) line has its northern terminus in Kenosha, the only Metra line and station in the state of Wisconsin.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Hop, a modern streetcar system in Milwaukee, began service in 2018.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The 2.1 mile (3.4 km) initial line runs from Milwaukee Intermodal Station to Burns Commons.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The system is expected to be expanded in the future.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Over 68% of Wisconsin residents live in urban areas, with the Greater Milwaukee area home to roughly one-third of the state's population.

name: wisconsin
sentence: With more than 594,000 residents, Milwaukee is the 30th-largest city in the country.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The string of cities along the western edge of Lake Michigan is generally considered to be an example of a megalopolis.

name: wisconsin
sentence: With a population of around 233,000 and metropolitan area of over 600,000, Madison has a dual identity as state capital and college town.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Madison's suburb, Middleton, was ranked the "Best Place to Live in America" in 2007 by Money Magazine.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Medium-size cities dot the state and anchor a network of working farms surrounding them.

name: wisconsin
sentence: As of 2011, there were 12 cities in Wisconsin with a population of 50,000 or more, accounting for 73% of the state's employment.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin has three types of municipality: cities, villages, and towns.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Cities and villages are incorporated urban areas.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Towns are unincorporated minor civil divisions of counties with limited self-government.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin, along with Minnesota and Michigan, was among the Midwestern leaders in the emergent American state university movement following the Civil War in the United States.

name: wisconsin
sentence: By the start of the 20th century, education in the state advocated the "Wisconsin Idea", which emphasized service to the people of the state.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The "Wisconsin Idea" exemplified the Progressive movement within colleges and universities at the time.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Today, public post-secondary education in Wisconsin includes both the 26-campus University of Wisconsin System, with the flagship university University of Wisconsin–Madison, and the 16-campus Wisconsin Technical College System.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Private colleges and universities include Alverno College, Beloit College, Cardinal Stritch University, Carroll University, Carthage College, Concordia University Wisconsin, Edgewood College, Lakeland College, Lawrence University, Marquette University, Medical College of Wisconsin, Milwaukee School of Engineering, Ripon College, St. Norbert College, Wisconsin Lutheran College, Viterbo University, and others.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Residents of Wisconsin are referred to as Wisconsinites.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The traditional prominence of references to dairy farming and cheesemaking in Wisconsin's rural economy (the state's license plates have read "America's Dairyland" since 1940) have led to the nickname (sometimes used pejoratively among non-residents) of "cheeseheads", and to the creation of "cheesehead hats" made of yellow foam in the shape of a wedge of cheese.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Numerous ethnic festivals are held throughout Wisconsin to celebrate the heritage of its citizens.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Such festivals include Summerfest, Oktoberfest, Polish Fest, Festa Italiana, Irish Fest, Bastille Days, Syttende Mai (Norwegian Constitution Day), Brat(wurst) Days in Sheboygan, Polka Days, Cheese Days in Monroe and Mequon, African World Festival, Indian Summer, Arab Fest, Wisconsin Highland Games, and many others.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin's music festivals include Eaux Claires, Country Fest, Country Jam USA, the Hodag Country Festival, Porterfield Country Music Festival, Country Thunder USA in Twin Lakes, and Country USA.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Milwaukee hosts Summerfest, dubbed "The World's Largest Music Festival", every year.

name: wisconsin
sentence: This festival is held at the lakefront Henry Maier Festival Park just south of downtown, as are a summer-long array of ethnic musical festivals.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Wisconsin Area Music Industry provides an annual WAMI event where it presents an awards show for top Wisconsin artists.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Milwaukee Art Museum, with its brise soleil designed by Santiago Calatrava, is known for its interesting architecture.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Monona Terrace in Madison, a convention center designed by Taliesin architect Anthony Puttnam, is based on a 1930s design by Wisconsin native Frank Lloyd Wright.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wright's home and studio in the 20th century was at Taliesin, south of Spring Green.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Decades after Wright's death, Taliesin remains an architectural office and school for his followers.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Drinking has long been considered a significant part of Wisconsin culture, and the state ranks at or near the top of national measures of per-capita alcohol consumption, consumption of alcohol per state, and proportion of drinkers.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Consumption per-capita per-event, however, ranks low among the nation; number of events (number of times alcohol is involved) is significantly higher or highest, but consumption at each event smaller, marking Wisconsin's consumption as frequent and moderate.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Factors such as cultural identification with the state's heritage of German immigration, the long-standing presence of major breweries in Milwaukee, and a cold climate are often associated with the prevalence of drinking in Wisconsin.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In Wisconsin, the legal drinking age is 21, except when accompanied by a parent, guardian, or spouse who is at least 21 years old.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Age requirements are waived for possessing alcohol when employed by a brewer, brewpub, beer and/or liquor wholesaler, or producer of alcohol fuel.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The minimum legal age to purchase alcohol is 21, with no exceptions.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Absolute Sobriety law states that any person not of legal drinking age (currently 21) may not drive after consuming alcohol.

name: wisconsin
sentence: On September 30, 2003, the state legislature, reluctant to lower a DUI offense from BAC 0.10 to 0.08, did so only as a result of federal government pressure.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Wisconsin Tavern League opposes raising the alcoholic beverage tax.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Milwaukee Journal Senatorinel series "Wasted in Wisconsin" examined this situation.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The varied landscape of Wisconsin makes the state a popular vacation destination for outdoor recreation.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Winter events include skiing, ice fishing and snowmobile derbies.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin is situated on two Great Lakes and has many inland lakes of varied size; the state contains 11,188 square miles (28,980 km2) of water, more than all but three other states—Alaska, Michigan, and Florida.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Outdoor activities are popular in Wisconsin, especially hunting and fishing.

name: wisconsin
sentence: One of the most prevalent game animals is the whitetail deer.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Each year, in Wisconsin, well over 600,000 deer-hunting licenses are sold.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In 2008, the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources projected the pre-hunt deer population to be between 1.5 and 1.7 million.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin is represented by major league teams in three sports: football, baseball, and basketball.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Lambeau Field, located in Green Bay, Wisconsin, is home to the National Football League's Green Bay Packers.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Packers have been part of the NFL since the league's second season in 1921 and hold the record for the most NFL titles, earning the city of Green Bay the nickname "Titletown USA".

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Packers are the smallest city franchise in the NFL and the only one owned by shareholders statewide.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The franchise was founded by "Curly" Lambeau who played and coached for them.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Green Bay Packers are one of the most successful small-market professional sports franchises in the world and have won 13 NFL championships, including the first two AFL-NFL Championship games (Super Bowls I and II), Super Bowl XXXI and Super Bowl XLV.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The state's support of the team is evidenced by the 81,000-person waiting list for season tickets to Lambeau Field.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Milwaukee Brewers, the state's only major league baseball team, play in Miller Park in Milwaukee, the successor to Milwaukee County Stadium since 2001.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In 1982, the Brewers won the American League Championship, marking their most successful season.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The team switched from the American League to the National League starting with the 1998 season.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Before the Brewers, Milwaukee had two prior Major League teams.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The first team, also called the Brewers, played only one season in the newly founded American League in 1901 before moving to St. Louis and becoming the Browns, who are now the Baltimore Orioles.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Milwaukee was also the home of the Braves franchise when they moved from Boston from 1953 to 1965, winning the World Series in 1957 and the National League pennant in 1958, before they moved to Atlanta.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Milwaukee Bucks of the National Basketball Association play home games at the Fiserv Forum.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Bucks won the NBA Championship in 1971.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The state also has minor league teams in hockey (Milwaukee Admirals) and baseball (the Wisconsin Timber Rattlers, based in Appleton and the Beloit Snappers of the Class A minor leagues).

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin is also home to the Madison Mallards, the La Crosse Loggers, the Lakeshore Chinooks, the Eau Claire Express, the Fond du Lac Dock Spiders, the Green Bay Booyah, the Kenosha Kingfish, the Wisconsin Woodchucks, and the Wisconsin Rapids Rafters of the Northwoods League, a collegiate all-star summer league.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In addition to the Packers, Green Bay is also the home to an indoor football team, the Green Bay Blizzard of the IFL.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The state is home to the seven-time MISL/MASL Champion Milwaukee Wave.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin also has many college sports programs, including the Wisconsin Badgers, of the University of Wisconsin–Madison and the Panthers of the University of Wisconsin–Milwaukee.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Wisconsin Badgers football former head coach Barry Alvarez led the Badgers to three Rose Bowl championships, including back-to-back victories in 1999 and 2000.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Badger men's basketball team won the national title in 1941 and made trips to college basketball's Final Four in 2000, 2014, and 2015.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Badgers claimed a historic dual championship in 2006 when both the women's and men's hockey teams won national titles.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Marquette Golden Eagles of the Big East Conference, the state's other major collegiate program, is known for its men's basketball team, which, under the direction of Al McGuire, won the NCAA National Championship in 1977.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The team returned to the Final Four in 2003.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Many other schools in the University of Wisconsin system compete in the Wisconsin Intercollegiate Athletic Conference at the Division III level.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The conference is one of the most successful in the nation, claiming 107 NCAA national championships in 15 different sports as of March 30, 2015.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Semi-Professional Northern Elite Football League consists of many teams from Wisconsin.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The league is made up of former professional, collegiate, and high school players.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Teams from Wisconsin include: The Green Bay Gladiators from Green Bay, The Fox Valley Force in Appleton, The Kimberly Storm in Kimberly, The Central Wisconsin Spartans in Wausau, The Eau Claire Crush and the Chippewa Valley Predators from Eau Claire, and the Lake Superior Rage from Superior.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The league also has teams in Michigan and Minnesota.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Teams play from May until August.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin is home to the world's oldest operational racetrack.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Milwaukee Mile, located in Wisconsin State Fair Park in West Allis, Wisconsin, held races there that considerably predate the Indy 500.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Wisconsin is home to the nation's oldest operating velodrome in Kenosha where races have been held every year since 1927.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Sheboygan is home to Whistling Straits golf club which has hosted PGA Championships in 2004, 2010 and 2015 and will be home to the Ryder Cup golf competition between USA and Europe in 2020.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Greater Milwaukee Open, later named the US Bank Championship in Milwaukee, was a PGA Tour tournament from 1968 to 2009 held annually in Brown Deer.

name: wisconsin
sentence: In 2017, Erin Hills, a golf course in Erin, Wisconsin, approximately 30 miles northwest of Milwaukee, hosted the US Open.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming ( (listen)) is a landlocked state in the western United States.

name: wyoming
sentence: The 10th largest state by area, it is also the least populous and least densely populated state in the contiguous United States.

name: wyoming
sentence: It is bordered by Montana to the north and northwest, South Dakota and Nebraska to the east, Idaho to the west, Utah to the southwest, and Colorado to the south.

name: wyoming
sentence: The state population was estimated at 578,759 in 2019.

name: wyoming
sentence: The state capital and the most populous city is Cheyenne, which had an estimated population of 63,957 in 2018.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming's western half is mostly covered by the ranges and rangelands of the Rocky Mountains, while the eastern half of the state is high-elevation prairie called the High Plains.

name: wyoming
sentence: Almost half of the land in Wyoming is owned by the US government, leading Wyoming to rank sixth by area and fifth by proportion of a state's land owned by the federal government.

name: wyoming
sentence: Federal lands include two national parks—Grand Teton and Yellowstone—two national recreation areas, two national monuments, several national forests, historic sites, fish hatcheries, and wildlife refuges.

name: wyoming
sentence: Original inhabitants of the region include the Arapaho, Crow, Lakota, and Shoshone.

name: wyoming
sentence: Southwest Wyoming was claimed by the Spanish Empire and then as Mexican territory until it was ceded to the US in 1848 at the end of the Mexican–American War.

name: wyoming
sentence: The region acquired the name "Wyoming" when a bill was introduced to Congress in 1865 to provide a temporary government for the territory of Wyoming.

name: wyoming
sentence: The name had been used earlier for the Wyoming Valley in Pennsylvania, and is derived from the Munsee word xwé:wamənk, meaning "at the big river flat".

name: wyoming
sentence: The main drivers of Wyoming's economy are tourism and extraction of minerals such as coal, oil, natural gas, and trona.

name: wyoming
sentence: Agricultural commodities include livestock, hay, sugar beets, grain (wheat and barley), and wool.

name: wyoming
sentence: The climate is semi-arid and continental, drier and windier than the rest of the country with greater temperature extremes.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming has been a politically conservative state since the 1950s, with the Republican nominee carrying the state in every presidential election since 1968.

name: wyoming
sentence: A notable outlier is Teton County, which has achieved notability for being the most Democratic county in Wyoming and has not voted for a Republican since 2000.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming's climate is generally semi-arid and continental (Köppen climate classification BSk), and is drier and windier in comparison to most of the United States with greater temperature extremes.

name: wyoming
sentence: Much of this is due to the topography of the state.

name: wyoming
sentence: Summers in Wyoming are warm with July high temperatures averaging between 85 and 95 °F (29 and 35 °C) in most of the state.

name: wyoming
sentence: With increasing elevation, however, this average drops rapidly with locations above 9,000 feet (2,700 m) averaging around 70 °F (21 °C).

name: wyoming
sentence: Summer nights throughout the state are characterized by a rapid cooldown with even the hottest locations averaging in the 50–60 °F (10–16 °C) range at night.

name: wyoming
sentence: In most of the state, most of the precipitation tends to fall in the late spring and early summer.

name: wyoming
sentence: Winters are cold, but are variable with periods of sometimes extreme cold interspersed between generally mild periods, with Chinook winds providing unusually warm temperatures in some locations.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming is a dry state with much of the land receiving less than 10 inches (250 mm) of rainfall per year.

name: wyoming
sentence: Precipitation depends on elevation with lower areas in the Big Horn Basin averaging 5–8 inches (130–200 mm) (making the area nearly a true desert).

name: wyoming
sentence: The lower areas in the North and on the eastern plains typically average around 10–12 inches (250–300 mm), making the climate there semi-arid.

name: wyoming
sentence: Some mountain areas do receive a good amount of precipitation, 20 inches (510 mm) or more, much of it as snow, sometimes 200 inches (510 cm) or more annually.

name: wyoming
sentence: The state's highest recorded temperature is 114 °F (46 °C) at Basin on July 12, 1900 and the lowest recorded temperature is −66 °F (−54 °C) at Riverside on February 9, 1933.

name: wyoming
sentence: The number of thunderstorm days vary across the state with the southeastern plains of the state having the most days of thunderstorm activity.

name: wyoming
sentence: Thunderstorm activity in the state is highest during the late spring and early summer.

name: wyoming
sentence: The southeastern corner of the state is the most vulnerable part of the state to tornado activity.

name: wyoming
sentence: Moving away from that point and westwards, the incidence of tornadoes drops dramatically with the west part of the state showing little vulnerability.

name: wyoming
sentence: Tornadoes, where they occur, tend to be small and brief, unlike some of those that occur farther east.

name: wyoming
sentence: As specified in the designating legislation for the Territory of Wyoming, Wyoming's borders are lines of latitude 41°N and 45°N, and longitude 104°3'W and 111°3'W (27 and 34 west of the Washington Meridian)—a geodesic quadrangle.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming is one of only three states (the others being Colorado and Utah) to have borders defined by only "straight" lines.

name: wyoming
sentence: Due to surveying inaccuracies during the 19th century, Wyoming's legal border deviates from the true latitude and longitude lines by up to half of a mile (0.8 km) in some spots, especially in the mountainous region along the 45th parallel.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming is bordered on the north by Montana, on the east by South Dakota and Nebraska, on the south by Colorado, on the southwest by Utah, and on the west by Idaho.

name: wyoming
sentence: It is the tenth largest state in the United States in total area, containing 97,814 square miles (253,340 km2) and is made up of 23 counties.

name: wyoming
sentence: From the north border to the south border it is 276 miles (444 km)

name: wyoming
sentence: The Great Plains meet the Rocky Mountains in Wyoming.

name: wyoming
sentence: The state is a great plateau broken by many mountain ranges.

name: wyoming
sentence: Surface elevations range from the summit of Gannett Peak in the Wind River Mountain Range, at 13,804 feet (4,207 m), to the Belle Fourche River valley in the state's northeast corner, at 3,125 feet (952 m).

name: wyoming
sentence: In the northwest are the Absaroka, Owl Creek, Gros Ventre, Wind River, and the Teton ranges.

name: wyoming
sentence: In the north central are the Big Horn Mountains; in the northeast, the Black Hills; and in the southern region the Laramie, Snowy, and Sierra Madre ranges.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Snowy Range in the south central part of the state is an extension of the Colorado Rockies both in geology and in appearance.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Wind River Range in the west central part of the state is remote and includes more than 40 mountain peaks in excess of 13,000 ft (4,000 m) tall in addition to Gannett Peak, the highest peak in the state.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Big Horn Mountains in the north central portion are somewhat isolated from the bulk of the Rocky Mountains.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Teton Range in the northwest extends for 50 miles (80 km), part of which is included in Grand Teton National Park.

name: wyoming
sentence: The park includes the Grand Teton, the second highest peak in the state.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Continental Divide spans north–south across the central portion of the state.

name: wyoming
sentence: Rivers east of the divide drain into the Missouri River Basin and eventually the Gulf of Mexico.

name: wyoming
sentence: They are the North Platte, Wind, Big Horn and the Yellowstone rivers.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Snake River in northwest Wyoming eventually drains into the Columbia River and the Pacific Ocean, as does the Green River through the Colorado River Basin.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Continental Divide forks in the south central part of the state in an area known as the Great Divide Basin where water that precipitates onto or flows into it cannot reach an ocean—it all sinks into the soil and eventually evaporates.

name: wyoming
sentence: Several rivers begin in or flow through the state, including the Yellowstone River, Bighorn River, Green River, and the Snake River.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming has 32 named islands; the majority are in Jackson Lake and Yellowstone Lake, within Yellowstone National Park in the northwest portion of the state.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Green River in the southwest also contains a number of islands.

name: wyoming
sentence: The state of Wyoming has 23 counties.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming license plates have a number on the left that indicates the county where the vehicle is registered, ranked by an earlier census.

name: wyoming
sentence: Specifically, the numbers are representative of the property values of the counties in 1930.

name: wyoming
sentence: The county license plate numbers are:

name: wyoming
sentence: The State of Wyoming has 99 incorporated municipalities.

name: wyoming
sentence: In 2005, 50.6% of Wyomingites lived in one of the 13 most populous Wyoming municipalities.

name: wyoming
sentence: The United States Census Bureau has defined two Metropolitan Statistical Areas (MSA) and seven Micropolitan Statistical Areas (MiSA) for the State of Wyoming.

name: wyoming
sentence: In 2008, 30.4% of Wyomingites lived in either of the Metropolitan Statistical Areas, and 73% lived in either a Metropolitan Statistical Area or a Micropolitan Statistical Area.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Wind River Indian Reservation is shared by the Eastern Shoshone and Northern Arapaho tribes of Native Americans in the central western portion of the state near Lander.

name: wyoming
sentence: The reservation is home to 2,500 Eastern Shoshone and 5,000 Northern Arapaho.

name: wyoming
sentence: Chief Washakie established the reservation in 1868 as the result of negotiations with the federal government in the Fort Bridger Treaty.

name: wyoming
sentence: However, the Northern Arapaho were forced onto the Shoshone reservation in 1876 by the federal government after the government failed to provide a promised separate reservation.

name: wyoming
sentence: Today the Wind River Indian Reservation is jointly owned, with each tribe having a 50% interest in the land, water, and other natural resources.

name: wyoming
sentence: The reservation is a sovereign, self-governed land with two independent governing bodies: the Eastern Shoshone Tribe and the Northern Arapaho Tribe.

name: wyoming
sentence: Until 2014, the Shoshone Business Council and Northern Arapaho Business Council met jointly as the Joint Business Council to decide matters that affect both tribes.

name: wyoming
sentence: Six elected council members from each tribe served on the joint council.

name: wyoming
sentence: Nearly half the land in Wyoming (about 30,099,430 acres (121,808.1 km2)) is owned by the federal government; the state owns another 3,864,800 acres (15,640 km2).

name: wyoming
sentence: Most of it is administered by the Bureau of Land Management and US Forest Service in numerous national forests and a national grassland, not to mention vast swaths of "public" land and an air force base near Cheyenne.

name: wyoming
sentence: There are also areas managed by the National Park Service and agencies such as the US

name: wyoming
sentence: Fish and Wildlife Service.

name: wyoming
sentence: Several Native American groups originally inhabited the region now known as Wyoming.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Crow, Arapaho, Lakota, and Shoshone were but a few of the original inhabitants white explorers encountered when they first visited the region.

name: wyoming
sentence: What is now southwestern Wyoming became a part of the Spanish Empire, and later Mexican territory, of Alta California, until it was ceded to the United States in 1848 at the end of the Mexican–American War.

name: wyoming
sentence: French-Canadian trappers from Québec and Montréal ventured into the area in the late 18th century, leaving French toponyms such as Téton and La Ramie.

name: wyoming
sentence: John Colter, a member of the Lewis and Clark Expedition, itself guided by French Canadian Toussaint Charbonneau and his young Shoshone wife, Sacagawea, first described the region in 1807.

name: wyoming
sentence: At the time, his reports of the Yellowstone area were considered to be fictional.

name: wyoming
sentence: Robert Stuart and a party of five men, returning from Astoria, discovered South Pass in 1812.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Oregon Trail later followed that route.

name: wyoming
sentence: In 1850, Jim Bridger located what is now known as Bridger Pass, which the Union Pacific Railroad used in 1868, as did Interstate 80, 90 years later.

name: wyoming
sentence: Bridger also explored Yellowstone and filed reports on the region that, like those of Colter, were largely regarded at the time as tall tales.

name: wyoming
sentence: The region acquired the name Wyoming by 1865, when Representative James Mitchell Ashley of Ohio introduced a bill to Congress to provide a "temporary government for the territory of Wyoming".

name: wyoming
sentence: The territory was named after the Wyoming Valley in Pennsylvania, made famous by the 1809 poem Gertrude of Wyoming by Thomas Campbell, based on the Battle of Wyoming in the American Revolutionary War.

name: wyoming
sentence: The name ultimately derives from the Munsee word xwé:wamənk, meaning "at the big river flat".

name: wyoming
sentence: The region's population grew steadily after the Union Pacific Railroad reached the town of Cheyenne in 1867, and the federal government established the Wyoming Territory on July 25, 1868.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming lacked significant deposits of gold and silver, unlike mineral-rich Colorado, and did not experience Colorado's related population boom.

name: wyoming
sentence: However, South Pass City did have a short-lived boom after the Carissa Mine began producing gold in 1867.

name: wyoming
sentence: Furthermore, copper was mined in some areas between the Sierra Madre Mountains and the Snowy Range near Grand Encampment.

name: wyoming
sentence: Once government-sponsored expeditions to the Yellowstone country began, reports by Colter and Bridger, previously believed to be apocryphal, were found to be true.

name: wyoming
sentence: That led to the creation of Yellowstone National Park, which became the world's first national park in 1872.

name: wyoming
sentence: Nearly all of Yellowstone National Park lies within the far northwestern borders of Wyoming.

name: wyoming
sentence: On December 10, 1869, territorial Governor John Allen Campbell extended the right to vote to women, making Wyoming the first territory and, later, United States state, to grant suffrage to women.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming was also a pioneer in welcoming women into politics.

name: wyoming
sentence: Women first served on juries in Wyoming (Laramie in 1870).

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming had the first female court bailiff (Mary Atkinson, Laramie, in 1870), and the first female justice of the peace in the country (Esther Hobart Morris, South Pass City, in 1870).

name: wyoming
sentence: As well, in 1924, Wyoming became the first state to elect a female governor, Nellie Tayloe Ross, who took office in January 1925.

name: wyoming
sentence: Due to its civil-rights history, one of Wyoming's state nicknames is "The Equality State", and the official state motto is "Equal Rights".

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming's constitution included women's suffrage and a pioneering article on water rights.

name: wyoming
sentence: Congress admitted Wyoming into the Union as the 44th state on July 10, 1890.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming was the location of the Johnson County War of 1892, which erupted between competing groups of cattle ranchers.

name: wyoming
sentence: The passage of the federal Homestead Act led to an influx of small ranchers.

name: wyoming
sentence: A range war broke out when either or both of the groups chose violent conflict over commercial competition in the use of the public land.

name: wyoming
sentence: The United States Census Bureau estimates the population of Wyoming was 578,759 in 2019, The center of population of Wyoming is in Natrona County.

name: wyoming
sentence: In 2014, the United States Census Bureau estimated the population's racial composition was 92.7% white (82.9% non-Hispanic white), 2.7% American Indian and Alaska Native, 1.6% Black or African American, 1.0% Asian American, and 0.1% Native Hawaiian or Pacific Islander.

name: wyoming
sentence: As of 2011, 24.9% of Wyoming's population younger than age 1 were minorities.

name: wyoming
sentence: According to the 2010 census, the racial composition of the population was 90.7% white, 0.8% black or African American, 2.4% American Indian and Alaska Native, 0.8% Asian American, 0.1% Native Hawaiian and other Pacific Islander, 2.2% from two or more races, and 3.0% from some other race.

name: wyoming
sentence: Ethnically, 8.9% of the total population was of Hispanic or Latino origin (they may be of any race) and 91.1% Non-Hispanic, with non-Hispanic whites constituting the largest non-Hispanic group at 85.9%.

name: wyoming
sentence: As of 2015, Wyoming had an estimated population of 586,107, which was an increase of 1,954, or 0.29%, from the prior year and an increase of 22,481, or 3.99%, since the 2010 census.

name: wyoming
sentence: This includes a natural increase since the last census of 12,165 (33,704 births minus 21,539 deaths) and an increase from net migration of 4,035 into the state.

name: wyoming
sentence: Immigration resulted in a net increase of 2,264 and migration within the country produced a net increase of 1,771.

name: wyoming
sentence: In 2004, the foreign-born population was 11,000 (2.2%).

name: wyoming
sentence: In 2005, total births in Wyoming were 7,231 (birth rate of 14.04 per thousand).

name: wyoming
sentence: Sparsely populated, Wyoming is the least populous state of the United States.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming has the second-lowest population density in the country (behind Alaska) and is the sparsest-populated of the 48 contiguous states.

name: wyoming
sentence: It is one of only two states (Vermont) with a population smaller than that of the nation's capital.

name: wyoming
sentence: According to the 2000 census, the largest ancestry groups in Wyoming are: German (26.0%), English (16.0%), Irish (13.3%), Norwegian (4.3%), and Swedish (3.5%).

name: wyoming
sentence: Note: Births in table don't add up, because Hispanics are counted both by their ethnicity and by their race, giving a higher overall number.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming's Constitution established three branches of government: the executive, legislative, and judicial branches.

name: wyoming
sentence: The state legislature comprises a House of Representatives with 60 members and a Senatorte with 30 members.

name: wyoming
sentence: The executive branch is headed by the governor and includes a secretary of state, auditor, treasurer and superintendent of public instruction.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming does not have a lieutenant governor.

name: wyoming
sentence: The secretary of state is first in the line of succession.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming's sparse population warrants it only one at-large seat in the US House of Representatives, and hence only three votes in the Electoral College.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Wyoming State Liquor Association is the state's sole legal wholesale distributor of spirits, making it an alcoholic beverage control state.

name: wyoming
sentence: With the exception of wine, state law prohibits the purchase of alcoholic beverages for resale from any other source.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming's highest court is the Supreme Court of Wyoming, with five justices presiding over appeals from the state's lower courts.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming is unusual in that it does not have an intermediate appellate court, like most states.

name: wyoming
sentence: This is largely attributable to the state's population and correspondingly lower caseload.

name: wyoming
sentence: Appeals from the state district courts go directly to the Wyoming Supreme Court.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming also has state circuit courts (formerly county courts), of limited jurisdiction, which handle certain types of cases, such as civil claims with lower dollar amounts, misdemeanor criminal offenses, and felony arraignments.

name: wyoming
sentence: Circuit court judges also commonly hear small claims cases as well.

name: wyoming
sentence: Before 1972, Wyoming judges were selected by popular vote on a nonpartisan ballot.

name: wyoming
sentence: This earlier system was criticized by the state bar who called for the adoption of the Missouri Plan, a system designed to balance judiciary independence with judiciary accountability.

name: wyoming
sentence: In 1972, an amendment to Article 5 of the Wyoming Constitution, which incorporated a modified version of the plan, was adopted by the voters.

name: wyoming
sentence: Since the adoption of the amendment, all state court judges in Wyoming are nominated by the Judicial Nominating Commission and appointed by the Governor.

name: wyoming
sentence: They are then subject to a retention vote by the electorate one year after appointment.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming's political history defies easy classification.

name: wyoming
sentence: The state was the first to grant women the right to vote and to elect a woman governor.

name: wyoming
sentence: On December 10, 1869, John Allen Campbell, the first Governor of the Wyoming Territory, approved the first law in United States history explicitly granting women the right to vote.

name: wyoming
sentence: This day was later commemorated as Wyoming Day.

name: wyoming
sentence: On November 5, 1889, voters approved the first constitution in the world granting full voting rights to women.

name: wyoming
sentence: While the state elected notable Democrats to federal office in the 1960s and 1970s, politics have become decidedly more conservative since the 1980s as the Republican Party came to dominate the state's congressional delegation.

name: wyoming
sentence: Today, Wyoming is represented in Washington by its two Senatortors, John Barrasso and Cynthia Lummis, and its one member of the House of Representatives, Congresswoman Liz Cheney.

name: wyoming
sentence: All three are Republicans

name: wyoming
sentence: The state has not voted for a Democrat for president since 1964, one of only eight times since statehood.

name: wyoming
sentence: At present, there is only one relatively reliably Democratic county, affluent Teton, and one swing county, college county Albany.

name: wyoming
sentence: In the 2004 presidential election, George W. Bush won his second-largest victory, with 69% of the vote.

name: wyoming
sentence: Former Vice President Dick Cheney is a Wyoming resident and represented the state in Congress from 1979 to 1989.

name: wyoming
sentence: Republicans are no less dominant at the state level.

name: wyoming
sentence: They have held a majority in the state senate continuously since 1936 and in the state house since 1964.

name: wyoming
sentence: However, Democrats held the governorship for all but eight years between 1975 and 2011.

name: wyoming
sentence: Uniquely, Wyoming elected Democrat Nellie Tayloe Ross as the first woman in United States history to serve as state governor.

name: wyoming
sentence: She served from 1925 to 1927, winning a special election after her husband, William Bradford Ross, unexpectedly died a little more than a year into his term.

name: wyoming
sentence: Republicans have a majority of registered votes in all but two counties: Albany and Teton, where they have a plurality of registered voters.

name: wyoming
sentence: In 2010, 93.39% (474,343) of Wyomingites over the age of 5 spoke English as their primary language.

name: wyoming
sentence: 4.47% (22,722) spoke Spanish, 0.35% (1,771) spoke German, and 0.28% (1,434) spoke French.

name: wyoming
sentence: Other common non-English languages included Algonquian (0.18%), Russian (0.10%), Tagalog, and Greek (both 0.09%).

name: wyoming
sentence: In 2007, the American Community Survey reported 6.2% (30,419) of Wyoming's population over five spoke a language other than English at home.

name: wyoming
sentence: Of those, 68.1% were able to speak English very well, 16.0% spoke English well, 10.9% did not speak English well, and 5.0% did not speak English at all.

name: wyoming
sentence: According to a 2013 Gallup Poll, the religious affiliations of the people of Wyoming were: 49% Protestants, 18% Catholics, 9% Latter-day Saints (Mormons) and less than 1% Jewish.

name: wyoming
sentence: A 2010 ARDA report recognized as the largest denominations in Wyoming the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (Mormons) with 62,804 (11%), the Catholic Church with 61,222 (10.8%) and the Southern Baptist Convention with 15,812 adherents (2.8%).

name: wyoming
sentence: The same report counted 59,247 Evangelical Protestants (10.5%), 36,539 Mainline Protestants (6.5%), 785 Eastern Orthodox Christians; 281 Black Protestants, as well as 65,000 adhering to other traditions and 340,552 not claiming any tradition.

name: wyoming
sentence: Due to its sparse population, Wyoming lacks any major professional sports teams.

name: wyoming
sentence: However, the Wyoming Cowboys and Cowgirls—particularly the football and basketball teams—are quite popular.

name: wyoming
sentence: Their stadiums in Laramie are about 7,200 feet (2,200 m) above sea level, the highest in NCAA Division I.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Wyoming High School Activities Association also sponsors twelve sports.

name: wyoming
sentence: Casper has hosted the College National Finals Rodeo since 2001.

name: wyoming
sentence: List of all Wyoming state symbols:

name: wyoming
sentence: According to the 2012 United States Bureau of Economic Analysis report, Wyoming's gross state product was $38.4 billion.

name: wyoming
sentence: As of 2014 the population was growing slightly with the most growth in tourist-oriented areas such as Teton County.

name: wyoming
sentence: Boom conditions in neighboring states such as North Dakota were drawing energy workers away.

name: wyoming
sentence: About half of Wyoming's counties showed population losses.

name: wyoming
sentence: The state makes active efforts through Wyoming Grown, an internet-based recruitment program, to find jobs for young people educated in Wyoming who have emigrated but may wish to return.

name: wyoming
sentence: The mineral extraction industry and travel and tourism sector are the main drivers behind Wyoming's economy.

name: wyoming
sentence: The federal government owns about 50% of its landmass, while 6% is controlled by the state.

name: wyoming
sentence: Total taxable values of mining production in Wyoming for 2001 was over $6.7 billion.

name: wyoming
sentence: The tourism industry accounts for over $2 billion in revenue for the state.

name: wyoming
sentence: In 2002, more than six million people visited Wyoming's national parks and monuments.

name: wyoming
sentence: The key tourist attractions in Wyoming include Grand Teton National Park, Yellowstone National Park, Devils Tower National Monument, Independence Rock and Fossil Butte National Monument.

name: wyoming
sentence: Each year Yellowstone National Park, the world's first national park, receives three million visitors.

name: wyoming
sentence: Historically, agriculture has been an important component of Wyoming's economy.

name: wyoming
sentence: Its overall importance to the performance of Wyoming's economy has waned.

name: wyoming
sentence: However, agriculture is still an essential part of Wyoming's culture and lifestyle.

name: wyoming
sentence: The main agricultural commodities produced in Wyoming include livestock (beef), hay, sugar beets, grain (wheat and barley), and wool.

name: wyoming
sentence: More than 91% of land in Wyoming is classified as rural.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming is the home of only a handful of companies with a regional or national presence.

name: wyoming
sentence: Taco John's and Sierra Trading Post, both in Cheyenne, are privately held.

name: wyoming
sentence: Cloud Peak Energy in Gillette and US Energy Corp. (NASDAQ: USEG) in Riverton are Wyoming's only publicly traded companies.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming's mineral commodities include coal, natural gas, coalbed methane, crude oil, uranium, and trona.

name: wyoming
sentence: Unlike most other states, Wyoming does not levy an individual or corporate income tax.

name: wyoming
sentence: In addition, Wyoming does not assess any tax on retirement income earned and received from another state.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming has a state sales tax of 4%.

name: wyoming
sentence: Counties have the option of collecting an additional 1% tax for general revenue and a 1% tax for specific purposes, if approved by voters.

name: wyoming
sentence: Food for human consumption is not subject to sales tax.

name: wyoming
sentence: There also is a county lodging tax that varies from 2% to 5%.

name: wyoming
sentence: The state collects a use tax of 5% on items purchased elsewhere and brought into Wyoming.All property tax is based on the assessed value of the property and Wyoming's Department of Revenue's Ad Valorem Tax Division supports, trains, and guides local government agencies in the uniform assessment, valuation and taxation of locally assessed property.

name: wyoming
sentence: "Assessed value" means taxable value; "taxable value" means a percent of the fair market value of property in a particular class.

name: wyoming
sentence: Statutes limit property tax increases.

name: wyoming
sentence: For county revenue, the property tax rate cannot exceed 12 mills (or 1.2%) of assessed value.

name: wyoming
sentence: For cities and towns, the rate is limited to eight mills (0.8%).

name: wyoming
sentence: With very few exceptions, state law limits the property tax rate for all governmental purposes.

name: wyoming
sentence: Personal property held for personal use is tax-exempt.

name: wyoming
sentence: Inventory if held for resale, pollution control equipment, cash, accounts receivable, stocks and bonds are also exempt.

name: wyoming
sentence: Other exemptions include property used for religious, educational, charitable, fraternal, benevolent and government purposes and improvements for handicapped access.

name: wyoming
sentence: Mine lands, underground mining equipment, and oil and gas extraction equipment are exempt from property tax but companies must pay a gross products tax on minerals and a severance tax on mineral production.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming does not collect inheritance taxes.

name: wyoming
sentence: There is limited estate tax related to federal estate tax collection.

name: wyoming
sentence: In 2008, the Tax Foundation ranked Wyoming as having the single most "business friendly" tax climate of all 50 states.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming state and local governments in fiscal year 2007 collected $2.242 billion in taxes, levies, and royalties from the oil and gas industry.

name: wyoming
sentence: The state's mineral industry, including oil, gas, trona, and coal provided $1.3 billion in property taxes from 2006 mineral production.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming receives more federal tax dollars per capita in aid than any other state except Alaska.

name: wyoming
sentence: The federal aid per capita in Wyoming is more than double the United States average.

name: wyoming
sentence: As of 2016, Wyoming does not require the beneficial owners of LLCs to be disclosed in the filing, which creates an opportunity for a tax haven, according to Clark Stith of Clark Stith & Associates in Rock Springs, Wyoming, a former Republican candidate for Wyoming secretary of state.

name: wyoming
sentence: The largest airport in Wyoming is Jackson Hole Airport, with more than 500 employees.

name: wyoming
sentence: Three interstate highways and thirteen United States highways pass through Wyoming.

name: wyoming
sentence: In addition, the state is served by the Wyoming state highway system.

name: wyoming
sentence: Interstate 25 enters the state south of Cheyenne and runs north, intersecting Interstate 80 immediately west of Cheyenne.

name: wyoming
sentence: It passes through Casper and ends at Interstate 90 near Buffalo.

name: wyoming
sentence: Interstate 80 crosses the Utah border west of Evanston and runs east through the southern third of the state, passing through Cheyenne before entering Nebraska near Pine Bluffs.

name: wyoming
sentence: Interstate 90 comes into Wyoming near Parkman and cuts through the northeastern part of the state.

name: wyoming
sentence: It serves Gillette and enters South Dakota east of Sundance.

name: wyoming
sentence: US

name: wyoming
sentence: Routes 14, 16, and the eastern section of US 20 all have their western terminus at the eastern entrance to Yellowstone National Park and pass through Cody.

name: wyoming
sentence: US 14 travels eastward before joining I-90 at Gillette.

name: wyoming
sentence: US 14 then follows I-90 to the South Dakota border.

name: wyoming
sentence: US 16 and 20 split off of US 14 at Greybull and US 16 turns east at Worland while US 20 continues south Shoshoni.

name: wyoming
sentence: US Route 287 carries traffic from Fort Collins, Colorado into Laramie, Wyoming through a pass between the Laramie Mountains and the Medicine Bow Mountains, merges with US 30 and I-80 until it reaches Rawlins, where it continues north, passing Lander.

name: wyoming
sentence: Outside of Moran, US 287 is part of a large interchange with US

name: wyoming
sentence: Highways 26, 191, and 89, before continuing north to the southern entrance of Yellowstone.

name: wyoming
sentence: US 287 continues north of Yellowstone, but the two sections are separated by the national park.

name: wyoming
sentence: Other US highways that pass through the state are 18, 26, 30, 85, 87, 89, 189, 191, 212, and 287.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming is one of only two states (South Dakota) in the 48 contiguous states not served by Amtrak.

name: wyoming
sentence: It was once served by Amtrak's San Francisco Zephyr and Pioneer lines.

name: wyoming
sentence: Public education is directed by the state superintendent of public instruction, an elected state official.

name: wyoming
sentence: Educational policies are set by the State Board of Education, a nine-member board appointed by the governor.

name: wyoming
sentence: The constitution prohibits the state from establishing curriculum and textbook selections

name: wyoming
sentence: The Wyoming School for the Deaf was the only in-state school dedicated to supporting deaf students in Wyoming before its closure in the summer of 2000.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming has one public four-year institution, the University of Wyoming in Laramie and one private four-year college, Wyoming Catholic College, in Lander, Wyoming.

name: wyoming
sentence: In addition, there are seven two-year community colleges spread throughout the state.

name: wyoming
sentence: Before the passing of a new law in 2006, Wyoming had hosted unaccredited institutions, many of them suspected diploma mills.

name: wyoming
sentence: The 2006 law is forcing unaccredited institutions to make one of three choices: move out of Wyoming, close down, or apply for accreditation.

name: wyoming
sentence: The Oregon State Office of Degree Authorization predicted in 2007 that in a few years the problem of diploma mills in Wyoming might be resolved.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming's media market consists of 16 broacast TV stations, radio stations and dozens of small to medium sized newspapers.

name: wyoming
sentence: There are also a few small independent news sources such as Wyofile.com, a non-profit news site and Oil City News.
